reviews.review: A very sad stop. Just imagining how many persons were killed in this shore at the second world war makes you really sad. And makes the feeling even worse when you know that were Hungarians killing Hungarians.
Family trip. Very impressive memorial for victims but we were disappointed of so called politically correct text by this memorial. There is no mention that the victims were all but Jewish!

Viking River Experience. Unfortunately the time in Budapest was too short but Suzi being an excellent guide helped me make the most of it. I was deeply touched by the history of this Nation and remember some of it, but the German and Russian occupations related in fact what I was experiencing first hand. This is a beautiful city day and night and my only wish is that some dissatisfied with the US should see this to better understand how fortunate we are.
Nice photo/ historical monument . At the edge of the river just down from the parliament building these shoes are placed along the waters edge. It's a relaxing walk along the Danube and a nice photo
Surreal . This is a must see. You can get there on the #2 tram or walk along the river from the four seasons hotel or the ritz Carlton. It is a beautiful and moving tribute to the holocust.
Impressive. When you are in Budapest you should definitely visit the shoes on the Donau. You can feel the history there...so sad! Looking at those shoes brings what happened there closer.
nice. nice place for walking and feel nice weather on danube you should read the story of this place before to go
A very moving memorial.. A very moving memorial to visit. Easy to find on the Pest Danube riverbank, close to tram connections and other places of interest.

One of the highlights of Budapest. Make it a priority to stop and see the Shoes on the Danube memorial in Budapest. This simple memorial is very powerful, particularly in the morning when there are less people around.

Simple, but effective reminder of the sorrow. You could easily miss this waterfront attraction, but don't. If you are near the Charles bridge, walk along the waterfront for about 1/2 mile or so and you'll see them. Read the history beforehand, because there is no explanation there.

An impressive memorial place - a must!. It is simply shaking to see the shoes sculptures in bronze remembering us of the millions of Jewish people killed by the Nazis during the war. The shoes look so real like they were taken off a few minutes ago. I simply looked around to see the poor victims but nobody was there looking like everyone felt into the Danube...
Moving memorial. Moving memorial to the people who lost their lives when shot and thrown into the Danube ,very well done !
Poignant. A walk to parliament along the Danube you will see this tribute as people fled to the other side and left belongings behind you should never forget what happened

Very Moving. Another example of man's inhumanity to man. Jew were shot by the Arrow Brigade towards the end of WWII and their bodies fell back into the Danube to be carried away by the current. Shoes by the edge of the Pest-side promenade remind us of those terrible times -- very moving.

A disgraceful Memorial. A memorial of the sad days of the NAZI during the WWII. This memorial is situated very near to the House of Parliament and the Chain Bridge. You'll find a good number of iron/bronze shoes representing innocent Hungarian Jews, men, women and children who were shot by the NAZI but were to leave their shoes by the Danube River. The shoes during WWII were very valuable and the NAZI didn't want to lose these shoes.
Bronze Shoes. Interesting and significant memorial. Worth stopping for a look as you wander along the river. There isn't much else to say

A Poignant Memorial. It was chilling in its simplicity. We walked the wrong way to start, looking for the spot, it really isn't far from Parliament and the Chain Bridge. To just see the shoes, that looked like they'd just been kicked off and knowing what happened to people - maybe having no idea what was to happen next (you hope maybe they didn't). It is worth finding and reflecting at this memorial.
Worth seeing. A unique and powerful monument, this is Hungary's largest recognition of the Holocaust. It's worth quietly reflecting on for a while.

The most moving thing I've ever seen. We were surprised to come across these metal/concrete -but so lifelike -shoes and boots just "left there" on the side of the river. The human misery of this tragic past just hits you like a sledge hammer .
Beautiful memorial . This monument was definitely worth finding. It is a solemn reminder or what happened here. Startling to see children's shoes.

Somber memorial. One of my top sights to see in Budapest. Simple but chiilling...60 pairs of iron shoes representing men, women and children who were among the 20,000 Jews who were shot and fell into the Danube during WWII. They were made to remove their shoes before they were shot because shoes were a valuable commodity during the war. So sad.

Take a moment to THINK. Great monument honoring the people who lost their lives at the river side during the war time... It feels like it happened yesterday. Shame that there is no good explanation in English - may be that would prevent stupid tourists from taking smile photos when fitting the monument shoes...

A Sad and Simple Reminder. We were in Budapest on a river cruise and this memorial is a very short walk from where the river cruise ships dock near the Chain Bridge. Very simple, yet touching memorial.

deeply moving. A deeply moving and somber memorial representing the loss of innocent lives at the hands of madmen. Note, some people here do not treat the memorial with respect (I noticed people trying to put their feet inside the bronze shoes).

Testament to Hungary's Past. Located just a short walk from the Parliament at Kossuth Lajos Tere station, these concrete shoes found on the Danube riverside have been placed to commemorate the shooting of Hungarian Jews by the Nazi's. To people whom have never visited Hungary before, these shoes are difficult to locate, but once you have found them, they are a very sobering reminder of a dark part of Hungary's past.

Saddest Memorial. To see this memorial to the victims of the Nazi is the saddest I ever seen. One can never find it possible that any human being could do such a thing to another human being. Yet it was real and it did happen.

Location is awesome and easy to find. This is worth the walk because the scenery is really nice. You can walk along the Tonava river and see all the bridges including the chain bridge and also the Parliament building. The monument makes you think about the horrible things that nazis did. This was quite nice continuum after the house of terror.Metro to Kossuth Lajos and then just walk to the Tonava river.
A beautiful memorial. This is a memorial to remember the thousands of Jews that were shot and thrown into the Danube. Just takes a few minutes but very worthwhile.
The history behind!. You have to join free walking tour then you will know the history. This monument is about to the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45.

Moving memorial. This memorial is an extremely moving piece of art. It is very close to the parliament building, so we just happened to walk by, but after reading about it we were impressed. A must see when visiting Budapest.

Dedicated to the Jewish people of WWII. Somber and sad reminder of the horrific events of WWII. This is a memorial to the 3,500 people that were shot on the banks of the Danube near the Parliament Building. This is a "must see".
Emotional experience. Hungary is so hospitable that it's good to be reminded that it wasn't always so. This really brings it home!
A sad part of history. I'm very glad to see that this sad part of history is being honored near the Danube, in quite a creative way.
Very sobbering. Worth a visit and taking a moment to reflect on the dreadful things humans do to each other. Not far from the chain bridge.

Very thought provoking. Beautiful Budapest lots of history beautiful architecture lots to see and do. Lots of traditional restaurants offering a wide variety of dishes. Definitely a bucket list entry for any culture vulture.

Tour of Budapest along the Danube. This memorial sends chills up and down ones spine. Just to visualize this happening to these innocent victims is beyond heartbreaking. A thought provoking way of never forgetting.😪😪

Man's Inhumanity to man. This was the saddest part of our holiday and it is a sad indictment to the human race that such a thing could happen and in a world full of beauty the depth of depravity that man can sink to is unforgiveable.
Very poignant. A very different and poignant memorial. Commemoration of Jewish people who suffered at the hands of the Nazis in the city of Budapest.
A little creepy. I understand that these are installation pieces to commemorate the Jews, but casually walked last them upon leaving the Parliament and was slightly creeped out.

Must see. Hungary has a difficult time telling its history. In 2014 a monument was opened claiming that the 2nd world war was something that just happened to Hungary. The truth is that Hungary was a willing partner and was one of the first countries with antisemitic laws. That this monument only mentions "people" who were killed on the banks of the Danube and not that they were Jews also leaves out part of this dreadful history. Must see, but know that the description is part of the rewriting of Hungarian history.

Haunting. I've always been very interested in the holocaust and the war. I've been to Poland twice and not until I came to Budapest did I realise that the largest number of Jews murdered were actually Hungarian. The shoes epitomises everything about that wicked time. Such a thought provoking display.

A memorial worthvisiting. It is a shame that the Hungarian Government did not take the proper steps to highlight the fact that thousands of Jews were murdered by Hungarian soldiers at this place. The memorial is not illuminated at night and the authorities seem to have made all possible efforts to hide the place from the general tourist visiting the city. This place certainly deserves a visit.

A silent memorial at the Danube. The most terrible period of the Hungarian history was in the last days of the year 1944. The Hungarian nazis signed by the arrowcross killed wemen, children, old people to the river just because these people were Jews. These people had no chance to survive. They left their dresses and shoes at the riverside. This memorial must show to the youth that their is no other way than the peace between the nations. PLEASE VISIT IT.

Poignant Yet Somewhat Small. This site commemorates the Hungarian Jews who were shot and/or forced to jump into the Danube to a certain death during the Nazi occupation. As such, it is very moving. The memorial simply consists of bronzed shoes beside the river. Having heard of it many time, we were struck by how small the site actually is. This doesn't detract from its impact, but is simply a short observation.

Heart-piercing memorial. In order to remember the victims of the holocaust, there is a memorial on the Pest side of the Danube in Budapest, close to the Parliament. 60 shoes made of bronze are left on the Danube band. This is to remember those Jewish people who in 1944-45 were led to the Danube in groups, forced by Hungarian nazis to take off their shoes and leave back these valuables and then were shot into the Danube. The statute is created by Gyula Pauer.

A must to-do item in Budapest. I have heard and read so much about this, but was disappointed to see that the tourists are destroying such a beautiful and sensitive display. They push candles into the shoes and the wax and flowers dying in the shoes makes it look dirty and uncared for.
Sad to see. Beautiful old fashioned shoes marking the spot of a tragic event. Very close to the Parliament buildings on the Pest side of the river.
A Moving Holocaust Memorial. Do not hesitate. This is a must-visit site. It is very moving and important to see. You can combine it with a tour of the Parliament and the 1956 Uprising Memorial.
Simple and moving. This was a very moving memorial right on the walk along the river. It's simple presentation left a lasting impression. This was worth the quick walk down from the chain bridge

This had an incredible impact!. Seeing the Shoes on the Danube Promenade has had a genuine impact on all four of us visiting. This memorial to the Jews who were lined up, told to remove their shoes, then shot where they would then fall into the river was such a visual reminder that we must never allow this type victimization to happen ever again.I watched as people visiting this memorial would try to take a picture (as I did) and I wondered if they were as affected as we were. It is important to absorb the meaning of what our history tells us in order for us to be guarded against it repeating itself.
Sobering Experience . Visited this with my wife and family. It is a very sobering experience. Beautiful memorial where people bring flowers and candy to honor the Jews killed here.

An emotional and simple display of history. This simple but emotional display of the plight of the Jews during this time in history is something that you might miss if you aren't looking for it. It is along the sidewalk next to the Danube near the Parliament building. It's simplicity adds to the power of the history. Simply shoes of the Jews as they are taken away. It is in the open, public, free and moving. If you are anywhere near the Parliament building make the effort to stand in this spot and think of what happened. It can take five minutes or an hour depending on how much you want to think of the past.

Keep the memory alive. The shoes on the banks of the Danube river are a reminder of the Jewish people killed by the german in 1944.Before slaughtering them the killer force the victims to take off the shoes.

Poignant Memorial. At first blush, it's easy to overlook the Shoes on the Danube Promenade MemorialBut it's not to be missed. The deep feeling and poignancy of the meaning behind such a subtle memorial is both profound and powerful.

Riveting. Riveting place to see and reflect upon. A memorial to those killed in this manner, shot on the banks of the Danube, because there to many to transfer to the killer ovens. All that was left behind of the individual, adult or child, we're the shoes they were wearing. Poignant.

emotional experience. a strong emotional commemoration of a horrible time in history brought about by the simplicity of the shoes left behind. each pair is different as was each individual the was killed.
Affecting. A good statement piece of art that was very poignant. A quick stop along the riverside walk to the parliament buildings.

Sadness reigns. I guess this is as good a memorial as you will ever get to bring home the tragedy of the fleeing jews. It is a moving experience that quickly brings you to silence and reflection in a way no stone monument ever will. Baby's shoes ..... say no more.

Quirky and moving. If you are in the right frame of mind to contemplate the Holocaust, it's a very moving exhibition. The 'empty' shoes represent those who died. Flowers and candles are left in/near the shoes by parties unknown.There is no charge for this attraction. It's simply sidewalk art, accessible to those walking along the Danube on the Pest side, south of the parliament building.Even if you're not in the frame of mind to contemplate man's inhumanity to man, it's an interesting piece of art, which makes for a nice photo or two overlooking the river and the Buda skyline.

Haunting and beautiful. This was a stop on our walking tour of the city. Our tour guide explained about the harrowing history of this spot; where so many people were shot, ordered to take off their shoes on the bank before going to their deaths. This monument represents that atrocity, and it gave us shivers to think of what had happened.
Simple but profound. The sculpture itself is very simple but immensely thought provoking and is a fitting memorial to the victims of fascism.
A monument for the jews. copies of original shoes of jews who were brought to the danbue river and shot in the head straight to the river
Great Tribute.. This is a great tribute and gets you thinking of what human beings had to go through and endure not so long ago.

Truly unique memorial. Budapest is a city filled with charming little statues, statues to local poets and foreign leaders and movie stars (like Reagan and Colombo) and every day people (like policemen). There are also large statues, like the St. Stephen's statue at Fishermen's Bastion and the huge statues at Hero Square. Several controversial monuments commemorate the time of WWII, most recently the Monument to the Victims of the German Invasion, which whitewashes the role of Hungary in the war. I felt that the inscription at the shoe monument was also vague, not referring to the Jews as the victims, and Hungarian members of the Arrow Cross as perpetrators. But of all the Monuments, this simple collection of bronze shoes by the river was the most touching we encountered. It really brings home the horror of the murder of innocent men, women and children in the gruesome way of shooting them by the side of the river in 1944-45. Well worth the visit to pay your respects. The monument is easy to find, just walk along the river between the Parliament and the Chain bridge and you can't miss it. Be careful not to cross the two lane highway right in front of the monument but at the light a little ways up the street.

This is a special place. If you get a chance to go by the river and see the shoe memorial, please stop and think of the history that went on behind this memorial. This vibrant and alive city can make you forget its tumultuous history.
Beautiful . Go see it, it doesn't take long and is worth it. Easy and beautiful tribute. Such history in this city.

Moving memorial. We've seen a number of memorials to the murdered Jews of Europe, and this one is among the best. We find that the simpler they are, the more moving they can be. The casts of men, women, and children's shoes lined up on the bank of the Danube (near the Parliament building) makes one cry at the barbarism of the fascists who lined up Jews at the edge, shot them, and pushed the bodies into the river. In a city sorely lacking in public rememberences of the atrocities that occurred there, this is a standout.

Very Powerful and Tearing Reminder. The Shoes on the Danube Bank memorial is a powerful and tearing reminder about the Jewish holocaust during WWII.Captured by Nazis, Jewish population of Budapest were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It was especially emotional to see baby shoes with little angels figurines, candies and candles placed in them.
Haunting. We passed these on our bus tour and the story behind these is fascinating and very sad....Budapest if full of these little gems of history

A Very Poignant Memorial. This was a special piece of art by sculptor Gyula Pauer which represents the Jews that were killed in Hungary during the Holocaust. The Jews that were killed at the edge of the Danube were ordered to take off their shoes before they were shot. This is a very moving piece.
Sad but beautiful. . Set alongside the river it's a sad sight to see but I would recommend going. It is right next to the parliament so you can do both together!

A reminder.... The shoes are left in memory of those poor people who were shot and then thrown into the Danube. It is heartbreaking to look at the different size/style of shoe,men,women's and childrens and to think of how they died

Poignant Reminder. By the Parliament Building on the banks of the Danube worth seeing but a moving experience, if you ignore those tourists trying to move the shoes or photograph them at ground level.

Heartsicken. I learned about this during the walking tour. These iron sculptured shoes are along the Danube river close to the Parliament House. I learned about the stories behind this memorial and it's a very humbling experience. We shall not forget what happened to the Jews...
must. silent, but poweful message you will get from those shoes. I visited this site in the winter and got tears.
Very Poignant. Quite basic but all the better for it in a city where there are so many competing attractions. Horrific story tastefully portrayed.

Touching Tribute. I feel sad when I saw these 60 pairs of rusted period shoes cast out of iron. These rusted shoes of different sizes and styles reflect how nobody was spared from the brutality of the Arrow Cross militia.... Shoes came in different sizes depicting children, women, businessmen, sportsmen.... etc.) Blessed to be able to visit this memorial. Not to missed when you are visiting Budapest.
Thought provoking nice tribute. Walked along riverbank to see the shoes, quite thought provoking and people had left tealights which i presume are lit each night.

A grim reminder to Nazis killing of Hungarian jews. Sculptured shoes looks real along the Danube on the Pest side just 200 meters from Parliament House ... walk towards the Intercon hotel side ...People lit up candles during night as a homage to the Jews

Powerful. I had seen pictures of the Memorial and had read the chilling background - but I was surprised how very powerful it was seeing the shoes for the first time. It was interesting to see how people approached the shoes - some wanting to walk and sit among them, others looking from a distance - but all very respectful.It is a short walk from the Parliament and I would really recommend this - lest we forget.

Very moving . Had to see this , it was more poignant as it co incided with Rosh Hashanah so there were a group of Jewish guys singing with a guitar and lighting candles , throwing bread into the river which is symbolic of casting ones sins away before Yom Kippur. Bearing in mind this was the last view for those who were slaughtered for their religious belief should move anyone be they Christian or Jew , very moving tribute to slain innocents and how barbaric the human race can be. Worth a visit and silent reflection as to how historically people have been persecuted.
Disturbing. A sobering and poignant reminder of what happened when misguided people take charge of a nation. Have we eliminated all such atrocities.

A Moment in Time Almost Missed. Be sure to include this little advertised memorial during your visit to Budapest. During the Second World War, Jews people were rounded up and shot on the banks of the Danube. Only their shoes remain. A moment in time is well captured in this touching memorial.

No more affliction. Visiting this spot, one must truly feel sad for those Jewish victims between 1944 and 1945 who had to take off their shoes with their heads being pointed by guns. Here is my interpretation about the artwork: No matter rich, poor, or tortured, they were all ultimate victims of the fascist Nazi. Even some mothers were murdered with their sons.When the militants of Arrow Cross pulled the trigger, all the social class bubbles were bursted and tortured bodies fell into the Danube. Let the river gently carry each body into permanent sleep. Hope this world no long has affliction.

Jewish Holocaust memorial . We were told of the treatment of Jews in Hungary on the free working your . The Jews were marched to the Danube , told to remove these shoes and then shot / thrown in the Danube . A very touching experience . Take the number 2 team to the Parliament Building and then walk back along the river bank to see the memorial
Poignant . A touching monument to the Jewish people that were killed in world war 2. Definitely a must see. Very easy to find: you usually see a crowd of people along the river where it is situated.

Historic views.. This is definitely a place you want to come see, even at night. It is right next to the parliament. Do some research on this and you'll understand the history behind the shoes. It was surreal to be there knowing how real this tragedy was.
Spoilt by litter. It is, or at least could be, a very poignant work of art but I'm afraid isn't is spoilt by the constant lighting of tea lights and flags on it .
Very moving. Make sure you research the significance before you go and you will get more out of it. Also an amazing view of Buda.

Truly touching. Located between the Parliament building and the Bridge of Chains, this memorial is right on the edge of the Danube. It is a very nice memorial and truly touching. We took a few moments to just close our eyes and remember. It is definitely something you should see.
Sobering. We almost missed this but went for a run and saw it along the river. Beautiful concept and well done.

Poignant and elegant. A very touching memorial to an atrocity from the Second World War, when Jewish people were rounded up and shot on the banks of the Danube. Their bodies fell into the river and only their shoes were left behind
.

Thought-provoking history. This monument is a thought-provoking and sad memorial to all those who were lost during the middle of the previous century.
So subtle in nature, but moving at the same time. Well worth stopping off when passing.
Poignant Reminder. Was impressed with this memorial. What better way to cause reflection of horrific shooting of a Jews rounded up during holocaust. Very moving.

Moving memorial. This is a moving memorial at the side of the Danube. Worth taking a quiet, reflective moment here. Would be easy to miss but if you are at the Parliament building it is very close by.
Thoughtful Attraction. This was something we wanted to see. It was very thought provoking and it brought home how cruel humans can be.
An interesting tribute. This is an interesting memorial to the Jews that were executed in this spot during World War II. Not far from the main part of town

Shoes on the Danube Bank. This is one of many poignant European holocaust memorials in Europe and was conceived by film director Can Togay along with sculptor Gyula Pauer to honour the deaths of Jews by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen. I thought it particularly sad as the killing continued despite Germany's surrender. Whole families took off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water or, when bullets ran out, were bound in groups with barbed wire and thrown into the river. Lest we forget.

Swindon visits shoes OMG!!!!. Did not know the the history about this until we stumbled upon this after visiting the incredible Parliament building. We were gutted to find out what had happenned, way back when Fascists ruled. Very emotional
Very poignant. The metal sculptures of shoes on the river brink to comemmorate those shot into the Danube in 1945 is quite moving and simply effective.
Very touching. When I first saw it, I didn't know what it was. Then I went back home and read about it. It's near the Parliament

Very heart rendering. This is where literally thousands of Jews were forced to take off their shoes and then they were shot and fell into the river. The bronze shoes are relicts and really humble the sight seer. Wow, it was heart felt.
memorial to lives lost. very moving tribute to the lives of those lost in a turbulent time in our history,not to be forgotten
Simple and very moving. Take a walk from Parliament along the Danube promenade and stop to see history and remember what horrors hate leads to not just in the past but the present.

Somber . My wife and I visited 'the shoes' and were immediately taken with the memorial. These memorials are important places to show where we have come from and where we are now. It's important that we never forget these atrocities and this memorial goes a long way in making sure we do not.

Amazing memorial. If you didn't know this was there you'd miss it and that would be a shame. Very touching way to remember the Jews that were murdered in 1956, when you see the children's shoes there it sends a shiver down your spine. Some have said it's disrespectful to take photos but I think it raises awareness of the horrible event and it makes people remember. A must see.

Touching exhibits along Danube Promenade. The exhibits were near to Parliament Building and alongside of River Danube. Touching stories on those who lost their lifes during war time. We have the chance to visit this site during our night tour there.
Poininent Reminder. Visited shoes on the Danube, poininent Reminder of what man is capable of at his worst. Very simple but effective memorial.

Very Moving. During our tour of Slovakia, Austria, and Hungary we visited many monuments and museums commerating the Jews, but these simple bronze shoes are by far the most powerful, to fully envision the execution of people standing on the banks of the Danube and allowing the bodies to simply fall in and float away.It might be kind of difficult to find them if you are not already on the promenade, or to find a place to safely cross a busy street, but use you map and find them for sure.
Thoughtful. A artist's way to describe a horrific event of the past in a way that words could not. Each set of shoes offers a description of a person whose life was taken on that day.

Powerful art. More than any other magnificent building or statue or monument in Budapest, this simple installation made me think and feel.
The signage nearby does not do it justice.

Sad reminder of the past. I actually stumbled across this by accident. I wasnt sure what it represented (although I knew it must have been people that died) and looked it up for trip advisor to tell me its for people who lost their lives in WW2. I thought it was a really beautiful memorial. It really makes you think about what happened in the past in Europe. Its very easy to find along the river promenade.

Take a quiet walk on the riverbank to see this.. This is a most moving memorial to Jews that were murdered and thrown in the river. The shoes are bronzed and the smaller ones will particularly affect you.

Very moving. It really goes without saying that the history behind this is what's so moving about it. The actual artwork is very well done. It is touching to see that people have left stones, candles, flowers and ribbons in the memory of all those lost.

Heart wrenching. . One of the most authentic and heartbreaking Holocaust Memorials I've ever seen. A row of shoes evoked emotions we will never forget. I broke down and cried at the baby shoes. Collect stones, you'll want to leave many.

A Moving End to an Exceptional Tour. We took a 4-hour Jewish toiur of Budapest that ended here. It was a fitting conclusion to a very intense tour. It's worth it to see this even if you aren't on a tour. Extremely tragic and moving.

Simple and moving. Not sure its right to think of this as a tourist attraction. It is simple and moving and yes makes an interesting photo, but take time to think what it means - especially the childrens shoes.
Touching exhibit. Very touching. Better to visit here and remember, than to pay money at the Terror Museum. It's on the banks of the Danube and free.

So sad. I witnessed the horror of the event that caused this display. History was incredible and impressive to actually see this place. A must see with a host to tell you all about the event that caused this display.

Touching. This was a really nice tribute to those who were shot into the Danube. Never to be forgotten. It really is a must see and is only across from the parliament building. Bring a tissue as it will touch your heart.
A very moving tribute. An incredible tribute to the lost soles of 1956....especially at night when candles are lit in many of them
A chilling reminder of the past history of Budapest. The Shoes on the Danube promenade are a heart-tugging memorial to those Jews who lost their lives their during WWI

Memorial. We came across this and weren't sure what it was though it seemed to be a memorial of some kind. Came back to hotel and googled it. Read about it before you go. So tragic. You will appreciate it so much more.

Another monument to the brutalities of people who need victims to cover their own deficiencies . 60 pairs of shoes along the river bank, each representing several thousand people (Jews) who were shot and their bodies thrown into the Danube.
Would almost miss this. You would almost miss this if you didn't know it was here but would definitely recommend seeing. Meaningful monument

A moving tribute. This memorial installation on the banks of the Danube is worth seeing, its easy to get to, just below the Parliament building. The shoes are so life-like. I know other reviewers have expressed annoyance at individuals taking photographs, but I think its important for images of this memorial to be shared. This is a very moving reminder of what happened here.

Very sobering. A must see as you walk along the river on the Pest side. A very moving and sobering memorial. It is not far from the Parliament building. Shoes of all sizes and shapes scattered along the promenade. It is a lovely walk along the river.
Poignant. A poignant reminder that you could easily miss, however it is on the river just below the Houses of Parliament.

Don't make this part of a paid tour. You'll see the spot from afar as you notice a crowd of visitors contort their bodies to take arty-farty photos. It's right by Parliament House so you'll find yourself walking past it without any detour required. Within a km you'll stumble across far more poignant reminders of the horrors perpetuated on the people of Budapest. And with visitors treating them with much more respect.

Very moving memorial and a nice walk along the Danube. If you are walking along the Danube from the Parliament building to the Chain Bridge you can't miss the Shoes along the Danube. It is a surprisingly touching memorial and worth a visit. If you have also visited the Terror House you will definitely understand the context of the memorial.

A site with a great story. Hearing the story behind the shoes along the river was quite eery, but made it all the more interesting to see. Walking along the river is a beautiful site, and seeing these shoes along the way reminds you of what Budapest (and the people) went through during the war time.
Very Moving and Sad. A must see in Budapest. Very moving and also so sad. A really thought provoking memorial. I wish we all lived in peace with each other.
Very moving. Worth a visit if you are near the Parliament. Very sad but very moving.A beautiful memorial for a devastating era
memorial. Very poignant site, wanted to see this memorial as had heard about the blowing up of the bridge with over 200 people on it during the war, lots of candles and flowers left there

Nothing special. Original and capturing imagination when you think about the reason why it's standing there, but all in all its just shoes beside the river. Maybe I'm too shallow for it, but if you miss it, have no regrets.
Poignant and moving. Just a brief visit yet so moving and sobering. A very apt memorial to atrocities of the Second World War
Very moving. Definitely a must see. Very thought provoking and moving, especially when you see the children's shoes.

Do not miss it - a very touching and deeply moving experience. Humans doing horrible things to other humans for no justifiable reason.... bringing it home by displaying shoes at the exact spot where people were killed.... A very good way to force us to think of shameful chapters in history more than we do...
Good. Very interesting and must see, lots of people there, very busy but a nice walk along the Danube to get there
very moving. moving tribute to very sad plight of people shot by crossbow by river during ww2 brings home the horrors of war
A sad reminder. During a visit to the shoes memorial you may see relatives lay flowers, wreathes or light candles to honour the fallen who have given their lives.

Remembering those who were victims of the holocaust. After visiting the parliament, we headed to see these bronze shoes modelled on 1940s footwear of those who were shot into the Danube by the Hungarian Nazis. It is a grim reminder of the evils committed. Flowers and candles are placed next to some of these shoes as a mark of respect.

worth a visit if you are around. This is not a huge attraction, but on the other side it has 2 aspects making it unique. The first is the reason of its existence, the tribute to whom was murdered in this place, the other point is despite to be a simple scultures of shoes, is not something we can see often. In the end, if you are around worth a visit, and it will not take long time.

Very poignant.... This is a must see...we need to remember what happened in that terribly brutal time of history. This is not a macabre memorial....but a very tragic and poignant reminder to all generations. Lest we forget...
A must see. A must see when in Budapest , easy to find along the banks of the Danube. Very hard hitting to see and very humbling

A moving tribute. This was a very moving and sombre portrayal of an immensely black period in human history. The children's shoes In particular brought tears to my eyes. This small sculpture is right on the banks of the Danube prior to reaching the House of Parliament walking from the chain bridge.
A moving memorial. In 1944 the Hungarian Nazis belonging to the "Arrow Cross" movement have murdered thousands of the Jews of Budapest in a most cruel way

Must see. This is a very moving memorial, however we walked past it twice as it is down on the waterfront. One of the receptionists at the hotel had never heard of it which I found very strange. Though there are many to see. It's among the must see monuments as is most of Budapest. A lovely city that has some type of sculpture or monument wherever you turn your head.

Thought provoking and moving. The memorial of the shoes proved very thought provoking and moving as you walk to the parliament along the Danube from the Chain Bridge The memorial marks where the Jews took off their shoes before they were shot and disposed of in the Danube. The shoes were worth more than human life - a memorial to brave souls in a barbaric world

Shoes on the river. Very moving monument to the Holocaust victims that is worth seeing. 60 pairs of bronzed shoes sit next to the Danube where Jewish victims were ordered to take off their shoes and were then shot and fell into the river.

A Sad Reminder. For those going to see this they probably know what it represents. A representative of those persons, mostly Jews, who were lined up by the Danube and shot by the Nazis only to have their bodies fall into the river. A sad reminder, especially with the pair of toddler's shoes. Certainly a necessary visit for Jews and probably anyone with a conscience.
Worth taking a few minutes out. Come here after visiting the Parliament houses, they are on the other side of Parliament along the Danube banks. Very touching memorial.
Very sad.. Really worth seeing these shoes. It's a really poignant memorial especially when you see the child sized boots. It really does make you ponder on the cruelty of man.
Moving!. To see the shoes, known they were placed there by family/friends of someone who perished during WWII is overwhelming.

Delicious lunch!. My husband and I dined here last week and had a nice lunch. We started with a drink called an Aperol Spritz which was delicious. We ordered a Margarita pizza which was big enough for us both to share was very good with a thin crust. We both ordered dessert an expresso mouse and a pastry with white chocolatier mousse. Both desserts were tasty and a nice ending to our enjoyable lunch.

Great place to visit, especially if you're a history lover.. My husband and I really enjoyed the facts about the bronze shoes. Our guide was so knowledgeable, and it seemed so real. Very sad, but so interesting.
Poignantly thought provoking. A very moving memorial. I just spent some time there in quiet reflection. This is not a place for selfies to be taken....
Moving tribute!!. A very sobering memorial on the river. One of the must-see attractions! Well worth taking a few minutes!
Moving!. You are walking down the Danube river and all of a sudden you see these shoes on the side of the river... Very moving and touching what it represents.
makes you think. we weren't quite sure what the shoes were all about (until we looked it up) but just seeing it made us pause and reflect.

A must see when in Budapest. Moving, emotional and very powerful. Love the idea of this display! The range of shoes is fantastic, there are women's court shoes, mens workboots and many children's shoes. They are in a convenient spot near the Parliament buildings which are another not to miss.

A silent reminder of a dark past. This memorial is only a short walk along the river and more than worth the effort. It subtlety reminds visitors of a much darker time in the history of the city and does it in a subtle and thought provoking way.
Moving Tribute . Simple & effective; definitely worth a visit; we hovered here for a while; good to remember; worth taking a few minutes to pause
Disturbing. Very poignant. One could really visualize the atrocity that took place.Another reminder of the evil that can occur during war.

A breath-taking experience !. This must have been one of the most horrible events that took place on this spot during the war. How cruel men can be. Arrow-soldiers shooting people after having made them take off their shoes before falling in the Danube. Es war nicht immer "der schônen blauen Donau !"

Shows the dark past of Budapest. Budapest today is a beautiful, peaceful city but, as with many European cities occupied during WWII ,Budapest, it has atrocities in its past, and the Jews were on the receiving end, more often than not. In Budapest, in an episode in which I understand 20 000 Jews were murdered, Jews were lined up on the banks of tbe Danube, made to take off tbeir clothes and shoes, then shot in the head such that their bodies then fell in to the river and were washed away downstream. Near to the parliament building, it is a moving tribute to those killed in this way; maybe thirty pairs of metallic shoes just standing there on the promenade.Makes one think, Hungarian and non Hungarian, Jew and non Jew.

For my relative's memory living in my hart forever. I could not hold my tears it touched me so deeply. This nyilas terror event of killing the Jews by shooting them into the Danube river and ordering their victims to leave their shoes behind is captured so emotionally that it is unforgettable

One of the more moving memorials I've ever seen . Make sure this is included in your MUST SEE itinerary of Budapest. Seen many a Holocaust memorial in my life, but this one stands out in its simplistic poignancy. Remarkably moving.

A poignant memorial. There is no cost to visit this very moving memorial - apart from the cost on the emotions!Such a moving memorial is well worth visiting - it is just down the embankment from the Parlement (one minute?) and simply consists of pairs of shoes without owners - the owners having been the residents of the City who were shot and thrown into the river during the second world war.I recommend this as a place to spare a few minutes for reflection - the shoes are people! Gone forever but should never be forgotten.
Very moving. Very moving, but not sure a lot of tourists taking selfies really understood what the shoes symbolised.
Sad and touching. Worth to visit. Close to the Parliament Building, The shoes create a feeling of sadness and as a reminder of humanity.

Worth a walk by if your are in the area. I had read about the shoes. We happened by them as we were walking up the street along the Danube. It is fairly close to the major hotels on the Danube so it is an easy walk if you are interested.

Powerful memorial. You must walk along the Danube to see this touching memorial. It is easy to spot, especially as there are often a few people around the area. It's a simple memorial but sends out a powerful message, it is very well done. In my opinion it is definitely a must do when in Budapest!
So sad. A very sad place to remember. Well worth the visit. The areas was a wee bit dirty and could be improved with a clean up.

A MOVING TRIBUTE .... .... AND STARK REMINDER of man's inhumanity to man. Pause and remember.
This creative memorial is within walking distance of the Cruise Line Docks and hop on/ hop off bus stops. It can be visited as part of a Jewish history tour or independently.

Touching Reminder. A touching memorial to the lives so tragically taken and a grim reminder of man's inhumanity to man. Memorials like this pull on the heart strings of anyone with a touch of decency and should be seen often to remind people how cruel ignorance and intolerance can be,

Harrowing . Stumbled across this memorial on the way to Parliament buildings.
We took a couple of minutes just to sit, take one or two photos and to remember. It's very hard to understand what happened during that time, but it is such stark reality, especially seeing children's shoes there too. Worth a visit.
Well done Memorial. Take the time to visit this site. It's a very simple, well-done Memorial and sends a very powerful message.

One of Many Sad Reminders. Hungary has a number of sites like this, that are reminders of their horrible past and they way they treated Jews. This one remembers the faction that picked up where the Nazis left off.
City break . We visited the Danube we saw the shoes that were lined up on the edge it was so moving and a must for anyone visiting this beautiful city

Deeply moving. This quiet little memorial takes a bit of effort to find but is one of the most moving you will ever experience. Sit for a while and let your heart and imagination fill in the gaps of the events not depicted.

Easy to overlook along Danube. From the Parliament Building, be sure to walk south along the Danube. This is not necessarily a destination in of itself, but it is definitely a must see to remember those who lost their lives because of prejudice and bigotry. Each shoe tells a story; wonder and reflect upon the real person who lived and cruelly lost their life. The first time we were in Budapest we walked by without noticing it, for the crowds! People brought candles, and others write in journals or sketch on the riverbank.

a very moving sight. having read of these shoe sculptures alongside the River Danube [ not far from the Parliament building ] we decided to see them for ourselves. This was a very moving experience. We understand that they are a memorial to Jews who were pushed into the river to drown by the Nazi's

Return to Budapest. We had intended to go here 2 years ago, but illness prevented that. This time we went and found the simplicity and mundane display of the exhibit both moving and memorable. Ice cream needed afterwards.

The reality of Prejudice brought to life. The story behind this is very sad as you see first hand the reality of war time prejudice. There are 66 pairs of shoes, mens, womens and childrens that have been bronzed in the places they were left on the bank of the Danube. I will not go into the story here, but worth a short visit. No fee.

Shocking impressive small monument. If you are near the parliament house this is a must place to see , its not a big monument but very impressive and helps to understand what was going there during war war 2.
Sad, but worth a visit. Walked by here after hearing about the history. Was touched by the way the shoes were laid out. Very sad bit of history, but I was glad to see that it has not been forgotten.

Must see. I had read about this before traveling to Budapest and wanted to go and see this. It is free and relatively easy to find on the Danube River bank in front of the Parliament building. It was very moving and thought provoking to see all the different type of shoes and to think about the horror of what happened.
Shoes on the danube. I would highly recommend this very evocative monument- the Hungarians are not afraid to show their history, good or bad.

Thought provoking.... We walked along the Danube to see these on a beautiful sunny afternoon. It's very simple, but all the more powerful a memorial for that...lest we forget the price some paid for us to have that stroll and casual conversation...
Incredibly movinig. This is such a moving memorial. You can almost picture in your head the atrocities that went on here. A must see when in Budapest.

Touching . So thought provoking !! Costs nothing ! It not often things are free !! But you can visit this beautiful memorial free of charge. It's situated just on the river Danube. It's such a wonderful memory to all those people who lost their life's in such a horrific way.

Must See. In Budapest you may visit a lot of monuments of historical persons and simple sculptures. There is a very well-known, there are those that are mentioned less frequently (for example, a monument to Kalman Imre, or a compositions in the vicinity of the Nemzeti Szinhaz/National Theater and the Ludwig Museum).But there is a memorial that does not leave anyone indifferent. Simple in execution, but leaves a strong impression. Heart wrenching Holocaust Memorial on the Danube embankment remains forever in the memory of all who saw it firsthand.This is the place, which they say «must see».Be sure to visit.

a reminder of mans inhumanity. a reminder of a awful part of hungarys past and part in ww2, these iron shoes represent the 3000 or so people who were shot on the bank so there bodies fell into the river and swept away
Shocking and Breathtaking. One of the more shocking memorials I have ever seen.Very minimal, if you don't look for this, you will not find it.Hearing the story behind it brought me into tears.
Sad Memorial. A really sad thought provoking memorial in memory of Jews who were made to remove their shoes before being shot on the bank of The Danube. Just a short walk from Parliament
Very poignant. A somber reminder of what man can do to man. Worth taking time out to visit. Relates well to other attractions such as the House of Terror on Andrassy Street

An Absolute Must See. If you miss this memorial you haven't been to Budapest. Admittedly not easy to find along the Danube but worth the effort. Poignant and heart wrenching, it is a significant and subtle reminder of a time that we must never forget. Go there!

Moving monument - a must. The sight of these shoes, marking where many Jews were shot and then fell into the Danube, was such a moving experience. I found myself crying as I walked along the display. Many people had put flowers or candles into the empty shoes.
Very touching. When you know the history the Shoes Monument is highly meaningful.It is very touching. It is easy to find near Parliament and without any written words tells a story of loss.
Very moving. This simple but very moving memorial is definitely worth your time to visit. Just across the road from the Parliament building.
Poignant. Another Holocaust memorial--this one very specific and personal--and visitors seemed to really want to interact with it. Definitely not to be missed.
Sad. A sad story, but a beautiful tribute. There's loads of history along both sides of the river, worth a look if your interested in that type of thing.

Cool. This is very cool. Especially in the night when you don't really understand what's what.
A romantic place on the river side.
You shouldn't miss it.

Makes you think. We were looking for the 'shoes' and they don't seem to be mentioned in then tourist information which is strange, so we literally stumble across this very poignant piece of art which is s memorial to the Jews who were shot on the bank of the Danube and fell in just to be swept away.
A good reminder. With a shocking story behind, the monument doesn`t let us forget the killing during Nazi rule. A great reminder to everyone, so we dont let it happen again.
Moving memorial . Simple but subtle memorial on the side of the river. To those who lost their lives during the holocaust.
Shoes memorial. Lovely tribute to victims of the holocaust,simple and chilling. On the east side of the river, not far from the parliament building
Take 5 minutes to stop and look. Not something to go out of your way for, but it is worth paying a visit and thinking about the actions that prompted such a display

Simple moving tribute. As in the title, this is a simple, moving tribute to those Jews that were murdered during WW2 and dumped into the frozen Danube.
What isn't explained is that (according to our guide) this was carried out by the local Hungarian fascist White Cross and not the German Nazi's.
Very moving. Such a simple memorial, but I found myself crying. Be sure to spend a few minutes on your way to or from the parliament building.
Moving Experience. Well worth a visit given the second world war history of Budapest and its Jewish inhabitants. Easy to get to from Buda and Pest.

A moving memorial easily accessible. Memorial to the few thousand Jews shot and thrown in the river by the Nazi influenced Hungarians. They were forced to remove their shoes before being killed and these are metal replicas. The memorial is right on the riverbank near Parliament.

A site that must be seen and contemplated. This simple, unobtrusive memorial is very, very moving. Everyone visiting the city should stop here and contemplate what occurred. It is a little difficult to find, but very much worth the effort. I believe the artist wanted it to be present but not have signage to find it. It makes a bigger statement this way. It is not directly in front of the Parliament building, but a short distance from it right at the edge of the river, very near the Parliament water taxi stop.
Budapest Sites. This is a very touching memorial. The men, women, and children's shoes evidence the horror of the era. It is within walking distance of the Parliament building.
Must see!. This was a moving representation of the time the Jews were executed. Think it needs to be seen by all. A gruesome time in history. Glad that the monument was there!
Holocaust memorial. A moving and thoughtful simple memorial to thousands who perished at the hands of the Hungarian Nazis
Compelling. This is quite an emotional thing to see - especially the variety of shoes and boots - most especially the children's.
Very impressive. It must see place for tourists. Very impressive and historical place. Better to read the history of this before, to understand what is it.

Moving and worth seeing; too bad Budapest authorities won't help tourists find it. This memorial is to the thousands of Jews shot and thrown into the river by Hungarian Nazi sympathizers during the war. The victims -- men, women, children-- were made to leave their shoes on the river bank before they were killed, and this sculpture monument is of pairs of shoes of all styles and sizes. It is about a 5 minute walk from the Parliament, right on the river bank, across the street from a Commerzbank. I say this as direction because you may not find it otherwise. I could find it on no tourist maps, no tour books, there are no directional signs, and no one in authority whom I asked could direct me to it. If you do not walk up the riverbank from the Chain Bridge and try to access it from Parliament, you'll have to cross the tram tracks and a busy highway to get to it.Still, it is worth seeing and spending a few minutes there if you can.
A very moving memorial. It is hard to think of the cruelty toward the Hungarian Jews, and this display of the barbarity is very moving.
Sad and Moving. Located along the river enbankment near the Parliament, this moving monument is definitely worth seeing (possiblty after your tour of the Parliament.)

An evocative, must-see memorial - different from anything else anywhere.... This is a simple, deeply touching memorial to those victims of the Hungarian Arrow Cross who were shot and killed on the banks of the Danube in 1944, their bodies were tossed into the frozen river, and only their sad, abandoned shoes were left on the shore. The memorial is simple and deeply touching - and should be visited, especially now, when the nastiest kind of racism, xenophobia and antisemitism is again on the political agenda of the present government.

Very sad, touching but a must see. This is a replica of the shoes of the people that were ordered to take their shoes off and were shot and fell into the water off the edge of the Danube. It is a simple display of shoes but very moving and sends a powerful message when you know the story behind it.My friend was brought to tears when she saw the shoes.

Brings a lump to your throat. A simple memorial to people murdered during WW2. Shoes on a riverbank. So much more than just that, as you look at them you cannot help thinking about the events of yesteryear.

Very interesting . Very powerful and thought provoking memorial. Beautiful setting along the Danube but reminds us of a dark time in the city's history. If you are visiting the parliament, it is just along the river bank. I would also recommend walking from the parliament to the chain bridge as this offers great views of Buda across the water
A poignant exhibit. This simple exhibit says it all. A definite must see for all visitors to Budapest. Lest we forget the cruelty of humankind.
Very Emotional Memorial. Be sure to read about this memorial before visiting. It will be hard to keep tears from your eyes. Very well done.

The shoes are a sad reminder of war. Local people were lifted from the street by Nazis in 1945. Taken to river, shot and thrown in. These bronze shoes of varied size and style are a wonderful memorial of the horrors of war.

Homage to Domestic Hungarian genocide. The Hungarian Nazi collaborators (Arrow Cross Party) eagerly and lustfully carried out the mass murder of Budapest's Jews and some Romani in 1944. The Jews of Hungary were spared throughout the war but when the "liquidation" order came, no Jew was spared. This simple memorial is close to the Hungarian Parliament. It makes you think and compare modern, Democratic and Western Hungary only yesterday, shooting innocent Jews and dumping them into the flowing, cold Danube. The memorial is controversial in that it states that it is dedicated to the victims of the Holocaust while kind of leaving out the word, "Jews". There is sign in Hebrew as well. This is a must site to visit as you enjoy the hustle and bustle of this great city that must, forever, live in the shadow of collaboration in the murder of so many Hungarian Jews. So, while enjoying the sites, pay tribute.
Important attraction . This small attraction is very subtle but has a strong message. Very glad we visited as it is well presented. Beautiful in its simplicity. Glad we didn't miss it.

Terror Falls. Incredible reminder of what happened in this [now] quite amazing, near overwhelming [in a good way!], vibrant city seventy years ago. Whoever comes here is then honour bound to visit the Museum of Terror in Andrassy Street. And then you will understand why.
Powerful Memorial . We took the time to sit down and soak in the horror these victims endured. It is truly a heartbreaking Memorial.
Very Moving. We were waiting for our Parliament tour and saw this exhibit along the Danube. Very moving, especially after hearing about the Jewish History tour
Poignant tribute.. Just along the Danube from Chain Bridge. A poignant tribute to the many people that lost their lives.

Very moving. Bronzed shoes stretched along the Danube give a feeling that will move you for a long time. From small
Children shoes to families in a group you can only imagine the horror faced by the Jewish people trying to escape the Germans. Absolutely a must see.

A part of our history. If you don't know for what these shoes are standing for you might say it is just interesting. But when you know that this is a part of a history you will get goosebumps standing at that place.
Moving memorial.. Located just next to the Parliament building on the River Danube (Pest Side). Very moving, although no explanation for those just wandering past!

Couple . It's a moving monument and aptly placed on the river's edge where Jews were shot before falling into the river. They were asked to remove their shoes so they sank easier. It's good that Hungary are taking responsibility and admitting to their Nazi collaboration. It's a sad but meaningful memorial .

Very touching memorial . If you walk to the parliament way along Danube river , you can see this 60pairs of shoes made of iron which include men, women and kids sizes. This memorial was created by sculptors Gyula and Togay to commomarate those victims who were shot into the Danube by Arrow cross men especially the victims were Jewish people mostly . Visit this place and pay you respect to the souls.

Unexplained Memorial. This has the potential to be an effective memorial for those who were shot into the Danube by Nazis but it had no signage or plaque to explain that. Luckily, I heard the history from a tour guide. It's not far from the Parliament and part of a nice to walk along the Promenade so it is quite nice to pass.
Deeply moving. It is hard to imagine the evil that humans can do to each other...but at this place we bear witness to murder and evil beyond words. The shoes tell all.
Beautiful Tribute. Located on the Danube river bank right next to Parliament, this is a moving tribute to Jewish lives lost in Budapest during World War II.
Dramatic . This shoes very near the parliament . They are on the walking area . Their story are so sad . They are about people who were killed in world war II.
Very poignant and humbling. It brings it home how dreadful that era in history was. Adults and children's shoes discarded just before inevitable death

Very simple, but moving memorial. A small memorial to Jews murdered in 1945 in Budapest by the Hungarian Nazis. It consists of a set of metal shoes, representing all that was left of the people who were shot, after they had fallen into the Danube. Look, and think... how can people do this to each other?

Wonderful Budapest. We have just spent 4 days in Budapest and what a wonderful place it is. One of the things we saw whilst there was the "Shoes on the Danube Memorial" it is a very fitting memorial and makes you stop for a while and remember those poor Jewish people who lost their lives there. Long may they be remembered.

An emotive memorial. Just along from The Parliament building.Surprised, but glad that it did not feature in any of the walking tours ( would make it too crowded). Very emotive, particularly when viewing the children's small boots. These memorials are so important....we should never forget.We took photos of the shoes but we didn't personally pose next to them, as it just didn't seem appropriate.

A visual reminder of the horrors of WW2. We went out of our way to find this monument. It is low key, but carries a punch. So glad we had read about it first. You need to stand and just absorb the scene.

Moving. I have not seen this monument close up but seen it many times from the 2 tram. That everyday passing seems to make it even more poinent and real. It is like it happened yesterday. Really startling and moving, you can imagine the scene.
Came across this by accident... Haunting. We came across the shoes by accident. The impact was emence, very emotional, you could not fail to be moved by it.

Big impact. For such a small display in a city of big buildings it definitely packs a punch. You can't escape Images of people lined up facing into the river awaiting there death. Poignant moment.
Disappointed to see people taking smiling selfies at a monument that stirs up such emotions.

Touching Memorial. Such a poignant and touching memorial which just makes you want to sit quietly and pay respects to the lives lost in war. We spent an evening here watching evening turn to dusk and night and it was breathtaking to watch the city light up by the dusk hour.

This One Will Touch You If Your Heart Is Soft at All!!. This memorial isn't one of great glitz or glory. This is about the inhumanity of one man to others. The Hungarians have taken shoes (I was told they had come from families or people who had actually perished in the Death Camps of Hitler's German/Austrian/Hungarian/Japanese and Italian alliance. When you leave the Houses of Parliament go to the river and head towards down town (towards the Chain Bridge). After about a 1/8 of a mile you will come upon the shoes. They are bronzed and placed in a row. You will find a woman's shoes, a child's shoes and various other shoes. When I came to the family group I was deeply touched. There were the boots of a man, the shoes of a grown woman, the smaller boots of a young boy and the tiny shoes of a little girl. This is when it hit home. This was a real crime against real people. I recommend you take the time to see this. If we are to learn from the past and not repeat the injustice and inhumanity of this type of crime we need to see these types of memorials. I take my hat off to the Hungarian's for have the fortitude to put this simple memorial where everyone could see it. Anyone who visits Budapest should go and think about what you are looking at.

Very important memorial . The shoes commemorate a horrible event in hungarian history, one many are unaware of and others would like to cover up. When the Hungarian Nazis took thousands of Jews to the river and executed them so only their shoes remained.
Haunting. Definitely a place to provoke thoughts. History is very sad but at least these poor people are not forgotten.

Very moving.... It's a very compelling piece of art which brings home the tragedy of a dreadful incident. People will either feel the significance of it and remember it for what it represents or they won't because they don't have the sensibility to do so. That's all I can say, really.
Will make you pause. A powerful memorial to the Jews who were forced to step out of their shoes before being shot by fascists in WWII.

Atrocity of man v man. This really hits home the atrocity that this cities people endured. It is a very simple monument but delivers a very powerful message. Take 10 minutes out of your time to pay respect to this monument you will be glad you did.

Simple but moving. Its always the simple things that can be the most effective and this is one of those things. Take the time to walk down to this memorial and think about the people who it is dedicated to and why it is there.
Emotional site. War time atrocities remembered. The shoes are a symbal of the time unfortunately. The site is very close to walk from the Chain bridge between Pest and Buda

Weird. It is weird to see those shoes. you will have mixed feelings about those people who committed suicide. The shoes look real and give you the impression of how people jumped in the river.
Worth seeing
Nice to see. You can pss by un noticing the shoes on the ground (we did the first time). It is not impressive, unless you have read about the story
Metal Shoes. I think these metal shoes have some important meaning to them but sadly I am not aware of what that is but it was cool finding them along the water :)

Interesting tribute. Seeing the Shoes Memorial was a moving expereince when we were told that the shoes represent all the Jewish people who were drowned in the Danube just because they were Jewish! This is a very creative and moving way for the artist to represent this atrocity.

A moving tribute but quirky too. It grabs your attention as it is such an unusual tribute, a nearby plaque gives the sad history of why these assorted men, women and childrens shoes are sculpted so realistically on the edge of the Danube,

Shoes?. I appreciate the purpose of this art-installation.
A remembrance of the jews being killed during the terrible Holocaust.
But this is "merely" a lot of bronze shoes.
Look at it, if you pass it by incident. But don't make specific plans to see it.

Heartbreaking and Poignant. Although we had already visited the Jewish Quarter, the Old Synagogue and the Museum..... The most important, poignant and touching of all symbols of holocaust is the shoes along the Danube. Not to be missed by Jew and Gentile.
Very moving. A strange site to behold given its meaning. This is a very eerie, sad attraction to visit. People leave flowers here and light tea candles.
Moving. Very moving and thought provoking sight. Something you must see when you are in Budapest. Right next to Parliament.
A simple but moving memorial.. Make sure you read about this before you go, because there are no explanatory plaques at the site. Definitely worth a 10 minute visit.

Essence of pain. I have been all over the world and seen many monuments commemorating Holocaust but this one made especially deep impression on me . I could not hold the tears when I saw children shoes I thought about my very much alive niece and nephew still babies. If they were here Hungarians would have threw them into that river. Unlike Germans Hungarians show very little remorse of what the did to their own Jewish community! They even have a pic of their soldier in German uniform at one of the historical site. It is sad place but it need to be seen because it will happen again if we forget.

Tissues Required. A very sad part of Hungarian history beautifully reflected on the riverbank. I suggest you read up about it before going as the English explanation (or any explanation) is rather short and doesnt give the full story.
Jewish site but sad.... Left over shoes to symbolise those who have died in the war. A Jewish site that would make anyone sad for those who have died. Peace in the world. ☮☮☮☮☮☮☮

Very touching and well designed memorial. We found it extremely poignant and very moving. Definitely a must-visit in Budapest. It was very close to the Parliament building which was another magnificent sight.
Very touching. A very moving memorial to the Jewish victims of the Hungarian fascists in WWII. Very close to the Parliament along the Danube.

A moving tribute to a terrible historical fact.. Walking along the Danube in front of the parliament buildings is a great way to spend an hour in Budapest. We came upon this memorial and found ourselves moved by the tragedy of the war and yet grateful for the courage of the Hungarian peopleacknowledging their part in this event. It is striking to see the variance of people, without discrimination, who met their end in this way...young, old, male and female. Thank you, Hungary, for this reminder of how easy it can be to loose sight of what is right thinking you are acting appropriately.
Simple yet powerful memorial. A very simple yet powerful memorial. Well worth walking along the Danube to pay your respects and remember the fallen
Budapest . Walking along that east bank and you come across this memorial to the city Jewish community. Very poiniant

Visit to Shoes on the Danube Memorial. This is very close to the Hungarian Parliament complex, just 5 minutes walk down the Danube bank It is a poignant and moving memorial to the victims of the Holocaust. We went with our local guide, but even without a guide it is not easy to find. There is not a lot of information at the site about what happened, just a few plaques in honor of the victims. If you want to learn more about the memorial you'll need to read a guide book or use a local guide.

Shivers down your spine .... It's just one of the many monuments in Budapest, but one that sends shivers down your spine when you're there. Imagine literally standing in someone else's shoes and being shot ... Seeing a pair women's shoes with a single white flower next to it, or a pair of children's shoes with a some sweets in it, brings tears to your eyes and makes it a very powerful monument. Just go there, realise what happened and make sure it will never happen again ...

One of the best Holocaust memorials in the world. I personally think it is a must see while in Budapest. It is a memorial of thousands of people shot to Danube during the Holocaust in Budapest. They were rounded up from the streets of the city, because they had yellow stars. And shot. This memorial reminds us of this event, and it is to give us a lessons how fragile the life is. The metal shoes, of different sizes, kids', women's and men's shoes, show total atrocity of the war and Holocaust. It is shocking, because you start to think, imagine, what actually happened to those people who left their shoes on the shore. If you visit Budapest, go and see it

The shoes of the Jews.. Shoes/boots,Leather of all members of families that have been preserved for all to see. At the waters edge, near the Parliament building. Left by Jews that were murdered and fell into the waters. A must see reminder of world war 2. ..
Lest we forget. A reminder of the horrors of not so long ago when the Germans moved in. I.think Hungary suffered more than most.
Poignant. This placement of shoes on the riverbank to tell the sorry of people who had their shoes removed before being shot and being pulled into the Danube

Budapest monument . The shoes on the Danube memorial is hard to see but very moving. It is a memorial of the Hungarians ( mostly Jews) who were lined up by the Danube and shot. I believe it was in 1944
Remnants of WW 2. So glad we stopped and saw part of Pest history. Powerful small monument but left me with a chilling feeling.
To never forget. Wonder along the river, if you're are in Budapest just walk trought the Danube (near the Parlament) to see that!

worth to visit. This row of bronze shoes just 250-300 meters from the famous parliament by the Duna river is a sad memorial for those who executed here during WWII. In a bronze plate which has been placed on the pedestrian side of shoes has not indicated these are executed by Nazi, and that was interesting for me in spite of telling the gossip by people.

Tears tears and more tears. Situated in heart heart of one of the worlds most beautiful countries is the heart of the atrocities from the Second World War. No words are needed hear.....the very sight of these shoes.....some large and some tiny represent the persecuted who were pushed into the freezing waters of the Danube. It is heartbreaking. Don't miss it. Pay your respects here. Take a silent walk remembering those who died. The setting is magnificent but take your tissues as this will pull at every heart string. After this take the Jewish heritage tour....well worth every cent (and it does cost much either)

Sad and moving! A truly "real" experience.. Upon hearing the story of those shot & thrown into the river, you feel sad while standing there. The shoes are a solid reminder of a time in history that should be remembered for the sake of their souls.
Incredibly meaningful . I recommend either seeing this on a tour or read about it before and then visit because of the meaning behind the memorial. It's simple and powerful!

Just past the Parliament. A really sad story. A truly touching exhibit. This represents all that was left of a group of people herded away by the Nazis during World War II. Moving to see the shoes right at the edge of the Danube. Says more than many other grander monuments.

Sad reminder of the those who perished during the war. This row of bronze shoes/boots by the riverside is only 300 metres from the Parliament building so no distance to stroll along and see.
It is in rememberance of those executed during the war on this very spot.
Very moving and when we visited last week there was a fresh rose on one of the shoes.
Somber part of history. If you are in Budapest it is a must see and a tragic part of history. Take a nice stroll down the waterfront area and stop by to see this memorial

A stunning reminder of what hatred can do.... Thousands of Jewish people were shot and thrown into the Danube..just because they were Jewish.
We need to remember this!

Traumatic but very worthwhile. This is one of the most moving memorials to the holocaust that I have ever seen and I have seen many. Its most affecting aspect is its simplicity and is a worthy reminder of the needless suffering inflicted on innocent people by the Hungarian Arrow Cross and their Nazi masters.
Worth a visit. Located on the bank of Danube, just next to Parliament house this is good place to stop and think about past.

Important Memorial. The Shoes on the Danube is a memorial on the Pest side of the danube, not far from the parliament building. It was Created to honor the Hungarian Jews who were killed in the same place during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river. It is a beautiful way to make sure that everyone who walks by is aware of what happened there.
GReat for photos. Great place to shoot photos. Near the Parliament. but be very cautious with kids because the shoes are next to the Danube and it is easy to trip into the water (no fence)

Shoes on the Danube. I found this memorial to be very moving. I watched many others react the same way as they came up to it. What was missing was a memorial plaque of some type - I think it would have helped some who had no idea what they were seeing.
Moving. One of the most moving humanised memorials we've seen. A really touching monument & nice to see people being respectful of this tragedy.

A very emotional place. This wasn't in our guide book, but we heard about this memorial from someone who had visited them. The shoes were sculpted in 2005 to commemorate the shooting of Hungarian Jews by the fascist Arrow Cross militia in 1944. They were ordered to take off their shoes before being shot and fell into the Danube. There are children's shoes, ladies shoes and boots of all shapes and sizes. There are three plaques on the waterside path one in Hungarian, one in English and one in Hebrew. It is a very emotional place on the banks of the Danube.
Thought provoking monument. Very thought provoking and moving monument. I would recommend reading some history on it before visiting, as there is no placard or description.
Moving. Moving but abrupt - you come across them so quickly and there is scant information about when it was decided to have this memorial or by whom.

Really great monument. It makes great impression, makes you think about the past about how lucky we are to live in peaceful times. Totally worth visiting. Bring an umbrella if rains, as it is outside.
Thought provoking. Worth going to look and to take the time to think about what the shoes mean. A reminder to us all. Took photos that I will look at

Simple but Powerful memorial. . These shoes are right by Parliament on the river. I am really interested in WW2 history and this is a powerful but simple memorial to the poor Jewish people in the war.

Moving Memorial. An interesting memorial to those killed during the Holocaust. The shoes make it very real. I stood & put my foot next to many of the shoes & thought about who might have worn them. Don't miss seeing this.
Worth a visit. Beautiful views of the river and buda side (castle etc). Easy to find. Didn't see an information sign of any kind.

A Sentimental Place. One of the very different types of memorials ,it is situated on the river banks of Danube on the Pest side and is within 5-7 minutes from the iconic Chain Bridge. It is a tribute to the slain Jews who were killed during the 2nd World War.
