A moving experience . I hadn't expected to see so many shoes - men's, women's, and children's. Some had tea lights in them and one pair of tiny shoes had candies. Very moving to think of what happened to their owners. Highly recommend this spot, a short walk from the parliament building.

Touching but frustrating at the same time. What a horror story. The historical event was so tragic and horrifying. It strikes you and it's painful. While visiting we've been read a testimonial affidavit given by a woman, a girl at the time, who watched the murder take place. She described it in a magnifying laconic way. No emotion involved. Just description of those hundreds taken to the Danube and shot and thrown there by the riverside. Woman man children all gone for ever taken by the river. T e r r i b l e!!!!Yet no note, no memorial statement no nothing to be found at the spot, to honor those whose life was taken-for only their shoes......few anemic words which doesn't even include the existence of mostly Jews amongst them. We've visited many sights in Berlin with an awful historical context. All respected the memory and at the same time showed certain responsibility for those tragic event. Such an approach is not to be found in Budapest nor at this powerful memorial. How very frustrating. How disappointing it is!
Poignant Memories. This memorial for the Jews who were lined up along the banks of the Danube in Pest, required to remove their shoes, shot and tossed into the river is quite sad...
Moving experience. Seeing the shoes and learning the story behind this was some history I felt very moved by. Absolutely must stop by and pay respect.

Somber Memorial to Massacre of Jews. Subtle but profound memorial to the savagery of the Holocaust. The shoes signify the last moments of the many Jews that were forced to remove them as they were shot into the Danube by the local Arrow Cross gangs (the day the Danube turned red), apparently bound to outdo the Nazi SS in horror and atrocity. The memorial plaques are way too subtle as they barely mention the context (one has to do independent research to grasp the magnitude) and the reference to "victims" is casual, failing to mention they were killed because they were Jews.

Memory of the human evil. Memory from the days when evil sign in Europe. When people were murdered because they were others.When hatred has caused neighbors to kill the people who lived with them for generations.Hundreds of Jews were forced to line up on the bank, grabbed their shoes and shot them. The dead thrown into the river. Bloody Red Danube

Must see stop in Budapest. This is a must see stop for visitors to Budapest. Very moving. It's very easy to get to. Important for the Austrians to visit as well as they have not yet lived up to the participation in the Holocaust.

Worth a visit if you like walking around and exploring.... Would recommend this as a good "out all day and exploring" activity. It'll only take you 5 mins to look at but its very humbling and situated right on the Danube so has lovely views across the river as well when you walk to it.

Memorial visit. It was a very humbling experience to visit this quiet & solemn site after getting to know the background in specific. Crime of murder committed against humanity by killing innocent human beings including women & children by Nazis. The only crime of those murdered was that they were helpless Jews !!!! Killed & thrown in Denube which is the only witness to this one of the many such horrific scenes during II WW. RIP.

Take the time to see this!. This is a sobering monument/ installation, due to the location. This monument was erected where the event happened. It is easy to see why the shoes are placed here, with the proximity to the river.
An imaginative re-creation/ reminder. Go see it.

Go take a look at the shoes. Not very well advertised but a friend had told me about these so wanted to see them for myself. Read about them before you go and they will make sense. All very sad. Not far from parliament building if you want to find them.

Overrated. An interesting installation but Budapest has so much more to offer. At no4 this is definitely overrated. Would really only visit after seeing the top 20 or so other sites. If you are interested in the relevant historical context rather go and visit Terror Háza and get some real understanding of the whats and whys.o
Moving. Very very moving tribute to Holocaust victims committed by a wicked ideology, this memorial should be visited by old and young and never be forgotten.

Minimalist memorial to savage butchery. This is a simple memorial consisting of two bronze plaques (one in English and one in Hungarian) installed in the ground and a number of pairs of shoes (or occasionally just a single shoe). It commemorates the summary execution of Jews on the banks of the Danube in the closing months of World War II as Soviet Armies fought the Nazis for control of Budapest. It is worth having a good travel guide to completely comprehend the brutal and savage acts which this memorial commemorates. Apparently, the skeletons of those summarily executed here were discovered only recently during reconstruction and/or repair work on one of the Danube bridges. It took some time for forensic specialists to identify the bones and connect them to events in Budapest near the end of World War II. It is no place for selfies or a place to have your picture taken. It is a place to understand better the inhuman savagery of World War II and the Nazi regime and resolve to never let such things happen again.

A sad memorial. You would have to know the history to get anything from this visit,I found it quite moving.The shoes serve as a reminder or maybe a warning to the cruelty that humans can inflict on another.
Tragic History . While this is a quaint installation it a must visit as its reminds us of the horrific treatment people endured through the meaningless wars.
Very moving.. A place to reflect on the poor women, men and children who died in WWII...at this spot. A simple, and yet profound & moving memorial.

This is a must see and think about. Thinking about what took place in the past is something we all shouldn't forget.We live in an era that hopefully will remain separated from these things. But no it still goes in other parts of the world even today. To think about people standing at the edge of the wall and being killed and left to float away is horrible. View this site and think about it.
Stop for a moment. I sat there for a few minutes, silently. This is not a simple place. You may forget which year is now and see these shoes as if these people were murdered right now..

Simple but moving. Near parliament along the Danube you find this very moving memorial.
Simple but clever. Worth it to just sit for a few moments and reflect.

Sad memorial. Seeing this memorial was sad but a sobering memory of how brutal things were during the war. Several Jewish men, women and children were lined up along the Danube River, made to remove their shoes and then shot into the river. Their shoes are the memorial standing.
So evocative. No words are necessary. Each person will take something of their own from this amazing and simple memorial.
Historic momument. Its good to visit this. According to the history there were people who have been killed by the nazi in 1940.

Nothing special. Besides the beautiful view on the Buda castle and the Danube from the statues, it's truly nothing special or even emotional at it's slightest. I'd recommend putting this to the back of your "things to see in Budapest" list. I wasn't amused.

Thought-proviking. Despite its simplicity, I found this memorial extremely thought-provoking and moving and most definitely worth visiting.
Located outside the Houses of Parliament.

Impressive. Thinking about what happend in the past isn't my first thought, but it's something we cannot forget and therefore I had to visit. It's hard to think what must've happend and I believe that the victims deserve to be remembered, although not by name but due to what's done to them. It's just shoes you'll see and hopefully no one will every have to fill those shoes.

Just a piece of history. What a shame that very few people know that the sculptor Gyula Pauer created this wonderful site to honour the Jews who were killed by fascist in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water and the only shoes represent what was left behind them. So, take a moment to honour them. A plaques will be a great explanation as i saw many people walking by, admiring but not knowing what the shoes represent.

A Sobering Monument. This collection of bronze shoes lining the Danube near the Hungarian Parliament are a sad reminder of Hungary's horrific past. In December 1944 and January 1945, Budapest's Jewish community was rounded up by members of the Arrow Cross Militia. They were marched to the edge of the Danube where they were ordered to remove their shoes, then shot. Their bodies then fell into the river and were carried downstream.Designed by Can Togay with sculptor Gyula Pauer, The Shoes on the Danube Bank was unveiled in 2005. This movement is definitely worth a visit.

Very sad but beautiful memorium. I do not think tourists quite understand why these are here. We had a tour that explained. Its a very sad but beautiful memorium. Not a place to take selfies though! Come on people, have respect.
Moving memorial. Very thought provoking memorial on the banks of the Danube. Time to stop and remember. Well worth a visit

Keep your eye out!. This heart-wrenching reminder of the souls that were loss mindlessly and viciously during the Holocaust is easy to pass right by. While walking along the stretch of the Danube really keep your eye out for it, as if there is not a small crowd already it does not grab attention from the view across the river.
Sad. This site is very important if you love history and to understand the struggles of the Jews in Hungary.Recommend going early as it gets crowded

Stop and pay your respects.... A sad reminder of the Jewish community in Budapest, almost entirely wiped out. Sadly, many tourists were snapping pictures without having a clue at what they were looking at. :-(

Touching memorial. This memorial of WW2 and the Holocaust is one of the strongest I have visited. It devastates me to think about how it must have been for the people standing there in those shoes. We must never forget.

Heartbreaking. This is the saddest and most touching memorial to Jews killed in World War II that I have ever seen. The shoes look as though their owners had just stepped out of them now, rather than in 1944 when their owners were killed.

A mesmerizing study in minimalism . It's a powerful and iconic depiction of terrible times, but also an unobtrusive part of the landscape. It doesn't shout "look at me", but rather draws you in. While we were there, a father and his young son passed by, and the child insisted on adding his flip-flops to the line of shoes. It was a surreal sight. We approached the father and explained the meaning of the memorial. The moment of quiet and somber understanding demonstrated the power of this project.
Must visit in Budapest. Very important place to visit and to remember. To see what evil can do. Even in such dutiful place. No one forgotten, No one forgiven!
intersting memorial. If you are walking by the parliament building near the Dunabe you will stumble across this memorial. Many of the shoes have candles in them.
Nice Memorial. A nice memorial to the Jewish people who were shot and killed here but a shame people don't realize what this is for and can be disrespectful trying on the shoes and taking selfies!

Poignant place . Given the story behind this monument, it is actually quite a sad few moments to stand and reflect on what these people must have went through. To say I enjoyed it would be wrong as seeing casts of children's shoes who eventually were killed was not enjoyable but it was an experience in will never forget and well worth the walk along the Danube.

Beautiful memorial. Absolutely worth a visit. The memorial is so poignant and moving. I would recommend visiting after a warm day when the weather is good because the sun setting over the Danube leaves a beautiful silhouette and the shoes seem so real.
Pretty . Really pretty and symobolic!! A must visit when walking along the Danube bank! Easy to find. We used google maps!
emotional experience!. This was a very moving experience and really made you think and reflect on the cruelty of the atrocities of war. Although it is about the past it is very relevanct today

A nice attraction but nothing extraordinary. Tourist attraction like any other. I personally don't think it shouldn't be in top 20 in Budapest. There's a lot of better things to see, but a walk during the night is wonderful on the shores of Danube.
Very cool. This memorial was very impactful and helps you connect the beautiful city today with a dark period of history. Everyone visiting should walk by these before/after seeing the parliament.
Must see. I think this is something you should definitely drop by when visiting Budapest. It is a very moving memorial and relates to a key part of the city's history.
Incredibly moving.. I recently saw this listed as one of the must see sculptures in the world. To be honest, I stumbled across it... Fortunately. A beautiful memorial to a horrible time.

Oh so striking, humbling is not the real word. It is when you see this kind of shrine or any holocaust remembrance it brings you back to earth. We should be so grateful to these people who gave their lives so some day we might prosper. Although in todays world it is getting harder every day.

A memorial not to be missed. A very moving memorial to the Jews shot by the Hungarian Arrow on the Pest side of Budapest close to the Parliament building. As the Nazi retreated to the Buda side in advance of the Russian liberation, the Arrow Cross rounded up mainly Jews along the bank of the Danube and shot them point blank in the back of their heads so they'd fall forward into the Danube and wash away downstream. As the Memorial is close to many major hotels, near the Parliament, and takes a few moments of introspection, it should not be missed.
This exhibit takes your breathe away.. seeing these shoes and knowing the meaning of them and the placement was astonishing. It gave me goose bumps.
Worth the 5 min walk. This is a 5 minute walk from the Parliament building and is worth it to pause and remember and honor the holocaust victims.

Heartbreaking but thought provoking. This small, but perfectly formed monument, is a little gem on the riverside. Not far from the parliament building if you walk along the river you'll come across these shoes. In a city that is full of beauty this is a stark reminder of the horrific acts that took place here.
Really good tribute. Very interesting tribute to those who died in the war. Very thought provoking and I'm really glad i went to see these.

Touching tribute. The story behind this memorial is one that will stay with you for a long time. It is hard to fathom those that would line up people; men, women and children, and shoot them because they were Jewish. The tributes that are left are also just as touching. A must see in Budapest.

Jewish Budapest Walking Tours. The Shoes on the Danube is a memorial to the Budapest Jews who were shot by Arrow Cross militiamen between 1944 and 1945. The victims were lined up and shot into the Danube River. They had to take their shoes off, since shoes were valuable belongings at the time.The memorial was created by Gyula Pauer, Hungarian sculptor, and his friend Can Togay in 2005. It contains 60 pairs of iron shoes, forming a row along the Danube. Each pair of shoes was modeled after an original 1940's pair. For more of an insight read 'One of Budapest's Most Moving Memorials: Shoes on The Danube'.The memorial is between the Parliament Building and the Hungarian Academy of Sciences, by the Danube.
Sad memorial. This commemorates the organized massacre of Jews, not by the Nazis but by local hoodlum fascists. In its simple understatement, it is very powerful

Touching memorial. The shoe memorial is a short walk from Parliament and is worth a visit. It is simple and low key and is a reminder of a dark period in European history. I found it a very moving and a sad spot. The different sizes shoes represent the men, women and children who were ordered to take off there shoes before being shot into the Danube and carried away by the river.

A moving and thought provoking sculpture . Went for a stroll along the river bank and came across these shoes by the river, just before we reached the parliament building. A very thought provoking sculpture.

Moment to reflect . Whilst meandering along the river it's worth stopping to see the iconic shoes on the danube as they are a symbolic reminder of times gone by. They are located on the Pest side of the river close to parliament.
Thought provocking. A must to visit not far from parliment building a solemn reminder of young lives lost tragically many years ago
Interesting.. Nothing special, but interesting to see, good story lies behind these shoes. Its not far from centar so you can just walk to here.
A sad but necessary reminder. This is a very heartbreaking memorial to the Jews murdered by Hungarian Nazis. While the site may be a little difficult to access it is well worth the visit.

Simple but very moving. Make sure you visit this sad spot. Clever simple memorial which I found terribly moving knowing a lot about the history of 1944-45 and the atrocities of the Arrow Cross. A must see.

Very Powerful Image . It is difficult to express the powerful image this tribute to the Jewish people whose lives were lost here under the Nazi occupation. You have to go yourself to see this
Memorial

Interesting, moving, but not spectacular. If you do have time to walk from the Parliament house down the Danube I certainly recommend you to do it as you will come across this monument (it is maybe 5-10min walking distance from Parliament house). If you are in a rush and do not have much time for walks, do not bother to stop here it really is not that spectacular although it is moving once you learn the story behind it.

Shoes on the Danube. Don't visit this memorial before reading the history of it first. Who would believe that such evil existed. Many bring flowers to honor the memories of the people murdered here. I was touched when I saw that
Just shoes with history. I stumbled across the shoes when walking along the riverside and I know there is history to the shoes but for me it was nothing special.

A moving tribute. Worth a visit and some quiet contemplation. Hungary has a difficult political history and this memorial to the victims of the internal Arrow Cross militia is truly moving in its simplicity. Worth finding out more at the National History Museum on the hill in Buda.
Lovely tribute, interesting history. Really I implore you to read up on your history of Budapest, it is very very interesting. It will give you a much deeper appreciation of this memorial.
just shoes. For some people it is good attraction but for me just shoes hanging by the river .It's not easy to find it as well
Makes you think. A really sad reminder of the horrific things that happened in the war, seeing all these shoes really does make you think
Very Solemn. To see this memorial is very sad to know these men, women and children lost their life here. It should remind us to not let this happen again but do we?
Very moving. A tribute to the Jews murdered on the banks of the Danube. Simple, but the variety of shoe types brings home that each of the hundreds of thousands massacred was an individual.
Touching. Low key but touching memorial to the Holocaust , worth checking out. Next to the river by the Parliament building.
A Tragic Remembrance. This memorial is in remembrance of the Jewish residents who were taken to the Danube and shot. It is a very poignant picture of the atrocities that took place.
Moving Memorial. A beautiful way of remembering a very dark history and the victims. People still leave flowers, prayers and candles here so it is not static but an active memorial.

Moving. Close to the parliament building so worth seeing when you visit there. This is an emotional experience that allows you to reflect on some of the great harm humans can do to each other. I just wish people didn't use it as a place to take a selfie, a bit disrespectful? :-(

A poignant reminder.... The bronze shoes lined along the Danube river are a poignant and moving reminder of terrible events in our history. Very simply done and in a place where being still and reflecting happens naturally.
Makes you think!. You will not notice these at first. We didn't until we had been to the House of Terror. We went back to see them, they are for real, really hits hard when you see children shoes.
Emotional . Interesting experience. Sad and great in the same time. Absolutely worth to visit. Some background information would be nice though.
History but not much more. Very sad history behind the monument but only really need 2 minutes to experience it . Free and worth seeing on way to parliament.

A somber must-see memorial. On the Danube (Pest) side. You can walk from the Chain Bridge on way to Parliament. This memorialzes the Jewish people who were shot and killed there. They were told to step out of their shoes and move to the end of the wall so when they were shot they would fall in.

Beautiful in it's simplicity that causes shivers to go up your spine. It's located right along but the danube river bank so it's not like you're going out of your way to see such a simple memorial but it definitely does send the shipper up your spine with this beautiful simplicity and what it represents of what actually happened
Moving sight. Walked in the wrong direction for 1h looking for this but it was worth it! Moving memorial, tales you back in time and shakes you up.

An Eternal Slice of time.. It's simple, don't expect luxury. But this kind of work are eternally facinating to me, helps to remember what pride and lack empathy are capable of. I hope we learn from the past, and won't need new memorials like this in the future.

Romance on the Danube. What a beautiful walk either by day or by night. I prefer night when Buda is alight and the Chain Bridge is in its prominence. Stop along the many cafes and restaurants. Walk arm in arm with your loved one along the banks of the most romantic river in the world. This is the place to be.
Sad story behind these shoes.... We were passing Danube and saw there are many shoes next to the river. When we searched found that these are the memorial of the murdered Jews in WW2.
A moving experience. A popular attraction that is both emotional and moving. The memorial is located on the river's edge close to Parliament House.

A stark representation of the villainy of man. a simple set of shoes showing how an element of society could turn on its own people and treat them in such a horrific way . good to show we should always remember and never go back to it . we did not realise the history of hungary till we saw places like this . truly shocking and humbling to see
Touching Memorial. As part of any walk down the Danube, don't miss the Shoes. They are a very nice tribute to the people who died in the Holocaust.
Touching monumnet of horror. The shoes are placed casually, as the owners just stepped out of them - as they did, before being shot and thrown into the river. A touching monument of human evil.
Great way to remember who sacrificed thei liv. Just a few meters away from the Parliament building this site is a reminder of the ugly face of wars. Only if we could learn from our history :(

Beautifully done. the subtle monument to the atrocities committed during the war allows the visitor to feel the victim's humanity. The monument is both a disturbing and beautiful tribute to those killed. If you visit Budapest, it is a must see.
Extremely emotional document of history. Just standing by this document creates the feeling of terror all the victims of the holocaust must have felt... shivering.

Somber memorial. Memorial to Jews killed and dumped into Danube in WWII. Bronze shoes of WWII era permanently affixed to edge of river walk.
Quiet, somber memorial to those that died here.
Near Chain bridge and Parliament.

A must see when visiting Budapest. It is important for every visitor to Budapest to take the time to see the shoes and to also be reminded of the events that lead up to such memorials. A salutary reminder of the evils of history. A must see!

Simple memorial . This simple memorial we went to see which was a short walk from our hotel (Sofitel Chain Bridge) on the Pest side near the cathedral. There is a small plaque to commemorate those Jews who lost their lives in the Danube
Simple, touching. Just a small monument reminding us of a great tragedy of Jews in Budapest. It is a symbol of executing Jews on the bank of Danube.
Moving. Though difficult, it's important to learn from our past. An artistic shrine to the evils of the past. A beautiful and moving space.

Sad and important piece of history.... ... Really touches your soul on the very deep level.. There are little notes in different languages that people are leaving inside the shoes... Good place to stop and think ... Even if you are not touched personally by the tragedy, it will make your soul move...Such a nice way to remember those who were killed.. you definitely will feel the connection...there is no need for big monuments... those shoes speak for themselves...
Moving and interesting memorial. This is a memorial to the Jews during WWII who were shot and fell into the Danube. They were made to take off their shoes before they were killed. Very sad memorial

Memorial to a very sad historical event. The memorial of metal cast shoes is in from of the parliament building along the bank of the Danube. In November 1944 the fascist group, Arrow Cross, rounded up a group of Jews to the banks of the Danube, made them take off their shoes, and shot them in the back of their heads. No one is sure how many were killed. This memorial of metal cast shoes was erected here in 2005. I was upset watching a young woman sitting among the shoes with a big grin on her face, posing very happily while her father took photos of her. Her lack of respect for what happened here was sad. There is a plaque that explains why the memorial is here.
Sad... Deeply moving simple little monument... People put flowers in the shoes to show their respect for the victims. Certainly deserves the walk.

Simple monument. What a very simple idea to remind everyone of what happened to the Hungarian jews so long ago. Walking along the river's edge you see countless shoes to signify all the lives lost. Sad and moving.

Quite an unusual place. Another place we walked to we came here after the Cathedral its not far to walk. Very interesting and sad history which prompted me on my return home to do some research to find out more about the tragic events

Moving. Although I came upon this simple memorial unexpectedly, I knew, even without seeing the plaque set into the ground nearby, that this was a memorial to all the Jews who lost their lives in the Holocaust. Very moving.
Tool much garbage around.... It's clear that they do not clean often... Some people have no respect of such art arrangement... stickers on stick on art pieces...

Simple but touches your heart. Shoes on Danube is about 5 mins walk from the Hungarian Parliament along the river on the Pest side of Danube towards Chain bridge. Chain Bridge is another 5 mins walk from this monument.It is a very simple monument but it definitely touches your heart. Especially, when you see shoes that are smaller, that could be of the children. Reminds you of the terrifying past for the Jews in Hungary.

The Horrors of the Innocent Victims. It is sad that little is written about this memorial. It does evoke pain and conjures images of what these poor children, women and men had to face as they were murdered and their bodies thrown into the cold waters of the Danube.

Poignant reminder of Nazi horror. It is stunning in its simplicity. As I stood staring at the shoes I could easily see the people being shot from behind, then their dead bodies being pushed into the Danube

Moving. This is a beautiful and moving monument, shockingly more so than I expected. You can't help but be filled with emotions when you see votives lit for those who lost their lives here, or a young child place a wildflower blossom in the shoe of a victim who could not have been any older than they themself are.

Didn't have my size!. Visited this on the way to Parliament and honestly it's pretty hard to miss. Just look for a big group of people looking at the floor or queuing to get a long shot of the shoes. I was looking for someone who worked here but couldn't find anyone. Decided to try some of the shoes on and got some funny looks from tourists. Shoes are really hard and seem to be glued to the floor for security reasons. Would have liked to see if they were comfortable but couldn't. Would shop elsewhere for shoes.
Lonely iron shoes..... Lonely iron shoes, to remind a story that should never be repeated more.Memorial of the genocide of thousands of Jews
shoes. found on our last day in Budapest, very moving found on the river just below the parliament buildings
Impressive sight.. No information is supplied at the sight, you should bring a guide book or of some kind.Be aware that the sight is crowded.

Interesting history. Lovely place to sit and take in the view. We just googled the history - This world-famous composition, which comprises 60 pairs of metal shoes set in concrete on the Danube embankment, was set up in the year 2005. It commemorates the Hungarian Jewish victims of the killings committed by the Arrow Cross militiamen, the pro-German, anti-Semitic, national socialist party members of Hungary in 1944-1945. The killings usually took place en masse - the victims were lined up at the embankment, and shot into the Danube, execution-style. At three separate places of the memorial, cast iron signs read in Hungarian, English and Hebrew: "To the memory of victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944-45". This is a very simple but very moving memorial.

An amazing small remembrance of the holocaust. 50 bronze shoes on the bank of the Danube is a way to remember 8000 Jews who were killed as the war came to an end in Budapest. In 1944 these men, women, and children were told to take off there shoes and then were shot in view of the whole city.
very moving and appropriate. we nearly triped over this whilst walking at night, went back in the day and just on the other side is a plaque telling you it is to remember those shot into the river
Poignant. Very moving depiction of Hungary's history. Quite a sight to see with the sheer number of shoes displayed. Very moving.

History Right There. This was an amazing place to take my family. History right in your face. This location came to play a few months later when walking through Auschwitz and my son found a photo of the shoes and realized the connection.

Deep;u ,moving memorial. Only one other memorial has gripped my heart so strongly. Stand over the pair of children's shoes. Contemplate how this child was probably ties to his family. The Hungarian Nazis, the Arrow Cross, shot one of the parents. The family falls in, together. They drown together in the frigid December current. This is only steps from the massive Parliament building. This is a MUST see on your visit to Budapest.
A pice of history. It really makes one think about what happened and terrible it must have been back then. It's a really good way that they have done it.
Beautiful monument. This is a beautiful memorial to the Holocaust victims. I recommend visiting it when going or returning from the Parliament.
Don't miss... A must not miss while in Budapest. We found it to be a very moving, reflective and reverent experience. Within relatively easy walking distance of the main shopping area in Pest.

Poignant reminder of the horrors of war. This easily accessible and free site offers an understated but powerful and contemplative moment to remember the victims of the Nazi occupation of Budapest during WWII.

A moving visit. Unassuming memorial with a powerful impact.The shoes in all different sizes (including children) really hit home how horrifying these atrocities were. Spend some time there and take it in.

We must never forget.. After just visiting the house of terror I felt I had to visit here and spend some time just to reflect The shoes are so powerful and keep the memory of those poor people alive. Well worth a visit.

heart rending display that tells an important story of needless terror and horror.. came upon this by accident and had to sit and contemplate just what happened and why this sculpture was here. Never forget the horrors that humans inflict on each other is the message.

Must see. Simple, but heart-shattering. Don't miss this free sight. Bring your kids and tell them about what happens with evil is allowed to persist. Good on Budapest and Hungary for capturing this unforgettable tragedy.

A moving memorial. If you stroll along the Danube, you definitely need to pause at this memorial and appreciate its significance. You wouldn't think a line of rusting iron shoes lined along the riverside would be that impactful, but it was genuinely moving. The shoes, big and small, represent lives brutally taken by the Nazis during World War II. Many people stop here to take pictures, as it lends itself to that, so it lacks the serenity for quiet contemplation, however.

Simply done, deeply felt. Empty pairs of shoes on the River Bank shows where some of the Jews of Budapest were executed and their bodies fell into the river. Is it a Holocaust Memorial ? Yes ! Is it thought provoking ? Definitly. See it !!
Remembers the war. A different aspect of the war in Europe. A tribute to the many who chose the Danube as an escape route.

Should be included on your walk around Budapest.. This is a small, quiet memorial to Hungarian Jews who were murdered at the river's edge by being shot or being pushed alive into the river while tied to people who were shot. Powerful, simple memorial to a terrible event.

Jewish memorial . A very touching memorial to the Jewish lives lost to the Nazi's. Especially touching when you see some of the shoes belonged to children. Easy to get to, near the Parliament building, by the Danube river.

A Loving and Moving Tribute. Any guide or guide book will tell you the gut wrenching story behind this memorial, but it speaks volumes even without that knowledge. This is one of many Holocaust memorials and displays in Budapest and one that you will not forget..

Rating tragedy or idea to commemorate it?. Brilliantly shocking idea to remind passer-bays about what had happened there.Easy to find, between Chain Bridge ans Parliament Building. Sadly some people have no idea what is the meaning of that memorial and add their own shoes to take a photo. Maybe a big board with an explanation and some historic photos would do the trick.
Tought provoking. Worth a visit. Simple but makes you think.On the bank of the Danube towards the houses of parliament
Danube shoes. Very touching sculptures on the banks of the river . Worth a visit to sit awhile take time out and remember .
Emotional. Once you see the shoe's of men, women and children who were exterminated during the Nazi occupation you ask how could this have taken place.

Extremely moving memorial. Although the memorial comes under the heading 'attraction' it seems an inappropriate title. Similarly, a star rating is inappropriate but it gets 5 from me in the hope that readers will visit the site, because this simple collection of shoes is one of the most moving sites of remembrance I've ever seen and it provides a fitting contrast to all that is so good about Budapest for the tourist. It is a series of bronze shoes set in the footpath next to the Danube where Jews were shot at the water's edge and the bodies tumbled into the river leaving the shoes behind. It is located between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament building.

Evocative . This is a sight really worth seeing. Brings on a lot of feelings, and it tells about a tragic time in our history that is important to never forget. It lacks an information sign however, so it might be worth checking out the background of the monument before going there.

Do this after or before Parliament Tour. This is a great monument to honor the Jews that were killed here by the Danube. Pictures of the shoes with the Castile Hill in the background turn out great. But please be respectful and don't take a selfie at a memorial. You look tacky, insensitive and dumb if you do.

A simple but stunning reminder of the horrors of war. This monument is not to be missed and is dedicated to the Jews that were shot in to The Danube by the Nazi's . It's simplicity has a massive impact and makes you contemplate the horror of WW2.
Poignant. . A free art installation which makes you stop and think about the atrocities of war. Go, you won't regret it.
The cruelness of humans. Unbelievable beautiful memorial for really horrible thing in the history. Easy to find from bends of the Danube

Touching tribute. The shoes are placed on the very spot where the brutal events happened, serving as a powerful memento. You can see them on your way home, morning run or walk in the evening. They remind us and teach a lesson to be better, and it is a powerful reminder.

Heartbreak at the breakdown of humanity. It's simple, but incredibly poignant. Standing here you, looking at what was left memorialized in brass, brings one into that moment when brutality and inhumanity took hold. Slip this in when visiting the Parliament; it's only a few minutes away.
Very moving. I found thus an extremely powerful memorial. It is very simple but very moving, and I would highly recommend it.
Powerful. Research the history of this installation before you go. We had the benefit of tours in previous city who told us about the shoes.

Heartbreaking. This is a place we had to do some looking to find, but it was a somber memorial of past atrocities. The memorial is bronze shoes that have been made reflecting a photograph from around the mid 1940's.What happened was during WW2, Jews were lined up facing the Danube River, made to take their shoes off, and then shot in the back and fell into the river. It was a horrible thing, but also something that should not be forgotten. You will see shoes from men, women, and the hardest to bear were the children shoes. Some that look like they belonged to toddlers were there. (T_T)While it is a dark and horrible thing, it is a good reminder not to repeat events like this ever again. I recommend everyone to take time from their visit of Budapest to see this in person.

Shoes on The Danube. Whether you are staying in Buda or Pest it is guaranteed during your visit to Budapest that you will find yourself strolling along the edges of the Danube somewhere and at some point. Whilst the views are spectacular and the moments timeless I urge you to stop by what I consider to be one of the most moving memorials that can be found openly in this fantastic city, and possibly in Europe.

Very moving Holocaust remembrance. This is located along the Danube River in the heart of Pest. It is shoes in concrete that the poor Jewish people had to leave prior to being sent to the death camps. Really not much more than a drive by.
One of Budapest's must see attractions.. This is a truly moving site that should not be missed if are passionate about the effect of WW2 on the people of this country.

Moving. We did a Jewish Heritage tour in the morning and then walked over to this site later in the day located near The Parliament building. The simplicity of this exhibit is haunting and brings home the atrocities of the Nazis.

Very touching and horrifying. This monument is not to be missed. It's near the Parlement so you can easily combine it with a visit there. When you think of what happened here and what it symbolizes it's truly horrifying that us humans can be so cruel. It's great in it's simplicity and therefore has a bigger impact. We managed to miss it on our first trip, but I am really glad we found it on this trip.

History tour. This site made me sad and shed a tear for the people and what they went through. You have to walk to this site as if your driving you can not stop, it is a walk up to site. The walk is nice and the view of parliament building the castle is all on the way

Makes you really think. Great art should make you think. I have never seen a memorial which has left such a mark on me. This is so simply yet a truly remarkable way to remember the victims of the atrocities, men, women and children. Very very moving.

What an artwork and what a story it depicts. Shows so much in a simple manner and thus tells the horrific story in what seems a respectful way.The artwork or monument by the riverbank causes reflection.
Striking. If you know the history here, all you need are the shoes to get the effect. One long line of all manner of old shoes, bronzed, along the Danube.

Striking memorial for Holocaust victims. A striking memorial to commemorate Budapest Jews who were shot into the Danube by Hungarian Arrowcross Nazis in 1944. Worth seeing, showing to youngsters and spend some time of reflection and rememberance.

Haunting!. While the reviews for this were mixed, I made the effort to visit as I was very intrigued by this attraction. What a haunting experience, the shoes were so realistic and to picture the men and women and what they must have felt at this time was so haunting!! Such a solemn place, but a unique memorial as well! As I tried to describe this to other tourists that inquired about it, I got goosebumps again just telling about it!
Touching and worthwhile . This is an hard hitting monument commemorating a sad occurrence in Hungarian history. Worth a visit. Whilst there you also have some beautiful views of the Danube.
Great significance low impact. Rusted old shoes by the Danube. If you walk by it fine but no need to make a detour to see it. However, it is of high historical significance

A tragic reminder amongst the hustle and bustle of riverside Budapest. What a moving memorial , so simple but thought provoking. what a pity some visitors felt the need to pose amongst them for a photo shot.

Very moving reminder of some of the horrific events of WWII. Near the Chain bridge and just down from Parliament -- easy to spot because there are people gathered in this small area of the walk -- or at least there were on the several occasions we passed by. Powerful exhibit.

Very emotional. Very emotional monument in the name of Hungarian Jews shot and killed on the Danube bank, definitely worth seeing considering it's free and on the scenic promenade. We came here after a trip to Vaci street - public transport makes visiting easy.

Sad. A simple memorial to thousands of Jewish people who were lined up and shot then pushed into the river. It's a shame that some people seem to have deposited rubbish inside the shoes. Worth a visit though.
Sad sight. Remember all the Jews that got killed by the Germans, their shoes are there as a reminder of how not do it.

History of atrocities. Very important piece of history,sadly there was no information given about Hungary's role in the extermination of Jewish families during WW2. There could be more accountability here, at least a plaque describing how men, women and children were shot, here, and pushed into the Danube.

Wvwpery moving.. It's amazing that something so simple can be so moving and meaningful. Well worth finding. Reminds one of the awful past that Budapest has gone through and a history that must not be forgotten.

Very touching experience. A simple yet powerful image of the cruelty of war. The reproduction of shoes of Jews removed and left along the banks of the Danube before execution is a stunning example of how a simple image can evoke emotions and feelings - which is what art is supposed to do. Simply stunning.

fantastic memorial, high impact. This memorial is to pay respect to the Hungarian Jews who were bought here to be killed during the second world war. We spoke to a man there who told us that the Nazi's would bring people of Jewish faith here and tell them to remove their shoes before pushing them in or shooting them in the back of the head and letting them fall in the river. The shoes are there in memory of them and the horrific acts that took place. Its just a bit further down the river front on the right hand side of the parliament (as you look at the front of it). It it well worth going to see and remember.

Not to be missed. These are a peace of history that should be seen ..they are on the edge of the Danube just between parliament buildings and the chain bridge..costs nothing to see..and makes u think of what people went through

A sad reminder of the 1944-45 events.. Simple memorial to the suffering of Jewish people in Budapest during WW2. The shoes and the small caption are evocative enough and do not need further explanations.
Amazing find. Amazing find, it's next to the parliament building down by the river, incase you were wondering. It's such a sad but powerful remembrance for the people that went to war.

Strong impact of me. This is the memorial for the hungarian jews who died during the second WW. Of course nowadays is mainly tourist attraction. But it symbolises people who were murdered and thrown to the river. And only the shoes left. With this thought in your mind I thing u can have the same weird feeling as I had there. It is also very photogenic place
Simple but powerful memorial. This is a simple but yet powerful monument. Hauntingly beautiful. I could totally imagine the scene when the cruelty took place.
Touching memorial. This place is where many Jewish people were shot during ww2. Before being shot, they'd have to remove their shoes. Another sad chapter of human history.
Great piece of art, sad story behind it. Brilliant piece of art, only a short walk from the parliament building. People seem to leave flowers in the shoes as a tribute
Amazing tribute. Well worth a visit. On the banks of the Danube this is a very thought provoking memorial. Not sure if unique but takes you back to the bad old days.

The power of street art!. Everyone should visit this place multiple times when visiting Budapest. Not only its a brilliant piece of a street art but it shows in a drastic manner how cruel nazi germans were. Dont hesitate to bring a flower to honour the victims.

An interesting bit of history. We saw this on our walking tour, it's a great tribute to the history of Budapest and it is worth seeing. I would read up on the history before having a look just to get your head around what happened. It's right next to parliament so easy to get to
The past can be so cruel . Easy to locate by the river opposite the parliament building. A time to sit and contemplate what others went through, but why?

A memorial site to remember. Very simple, but touching. A place next to the Parliament house, easy access to, and worth the walk. Since all by the river, it may not fit for young kids who run around for safety reason.
An important memorial of the jewish victims. An imprtant memorial. Illustrate deeply the brutaliry and cruelty acts of Nazi's and fascist. We will never forget

Melancholy !. Don't visit this place of you are deeply affected by things as this place will haunt you with the story behind it. It is a small walk on the promenade with some shoes but it conveys so much.

A special monument to Holocaust victims. Original monument most realistically illustrates the horrors of war
I wish there was a convenient place to stop near the monument
A disgrace that any references to identify the victims is missing

A must see. This monument is to 60 men, women and children, who were dragged from their homes, marched down to the Danube River, near the Parliament Building. And the reason was because they were Jewish. So sad and not to be forgotten.
Nothing interesting. Don't waste your time looking for this. It's right next to the parliament on the river side. Just pass them on your way to another site.

Touching place by the Danube. We wanted to visit this place after visiting the Holocaust Memorial Center and it was just touching to see all small shoes filled with flowers and candles. Imagining all horrid things happened ~70 years ago...
Easy place to visit just by the parliament house, watch the traffic!
A sad remembrance to a past gone era.. A memorial you should take the time to visit. By the river, makes to wonder how much sadness and pain innocent people went through.
Sad. Was walking alongside the danube. Came across this. It was really sad. At first i thought it was the people who left budapest but then i realised what it was
Great monument to see. Very simple but effective monument to commemorate Jewish victims. You need to read the history about this

Incredibly Moving. During the 2nd World War, some of Budapest's Jews were taken to the river's edge, made to strip and were executed, their bodies falling into the Danube.
Before visiting this moving and heartbreaking memorial, please read up on what occurred there. It was incredibly disturbing to see people mocking and taking inappropriate pictures.

Poignant. Such a simple and affecting idea to commemorate the Jewish victims of the Arrow Cross in this way. Stark and in great contrast to the beautiful view of the Danube and Buda hills. Very moving.

Haunting. Beautiful way to remember the awful treatment of the Jewish people. Has a haunting quality about it.
Would recommend reading the history behind the monument before attending as there is no signpost to explain.
Must see. Impressive monument by the Danube. Just a little down from the parliament . A bit difficult to find.

Strikingly different memorial. Sometimes less can be more. That is the case here, where shoes on the waterfront are the entire memorial. You can't help but stand there and put yourself in the, umm, shoes of the victims. That is the point, of course.

Powerful memorial. Such a sad and powerful memorial dedicated to the Jews instructed to take their shoes off before they were shot into the river during WWII.
It's right by the Danube river bank near the Parliament and a beautiful walk along the river.
Impressive. Impressive monument at the side of the Danube river. Leaves a lot open for you own imagination. And a nice spot if you like to do some photography.

Outstanding dramatization. Simple iron shoes in the style of riveted on the riverside, where the Hungarian Nazis kiled and dumped to the river those Jews for whom nor the time, nether trains were available to send them to Germany. The artist, who created this monument has achieved an outstanding dramatization of the touching circumstances. It is a must to visit, who want to remember. It is a big shame, that lately some of the shoes are vandalized and/or missing.It seems that the Hungarians did not learn the consequences of the war.
Poignant. It's so hard to believe the kind of cruelty and disregard for human life this memorial represents. It's easy to find along the river near the Parliament building.
Poignant. Go for a stroll around the river in front of the Parliament and you will come across metal shoes as a memorial to those Jews who got shot along the Danube. Very touching.

Simple But Poignant. Blink and you'll miss it. That's because the Shoes on the Danube Memorial is so small and simple and it is this which make it so effective. Dedicated to the victims of Jews shot into the Danube by the fascists during WW2, its is very moving. Every visitor to Budapest should stop by this memorial and pay their respects for those who were murdered.
nice wiew. This place is quite close to Parlament just a few steps and you cn také a nice pictures with this iron shoes, parlament, Dunai river or Buda castle from there.

Poignant !. The best way to see Budapest is on foot and if you walk the Danube (pest side) between chain bridge and Margaret island you will find this memorial (near Parliament) ... simple yet incredibly powerful.
Must visit. Very emotional place, very touching .. We must know the history .. Almost 30% of Budapest before the holocaust were Jews whom build the city.. Very sad

Must see in Budapest. Most of the people were searching for its location, just across the parliament building, on the river side. Having known the story behind it and seeing the kids shoes on the shore is pretty upsetting.
Somber reminder. It was a powerful display and account of more Jewish lives that were lost to the Nazi party. It is not difficult to find as you walk along the river bank.
Historic and interesting . This is just something that's worth seeing due to its historic story. Only a small strip to see but interesting yet also sad.

Hungarian history on Danube bank. Hi viewers!
Danube banks are undoubtedly awesome place to visit. witness and enjoy the sunset here and if you are a history lover then you can visit promenade memorial free of cost on your walks on Danube banks from chain bridge to Parliament.

Beautiful Danube Promenade. The Danube Promenade is really beautiful. Get down at the Kossuth Lajos ter Metro Station on M2 line, which is just one station away from the main Deák Ferenc tér Main Metro Station. Can walk to Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial in 10 minutes. One could see the Parliament Building too.It's nice to get on Tram number 2 from opposite the Parliament. This does a scenic journey along the Danube Promenade. One can take good pictures of the Buda Castle, the Chain Bridge, etc
Moving. This was a very moving tribute to victims of the war.Make sure you go to see this, it will bring you undone.
its okay. its just a monument, look at it for max 5 minutes and continue no big attraction. a plaque with information would have been nice

A touching monument to a sad event. Seeing the empty shoes emphasized the humanity of the lives that were unjustly taken at this site. I hope that seeing memorials such as this will inspire humanity to cease from senseless slaughter of fellow human beings.
Another Reminder. If you critisize you are anti-semetic. I was surprise at how little the visits were to the 'monument' on the banks of the Danube. Makes one wonder
Moving tribute. Make sure you read the story behind the shoes. It is a very moving tribute to those who were murdered on the banks of the Danube. Well done.

Understated but powerful.... One of the most beautiful and heartbreaking memorials I've seen to date... simple yet incredibly powerful. Not on many tourist maps, you simply have to walk the Danube (pest side) between chain bridge and Margaret island to find it, not far from Parliament.

Moving. The shoes on the path next to the Danube were very moving. I took some photos and now when I look back at them, the most poignant one is the picture of a single shoe. It is a Holocaust memorial, representing the Jewish people who had to remove their shoes and coats before being shot and their bodies tossed into the Danube. Their shoes and coats were then given to other people. The monument is simple but effective.

More than shoes. This memorial is simple but means a lot. Many of the jews that were murder stood at the dock and were forced to take their shoes off before being shot into the Danube River. This is a truly moving memorial. At the memorial I saw a pair of shoes that looked like a homeless person left it there. I thought that was very disrespectful. I hope when you arrive they will be gone. This is a must see site in Budapest. Enjoy your time in Budapest. If you thought this was helpful please like.

Moving Memorial. When we first came across this Holocaust memorial along the banks of the Danube, we thought it was poignant but didn't know what exactly it meant. Since learning it was for victims senselessly shot and dumped into the river, the memorial became doubly moving. I highly recommend a walk along the Buda side of the Danube anyway, so be sure to stop here on your walk and leave a stone or flower to remember the Hungarian Holocaust victims.

Interesting historical landmark. This place is remarkable yet so easy to miss due to the low key display and lack of crowds. The historical element of it makes it both wonderful and sad to see. Don't expect anything grand or over the top as this is simply a memorial for the Jews that were murdered. Would highly recommend to anyone visiting Budapest.
Shocking and breathtaking. I can't even try to imagine the events that happened there. Impossible to stand there without a waste of emotion especially at night with the candles lit.

An exceptional memorial. Memorials are so often boring and/pathetic. However, I find this one outstandingly original and moving reminding visitors or people just walking by to the horrendous murder of hundreds Budapest Jews by local fascist gangsters. It has been conceived in a kindred spirit with a painting by Margit Anna.
Moving. Walked a long way to see this and it was worth it. Such a simple concept that captures the moving story of these poor people.

Eerie and reflective.. Visiting here on a hot summer’s day still brought a chill. To see the preserved shoes, some of who were children's, and to know the history behind them really makes you wonder and reflect on what happened, and how we need to prevent this from happening again. Read up on the history of this before visiting, it adds to its meaningfulness.

Really impressive reminder. This reminder of WWII definitely gives you the chills once you know the story behind it. It stretches out for about 40 meters and its basically shoes cast in iron standing at the edge of the water. It is a reminder of the jews who where told to stand there, take of their shoes and step besides them before they were shot in cold blood and would fall in the river.
Simple but touching. It is designed very simples with shoes along the bank. But it could make you emotional when remembering about the tragic history.

Emotionally compelling. If you're looking for something to humanise some of the inhumanities that took place in our history - this is an emotional place to start. The story is compelling, and the visuals are simple but gripping. A lovely, sombre place to visit.

City break . What can I say very moving
Read your history before hand do you understand the meaning behind this memorial. To think that because of their belief they were shot in the back and have no grave as washed away
Favourite memorial in Budapest. Easy to find on the river a few minutes from Parliament buildings. Very simple and emotive memorial. Read up beforehand as there as little information at the memorial.

Moving. We wasn't sure what to expect but it was very moving to see the shoes on the side of the river.
The small child's pair of shoes was especially poignant.

Memorable.. You can read about these in many places such as in books or the internet, but it is not until you actually visit and see the shoes next to the flowing river, that you can actually get a sense of how the poor victims could of felt at the time- may visitors have a quiet reflection here at anytime of the day or night.

Simple, moving Memorial. On a sunny day jammed with tourists it's hard to believe that many Jews were executed and thrown in the river directly in front of the Parliament. Definitely worth a stop and a reflection on events not that long ago.
Smaller than expected. There are much better and more interesting things to see in this lovely city. Just take it in as you stroll along the embankment alongside the River Danube.

In memory of those shot by the river . A memorial made to honor the lives of Jews and others labeled as "different" by the nazis. Shoes of the lost lives that were shot and thrown into the Danube river.
SAD. It was sad to see the memorial to the Jews killed in World War II. The memorial is very simple, yet conveys the heartbreak and loss of the victims and their families.
Sad Reminder of a Horrific Period. We just drove slowly by the shoes on the promenade as our tour guide told us the very sad story. A somber reminder of inhuman acts.
Unexpected. While using our free time to explore the area around the Parliament building we walked back to our ship passing this memorial. It was very sad and very disturbing.

Poignant memorial. Very simple but poignant memorial to the Jews shot and dropped into the Danube a mere 2 weeks before Budapest was liberated after WWII. Especially chilling is the little shoes belonging to a small child. Hard to imagine such atrocities happened.
A fitting reminder.. These shoes provide a poignant reminder of lives lost and the evil that men do to one another. Hopefully it helps remind visitors of the futility of evil.

Stunningly simple and somber. A visitor could easily pass this memorial by, missing it totally. It's not a big statue or a monument, it's just shoes... shoes of those who lost their lives during Hitler's WWII vendetta against the jews. You can feel the spirit of sacrifice here; it's humbling and sacred, even with the distractions around you. Best to visit this place in the early morning.

Powerful Tribute. This is so incredibly understated and so incredibly powerful. What an incredible tribute to those Jews who died at the hands of the Nazis near the end of World War II. It is quite moving and something you cannot easily walk away from quickly. It really makes you think.

Beautiful, humbling reminder. This is a very beautiful tribute and a very sad reminder about the awful events like many in that era. Can get really crowded with everyone walking all over everything for the perfect photo or "selfie", so if you're visiting these sepcifically, go early in the morning. Only point off was for the lack of maintenance of the project, these should be kept simple and rubbish free.

Sad and powerful image - worth a visit!. When walking near Parliament take a trip down to the river Danube and just remember the terrible things that took place in history and value your own freedom to walk around such a beautiful city.

Moving Reminder of the tragedy, but nor a must. This memorial is a moving tribute to those who lost their lives. I am sure to family members affected this is a 5 star stop, but for everyone else it is just another memorial. The Great Synagogue is the must stop for this experience. This Memorial is on the river front between Parliment and the Chain Link Bridge. It is a lovely walk at night - many couples in various forms of embrace and you can see this memorial on your way - but there are other things to do and see first.

Very nice and atypical. It's a very good way of representing the things happening there in the past and very mobilizing to see this shoes there. They seem very real and the Danube just at the side gives them even more this nostalgic appearance. Really liked them.

Shocking, sad. Shocking view of the shoes, a monument dedicated to the jews that were brought in from . of the Danube and shots by the nazis. It is a sad remembrance of the horrors committed during World War II. We should pray that the world will not have to face such atrocities again.
Must-See in Budapest. A evocative, moving memorial, not to be missed. Be sure to read a little about the period and events in Budapest prior to visiting.
Sad. The story about this was sad. We passed it as I was on a tour bus but I walked down to it to see up close. read up on the story behind it.

Shoes on the Danube. It is not easy to miss this striking social but cultural statement on the shore of the great river Danube that reminds its citizens and visitors about the complex and difficult Hungarian history and suffering. The shoes on the shore are a reminder of the loss of people who have lost their lives.
Shoes. That was truly a sad thing to see. Bless them for remembering them. Something interesting to see in Budapest
Poignant and moving.. The shoes on the Danube near the parliament building serve as a reminder of the dreadful atrocities Hungarian Jews experienced during the war. Worth a visit so we never forget.

Very moving exhibit . You need to know the back story of this exhibit to fully feel the impact. This exhibit is quite moving once you do.
I recommend it.

Heart-wrenching. Remember. Never forget. These were people just like you, with hopes and dreams, and children to protect. Murderers with hate in their hearts put a cruel end to the people who stepped out of their shoes to drown in the river.
A very moving memorial . This is a very simple but moving memorial to the victims of the Arrow Cross who were murdered here. You should also visit the Holocaust Memorial at the Great Synagogue.

very special memorial site. The site is Relatively new and located on the banks of the Danube on the Pest, approximately 300 meters south of the parliament.
the site is in memory of the many Jews who were Killed at the banks of the Danube During the Second World War By Nazis and members of the Party of the Hungarian Silver Arrow.
Heartbreaking but Effective. This exhibit is so real and displays the horrors that Jewish people endured in the second world war. A very touching memorial.

Very moving. This is perhaps smallest monument in Budapest, but it together with the Parliament building and St. Stephen's basilica were my top 3 attractions in Budapest.
It is the situation where very simple idea (shoes on the riverbank) can convey complex emotions. Sit at the bench, look at the river and boats passing by and reflect.
Poignant . I stumbled across this memorial when visiting in October and made sure to return on this visit. A simple, moving tribute.
Sad reflecting.. Very sad to think about the reason why the shoes are at the side of the river but it is a must just to pay your respects.

Very moving an amazing memorial . An amazing memorial to visit and learn about what happened in the year 1944 with the nazi occupation of Hungary and how they tried to kill all the Hungarian Jews. There were many heroes who tried to help save them. Unfortunately not all were saved and many were lined up and told to remove their shoes and shot right into the river. If you are in Budapest a MUST SEE

Put yourself in their shoes. This sits on the bank of the Danube, immediately in front of the Hungarian Parliament. There are shoes of men, women and children. You must stop, look and imagine yourself in their shoes. Terrorism is something we all fear. This is a memorial to those brutally murdered at the hands of terrorists in 1944/5.
Moving historical must see. A must see after the parliament building.Along the banks of the Danube it can be part of your walking tour.

A Poignant Reminder. Any visit to the Hungarian Parliament should also include the short stroll to the Danube promenade to see these shoes, cast in bronze, and which symbolise, and are a memorial to, the victims of a wartime regime which saw to the brutal execution of so many innocent men, women and children.Upon this spot many were lined up and shot, their bodies falling or thrown into the Danube. Such are the atrocities of which human kind is capable and which we, the citizens of today, have a duty to ensure that nothing of such dreadful enormity should ever happen again.This is a place for quiet contemplation and reflection.
a must see as a memorial!. Definitely worth seeing. It's interesting to know about the history behind this memorial and definitely observe the fine details of each pair of shoes! Surreal!

A simple and wonderful tribute. The shoes are along the bank of the Danube. They were taken from Jews prior to being sent to the camps. The shoes are preserved in bronze and a stark reminder of what happened in World War 2. It is a simple but very moving memorial.
A place to see. Place you have to see when you are walking along the Donau. A moment of silence. Also our kids were interested to see.
Very Moving. Our cruise ship just happened to be docked just next to this memorial, so we didn't have to travel far. A very moving tribute.
Small but striking memorial.. This was really moving to see in person. The artist truly captured the absence of those taken during the holocaust.

Beautiful memorial. This memorial is not the easiest to get to but once you're there it is wonderful. I didn't realise how detailed and interesting it would be and it makes a wonderful memorial. I took several photographs here, which are now framed and make an interesting piece on the wall.
Very moving. Simple and powerful. This is close to the Parliament and well worth a visit. Of all the Holocaust memorials I have visited, this was the most moving.
Memorial. These 60 pairs of shoes made by sculptors made in memory of holocaust victims,this is near the Parliament building.
Worth the time to see. We came by car, but this didn't seem easy to access. Regardless, it is worth seeing and remembering those who are represented. Quite touching.
It's just a few shoes on the side of the river.. I'll be honest, I didn't really research this one, but we happened to be walking along the Danube and saw a few pairs of shoes sitting on the cement.

Sad. . Definitely worth a visit to see what the Hungarians did to innocent people, mostly Jews, who were lined up, chained, and shot. Most of the time only the largest person was shot which caused all the others to drown too as they were chained together.

Provocative and beautiful . This was an unexpected find for me when I was walking along the river, and I was very touched by the scene. These shoes of all sizes and styles, provoke a feeling of deep sadness and also beauty as they sit peacefully. Bless the many who fell here.

Touching . The story of these shoes is touching and you do experience deep feelings when you visit here. It is easier to walk to this point as the car would have to park a bit far anyway. There is no parking right next to the shoes. Highly recommended when visiting Budapest

Powerful Memorial. This is a powerful reminder of the Jewish community and others who were shot and dumped into the Danube during WWII. It is hard to imagine that each pair of shoes represents an individual.

Poignant monument. A very touching and poignant monument to the Jewish men and women who were made to strip and remove their clothes and shoes before being shot and thrown into the Danube. Could perhaps benefit from a more visible plaque to explain the purpose of the row of iron shoes left along the bank of the river as I'm sure many people pass by without knowing what they represent.
Eye Opening. A walk along the Danube about 10 minutes from the Intercontinental Hotel and you will see this Memorial. Very emotional to say the least.
A perfect bit of history. A definite place to visit when in Budapest and was very moving. It wont take long either, so make time for this.
Must see. The shoes on the Danube are a tribute to the Jews who could not escape. It's an installation and it is truly moving. The symbolism is a bit somber but also a reminder of the human tragedy.

Moving and humbling experience. I would not regard myself as an emotional person but seeing the shoes and thinking about what they represent brought a lump to my throat. The shoes are a poignant reminder of how easily ordinary people can be led by politically motivated rhetoric to either commit heinous acts or worse stand by and do nothing to stop the commission of these acts. You listen to today's politicians, Trump in the US and the rise in popularity on the European "national" parties and you hear the same fascist rhetoric about Muslims. Perhaps Mr Trump should pay a visit to the shoes.

Poignant reminder. This somewhat eerie monument just south of the Parliament marks the 1944–45 period when the Fascist Hungarian Arrow Cross militiamen rounded up mainly Jews and took them to the edge of the Danube. Here they were made to take off their shoes before being shot into the water. Their shoes were all that was left behind on the bank.My Tip: Follow the river south from the Hungarian Parliament for about 300/400 metres. The shoes are right on the river’s edge.
Following the steps!. As you walk near the river you will notice in a quite close distance these shoes,put there to honour all the Nazi victims.

Interesting. Very effective little memorial located at the bank of the Danube river, not far from the Parliament building.Especially moving in the night, when some of the shoes have little candles lighting inside them.

Simple and effective. This is one of the most effective simple monuments on the world. Congratulations to the artists. Bronze shoes are fixed on the left bank near the parliament. They represent old, big, small, women and children men. This is memory of and for the people. Some more maintenance can change this place to perfect.
Moving tribute. After visiting the Museum of Terror, you'll have a better understanding of this moving tribute to the Hungarian Jews.
A Lovely Tribute . A lovely monument to honour the memory of those who died during the war. You can visit just before it after your parliament tour.

Moving reminder of dark history. Along the Danube, not far from Parliament House you can find this striking monument to the victims of Naziism. These shoes represent the people executed and thrown into the river during the war. It's a moving tribute and stark reminder of the tragedy and horror of this period in history.

Moving. This is a very poignant place and worth a visit on the side of the Danube, not far from the parliament.
If you get chance read up why they are there as I feel it helps when you see them

Lovely little memorial. I had planned to visit before we'd even arrived in Budapest. It was very easy to find but I expected a little more not too sure what. It is a lovely memorial and defiantly worth visiting.
Sad place. The place located at the Danube river, remembering the Jews murdered by the silver cross party. The deference between the lone shoes and the landscape is stunning.

Pit stop.. If you're headed for the parliament, make sure to stop by here. Having a background into the history of the city however, is crucial for understanding and appreciating the displayed memorial. Take some time to sit back and travel back in time.
Heart breaking visit, a must memory. An unforgettable site in the memory of the jews murdered here during the holocaust and their bodies were dumped into the Danube. Heart breaking

During the tour. It was on our way. I think we wouldn't make a de-tour. Statues never made much impression on me.
This one is touchy. It reminds of the pain and terror the jews had been through. We stopped for a couple of minutes, we were just sitting on the bench and be quiet.
Nice walking by the Danube.

Sad story but not many people cares . Located not far from Parliament, just across the street (direction to the river) and walk +/- 150m.
The monument seems not really maintained because I saw some candy plastics inside few shoes. Very sad.
Come here in the morning or afternoon to take beautiful photos and enjoy the view Buda side from here.

Massive impact. I have seen memorials in some form all over the world. I don't believe any have hit me as hard in such a simple way. I'm not a history buff yet to see this almost puts you at that point in time in a virtually tangible way. It's quite upsetting but with a poignancy that makes the upset necessary

Moving. Simple and effective in making sure we never forget. 60 pairs of shoes represent 600,000 Jews who were killed in WWII. Not well publicised. On the bank of the Danube between the Parliament and the Chain bridge.
Vacation . A powerful memorial. Easy to find or you can view it from tram 2 as it winds it way down the river. A must see if you are in Budapest.

Something you must see . I hadn't heard of this before, but after a litte research before going, it was obvious it was a must. It was so touching to see, especially as some of the shoes were surrounded by flowers and candles, showing that they were remembered. Definitely something you have to see!

Moving and thought provoking. We just happened upon this Memorial on our first evening in Budapest, taking a stroll along the Danube. It was very thought provoking and definitely an impact. These are the type of memorials that cause people to stop, ponder and understand. It refers to the location where many Hungarian Jews were marched and ordered to jump into the river to their death by the Hungarian government. The shoes are in a state of looking like their owners just stepped out of them, men, women, children... you can feel the emptiness of them.
Vivid reminder of a sadder time.. Very moving memorial to the Jews who were stripped of their clothes and shot on this section of the river bank by the retreating German army toward the end of WW2.
Simple yet amazing. This is art at its best. Really heartbreaking to consider all the people killed without a trial during WW2. Would you have stood up to protest?
Very Compelling. A disturbing display that hits home. The children's shoes show how brutal the regime was during WW2 and the atrocities.

Touching memorial. Budapest has not forgotten the citizens lost during the Second World War. a touching tribute to this loss....understated and heartbreaking. In this time of renewed hatred, it is worth looking back at what can result from this awful attitude.
Moving. I saw this late at night, and people had lit candles and put flowers in and around the shoes. This added to the poignancy of the memorial.
Incredible. We went at night and found it incredible. The meaning behind the shoes was truly exceptional. Highly recommend when visiting Budapest.

Confronting and very poignant memorial but a must see. This is a memorial to Jews who in WW2 were taken to the banks of the Danube, told to take off their shoes, were then shot and they fell into the Danube. Shocking, confronting, but a must see and easy to combine with a visit to the Parliament as very close by. A place to reflect....

Tribute !!. Sixty pairs of old-fashioned shoes o0n the banks of the Danube River in Budapest. There are women's shoes, men's shoes and children's shoes. These shoes on the edge of water, scattered and abandoned, as though their owners had just stepped out of them and left them there.Reminding the history .... And Make one realise never ever "such crime to Humanity"

Lovely tribute. This beautiful little art exhibition is free and marks a spot where Hungarian Jews were shot and killed during the Second World War. Each sculpture - of shoes from the era - is beautifully crafted. However, people put candles and flowers etc. as their own tribute into each, and it really makes a mess of the art. I understand people's desire to also show their homage to the victims, but it really creates a mess of what is otherwise very moving.
Must see. This is a place you must visit...nice activity outdoors. Interesting story that makes you sad but excited.
simplest memorial, too big in meaning. Just go and sit at the riverbank. Think how this happened. It is not possible to be not effected from such a simple memorial.
Right next to the Parliament. You can include this into the day trip to the Parliament because it's just 5 minutes walk. There aren't any information board though so I was a bit disappointed
