Interesting to know the history. First time we saw that place were confused about the signification. Later, reading the history of that place we dicovered that Shoe promenade is related with Jewish drama, during second World War.

A poignant and moving tribute. My wife and I and another couple stopped at the Shoes on the Danube Memorial at the conclusion of our Viking River Cruise. It was a poignant and moving tribute. It created a moving and memorable experience for us.

Go, if you are up to it. It's difficult to imagine, let alone comprehend, something as monstrous as shooting people into the river. We considered these shoes and boots a "must visit", but we did not have children with us. They need to be of a certain age to be able to digest it properly, maybe helped by their parents..

Deep Meaning. The bronze art sculptured shoes at the edge of the cement embankment can bring tears to my eyes to recall what it is about. Very simple, with so much unsaid; A very meaningful memorial to those that were murdered at the hands of the Nazis and their Hungarian allies near the end of WWII; The Jewish people were gathered, Men, Women and Children and told to remove their shoes. They were standing right where the bronze shoes are now, when they were shot and fell dead into the Danube.

Danube Promenade Memorial. Its very simplicity and starkness make it extremely powerful and moving. Here less is much much more. Of particular importance, it singles out the Hungarian Arrow Cross, as the perpetrators of this atrocity, instead of conveniently blaming the Germans for it.

Trip hazard.. A strange memorial to the poor sods executed and dumped into the danube. Not the usual epitaph.
Will mankind ever learn?

More Than Just Shoes. As you stroll along the Danube in Budapest, your eyes will come to a memorial so simple, yet so stark. Shoes, of every size and description appropriate for wear in the 1940s. The shoes are metal replicas of those worn by Jews shot by Nazis leaving the area in haste, but not before they killed thousands and tossed their bodies into the river at this spot. No signs I could see to mark the site. Blown away by the contrast between the beauty at the location and the terror of that time.

Sadness. The story behind the shoes is heartbreaking ..... The Jewish people have perished in all forms, but this tribute that you can actually experience is heart wrenching. Everyday that I visited new flowers and candles were there. A must see. I placed my feet around the shoes for an unforgettable photo shot...... Do not miss this site
Simple yet moving.. Stopped on our way past and reflected for a few minutes. It just reminds you in a very simple way how lucky you are.

Simple, but poignant reminder of the suffering during/after wars. Simple, but poignant reminder of the suffering during/after wars.We only drove by, but when you she the display, it is a reminder of what we/most people take for granted.

Simple but moving memorial. It's difficult to rate this as an "attraction" as it's really a very simple "sculptural memorial" to Jewish people who were killed by the river. There are one hundred metal shoes of various sizes including children's "shoes". There were a number of people there when we arrived all of whom were standing silently taking pictures or bending down to look. There were two plaques at either end, one in English, the other in Hungarian, indicating that this was a memorial to Budapest Jews killed by the Arrow Cross militiamen. It was very moving just to stand there, looking at the shoes and imagining the horror of the plight of victims who had stood there some 72 years ago.
Visually excellent and moving. We wandered down to the embankment and saw the shoes. Very moving tribute to the brave men, women and children killed in the war.

Memorial to Budapest's sad history. Terribly poignant to witness these shoes of Jews who were shot and dumped in the river during WW2. Many are of children and women, innocents killed for no reason. There are flowers placed in some of these shoes and I found it incredibly sad to sit by the river and reflect on what happened here.

Budapest Shoes. The bronze shoes represent the lives of Budapest Jews killed by the militia during the war. They were killed here to fall in the water so the militia wouldn't have to bury them. This is a very moving memorial and shouldn't be missed.
Went at night, a sight to visit while in Budapest. A nice stroll on the boardwalk to see this sight in front of the Parliament building. Nice during the day or at night with the lights of the city.
Worth the visit. It is shoes on the Danube....a tribute / remembrance to the Jews that got shot by militiamen during WW2 era, quite sad story to it, but worth the visit to see this

Emotional stop. The shoes on the Danube is located between two bridges where the people were asked to remove their shoes before they were killed and fall into the river. It is very emotional just thinking what these people went through and how significant it is to see all the shoes lined up. The majority of people only spent a few minutes looking and taking pictures but you could see everybody was affected by the image. Worth a visit as it reminds you of the history of the country during the war.
very poignant. Not shown on the tourist maps. Close to the parliament. Very thought provoking. On the edge of the river with no explanation needed or given.
Very nice. This is a memorial to the Budapest Jews who were shot by Arrow Cross militiamen between 1944 and 1945. This is a must see location.
Walking . Just when u walk from parliament building to chain bridge it is on the way... metal is shoe memory along danube

The evil of man. Poignant, brought tears to my eyes. One can see that some of the victims here were children no more than a couple of months old...ladies and men. All exterminated for no reason whatever. The Hungarian Government should do more to respect and preserve thsee shoes and place as a reminder of human incivility and wickedness. The place should be fenced off and proper memorial erected, preferable a baby and child as a monument, not the plague on the gravel placed in 2005, open to abuse...people walking over it and generally derespecting the memories of the innocent victims.
Very moving. I had not heard of this, and was very moved by the story behind this display. We just happened across this while walking along the river.

They're Shoes!. I know it's probably looked down upon to say this, but they're just shoes! I understand that this has a rich, cultural history that we should learn from, but it's not like there is a huge exhibit explaining the history of that part of history next to the shoes. If it did, and if it was informative and interesting enough, I'd give higher marks for this attraction.If you're at the Parliament building anyways, and you've got time to spare, you might as well walk around to this. But don't be fooled, they are just shoes after all!Okay, my review might be slightly biased as I love studying that part of history and have visited so many other places that do explain a lot more, including sites and museums you could spend a whole day in. Also, it was pouring and it was at the end of a gloomy, rainy day in the middle of summer!

Moving Memorial . This monument is over 100 shoes, of all different kinds, some very elegant, some work boots, and some belonging to children. The shoes are lying at the side of the Danube about 300 meters from the Parliament building. It is to commemorate those who were shot by the Militia men in 1944/1945 and fell dead into the Danube. Poignant.

Moving monument.... As simple as this memorial to the Jews murdered during the war is, it sends chills about the inhumanity in the world. Even more moving was the recent addition of a real shoe to those in the memorial. That addition made me want to know its story as well.In addition, we recommend visit to Liberty Square and its monument as well.

Heart touching. It is sad for me to think about all the lives unfairly taken away by Nazis in the holocaust. This is a raw memorial and will leave you in tears. I would recommend taking tissues with you. Never forget.

A poignant slice of history. As you walk in front of the impressive parliament building, along the banks of the Danube, you can't miss the metal shoes perilously close to the edge. Upon enquiry you learn that it is to commemorate Jews who were shot by Arrow Cross militiamen during World War 2. As your mind travels back in time trying to imagine the horrific scene, your eyes fall upon the children sized shoes.

very moving. A time to stand and reflect - very poignant. The walk alongside the Danube is definitely worth it - just be careful to get on the right side of the road (the Danube side) as it can be tricky to cross the road otherwise.
Moving. I did not know the full story of this and had to look it up. A moving artwork that is a stark reminder of man's inhumanity to man.
Beautiful memorial. It is a really simple but affective memorial - you can be sat admiring the view on the bank of the Danube and in front of you is a very effective memorial! I love it

Thoughful. Anyone who comes across this must think about how lucky most of us are to live a free life. It is very sad to consider what some people have gone through and it is well worth seeking this out and take time to think.
Very moving. Came across these shoes just by chance walking along the Danube. It made you stop and think about the people who owned them.Very thoughtful moment.

Simple and moving. This memorial to Hungarian victims of the Holocaust is one of the most simplest and moving memorials you will ever see.This is where Jewish prisoners were made to stand naked, facing the river, before being shot in the back so that they fell into the river and were washed away.Some of the shoes contain candles or flowers, presumably left by relatives of those who were murdered here.Please don't miss this place.
Very interesting. What is there to say? It is a good place to remember what has gone on in the world, and how horrifically Jews were treated. Definitely makes you think.
Moving. An extremely moving piece of modern art. Don't miss this. Quite hard to find if your not careful. Look just in front of parliament on the riverside.

A poignant reminder . A poignant reminder of the treatment of Jews in Hungary. Imagining innocent men, women & children being asked to remove their shoes before being shot & their bodies falling in the Danube puts life into perspective. An installation like this hopefully reminds people of how cruel humans can be to one another.

The shoes of sorrow. This is one of the smallest but most moving memorials of the Holocaust- but so so powerful in its simplicity. It's a MUST SEE memorial, as it symbolises the horrors of the Nazi occupation of Budapest ! It's also a grim reminder of all the current atrocities that take place in the world. Powerful !

Realy touchs your humanity and your conscience. Really creative idea that shows some small things can touch your humanity and your conscience. A place where you feel really sad , in front of the Parliament, a memorial for the holocaust. Everyone has to visit. Read the real story behind from internet etc before visiting. Look deeply inside the shoes.

Cool little treat. Not your topical attraction but still a good spot to visit. We made it on a fantastic day so the photo ops were amazing. It might just be a bunch of shoes attached to the ground but the whole scenery is fun. Plus it's only a short walk to parliament building and also Margaret Island.

Interesting perspective of the Holocaust. The events that these shoes signify were horrific, and the memorial is intriguing, but I felt the location on a riverside walkway with lots of traffic took away from the experience.

Always remember . During a trip to Budapest, while standing on the shore of the Danube, and looking over this beautiful river to Buda, it is important to remember that a lot of terror and pain occurred at this location. The shoes on the Danube is a subtle (maybe too subtle) but powerful tribute to the Jews murdered by the Nazis and their bodies tossed in the River. They were forced to take off their shoes before being killed by the Nazis. Always remember. Never again.

It made me weep. My son and I were walking along the Danube watching an air show sponsored by RedBull that was over the Danube. We came upon this across from the Parliament building back end.A young women explained in English the historical significance and as I saw baby shoes, I cried.It's just a little something. But worth many hearts and tears.A must see for history buffs

Moving tribute.. This memorial is one of the most moving scenes I have experienced in regard to the Holocaust. Looking at these shoes of various sizes, for men, women and children, your minds eye can see the scene that must have taken place, though I can't say my brain allowed me to experience how horrific it must have actually been. A must see for those interested in paying tribute to those who lost there lives so senselessly.
Shoes Budapest . Very simple moving monument, close to the Parliament building on the Pest side. Tribute to those who were executed by the Danube.

One of the Most Moving Tributes to Lost Jewish Souls. I think it is the human scale of this small but powerful statement about the Nazi's treatment of Jews during the Holocaust. Budapest's citizens -- men, women and children -- were lined up along the ballestrade and shot. Bronze shoes of every style line the walkway, reminding us all of the terrible sacrifices made during WWII.

It's not an attraction. This shows a very sad moment in the lives of many people, just before being shot to death. It must be reminded as a "NEVER MORE", . The lives of all the races, colours and religion deserve respect.
Sad, sad story..... These shoes are cemented along the edge of the river Danube. True story. The Jews, men, women and children were lined up, asked to remove their shoes, and were shot!!!!

Reality. We'd heard about the Shoes on the Danube and came across them by accident as we walked along The Danube, but they acted as a very harsh reminder of a part of the history of the city that must not be forgotten.

A must see tribute. These shoes are a touching reminder of those who lost their lives so tragically in the holocaust. We stopped to remember on the short walk back from the Parliament to the Chain Bridge and are glad that we did. It is so different.
Thought provoking idea.. Very unusual idea, but I really like the thought. Well done to the sculptor and the city for the creation.
The memorial is so hard. must visit place, just behind the Parliament, a memorial for the holocaust. a place every one need to visit.
Chilling. Very sobering display, makes you think! We stood for a good half an hour in silence. Pity that others couldn't or wouldn't do the same
emotionel monument. the Shoe monument on the Donaupromedade, near the Parlement. At the end of WOII peoples were killed here and they had to take off there shoes.

Sorrowful place . You need to stop here just to remind your self of mans in humanity to man. A sad memory of people killed here but a must stop. Very simple memorial sixty pairs of bronze shoes. The Jewish people were told to take the shoes off before the nazies shot them an dumped them in the river.
Very worth wile. Such a thought provoking, considered and respectful memorial to the victims. Just to sit on the wall opposite for a few minutes and think about the memorial was very worthwhile.
Very moving. Very moving and emotional monument to those who lost their lives during the Holocaust. The array of shoes stops you in your tracks.

Impressive Shoe Monument in Budapest. When you are in Budapest, then pay a visit to the shoe monument. It`s very impressive by it`s simplicity and we simply have to remember the innocent owners of the shoes and their horrible sad fate.

Very eerie, sad and a good wake-up call. Knowing the background of this memorial caused it to be so sad and eerie, especially because we walked there at night. I do highly recommend it though, because it serves as a wake-up call that we all really need to live in peace, and we see just how fragile human life is. To think that this happened in recent history should be shocking, but unfortunately we see so much evil today, and we are reminded that our very existence is a miracle that is renewed daily by the One Above. This memorial is approximately a 10-minute walk from the Chain Bridge, no money required, so it's an "easy" site to visit. Definitely a must-see for all.

Profound Experience. Part of our walking tour through Viking River Cruise. This work of art is a memorial to Jewish citizens of Budapest, victims of the Holocaust. A tribute to those who died and a profound experience for all who visit.
Never forget!. A gut wrenching memorial to the Jews murdered by the arrow cross movement. Located on the Danube by the parliament building

Emotional. We visited the Shoes on the Danube and found it very moving and emotional. The simple display of such a variety of shoe sizes and styles made one think of the ruthless act of brutality which took place at this spot.

Heart wrenching memorial to heart breaking historic events . I found this a very touching memorial. Particularly if you're aware what happened here. Manages to translate the huge drama that is the holocaust to a real up, close and personal, intimate level. Just look at a single pair of shoes and consider what transpired here, not even that long ago...

Sad place.. Sad place. If you are looking for fun, lease don't visit it because you'll spoil your mood. But it definitely is the place that you need to see at least once. It's very close to Parliament. I was walking along the Danube river and passed the shoes, otherwise I'd not go there. It's just too hard to see it. :-(
Jews Were Shot Into the Danube Here. The shoes represent those left behind when, during WWII, jewish residents were lined up along the river and shot. Very very sad and a lovely tribute.
Moving monument. This simple memorial is very moving & dramatically presents the horror of the killing of the Jewish people in the time of WWII.
Sad to see. Visit this free ,spit,some metal shoes which remembers the innocent people who were killed ,made me cry when I saw shoes a child

What a memorial!. This is rated so high primarily because of its significance and its outstanding representation. However, it is barely maintained and of little or no significance in all tours. But if you're in Budapest; this won't take more than a few minutes to visit and is a must see. It is just down the steps from the Hungarian parliament by the banks of the Danube river. So about a 5-6 mins walk from the parliament along the river towards the chain bridge. Carry a candle or flowers if you'd like to leave a prayer or a token of your thoughts in the shoes

Somber and Touching. This memorial is right below the Parliament building on the Danube River . It is so sad to think of these executions. The shoes are very moving and touching. All sizes and all styles, both men, women and children. We must never forget the evil in men. We must always remember that love, community and forgiveness are our better selves.

Extremely moving tribute. To be honest I had no idea that so many Hungarian Jews were killed during the holocaust, 600,000 I learned, with thousands shot on the side of the Danube. A tragic part of our terrible history as a human race. A very simple and moving tribute. A must visit.

Another piece of disturbing history. The concept is special but the act behind it is disturbing. Standing there after having a nice walk on the premonade and understanding what happened there that inspired this exhibition.
Memories. You must go and pay your respects, this is so humbling and reminds us of what we have to be thankful for

Tasteful Memorial on the banks of the Danube. Given Hungary's history in WW II, this is a tasteful and moving memorial to those who lost their lives during the war. Recommend stopping to visit if you are in Budapest.
Moving display. Ideal to visit when you go to see the Parliament buildings, just along the water side. A series of shoes signifying those killed alongside the Danube during the war I believe
Let us never forget.... This monument is incredibly moving. It made me feel as though those poor souls were standing right beside you as you overlooked the Danube.
Beautiful but sad memorial. These shoes are a great commemoration of those who died by being shot into the Danube. It is, of course, very sad, but also extremely poignant.
Poignant viewing. Walking past these shoes placed there in memory of past people, it's timely to remember all those who have suffered in the past.
Inspirational. An Inspirational and somewhat emotional memorial on the banks of the river Danube. I almost missed the shoes that are scattered along the promenade but definitely worth finding.
Must remember. all time, You are here, must remember the thousends of innocenct victims were killed here. Do not let do it again!

This was a truly soulsearching experience. When we searched for this memorial we did not know what to expect. Even today long after the trip to Budapest this memorial keeps coming back to me. Somethong so simple as shoes can get your imagination going about the life of the person who owned the shoes and their last thoughts before being killed. A really dramatic memorial I would really recomend to everybody who visit Budapest.

Very moving and unsettling. . You come upon this dramatic, but simply monument to the Holocaust along the Danube walking path between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament. It's simplicity and touching realism recreates the horror and inhumanity to man that existed during WWII.
Poignant. A must see when in Budapest.A simple walk on the rivers edge between the Parliament Building and Chain Bridge. Very significant monument to the Hungarian people.

Moving testimonial . This is a very moving Holocaust memorial. It is right along the Danube and a very short walk from the Parliament buildings. My only regret is that the Hungarian government has yet to take any responsibility for their part in the murders of the Jews and anti semitism is still evident in Budapest- so sad.
Poignant reminder. Down by the Danube, a reminder of the murder of Jews, shot by the riverside and allowed to fall in and be carried away

Heartfelt monument. Is a very eerie reminder of the jews that lost their lives lost during World War II. About 60 pairs of shoes line the banks of the Danube. I highly recommend going on the Free Jewish Community walk to hear a ton more about the Nazi occupation
Nice walk. If you choose to take a nice walk along the Danube to enjoy the sightseeing of the city, you won't miss this memorial near the parliament.
A sad place. A place with deep and painful history, good to pay respect for the ones who have been suffered. Very close to Parliament and chain bridge

Emotional and touching. Found this memorial by accident as we saw it from the Hop On Hop Off bus.Walk along the promenade to this touching tribute to Holocaust victims who had to take off their shoes before being shot and tossed into the Danube. Brought tears to my eyes.

Budapest anniversary visit. Positioned close to the Parliament Building this is one of those exhibits that will make you think about the attrocities human beings carry out on fellow human beings. I hope this is never removed to ensure we do not forget and repeat the horrors of our past.
A must see in Budapest. This memorial is very important to visit. It is great to acknowledge history and learn from it. It is located right next to the parliament.

A bit of History. I found it to be very appropriate that they are placed within sight of the Parliament. Perhaps it serves to be a reminder for future governments.
Please don't be too disrespectful by climbing all over them to take selfies !
Extremely moving to see . Words don't do justice to the wave of emotions I felt upon first seeing these seemingly non-descript shoes from so many years ago. We MUST NOT FORGET!!
Very moving memorial. This is such a moving, heart breaking memorial. Simple but powerful & would recommend that any visitor to Budapest to go & see it. We must never forget!

Poignant visit. This was one of the memories I wanted to take away from Budapest with me, I was taught about this at school as well as the other atrocities of the holocaust and it as stayed with me. I wanted to pay my respects, but nothing could have prepared me for the overwhelming feeling of sadness that I felt when I seen the monument as a reminder to what happened. I suppose it effects people differently. Although I felt sad I also felt a sense of peace and was extremely happy that I was there. I would say it is more a spiritual place to visit, but that's my opinion.

Sorry to see this memorial in this condition. Budapest is filled with monuments, memorials to heroes, martyrs, saints, mostly in good shape. This one is right on the river, but remote from the city. You have to cross over a couple of lanes of fast-moving traffic to a barren bit of pavement where the shoes seem corroded. Is this a coincidence? Later in our Budapest visit we were alarmed by a shouting band of paramilitary marchers (on October 6 street) demonstrating against gay pride. We also saw a Jobbik rally at City Park: a hundred or so anti-semitic Hungarian nationalists with enormous whips cracking. Fortunately we couldn't understand what they were saying. They were unopposed.

Beautiful to see but a sad story behind these shoes......... A must see especially if you are a History Enthusiast. Situated along the Danube River between the Chains Bridge and Margaret Bridge. Beautifully displayed a piece of history that makes you cry......
Don't miss this!. A very simple but moving memorial to those who perished at the hands of the Nazis during the war. Not uplifting but something that cannot be missed.
Symbolism. A succinct but emotional tribute to the victims of war crimes here. Only a 5 minute walk from the subway line.
Great tribute. A moving and unique tribute to the victims of the Holocaust in a beautiful setting along the banks if the Danube
Very Moving Memorial. 1 in every 10 Jews killed in the holocaust was Hungarian. This is a very moving memorial the 600,000 Hungarian Jews, thousands of whom were shot on the banks of the Danube

Impressive. The row of shoes on the Pest bank of the Danube is all the more impressive as the concept is so simple. One can imagine the Jewish families being forced to take off their shoes on the banks of the Danube on a freezing winter day before they were shot and their bodies fell into the river. The iron shoes are so realistic that you can picture the feet that deformed them. One pair of a small child's boots is particularly evocative of the horror.
Heart wrenching . A memorial for the Jews that were told to remove their shoes before being executed and thrown in the Danube. A powerful place that stirs a lot of emotion.

Simple but emotive. Another must see along the Danube between the Chain Bridge and Parliament. A simple idea but very emotive. Of all the amazing tourist sites this was the first thing that our driver returning us to the airport asked us if we had seen. He obviously felt it was a very important and moving mamorial to those that died. He was nearly in tears as he described how the shoes of those killed were taken and sold.There are many reminders of the suffering that these people have endured in the hands of occupiers and other internal conflicts and this simple tribute and reminder is as effective as any.If you cannot get to see it along the promenade you will see it from a distance when taking a boat trip during the day which really is a MUST DO to get the best view and photos of all the buildings on both sides of the Danube..
Poignent memorial. Simple but effective memorial to the horrific events that occurred here during the second world war. Can be linked in with a visit to Parliament.
Food for thought. A very sobering experience! It is an unassuming monument that speaks loudest in its silence and simplicity
Pure history. Simple but not to be missed... By the river bank just south of the Parliament. It remembers the jews who were thrown to the Danube in 1945

Powerful display of Evil. This is a powerful example of the evil mankind can have for one another and a very important tool in teaching our children and the next generation peace and tolerance. My only negative is that there needs to be some educational signage there to educate he public. If you go, please read up on this display and the events it represents prior to going to the monument. It is a powerful experience and one that I feel everyone worldwide should experience.
Most eloquent memorial on our tour. A very evocative exhibit, but best to go with a guide who can relate the tragedy of Hungarian fascism as well as the Nazis.

Must see . Stunning, heart breaking, but a must see. It's not a tourist attraction, but a reminder of tragedies gone by and how lucky we are to have our freedom now. Puts everything in to perspective.
Powerful Memorial. Do the research and history before you go and then the memorial is so powerful. What a touching tribute to those who died during a difficult time.
Sad memory. Take a walk from the Parliament building to the shore and you will see this sad memorial of the jewish people killed by the Naciz and thrown them into the water. Very realistic...
Beautifully sad tribute to lost lives. The pair of little boy's shoes are heartbreaking. Wonderful to see that to this day people remember (candles and stones are placed on the shoes).

Memory that should not be . It is one amasing way to remember and visualise the Horrible thing that happened once.These shoes made me have tears on my eyes.Go and visit it with a guide who can tell you the story behind.
See on your way. We didn't know what this memorial was for when we saw it, but we guessed right. There is an explanation near the memorial, but we did not see it. I looked it up later.
wonderful unique monument. not like anyother monument, this one is unique and deeply touching. candles, flowers that tourist dedicated makes even deep connection between audience and the work.
Must see!!. Such a simple memorial but so powerful. Very powerful and the baby shoes were hard to look at. Don't miss this as you can easliy walk by it!!
A sad reminder. Many metal shoes as a reminder of the number of Jews killed by the Nazis and thrown into the water. A must see.

realistic shoes. you should check it, it is a memory of jewish people and I think at night it is so realistic like if somebody left his shoes there...and if you read about the story....that is so sad. It is really close to Parlament.

Must do. Walking along the Danube is something everyone needs to do in Budapest. Taking in the sights, walking around Parliament House is just amazing. Seeing the shoes on the Danube is very moving and emotional. Budapest is so full of history, this is a must do.

Thought provoking . Looking across the Danube at the palace and castle it's hard to imagine the turbulent past of Budapest
The shoes in various sizes is a stark reminder that we should pause and remember the past

Quite a Symbol of the Past. Nothing more or less, however the symbol of the abandoned Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial is a very strong reminder of the tragic past when human became less than they should be. One simple sight will stay within one's mind forever.
Very moving memorial. It's a moving thing to do, to take the time to contemplate one of the greatest tragedies of the 20th century through this very fitting public art piece. Really very good.

Almost missed this.. We had just finished a trip with our synagogue to Warsaw, Krakow (Auschwitz and Birkenau), Prague (Therzinstadt) and we didn't see this on the map. Very poor signage and publicity. Also, it didn't mention that these were Jews who were killed. If not for the Hebrew writing, one would think these were just "victims" of Arrow Cross.
Not much to see . I get there is history behind it but in its own right it's a waste of time unless you're already in the area. View of the river is good from here.

Shoes tell a story. A very moving exhibition on the banks of the Danube marking the site where Jewish families were driven from the ghettos in World War Two to the river bank and shot or pushed in to drown. Women's shoes, a child's boots, working shoes, broken shoes and a single shoe.....all bring home the sad loss of human life and the tragedies of war. Each shoe leaves the imprint of a person - someone who had a life.

Simple and poignant. Having read about this memorial I was surprised when I saw it that it was smaller and simpler than I imagined however it is very touching and really makes you really think about what went on and those poor people who suffered.

Moving Memorial. The Shoe Memorial is a beautifully simple, yet extremely personal and powerful testament to the brutal treatment of Hungarian Jews at the hands of the Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944-45. The nearby steps invite visitors to sit and take in the Danube, the memorial and its message.

Most moving. It is very sad to look upon the shoes of the murdered Jewish Hungarians who were pulled from their homes and slaughtered at the banks of the Danube. The shoes of a toddler say it all. Reminds us to remember the murdered and be grateful for what we have.
Simple monument yet it paralizes you.. Worth seeing as you imagine all the pain and suffering and the cruelty that went on for the people of Hungary during this war.

Sad to think of the horrors we humans do to others. The shoes on the Danube is a very moving tribute to the Jews during WW2. You easily think and feel for the millions of Jews and others who were killed during WW2.

Visit in the evening for peaceful reflection. . A unique memorial only a few minutes walk away from the parliament. We enjoyed walking along the river in the evening and stayed a few minutes to reflect on the memorial without so many other people taking pictures.
Simple, elegant, very touching. Loved to hang out there and contemplate the memorial/installation. It's very tasteful, easy to grasp, and on the other hand very mooving.

Emotional and beautiful memorial. This is so far one of the most touching memorial of WWII I have ever since. The representation of the unknown shows at the edge of the Danube is a powerful message to the Mankind saying - We are gone, but we will always have foot on eart.

Quite shocking.... The scene is quite shocking as you wonder how a government was ever able to perform such thing. This place is one of the many things that help explain Hungary's gory past in the hands of the Soviet Union and the Nazis. Nonetheless, I don't consider this place to be extremely important for a person to visit, specially if they lack time. If you happen to be in the area, of course go and take a look, but else wise visit more important places.
Poignant. Very good memorial! Unique, original. And when you look at that pair of baby shoes, you can't help but pause to think about what happened.

A very touching monument. Very strong and shocking way to express the extent of the horror that took place here. At the end of the Second World War, the Hungarians have done what Hitler didn't, and executed 12,000 Jews, men, women and children on the bank of the Danube. Each shoe is expressing the awful in a very lively way.
Moving memorial. The shoes on the Danube is a moving memorial to the Jews killed in Budapest by the local Arrowcross groups.
Somber reminder of the past. Very creative way to commemorate the great loss this city suffered in the last war. Make sure you wander down by the waterfront to find this low-profile monument

Touching. It's hard to believe, and very solemn. This is a great small monument with such a big and much deeper meaning. Standing on the banks of the Danube and seeing the bronze shoes will touch you, take the time to try and look at each one, they will speak to you.

Impressive reminder of the dead.. The pictures and description of this site says it all. Worth visiting in person to feel the impact of so many empty shoes (including child-sized) and what they represent.

Read about it before you go. It is a walking distance from the parliament. To some it would be just iron shoes and opportunity to take pics but when you read about it's historical significance you'll appreciate it better.

This history is enough to bring you to tears. Standing along side of this monument brings quiet to all the people that visit. There is no laughter and smiling selfies, just quiet reflection. Everyone that visits Budapest needs to visit this spot along the Danube.

Thought provoking . Go & See it for yourself. You need to be on the lowest level next to the river. Go down the steps opposite Gresham palace (4 seasons hotel) or past the parliament building and down those steps.

Powerful Reminder. Wow! What a powerful reminder of the tragic reality that this country and its citizens lived through. Seeing Holocaust museums is one thing, but to see shoes just sitting on the shore of the river is a powerful and sobering experience.

A must for anyone with Jewish heritage. What a touching memorial to another sad piece of WW II Jewish history in Budapest. You will meet others from around the world who are paying respects to those exterminated in yet another tragedy. Just up river from the Chain Bridge and easily accesible on foot from the Ritz Carlton Budpest.

Thought-provoking. An understated memorial, one of many important memorials across the city. It's worth reading up a bit on the city's history before visiting to truly understand the importance of this.

Must go, it will give you some perspective.. History of Hungary is quite tragic and this memorial puts in a very direct perspective the frustration and harshness of the war. Go with respect and enjoy some silence.
Sad reminder. If you are visiting the parliament then you only have to walk a few hundred yards to see this. A sad reminder of history and how awful we can be to each other.

Moving and thought provoking . I saw this on the list of places to visit and dismissed it.
We came across it on the way to parliament and now understand why it is a must.
It is one of the most thought provoking, simple, emotional things to experience.

Solo American Girl - Budapest Siteseeing. Admittedly I was not really aware of this attraction when researching things to see in Budapest, I put it on my list of sites, but didn't give it much priority - You have to see this! It takes you back in time to sad history of this river during WW2. It's hauntingly beautiful & moving. I'm so glad I took time to see this! It's such a simple brilliant memorial.
Moving. What a powerful, moving memorial. It is so simple but says so much. Don't miss this, its just beautiful.

A time for remembering.... I challenge anybody with human emotions to pass by this and not be affected by it. The history of why these shoes are here and the message it conveys cannot do anything else but affect you. It is alongside the Danube close to the Parliament building.

Hardly a word was spoken. The sixty pairs of shoes, made of metal, are a very simple but also a very poignant tribute to the murdered Jews in the community - not by Nazis, but by fellow Hungarians. They were shot on the river bank for "convenience", their bodies fell into the river and were washed away. It was a more moving sight than I had expected, and although there were numerous people at the site when we arrived the standout thing to me was the silence - hardly a word being spoken, and if at all only in a whisper. The saddest pair of shoes has to be those that would fit an infant.

Chilling.. To happen upon such a chilling memorial to the murder of innocent children and adults in the late Spring of 1944 - just a short time before WWII came to an end - reminds the tourist of how precious our freedoms are.
Moving experience. When you know the story behind the shoes, it is quite a moving experience to stand on the banks of the Danube and imagine the events that happened on that spot.
Moving. A very moving memorial. Touching and thought provoking. Very simple in the idea but the shoes say so much about the situation
You must see this!. We missed this the last time we were in Budapest. It was #1 on my list of things to see this trip. It is heartbreaking. The story is listed right there near the shoes.

Average emotional manipulation. I still don't understand why jewish assassinations get more coverage than , say, mayas in Mexico, or Hutus in Africa.
Therefore this memorial is for me just "average" and with no interest
Shoe Memorial on the Danube . The 'Shoe's along the river Danube' is easy to miss. Directly under/across from the Parliament building. Not sign posted.

Poignant reminder of the evil in this world. I believe everyone should walk by the shoes and try to learn the history lesson it is trying to convey. I challenge anyone to not tear up when they see the children's shoes
Very moving. Budapest has a strong history with the persecution of the Jews and this is a horrendous tale. Take the time to stop and consider the lives lost in this brutality.
Exciting shoes on the bank. To remember and not forget the holy victims which didn't have chance to live. Exciting memorial bank next to the Parliament

Confronting . An extremely confronting and profound site to visit
We were overwhelmed with emotion
Do not know what else to say
Budapest is a city full of confronting history

Touching art sculptures. I have been to Budapest several times but had never seen the sculptures of the shoes on the Pest side of the Danube river. One has to read about this part of WW2 in Budapest. It's very touching to say the least.
Wonderful monument. A beautiful, thought-provoking monument to Hungarian Jews from WW2. The shoes on the danube are well worth a visit.

Memorial. A very moving memorial to victims of a terrible period in human history. The shoes, all shapes and sizes were once worn by people. One stands and wonders of who they were and what stories their shoes could tell.

Shoes on the Danube. Very powerful memorial.
Everyone should go see it and understand the story behind this memorial.
Unik.
Touching. We found this attraction hard to locate and only came across it by chance on our last day. Touching to see the line of shoes close to the river
A poignant memorial. One cannot escape this when you walk along the pathway of the Danube river. The shoes, its owners and the sad story behind reminds us all of how important freedom is to all.

Touching and sobering memorial. It's hard to imagine how inhuman we can be to each other and the barbaric things that we have done, and continue to do, to each other. Shoes on the Danube is a monument to those who were forced to take off their shoes and then murdered and dumped into the Danube during WWII. Don't miss it.

The soles of lost souls. This understated memorial represents countless Jews murdered in the waning months of Nazi occupation. When it became evident that the Third Reich had lost control in Europe, Jews not sent to Death Camps were lined along the Danube and shot, their bodies summarily tossed into the river. The “shoes” are symbolic. True, those facing firing squads were forced to remove their shoes, but teeth were pulled for the gold fillings. Rings that couldn’t be removed caused fingers to be lopped off, the bodies mutilated—no dignity in death. Located along the Pest side of the Danube, between Chain Bridge and the incredible Parliament palace, these metal shoe replicas also reflect the genius of the sculptor. That person knew that the metal would rust, the patina suggesting the color of old leather. Erected on April 16, 2005 (depicted in the accompanying photo), these “shoes” appear to be of the style and age of the mid-1940s. There is description of what this memorial represents, other than a brief overview. It's necessary to research the symbolism and the atrocities of the Nazis' attempt at Jewish genocide to truly appreciate this memorial.Budapest is filled with outdoor art and sculptures. Take time to reflect on what this sculpture represents, and appreciate the beauty of the artistic representation of something so symbolic.
Sobering. Sobering reminder of the past, but very well executed sculpture. Just a shame it was ruined by a few tourists who didn't realise the significance of the message.
Interesting!. Lovely to walk by and take pictures! It intrigued me a lot and was something different on the river bank
Sad but true. It was sad to see these bronzed shoes but I guess that it is good to remember the terrible things that happened to people during the war.

Moving but lacking in information!. After seeing this on the Internet we were interested to go and see it, however as with most of the historical sights we have visited in Hungary, we came away with no additional knowledge than we came with. I would have expected a little more information than what was on the plaque on the ground. This appears to be a period of history that is difficlt to learn about in Hungary. However the shoes are a moving tribute to those who were killed. It's a must see on your visit to Budapest.
Right next to the parliament. Worth checking if you are walking nearby! Really touching, especially little shoes of a child. It made me think about the horrors of holocaust.

A Memorial to a Group of Budapest Jews Killed on this site during WWII. There seems to be some confusion about this memorial. We were told by someone who lives in Budapest that it is a memorial to Budapest Jews who were shot into the Danube River during the WWII holocaust. They were forced to remove their shoes because the shoes were considered valuable. The shoes in the sculpture were made to look like footwear of the 1940's. This was a sobering memorial.
Must See. This is a must see and a very powerful and emotional statement. Its right next to the Danube and Parliament building. Its sad to see all the different shoes, the childs pair especially.

A sobering reminder of past. The shoes along the Danube sculpture gives remembrance to those lives lost when Arrow Cross militiamen shot people during WWII. They were ordered to take there shoes off before they were shot and fell into the Danube river. This sculpture is a somber reminder of the wrongs committed.
Ok but not sure of the point?. Ok but not sure of the point? Really it is just a number of shoes scattered along the river bank promenade!

Memorial to the millions of Jews in Europe. The shoes on the Danube was very moving. This was very well done, and a tribute to the Jews during WW2. You can easily remember the millions of Jews and others who were killed during WW2.

a good reminder. In this time of rising extremism and racism across the European continent, we need even more to be reminded of the horrible events that past inflamed nationalism and far right extremism brought to the world. It is not only a reminder of the genocide against Jews but also Roma, LGBTQI people, political activists, etc A must see for anybody visiting Budapest, since it is also a great stroll on the Danube from the chain bridge to the Parliament.

Hair raising. Although it isn't signposted or mentioned in most travel itineraries it is a must see. It is such a sombre place and even for the people with no opinion on history or tragedy it will leave you thinking of how nd why it happened. It is situated just before Parliament by the river

Thought-provoking. This is one of those small memorials about a massive historical event that just makes you stop and think. No names - very little information - but enough to provoke reflection and consideration of those terrible times. The memorial is located near to the Parliament on the Pest side along the river.

Very moving Memorial.. Set on the Pest side of the Danube Riverbank, this is a very simple and sensitive memorial to those Jews who where killed during the Second World War. A collection of different types of shoes, boots and sandals of all ages, it highlights that no one was exempt from the slaughter. Candles and flowers are also laid here to add to the memory. A very beautiful and respectful tribute to those who were murdered. Job well done.

Worth the lump in your throat!. This is a heart wrenching memorial. My understanding is: Where the shoes are, is the location the fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II lined up Jewish men, women, and children who were told to remove their shoes, were shot, and fell into the Danube. The memorial is south of the Hungarian Parliament on the promenade. I have been to other Holocaust Memorials, but this one really struck a cord with me. A sad reminder of man's inhumanity to man.
Worth it!. This site is just below the Parliament building. It does not take much time to stop by but it is worth it.

Simple & Powerful. This memorial is very touching. People light candles & leave flowers to remember the many who were killed by the Nazis. The use of real bronzed shoes is very powerful. A somber but important place to see.

A bit of history. It is interesting to walk along the Danube and stumble upon this bit of history. Though it was difficult to find any plaque or write-up, there were locals walking along who were very helpful in explaining the significance of this

Something to see as you pass. We came across this whilst walking from parliament to Buda castle.There isn't much there to explain what it is and not worth going out of your way for as I thought it would be from what I had read.

Tugs at your heart. This depiction is a blast from the past. Painful memories come alive especially if you are aware of the gory holocaust period. The shoes make a powerful statement and reminds you of the thousands of lives lost and plucked out cruelly for nothing. But are we learning from our mistakes? This brought mixed emotions in me.

Often overlooked - close to Parliament. The Shoe Memorial is relatively recent - just 10 years old. It is often overlooked by most Budapest tourists. If you are near Parliament just go down the steps down stream from the building and walk another 100 meters to the memorial which commemorates a specific time in the history of the Holocaust. Before you go read the story of Raoul Wallenberg. It will greatly enhance your appreciation of this place.

Simply done and deeply significant!. A haulocost memorial as a simplistically display of shoes removed at the edge of the Danube just before being murdered. Anti Jewish shootings at the end of Second World War, during last year of pain for the city.

Nothing special. This is very small installation of some rusty shoes. Visit it only if you pass nearby. You can combine it with the visit to the Parliament, but you should walk very close to the river.
Moving.... Great art installation. Worth a visit and time to reflect as you stroll along the Danube. Very close to Budapest Parliament House.
Shoes on the Danube. Interesting, historical, moving. Near the Parliament on the Pest side along the river. You typically see this on the way to Parliament along the river drive
Has to be seen to help appreciate the sad wartime history of Budapest. Before visiting Budapest I had forgotten the part it played in conflicts. This really brings it home.

Very touching but needed a plaque . We visited the memorial and it really is a very touching memorial, however it felt that it needed something there to explain it's meaning to those that weren't aware

Emotinal. We had heard about this and despite the weather, went out of our way to find the shoes. Very emotional and a stunning idea to preserve the memory of those harshly treated by the Nazi regime.
Very moving. Very moving experience to see the shoes on the Danube. I'd seen them on uk tv and thought it was must see. You cannot help but be saddened

Worth a visit . Very poignant monument by the riverside. Would recommend a visit for photographs. Worth reading up about before hand. Another reminder of Budapest's history, along with the Terror House.

Touching, moment of history. A touching monument for Jews who were murdered by the fascist Hungarian government during WW2. Signage surrounding the monument (were no Jews are mentioned) indicates the unwillingness of the Hungarian political elite to confront their past role in WW2. Sad.
Simple and powerful. Just the image of shoe sculptures on the embankment turns history into life. Very simple. Incredibly powerful. It's an easy walk from the parliament building too.
Poignant. A must visit. Makes you think about what those poor people went through. The child's shoes are particularly harrowing to look at

Moving. This succeeded in making me contemplate the dreadful suffering of the Jews here. The simplicity of the Shoes and the setting on the banks of the Danube where the murders took place may really affect you.

Poignant memorial. Seeing the line of shoes and boots was very moving. Jews who were about to be executed left their shoes for others to wear as Budapest was experiencing a bitterly cold winter, and having shoes to wear could mean the difference between life and death.
Emotional. Heart wrenching to see all the lives lost. Beautiful memorial with class. Very emotional to look at all the sizes and styles, even the children ones.

Humbling......the power of art when less says more. Such a simple way to signify such a terrible crime, near to Parliament on the Pest side.
Easy access from the tram or the water-boats also.

Ww2 memorial . The memorial is located close to Parliament. I had seen reviews and made the effort to visit. It's a crying shame that these poor victims lost their lives in such a tragic way. It's worth visiting the memorial if you're taking a stroll along the Danube.
Remember the Holocaust and WWII. A drive by is all that is necessary. What a simple and clever memorial to the Jews who perished during WWII. Meaningful for everyone.

Emotive memorial. You just come across it as you stroll along the ' Pest ' Promenade. The abandoned empty shoes as if their owners have just simply abandoned them and jumped in the river. An emotive memorial to those who who were taken without warning in a deliberate act of genocide. The shoes evoke the reality of the camps, in that all that was left were small personal items such as shoes, collected to recycle.

Poignant moment on the Promenade. This city is so gorgeous and friendly it would be easy to forget all the horrible things which have happened here, but you can't truly appreciate how wonderful it actually is until really understand what these marvelous people have been through. This is the place to stop and think about it.

Heart breaking and yet so important. The shoes on the Danuba are a painfull reminder to the crulness of the humam kind. We were choked at the sight of thos testimonial objects. It was amazing to see people from all over the world paying their respect.

A touching tribute. It's small, but it's a good place to stop and reflect. The shoes themselves look very realistic which certainly makes you think. I wouldn't say this was necessarily worth a standalone visit but when combined with the Parliament building and St Stephens Basilica, it makes an interesting part of a trio of visits. It's just a short walk along from Parliament.
moving tribute. I highly recommend this monument for any traveller to Budapest. It is a simple, but extremely moving tribute along the Danube

A sad day in our history. We were doing a bus tour when we got to the spot were all the bronze shoes were I guide had told us that children woman and men were made to strip of there cloths and hold hands and the nazis shot every second one it was in the winter and there was ice in the harbour.so they all perished.the only thing that was there were shoes .that is why this was a dribute to all who lost there lives.It did put a bit of a damper on our trip But it has to be seen.and acknowledged. A very sad time in our history.amen!RIP.

Simple but evocative . I purposely avoided Holocaust and Nazi stuff during this trip but it is all but unavoidable. However, we did make a trip to the shore of the Danube to see this. It is simple metal casts of shoes, worn with time, filled with the detritus from the river...a sad reminder of the people whose shoes were worth more than lives by the animals who murdered them.

Very moving. We were advised not to miss this and now I know why. This monument was such a moving tribute to the Jewish people. It is a visual reminder of the atrocities of the war that shows us just how terrible it must have been. A must see that will stay with me forever.

So touching. Such a touching memorial to a sad time in history. Beautiful and understated but a must see. You will find it by walking along the promenade next to the river, near parliament. You might not see it as obviously if you walk near the road.
So so. It is very strange. No one know what is these? Why it is here. No sign to explain. But it's okay. Proper for take photos.
Sad and emotional experience. This memorial is very interesting but if you remind what was it about it is really very sad. It is neccesory to remind these dark times of human being!!!

Moving monument. Given meaning by knowing the story - Hungarian Fascists lined up Jewish people, men, women, and children, had them take their shoes off, and let their bodies fall into the Danube. Visit is somewhat spoiled by tourists taking selfies here, as though it were just an art exhibit...
Sobering and a wonderful tribute. Take time to walk by and if at all possible, sit and reflect. A beautiful tribute to the Hungarian Jews who lost their lives due to hatred and antisemitism.
Lovely bit of history on the Danube!. Lovely bit of history on the Danube - a must see. Very easy to get to and represents the valued history of the locals.

Strange ferling. I was a little quite when I saw the shoes monument. The story behind is very sad, Jew were forced to take of their shoes (to sell them later) and then shot and thrown in the river. Sad to see Hungsria tries to hide their role in all of this blaming the Germans (when in reality they partnered up with them for most of the time)

Moving tribute . Very moving tribute to the Jews murdered by the Hungarian Nazis in WW II. If you are in Budapest you need to see this monument. Notice that the plaques mention the word victims but everyone killed here was Jewish.

Poignant display. This is a really affecting memorial, and quite close to parliament so not something you have to go out of your way for. There's two signs (English and Hebrew) marking the site - it's also reasonably busy, and though the crowds were respectful I'd recommend going early or late in the day if it's a more personal moment.
Sadness. I wanted to see this as had been told to go past and have a look. It gave me goose bumps to think what happened at that very spot.
Solomn reminder. Subtle and powerful exhibit of a very bad time in Hungarian history. Beautifully expressed on the shore of the Danube.
powerful. you have to really look for this but it is worth it. this is a powerful display from where Jews and other unfortunates were lined up along the river and and shot during WW2.
A significant location marking Holocaust in Hungary. not only Jews must-visit this location with the tour in city. Memorial site for the Holocaust in Hungary

Touched beyond words.. This may be a seemingly small gesture and unassuming space in the landscape of this bustling city....but the impact it made on us all....In its simplicity was overwhelming. Go and honour those who deserve to be remembered.
Shoes on the Danube. Very strong imagery. And the fact that there are no railings add to this. The story behind it really grabs ahold of your emotions.

These shoes represent a horrific time. We just drove by, but were told this is not the actual spot that the Jews were shot and then put into the Danube but does commemorate the act. We were also told the value of the shoes... even during the Russian occupation.

What can I say. We were walking along the danube when we came across the shoes. It just hits you when you think what these poor people had to endure. Let's hope history never ever repeats itself and the world never forgets.
Sad. It's good to take a moment of remembering the war but it's a sad thing. I've never seen such kind of memorial, it's something special and worth taking the stroll on the way to the Parliament.
Emotional. Tissues at the ready for this one. A truly moving tribute definitely worth a visit and easy to find just before parliament.
Stroll down Danube. This is worth seeing. Very sad to think about all the Jewish people who died here. Very sobering to be here at sunset. Take a minute out of your trip to walk by.

Poignant . A well fashioned and touching memorial spoiled only by people who seem to think that their desire for a photo entitles them to step right in front of others seeking the same thing.
Pick a quiet time when you can reflect a while.

moving. this memorial was a poignant reminder of mans inhumanity to man sitting on the banks of the Danube.It was a reminder of the Second World War and the atrocities that were committed.The bronze shoes were of different sizes and shapes and the bronze plaque is on the walk way

A sad moment in history. We traveled with a couple and he was born in Hungary so we were lucky to have a person with the history of this city and country during the war, revolution and communist rule. Horrible, horrible times. These shoes represent people who had to stand on that bank, remove their shoes and then be shot and fall into the river. The children's shoes really makes an impact! I believe there are 70 pairs of shoes there. It's free, and just a short walk.

A moving exhibit. This was very touching to see these shoes and learn the history behind the shooting of children, women, men during Nazi era. I was particularly struck by the tiny child's shoes that had been filled with little candy treats.
Humankind at its worse. This poignant art work is a chilling reminder of the suffering of the Jewish nation. A simple yet heart breaking reminder of the past
Simple but powerful - a short walk from the Chain Bridge. If you're nearby, take the time to make a short visit. This is a simple but powerful memorial to those in the Jewish community lost.
Poignant. This elicits a moment of silence as you're walking along the Danube. The story behind this "monument" is heartbreaking.
poignant. If people do not know, they may think that this is just a shoe, However, this simple memorial shows a lot of meanings to the past. I could feel the sadness when looking at the shoes

Moving. It is not until you realise the oppression that the country went through in the 2oth century and you see the memorials that you get a real sense of how fortunate most people are today whatever we think.
Fantastic. One of my highlights. Well worth visiting the shoes, very poignant. The shoes are located just in front of the parliament building.

Emotional and beautiful reminder of crimes to humanity.. A thought provoking peice of artwork.Dedicated to a dreadful crime during 2nd world war.A time to stop and think of the many men,women and children killed.

Touching and poignant. I agree with most who say this is a very poignant memorial. I wasn’t aware of this particular memorial or the history behind it. Just having come from Israel, it was a very simple, but meaningful, tribute to those who died in this horrific manner. Worth the stop.
Poignant reminder of mans inhumanity to man. The Nazis lined people up on the bank of the Danube, made them take off their shoes and shot them into the water. Never let this be forgotten.

Different, simple, haunting. Very poignant and sombre reminder of one the darkest times in recent history. Subtle but moving. Have given it 4* rather than 5* only because we felt that there could've been a bit more information available to inform visitors in greater detail about this important memorial.
Worth the walk. Set along the Danube this is a stirring tribute to the victims of a terrible event in history. It's worth walking over and checking it out.
Moving. A very moving memorial/monument next to the Danube river. One of the highlights of Budapest. A must see.

A must visit. I first saw the images of the shoes on the Danube in the Holocaust memorial building in Berlin, and was determined to visit them someday. The shoes don't jump out at you, you could easily walk past them at street level so make sure to follow the river down to the Parliament building.The shoes are a beautiful memorial, and at night, with candles, very eerie and thought provoking.

Moving Memorial. We read the history of this memorial before attending to better understand its meaning.It is perched on the banks of the Danube not far from the Parliament building and has a distinct presence and a certain amount of feeling eeriness about it. It is a simple and subtle reminder of the atrocities that were once committed unnecessarily all those years ago.Very moving and worth a visit

Good find . Continue walking along the river on the side of the parliament and you will see these shoes on your way. Quite an interesting find. In my opinion, you can do it in the night as Budapest is amazing to view in the night when you walk and can see the parliament and castle hill lit up in the night
Touching. This shoes represents all the jews trhown at the Danube by the Nazis. It is an image of sadness and frustration. A memorial place somehow

A piece of history . A gentle reminder of the past, situated along the riverside and away from the main hustle and central areas it's worth a little walk. There's something touching and reality that this happened a sad sorry but if your in the area have a wander up.
Somber reminder. A quiet place to meditate on the atrocities we must never forget! The shoes are lined up along the bank of the Danube river where they were shot and they fell into the river.
Nice walk along the river. Sad sight.. Shoes of the Jews who were shot and thrown in the river.. Very good memorial and a must visit. Check it out in the evening..Lite with candles
Very moving. Free. Along the riverVery movingClose to parliament Would be helpful to have some explanation plaque nearby but still worth visiting

Subtle and Moving - but take care by the river if you have young kids. This is a simple but very effective memorial artwork, which I understand remembers Jews slaughtered in Budapest during the war and then thrown into the river (but their shows were not).It's a haunting and provoking image. It doesn't take long to look at but lasts with you for much longer. Makes you think about how easy it is to scapegoat foreigners or immigrants or those who are just different, and to dwell on the hidden darkness within humanity that comes out in dark twisted forms in unpredictable times and places. And to ponder how the easy cowardice of going with the herd allows this to happen. Sadly still seem all too relevant today.I wish they had some sort of information by it to mark its significance and explain the backdrop to those who do not know. It would be all too easy for people to stumble on this and mock it without knowing that, and its power to reach out is diminished as a result.I'd also warn parents with kids that this stretch of river promenade across from the Parliament area could be really dangerous. There are no barriers or railings to prevent people tripping into the deep, wide Danube. And if you did, the current is strong, there are no lifebuoys to throw in, and there are no or few steps to get out.

Very emocional. It is a very emocional monument to represent the Jews killed and thrown into the Danube River during World War II. It is very close to the Parliament and certainly can be seen in the same day.

History . Interesting history which I didn't know about shoes on the Danube ... it's very sad to learns about those people in during 2nd world war ... It's not very far from parliament ... it's take you about 10 mins walk ...
Thought provoking. Quite simply a thought provoking reminder of what the Jews endured during the second world war. I personally found it quite hard hitting.

Thought Provoking. This was one of the only things I knew about BP ahead of time and I really wanted to see it. It's a very moving memorial, if a little messy from candles and assorted things being put into the shoes. Knowing some of the complex history of the city helps to understand the memorial. Sad indeed.

Makes you stop and reflect. Take a few moments from the hustle and bustle of Budapest to go and see the shoes... Very moving and touching when you know the story behind it.. I cannot understand why people take selfies at a place like this..

Impactful. It was hard standing there knowing what happened here before along this river bank. The shoes presented such a strong image about human and wars. If you near the parliament, please do yourself a favor and come and have a look.

So no one will ever forget, a wonderful tribute. This was a bonus for us as we didn't really know about it except when our airbnb host sent us a website showing this sculpture. You can see it from the 2 tram but it is important enough to stop by and do some photos. What a memorial, the small but important part of our daily life is a testimony of the suffering of the people during the war. I pray that you will see the candles that have 3 languages on them-Hebrew, English and Hungarian. Another testimony to the depth of the loss. We took tram 2 to the parliament building and then just crossed the street. easy on easy off with a day pass from the metro. You are also close to the river cruise spots and boat ferry dock

A haunting and emotional display. It really is quite a sight to see these 60 pairs of shoes on the Danube bank as a reminder of the massacre of Jews undertaken here by the Nazi's during WWII. There are 60 pairs as the memorial was placed in 2004 (60 years after the event) but in reality many more Jews were forced to take their shoes off here before being shot. It's a very emotional experience.
Beautiful. Real-looking shoes. Close to parliament, beautiful and touching monument. And must to see! Maybe better looking evening nights when lights are on.

Haunting . These are on the banks of the Danube near the Parliament building. Definitely worth a visit. So poignant and beautifully done. From a photographic point of view it was a shame that there were so many old candles and bits of ribbon, but it still leaves quite an impact.
Poignant memorial. One of the saddest memorials to those murdered in the Holocaust. What remains are the shoes they cast off. Very moving.

Poignant memorial. Had been keen to find this memorial on our tour of Budapest and as I thought it had quite an impact, found it very emotional as you would expect, a lovely tribute to so many lost lives
Shoes. These were varied and unusual to see although there was nothing to tell you if they had any significance but worth a visit.
wow. What an emotional site to see along the edge of the beautiful blue Danube river. Budapest has amazing sites, this one really makes you stop to think, and be grateful.
very touching tribute. worth a visit, interesting and very touching almost haunting tribute to the Jews slaughtered by the Nazi s located by the Danube close to the Parliament building

Very moving. The shoes themselves were very moving. Particularly when you get to the middle. However, for such a great loss it needs someone to look over it once in a while and sweep up some of the debris left there by the rains.
Very thought provoking. This memorial, while simple, is very thought provoking and exemplifies the atrocities of WWII very well. You will be somber after leaving the memorial
Historical significance?. Ran by in the morning and saw it. Took some photos and that's it. Probably have more significance in the history of the city.

Worth a quick visit. Not much else to add, but if in the neighborhood, it's worth seeing to be reminded of a sad part of history.
Not in great condition these days, but almost adds to it.

So moving. I love city breaks but it's so easy to get caught up in the hustle bustle and the buzz of the city, especially in a place like Budapest that has a buzzing nightlife. This memorial really makes you stop in a busy city, think and remember. So moving.

Impressive memorial. Impressive memorial to the killing of Jewish innocent civilians during the dark period of World War II by Hungarian troops.
Symbolic site which illustrates the horror of the period.

Moving. Read about this before we went to Budapest don't think everyone who was there understood the story behind the shoes so moving I expected just men's however there was men's, women's and small kids and most of all a few that looked like they had been placed recently worth a visit
A Must See. Never under estimate the power of a simple display it evokes a very different time and a time that should never be forgotton
sobering. The shoes are not far from Parliament and well worth the walk to see them. It is another sobering reminder of Hungary's past and is very moving to contemplate.
Very good attraction. This is well worth going and seeing all the history. It is a surprisingly moving piece of artwork. Central location

One of the few visible signs that so many Hungarian Jews had been murdered. The shoes are a poignant reminder of those who were murdered by their fellow Hungarians. We had wondered where all the holocaust memorials were - Hungary, after all had a huge Jewish population. We found out why on a visit to the grand synagogue. The majority were rounded up and sent to death camps or killed by other Hungarians - the arrow men militia. We were unaware of Hungarian history during the war and hadn't realised that they started out as nazi collaborators before changing sides as the end of the war approached. Hungary today still seems to want this part of their history put in the shadows, if not completely hidden. The shoes are a very simple but effective reminder of what humans can do to each other. We sat on the banks of the Danube surrounded by beautiful buildings with the shoes making a sunny day somber.

Do your research first. I noted there were tours of this attraction for $90USD, dont pay the price. Do your research beforehand about the Jewish people who were executed on the Danube and take a stroll along the waterfront. If able, take a small candle to light near the shoes. Its a very moving tribute to those who were executed on the waterfront.

This is a must see. I kept on walking around the place and also went close to the exibits as some of them are so well made you believe they're natural. Read the plates with the description so you understand the moral value too.
Interesting . It's interesting and also sad to see what ppl may have gone through. Its a small memorial which u can find on the way from Parliament to Chain Bridge walk along side the river.

Short but memorable visit. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade are only 100 metres from the Parliament building. Hungary's history is so extensive that one should take at least 5-10 minutes to remember those that died tragically. Unfortunately there are only signs in Hungarian to describe the monument so it is recommended to read up the history and the meaning of the shoes before seeing them.
One of the most moving. We've seen quite a few memorials on this trip, but this was one of the most moving we encountered. Simple, and stunning. I really recommend walking to see this up close.
Heartbreaker. Take a moment to stop and see this simple tribute to the Jews who were murdered by the Nazis. Never forget.
Heartbreaking. Wonderful thing to see during your time there and it's nice that it's close to parliament. It's very simple and yet very symbolic.
Very touchy . This is a place that makes you to remember what happened here on WW2 and should not forgotten. Forever.

Extremely poignant. After hearing so much about the atrocities against the Jews during my trip, this memorial on the banks of the Danube was immensely poignant. The sculptured shoes are in all sizes and shapes belonging to men, women and even children - to show that no-one was immune to the savagery inflicted upon the Jewish community during the war. The memorial is unique, free, and very easy to reach. Every visitor to Budapest should take a stroll along the Danube and see the memorial.

touching and sad memorial. On the edge of the beautiful Danube, almost in front of the back of the Parliament, you can see a homage to the Jews killed by the fascist Arrow Cross during the WWII, the monument Shoes on the Danube Bank. The Jews, back then, were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river to be carried away. There are sixty pairs of iron shoes created by the sculptor Gyula Pauer. In my opinion, one of the most moving monuments within the city.

Sad but beautiful. Everyone visiting Budapest should visit this piece of art which reminds us of the cruel history. Remind us all to be tolerant of our neighbors and people from different cultures/backgrounds.

Very moving however incomplete description. The actual sculpture is done very well with a viewers complete need to reflect on the atrocities which occurred at this site. However, the sign reads "memorial to the victims of WWII". The murders which took place at this particular site were of the Jewish residents. While many ethnicities suffered greatly by the Nazi regime, and their conspirators, the signage at this site could have been more comprehensive in its description. With that said, this is a must visit.

Lovely. Very sweet memorial for the victims of Jews killed by militia in Budapest.Very easy to find if you follow along the bank of the danube and pretty much along the way to visiting most other places so worth a stop.

a moving holocaust memorial. When in Budapest, the walkable city, you should definitely walk along the Danube. When you are almost to the Parliament Building after passing the Chain bridge, you will find this unusual memorial to Jews who were shot here so that their bodies fell into the Danube. Replicas of shoes of all types including children's shoes--so sad.

A testimony to the strength of the victims of The cruelty of people in war. A simple yet effective epitaph to the victims of this atrocity of World War Two a place to be humbled, inspired, reminiscent and respectful. The vocabulary isn't sufficient to describe the emotions felt at this small and almost unnoticeable memorial not far from the parliament building. If you have the time just go pay your respects.

Heart Wrenching!. We passed "The Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial" while on a bus tour of the city. It was a somber experience but one that should not be missed. The promenade itself is a picturesque walk and if given some free time, well worth the experience.
Moving. Very emotional to visit here, take a stroll along the Danube and visit this on route. Easy to find due to the gathering of tourists daily.

A monument to history, and the horror of war.. This is a very modest but telling monument to the horrors of war. For a short stretch of about 50 yards on the bank of the Danube there are boots and shoes made of metal set into the concrete they are many sizes representing men ,women and children.
