They are symbolic of the action of the Nazis in WW2. Until 1944 Hungary had been allies of the Nazis, as Russian troops advanced Hungary switched sides or at least tried too. The result was that German troops invaded and took over the country and immediately started to transport mainly the Jews to the concentration camps such as Auschwitz on at least one occasion when Eichmann could not get enough trains they simply lined up men, women and children on the edge of the river bank and shot them so that they fell into the Danube. Thus we have a telling memorial to the horrors of war. It should make everyone pause for thought.
Sad story. If you walk at the bank of Duna you may see them, as we did. Means nothing if you don't know the story. But makes your heart breaking when you learn the story!

Humbling. The fact the shoes are replicated into metal ones is testimony that such acts are humbling. People are seen sitting there, taking photographs and people have left flowers and notes etc. Very humbling experience. Close to the parliament.

Memorial to Jews Killed by Arrow Cross Militiamen. Sixty pairs of iron shoes have been placed along the Danube by film director Can Togay and sculptor Gyula Pauer to honor the men, women, and children murdered on Jan 8, 1945 by fascist Arrow Cross militiament.

Monument not to be missed. The shoes along the banks of Danube represent a horrific moment in Budapest history. It's very low key and simple, yet will give you a full force shock about human cruelty. Something not to be missed.

Sad but moving. This is an artist memorial to the jewish people that were killed by arrows and falling into the Danube. It was a sad but very moving memorial. It is by the river walkway not far from the Parliament house.

Shoes. Attached to the concrete banks of the Danube, this is a very poignant and real reminder of what the Hungarians have suffered. People left their shoes on the bank and killed themselves in the Danube rather than face persecution. If you like history (much of theirs unknown to us) try to talk to locals especially those over 70.

Striking memorial. A striking holocaust memorial that should certainly be visited whilst in beautiful Budapest. A short walk from chain bridge towards margaret bridge on the Pest side of the Danube river.

Deep full meaning. I really loved that idea and how beautifully (in details) the memorial is done. I was little bit said that the "shoes" are in bad condition and the memorial is really weatherworn. But though it is worth to see! (I haven´t seen in but friend of mine told me she passed there at night and it was really moving with all these candles lit up.)

Touching... The shoes are not sign posted for good reason but it is a must see even from a photography point of view to just standing and seeing the emotion in some people. Flowers and candles are occasionally left from maybe family members or loved ones. The shoes can be found between the parliament building and the chain bridge.

Beautifull memorial. This is simply one of the strongest, and most sielent memorial I've ever seen. The sumbology with the shoes left at the edge of Donau is realy strong, and even more strong in the non-brutal form.

Unique. This is a very unique and interesting memorial honoring the memory of those shot and killed into the Danube during the holocaust. Moving and poignant. It is worth the walk. Easy to see by heading north from the Chain Bridge on the Pest side of Budapest along with a stop at Parliament to see the building.
Sadness. These shoes seemed real. The history of these men, women and children that have been killed in Danube...I felt sad for them
Go see this. We went to see the shoes as part of a bike tour. Very moving and well done. There's no big sign, just metal shoes left as they were.

A tribute. Diagonally opposite the Parliament and sited on the bank of the river on the Pest side, it is easy to find and reach. Spent less than ten minutes here. A tribute to those who lost their lives..
Very interesting and unique. Shoes on the Danube is a very intriguing exhibition by the water. Would definitely recommend visiting.

Very moving. People have put tea-lights and plastic flowers amongst the little sculptured shoes, which on one hand makes it look tatty, but on the other adds to its sadness as you realise these were today's visitors' family members

A Quiet Symbol. This simple, honest remembrance of deeds past is so thought provoking and sad. The line of bronzed shoes and how they came to be there will just break your heart. Very emotional memorial.
sad. This is something everyone should see. once I learned the story behind the shoes my heart was sadden

Intriguing display leaving with questions unanswered . Not too sure what they represent, but stumbled (almost literally) across them whilst walking along the River Danube at sunset. There are dozens of metal casts of shoes, both sexes, in all types and designs.
Most had small wax tea-light candles in, or adjacent to them.
They are set into the concrete "towpath", with a brown rusty appearance.

Free for all. Free for all to see. An unusual memorial to Jews killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in World War II. They had to take off their shoes and were shot at the edge of the water. The shoes left behind on the bank.

An Important Memorial . The Shoes on the Danube Memorial commemorates the Jews that were killed by the Hungarian Iron Cross militia in 1944-45. The Jews were brought to the river, forced to take off their shoes and then were shot so that their bodies fell into the river to be washed away.The Memorial simply shows a series of brass shoes left by the side of the river promenade. The memorial is a bit difficult to access and there are not clear signs how to get there by the nearby streets.

A very moving memorial. The simplicity of this memorial makes the atrocity that was committed here so much the greater. The shooting of innocent Hungarian Jews into the Danube by anti-Semitic militiamen is shocking and heart-breaking. The very ordinariness of the shoes (cast in iron) shows how no man, woman or child were spared from the brutality. Take the time to visit this memorial and remember how fortunate you are.

Read up about this. Seeing the shoes on the Danube was part of our plans for the day, it's located opp Parliament building next to the River. It was clear that many people were just walking past and had no idea what the monument was. There isn't any decent factual material on site so it would be good to look up beforehand. The shoes commemorate the event during WW2 where Jews were rounded up and shot into the Danube. There is no mention at the actual site that the victims were Jewish which I think is appalling (although someone had placed an Israeli flag in one of the shoes).

Touched my soul. This is something that you can pass by without noticing, however, knowing the story behind it makes your heart break. They had 2 people tied up together and killed one of them so that the other one would drown by the dead body's weight. The replica of the shoes of these babies, children and adults, show the only thing that was left after such a cruel act. You can only have a moment of silence at the scene. It is even more impactful after visiting the Terror Haza.

Read the history beforehand to fully appreciate this moving memorial. Another free attraction, this is worth a visit. It is on the Danube near Parliament so it would be good to combine this with your visit to Parliament.
Small, but historical. If you don't know why these shoes are here, you can easily miss the meaning of it. But the story behind this, makes it a historical place.
Poignant Tribute. Very sad reminder of the Nazi atrocities. Shoes of children, men, and women alike who were shot dead by Nazi militiamen along the Danube

Powerful reminder. The shoes placed along the edge of the river represent a rather powerful and moving reminder of those that lost their lives during the Holocaust in WW2 especially the shoes of a little child. It evokes powerful memories. We were there just before Christmas so we missed the crowds and managed to get a good view and photos.
Stop by. It's worth it walk along the Danube river and check this out. The vibe you get is unique. During night time they light candles inside the shoes and you feel how great this monument is.

Most important. This memorial statue is extremely important, and in my opinion, most horrific one, regarding WW2.
As an Israeli Jew, 3rd generation to a Holocaust survivors, I believe this is a must-see site. .

Very unique memorial. This is a very moving memorial to the jews that were shot at the riverside by the Hungarian Arrow Cross (Nazis). They were shot at the riverside so that the river would remove the bodies. These are bronze shoes representing what was left behind.
Moving. Very moving monument to those who lost their lives in WWII...if you are lucky, you will be able to view it without too many tourists sitting/standing among the shoes.
Dramatic Demonstration of Holocaust Horor. Many Jews were killed at the river. The display represents their shoes on the edge of the dock. One was that of a child. We were litterally breathless.

Simple, yet powerful. Having got off a river cruise, the 6 of us took a slow walk in quite warm temperatures along the promenade as one of the group had specifically stated she wanted to visit this memorial. We were not disappointed. It is a very simple idea yet it evokes powerful memories of so many atrocities in so may places and particularly this one here.
Beautiful. Beautiful memorial in honors of the jewels who got killed. Emotional. Worthy to take a look and if possible go with a guide to get some of the history.
Holocaust memory . On our first visit in Budapest we went to the shoes memories of the Holocaust. It was very emotional to be there and a very important place to visit.
A must see. Very emotive , also went to the House of Terror museum which gave me a better understanding of what these shoes meant and stood for
Very touching memorial. We came across this location by accident, and found the history of the shoes very touching. We do not understand how people can be so cruel.

Poignant memorial.. This an unusual but poignant memorial. It is composed of metal shoes along the embankment of the Danube, close to the Parliament building. It is in memory of the victims who were shot and killed by the Arrow Cross Militia men in 1944/45.

Moving memorial. I cycled an extra bridge/ block to visit the Shoes and thought it was well worth it.
Given the tea light candles around. I imagine these shoes attract night-time visitors too.

Very moving tribute . Shoes on the Danube Bankis a memorial in Budapest, Hungary. Conceived by film director Can Togay, he created it on the east bank of the Danube River with sculptor Gyula Pauer to honor the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank. Visitors have left flowers, candles etc as memorials to the victims. A very sobering representation, definitely worth a stroll along the Danube to see.
Memorial. A very moving tribute tothe fallen. This is a simple memorial but very thought provoking. Very easy to find a short walk from the Parliament building.

Poignant and beautiful. I wasn't aware of this memorial installation and when I came across it walking along the Danube to the Parliament, I was pleased to find it. The down side is that it is a memorial to resistance fighters who were executed on this spot and their bodies pushed into the river. An acute reminder of the atrocities that war brings.

Very moving due to its simplicity. Its a deceptively simple memorial that makes you think about the terrible things that happened here in the past. You need a guide or a book to explain it as there is not a sign in English.
very moving, clever idea. historical and moving. visit in the morning, less people. there are candles, so it must be lit up at night which would be interesting

that chill in your spine.... what did the world go through just less than 100yrs ago? did we learn anything? the way tourists see this art; especially the shoe of a child... you watch is for a while sitting there and possibly a tear runs down anyone's cheek... not to be missed and spend a half an hour, probably at dusk or dawn...
Sad history. Worth seeing since it's 5 min from the Parlament. The history behind the shoes is very sad. Make sure you read about it.

Interesting. It was on our way to the parliament. You cant miss them if walking on the danube. It has a dramatic story which makes the place quiet. There is no explanation there, so u have to make ur own research

A moment to reflect. This was both beautiful and sickening at the same time. The beauty of the artists work and how well it conferred the horror of what had happened on this site. One persons humanity in making sure we will always remember the inhumanity of others upon the men, women and children that died here.

A simple but very touching memorial. We came to the shoes on the Danube with our tour guide who told us the true and very sad story of the shoes left by the Jews killed during the Second World War. The memorial is very touching and reduced many to tears
Different memorial. I'd heard about the Shoes on a documentary and thought it would be interesting seeing them. Nice walk along the Danube, special memorial.
Sad but necessary memory of bad times in the history of Budapest. A must see. An understanding of how bad it was for the Jewish people in the City towards the end of WW2.

Very moving. If you walk along the Danube on the Pest side, you will come across this simple yet profound memorial. The life-like shoes are very thought-provoking. Definitely take some time to visit this memorial.

Very moving memorial. We saw the shoes from our boat ride up and down the Danube and also as we passed by them by bus. The shoes are very poignant. If you have the time it is better to see them up close but also seeing them as we did still made you feel very strongly.

Poignant.. Very poignant sculpture, makes you pause a moment.
This certainly makes you reflect on how low humans can fall.
Must see!. Unique memorial by the Danube. It gives you the possibbility to feel deeply about the victims of the Holocaust.

Worth Seeing. This memorial was created to commemorate a historic event that took place during the world war. Jewish people were rounded up, lined up along the bank of the Danube at this location, and shot. The shoes are of different styles, mens womens and children, and made out of metal. Some visitors have left candles and ribbons. This memorial is located right across the street from the Parliament House which is also worth visiting. (See my other review)

Shoes on the Danube. I had always wanted to go to see this memorial and it was very moving. I was disappointed by the way people have left multiple burned tea lights and various trinkets in and around the shoes that I know was meaningful for some but really took away from the full impact.
Emotional experience. This memorial to the Jewish people will have you in tears. I looked around and I wasn't the only one.
Moving memorisl. A very simple memorial that amply tells the story of a tragedy. Not a major attraction but worth a visit when visiting parliament.

How can shoe sculptures be moving?. If you walk along the river bank on the Pest side near the beautiful Parliament building, you will come across many pairs of bronze sculpted shoes. A strange sight at first glance, but then you discover they represent the Jews who were shot by fascist militiamen during the second world war. They were made to take off off their shoes before being shot and their bodies fell into the Danube and were swept away. Another sad representation of a dreadful time in our world history. Now, it is obvious that people still remember them as there are candles which have been lit nearby. Very moving.
Thought Provoking.. Sad memorial but necessary to visit and remember what happened in the past, It is very moving and humbling.

Moving. This was one of the few 'must see' items on my Budapest list and it didn't disappoint, I found it very moving to see the shoes and sat for a while imagining how it would've been. The way the shoes are laid out makes it very human and real.
Free. Cute while walking along Danube river from parliament building towards chain bridge do walk and see shoes

Moving and deeply humblin. This was a must- I missed this our first trip here and was so happy when I went for a run and saw it. Grace and love we're all I could think of- these are a kind and loving people in this city

Poignant memorial. There are 60 pairs of shoes on the Danube by the Hungarian parliament, not to represent the number of Jews killed but the anniversary. Jews were taken to the bank of the Danube and told to take off their shoes (which were kept, because they were valuable) and then shot by militiamen in to the water. There are always lots of people here, so you're unlikely to get that moment of quiet reflection by yourself unless you go really early or late at night, but it's moving nonetheless.

Think Twice World! Shoes of the People. These are the shoes that beckon to all humanity. Never Never Ever again. it is a chilling reality amidst an idyllic river cruise, or neat city - Budapest - stop. Nothing more to be said.

good photos. We did not know what the reason for all the shoes were but they certainly left us with the impression that they were where people had drowned (I do not know if this is so) but they are very unusual and made some grat photos
Sad. Sad place, but we need those to remind current generations of the mistakes of the past ones. Our mood switched suddenly when we reached this memorial.
Shoes on the Danube. What a sad memorial but a necessary one. Anyone visiting this display of shoes left behind by the people who were shot into the Danube will be moved.

Heart breaking. I have always been drawn to stories of WW2 and as a kid I read Anne Frank's diary numerous times that it is now dog eared. To visit this shoe installation breaks my heart because the reality of what happened was right in front of me. I said a prayer for all those souls.

Humbling. My family was reading Rick Steve's "Walk around Budapest" and we stopped to take in this memorial. While I had read about the memorial, actually seeing all the candles and mementos sprinkled around the shoes was humbling. Understanding what actually happened here was very humbling. The artists idea to immortalize the Jews that died here was brilliant. Even though this wasn't part of the "tour" from our book, I was thankful we paused to see it.
Very moving. We saw this monument, heard the story, and found it to be moving and heart breaking. How sad history is sometimes.

Sad but worth Stopping. We went for a walk down the river today and found this memorial. It is so sad what mankind can do to one another. And feel ok about doing. But the memorial is very cool. The kids shoes are the hardest to see.
Poignant. Not where I expected it to be as It is outside the Parliament building. Very poignant memorial to the Holocaust and the terrors faced by many.
Heartbreaking monument. Even if you don't know why the shoes are there, you understand something terrible happened there. A very sad place, horrible story.
A reminder of the inhumanity possible in societies. This is a brilliant sculpture, read up about it before your visit to acquaint yourself with why it is there. Moving

Heartbreaking. We spent quite a while here, just looking at the shoes, and the Danube, and imagining what these poor desperate people must have felt, not being able to protect themselves or the most vulnerable, the children, among them. May God forgive the perpetrators.

Moving yet subtle. This memorial is a very moving yet subtle reminder of the people who were killed here. The detail in the shoes is astounding; they look like they're really made of leather until you get close and see they're metal! And when you think about the people who the original shoes belonged to, and what happened to them at that spot, it's a very sobering reminder of the tragedies of WWII.

Solemn. Take a few moments to honor the Jews who were killed by fascists during WWII. What a moving memorial that helps to engrave history onto our hearts. May good men never stay silent in the face of such atrocities.

Unforgettable experience.. This is a simple but heart-breaking monument to the thousands of Jews of Budapest who were forced to remove their shoes before being slaughtered on the banks of the Danube by the Nazis, who considered their shoes more valuable than their lives! It is a must for any visitor to Budapest. I am writing this 3 months after visiting, but the image still haunts me.

A poignant memorial. These shoes are both poignant and a chilling reminder of a sad, even horrifying event. They are cast in bronze and there are many candles and stones that show the Hungarian Jews who we shot 1944-45 by their fellow countrymen are not forgotten.
Shoes on Danube. Don't lose time here, nothing special to see. The view on the shore of Danube in the evening worth seeing.

Touching, moving..unless you have a heart of stone. "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005."Go visit and reflect. Or even genuflect. It will do you good!
Thought Provoking. Apparently the Jews were marched here naked, shot and dumped into the river. All ages as represented by the different shoe sizes and types. Lest we forget.

A stroll through History. Takes you straight back to history. Sad, gives you the chills at the same time. Please do include this in your itinerary while on the visit to the iconic bridges of Budapest and the Danube river.

Heartbreaking story behind this beautiful monument.. Impressive monument, made for the jews who got killed on this part of the promenade. They had to take of their shoes before they got killed and fell in the Donau. It's a monument you can easily miss, because there is no big sign or a story on a stone. Be sure to check this out. When you stand on the side of the parlement with your back agains it, you will find the shoes to the left.
Thought provoking. Worth the trip - makes you feel very lucky to live in todays day and age. Knowing the past helps put the present in perspective.

A touching Tribute. Such a simple permanent exhibit, but so powerful.
Go and learn more about the history of Hungarians during the war and this small tribute will take on greater meaning.

Surprising. Even up close you think you are looking at real shoes and only after a bit do you realize you are seeing a display. It's a simple yet moving reminder of the terrible murders committed here 70+ years ago.

Somber, moving memorial.. This is a memorial that sneaks up on you. The setting is mundane: a busy street nearby, the laughter of passing pedestrians, the sparkling Danube flowing past. Then you take a moment to sit and reflect on what the shoes represent and the experience they evoke. Just a brutally effective remembrance.
a poignant piece of history. this is the 2nd time i have visited the shoes on the Danube Promenade and still makes me feel so very sad and is heartbreaking what these poor jews went through

Impressive memorial. These shoes are the only thing remaining from people made to criminals for minor reasons. Keeping that in mind, the memorial is impressive, but make it part of your walk, not its destination.
Tears rather than rating. This monument in its simplicity told more of the story of those poor victims than anything in writing ever could. Powerful indeed.
Very moving. This is one of those places that will be very moving, causing you to reflect on man's inhumanity to his fellow man. Have we learned anything in 70 years?
Simple and impressive. A very simple monument but full of meaning and very moving! It's beauty lies in its significance when dark days seam to again be on the horizon for the western world!
Memorial without words. Near the parliament - on the way to the city - you find many shoes - men, women, children .... you don't need words ...

Simple but impressive. Knowing the history, this monument was quite impressive as it really captures the essence and feeling of what the artist tried to capture.Located right on the Donau dock, you get a lovely view of the Buda side as an extra.Downside is the accesability,. You cant cross the road anywhere in the area without risking your life.Would be a great idea to add something like a pedestrian crossing.

Emotive . One of the selling points of Budapest is the Danube and probably the most emotive and resonant sights is the memorial Shoes on the Danube, another highlight of a country that pays respect to the past with a well managed and excellently presented memorial. Puts a lump in your throat and takes your breath away, and makes you truly grateful to have a good life. An absolute must see for all.

Poignant. Simple but effective, this memorial is a poignant and respectful tribute to the Jewish people who were shot into the Danube by militiamen. Take a moment to ponder, it's next to Parliament so worth crossing the road for.

Use your imagination just think if it was you standing there-the only thing left from you, is the pair of shoes you wore. I think it is very hard to judge the "Shoes on the Danube Bank" on Trip Advisor. At the same time I think it is very important this memorial has been made in memory/to honor the people mainly jews, who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross in Budapest during World War II.Just imagine: "if we were one of the people standing there, you may know, you are next in line, the vary next moment you are shot, and the only thing left from you, are the shoes you wore, it could not be more sad or moving".I think it is very important you take the time and visit the memorial "Shoes on the Danube Bank" - give yourself the moment it takes to see all the shoes on the Pest side of the Danube. It is a piece of the World's History left there as a memorial.

Very poignant!. An incredible visual of despair and tragedy from all walks of life, as depicted in these shoes. Makes you really wonder what these people must have been feeling as their lives ended too short.

A chance to pause and reflect. This is situated about 1 minute from the Parliament building. After marvelling at how beautiful the Parliament building is, it is only right to find time to remember those that were tortured during the war by being made to remove their shoes before being shot to their death as they fell into the Danube. What sort of a monster was Hitler and it is reminders such as this that should deter us from allowing any such atrocities to happen ever again.

Impressive place. Impressive place which really symbolizes well part of the WW2 horrors that took place in the city. Can be well combined with visit to Parliament (is close by). Be careful crossing the busy streets.

Thought provoking!. As this was a stones throw from our hotel, it was the first of the many sights for us to see in Budapest. It wasn't' until we were told the full story that we reallsed just how poignant they are. It is difficult to believe at first that they are made from metal, so fine is the craftsmanship, but as the story unfolds they cease to be shoes, and represent the hundreds, or who knows how many people were murdered there!! A simple yet powerful reminder of the atrocities carried out less than a century ago!
Very different . Take a moment to go and see this completely different memorial. This is absolutely beautiful and well respected with beautiful views all around

Very moving tribute. We walked along the embankment after visiting the Parliament and came across the Shoes on the Danube Memorial. It is heartrending to see the different pairs of shoes and even some single ones. The most upsetting are the children's shoes. We had been told the story of the executions on the river bank and this was somehow worse as it was a group of their own people who carried it out.I think it is a timely reminder of what people can be capable of and it must not be forgotten. Everyone should go to see this memorial as it is stunning in it's simplicity.
Poignant. Much is written about this elsewhere concerning the terror these shoes commemorate. Take 15 minutes just to contemplate the sadness.

Best memorial I've ever seen. It was moving and horribly beautiful. Makes you think and realize how lucky you are. The best memorial I've seen to the Jewish people and other victims. Definitely make time to see this while in Budapest.

Very touching memorial, . If you come to Budapest, you must see this memorial of mens, women's and children's shoes on the bank of the Danube. A fitting tribute to the atrocities committed by the Nazis

Take in the horror of it all.. This is a moving memorial, incredibly powerful. Whilst in Budapest, come and see the shoes and take a moment to reflect on the truly tragic events of past world wars. It reminded me how grateful I am to even be alive.
Interesting. We passed by this "monument" and found it unusual and interesting. Not sure I would go out of my way to see it, but it is meaningful.
Moving memorial. Such a powerful memorial to the people who lost their lives at the edge of the river at the end of WWII: Don't miss it.

Never forget. This memorial to the Holocust reminds me of the Vietnam wall in Washington DC as it takes away your breath and brings back memories of lost families and future generations who would have contributed so much to our world. Should be seen by all as we must remember the past in order to avoid this in the future; and regrettably is still recurs in our world today.
Touching tribute. Of all Budapest's statues we found this the most poignant. A wonderfully touching way to remember the sad history of this beautiful city.
Moving . Walk down the river , enjoy the beautiful scenery, then come to the shoes . It's a must see , and a sad reminder of history . Take a moment , take a picture , don't forget .
OMG. One of the most moving memorials I have ever been to. After learning and realizing what it represents it almost takes your breath away and gives you chills. Its beautiful.

A part of history that should never be forgotten. . This is the most moving monument I've ever seen & I'm not ashamed to admit it had me in tears. If your visiting Budapest then I would recommend going to see this but take some tissues!

A moving and understated monument. During the last year of WWII, as the Hungarian fascist party reached power and compelled by the occupying German SS, tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews were rounded up. Most were loaded on trains and sent for hard labor and extermination to Auschwitz and other camps in Germany and Poland. On the night of January 8 1945, dozens of Jews were lined up on the Eastern bank of the Danube and executed: there bodies fell or were dumped into the river. IN 2005, sculptor Gyula Pauer composed this monument, consisting of 60 pairs of shoes, made of iron and placed on the banks of the Danube at the approximate site of this horrendous event.

Metal Shoes. We went to see the Memorial next to the Danube. It was a great sobering experience. Learning what exactly happened at this location certainty helps understand and appreciate the memorial.

River stroll.. This is a walk we did every day, a walk from Margaret bridge to the Chain bridge. On the way you have the wonderful Parliament building to the left before stopping at the Shoes a very moving place where many thousands of people stop to reflect on the cruelty of man to man.
shoes. People like to put candles in those shoes. And we would like them to be lightened at night. Beautiful view of the Parliament and over the Danube and other buildings on the other side.

Very poignant memorial. We went to see the shoes on the banks of the Danube, in front of the Parliament Building. It is a very poignant memorial that makes us remember the victims of mans inhumanity to their fellow human beings.

True art. This is one of the most profoundly moving art pieces I have ever viewed. Standing where it happened. Reflecting on the symbology of the shoes...knowing the significance of each one profoundly moves the soul. Do not miss this while in Budapest. Never forget. 60 pairs of shoes, 600 shot into the Danube, 600,000 Hungarian Jews killed, 6 million Jews total killed.

A touching tribute . I found this sculpture really touching. There is no brutal signs describing what the shoes symbolise but I feel like it is fairly obvious. A very beautiful memorial that is peaceful and not standard like lots of memorials tend to be.

The Past, the Present and the Future (?). This memorial is equally topical today as it was after World War II; Europe on the other side of dangerous waters. A very moving and special place along the Danube.

Very moving experience. A small but very moving tribute of sculptures along the river representing the losses of the war. The different shapes, sizes and styles of shoes really do hit home, especially the tiny shoes of children. Worth spending some time over and reading up on the related history whilst you're there
Shoes. Very moving as I know the story behind the shoes. A board descibing why they are there would be useful for other people
Poinent. Gives you a real feel of how lives were lost in the Holocaust, so sad. A very Poinent reminder of the war.

Incredibly moving. I didn't expect to be moved to tears as I was. A very sad memorial to such a tragic event in the not so distant past. Very important I think in understanding the struggle within Hungary now to reconcile their past.
Sentimental. Take your time to absorb what that really means for today's history of all people and not just the suffering that the Jewish people had to endure during WWII.
Beautiful and subtle memorial. A very moving, and human memorial. Not artsy or imposing. It's important to never forget the human cost of our politics and policies.
Take time here. It's not a big site or anything but it's poignant ; seeing the shoes at the side of the Danube makes you think of the people who once wore them .
A must see. A very sobering experience. For me, shoes are very much part of real people. A reminder of shocking events in the past .....
Thought provoking. Important to take a few moments to remember. Just to take a bit of time to sit and reflect. Easy to miss though

A Sobering Experience.. This memorial won't take you long to visit but you must go and see.During the war, Jews were lines up on the bank of the river, told to remove their shoes before being shot in the back with arrows allowing the bodies to flow down the river.This is a big reminder of what really happened. It was actually quite emotional.Another must see land mark.
Moving. This was a very moving experience, especially if you have visited the Terror Museum and understand the reigns of Terror under Arrow Cross and the Soviets.
Danube shoes. We walked down to see the exhibit from our hotel. It was heart wrenching to see the shoes and what they represented.

Hauntingly Sad. So Sad!!! A haunting reality check of yesteryear. So hard to take and to understand what went on back then but nice that they see it fit to pay tribute to those who lost their lives back then in such a horrible way.

Serene. Beautiful and very sad and pointing memorial. Very cleverly done and thought provoking, just so very sad, terrible times in this country's past. Well done to the designer, maximum effect, respect 100%.
very moving. came by this by chance, not very well listed but so glad I had seen it very moving and sad. do check this out

Symbolic. The nature of this memorial was touching and very powerful, it's not showy and over the top but extremely poignant especially the children's shoes. My only disappointment was the fact that it was so messy with old silver tealight holders, dead flowers, stones and some rubbish. I appreciate that people have wanted to honour the anniversary date but it's a shame that it's not restored to its original intention. I appreciate others will have differing views.

A moving visual. When we went to Budapest, I definitely wanted to see this landmark. It was difficult to understand its location. So let me tell you it's almost in front of the Parliament Building on the Danube. It's a good reminder of the atrocities committed against the Jewish people, but so sad. I highly recommend you stop by and spend a moment and get this picture locked in your mind so we never repeat this history. It would be a good learning experience for your teenage children as well.

Neat!. When I walked by, and saw some people taking pictures, I wondered what these shoes were for. Later, I found out the purpose and meaning of it. It's neat, but sad. It's a memorial. Offers good photo point, and the landmark architecture on the Buda side are just right across the river.

Truly moving . Upon arrival in Budapest after checking in to our hotel we walked along the Danube to this tribute to the victims of the Nazis. We were moved to tears by this simple yet elegant memorial. Sometimes there just aren't any words to describe an experience, this is one of them. Must be seen.

A Sad place to visit. The shoes on the Danube Promonade in Budapest, Hungry are a very thought provoking area to visit in this beautiful city. They signify just another time in this world where man decided that lives of others were not important. Children, women,and men were murdered by an enemy, simply because the enemy wanted their shoes. When will madness in our world end??? Will it ever?

Memorial. You have to see this in memory of all the Jews killed it's very poignant along the Danube and it's not far from the parliament building . Men's women and children's shoes make it a sad reminder .

Very moving. There isn't one can say much about this memorial to the numerous jews who were butchered by the nazis also on this spot by shooting them into the river Danube. The memorial speaks it all.
I love this kind of monuments . What can I say? This is a beautiful and heartbreaking tribute to those who were killed during the war.
Must see in Budapest. All visitors to Budapest should see this and understand what hatred man is capable of and what damage man can do.

Poignant reminder, beautiful tribute. My boyfriend and I took a walk along the Danube on our first night and came to visit this memorial. There were quite a few people there even though it was a chilly February evening. Candles had been lit inside the shoes, there were balloons too and the atmosphere was haunting but warm at the same time. We sat a while and just got lost in our thoughts. It's a beautiful memory for me.
quietly powerful. The shoes are a reminder of WWII and were quite poignant to see. At the water's edge on the Pest side of Budapest, they are a spot for quiet reflection.

It says it all.. I have visited this small part of the Danube more than 3 times, every time I go through here it gets to me. The horrors of the human race against each other during those years are a scar in our history and this place just reminds me of how valuable life is and how we should respect others no matter their where they come from.
They are just shoes. They are just shoes, but great to see and can be visited easily when travelling around the city. You need to see them for yourself!
Interesting and contemplative attraction. Beautiful memorial to a slightly harrowing event. Worth a quite walk by during a tour of the city. Really close to all other attractions

Moving tribute to slaughtered Jews. This little known art installation is a must see - right behind the Parliament on the edge of the Danube. An artist has created and installed bronze shoes to represent the shoes of Jews who were brought there, forced to strip (hence the shoes they left behind) and shot.

Not an easy place to go - gut-wrenching. Apparently, the Hungarian government won't allow the plaques to say that the 60,000 victims were Jews. So, you have no idea who was murdered here and how many...
horrible !!. when we saw our people's history in budapest, it was very hard to get in mind. some of our families were there this times.

A great reminder of terrible days. These metal shoes are placed almost in front of the Parliament building! Quite worth a look if you are walking by, it reminds us off difficult times and of the sufferings of the Jews and families who were thrown in the river.
Powerful. This simple but thought-provoking work of art is definitely worth visiting. The memorial is elegantly done, from both a formalistic and a political perspective.
sobering. a thought provoking monument to eastern struggle against the original iron lady. truly remarkable how few people you will see here..

A haunting and very moving memorial. The most relevant memorial that I have seen for the horrors of Hitler. I came upon it by accident and found it very difficult to look at. It really personalises the horror. Not for the faint hearted.
Poignant memorial. A beautiful and thought provoking memorial to victims of a second world war atrocity. Well worth taking some time out to visit

Simple yet remarkable. This will be a highlight of my visit to Budapest. They spend millions on walls, museums, fountains. This remarkable holocaust memorial is profoundly moving. This may be the most heartwrenching memorial seeing shoes lined up on the banks of the Danube knowing thousands of Jews lost their lives in such a horrendous way. It is steps from the bridge and Parliament and is really a must see for a time of reflection.

Simple but moving. Simple but moving memorial of shoes that had to be left behind by Jewish people before they were forced into the river. Some have flowers and candles. if visiting get onto the waterside as soon as possible, it is difficult to cross the road at the shoes.
Moving. We came upon this monument by chance. It was very moving. There is so many historical details we don't know. It is important to remember, lest the mistakes of history are repeated.

Remember,,,. The memorial of shoes reminds us that in the same way that the human being is capable of the best, is also often capable of the most horrific acts such as to take the life of someone just because they are different from you ... a place to visit in silence and to reflect ... a lot ....

worth a visit. worth a visit when you are walking around Budapest, it is just behind the parliament building and served by tram as well. Do read up on the history if you would like to understand why the shoes are there......
Moving. Very moving tribute to the people who lost their lives. I found it to be fitting and a way of remember to never let this happen again. Very poignant position.
Lovely memorial. The memorial lies on the bank of the Danube, not far from Parliament buildings. Definitely worth going to see.
Very moving. This installation is a haunting reminder of Hitler's slaughter of the Jews of Budapest. It's a short stroll from the where our river cruise ship docked

Powerful Memorial. The monument is located on the river's edge, a short stroll away from the Parliament building on the Pest side. It is a moving and powerful memorial to the Jews massacred in Budapest during World War II, when they were ordered to take off their shoes before being shot in the back and falling into the Danube. It is very sad to think what these poor people went through. It's a must-see when visiting Budapest.
the shoes. Whenever you pass by you must remember the past never to be forgotten It symbolizes what the citizens of this beautiful city went through.Even on a rainy day is worth to visit .
Shoe Memorial. Very simple touching memorial! The candy left in a child's shoes tugs at your heartstrings. A must see to experience Budapest

Impressive.. I have seen many monuments and/or statues in Budapest. Knowing the story behind the shoes, this monument I will remember once back home again and the others will be long forgotten. It is a very strong statement in all its simplicity. The cruelty of a war...
Very moving. I would suggest you visit the House if Terror first to understand about this memorial. It is very moving.

In its Simplicity a Very Powerful Message. This memorial isn't clearly displayed on maps. I suggest one reads the history behind it to really appreciate the significance of it. A simple but powerful message.

An Artistic Memorial for Sad Event. Located on the Danube boardwalk on the Pest side, this chilling exhibit commemorates the victims of the Arrow Cross militia. Not a "Must-Visit", but If you're on your way to Margaret Island from the area of the Parliament then it's worth a few minutes stop.

Heavy. If you think of the fact that you're standing where many people were shot to death, or drowned becaude they were tied to someone who was shot...it is a beautiful monument, with a history never to be forgotten

An important memorial to the WWI tragedy here. It is worth the walk to remember and recognize the horror that occurred here. The only downside is you must walk a distance because there is no place to stop or park a car nearby.
Unmissable. Such a beautiful, poignant memorial to a sad part of history. You cannot help but be moved by it. Not too far from parliament building so well worth a visit.

Someone's thoughts. its nice to see these and then read about them.
a tiny stretch but well placed. catches the eye. They kind of tell a story by itself.

Very moving. A sad chapter in Hungarian history was how they killed or shipped off to concentration camps, thousands of Jews. When they killed some of the Jews by shooting them in the back while the stood on the banks of the Danube River, they made them take off their shoes. The display on the riverbank is iron replicas of the shoes of men, women, and children that were murdered and their bodies thrown into the river. Seeing the shoes of women and children brings feelings of despair that anyone could do such a crime against the innocent. The shoes have become a memorial, with many filled with flowers and other memorabilia.
Sad, thoughtful memorial. Shoes on the danube is a very emotional and thoughtful memorial. Definitely worth a visit whilst walking along the river.

Credit to the designer. This subtle, well thought out memorial creates a very moving feeling and one that stayed with me for a long time. Found on the bank on the Pest side walking from the Chain bridge towards the Parliament building. Well worth taking time to appreciate.

Very nostalgic . Worth taking a 10 min walk out of the centre just to see these. Although I'm too young to remember the war the sense of loss hits you as you stand on the water's edge and believe that there were actually people who stood in the same spot.

Emotional Display.. Very emotional tribute that gave us chills as we read the story behind the Shoes on the Danube. I urge you to stop by what we considered to be one of the most moving memorials that can be found in this fantastic city.

Beautifully made artwork and such a sad reminder.... To see these metal representations of so many pairs of cast-aside shoes and to understand why they are here is so saddening and demands time for respectful reflection on a world that we hope has now long gone by...
Shoes on the Danube. This beautiful, simple and poignant memorial is a must - so that we never forget what happened in Budapest - people put candles in the shoes to remember those killed.
interesting. interesting idea to grow plants inside it , just new idea nothing there to do other than chill ........

A time for reflection. Situated on the edge of the river these bronze shoes are just so poignant it brings home how cheap the Nazi's thought life was compared to a pair of shoes. It is worth sitting for a few minutes and reflecting how fortunate we are
Interesting. It is an interesting site close by to the Parliament right on the river edge. Good to visit and to understand the history.

Very Emotional and Should See. I was on a River Cruise that was docked at the Chain Bridge and this is a short walk up from there. The emotions that this display takes you is worth going out of your way to see. It will not take a long visit but it can be very thought provoking as you think about what this represents. The child's shoes really struck a chord with me.
MOVING TRIBUTE. This is a very moving tribute to the victims of the Nazi regime. Makes one appreciate their life in the US without fear of reprisal
Romantic or Dirty?. You can light a candle inside for nice photos, you can go on your away back/to Parlament. Dirty, should be clean more often.

Not Forgotten. We learned about this on the bus enroute to the Parliament tour. My wife decided it was a priority to go back and see on our own. This is one of those memorials that is easily missed if it is not pointed out...but worth visiting. We noticed people put tea candles inside the shoes.

Small, but impressive. We visited the Parlement first. After this we crossed the street and just walked back towards the Chain Bridge. You will see the shoes during that walk. Very pretty and impressive. For great pictures, visit them during sunset!

Poignant. We walked here after we'd been to the Terror Museum which explained everything that Hungary went though during and after the war. It was slightly snowing and we were the only people here so it felt very sad. If you're into your history definitely worth the walk to find them as it gives you a moment to reflect on the people and what they went through.

Don't miss it. A place full of history.. A place full of history. A place that can put you on thinking on the human nature. A place that can make you a better person if you undestand what happened here.

It's beautiful and touching. It's a free attraction that's easy to get too. I've seen photos, however once you're there the shoes are so realistic it's very sad and touching. There's truly a sense of gloom when you walk by and try to put yourself in the time period of all these people being slaughtered. Go for a walk, check it out.

Very moving. This was one art exhibit we knew about before planning our trip to visit Budapest. Few sculptures tell a true story that simply and powerfully. The empty shoes provide such a sad contrast to the otherwise serene and peaceful Danube. Do not miss the Shoes on the Danube Bank!

A must!!!!. A memorial to remember the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, then shot at the edge so that their bodies fell into the water. The shoes look like real leather but are made of steel, it was worth the long walk it's on the pest side near the parliament there are no signs so keep an eye out for it.

Horrifying. Words cannot express the importance of seeing this memorial.We can never appreciate what the victims of the Holocaust endured, but for some reason listening to the water of the Danube lapping just feet below the shoes made to represent those that were killed in that exact location was more than thought provoking, more than saddening, more than horrifying. This memorial is something you need to witness and experience.

A piece of history. Located right next to Danube at the Pest side, Promenade Memorial makes you shiver. The history of people that were forced to take off their shoes before getting shot and thrown to the river. A visit to the Hollocaust museum is a place to go before Danube Promenade Memorial in order to understand the deeper meaning of a simple yet so important attraction.

Thought provoking!. This is on the Pest side of the river near the Parliament building. A very poignant reminder of the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were said to be ordered to take off their shoes, then shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river. The shoes look like real leather but are made of steel and people have put tea lights and religious items in and around the shoes. It is extremely moving and emotive, although like a lot of monuments in Budapest there are no barriers around them which is hard to get used to and you aren't sure about different cultural practices but I did find it hard to comprehend when people were putting their feet in the shoes, but then a lot of other monuments kids/adults were climbing over too so perhaps it is a Hungarian cultural thing.

Heartbreaking Memorial. This memorial doesn't have the crowds of tourists the way that many other Budapest monuments do. In fact, it was basically deserted when my friends and I got there. There weren't a lot of signs so you'll need to check a map even though it's right on the river.You can't get the impact of the monument from looking at the pictures. It's absolutely heartbreaking to stand on the side of the water and see what people saw in their last moments. The shoes are purposely made in different sizes and types, and it emphasizes the range of who stood there in their last moments. The children's shoes are a particularly painful sight. The shoes really look like real leather even though they're metal.People leave behind flowers and tealights in memory of those who lost their lives.
So-so . Nothing special cause of a lot of many kinds of rubbish inside the shoes... :-( Flowers, I can understand but bottles and other stuff nope...

River cruise . This was such a sad and touching experience. The shoes are lined up on the edge of the river wall. These shoes represent the Jews who were killed during the war. You'll see children's shoes, men's and women's . Some have little mementos inside them. Very touching ....

Moving monument . A poignant reminder of fallen Jews killed in the name of war. I had a great grandparent who was a Russian jew so meant a lot to see this. People have put tealights, religious items and even a peace Lily. So simple yet so moving.
Really poignant. A small and poorly signposted memorial which is nevertheless heart trending and personal. The shoes represent those Jews shot on the banks of the river Danube into the river.

Powerful exhibiton of real life event in past.. A very clever exhibition made on the path of the Danube and it is so emotional to look at those shoes of all sizes including little one.The shoes all look like real leather but actually made of steel.And it is free to look at.Worth it if you visit Budapest and a walk along the Danube is just as good to see this town the house of Parliament.
moving place. There is a place on the river, where you can see parts of shoes on the shore - this is sign for the murdered jews

Pausing to See the Danube When It Was a Place of Death. Before the Russians arrived at the end of WWII, many Jews were rounded up from their "safe homes" and marched to the edge of the Danube to be shot and thrown in. Some were not shot, but tied to those who were and pushed in to drown in an ice cold river to drown. During the time, the Duna's image changed for those who were left to live in the crumbling city. Instead of a place of beauty and pleasure, it was a place of death and immense sadness. I think to come on a cold cloudy day at dusk (most of the murders were done in the night) and stand among the shoes can help you connect a little with the starkness and tragedy of this time.

Thought Provoking. During WWII thousands of Jews were executed on this spot at the edge of the Danube and their bodies thrown into the river. Before they were killed they had to take off their shoes because the citizens of Budapest needed them more than they did. This memorial is a tribute to those killed. Dozens of pairs of bronze shoes (modeled after actual shoes from that time) are lined up along the Danube. It looks like the owners just stepped out of them. People come from all over the world to put flowers or light candles at the memorial. It is one of the most heart wrenching memorials of the war that I have seen. It is just down from the parliament building and a must see if you are in Budapest.

Very distressing.. Whilst on our Danube river cruise the commentator asked us to look right.We all looked on as she explained why all the shoes were on the side of the river.Apparently they are all cast in iron......what a tragic story.visited 4th may 2016
Visir Budapest. Beat the parlament YouTube will find a memory of the many jews deportet from the city the last month of second world war 2

Emotional. Didn't know what this attraction was all about until I saw it. The meaning on the ground made everything clear....very emotional to see the shoes....and to learn of the history. Pay this tribute a visit...it will make you think.

Haunting memorial. Poignant spot to pause for thought and reflect on the sad history. Lovely spot with a great view to take in as well, but primarily the memorial and tribute to the Jews is essential visiting.
Should Never Happen Again. I gave 5* because it's really worth to see and helps remembering. Hopefully it helps everyone to make sure coward killers never gain power.

Heartbreaking. Just take a stroll along the Danube and you will walk upon this beautiful touching memorial. It really is extremely heartbreaking especially the toddler shoes. Sit along the Danube and take in all the history that comes with it.

Sad but a nice promenade.. It's a beautiful promenade witha beautiful view to make on a sunny day. The shoes represent a sad piece of history.
Take a time to admire the soroundings and the river.

We must not forget.. Spent a few quiet minutes at Memorial for Budapest Jews killed by the Germans. This memorial is bronze shoes remembering Jews who were marched to the Danube and then machine gunned so that they fell into the river.
Worth the time although you will not "enjoy" it.
We must not forget and we must remind those who would forget.
Somber but yet inspiring. . Eye opening tribute to the Jews that lost their lives in WW2. Tourists leaving flowers in the shoes made the experience even more poignant.

Depends what time you go. As you can see from my photos it's a great spot for some quiet reflection of the atrocities the nazis commited, if you can find a moments peace with all the mobs of tourists. Maybe going early evening would be better.

Sad but great memorial . This memorial is really sad as it shows shoes from all ages who were shot and thrown into the river during the war. It was lovely time see candles and flowers by some to show they are not forgotten.

Taylor's Tours. I came across this site when walking back from the Parliament Building on the banks of the Danube. It was very moving to see these items especially the small children's shoes. A very sad reminder of man's inhumanity to man. I would suggest that you visit if only to make you think of what happened not only here but worldwide.
If your on the river walk take a moment to stop and see thsi.. Read up on the history, many people stop and place flowers in the shoes. It is a rememberance of a bad time.
Poignant reminder of unhappy times. A very thought provoking memorial using cast iron copies of the shoes of Jews shot by the Nazis on the bank of the Danube. Lovely and sad at the same time.
Beautiful . The shoes are certainly eye catching - however this whole waterside area is definitely worth a visit. With the parliament building to one side and buda on the other it is very picturesque
A Somber Reminder of a Terrible Time..... this is located almost in front of the Parliament Building - it is a sad reminder of what happened there. It is a must see.
Emotive!. These shoes are to honour the departing Jews during WW2. An emotional tribute (although I felt Haribo in the children's shoes a little irreverent).

Very moving. We walked past the shoes on our way back from Margaret Island to our hotel. Very interesting and very moving. A little more information explaining the background to the shoes would have been helpful a the site.

Very touching memorial. Memorial to Jews killed in WWII and whose bodies were tossed into the Danube River. I believe there are 60 pairs of shoes. it is a good thing we heard the story from our tour guide because there was only 1 small plaque discussing what happened.

A moving memorial. I had read about this memorial before we got to Budapest and wanted to visit it. Along the Danube just between the Chain Bridge and Parliament. A very simple but profound tribute to the Jews who suffered in the hands of the Germans during the 2nd world war. This is incredibly moving and made us very emotional. After visiting Auschwitz last year, this visit stirred memories of the suffering that families and individuals went through all across Europe in their own ways. A beautiful setting for contemplation.

Poignant tribute to the jews. Didn't think we would be so affected by a line of cast iron shoes along the Danube. Very moving tribute to the Hungarian Jews who had to remove their shoes before being shot riverside in the Second World War.

See it. This memorial has an interesting historical significance that it is a little emotional. People put candles and flowers in the shoes. At some point you should walk down the Danube, and when you do, stop here and take some time to reflect.
Incredible. This is an incredible place to visit. The history & emotion behind this sculpture/s are worth the visit, it's also just a lovely walk along the promenade.

Missing meaningful signs - still strongly tecomended. I was surprised to see people know nothing about the place and about the murder story. There was no meaningfuk explanation. Beside that, if you know the stort, strongly recomended.

So sad!. We were staying at a hotel right across this location and from our balcony kept seeng people walking very slowly around this area. We finally made it to visit the Parlament building and when walking back towards downtown came right to see this memorial of the Jewish people of met their death by being shot and their bodies dumped in the river.

A moving tribute... What an impressive memorial, on the waterfront, just along from the Parliament. So moving, and one can just imagine those who had to jump into the river, its symbolic and meaningful.
Touching. Touching installation. Makes you think of all the horrible things, that were done. 2nd world war was a terrible time for humans.
A jump in the past. This location remind the WW... It's a tribute to the poor people shooting during the WW. A pieces of history that we never forget.

Beautiful memorial. The backstory behind these copper shoes is heartbreaking. I didn't realise what a rich Jewish heritage Hungary had until I visited. This particular sight really inspired me to read more about the impacts of WW2 in Hungary.
A heart rending tribute to the lost. NOT TO BE MISSED.. This monument is very emotionally touching and makes you think long and hard about how lucky you are.
Shoes On the Danube Memorial.. A rather sad reminder of the past politics of the country . Thought provoking , rather moving , be careful with children this memorial is right on the rivers edge.

Touching memorial. A sad memorial along the Danube. There were flowers and candles put into the shoes. There were a pair of tidy kid shoes which remind us the innocent kids were killed during the cruel war. Worth a visit.
powerful sculpture. well worth a stroll along the river to see this very poignant remembrance sculpture - the mix of shoes from children to adults is a sad sight
Shoes on the Danube. A thought provoking and moving memorial. We visited the shoes on the Danube after visiting the Terror Museum.

Beautiful and touching memorial - must visit in Budapest . Very touching and awakening memorial. To stand on the same spot as some of the victims of the nazis really drives home the history that we all read in the books. The shoes on the Danube was one of the highlights of my Budapest trip and I feel m its a very fitting and sensitive way for the city to honour those that lost their lives on the spot. Visit is recommended
must!. every one who visit budapest must stop near the Shoes on the Danube and remmber and never forget the cruelty of the people that killed innocent jews - men, women and children in 1944...

Reminder of the past. We visited the shoes on our final day. A moving memory of a horrific event. What let it down to me was the old candle holders etc just left there. Appreciate people want to leave a candle. Moving tribute to a horrific event and a must visit.
A quiet moment of reflection. Easy to find on the river bank. Take a moment to reflect on history and whether we have learnt anything from it .....
Surprise stop and emotional. We came by these by default while we were walking along the Danube towards the Houses of Parliament. It was very emotional monument and well worth the stop.
Impressive. We made a family trip. Thanks to those who made this memorial. Easily reachable by metro. Short walking there.
Unique. Our guide expained the meaning of these shoes on the Danube. Very important part of history and unique art.

Sad but beautiful memorial. I thought this was a fitting memorial for such a sad part of history. Seeing the shoes with things that people have left, flower, candy in the childs shoe, etc really hits you in the heart as to what these people were put through. I think if there had just been a plaque it wouldn't have been as meaningful.
It leaves you speechless.. It's a little bit hard to find and surely is not a must see attraction but it's a powerful memorial full of meaning.

A touching tribute. It seems almost inappropriate to rate this given what it represents - however I have done so even if it just encourages people to see it and learn about what happened.A touching tribute and definately one to see.

those empty shoes are a shocking memorial. walking on the bank of the danube. with the pastoral surrounding you are encountered with a shocking memorial of the horrors of world war 2. those empty shoes are a vivid reflection of the horrifying years of the war. i started crying thinking of the men, women and children who were shot and thrown to the river just because they were jews!!!
interesting and touching monument. Important memorial site for WW2 inocent victims. Nicely done, the simplicity of themonument makes it so profound!

Yet another reminder. We had already visited the Jewish museum in Prague where there are 80,000 names of Czech victims of the Holocaust and a heart rending room of pictures drawn by children who had been taken to the "model"ghetto built by the Nazis at Marienbad and had been moved to tears by that experience, but the sight of the 60 pairs of shoes along the banks of the Danube (recreated in iron) representing to 6 million Jews who died in the death camps was yet another reminder of what still seems to me to be absolutely ununderstandable behavior. My hat is off to Budapest for creating this memorial and I was further touched to see that many of the shoes had small candles in them and these are lit up at night.Don't miss it! You can get there easily on the red Metro line.

A very sad place. This is the saddest place I have ever seen in my travels. The Shoes on the Danube Bank is a memorial which was created by film director Can Togay with sculptor Gyula Pauer as a remembrance of the Jews who were killed in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to remove their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the Danube river and this represents their shoes left behind on the bank.

Poingant. Any visitor needs to remember who did this. It was the Hungarian Arrow Cross and a visit to the shameful monument in the nearby Liberty Square depicting an "innocent" Hungary is worthwhile and note the ongoing protest. It is a pity that the shoes are not more easily accessible.
Meaninnful genocidal monument . Near to Hungary Parliament and on the Duna edge. If you have gone to see the parliament you should see these metal shoes.

Moving memorial. This moving tribute to those people who were executed during WW2 is close to the Parliament Building on the edge of the Danube. It consists of pairs of shoes made out of metal in likeness to the type worn at the time, it is sad to think of the tragic end to these lives. People visiting seem to place candles in the shoes in remembrance. Its a place to reflect of the waste of life that occurs in war. You should visit this reminder of the past
Simple yet powerful. One of the most simple, beautiful and full of meaning memorials I've ever visited. You can feel the aura of the place, definitly go there considering its close to the parliament.

Very poignant. We went to look for them as we had to see them! however if you just were just to one across them at the side of the River it must be a stark thought as to what had happenedAnother must see of a trip to this beautiful City

So worth adding to your list of places to see. This unique tribute to lost Jewish lives will leave you speechless. I'm not sure I can think of any other memorial site that touched my emotions as much as this. It's shockingly beautiful. Go.
Shoes. Next to the Parliament Building but it is sad to see where these people were killed in the crossfire
Chill-out and take pics. Not much too see unless you know the story, but an interesting place to have a break reflecting on the river Danube views and take a few unusual pictures.
Surprise finding!. Sad reminder of the execution of Jewish women and children by the Nazis and who were then thrown into the Danube.Commemorated by lots of shoes of various sizes.

Poignant and Mesmerizing. The story behind the shoes left behind is horrific and should not be forgotten. This memorial serves that purpose so very well. Along a river where luxury ships cruise sits a beautifully simple reminder of man's inhumanity. It's beauty is in its simplicity. A lesson for all of any faith and a valuable teaching experience for older children. Don't miss this memorial.
Memorial. One of the most interesting memorial monument i have ever see. Very touchful and you understand that Hungarian are not hiding their history.

A Touching Memorial. As the plague states "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by arrow cross militiamen in 1944-45" Erected 16th April 2005. It does not state that these victims were Jews who were killed for no reason. From what I understand they were asked to remove their shoes before being shot to death. I wept.......

Very poignant memorial . The sight of all the shoes at this memorial certainly stops your breath for a second or two as you think about what it represents. Had a chat about this with some local people and they seem to offer a different story but the memorial is there and represents the death of innocent people all in the name of war. Very poignant.

Moving in it's simplicity. As others have said this was really moving. It's simplicity makes it even more poignant. Take time to read the reason why the local people placed this memorial in front of the Government statue/memorial and it makes it even more poignant. It's also near the Parliament buildings and the beautiful views alongside the Danube and so well worth wandering slowly along the streets taking in the beauty and atmosphere. The fact it's so understated makes it even more moving.
Spooky. A well done chilling memorial to an act of pure evil/ men at their lowest, on an amazingly beautiful nature background!.

A Moving Memorial. Just a few steps from the square where Soviet Tanks mowed down unarmed Hungarians in 1956, another memorial can be found. Forty bronzed pairs of shoes evoke emotion and sorrow for 40 Jews executed by pro Nazi Militia in 1944. Throes walking slowly past were almost silent, many wept at the sight of a pair of baby shoes, so poignant, such a harsh reality of lives lost.

Sad and amazing. In Budapest u can see lot of thing's in the street that show the war or other bad things.
When I run in the danova saw that and stop and it's really make u think on your life ...

agony and reality of a history that is complicated. This part of the world defies easy answers to hard realities. "Lesser evils" have been the choices taken by those who say they had no other choice. The shoes make their own statement, I chose to view and hurt for mans ability to be in a place of such beauty and see testimony to mans basest conduct. We must not forget nor think we are not capable of those things.

Memorial site. The memorial site is chilling reminder of a dark age in the Hungarian history in WW2.The artist try to show the monstrosities that the Natzi's and the Hungarian party Nyilaskeresztes did to by executing jews on the bank's of the Danube.

Impressive. Budapest honors it's pay with this monument of one of the city's dark pages.That we never forget the brutality of WWII.Take a couple of minutes in our busy live to realize what people can do against each other.
Poignant. 60 pairs of bronze shows modelled on footwear from the 1940s commemorate those who were shot into the Danube during the 2nd world war.
A Must See in Budapest. The Shoes on the Danube is a very moving art installation honoring the Hungarian Jews who were killed along the banks of the Danube at the end of WWII
Very Humbling. To see the Memorial was very touching and signified the atrocities the Jews faced living in Budapest.
Walk along the Danube. When taking a walk along the Danube, came across this beautiful and very poignant memorial to Jewish victims during the war.

A sad reminder of the atrocities commited.. This memorial can almost bring you to tears. There is a plaque embedded into the walkway: TO THE MEMORIES OF THE VICTIMS SHOT INTO THE DANUBE BY ARROWCROSS MILITIAMEN 1944-1945....this location is within walking distance of the Parliament and should be visited by all including minors who need to be reminded of how heartless and cruel one man can be to another.

Disappointed. Although quite poignant we didn't feel this had the same impact as the memorial to the fall of communism does in Prague. I think we thought it might be bigger. If you are going to walk along the river bank to see the parliament building then it is worth a look but we wouldn't go out of our way to visit,

One of my favorite memorial. This place is a memorial of human violance and brutality but expressing it in a beautiful and gentle way. This place is not a juwish monument only, this place is for all the diffenent people. Gays, romas, all different minorities and different religious. All were shot to the river here who are different. I am different. Be different, be free, stay alive! Sit here for a few minutes and feel the energy of the place, any time is great to walk there!
Sad story. Just in front of Parliament house , around 200 m walk to Chain bridge side on the Tuna river side ... Very sad story , after seeing the shoes it makes more sense than before...

A poignant reminder of the Jewish Holocaust.. I read about the memorial before my trip but happened to come across it walking back from the Parliament building. I found it quite moving with small plants having been planted in some of the shoes

Beautiful tribute. We stumbled upon this memorial as we were walking back from Parliament. It is a beautiful tribute to a tragic event. There was a strong sense of emotion as people paid tribute to the many people who were killed there... different shoes capturing the diverse range of people killed. Would have liked a little more information about the circumstances of their deaths.
Sad history. I was there with the free walking tour, the history they represent is amazing and is a good way to remember the victims of the second world war.

Very sad.. This is a very touching memorial. With a much greater meaning. I challenge anyone not to feel a great deal of sadness when looking over these shoes and over the bank of the danube. Knowing what these shoes represent. A sad time in budapest/Europe's history.

A moment of thought. We walked pretty much the length of the river for fun but also knowing this was on it. This is a simple, yet moving memorial and tribute to those whose final moments happened here. It is not a big song and dance around it but when you stand next to it and reflect it really hits home. The entire city is steeped with history, some good, some bad. This is one of those that should not be forgotten.

Poignant reminder. A simple but poignant reminder of the terrible treatment of the Jews during WW2. On the riverbank near Parliament House - blink and you might miss them, but make the effort to find them. It is the least we could do to honour and remember all those people murdered just because of their religion.
very moving tribute. the story behind this tribute to victims was very moving & made you think about what some people went through really made you think how lucky some of u are

Near Parliament. After touring the Parliament we were walking along the river back to our hotel when we stumbled on the memorial to those who fell in the 1950's revolution. It's a very simple memorial, literally just shoes, many disintegrating, most filled with small gravel to keep them in place, some with flowers or a plant in them, some with votive candles. It was simple but moving.

Horrific. Not really a tourist site but a stark reminder of atrocities of a bygone era. Saying that, a must visit as it puts so much in perspective. A haunting feel as one departs, knowing that this symbolizes that fact that so many were shot.

Strong reminder. A piece of public sculpture can be average, can make sense or be beautiful. This one is way more: with a handful of bronze shoes standing alone on the river bank it tells a deep and sad story to remember in order to never happen again.

Why we travel. seeing this memorial reminds me why we travel. Without traveling most of us would not know of such tragic events. The pictures we took here have brought up the most questions from our friends, than any other images we took during our Danube trip.
Very poignant. Simple yet stunning piece of artwork that delivers a powerful message. Definitely worth a look when visiting the Parliament - or even if not.

A moment to remember. These bronze shoes were placed here as a monument to those who had to remove their shoes before being shot. Jews and other prisoners at the end of WWII. Tiny baby shoes, Women's small shoes and men's shoes. No one was spared. Go to remember
Holiday. Worth just walking along the Danube has it is lovely and to go and look at the shoes and read about the history very sad.

A part of History we never learned. This was the most touching "monument" The tiny shoes that are lined up along the Danube river are bronzed and tell a very sad and tragic story of what the Jewish children endured. Get ready to pull out your Kleenex, it will tug at your heart strings!

Very sad indeed!. I was very keen to see the memorial. I went there, took the usual 'touristy' selfies. But at the end of it all; it was quiet saddening & depressing to see them. Of course, please do visit the place... Not your typical tourist spot!

Very moving. This memorial is located near the Parliament building. It's a short walk from the metro and the yellow trolley that runs up and down the Danube Promenade. Trolley tickets must be bought in the metro, not available on board. Be sure to validate once you board the trolley. Fines are steep and they really do monitor. I was stopped to verify mine was validated as I exited.
