Monument to the Jews. An artistic monument of 60 pairs of metal shoes depicting the Jews that were killed during the Second World War in Budapest.
Humbling. We stumbled across this tribute as we walked the bank of the Danube. Certainly puts life into perspective. Very well done to the artist who did this.
Amazing experience. Love it. Definitely recommend for everyone visiting Budapest. The location is pretty easy to find, as its on the riverbank and not too far from the Parliament.
Must visit. Very touching memorial. There are flowers and candles on shoes. It really makes you think. It represents war and evilness of people.
A moving tribute . On the bank of the river, sculptures of discarded shoes scattered amongst which were flowers and lit candles. Nice to know people still remember
Interesting memorial to murdered Jews. Beside the Danube just south of Parliament. Iron shoes memorializing Jews murdered and thrown in the Danube.

Haunting Reminder of Hungary's Past. If you find yourself down by the Parliament building, walk down to the Danube to see this chilling memorial. Hundreds of thousands of jews were deported from Hungary during WWII and while there are reminders throughout Budapest, this has to be one of the most powerful.

shocking remind of the Holocaust. Shoes are there to remind of the hungarian jews arrested by the 'Nyilàs' pro-nazi army and party, many of them killed and thrown in the river, other deported. very important not to forget

Powerful image along the danube. Walking from the Parliment down the Danube you will encounter this monument. A great walk - powerful experience. Great photo opportunities as well. Many of the side streets have great cafes up from the river.
Shoes.... These are all made by local artists to remind everyone of what happened all those years ago, it's a fantastic and thoughtful tribute...

Nice little memorial, but not much information on site. I may have missed some explanatory signage around regarding the memorial, but it didn't seem like there was much in the way of clarification as to what it's purpose was, etc. We knew of it from online research, etc. That being said, it's a very tasteful little memorial. Some folks are still leaving flowers, candles, etc.

Makes One Think. Such a simple display of bronzed shoes can have a very powerful effect on one. A place to stand and reflect at the cruelty of the human race as well as the compassion people can have for one another. Definitely worth a walk past.

A lovely touching tribute. If you're heading down to the Danube shore please take the time to view this memorial it has such a horrific story. It is a pity however that some tourists do forget this and take smiling selfies or take off their shoes and try to fit their feet into the memorial!!

Very moving. I knew nothing about this memorial until I had googled Budapest. None of the guide books I had bought included it. This probably affected me more than anything else I had seen.It is a memorial to those Jewish people who were lined up on the banks of the Danube facing Buda and then shot so that they fell into the river and were washed away. The memorial is on the banks outside parliament to act as reminder.The shoes typify the different ages and gender of those killed by the arrow cross henchmen in 1944/5. It's a relatively new memorial (2005) that should be included in all guide books as its a must see.

Very meaningful symbol. one has to stop, if you are riding a vehicle because it's easy to miss the memorial. Unlike the huge and spectacular structures around, this is quite hidden...at the edge of the river. The memorial is an emotional remembrance of the love of the Jews for their countrymen. It is a symbol of an unselfish act of love for another human being. The memorial is indeed a constant reminder both for tourists and the locals of the tragedy that should never be forgotten. These shoes speak to everyone and it will has different meaning to everyone.
Worth passing by on your walk. Beautifully made, touching and historical. Pass by one your walk along Donau. It's sad, touching and beautiful at the same time. Worth seeing.

an emotional experience. I knew about the memorial before arriving in Budapest so made a point of going to it. It is a quiet but poignant reminder of what too often happens to people. I spent time just looking and pondering.
Sadly stunning. This is a must see for any visitor to Budapest. Representation of the terrible events at the end of WW2. Most people come away profoundly saddened.

Essential for visitors. On this spot hundreds of the city's Jewish men, women and children were machine-gunned by their fellow countrymen under orders from the Nazis in WWII. Their bodies fell into the river and were washed away. Before thy were murdered, they were forced to remove their coats and shoes because they could be used by German civilians.This stark reminder acts as a marvellous memorial, both to these people, and to many millions like them killed in WWII

Incredible memorial. Really touching memorial. Not much on tyne real story behind it to see there. Just a few steps from the Parliament building...Seeing all the shoes, all sizes, both genders, left in place as they were to be executed is very relate able, in terms of being able to connect. Absolutely worth seeing.

Poignant reminder . The sad scene of these shoes on the quayside shouldn't fail to move you, men's women's and children's shoes as a reminder of the horror to which 'man' succumbs to. Worth a visit if only to remind us all how lucky we are.
Very moving . A simple but effective memorial which was very moving. It's well worth a look as its so near to the parliament building and it has a very unique feel to it
Interesting history. Walking along the Danube river you can come across this piece of art. Otherwise you can keep a look out for it when taking the trams!
A moving memorial. Well worth a look at this moving memorial. There was quite a crowd and lots of flowers around the shoes when we were there.
Fitting memorial . Well designed, thought out and executed memorial to those shot in to the river Danube by the arrow cross national front party. Harrowing reminder

Moving tribute on the Danube. Worth a visit as you walk along to the parliament building. It's after the chain bridge and a lovely walk along the Danube. You cannot believe this happened to innocent people and their bravery is commemorated beautifully. Don't miss this. Budapest highlight.

Beautiful, poignant memorial. This is such a moving memorial that is done so well and is so innocuous, you'd miss it if you weren't looking for it. It is meant to represent the Jewish Hungarians that were massacred along the Danube, and is such a subtle yet powerful tribute.

Moving. This is so simple, yet so powerful. A must see whilst walking along the Danube. A tribute of Bronze shoes to honor the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II, the victims were ordered to remove there shoes and stand at the end whilst being shot & their bodies falling into the river. Terribly moving.

Moving. A moving memorial.......you need to know your history and be the sensitive type. Even more moving, is a small memorial of suitcases, shoes, belongings and stories in Independence Square, near Parliament but I don't know what it's called and can't find it on this site.......we just came across it.
Small sculpture yet really sad. To remember the Jews killed during WWII. It is worth visiting and show some respect for the people who died there.

Totally Mind Blowing Experience. You will be totally affected by the Shoes on the Danube Promenade. We didn't know what to expect when our tour guide told us to go down to the river while she was getting the car to pick us up. We walked down to the promenade and couldn't believe our eyes when we saw all the bronzed shoes on the edge of the river. You could feel the pain of what happened there. It brought goose bumps to our bodies. It's something you shouldn't miss while staying in Bupadest. It's a must see!
shoes at the Donau promenade. we had a biketour with a guide. he told a lot of the history of the shoes and a lot over the war and the protest.

shocking reminder of what happened about 70 years ago. The shoes placed on the pier by the Danub not far from the house of Parlament symbolyse the tragic death of people whose only blame was being jewish. sad part of budapest history
Really interesting. We observed these from the bus but did not know what they were. The day after we saw them again and a tour guide explained there purpose, really interesting but sad.
A moving tribute. There are many excellent statures and sculptures in Budapest, but none more moving than this simple yet powerful tribute.
Great tribute . This is a great tribute to the people who were shot into the Danube by the Nazi's during WW2. They were instructed to take their shoes off first.
Confronting. Glad we took the time to wander around Budapest and find this memorial. Very confronting, made you think of what these poor people went through, may we never forget their suffering.
Danube Shoes. Moving site and story. We were walking along the Danube and came upon the shoes, later when taking a city tour the guide told us the story of the shoes.
Nice memory. It seems really interesting and it's nice gesture as a memory of people who died there. I like the idea but I didn't like the shoes were rusted.

Sadness . This is one of the saddest things I've ever seen. The shoes are there as a permanent reminder to the suffering and persecution of the Jewish people who were marched to the river and killed. Forced to remove their shoes first as the shoes were worth more than their lives, and sent back to the wives and children of the shooters.We must never forget the suffering of those during that time.
You should visit. This is a very understated monument to treatment of fellow humans. It is located slightly before the parliament on the Chain bridge side.
Highly moving. Well worth a visit to rember the victims. This piece of art is powerful and thought provoking. A worthy memorial to those who suffered during a painful time.

An utter hipocricy for the generally anti Jewish population of Hungary. a horrible fact is that with the formation of the Arrow cross party in 1940s Hungary , this nation showed only too well it's devotion to Hitler's doctrine of hatred towards the Unter Mensch which included the Jewish section of the indigeonous population . its also a shame that the contemporary Hungarian shares these horrific & outdated views which makes a sham of this monument . It's also a shame that the Israeli's send their kids to the various execution centres located in Poland to walk around waving their flags & scowling at anyone they dont like the look of . as history shows us , all people learn from history is how to do unspeakable things to the next lot of victims , please excuse me , I have to go away & cry now .

Incredibly thought provoking.. In a City full of beautiful sculptures and artwork, this is arguably the most memorable of them all. Truly haunting, and thought provoking, and bringing the sadness of the past back to life and in a very human and touching way.

Protest. One of our most moving experiences in Budapest. A popular monument that rose in opposition to a political attempt to whitewash history. An "historical" monument that has powerful contemporary meaning.
Moving exhibit . This is one of the most chilling exhibitions of Jewish suffering. Found on the Danube next to the Parliament buildings. A must see.

So very moving. My partner and I were having a stroll along the river when we came across this memorial. I knew it was there somewhere along that stretch but still was not quite prepared for it when we found it.So simple yet so poignant........the sadness actually stayed with me for the rest of the day, as it should do!! We all rush along at 100 miles an hour.......this memorial actually makes you stop and remember.....
Very sad. This is a sad reminder of the past. Very thought provoking. We mustn't ever forget the atrocities that were carried out.
Unusual site. Not sure what this is about, but the views over the river to castle Hill are great, and I guess this is something quirky and different

Poignant reminder of the horrors of the holocaust. A shoe sculpture by the River Danube in memorial to the Hungarian Jews who were killed during the Holocaust, pushed into the freezing river in winter to save on bullets. The childrens' shoes there are particularly chilling. If you can make a visit in the height of winter you can get a better idea of the horror of it all.

Moving. A moving tribute. Situated just along from parliament, this tribute was humbling for both myself and my children. We spent a while looking a to the shoes and imagining the poor people who had suffered.

"Simple but yet so powerful!!". As other reviews have said it is a must see.There was nothing about it in our guide book but we felt we must go. 60 odd pairs of shoes, men's, ladies and even childrens, all cast in bronze to remember the Jews shot by the "Arrow Cross Militiàmen" in 1944/45 on the banks of the Danube. Such a simple memorial yet so powerful, least we forget.

Moving Monument to a Dark Period in History. Easy to access and worth the short walk down the river from the Chain Bridge. Read the history before you go, and you'll get more out of it. A moving tribute to the Hungarian Jews who died near the end of WWII.

Moving tribute.... Well worth a visit are the shoes by the Danube, a tribute to Jewish people murdered by the river Danube. They fell into the river. Shocking, thought provoking, and very well designed.
Moving . We felt this was a very poignant tribute to the people shot by the nazis. I'm glad we went to see it, it was easy to find once you knew which direction to go in!

Emotional moment. You cannot help but be moved by the sight of this monument to those who died here. The shoes look so real, the baby boots brought an instant tear to the eye. Well worth going to see.

Sombre memorial. This memorial is located close to parliament building & can easily be seen when walking along the river towards the main shopping area, vaciutca. It is simple but gets the point across very well.

Moving . I had heard of this memorial before our visit and wanted to see it for myself. I think the design of the memorial is very effective making everything that happened so much more real and horrific to imagine. The shoes were brilliantly done and it's nice to see them filled with shoes and tea lights as a tribute. This was easily reached by foot from the centre.

Good if you take your time to stand still and think. There is big chance you just walk by this little monument, not knowing what it stands for. If you take your time to get to know the history behind it you will get speechless. There were a lot of weird times in Budapest.
Moving memorial . This simple but effective memorial stops you in your tracks and makes you think of the devastating and sad reason these shoes are here.

Disturbing but moving and essential stop in Budapest. Apparently when the Nazi's knew the war was nearly over they started executing Jews quickly. Every day they would line up groups of 3 on the riverbank, tie them together, and shoot the one in the middle- this was apparently to save bullets. The two who weren't shot mostly drowned when they pushed them into the river. What was most shocking was that it was done in front of people going in to work and children were killed too. This is a touching monument to ensure people do not forget the pure cruelty and evil that people are capable of.

Evokes poignant reflection. Just to the south of the Parliament building on the bank of the Danube and easy to stumble upon - a memorial to those shot into the river by Arrow Cross - metal shoes and a haunting impression of the reality.

not sure what this was. We stumbled upon this while walking along the river. We didn't really know what it was, as we were brand new to Budapest. After we saw the October 1956 uprising display at the parliament, this made sense.
Quiet reflection. A small and moving memorial to those lost in the Holocaust. A few steps from the Parliament building and an essential part of any visit to Budapest.

Sobering reminder of WWII. We only drove by the Shoes on the Danube, but were struck with this haunting reminder of the atrocities of the times. Very well done. Sixty pairs of shoes of all varieties to represent 60 years since it happened. Just a short walk from the Chain Bridge.

A very sad memorial. Was in Budapest a few weekends ago for a hen party and some of us decided to arrive a day early to have a little explore around the city. We came across this on our way to the Parliament buildings and we were a little bit taken aback. It was a thought provoking and emotional experience

Stark reminder of brutal events. Shocking that people were lined up on the river bank and shot into the Danube. These shoes remind us of how badly people are treated in conflict. Shoes were clearly of all ages and genders. Cruelty does not discriminate.

Surprisingly emotional. I hadn't heard about the "Shoes on the Danube" until we happened upon it. Its quite a thought provoking and emotional memorial and a fitting tribute to those killed. The shoes actually look as though they've just been left there, and there are childrens shoes too which brings home the attrocities which took place in this city.
Tribute. This is a tribute to those people who lost their lives under horrible circumstances. Well presented and very tastefully done.

Interesting Sight. Shoes were laid along a small stretch of the riverside. In my own opinion, nothing special. But together with the riverside view, I would say it is quite a relax walk along the river. There were many other activities along the river and it is a good idea to explore the area.
A must see!. Possibly the most beautiful and poignant memorial i've ever had the privilege of seeing, it is thought provoking and you must go visit whilst you are in Budapest.

Very moving. Before visiting Budapest we watched the film 'The Music box' which tells the story of the atrocities committed by the Arrow Cross death squad in 1944. To stand and look into the Danube and visit this memorial is extremely moving, particularly if you know the story behind it.

“this place will give you a lump in the back of your throat”. we stumbled across this memorial whilst walking aroung the city. at first you wonder what it is but i got a very strange feeling here, cause i didnt know that before split seconds later i saw my girlfriend she is jewish started crying and told me everything about it, what happened to these people having learnt it in school. But when you are standing there on that bank and can see these shoes, so real and lifelike it really hits home that these are copies of the shoes of real people, real lives. we walked back down in the evening and the shoes had been lit up by tea light candles. it is somewhere that i will go back to visit if we return to budapest

Must see, an important part of history. We went around sunset time and there was no one else walking along the promenade. It was a very somber moment but well worth the visit. It is right along the river and close to many other attractions so it would be silly not to stop here for a moment.
Worth a look. This monument is original in its design and simplicity and yet thought provoking and extremely powerful in its message.

Very very thought provoking. As the Danube flows past fast and deep the thought of men, women & children standing at this spot waiting for the heavy bullets from the firing squad to punch their bodies into the water to be carried away is unsettling.The bronze shoes in all shapes, sizes and wear sitting at the water's edge, some with a flower in them and some with a small candle placed as a sign of respect really focuses the horrors that happened in Europe during the war.You must visit

Very moving. Located on the banks of the Danube this memorial is a very sobering reminder of the horrors of WW2. Thousands of Jews were murdered. They had to remove their shoes before being shot and their bodies fell into the Danube. A very poignant image.
Such a Simple Holocaust Memorial. This exhibit when you read about how the Jews were treated at this spot is poignant. You walk away with how could humans treat other humans in this manner.

Very touching experience. Very close to parliament, along the Danube, one finds a collection of shoes, representing jews who were killed by Arrow Cross militiamen during WW2. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the river bank so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away.

Worthy of reflection....very moving.... Before coming to Budapest my knowledge of their tortuous history was scant to say the least. Taking time out and appreciating the horrendous impact of the Arrow Party militia made the trip to see the shoes on the Danube even more poignant. Take time out....and reflect.....what a tortuous history.
It made me cry. I went the by night and there were some candles on it made me very emotional. Its sad, but worth going!

Moving and poignant. A bit tricky to reach -- well, not that hard, but just not quite obvious -- this unique memorial to Jews killed during WWII quietly brings home the individual cost of the violence.

Moving. . A very moving memorial, we visited during a week day about mid morning but there were already many people already there paying their respects. There is very little information at the location but those who know their history can not fail to be moved by the sight of the pairs of shoes on the river bank.There are no signs to help you locate the memorial, but it is easily reached directly behind the parliament building.There is plenty of room to view the memorial or to sit in quiet reflection. People who ignore the lessons of the past, have no future.

Touching but nothing extraordinary. It is a wonderful memorial that express all the sadness about this period of 1944-45 when the militia of arrow cross killed Jews on the Danube river. Please keep in mind that this is a sad place. I couldn't understand people talking selfies smiling as if they were at the mall. Show some respect. Access is not as easy as it looks. The traffic is intense in the area and toy have to walk until close the the parliament to be able to cross the street.

"Poignant ". This is a memorial to the Jews that we're executed at the end of the world war, this is a public memorial and unfortunately some people were not able to give it the dignity and respect it deserved ,while most of us sat or stood reflecting on these horrors,a young couple removed there own shoes placeing them in the middle of the shoes than posed laughingly in a embrace in the middle of it for a selfie.

Touching memorial. A very simple but powerful message set on the riverside. Looking at the bronzed shoes offers you a view into the not so distant past where the unacceptable became commonplace. A lesson for all of us to not repeat the mistakes of the past.

Quite a moving piece of art..... The shoes are very simple but the history behind them is a terrible and very sad. I would not try and explain it you in depth you would be best to do a little research...the bottom line is that it is the scene of many executions in WW2 when victims stepped out of there shoes before being shot and falling into the river.
Very sad place. . This was definitely one of the interesting but also one of the saddest things i have seen to go and see the shoes and research them. It was a historical teaching moment.

A Good place to sit down and think a litle.. This is a great place to see and think about all the Jews that was exicituted here. There are sitting area there so one can sit and think how lucky we are to be a live. This is a fact we my not forget.

Simple and touching memorial. We had heard about this permanent installation of a line of shoes (in bronze) along the Danube riverside and we walked over to find it. We stood there imagining the innocent people who were made to stand by the river and massacred by members of the local Nazi-affiliated Arrow Cross militia in 1944-5. Highly recommended and very moving.
A place with a history. It is an emotional and a sad place. A place were innocent Jews were thrown to the Danube river. While walking along the promenade you can come across it.

History that shoud not be forgotten. We had gone by the shoes the day before but had been so busy looking at the buildings on the left hand side and wondering how they were so clean looking, we must have literally walked by without noticing, which on hindsight is unbelievable as it is a very poignant place. Its hard to imagine it all happened. That's the thing about Budapest , every corner you turn there is a different thing to look at. What I found moving was the children's shoes. You really need to spend a few minutes reflecting and paying respect to all those innocent people that lost lives,

beautiful but touching. Travelled here with some friends; we all heard of this but did not know it was in Budapest, close to where we were staying one night. The view is amazing and you can see a piece of history that should NEVER be forgotten.

Sentimental.. There is something deep in these simple pile of shoes on the side of the river. It is a kind of place that you visited in your holiday trip and will never forget forever. I recommend this place, not only for history enthousiasts, but anyone.
Nice. A really nice and simple memorial for the horrible event that took place here. It was a saddening sight that reminds us of the past.

part of the History of Budapest and Hungary. just 300m before you reach the Parliament, along the Danube on the Pest side of the city...the shoes depict and are dedicated to those who have been executed-shot during the war 44-45(almost 550000 people)...A memorial that reminds of something so harsh and unfortunately is part of the history of Hungary.
Please visit. This is not from the center, its worth the walk and to take 5 minutes to reflect how lucky we are !!!! very moving

Shoe's on the Danube. As we walk along the promenade on the east bank of the Danube we came across the memorial to honour the Jews who were killed during World War II, to stand there in silence and try to imagine what these poor people went through and especially when you see the shoes of a child.
Strange sight to come across . Came across these shoes as we were walking along the river side.There's a story behind them, very eerie seeing them all randomly on the river side

Simple but heart breaking. Although it's pretty small, the memorial provokes deeps emotions and thoughts, especially if you know what sad events happened there. Yes, it is really moving and I just couldn't hold my tears back.

Spotting Shoes on the Danube, Danube river, Széchenyi Chain Bridge, and Buda castle at a time. Location: you can access this part of the riverside easily by stopping at Metro station Kossuth Lajos tér. From that metro station you will first see the Hungarian parliament, and just walk nearby you will be in the riverside of Danube river. Go along the path towards the bridge, and you will find these Shoes on the Danube.Experience: actually there are nothing much besides the sculpture itself. There are no explanations on the story behind the Shoes. Indeed, it is a must visit place in Budapest, since you could get the best picture showing the Shoes on the Danube, Danube river, Széchenyi Chain Bridge and the Buda castle across the river.

A unique place. When you see the shoes it is a unique monument ! The horror against the Jews !!!
It brings memories of other places ! Simple monument but serves the purpose . I will never forget it !!!!
beautiful and moving tribute. Beautiful and moving piece of art. Well worth a visit, absolutely stunning. Not far from the parliament along the river.

So touching. Definitely worth seeing, especially if you're going to parliament anyway. But even if not. A very touching tribute to some of those murdered in the Holocaust. Tastefully done. Don't see how anyone could not be moved by this

A touching and beautiful memorial. It's easy to walk along by this monument, situated in a great location for taking pictures, both of the shoes, and of the various views over to Buda/ of the Parliament Building.
A great spot for reflection on past atrocities and a touching, thoughtful memorial.

Very moving instalation. Between Houses of Parliament and the Chain Bridge you can see this memento on Jewish people women and kids who were killed and let to fall into the Danube...Very strong instalation
Sadness. It's a touching spot that recriates the shooting of 70 jews during the nazi occupation in 1944. Very modest monument but full of sadness and hopeless.

A nice memorial!. A nice memorial to commemorate the jews that were sentence to death here many years ago. Being shot right next to the danube before falling to there death in the river. Walk along the Danube from chain bridge to the parliament or vice versa and you cannot miss this beautiful memorial.
Sad memorial . Really sad memorial that makes you think about the terrible things that happened in the war but definitely worth a visit.

Heart Wrenching. This is an extremely moving memorial to those Jews of Budapest that were killed near the end of World War II. It was a very moving memorial and well worth the time to see it and remember the victims. I noticed that for a very public memorial those viewing it treated it with the dignity and respect it was due. Go and visit.

Very moving. This memorial is very moving and sad! It is a good idea to read a little about the history of what and why this is there before you go see it! It is on the Danube River and should not be missed.

Moving and beautiful memorial. This is a definite 'must see' to anyone travelling to Budapest. Situated on the Pest side of the Danube River, the shoes are a very heart moving memorial to the Jews who suffered in Hungary.

Moving memorial to commemorate the inhumanity of war. This memorial to the shooting of Jews during WWII is just along the Danube from the Parliament building. It is a very poignant place and should definitely be part of your visit to Budapest, no matter how short. Recommend reading about it before visiting.
take time to reflect on the sadness. Very moving tribute to those who died during WWII - there are many memorials in Budapest - this one is very poignant
Moving. This is a moving tribute that demands sincere reflection during your time here. A beautifully crafted memorial.
Moving memorial. It's a good idea to read why this memorial is here before going to view it. A very poignant reminder of the inhumanity of war.

Sentimental touch. The Hungarians keep this memory strong and vivid in their mind, since fresh flowers and newly burnt candles are part of the scenery.
Dedicated to those who were shot dead by arrows in 1944-1945, the monument brings a sentimental touch to the city.

Stunning and thoughtful.... Such a pretty monument to lost lives....take a few moments to stop.
This is so easy to miss but something that should be on your must do list here in Budapest on route to Parliment Buildings.

A display that conveys 'We must never forget'....... I read about this exhibit before going to Budapest; seeing the exhibition, makes you feel the remorse and sorrow for the Jews who were executed and shot in cold blood on the banks of the Danube.........everyone should visit this memorial! Jon

Splendid! . These remains are a great way to appreciate the Hungarian history in the Second World War.
Would highly recommend visiting especialy since they are found very close to the Parliament!

very poignant!!!. Not from Parliament and very oolong the river, the shoes of all sizes can be found. Many containing flowers, Very touching experience, makes you want t to learn more about what happened.

A subtle, minimalist, solemn monument. A very thoughtful memorial to people who were killed by Hungarian Nazis at the end of WW2. They were lined up on the riverbank and shot, falling into the Danube. The bronze shoes seem scattered and abandoned by people.

Go there if you have a heart. It will make you feel and think of things you may not deal with in your everyday life. It's a very creative yet modest way to remind people of a dark slice of Hungary's history.
A bit of a walk, but worth it.. Read the history of this event before you go. It is a moving experience and reminder of the best and worst of humanity.

Makes you think. I was aware of this memorial before I came to Budapest but my partner wasn'tShe saw the small memorial in the Jewish museum and was intrigued - I explained the significance to her and she insisted on visiting itI think that the impact can only be described in that when she thought that she had lost the photo she had taken that she had insisted that we return - even if it made us miss our flight backIf ever you need to contemplate how man can be so cruel to man then visit this site - it will not leave you unmoved

If this doesn't touch you, you are not human. Seeing these shoes, is like seeing are the people who could have stood in them...A sad reminder of a very ugly passage in Hungary's history. Hungarian authorities like to make believe it was all the nazis to blame, and try to hide the active help that was provided by the authorities and the civilians. Anti-semitism goes a long way in Hungary, trust me...

Moving memorial. I'm really glad I was able to see this memorial during my time in Budapest - it commemorates the Jews who were executed during the second world war - the local militia would line up men and women against the banks of the Danube so that the river could carry their bodies away. The memorial is very moving and visitors have left candles, flowers and notes. A must-see if you are near Parliament.

Simple but moving memorial!. These bronze shoes facing the Danube are right in front of the parliament building. In World War II the Nazis got tired of transporting Jews so they lined them up in front of Parliament, told them to take off their shoes, shot them, and let them fall into the Danube. Although these shoes are bronze, even if you get up close and inspect them, they look like worn or worn out leather. This is an amazingly moving memorial.
Memorial . I saw this memorial on the tv a few months ago and made point of going to see it. We found it moving and interesting memorial it's not far to get to
Very moving memorial. A very simple but very moving memorial to the Jews that were shot at the side of the Danube. Situated close to the parliament building

Solemn but worth acknowledgement. I made sure that one of our first tourist visits would be too this monument. I want to make sure that my children saw and understood the importance of this message. Very poignant
Reminds bad memories. Near parliament building reflecting and reminding bad memories about wars. It is impossible not to be affected during your visit that place.
Humbling memorial. Must see if you're in budapest. Touching tribute to those killed by their own countrymen for being of a different religion
In memory for those lives scarified..... Great mark to remember those Jew people, who sacrificed their lives during Nazi period. Also, remind us the cruel of war.

Good place to remember!. It is really close to Parliament, so you can walk there and check it out. it is not something monumental, but has some kind of atmosphere what sends you back in time...to feel and live again our mistakes....
Heart breaking. Such a simple tribute but how powerful. Take time to visit and ponder how evil mankind can be just for worshipping the same God but in a different way.....

Remember and respect the victims.. This is a place for mourning. Remember all those innocent people, who were killed on this spot, and you will understand, why selfies look silly and inappropriate here.
Moving. It is hard to describe the depth of feeling and the poignancy of the visit.How can I describe a feeling that is indescribable .All that I can say is that you will come away changed

A+++++. It's a great memorial. Take a walk, spend some time there. Maybe look into the history and meaning before hand. I recommend spending a good 30 minutes there just taking it in, but also good if your in a hurry. Right by parliament!

A must see. The shoes are heart breaking. Most see in Budapest.
It's very close to the parliament house and just right by the Danube.
A Part of History we shouldn't Forget. Seeing the shoes by the Danube is a very poignant memory of the Second World War and what the Hungarians suffered throughout these dark years.

Moving Memorial. You do not need to book a trip to see this memorial
You can view this moving memorial when you walk along the river Danube on the Pest side.
It is to mark where prisoners were made to face the river naked then shot and fell into the river to be washed away.
Very touching. A poignant artwork to ensure generations to come will know the story of these poor people killed in cold blood. Very sad, but I think a must see if you visit Budapest.
Budapest 2016. You can find the shoe's between the Chain bridge and the Parliament building a very worthwhile visit if you have time.

Impressive memorial. The thoughts coming to your mind when you see this memorial are quite hard as there are no explication valid for this "monument".
But of course, highly recommended. 🌹
Nice. Not much to see other than the shoes themselves. The history behind them is the most interesting part, particularly knowing some the individuals that survived are still alive to this day.
half term with children. Daughter put her feet in a pair of shoes and was interested in the history of how they were placed there.

Powerful monument. The monument is extremely powerful and evocative. The writing alone the shoes fails to mention that all the victims were Jews and refers to their death in a rather odd phrasing. In English it's just stated that the people were "shot" and in Hebrew, they are referred to in language used to describe people who've died of old age, not murder victims. The monument is also hard to access. This is of course not a coincidence - Hungary has struggled to accept its responsibility in the genocide of its Jews.
Sad but beautiful . It felt so emotional seeing all these shoes and what they represents. A mix of beauty and horror... Hopefully it will NEVER happen again!

Made me emotional!. My group was with a local who told us the history behind this attraction. It was so sad and moving, it's a great memorial for those who lost their lives during World War 2 on that very bank. Seeing the tiny shoes that represent that even children were shot will move you to tears.

A poignant reminder from WW2. Came upon this moving scene while walking alongside the Danube in Budapest.Take a moment to stop and reflect how desperate the situation must have been for the frightened and vulnerable owners of these shoes at such a sad and violent period in that countries plight during occupation by such a cruel and violent regime.There are many moving tributes in the city regarding their occupation and indeed the uprising a decade or so later, but the shoes,and in particular those that belonged to an infant, are moving.

Moving. This piece of work represents and remembers those that were brutally murdered during the Second World War. Jews were taken to the river and shot..there bodies falling into the river. Husbands and wife's were tied together and one of them was shot causing the other one to fall in and drown

Sad to see. When we visited this memorial along the Danube it made us feel sombre knowing the story behind it. It would not mean anything unless you learn why the memorial is there and you will feel and look at it differently than you would have before. Well worth the visit to show your respect.
moving tribute to holocaust victims. easily accessible from parliament building, this simple monument to a dark period in hungarian history.

Another moving memorial. This is a piece of art to commemorate the atrocities carried out on the Hungarian Jews by Hungarians during WW2. A poignant row of sculpted adult and infant shoes portray the suffering that took place in this city. However I cannot understand why some people would rip some of the shoes up from the quayside and steal them. That is lower than a snake's belly!

A must see. Having visited Aschwitz last year, we had some idea of what to expect and how we would feel. Somehow the simplicity of " just shoes" made it more haunting. Executed by Hungarian militiamen rather than the Natzi
So poignant. It's lovely strolling along by the Danube but when you come across the Shoes it really makes you think what these poor people went through
Shoes. A very sad display of the way people treat each other. It brought tears to my eyes. Just thinking about what people in this country have put up with in history is amazing they are still here.

Please Show Respect. Folks, I accept that we all have our own way of dealing with situations, but understand what this unique monument is all about.Sorry but personally I do think it suitable that some choose to sit among the shoes, smiling and taking selfies.Can I ask that you visit, remember and show respect.Be grateful that you have the ability to walk away from this location and your freedom to choose your next adventure.
Very poignant. A fitting memorial to the horrendous atrocities that were committed here, and serves a powerful reminder.

A must see. My wife had read about this before arriving in Budapest. They were on the riverside opposite parliament. Although it was quite upsetting to think the shoes belonged to Jews,Hungarian nationals who had been shot and fell in the danube in wartime it made you realise what these people were going through in the war.Tourists were taking pictures but I'm sure some did not realise the meaning of the shoes which are made of cast iron and look very realistic.

A moving tribute.. There is something in the haphazard nature of the shoes which attempts to convey the brutal and sudden end for numerous Hungarian Jews on the banks of the Danube in 1944/45. Lest we never forget!
Sort of away from everything. Sort of away from everything but is a beautiful piece of Art. The wlak along the river is pretty relaxing don't get a Cab.

Very moving. It is so sad how the Hungarians treated Jews, but they are clearly remorseful. Thsi is an incredibly moving memrial to the murdered Jews and I was left crying. Do go and see it and it will trigger your thoughts on how mad the world is. I am so glad that we went. It is so very sad. I think the Hungarians are great that they are trying to face up to their past very poor behaviour. I am just a bit worried about their current leader....
Good monument. Seeing the shoes and knowing the history behind it makes you think. The children shoes are the most touching.
nice place to see. this is A monument to the Jews that Were killed during World War IIthe place is on the way to other attraction.

Must See in Budapest. These shoes are a tragic memory of the racism that killed millions during WWII. I find this spot one of the most moving in all of Budapest, a memorial to Jewish men, women, and children who were shot in the head and fell to their deaths in the Danube all because one race of people hated another and blamed them for their problems. May God forgive us this atrocity. There is a tragic beauty in this memorial that rivals all others in Budapest. 1 John 2:10-11

Heartbreaking but Essential. This is just about the most appropriate testimony to a really ugly side of Hungarian history - one they are trying to forget if the atrocious memorial erected in 2015 in Szabadszg ter is any indication. The silent shoes, resting in the shadow of Parliament, (the ostensible seat of just government), and facing multiple church steeples (supposed moral legitimacy) across the Danube, bear witness to multiple failures of both justice and morality. I live in Budapest and make sure all our visitors visit both the "shoes" and the "eagle" as great sources of past and contemporary Hungarian history. Rarely do memorials get it right, but the shoes do. Appropriate for all ages and interests.

memorial to WW2 victims.. SHOES ON THE DANUBE PROMENADE MEMORIAL is a very poignant reminder of the atrocities committed to innocent people during WW2 in this beautiful city and the world in general. The shoes make you think about the terror that innocent victims went through before being killed and thrown into the River Danube and are here so future generations can learn from the lessons of WW2 and the pointlessness of war.Very easy to find being on the banks of the River Danube by the Parliament building. A memorial that should be visited.

Thought Provoking. This memorial to the victims of the Holocaust is at the river edge near the Parliament. It is a very understated and simple memorial but totally effective and thought provoking. When we visited there were quite a number of other people and we all observed it in silence. A truly inspiring memorial to those who lost their lives

Very moving. Just south of the Parliament building on the Danube. 50 plus pairs of boots and shoes in cast iron to commemorate the 4000 Jews killed by the Arrow Cross Boys in 1944/1945. We were told that most of these killings took place in District 13 just east of Margaret Island to the north and then the victims were thrown in to the Danube.

A very strong experience. This monument leaves the viewer a very strong an hard impression of what the war was about like. The killing of people just becaus of their faith. We must not let the world forget. We must not let it happen again
Shoes. Interesting but certainly nothing to make an effort to see. Ideal as part of a pest bank visit walking from chain bridge to parliament/

Take five minutes to visit.. If your visiting parliament, or travelling on the 2 Tram just take a few minutes out of your busy schedule to visit the shoes on the Danube.
Stunning sculptured shoes in bronze with a very chilling history to them.
Also it's free 365 days a year day or night.
This place takes your breath away. . This is a must see on your trip to Budapest. It is right on the Danube in front of the parliament building of the city. The walk on the river is also beautiful.

Must visit. This is a very touching memorial and a great place to visit to reflect on the atrocities of war. The various sizes and shapes of the shoes makes the point that the killings took many lives and ended so much future potential.

Numbing. A reminder of the trials of the country during the Nazi and Soviet oppressions. A fine monument to the brave resistance of the Hungarain people. Situated on the banks of the Danube a short walk from the Parliament building.
Go. Go so you can bear witness and honor those who were so horribly murdered. Be reminded that cruelty and suffering at the hands of others continues.

Powerful memorial. Saw both up close and from a boat on the river. Both times experienced such powerful emotions. You can't help but imagine yourself in those shoes and feel so sad for the people they represent. You should see it for yourself.

Easy to find. Not sign posted but it easy to find going by the free maps that are given out around Budapest. I did know what the shoes represented from doing my homework on places to visit on Budapest but it would have been nice to have had something near by explaining a bit about the history and how the memorial came about as we were going around Budapest not on any guided tours. I found out more info when I read up later.

Must see. This small exhibition to commemorate the Jews who were shot after removing their shoes and them pushed into the Danube is a very moving experience . Very close to Parliament building but seperated from upper footpath by a busy road - walk to pedestrianised section by parliament and then back along waterside is safest way - very close

Kind of interesting but just a spot to look. Not sure this is a 5 star place. alone the danube which you need to cross major traffic to get to. I don't think it is worth the bother. Others may get the significance. I do not.

Meaningful memorial on the bank on the Danube. Worth going to see this memorial while walking around Pest - it was located not far from Parliament and St. Stephen's, so we had a nice time walking around and along the Danube. You do need to cross the river's edge at a crossing though, since there is a highway between the main sidewalk and the river walk.

Take a stroll at sunset. Walk from Parliament along the Danube and you'll past by the memorial. It's 60 pairs of copper shoes to represent those who were shot over the Danube during WW2. They were forced to take off their shoes before as those were valuable items that could be used. Very touching memorial that offers you a chance to reflect on the past.

Nice to see while walking along the river.. I went to see this today while waiting for a tour of the parliament building. It's a five min walk along the river from parliament building.
Interesting considering what it represents. Nice photo opportunity.

Poignant memorial. It was very touching, and very real. Looking at those abandoned shoes brought home the human vulnerability of all us and all the was lost in war and what was left behind. It is very simple but oh so powerful. The memorial is between the parliament building and the chain bridge.

Must see. Free sight 6 mins walk along the Danube from Parliament metro line 2.
Great for pictures and emotional.
Interesting . Interesting and poignant shoes by the river where Jews were shot and thrown in. Just a 2-3 min stroll from Parliament. Simple but good.

Tribute. We really wanted to see this tribute to the people but after reading other reviews not sure what we would find. The shoes are right in front of the Parliament building so we found them quite easily and is a fitting tribute to the fallen and worth a visit. Just take a moment to pay your respects. Sad but glad we did it.
Lovely memorial. We stopped off here after a visit to parliament as it is not too far. Very moving memorial and worth seeing.
Brutally impressive.... Standing at the Danube, seeing the view, the river, the Castle, the Chain Bridge, and thinking: it was the last picture what some people saw, is quite shocking.
Sombre. There are no words to describe. Just a feeling of helplessness for these poor people. Very moving. I am glad to have paid my respects.
Sad Reminder. The simpolicity of this memorial to people including many women and children is very poignant. It is a short walk from the Parliament building and the chain bridge.
Emotional. Its hard to 'rate' this as it is more of a thought provoking experience than an attraction. But I would definitely suggest taking time out to go.
Very sad. I was recommended visiting here and I am glad I did. It was very realistic and blunt, as to be expected. I would recommend to future tourists visiting here.

Makes you think. Walked along the river at 6:30 am on a Sunday so it was quiet. It's such a simple tribute but it really makes an impact. You have no choice but to visualise what happened. Worth a visit if only to remind you what humans are capable of.

Impressively sober... The "shoes on the Danube" monument is one of those mounuments where you will overthink the very sad things that happened during world war 2. It's very sober and that's excactly the beauty of it. It is really impressive.
Quite moving. It is worth reading up on this before you go to see it as there is't much of an explanation of what it represents onsite.

Very poignant. We saw the shoes from the No. 2 tram and made a point of going back. The shoes are a memorial for the people who were shot and fell into the Danube by Arrow Cross Militiamen (Nazis) in 1944-45. The plaque was in English and erected 16th April 2005.

Thought provoking .. If you intend to visit this memorial do read up about the history behind it as we did not notice anything on the riverbank apart from the shoes and a plaque. Do visit it..though it may bring a tear to your eye. Xx

Shocking and cathartic experience. A very expressive monument of the victims killed by Hungarian and German natzis at the end of the WW2.
Jews, communnists, resistants were massacred here without mercy. Worth to see and contemplate a bit how we can prevent terrible events like that...

great idea, very touching!. a poigient touching piece! great idea and thought provocking. only criticism is they need a sign or something explianing the piece. most people will know why they are there but the story still needs telling to people.

Worth seeing if you're walking along the Danube. This memorial is very impactful- my friends and I stumbled upon it while walking along the river and it's hard to imagine such a horrifying scene in such a beautiful city. Definitely stop by if you're close, it's a very touching scene.
Shoes on the Danube. A bit of a trek and not much to see, not in the best condition and not kept looking very good, but a moving experience and easy to find!

Very moving and simple memorial. This is a very simple yet moving memorial that pays tribute to Jews in Budapest that were shot next to the river. It prompted me to read more about Hungary during the war

Very Personal Memorial . We were really glad we went to see this memorial, it depicts a frozen moment in time & it is very sad to think that once people discarded their shoes and lost their lives. I felt that it was a memorial I could relate to as a simple action of the every day & it was very well collaborated.

This is important but hard to see...in several ways. The marker reads, "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by arrow cross militiamen in 1944-45." Raises more questions than it answers, to my mind. What makes this installation particularly poignant is that people have added ribbons to the bronze shoes and surrounded some of the pieces with candles that obviously have been lit. This is a small but clearly impactful piece of public art. BUT BE WARNED! Getting there is NOT EASY and straight forward! If you don't go to the horse and rider statue that stands just below (south of) the Parliament Building and cross at the light there, you will risk having to cross a very dangerous road with no safety precautions for a long distance in each direction. This is not an easily accessible place - plan ahead.

A touching memorial. A simple but moving memorial of the Jews shot on the banks of the Danube. It looks as though they've just stepped out of their shoes (which they were ordered to do before being shot). All sizes and styles of shoes, from a wealthy woman to an impoverished child and elderly citizen. Free to view. Look for a group of tourists peering silently at the floor.

An afternoon stroll in the sunshine. We came on this by accident as we walked up the river towards the parliament buildings.A poignant reminder of some of the more horrifying events in Budapest's past.
A must see. Very somber place to remind us of our past. Well kept memorial. Certainly a must visit for anyone but especially those of Jewish heritage

Long weekend break. We were in Budapest for a recent long weekend visiting all the sites and we included the "Shoes on the bank of the Danube". Poignant yes, a moment in time yes. Thoughtful yes. Make sure you do this on your way to Parliament though as you can easily miss them.
Must see. A very touching monument. 10,000 Jews were killed in a 6 week period during WW 2. Very poignant. Worthy reminder.

Art and emotion. This art/monument is not in the list with the top 10 things to do in Budapest, but it is worth a visit as you walk along the Dunab river, after your visit at the Parliament. It is so real and touching...

Moving, but don't plan on spending a lot of time. This memorial is very moving, especially after seeing the horrors of the Nazi and Soviet occupations of Hungary. Possibly the worst thing to come out of this is that it was largely prompted by the activities of the homegrown Arrow Cross movement, who were ruthless in their persecution of Jews.As you won't spend much time there, combine it with a visit to the extraordinary House of Parliament, only 5 minutes away. It is a little hard to find. If you approach it from Parliament House, go down to the Danube and turn left, walking for a couple of hundred metres and asking a friendly local!
Poignant Tribute. I had expected this to be a much larger memorial than it actually is. Nonetheless it is a very poignant and thought provoking tribute and worth seeing.

A most moving memorial.. Sculptors Gyula Paver & Can Togay have created a moving memorial to the Holocaust atrocities that happened along the Danube River. There are sixty pairs of rusted period shoes cast out of iron.People were rounded up from the ghetto. They were forced to strip naked on the banks of the Danube and face the river, a firing squad shot them in the back at close range so that they fell into the river to be washed away. This was a common practice during 1944-1945.I found this to be a totally moving experience.
Poignant memorial. A lovely poignant tribute to those who lost their lives during the Second World War. I'd recommend visiting early in the day to beat the crowds.
Poignant. This is located on the water's edge just south of the parliament buildings on the Pest side of the river. A very simple but moving memorial to terrible times.

Amazing!!. Me and my friend went to see them after we have checked-in the hotel and we were astonished with them especially with the history and significance there is behind them. Moreover, from here one can see Castle Hill, Fisherman`s Bastion and many other top attractions.

A memorable experience. We saw these shoes while visiting Hungary. Its a very moving experience when one really thinks about what the symbolism is with the shoes. The Jewish Quarter in Budapest is also an excellent place to visit for everyone.

Poignant and emotional. Set by the second longest river in Europe this is a fitting memorial to those that lost their lives during the Jewish purge of Budapest. It's emotional and moving so be prepared for a bit of introspectiveness.

Moving. This is a very simple but overwhelming at the same time,you have to stop and pause to take in the sculptured shoes and it is difficuly to imagine that we were standing in the same place these poor souls lost thiers.I actually could not take a photo of these shoes as I felt it was intruding.

Though provoking memorial but with a political twist. This is a very thought provoking and moving tribute to the jews who were murdered by the Nazis at the edge of the river. its just a shame that the memorial plaques which are in both hebrew and english don't mention the words jews or holocaust.
Moving tribute. There are rightfully many Holocaust memorials around Europe but this one is artful and reminds us of the human cost.
An emotional experience. I'm really happy that we got to see the Shoes on the Danube bank. It was quite an emotional experience, especially when you see the little boys shoes.
Touching Memorial. A very touching memorial to those Jewish Hungarian people who were shot on the banks of the Danube. The flowers and candles left in and around the shoes were heartbreaking.

Very moving . It might look like a bunch of shoes on the side of a river but Shoes on the Danube Bank is one of the most moving monuments I've ever seen. The shoes are dedicated to the Jews who were murdered by Arrow Cross Militiaman during WWII. They were ordered to take off their shoes and shot at the edge of the water so their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. Yep a visit here will make you feel sad, but I think everyone should try to come here when visiting Budapest.
Impressive . Very impressive detailed shoes along the river, reminding an episode which took place in Budapest during the WWII. Worth to pass by

Moving. These iron shoes are an artwork to record an atrocity that took place during the Second World War where Jews were shot into the fast flowing Danube by the infamous Arrowcross Militia. Very moving.

Emotional. I heard about the shoes by the river and it wasn't until I saw them for myself that I found a lump in my throat. The plaque says it all, very sad but important to have this memorial. It would be nice to have the names of the people executed listed near by.

Heart breaking memento of the late WW2 years. One should never forget what happened here in the winter of 1944 with innocent people.Save a little of your time when in Budapest to pay tribute to those perished here.
a place to think. It's a place with a beautifull view and this monument has a sad meaning...it's time to stop and think about the history.

A Humbling Experience. I could not imagine for a moment how helpless and terrified the victims must have felt when they were about to be shot and executed by their own countrymen simply because they were Jewish. A poignant reminder that beneath all the beauty of this city lies a cruel, violent and tragic past for some of the citizens who helped built ........

Moving and evocative. Budapest has layers of history and is incredibly interesting. I wanted to see the shoes on the Danube promenade and I wasn't disappointed. The simplest of memorials and yet one of the best I've seen. Where shoes line the side of the river flowers and candles have been placed to show that time passes but people are not forgotten.
Meaningful Monument. Stop by this monument on while you walk down the promenade. I googled it when I arrived not knowing the significance.
So sad. This makes you realise how lucky we are today . This is Very very sad but a must see. Great views of Budapest side from this site too.

Simple but effective . Easily missed this, but we searched for it after visiting the parliament building. Chilling and thought provoking. I thought some of the shoes were showing signs of wear and tear but the candles and floral tributes show that the victims are still very much in people's hearts.

Touching. If your on the tram no 2 get off at the parliament and then walk towards the Danube and there you will find the shoes dotted along the bank. We went at night and it was really special as the lights were reflecting off the shoes. This is something that doesn't take long and is nice to go and see

Poignant Memorial. Situated on the river wall in front of Parliament Building these sculptured shoesare thought provoking. The Jews were ordered to remove their shoes and werethen shot into the river. Even shoes of young children. A very cold wind blew down theDanube when we visited in February and it made it all very real. Could this happenagain?
Very moving. Great to stand there and reflect on the cruelty of man and the genocide inflicted during the second world war, go then walk to parliament square.

Stop and think. It may not be the biggest attraction, but when you sit and imagine the event it remembers, it is a well done and poignant piece of art and commemoration. Worth taking time to see and reflect.
Honorable Memorial. this memorial located several meters south to the parliament next to the river, make you think about the horrible thing in the center of this beautiful city...

Holocaust Memorial. A memorial to all the Jews who were lined up, shoes removed and then shot into the river during the second world war. We went early in the morning when there was no one else around so it was quite eery but peaceful at the same time. It seemed to get busier in the afternoons. Candles & flowers lay in between the shoes - very moving. Definitely worth taking a look. There isn't any history/information around the memorial so suggest reading up before visiting.

I loved budapest. A truly moving experience. I am so glad we visited on the last day of my holiday. A must see if you go to Budapest. This is a memorial of Jewish shoes before they are thrown into the Danube river. Many people gather here to pay their respects. Beautifully located and you can see chain bridge from here. Perfect photo opportunity.

Shoes of "son of Saul". Walking around Budapest on Pest side, in front of Parliament, you see several pair of metal shoes. You just stay for a minute and do not understand what are these shoes could be. You have to remember for those hungarian jewish people who were killed here during the 2nd world war. Shocking experience.

Interesting. This is a historical monument near parliament.It is a small section on the riverbank but it has a long of significance and historical value for a lot of Jewish people. Excellent view of the Parliament from here which is just a casual stroll away.
A passing by spot. It is a nice memorial site, and a place to really think about history. It is anyway just a small site. You should experience it combined with the parliament.

Very simple but very moving. This is a very simple memorial to the people who were shot and thrown in the Danube and made to remove their shoes - it seems all the more poignant because of it's simplicity - as it is on the bank of the Danube with lovely views I would definitely recommend putting this on your agenda

You must to visit the memorial!. Unforgettable experience... One of Budapest's most moving places! "Shoes on the Danube" is a memorial to the Budapest Jews who were shot by Arrow Cross militiamen between 1944 and 1945. The victims were lined up and shot into the Danube River. They had to take their shoes off, since shoes were valuable belongings at the time.

What an interesting piece of history.. This sight really made an impact on me, especially when you know the history behind it. I recommend reading a little up on the history on Wikipedia etc and then check out this sight. It`s one of these things that needs to be remembered.

Beautiful memorial. Beautiful tribute to those that lost their lives. Some of the shoes look newer than others, so much so that we thought they were actual shoes and not metal. Easy to find, very close to Parliament.
Sad . Such a sad memorial, shockingly accurate too, you could see people praying I'm the side, they're also in a very good location

Thought provoking. This isn't an all singing and dancing attraction, however it shouldn't, due to the context. The fact that we saw it in the pouring wind and rain just added to the depressing feeling.
Quietly sad. Good to take a little detour to visit this. Very moving. We went here after the house if terror. Get metro to parliament. Short walk then. Sorry to see the little shoes.

Interesting but not a must. I decided to check out the memorial on my walk along the river after going to see the Parliament. Its a nice touch to the scenery but not something I'd go out of my way to see. I took a few pictures, spent a few minutes there, then carried on with my walk.

thoughtful reflection. It was busy around the area so if you want a really reflective moment possibly pick your time of the day but its often the simple things we can relate to that can hit home. Conflict and war still happen and once people have gone all that remains are possessions without an owner & people lost forever. Perhaps being near the parliament it is a good message and especially time to reflect what the country has come through whilst enjoy what it is today.

Shocking. When you arrive at Parliament, walk along the Danube river, towards the chain bridge, you will see all the bronze made,shoes, remaining at the side of the river. It reminds us the history, when Hungarian nazi killed jews. You can see mens, women, and childrens shoes, all along the river. It is interesting and at the same time, very shocking moment.
Simple but very moving.. This is very simple but hugely thought provoking. Located just on the banks of the Danube it is something that anyone visiting Budapest should take the time to see.
Touching !. Easily accessible in the main area of the town. Sad story behind the memorial. Sit, relax and reflect there.

Simple tribute yet so moving. I had wanted to visit this monument after seeing it on trip advisor. It brought me to tears. It was such a simple tribute to those who died at the hands of fascists & serves as a reminder of the cruelty of human to human

A moving experience.. Had read up on places of interest in Budapest and wanted to visit this memorial. It is heartbreaking to know that innocent people lost their lives in such a brutal way. The artist has created a stunning visual to represent their suffering so that we may never forget.

A place to make you think. Worth a detour. The sight of these shoes are very moving given their significance, especially the children's shoes. A sad place to be on a grey winter day but so glad we went.

Very moving... We decided to have a look at the shoes on the Danube, to be honest I was very surprised how moving I felt. I've been to Auschwitz's and to see where some of the people started their journey thinking that they were going to a better life it is very sad.
Thoughtful reflection. From the tram the shoes looked like birds roosting. but walking along the promenade they are more apparent .there is also a plaque with a fitting description.
Moving. A lovely memorial to those who were forced into the Danube in darker times. It would be nice if there was a greater description but perhaps it is more thought provoking without.

Memorial. Very moving memorial to the thousands of Jews executed and thrown into the Danube towards the end of the 2nd world war. Apparently shoes were a valuable commodity and removed before the execution

Really touching!. You will find the place on your way back from the parliament at the river side.if you know the story of those shoes you might feel moved i know i did..its not a must but its on your way after the parliament why not take a minute to see it.

Nice Memorial. Something different. You can have a nice walk along the Danube from the Chain Bridge to Parliament and stop off and see these brass shoes in memory of those shot into the river during the war.

Ok.... It's a normal place with lots of meaning for the history of this Country under the war periods.
It's has a stronger meaning if combined with other war period symbols like the house of terror and hospital.
Photo opportunity. Worth trying to find if you are strolling along the waters edge. Touching tribute against a lovely backdrop.

A beautiful tribute but easy to miss!!!. 60 pairs of shoes commemorating the lives of Budapest Jews who were shot on the banks of the Danube in 1944 by the pro-Nazi regime in Hungary. Very moving and unique.... See it at night if you can as they are lit with candles.

Powerful and reflective. I visited this early evening, it felt the fitting thing to do after I visited the Holocaust Museum the same afternoon. Directly on the banks right in front of the Parliament, a very fitting tribute to the victims. With others leaving tea candles inside some of the shoes lit, its a fitting tribute from the artist and looks great as the city starts to light up as dusk comes.

Really touching experience . Walking along the river..and then find those shoes in front of you was really Impressive and the rainy atmosphere of that day made the experience a little bit more sad. But anyway everyone of you have to go here and visit this monument.
Great history . If you are in Budapest to see the history of the city then it's a must do! Very symbolic and a great area to visit. You can see parliament from here also.
Impressie monument. If you ever visit Budapest, visit the "shoe monument" naar the House of Parlement on the Side of the Danub.It will give you an impressive view of what war can do.
Represents something. Nice photo opportunity but it's not 100% well looked after. It looks a little scruffy but then I guess it is meant to a little.
Simple but affective. Walked along the Danube to see this, glad we didIt is very simple but powerful at the same timeTake 20 mins out of your busy day to stop and think how lucky we are
Disappointing. It was about five minutes away from the parliament building.the story behind the shoes was interesting.it was great to see the shoes all different sizes etc. It was unkempt though.
Moving. Outside the parliament building. A moving tribute to those who were killed in the war. Very emotional and moving tribute.

A ramarkable place. Whoever visits Budapest, to see the Shoes by the Danube is a must. To remember those jews whom suffered the most horrible death man can imagine from their 'fellow' countrymen. Please bring a flower and drop it to the water and see how those people must have sunk into the stream of the river.
Simple with a big message.. Easy to get to on a required stroll along the river, the exhibit delivers a powerful message of what happened here.

Powerful Tribute. Budapest doesn't exactly have the happiest of histories, and perhaps one of the darkest times in the city's past is during World War II. Jewish people were treated like animals and herded in and out of ghettos and to concentration camps. Many Jewish people were forced to take off their shoes on the banks of the Danube in Budapest and were shot by fascist militiamen.This memorial is a tribute to the people who lost their lives. It's between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament House and is certainly worth a stop to reflect and think about what happened on the banks of the exact same river.

Very moving. On leaving the Parliament buildings we walked along the Danube heading for the city centre. This is where you will find the Shoes on the Danube. This is a very low key installation with no fanfare or signs pointing it out and no information explaining its significance. The shoes speak for themselves. Incredibly sobering - particularly when you see the little children's shoes. Budapest is a beautiful city, but one certainly senses that it's people have suffered much.
Memorable. Tribute to the Hungarian Jewish community, killed during the Second World War. Very good idea for presentation..
Poignant. This was a lovely memorial to visit. Knowing the story behind this area was very thought provoking and most people seemed to take a few moments to reflect.

Moving Stop on the Danube. If you approach by car there is no easy way to view the memorial. It was told to us by our guide that people were asked to removed their shoes prior to them being shot. The shoes represented to me the human side of this event. Just located in an hard place to get to by car.

A simple and amazing memorial. Many memorials could be considered to concentrate on the act of remembrance, I found this one stunning from the perspective of encouraging personal insight into a devastating period of history which should never be repeated.It is located between the Parliament building and the Chain Bridge and all of our group (18 to 56 years of age) would describe it as a must visit.
Fitting tribute to the Jewish people . Thought provoking Breathtaking MovingPoignant Masterpiece IndividualTragicRespectful A fitting tribute xx
Not to be missed. This memorial is remarkable and raises one's awareness to the terrors experienced by the Jews in Budapest during World War II.

A poignant reminder and tribute. Worth taking a few minutes to just stand by the river by the shoes on the Pest side, not far from the Parliament Building. This is just one of the memorials around the city, this one is a tribute to the Jewish people in Hungary who were executed. Worth taking the time to find this touching memorial.

A memorial by the Danube. The iron shoes that look out over the Danube represent the Jewish people that were killed here. A very sombre and touching memorial that overlooks a beautiful setting. It's a 5 minute stop but a memorial that gives humanity to a brutal history.

Moving tribute. Once you understand what those shoes mean... it becomes a very solemn and moving affair. Hard to believe people are capable of that kind of savagery. If you are on the Pest side of the river and you are a student of history you should see this beautiful monument to a terrible time in human history. It honors the memory of the thousands of Hungarian Jews that were executed by the waters edge.
Very touching. Great monument. Must see in Budapest. Easy to miss if you are not careful. Even on a very wet day it was worth a visit.

A touching tribute.. The shoes on the Danube is something that has to be seen when you go to Budapest.Though it is small and not obvious it is a very touching reminder as to the suffering of those poor souls who were executed on the banks of the river.

VERY MOVING. A very touching monument to Jews shot into the Danube at the end of WW2. It was made more moving that these Jews had believed themselves to be saved and were only killed once the city had been liberated.
A touching memorial. You need to know the story behind these shoes. We saw them at night and there were some candles around them - it's really beautiful and heartbreaking at the same time.

Heart breaking. The walk to the shoe takes in the Parliament buildings so its worth the walk and quite moving as the shoes are a reminder of of the evil inflicted by the uneducated evil bigots of our time.
Very moving. This is a must see. It's quick and simple but very powerful to see. It's an easy walk-by heading to or from the Parliament building.

A must . Given the reason for the shoes here on the bank of the Danube opposite the parliament building , it's well worth taking some time to sit and contemplate the horrific fate of the people the shoes represent.
Beautiful memorial. this place is full of history and is worth to walk by after a visit to the parliament! places full of history!

Touching memorial. A poignant reminder of a tragic event done in a very respectful and meaningful manner. It isn't a big memorial but worth visiting to learn more about and get a better understanding of the history of the city.
Sad reminder. Its a sad reminder of people fleeing the war, shoes of all shapes and sizes of women men children shoes were left behind due to war and persecution.
A thought-provoking scene. Beautifully done, the sight of these shoes makes you stop and think for a moment about how sad and cruel some past eras were.

Moving.... Please take your time if you decided to come and see them.Don't scream, just stay there and imagine how it was back then, how it happened. How it feels to loose a child, or a family member because of its religion.It is very moving, but -as a local hungarian- i think this is one of the most powerful memorial in the city of Budapest.

A very moving experience.. Walking along the Danube and seeing the commemoration of the murder by Hungarian Iron Cross killers of innocent Hungarian Jews during WWII brought a somber reflection on man's inhumanity to man, In its simple display of the empty shoes, the art presented the horror of the Holocaust perpetrators in a graphic fashion.
Stark Yet Tasteful Memorial. Such a nice memorial of a tragic event in Hungarian Jewish history. A simple reminder that captures a world of tragedy

Sad history on the Danube side. We had a local friend who explained us about the bloody history of the city. This is a memorable for the Jewish people who were shot in the critical times.Watching the shoes makes you said...but it is still a memory.

A must see when in Budapest - powerful message. This piece of commemorative art is extremely moving to the heart and soul.
