It is actually frighteningly chilling to see and imagine the horrors that happened to human beings at this place and the Danube bank during the German occupation. That local extremists were the real culprits makes it even more frightening to know about, especially since may of them never got prosecuted. Go there - see and you will never forget.

Easy to Find and A Good Place to Stop and Think. I had read about the memorial on TripAdvisor and wanted to stop briefly to see it. It was easy to find (just south from Parliament) along the Danube River. I was surprised to see so many other people there taking pictures. There are no extensive signs or plaques explaining the Memorial just a small sign honoring those who were killed by Arrow Cross Militia Men in 1944/45. I went home and did a little reading up on the events themselves. I had never known much about Hungary's involvement in WWII or the life of Hungarian Jews during that time. I'm glad we stopped and paid tribute.
Very moving. A very moving reminder of very dark times.Everyone who walks along the Danube in Budapest should take a moment regardless of there own beliefs.
Haunting. Beautiful artwork in memory of the Jews shot into the Danube in WWII. Certainly worth a visit. Situated between the Parliament building and he chain bridge.

Not worth the bother. It took us some time to find this location by the river Danube and almost missed it as the shoes can not been seen from distance and you can only see them when you are close by. We did not find them of much interest, maybe because we had to walk some while to find them. All the shoes are made of metal with some rusting away!

Moving Tribute. Stumbled upon this exhibition walking along the Danube on one of our first days visiting the city. It was certainly a touching tribute to the lives lost when they were shot and the bodies thrown in the river.

Touching. I don't know if I can say it is excellent, but there was no other score to give to this memorial, which from my side, I would say it is one of the most touching Holocaust Memorial. The shoes on the river bank, in memory of all those who were shot into the Danube by the end of the WWII. Coming to Budapest, you are or not of jewish religion, doesn't matter, it is a symbol for the inhuman. Symbol of how Evil people can be, and how not to be, how to respect each other, and how to try to keep peace on this small Planet.

Beautiful and tasteful memorial. Very subtle and beautifully done. Definitely worth a few minutes as you stroll up the river.Though maybe don't take a selfie with the shoes. Not tasteful. Or beautiful. Or subtle.
Touching. If you blink while walking along the river, you might miss it. It is a heart wrenching Holocaust memorial.
with respect. If you want to see something different...is a good place to see but is a serious remind of trouble times to the country and the people that passed for ... So see it with respect

Simple but heart-breaking. One of the most touching monuments I've seen. To those who don't know the story behind it it might appear to be a mere line of shoes on the riverbank. But the moment you realise those could be the shoes of the Jewish people forced to take them off seconds before being shot dead into the river, the scene changes completely. Simple, modest and yet so heart-breaking it's hard to hold back tears.

An Art of New Kind. Another masterpiece for the art lovers in memory of the lost ones. At first you don't realise what you are looking at if you don't know about it before hand. That happened with me as well. But when I read about it I came back to pay a visit
Heavy, sad and beautiful. it's beautiful and at the same time sad. I hope the heavy environment around it will help avoiding such horrible tragedies for the future.
Thrilling. A thrilling monument to those who were murdered by Nazis. I didn t take a photo of it-I couldnt "catch" the pain..A must see

Memorial. We were lucky to have very beautiful weather during our stay so we were walking a lot on the Danube promenade. That is how we found the memorial. It is really something to see. We should not forget the past.
Beautiful hommage. Really nice monument but also very sad and moving. There are always flowers at the statues. A must-see in Budapest.

Overwhelmingly Emotional but Subtle Art. We should never what happened to the Jews and others whom the Nazi's murdered. This monument tells so much by the casts of shoes left by the side of the river. Take your guidebook--this is a must see!
touching. A very nice memorial for those who drowned all those years ago, with flowers and sweets for children left behind.

most touching Holocaust memorial. It takes a moment until you realize what you see....take a moment to remember those who were killed here! The pictures of the memorial remained in my head all the time we had in Budapest!
Wonderful art on the river. The tragic story of the shoes on the Danube brought to life. Another must-see for history buffs or art lovers.
Thought provoking . This is on the way towards the parliament along the waterfront. A very moving tribute. Sad to see that some of the shoes have rotted.

Powerful. Stumbled across this memorial late at night and guessed at its meaning. Revisited in the day and it is stark and powerful. A very good memorial to a horrific act.
Please nobody else steal these shoes!

Very moving. The memorial reminds the many Jewish victims, who during the Holocaust were rounded up by Hungarians, tied up to each-other and then pushed into the Danube to their death.Unfortunately it seems that the monument is deliberately inconspicuous (there are no directions to it - just follow the Danube to the direction of the Parliament) and now even neglected and let to rot. But I found it very moving in its humbleness.
Heartbreaking. We stumbled upon this on a walk by the river and I had no idea what it was a monument to until i googled it. Very sad. Glad we saw it and what a touching monument to those lost.

Very Sad. Thankfully I stumbled upon this memorial just walking alongside the Danube, It is very moving and emotional when you realise the suffering and horror that occurred in that exact spot. It is about a 5 minute walk to the left of the parliament building.

Moving . Simple yet poignant reminder of the atrocities of the Second World War that were carried out in Budapest.
No descriptions beside the monument but if you know your history you know what this represents
Beautiful . Such a great way to remember the lives lost in WW2. Its a great place to visit whilst walking along the river and very close to the parliament building.

Very nice way of telling a story. I really liked the idea of this memorial and it really puts you in the shoes (no pun intended) of these people that had to dive in the river to save themselves. Worth a visit!
solemn and thought provoking. A trip to Budapest is not complete without looking at the Shoes on the Danube Promenade. Quite thought provoking and solemn

Rich history. Definitely worth a visit, the lovely walk alongside the Danube is worth it and then to read about and witness such a moving tribute to an important piece of history is something that should be cherished.

Somber moment. Lovely memorial for the Jews who were shot into the river in 1944. Really hits you when you look down and see shoes that look just like yours. Really a touching experience being here and thinking of those who died.

A very moving monument to those who lost their lives. It's just a short walk to this memorial on the Danube. There are 2 plaques commemorating those who were shot into the Danube in WW2. Well worth going to pay your respects.
Powerful memorial place. Easy to find and well worth visiting. Would recommend a tour to fully explain the history behind the memorial.
Worth a visit. The shoes on Danube are definitely worth a visit, very close the the chain bridge and Hungarian parliament building too! Lovely views from the memorial too!
Sad but true. I would highly recommend a tour to explain the shoes. Close to the parliament and excellent representative of how history should not repeat itself.
Powerful memorial. Powerful, evocative memorial on the banks of the Danube river. Easy to find and well worth the visit.

Everybody is quiet!. A memorial place close to the Parliament at the shore of the Danube. There were around 50-60 visitors when me and my friend was there, they were all quiet! The choice these Jewish people had to do was horrible! Leaves no one without feelings!
Touching memorial. This is a very touching and different memorial. Just a simple reminder of what has happened. Just stating the obvious, that there will always be something missing.
Simple, moving, perfect.. Horrifying and moving memorial piece, just as it should be. Very poignant. As far as I'm concerned every one that can see it, should.

After Visiting the House of Terror, Go See the Shoes on the Danube. The shoes are along the walkway and tell their own story. We'd just visited the House of Terror and seen the horrors perpetrated on the people; seeing the shoes to commemorate those who were thrown into the Danube added an extremely solemn note to what we'd already seen.
Sad and vivid. This is a sad memorial to the thousand of Jews who were murdered by the Nazi and thrown into the river at this site.
very emotional. We saw photos of memorial before, but only today we visit plase near parliament of Hungary. Shoes memorial is very emotional and touches our hearths....
A striking reminder!. A striking reminder as you're walking along the calm riverside, about the horrors of the Hungarian people in World War Two. Worth a look and a pause to think. Underrated.
memorial for the holicost. weather you are Juwish or not you must remember the hollycost. it is on river side. not many people and not crowded.important to remember the past!

No mention that the victims were murdered because they were Jews!!. A must see in Budapest
We visited the memorial which is one of the most impressive holocaust memorials that exists in Europe.
Only one thing is missing - the victims were murdered for one reason THEY WERE JEWS
Someone in the city of Budapest didn't want to mention it - a dsgra

Emotional - moving. While I am not Jewish, I was surprised how profoundly this touched me. I was moved to tears as I looked down at the wide variety of shoes beside the grey-green water. The monument is a poignant reminder of what our better selves need always to guard against. The day we visited was overcast with a chilly breeze. It seemed to highlight the chilling events that these "shoes" silently memorialize. Truly a must-see.
Humbling. another reminder of how Nazi Germany influenced Europe and Hungarian Jews. This is easily found along the banks of the Danube River on route to the Parliament buildings. Free
So Poignant. Visited the day after Holocaust Memorial Day,so poignant...The sculptures are so beautiful but so utterly tragic
Worth a visit. The Danube is worth walking along and to stumble on the shoes which are directly on the waters edge is a welcomed experience.

Simply moving. At breakfast our second morning in Budapest, my sister told me on her morning run she past a bunch of shoes on display by the river near the Parliament Building. In my research before our trip, I had read about "Shoes" and told her about the Memorial. It was one of the things I wanted to make sure I saw in person while we there...two days later I did.

It speaks for itself. A very simple but powerful sculpture to represent those murdered by Hungarian Nazis, shot and dumped into the danube...just another sculpture really until you look closely, a pair of womens shoes next to a toddlers shoes, flanked by male shoes, brings home the brutality of the moment.

forlorn. It was moving seeing these forlorn aged shoes cast in metal on the banks of the Danuube reprsenting the lost souls of Jewish people in the Holocaust. Pleased i saw them on the way to the Parliament building whose sculptures and statues and the building itself are very impressive.
Beautiful art - to remember. That is a remarkable way to remember the people who perished with the hope of a better life. Must stop by on the way to the Parliament.

Understated and Thought Provoking. If you just come across these assorted shoes whilst walking along the riverside they can seem like foreground props for a photograph across the Danube... When you know the story behind the shoes - they are chilling and thought provoking.
Moving. This is a very moving site to see especially when you read the history behind it. I wouldn't miss it if you are in Budapest!

A place for reflection. It's a inviting place for reflection and emotion. It's very simple but i think moste people some how get touch by it and I think it's something you have to see when in Budapest.

Thought provoking. One of the most moving and sad monuments I have seen. This simple art work prayed on my mind for days I was especially moved by a public work which draws attention to a dark and shameful episode in Budapest's history. All credit to the bravery of modern Budapest in erecting this memorial.

Very impressive, lots of emotions with minimum means. This is something which should be seen to be reminded of the Nazis terror against the Jews in WWII.
Doesn ´ d need more explanation

Dauntingly sad. I have heard about this from a friend and decided to go and look for it. Easy to find if you walk from the Chain Bridge towards the Parliament building. Just a small area with the shoes and a memorial sign. Almost easy to miss if you don't walk on the walkway next to the Danube.
Very sobering experience.... Seems a bit odd at first thought but when you visit, you feel the power of a simple memorial. Personal notes and comments really make this hit home...
A vital reminder to the atrocities during the Nazi regime. Take time out to wander along the Danube and visualise what occurred to these Jewish people during Hitler's invasion. A must.
Charming. Charming monument to commemorate such a terrible incident. I recommend visiting and saying a prayer for the deceased..

Memorial. Extremely moving to look at the shoes from holocaust victims which have been bronzed and made into a memorial on top of the River wall outside Parliament House. Many leave flowers as tributes to their courage. Annoyed to see a Japanese tourist sit down among them to have her photo taken! Some respect please!

moving. me, my father and my brother went to Budapest. had heard about this place from an hungarian friend who fled from the communistic terror after the fall of the nazis. This monument really in the simplest of ways touches you and it shows the cruelty of dictatorships. binding people back to back, shooting one and throwing them into the water, after they removed the shoes which were preserved.

Not big enough.... The memorial site is not big, and I do believe that it's missing some explanation. This important place needs
Some publicity

A strong experience. The spot where the shoes are situated is not really marked and you get there while wondering along the danuba on the pest side.The stories about the mass killing of jews by pushing them into the water, being tied in a group, so there was no chabce for them to escape and be saved of drawning are so sad and outrageous. The monument makes them so real. It is a must.
Very sad. A reminder of those who were sadly killed. Worth a visit to pay respect and also a part of history that will never be forgotten.

Simple but powerful. We visited Auchwitz a few years ago and there is a room full of shoes. It is the most claustrophobic room I have ever been in. For me it was the moment Auchwitz overwhelmed me. Horrendous. Many of hose who lost their life there were Hungarian Jews. This Small but powerful monument is very moving.

Shoes On The Danube. A unique but sobering memorial in remembrance of those who lost their lives in this atrocious historical event. Although quite chilling when you think about what these poor people went through, it's worth the visit just to pay respects.
Overwhelmimg. The memorial is dedicated to the victims of the Holocaust. A very fine work of art - the symbolic shoes of the Jews that were shot by the banks of the Danube.

Very sad sight!. Places like this always remind one of how evil people can be to one another. Situated right on the water's edge it a sobering sight. Realistic shoes commemorating an awful incident. Worth the visit.

Shoes. i,m not sure how to describe this . It represents a terrible atrocity and therefore people having their photo taken sat next to the shoes seems bizarre. It is also part of history and is marked for remembrance . As memoriums go it's a nice one.
So sad. Went a couple of days ago bitterly cold so it made it more real the thought of families being thrown in the water alive and death being a short moment away so sad

Amazing. Stumbled across this art set up on the off chance of us wandering along the Pest side of the river. It really does capture the heart and shows emotion.Very simple but very catching. Beautiful memorial.

Touching Monument. This monument is really worth visiting, especially if you know the story behind it. The way it is done is very clever and it is a part of history you can't hide from. I think it is a memorial to those poor people persecuted because of their religion. Also interesting is the debate about Hungary's involvement in the Holocaust. It opens up a number of questions
good for history and photos. This place on the river Danube is historic the Jewish people and their history, so we were told. Very sad story but true.

Not a place to spend half a day, but make sure to drop by when in Budapest. A small, heart-touching memorial to the Jews shot by the bank of the River Danube. Nothing much to see, but it is nice to visit such a memorial, and reflect about how different things were just 70 days past.

Moving. A very moving tribute to the victims of war. A must see to appreciate the atrocities committed. Very close to other main attractions and easy to get to while enjoying the scenic walk along the Danube

Emotional Tribute/Memorial. This was a sad but moving memorial to the victims of the holocaust of 1944. It is situated on the beautiful Danube near Parliament House and is worth visiting and taking some time to reflect on he past and share love for the future.
Cool, unlikely to get a good photo though! . Cool little thing to see as you walk along the Danube near parliament. Was worth a detour to see but struggled to get a photo without anyone else in!

Simple and very, very fitting.... I walked here early in the morning, no one was around and it made the whole time feel very poignant and fitting. I wanted to pay my respects without hundreds of other people around. I sat and reflected on the terrible tragedies of war. I loved this memorial site, very beautiful, thank you.

Thought provoking. I came across this on the way to the boat to go across the river. Any memorial to WW2 gets to me every time and this was no different. The different size of shoes reminder you that this was an event that affect everybody of all backgrounds, age, race and gender. Rightly so this memorial remains in a good condition so it can continue to act as a place of remembrance for all those who pass both locals and tourists alike.
Incredible memorial. We were quite moved by this memorial. This is not to be missed! People put candles in the shoes and light them.

A lovely view of the Danube and a sobering history.. This monument is a justified tribute to the Hungarian Jews that died during the Holocaust. The history is nice to know and I implore you to look into the history whilst at the monument, it is very sobering. The only issue I had was the other tourists, thinking it was okay to get down with the shoes and have their photos taken with them, not very tasteful.

Good stop between chain bridge and parliament. It a great stop if you're taking a walk by the river. My boyfriend and I were having a walk in the evening and we decided to check out this sight. I think the view is astonishing in the evening so I would recommend to check it out when the sun goes down!

Far more accessible than the Holocaust memorial in Berlin. Given that so many of Hungary's Jews were murdered by tying three people together, shooting one and then throwing all three into the Danube from this point, this memorial is incredible simple and achingly poignant. The shoes are all different and remind us that every one of those killed was an individual. In the city which has such a huge Jewish population and which still boasts the second largest synagogue in the world, it is shocking that the Jewish population is just 3%, so it is important that we remember the past and the long shadow that it casts over the present.

Such a touching monument!. A monument to honor the Jews who were killed by fascists in Budapest during World War II.. So touching! We sat there for a while thinking of all the people who sufered back then and how some things never chage.. People all over the world still are in great pain! It worths your time.. It's situated exactly under the Hungarian Parliament!

An Opportunity to Reflect and Remember. This is a fitting memorial and one that reminds us all of the unrest that these parts has endured during the past century. It's poignant, and it's a well created monument.

Subtle memorial . A nice memorial for such a sad event. It is situated on the bank of the Danube and worth a visit. Unfortunately there is no information at the site so you'll have to read up some other way.

Moving and memorable. We accidentally stumbled across this after visiting the parliament building. We were walking along the river and saw these shoes on the sided of the path. We saw some flowers in the little shoes and the flurry of people around the memorial, we went to have a look, but had little idea of what we had seen.When we got back to the hotel we realised what this memorial was, it's a very sad peice of art, but a very real feeling of sadness when you reflect on what happened there.It's a memorial to all the Jews who we lined up along the river side, asked to talked off their shoes, and then shot into the Danube river. There is also more information of this at the Budapest castle.

Be thoughtful with these kind of memorials. As everything related to the world war two and its terrible consequences, it is necessary to be conscious of the sorrow suffered by millions of people decades ago, Please, It is not "just" some shoes in the riverbank.

Walk the Danube and stop by. This is 10-15 minute attraction walk by. Take tram 2 or walk on Danube promenade towards Parliament building and you will find it.We were there by night and took some amazing pictures.
Solemn Remembrance. A solemn and poignant art installation commemorating the Jewish pogrom in WWII. Situated on the bank of the Danube River near the Parliament building.

Moving Memorial. Beautifully done, this memorial of rusting shoes represents the adults and children who first took off their shoes before being shot into the Danube by the Hungarian Fascists during WW2. Go at dusk when candles left by visitors have been lit. Unusual and moving this is a welcome addition to the memorials around town. Well worth a look.

Visit if you stumble across it. Very hard to review this historical site. Yes this was a site of execution during the last world war, howevwr you would not know it based on the lack of information at the site. We stumbled across this riding on the no. 2 tram. I know the jewish sites hold high importance in terms of historical importance, this in my opinion is more a form of artistic expression relating to an historical event. Respect and remember the past. Be faithful to it's memory.

Very moving. A very moving memorial to all those who lost their lives. It feels wrong to talk about this as an 'attraction', but it's well worth seeing, to take time to reflect on such an awful time in history.

Moving memorial. We visited Budapest in May 2015. Beautiful city and many lovely buildings and things of interest to see.The most moving, was the memorial to the people executed on the banks of the Danube. They were told to remove their shoes and kneel by the side of the river. They were then shot, and their bodies fell into the Danube.The memorial, models of the actual shoes, which are cast in bronze and placed by the side of the river. Shoes of all shapes and sizes, men, women and children. Well worth a visit.
Very moving. As other reviews have said previously definitely worth appreciating up close and remembering why it is there.

Remember..... I read about this before coming to Budapest and so it was a thing I liked to see. The thought of why they are there is with sadness but it's such a nice thing they have done in memory for all the Jewish people who lost their lives during WW2.
A moving Moment. This is in memory of all the different people who were killed by being shot and pushed into the Danube. Young, old, men and women. Such a sobering reminder.

A moving memorial!. This memorial is to the Jewish residents of Budapest who were killed by the Arrow Cross Nazi party in Hungary shortly before the end of WW II. They were shot into the river Danube after being lined up on the shore. And they were forced to take off their shoes, because shoes were so expensive and hard to find in Hungary at the time. An especially evocative memorial, the metal shoes remind us of that tragic time in history. This is Hungary's most heart-rending memorial. Don't miss it.

Powerful monument. During Second World War many Jews from Budapest were rounded up, tied tightly and taken to the Danube banks where they were shot and thrown into the river. The monument situated in front of the Hungarian Parliament might be only shoes but it is extremely powerful. Besides, the view of the Buda Castle district from there is magnificent. There is no fee to visit this monument.

Moving memorial. The shoes are memories for Jewish people who were shot here to the Danube on a cold Winter day.Worth to visit the place anyway if you visit the Parliament or walk in the area. At the Southern edge of the Parliament building there is a crosswalk secured by traffic light. Cross the busy street there and walk southwards.

Solemn and touching monument . This is one of the more human monuments to the wasteful loss of life in the 1940s. It's certainly worth visiting and spending a few minutes contemplating its significance. A short walk from Parliament, along the Danube it is definitely worth visiting and a trip to the 'House of Terror' - the museum remembering the murdered and disappeared - will provide the background context if you're unfamiliar with the context. It's not uncommon to find stones, flowers or other memorabilia within and scattered around the 40 or so pairs of iron shoes.
Sad but moving. Very sad but moving experience along the beautiful Danube in Budapest. Very close to the Parliament Building. Worth a stroll along the river to view..

Very moving tribue. What a solemn and moving place. Many of the shoes had flowers or lit candles inside them and as you stood and thought about the many people who died here you really felt transported back in time to WW2 era. We need memorials like this that move people and remind us of the horrendous consequences of evil actions. Thoughts were with the living relatives of those who died here

Don't miss this when visiting the parliament . A short walk from the Hungarian parliament on the river this is a understated and poignant memorial. Make sure you take a short walk to include this in your visit. Take a few minutes to walk past the shoes and reflect.

SAD HISTORY. More than 70 years ago, murderous gangs of "Arrow cross" (Hungarian fascists) gangs arrested Jews and sent them to the Danube embankment. Here they were shot right in the river where they disappeared for ever. Very few survived. The shoes are a reminder of the events that should never happen again. Very sad and moving and it has a profound message to our cruel age.
Worth going by if you are in area!. Be careful crossing street as there is no place to walk direct there. Interesting place to people watch and take a look at this art.

Poignant and not well publicised. Stumbled across by accident near to the houses of parliamnet. We had found no reference in the guide books so finding it was a shock. Its simple but gets the message across
Stark Reminder. A reminder of the attrocities commited against the jews back in the day. did notice a couple of pairs of childrens shoes which was quite moving

Incredibly Moving.... I'd been looking forward to visiting this one ever since I found out were going to Budapest. I cannot overstate how moving this work is; we stood near it for almost an hour, watching people interact with this very fitting tribute. There are all sorts of very personal tributes left here, along with the customary pebbles. A must see, but very emotional piece of work.
Poiginant. A moving tribute to all the Jews killed during the war. Near the Houses of Parliament. Def worth a visit
surprising find. Interesting find, historical and thought provoking on the edge of the river bank, promenade. First thought it was fishers left overs!
Touching . An emotional reminder to an abhorrent time in history, a touching piece on a humanitarian level. Fascism is still with us but I hope this sculpture helps to eradicate it in some way.

Poignant but not for the faint-hearted. This memorial was erected in 2005 to the Jews who were executed by the ruling Arrow Cross militia during WWII. It is a unique and very moving tribute. I found it quite upsetting, particularly seeing the small children's shoes in amongst the adult shoes. Nevertheless, a must to see and reflect on the horrors of war.
Nice place... The place has got historical importance for Hungarians.. located on the banks of Danube and opposite to parliament.. the view is simply great.. one cannot miss clicking few pics here...

Goosebumps. As I stood there, I pictured in my mind the men, woman and children who had been lined up on the banks of the Danube and mercilessly murdered. So very haunting - one of the saddest things I have ever seen. So lovely to have a memorial to the victims of this atrocity.
Heartbreaking. A must see: stand amongst this memorial and contemplate the fate of countless Jewish who perished along the Danube bank during WII.
A beautiful and unique-looking memorial. An unique-looking memorial by the Danube. You walk there from nearest metro station in 5 minutes. Simply worth visiting and won't take a long time.

Kind of moving tribute. This is just a collection of actual size statues of shoes, put there a few years ago to represent the horrific murder of Hungarian Jews by the Arrow Coss militia during the second world war. They were dragged from a nearby building, told to remove their shoes, and then shot so they fell into the river. There are only a few shoes, and apparently 20.000 Jews were killed in this way. The small plaque in the stones nearby talks of 'victims' rather than Jews, I am not sure why. The sight of children's shoes amongst them does make the memorial more poignant.
Historical. Nicely done,If you're in Budapest it is worth seeing it. Strong memorial for victims shot in Danube..

special. very nice to see those shoes standing next to the water. Hungarians but flowers in the shoes to remember the victims. This is a nice picture spot. If you walk from the Parliament to the Chain Bridge you pass these Shoes...
Sad, haunting..yet beautiful. It is a must see when in Budapest. Reminds us that wars are never justifiable and that the innocent are the one's who always pay the price of greed.
Hauntingly beautiful. A must see. A special memorial. Really makes everything hit home. Take a walk down the river and enjoy the sights along the way!
Remembering. Similar and unique from all the other holocaust memorials. The shoes along side the Danube leaves you only endless grief.
Stunning memorial. A unique and sad memorial, It is a walk down from the Parliament buildings along the river. The different shoes, child's, men and women's create a powerful image.

very surreal. This was a very moving tribute to the precious Jews who were murdered. We were moved to tears, especially after seeing baby shoes! The city of Budapest is magnificent. I think it is the most beautiful city I have ever seen. Stunning. We were there with Viking River Cruise and visiting the FABULOUS Christmas markets.

Very powerful. you almost want to pick up those tiny toddler shoes and take them to a safer place... No child had to suffer this way, including all the men and women that met their fate during that time. the memorial is alongside the Pest side of the Danube, and is easily reachable from walking on the trail of the Promenade, cannot be missed.
Strange, Quirky.. Make time to visit this strange display of boots and shoes near to the Parliament Buildings, haunting but very memorable.
Worth to visit. It's a very nice monument of the Hungarian Jew. It's very simple, but still able to evoke strong feelings.

Somber and touching. We stumbled upon them when walking towards the Chain Bridge from the Parliament on the picturesque path Ali g that Danube. They are so touching and a somber reminder of how terrible things were in those times and what people had to endure. So thankful for the freedom we have today and living in a free country (America).

Impressive if you know the story. You'll be walking the Danube and you'll see several statue-shoes... Nothing really special about it until you know the story of how the nazis forces the Jews to take off their shoes right before they were pushed into the frozen Danube. Then you see it in a completely different light
Simplistic but powerful memorial. While it is a small and simplistic attraction, it is one that should not be missed. It only takes a few minutes to see it so there is no excuse in missing it.
Simple but effective. You know the story, simple memorial but quite haunting and very effective. Not signposted (it's on the river bank near to the Parliament) but worth seeking out.
Nice.... Nice thing to see, it's not so much about it's beauty, more about this monument history and story behind it.

Moving & artistic tribute. The shoes are located a close walk from the chain bridge. They give a thought provoking reminder of the devastation which captured Europe last century. The shoes are scattered along about a 30 meter stretch of concrete next to the river and show shoes of all different styles and sizes representing the people of all ages and backgrounds who were put to death. This is definitely worth a visit as the memorial is very well done.
Nice, but... it was a nice step to do during my trip, it was grat to take pictures there, too.. but i was disappointed that there were no information about the story or reasons why they were there.

Stunning memorial. Hauntingly beautiful. I had heard there was a beautiful memorial along the Danube and I was not disappointed. First spotted whilst out for a late night walk in the fog on my first night in Budapest. The shoes are displayed along the Pest bank of the Danube River between the Chain Bridge and the Hungarian Parliament. There is a plaque on the floor stating what the shoes represent. The whole memorial is to represent those killed during the Arrow Cross Militiamen who were told to remove their shoes before being shot with their bodies to be taken by the Danube. Lots of thought has gone into this memorial and they have done it justice. I recommend seeing this memorial at dusk or in the evening as less people around and its hauntingly quiet.
haunting. one of the most moving exhibits memorializing the horrific, unfathomable acts of anti-semitism during the Nazi regime

Animal insticts.... It's said that before the Nazis execute the Jews, they forced them to take off their shoes. So, this monument is dedicated to the Nazis massacre. It gives you the chills. Makes you wonder what really differenciate us from animals...

Sad only in the middle of the city. It is kinda hidden in the middle of the city and its out any further explanation about the monument. We found it by coincidence and i really liked it. It really simple but makes you think about it.

Lovely Little Memorial. Very nice memorial, people still lighting candles and leaving flowers and notes with the shoes.A sad reflection of what happened here but nice that those people are remembered.Worth a look!

Touching & Sad. It's a sad reminder of Hungary's past, but it's surprisingly powerful. Worth a look if you're heading that way to Parliament. Maybe not worth going only to see the shoes unless you're connected in some way.

Walk by on the way to/from the parlamant building.. A memorial to the people shot by the danube river during the 2nd world war. If you are in the area i guess this is worth checking out. And you probably will be since Budapest ain't that big. It is pretty close to the parlament making it rather convenient for a visit.

Better than a thousand words. Visited this place right after the terror museum and it really impacted me because it places you right where these people would have stood. At first I was silly and thought that these shoes were real and preserved in glass cases or had some kind of moulding casted onto it, only to find that they are metal replicas. Still very powerful and worth the visit, especially after some background info.

An amazing sight . I came across the shoes at the edge of the river. I was not sure what they were for but felt they were linked to a tragedy of some sort. This is definitely a sight to view. I have since found out the history behind the shoes and they reinforce the memorial. This links back to tragic events in which Nazis killed Jews but gun fire in which their bodies fell into the river. Very sad history attached to this but still worth a visit.
Small but moving memorial. A small but thoughtful and moving memorial. Makes you stop to think and appreciate the freedoms some of us enjoy. Sad to think of the many who lost their lives.
Touching. A very nice way of making a monument. It's both small and in the same time big. Not like a normal monument, but very touching.
So what?. Ok if you are near the area you can go take a photo!! Other than that it is nothing special, just some shoes on the river bank.
Somber. Worth the visit, however is not much to see besides the shoes and a small plaque. It is moving tribute to those who were executed on the bank of the Danube.

.... Monument to the people who got shot years ago and their bodies fell into the river. Located next to the parliament on the promenade. Dp some research online before visiting it, it is really worth it

Interesting Memorial Sculpture but disappointed. The sculpture in itself was quite interesting and in a perfect place beside the river. However I was disappointed as it seemed to not be maintained very well and the area around it just seemed to be littered with trash. I understand that being an outdoor exhibit that it will prone to collecting some debris, but what was there just seemed to be a collection over a longer period than even a few days. Overall worth walking to though.
What..?. I have visited a couple months ago and my opinion is that this sightseeing is overestimated. Nothing special.!

Absolutely touching!. this place is really something! Combine the meaning of the memorial + the stunning view, and I challenge you not to shed a tear.... I loved it, possibly my favorite part of Budapest!

Devastating Art Installation Commemorating the Holocaust. Our small group (my husband, our 20-year-old daughter, and myself) were all affected for hours after seeing this powerful outdoor exhibit. Make sure to read up on the history of what it is commemorating before you see this, and I can virtually guarantee that you will not fail to be moved.
Historical place. This is a must to see where the shoes are laid near the river in rememberance of the people who lost their lives in the war.

Moving memorial. . Well worth the visit. An understated memorial which could be overlooked by which really moved me. It humanises the victims of this terrible shooting and is treated with respect with flowers and candles.

A most original commerative art to Jewish victims. A shocking landmark to remember the Jews who were shot into the Danube by the Hungarian arrow-cross nazis in January 1945. Bronze shoes and boots are scattered around on a stretch of less than 100 meters along the left bank of the river, near the Chain Bridge.
Must place. It s a must place to visit in Budapest. However, it is better you to search and find some information about these shoes. Impressing.
Very humbling. This is a beautiful memorial and very tastefully done. It's very humbling. I would recommend this when you are in Budapest x
Heartbreaking. One cannot visit knowing the story behind this attraction without being emotionally moved. I loved that people had left flowers in the shoes as a heartfelt condolence.

Moving tribute to a dark moment in Hungarian History. This is a very simple, but moving, monument - cast metal shoes representing the spot where Hungarian militia forced Jews to take off there shoes line up on the bank and shot them into the Danube.
Memorable sight. monument has both cast shoes and real shoes that people have put down as well. Moving place that is easy to get to.
Makes you realize the turbulence at that time. Very touching sculpture of the shoes of many Jews and others who were shot on the banks of the Danube and fell into its icy waters
A touching memorial. This was a beautiful memorial to take note of on a misty January morning, very moving and worth stopping to see.

Travel dairies - Budapest . Because I have read others experiences about the memorial it was easy for me to find the location . It was such a different experience and rest in peace for all the souls lost during WW 2.

Touching monument. I got very emotional comming here. I would recommend to read about it before I go here to know the history. The book "all the pretty shoes" is an example of a book about the happening, very sad and tragic.

Strange but moving. This was a strange monument. At first look I thought the shoes were real! I had to touch then to be sure they were bronze. When you realize that so many people were effected by such horrible atrocities .

Moving, powerful memorial. This is not easy to find but it is worth the effort to search for it. You can either spend minutes or hours at this site. I stayed for quite a while sitting by the promenade.A poignant reminder of a cruel part of human history and how we should and can do more in making this world a better place. Saw some tourists smiling happily and doing selfie with the installation. Please, please do not do that. Personally I find it very disrespectful.Go early in the day if you like some quiet moment at this site.
Nice surprise . Nice surprise while walking across the river towards the parliament! No sign mentioning the historical point of the shoes, you need to check the guide before.

Moving tribute.... This exhibition of discarded shoes along the edge of the Danube is a moving tribute to a very tragic time during WW2, when Jews jumped into the river to escape being captured by the Nazis.

Moving tribute. This is a tribute to the lives lost during world war 2. Thus is a tribute with a difference. Everyone knows of the atrocities of WW2 but this tastefully highlights the diversity of the civilian victims using only their shoes. My daughter cried when she realised that the Nazis didn't discriminate and murdered adults and children alike. This monument isn't far from the shopping areas in Pest and can walked to. It is close to the parliament building. Take a moment to remember those lives that were lost.

Busy - but worth a visit . The shoes were surrounded by people we did go during the middle of the day though. There were also people leaving things in the shoes and trash around the shoes which was disappointing if you wanted to get a good picture. I would recommend going earlier in the morning if you want to try and get some good shots. Worth the walk if it is not to far out of your way.
Very close to the parliament. Difficult to find tha shoes if you don't know where exactly is. When you fund them you feel something special.
Sad and brings back history. Very sad honestly just to imagine what happened here in history. A must see in Budapest. Recommended to see
A short walk from Chain Bridge. We were staying in a hotel near the Chain Bridge and heard about the shoes on the Danube so after a short walk we were able go see them.

Thought provoking. I had seen the pictures and imagined how I would feel, but wasn't prepared for the emotions the shoes evoked. The shoes are a poignant remembrance of those who lost their lives in the Holocaust. The most touching was the tiny pair - very upsetting.
Excellent Place for a moment of Reflection. This memorial is evocative and pulls the heart strings. Any reminder of the effects of unrestrained racism and nationalism is worth reflecting on

Moving. This moving memorial of empty shoes commemorates deaths during the Holocaust which devastated the Hungarian Jewish population in 1944 and 1945 especially. Emotional reminder of those tragic events.
[Silence]. Very beautiful homage to the innocent victims of war... Take your time to have a seat and burn a little candle.

A touching tribute. A very touching tribute to all the people who lost their lives. We were in Budapest the same day that the terrorist attacks on France happened and this was a peaceful place to reflect. Well worth seeing.

Take pause for absorption of this display. Suggest this area be visited early morning before the crowds. The Danube was still and the area was quiet allowing time to fully feel the emotion of what had taken place, very powerful.
Thought provoking. A poignant memorial to those shot along the Danube, although it's so unobtrusive that I nearly walked past it. Worth stopping just to pay respects.

Beautiful but lack of info . Great piece of art, great way of reminding passers by that we shall not forget.
However, We would have wanted a sign somewhere telling us more about the artist and History behind this piece. If you don't know what it is, there really is no way to know once there.
Sad, poinant, thought provoking. Lovely artwork and nice idea to remember those killed by the Hungarian version of the KGB. Worth a visit whilst strolling by the Danube.

Moving memorial. This memorial is close to Parliament and is a must-see. Very moving to think that it represents Hungarian Jews who lost their lives in that spot. Shoes were expensive so before their execution they would leave their shoes behind.
Somber and respectville.. In memorial to Jews taken to the river and shot towards end of WWII. Nicely done and very glad I went to it.

Symbolic of great loss. The shoes was a beautiful and touching memorial for the holocaust.Before you go you should read a little about the hungarian Jews. This specific story talks about how the naxis would make the jews take of all their clothes and belongings on the rim of the Danube, tie them together and shoot only one, the others would fall to the river with the one dead person to weigh them downThe shoes symbolize how the Nazis dehumanized the Jews. We can see, from all the different kinds of models and sizes, how the Nazis wanted to eliminate the whole race, no matter gender, color, or age.A touching memorial right in front of the parliament building. I highly recomend it

Very moving. Just walk along the bank of the Danube, from the Chain Bridge towards Parliament... it only takes a few minutes and then you come across a moving tribute to 60 people who lost their lives when they were shot into the Danube by Hungarian Nazis in WW2!When we got there, we realised that other people had placed candles and flowers in the shoes and we wished that we had thought of that... it was extremely moving and although sad, was well worth a visit.

this is a must see installation. shoes were in short supply so before the Jewish people were tossed into the river to die, they were made to remove their shoes and this is a memorial to that sad event -

Beautiful and so moving. Amazing memorial. A lot of holocaust memorials are huge, engraved or heavily adorned monuments. Shoes on the Danube is the opposite. Simple but so though provoking and powerful. It is a simple reminder of the horrors Budapest suffered and stops you in your tracks as you pass it, trying to imagine how the victims felt. Must not be missed
Very exciting. Very exciting, transfers very strong message .Shoes are placed midway, there are always people around lighting candles and place flowers.

very moving and impressive monument that makes you think.. you can't imagine what has happened here in WW II, i was very moved by this monument. take some time to reflect and decide what is really important in live.

A must see - a sobering reminder of WW2. Just down from the parliament building the shoes on the Danube are a must see when in Budapest as they are a memorial and a reminder of what happened during WW2 - the Jews were made to take off their shoes and were then shot, thus falling into the river and their shoes being left behind.

So moving !. I didnt expect to be so moved by the sight of the Shoes along the Danube - it is such a simple but so powerful monument - particuarily the sight of chldrens shoes - make sure to see it - it is very near the Parliament building

Sadness. When going through everyday life, one tends to forget about what people have been through. This memorial was a reminder of what the Jewish people went through during WWII. Just trying to imagine the pain and suffering was mind boggling.

Moving Tribute. Located on the river promenade just downstream from the House of Parliament is a moving tribute of bronzed shoes to memorialize the Jewish Holocaust victims. Some are adorned with stones, flowers and candles. Very sombering. The only thing that is missing is some kind of memorial plaque as the uninformed passerby may not know what they are looking at.

Must see. This place is a very expressive memento of Hungarian history . From this place the Hungarian nazis shot Jews to Danube river
Not miss it
Moving place. Moving place to visit next to the Danube river - a must visit - to remind you of the cruelty of war against innocent victims.
Solemn site. Powerful monument to the Jewish Hungarians who were killed here during WWII. The bronze shoes were adorned with small tributes, including flowers, candles and personal items.

Heart-Stirring. Perfectly located next to the calming banks of the Danube, this memorial is a beautiful reminder of the persecutions that a people faced, but also a reminder of the strength they had to overcome it.

Cruel reminder. This memorial is situated right on the Danube river and just before the Parliament. In order to reach it you have to walk on the pedestrian road between the Chain bridge and the Parliament.It is a cruel reminder of the suffering of the Jews during World War II where hundreds of Jewish men, women and children, were forced to remove their shoes and were then shot with their bodies falling into the river and then carried away.

Very interesting area to visit. This area was quite difficult to find as it is at the side of the road (just before the river). Once you reach the area it I'll be worthwhile visiting while you're near the parliament. Tip: bring a pair of shoes to leave behind (if you want). Highly recommended to visit this area during your visit.

Telling Art- Missing details . As others mention, for art's sake, this is a simple yet deeply moving piece that on its own, tells the story of the cruelty and inhumanity Jews experienced during WWII. And this time, at the hands of Hungary 's own Arrow Cross fascist who round up thousands of Jewish men, women and children , forced them to remove their shoes and brutally shot them so they fell into the Danube. What is extraordinarily disappointing are the memorial plaques in English, Hungarian and Hebrew which refer to these people as "victims". It is hypocritical to allow the memorial and not mention Hungary 's own stake in the holocaust with the absence of the word "jews" on the plaque. These were "Jewish " victims.....again. also, the memorial is not easy to find nor easy to reach. But worth it and moving.
Sad. I have seen a few monuments regarding WWII and its subjects, but this one affected me the most. It is a cruel reminder of a cruel chapter in history.
Somber. Painfully a wonderful reminder of the atrocities that took place. May we never forgot. Look for the inscriptions on the ground level. Moving in a non-threatening manner.
Thought Provoking. This simple memorial,to some of the thousands of jews that were slaughtered on the banks of the Danube, says it all. I have nothing more to add.

Shoes on the Danube and emotional sight.. Situated on the Pest side of the Danube near to the Parliment building. A sad sight the memorial of the empty pairs of shoes in memory of the Jews of WW2. They had to take off their shoes before they were shot by the Nazis and then their bodies fell into the river and were carried away... Brought tears to my eyes to think of the horrors of it all
Sad memory. I walked along the river side when I was waiting for the tour in Parliament House. It was a bit difficult to find. The shoes told us the sad stories.
Sad....... Very moving monument. The bronze shoes are a sad reminder of how cruel people and governments can be.
So sad. A very poignant experience on a cold miserable day. Really makes you think about life and how you die.

Emotional and powerful reminder. Walking along this memorial brought out a lot of emotions... A simple but thought provoking memorial. Vivid reminder of how fortunate we are... Don't ever let this happen again!
Very sad but good to see. A very creative depiction of an extremely awful event in budapests history. A good place to reflect.na few had candles in which was a love,y touch
Shoe monument, makes you remember the cruelty of war. Located on the Danube promenade. Monument that refers to the place where German soldiers executed Roma, Jewish and ennemies of the regime.

Perhaps one of the most moving yet simple memorials in the world.. It's just bronze shoes scattered on the riverwalk and nothing more. What is left is your imagination to remember how humans can be so cruel. We Americans tend to think of Germany as the country to blame but Hungary and Austria, while they like to act as if they were also victims, seem to have been willing partners in the holocaust.

Peaceful. After visiting the Terror House, we had to come here! The Terror House Tour gave us a great understanding of the history in Budapest and these shoes represent a great deal. It is breathtaking and unforgettable. We went on a cold day and it really make think about what the people suffered.
Shoes on the Danube. It will only take a very short moment of your day but it's worth going and having a minute to reflect. Very easy to get to by public transport.
No more any of this. Once again, I wish there will not be anything like this happen, no more war... Life is a great gift to us all, lets enjoy it, live in peace
Budapest attractions and memorial. This is great little free attractions but also a very sad monument to the victims of war. Good place for panoramic photography.
Poignant memorial. Go and see this poignant memorial situated on the river towpath near the Parliament building and reflect on one of the atrocities of WW2.

Makes you think of lost soles. A very moving place, can't picture what it was like to be killed at this place... The memorial is a lovely place to come and see and makes you think what you have in the world.. Peace for all is what everyone else wants and needs... Very moving....
Poignant.. A simple, poignant memorial, easily missed if you don't walk the river route to or from the houses of Parliament. Made us research into the history of budapest in depth.
Very Moving Memorial. Very moving memorial of the atrocities from the Second World War. Place can really bring to life the history for younger ones who have yet to grasp the realities of war.

Just wish the marker indicated the true identity of the victims. Simple and powerful memorial to the JEWISH residents of Budapest who shot to death on the banks of the Danube by the Hungarian fascists with their bodies dumped into the river. Just very disappointed that the marker failed to indicate that the victims were JEWS and not just "Hungarian citizens."

To remember. The shoes in the side of Danubio River is to remember the people that was killed in the river , during the War and the last think that they did before were took off the shoes. Sad, but important to remember.
Sad sight that hammers a message. It is sad to reflect when standing at this point. The shoes are well made in steel sitting at the edge of the Danube
Very good monument with clear idea. Emotional. One of the best and simplest monuments I have ever seen. Pair of shoes left on the embankment by killed jews.

Poignant site. 60 pairs of 1940 era shoes of people shot and dumped in the Danube by the Arrow Cross Nazis. The victims who were mostly Jewish, were lined up on this spot during World War II, made to remove their shoes before they were shot and dumped into the Danube river. Walking North along the river the big white mansion on the right is the Office of the Prime Minister.

A Somber Reminder of the Ravages of Life in War. This monument is a must see for anyone going to Budapest. It is situated on the Pest side of the River near Parliment area. The Jewish People were lined up on this spot during WWII and made to remove their shoes before they were shot and dropped into the Danube River. It serves as a reminder of what should never happen again in this world. And unfortunately does in some places. But it is so very poignant. Do not miss this.

interesting spot. interesting one to see, quite impressive to reflect about the past and what really happened. However, not really worth going just for it, nevertheless is across the road from parliament, by the danube, so if you are there don't miss it
A reminder of past atrocities!. There is something quiet haunting about this well presented memorial, particularly being visited on a overcast foggy day.A must see in Budapest.
Poignant. We included this in a walk from the parliament building to Chain Bridge, it is a very fitting and emotional tribute to those who lost their lives.
Empty shoes on the rives side.. This empty shoes at the river side is the memory of those Hungarian Jewish people who were shut and drop into the Danube in 1944.
Free View of the River Bank. It's by the river bank in front of the Parliament. A memorial reminder for those who died during the World War II. It's free, got a great view of the Danube Bank.

Pest's Horrible Past. Just a plain horrible way to die. How can some humans be so cruel? Especially in the last 80 odd years. Can you imagine being marched to the edge of the Danube River with loved ones, then told to take off your shoes before being shot and pushed into the water? These people endured so much. I am so happy for them that they are no longer under Nazi or Soviet rule. Places like this, I hope, will remind every generation to never repeat their past.

Not to be missed - incredibly poignant . Easily missed but so important and meaningful. It was quite difficult to look at the tiny child's shoes but we felt it was important to be reminded of these atrocities.

Megdöbbentő és elgondolkoztató.....Memory of the past....remember it happened...... I native hungarian....but I think I have to try to write few words about the "shoes"....when I see it first time although I know the history of my country I was just standing and the feelings run through on me....nobody can imagine or feel what felt thoose people...young ones, old ones or children who were standing in front of the gun fire when they were shooted to the river Danube....I think...no more words...come to see...and remember that the history can repeat itself.....
Sad; but a must see. If you don't know what this memorial is about; read about it.It is well done along the banks of the Danube. It is a must see.

One of the most impressive and poignant testimonies to the Holocaust !. We found this memorial by accident while exploring the outside of Parliament and the Danube. It is so simple and impactful, that you cannot help but feel the pain and loss of the victims of the WWII horrors. A must see!!

Moving but a little disappointing. There was nothing much to this memorial, it was undoubtedly moving but would have been better if it had been a little better kept. The shoes were mixed with litter and other debris which detracted from the memorial.
Beautiful Tribute. A heartbreaking yet beautiful, artistic tribute to the souls of those innocents whose lives ended so tragically on the Danube.

Harrowing reminder of a time never to be forgotten.......... Really easy to find and very accessible by foot. Directly opposite the very impressive parliament buildings are The Shoes of the Danube. Men, women and children once stood here and we're cruelly executed .............for nothing more then being alive.........very very sad
Profund emotion. If visiting the Palace, just walk few meter outside along side the river. Shoes represent what those souls went through during the war.

Poignant reminder of past atrocities. Came across this site walking from a visit to Parliament along the river to the bridge simply intending to cross over to the funicular and go up to the castle district. I had no idea what the installation was but surmised that it had connections to the Jews in Budapest or perhaps to migration. It was only when I got back to the hotel and googled it that I realised that I had been correct in part of my thinking but had underestimated the full horror of what occurred. It is worth seeing and pausing to think about past events, a beautiful and poignant memorial to those who died.
Sad history. Sad, sad, sad. History is bad - let it not happen again!!! We all need to be better people in this World. This is one of the saddest places in Budapest.
Make time to stop here. This is a very poignant memorial to the Jewish people who were murdered here and then drowned. It is a very simple memorial but so moving.

A poignant reminder of the barbarism of man to man. This is a simple little reminder of one of the rather nastier moments in Hungarian history, right on one of the spots where civilians murdered other civilians and let the corpses fall into the river.It could be mawkish, but it is not.You may have to walk up and down the riverbank for a few minutes to find the spot - it's not well signposted.

Stunning for the wrong reason. Never knew about this from previous visits and the reason behind them is not easily found. If you go to Budapest you must visit this part of the Danube then find the story!!!!!!

Historical Memorial. We walked the distance to visit the memorial and it was worth the journey. There isn't a lot of information and the plaque was placed there in 2005. This little memorial will give you a strong sense of Budapest's not too distance past.

Uniquely powerful. One of the more unusal WW2 memorials I have come across, and perhaps due to this it is a powerful one. A definete Budapest must see in the shadow of Parliament, 2 awe inspiring sights in such close proximitiy.

Very touching . It is a small memorial monument, but has a big impact.The story is written on a bronze plaque (I'll let you read it for yourself ).The monument is located just outside the Parliament building, so you can go there before the tour starts (no lines or waiting, it is open to the public).I recommend you go and take a few minutes to reflect on what has happened in this beautiful city during WWII.
An interesting story and worth a visit as you walk along the Danube. A sad story but a significant part of Budapest history. Go along and visit as you stroll along the banks of the Danube

Not that spectacular but interesting. I was traveling on the side of the Danube and i stumbled upon this place. It's an interesting idea and close to the Budapest House of Parliament. It's work 5 minutes of your time to see them.

Touching WWII Memorial. This plainly stated memorial along the Danube is a touching reminder to the atrocities of WWII. Standing there thinking about what the people went through while being shot and shoved into the Danube to drown all because they were Jewish is enough to bring anyone to tears.
All ages were shot and fell into the river.. Sad..takes a few minutes to see but a long time to think over the travesty. little shoes to big ones.
Moving. Simple, powerful and very effective. Very moving. Doesn't need to be more. Hard not to be touched. A quiet thoughtful spot in a busy city.
Nice Promenade. This is the last thing I would think about finding on my path in Budapest but the visual of this piece of art is good. You can make your own story of these shoes.

Breathtaking images. We found these, along the riverside, just below the Houses of Parliament. Some of these beautifully sculptured shoes were filled with candles, flowers and small mementoes which bought home how much was thought of the people no longer with us. They made me feel very humble.

Moving and poignant. This has to be seen .... Our children were deeply moved and it personalised many of the stories they had read in history books.Very moving to see the cast shoes of different sizes and ages with candles lit nearby at dusk.

Very moving. Visited her before heading to the House of Terror on somewhat of a remembrance day for us. 60 pairs of bronze shoes line a small section of the promenade. A very moving piece of art to remember the atrocities the Hugarian people have endured. Must visit if coming to Budapest.

Emotional Memorial and banks of the Danube. Another must visit in Budapest, this emotional memorial showcases the many Jews who were murdered on the banks of of the Danube by the Nazi's during WW2. The only let down is the description of the memorial isn't very visible and one could easily walk right over without even realising what the memorial actually stands for!

Moving monument. First off I went and read the comments who called this sight 'terrible' most claimed it was difficult to find. It couldn't be easier, it can be viewed from the 2 tram and is almost directly in front of the parliament building. Some claimed it wasn't much of a monument and I have to disagree, the shoes are laid exactly as you can picture them after the slaughter of these innocent people. I found this to be a moving monument and worthy of your time to reflect on these atrocities.

shocking. this monument - for the lack of a better word - is to commemorate the crimes against the Jews who were disgracefully shot into the river before and I think even during WWII. With its simplicity it never fails to shock me whenever I walk past it, it brings those horrors rather close to us, and grasps the whole meaning of equality rather good.

Poignant. Just a simple line of old shoes laid out over about a hundred yard stretch of The river Danube, close to the Parliament building.
A poignant reminder of the fate of many Jews under the Nazis during the Second World War.
Moving. Over Budapest on every street corner, square, etc, there are the most stunning and original statues and this is a prime example. Simple, but effective. Very moving.
A poignant reminder. Very simple but moving reminder of the atrocities of war.On the banks of the Danube, Worth a visit definitely
Makes You Think. This place makes you reflect on the sad fate of so many people persecuted during the Holocaust. It's sad that some people have ripped off some of the shoes.

Worth taking a look when walking along the river. While this memorial is lovely and worth taking a look when walking along the river on the Pest side, I wouldn't go out of my way to find it as Budapest has so much more to offer. I also found it difficult to find, however, that may have just been my experience.

A moving reminder . These shoes are a moving reminder of man's inhumanity to man and our ridiculous affiliations with religions and their biased and racists beliefs that some people are superior to others. 70 years later and the world has learned nothing.
Very crowd any time. Very strong atmosphere. But there's a lot of people any time. So, it's not a horribly monument as it have to be.

Not worth it. Budapest has so much more to offer than this place.. There is nothing really nice to see.. You don't really need to go there to see what happened during ww2 all of Budapest has nicer reminders and nicer places.. It was disappointing..
Moving momento. This was quite the moving piece of art. Worth taking a look when walking along the river on the Pest side.

Remember and remind. The monument is located on the Pest side of the Danube Promenade between Roosevelt Square and Kossuth square with the following text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005."The composition of the great Hungarian artist, Gyula Pauer, gives remembrance to the people shot into the Danube during the time of the Arrow Cross terror in 1945. The sculptor created sixty pairs of shoes out of iron. The Hungarian Jews were ordered to take off their shoes at the edge of the Danube and were shot into the water. It's very important to remember and to remind a dark period of our history to avoid similar periods in the future. Nowadays, the very right wing ideologies and parties get sronger worldwide, so it's more imortant to remind the result of this way. Nothing can be so strong memento like a great artwork! This monument is a shocking artwork. The artist, Gyula Pauer died in 2012. Walking on this Danube Promenade I remember him too.

Very moving. This is a very moving memorial to the victims of the Holocaust. We knew it was on the Danube, so we walked from the Parliament Building along the promenade toward the Elizabeth Bridge. The bronze shoes represent the shoes left on the shore when the victims were assassinated and their bodies dumped in the river. Many people leave flowers and candles. Very somber.

EVIL AMONGST US, PAST AND PRESENT. A very poignant and sad reminder of the black days of the war and Hungary's part in it. It is said that those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it, and that is so true. When we look at those shoes, we should also consider the evils that are happening right now, comitted by ISIS and the like. Evil walks amongst us, and it is up to us, men of concsience, to combat and defeat this evil, AND THESE SHOES REMIND US OF OUR RESPONSIBILITY
interesting wall. near town great place to visit lovely view you stand by these shoe find it hard it hard to take in the story behind these shoes very moving story
Touching. Beautiful to walk along the Danube- very touching moment when you come along the memorial and imagine what happened & lives lost.
Very humbling. Wondered what this was as we walked by. It is a commemoration to the Holocaust. Very moving and worth a short stay with some careful thought.
Great memorial. Poignant reminder why we should always fight against tyrannical cults. So sad and moving as the fast flowing Danube rushes by.
Mind numbing. A moving visual memorial, to the thousands of Hungarians murdered by the fascist Arrow Cross Militiamen in 1944/45. They were shot at the rivers edge and pushed into the Danube.
Overrated. I found this place overrated. It has some kind of historical significance which I didn't knew at the time of visit, therefore got bored.

Very moving. This is quite a sad place to visit, no real information contained at the site but if you know the story then the shoes along the river front are very sad and moving, a must see if you visit Budapest

Powerful, humbling!. A simple but powerful and humbling memorial to the many Jews who were murdered in this lovely city. Shoes and boots of all sizes - mens, womens and childrens - what more can I say?
Worth a visit. Wasnt sure what to expect, but this is definitely worth a visit when in Budpest. They way all the different shoes have been captured is quite poignant
Best piece of art in Budapest. Best piece of art in Budapest, an absolute must see. If you are in Budapest for more than 12 hours, you need to make sure that you find time to go see this.

Remembering History and a troubled past. I memorial created to remember the citizens who lost their lives during world war 2. Ews who were murdered for being Jewish. Makes y think about what really happened ad how. Touching to see the candles and flowers left too for the loved ones. Moving.

Fast worthwhile Stop. This is a worthwhile quick stop on any visit to Budapest. This is along the river next to Parliament and a great reminder of what happened all over Hungary during the Nazi regime.
Small memorial . This is a small dedication to the people who had been executed over the danube. Worth going if you're on your way to the parliament but other than that it's just ok

Simple but evocative memorial. Just some pairs of shoes of different sizes placed on a riverside walkway to commemorate Jewish victims who were shot then dumped in the Danube in the war years. A very simple but poignant reminder of mans inhumanity to man.

Surreal. Me and my mum visited Budapest in October and the Shoes on the Danube was one of the most memorable places we visited. Its such a surreal experience and really worth a visit! Very eery and surreal but so interesting, you really feel as though you are there and its a lovely memorial.I would also recommend a trip to the House of Terror to learn a lot more about the history of Budapest, very interesting and worth a visit! It helps you understand the Shoes even more.

Interesting tribute. This is a good stop as you're walking along the river past the bridges. It's worth to take a moment to reflect on the history of the town and the trials that some of its people have been through.

Simple but powerful. So pleased to have seen this small but powerfully moving memorial to fallen Jews. I think that it was the candles and stones that visitors had placed in the shoes that had the greatest emotion for me.
very moving art piece. Not widely publicized but worth the viewing. The thought of these replicas being shoes of those who died because of what they believed and who they were is chilling
Poignant. Very moving reminder of the horrors which took place here. Should be visited. It's near Parliament and very easily accessible by tram.
Poignant. what can one say to another memorial to mans inhumanity to man except atrocities like these should never be forgotten
Sad memorial - must see. Interesting to see but very sad and moving that people were either shot or pushed into the river to die.

Beautiful memorial. We stumbled upon the Shoes on the Danube whilst strolling along the river and recognised it as soon as we saw it! It's a beautiful, poignant and thought-provoking memorial. Definitely worth a visit - it's between the Chain Bridge and Parliament on the edge of the riverbank.
Provoking . Stumbled upon these shoes whilst on a bike ride. It silenced and moved us. What tragic times it must have been. RIP

Emotional. You cannot describe the emotional impact of this memorial. It makes the terrible tragedy so personal. It is something that you take with you and imbed in your thoughts. It is not as overwhelming and frightful as other holocaust memorials.
Sad and a must see . A great dedication to a horrible travesty. Very well put together and artfully placed. We enjoyed it and felt a connection!

To do when you go to the parlement. You can do by walk when you go to the parlement!
It significative That the jewish persons who was dead here.
So sad!
Take your picture and go to the parlement

creative memorial. I cannot get why this attraction is in the top 10. It's nothing special. If you walk along the river it's good to know why those metal shoes are there: during the Nazi regime Jaws were shoot down to the river. It's sad and make us remember the horrible days of the 2nd world war.

Very Emotional. This is a memorial on the bank of the Danube River which was created to honor the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during WWII. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank. There are dozens of sculptured pairs of shoes: men's, women's and children's. This was very emotional to see. This is located on the Pest side of the Danube fairly close to the Parliament building. I highly recommend visiting.
A haunting reminder of thBudapest's past. A very moving exhibition on the Danube promenade in memory of the people who were shot and thrown in the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen
Poignant reminder of the past. Whilst walking along the banks of the Danube you may come accross this reminder of the Jews who lost their lives. Worth stopping to observe

Shoes on the Danube. Very moving place to visit, and I think sad, but a 'must see' experience. We did not know about this memorial beforehand & unexpectedly came across. Added to our experience of Budapest.
Moving sculpture. The Shoes on the Danube is a sculpture that gives remembrance to people who were shot in the Danube 1944-45. Seeing the empty shoes next to the river bank was a touching experience.

You could easily walk pass this . We went to day to have a look and to be honest it was disappointed there is no information for the public to read.
Plus why are there people having photos with these shoes do they understand the meaning of them.
It is a sad part of the history and should be respected more
Simple, but moving.. This is a very understated memorial, but against the backdrop of some of the most beautiful buildings in Budapest, it really brings home the past.
Touching Place. A very impressing Memorial place. it's almost in front of the parliament house . What a symbolic thing. You must see it and pray:"no more".

Sombre. This is a very moving place to visit as it represents lives lost in Budapest
I love the fact that the shoes are very realistic in size and the position that they are in makes sure that all passers by see them
Moving thing to come across as you are strolling the banks of the river

Embarrassingly poor.. Essentially an "attraction" for those tourists with little if any knowledge of history. It marks the execution into the Danube of a few dozen people at a time when reprisal killings by the Nazis were commonplace around Europe and thousands dying in the gas chambers, let alone the further thousands dead or wounded in combat. The memorial itself is scruffy and lacks any information as to the reason or historical context of the atrocity.

Put yourself in their shoes!. This simple yet poignant sculpture expresses far more than words, and is a moving reminder of the inhuman atrocities committed during WW2. It can be found south of the Parliament building along the river embankment.
