A sad, but intriguing reminder or our past.... At first I didn't notice the shoes on the river banks, but when I did and heard the story behind the monument I felt overwhelmed and intrigued by them. A really innovative and poignant reminder of our not-so-far historic events.
Emotional. Great monument...Simple but with lots of emotions!!!!Take pictures and learn about their history!!its pretty difficult to find them though
Thought provoking. A place for quiet contemplation. Knowing what the shoes represent really is heartbreaking but they are a touching memorial to a period of history we should never forget.
Shoes on The Danube. A beautiful yet poignant tribute to times gone by, honoured to see this as its makes you remember the horrors some people were exposed to

A moving experience. This was a moving experience of how the Jewish people were treated during ww2...mans inhumanity to man..it was a special and moving to see all size shoes and realizing what happened that horrible day
Makes you think about the history behind it. Being Jewish, seeing this, really made me stand still for a while and put in me in their shoes. Literally...

Very simple but very moving. A must see when visiting Budapest. It's one of the most poignant memorials I've ever seen. The simplicity of it really makes you stop and think. Bronze shoes, for men women and children, on the bank of the Danube, in memory of the people who were shot here and their bodies conveniently allowed to just float downstream. It reminded me somewhat of the Empty Chairs in Krakow, equally effective though on a smaller scale. Do pay your respects.
Thought provoking !. Stop to take a moment to consider and appreciate the simplistic beauty of this monument along the river !
Touching memorial. Beautiful memorial to the Jews that lost their lives during WW2. Lovely view of the Chain Bridge as well. A must-see in Budapest.

Sobering. If this does not make you think.......nothing will.This is a memorial dedicated to the many people, mostly if not all of them of the Jewish faith. They were lined up along the Danube River.....told to remove their shoes (which were in short supply and could be used by others) and then they were murdered, falling into the river.Although it is placed in the general area where these murders were conducted, it is somewhat stark......by this I mean that there is no signage or anything else to delineate the memorial....you are walking along the river and there it is.Please, stop by and pay your respects.
Moving and powerful. Take a few minutes to read up on this memorial, then stroll down the Danube and contemplate this heartbreaking and tragic tribute. Deeply moving.

Very moving and emotional. This small but powerful display of bronze shoes was close to where our cruise ship was docked and I am glad we made the effort to see it. Not only was their a nice explanation as to what they represented, just seeing them and the offerings left by them was moving. Viewing others equally moved was emotional as well.

Shoes on the Danube. A somber place along the Danube where sixty pairs of shoes represents the site where the Nazi's killed the Jews and dumped their bodies into the Danube. Would be nice to have more of the story behind the memorial

A very poignant memorial. This could be better signposted because we weren't sure what we were looking at when we were there, but even so it was obviously a sad memory of tragedy which we later learned more about. So sad!

Shoes memorial. The memorial has a sad and interesting story behind it, unfortunately their isn't enough information at the memorial and you have to know the story before you come.
The location is just next to the parliament building so it's easy to reach.

A very moving memorial.. A simple memorial that says so much. Sixty pairs of 1940's era shoes, men's, women's and children's, used to honor those victims who were shot on the riverbank by the Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45, so their bodies would fall into the river. A silent and sad reminder of a terrible time in history.

Best war monument I have ever seen. Why must war be so cruel? This is the best war monument I have ever seen. It touches your soul. I recommend you come here and just silently think about life and how short it is.

A moving piece of art well worth a look. This art piece would be easy to miss, not far from Parliament on the banks of the Danube, Pest side looking out to the caste district. The monument is a stark reminder of the tragedies that have occurred in years past, and an opportunity to remember them. It will only take 5-10 minutes but worth a visit on route perhaps to somewhere else.

One of my "must do's". Very touching tribute to the Holocaust.. especially emotive was a single red rose put in a single boot. It should be on everyone's "must do list" when in Budapest. Easy to get to from parliament.

Sombering.. You walk the band of the Danube, past the parliament building from Margaret Island. A hundred meters or so. I sat and thought of ever had happened here. How sad is humanity to do this to each other. Will we ever learn.

Powerful memorandum for WWII.. Just stand by the Danube at this place, look at the shoes and feel the sad history of people shot into the river during the Second World War. Touching and heartbreaking.

Put yourself in their shoes for a moment..... You need to take a stroll along and just have a moment of silence to take in this powerful memorial, I found it very moving. It's worth reading up about the history to appreciate it more.
Dramatic. Or at least It can be if you know what it is all about! If not it is more like some odd shoes thrown away on the sore of the embankment.

Emotional. You should never leave Budapest without visiting this very emotional sight. It is a reminder that we should never never allow anything like this ever take place again. Love thy neighbour and live in peace.

Our most moving memory of Budapest. Fortunately I had read about this memorial, otherwise we possibly wouldn't have realised the story behind it.
I found it incredibly moving, to see the different sizes and styles of shoes representing a complete cross section of the community affected and the memory of it will stay with me always.

Poignant, makes you think twice.. Knowing what happened, the shoes are a a tough reminder of how cruel humans can be. I always stand still for five minutes in silence and look at the Danube. Whether it's raining, sunny or snowing, it's still a beautiful to stroll by the river...
Such a sad site. Powerful stop on our trip. Hearing the whole story of what actually occurred was chilling and seeing this as such a well kept monument genuinely moved me.
Heart breaking memorial. This memorial is heartbreaking but we wanted to pay our respects and it's very quiet and respectful glad we did it

Simple and moving. I had heard about the memorial from my brother who had visited the site earlier in the year and was quite moved by the simple way it was presented. A few of the shoes had flowers in them or other adornments which was so touching. It is a good place to sit and contemplate.
Simple, touching tribute. A moving tribute to those who lost their lives. I wasn't aware of this memorial but I'm very glad I saw it. As powerful as Auschwitz-which I've been to-but much simpler.
moving. Worth the time to go see this. I makes you think about what happened during those horrible times once again...we must never forget.
emotional. came across this memorial, couldn't help but be deeply moved at this simple but powerful memorial. must be visited.

Moving.. A small but powerful installation to capture the tragedy of the Holocaust.
Those into photography can easily spend half an hour clicking away.Or you can simply walk down the promenade ,sit on one of the interesting street furniture and watch the sunset over the river disappearing behind the Buda castle.
There are no words . . .. . . . to describe the horror. Right in front of the Parliament building, it reminds us that it was not too long ago this city endured terrible suffering.
Interesting. A bit disappointed because there were no plates with explanations of the symbol and who did this. By research before we knew what it was about. It's touching

Piece of history . Get off at the tube stop outside four seasons hotel and walk about 3-4minsutes and you will soon see the scattering of shoes on the pier. Felt sad once you know the story of what happened to the poor people. Worth a visit.

A must see. This memorial combined with the expanded information in the Terror Museum serve as a chilling reminder of what can happen when politicians gain too much power - everyone needs to see the horror of unconstrained power so we will never let it occur again

Moment of reflection. There are 60 pairs of sculptured shoes in 1940s design. Thankfully I had read about this memorial before travelling as I could find no information on site. The idea is simple but incredibly effective and emotive. You will find this next to the parliament building, reached by tram 2 or metro2

A Very Emotional Site to Visit -. This site marks the horrific actions of the Arrow Cross Nazi Soldiers who systematically shot and killed hundreds of Jews along the banks of the Danube. They were stripprd of their clothes and shoes, and dumped into the water as they were shot. This memorial only opened in 2005 (?), and shows 60 pairs of shoes (men, women, children) along the top of the river embankment. When you know the story, it is a heart wrenching thing to see. It can be awkward for those who don't know the history, and the meaning is somewhat lost. Jewish or not, you should visit this site, close your eyes, and cry for those who perished here.

ywo day break Budapest. This is a very moving tribute to the Jewish people who were forced to remove there shoes at the rivers edge before being shot, it is one of the simplest and best tributes i have seen.

Somber and memorable. Standing in the fall sunshine it is hard to imagine what this memorial commemorates and symbolizes. At first, I thought the shoes were real and merely fastened to the concrete. Looking closely they are either bronzed or cleverly sculpted to look like real shoes. The day I was there, someone had placed a real shoe amongst these metal ones, no doubt in sympathetic reaction to the horrors committed against the innocent. The current in the Danube, particularly where it narrows, is strong and fast and people executed there must have been quickly swept away. More impactful than a monument, this memorial, located near the Chain Bridge in Pest, is a must see.

interesting memorial for the holocaust. Although the story of the memorial respresents a segment of the holocause story in Budapest and the idea was very creative, the implementation was lacking. The site was dirty and not well maintained and lacked the impact of the message it was trying to present.

Stunning tribute to a terrible time . " less is more" this is excellent - so moving ... Speechless . I've seen many memorials and museums to horrible things that have happened in this world . This is one of the most touching .
so moving. A truly moving memorial to those shot at the banks of the river. A must see, soeveryone will not forget these brave souls.

Simple, but moving memorial. This memorial isn't grand and fancy, but rather simple and down to earth. And, that is what makes it so powerful and moving. It's simplicity leaves the event it remembers in plain view for your remembrance and interpretation. It is definitely worth a stop if you are in Budapest.

A simple and moving memorial. 22nd October 2015. This is alongside the Danube, about mid way between the Parliament buildings and the Chain Bridge. The memorial is a series of shoes (metal of course), apparently scattered at random, but in pairs, at the edge of the bank. It commemorates the many people taken to the Danube, shot, and thrown in. So simple and so moving. Well worth seeing.
Toughing spot .. It is a spot where words are useless..Respect .There are so many sad stories from word war 2 in many places !
Somber memorial. Not far from the parliament building this memorial of shoes on the Pest side of the danube was very sad but interesting.

Very Simple & Moving. On the Pest side of the Danube, near the Parliament Building, is this relatively new memorial to the Jews who were shot and dumped into the Danube late in World War II. I found it to be very moving.

Somber & surreal memorial. Its hard to get your head around the evil that underlies this somber memorial, as it sits now on the shore of this vibrant city. Take time to look at the variety of shoes...mens', womens' and even childrens'. Look at the notes and candles inside some of the shoes. IMHO, this ranks up there at the top in terms of memorials in terms of emotional impact.
Somber Memorial. Close to the Parliament Building whilst walking along the Danube. Rather sad and moving memorial. Worth a stop by.

Memorial to Jews Who Were Murdered by the Nazis. A beautiful monument to those who lost their lives during the Nazi occupation of Budapest. The sight of those shoes really evokes strong emotions. Budapest is such a beautiful city it is hard to understand why such inhumane events happened there on the shores of the Danube.

Very moving. This memorial was amazing and emotion provoking. The only other memorial we have ever seen that was as emotional is the Vietnam memorial in Washington DC. The shoes deplict the scene at the Danube river banks where Hungarians and Jews were lined up, made to take their shoes off, because of the value of leather, then shot and pushed into River. We would recommend it to anyone visiting the area.
Execution spot 1944. Impressive place close to parliament. And close to chain bridge. Boatbus stop nearby, so you can also use public water transportation for visit
Moving tribute. Be sure to ask the history of this exhibit if you haven't learned about it. It was a continuation of executions after the concentration camps were 'officially' over.
interesting holocaust monument. interesting holocaust monument, but it was a bit hard to find, the directions weren't exactly accurate.

Let's Us Not Forget. The 60 pairs of cast iron shoes lying at the river bank looked very unique and perhaps puzzling to some people who do not know the history or reason behind the placement of the shoes. When I was there, I noticed many people tried to take artistic photographs of the shoes. However, we should never forget the actual significant of those shoes. They are reminders that mankind could be so atrocious and cruel by taking innocent lives. We should be reminded that all men and women are equal and no one is above all.I also feel that the Hungarian Government should put up a notice or plaque near the display of shoes as reminder of the pain and suffering of the Jews.
Very moving. A sad but moving memorial to a tragic event in hungry's past during world war two. Can be difficult to find however
Very moving memotial. Historic event remembered in a very moving memorial may all souls be with their god. You can light a candle of remembrance no matter what colour or creed
sad site but.... ... once you are there, you will have a great view of the Danube and the Buda side, while only a few steps from the Parliament building!
Moving. Nothing more to say about this really other than its moving and thought provoking. A poignant way to remember the tragic loss of lives. A must see in my opinion.

A very touching memorial. This is a memorial to the Jewish Budapest citizens who were murdered during World War 2. I had read about the shoes ahead of time so it was more meaningful for me. I had not realized that it was Hungarian Nazi's that had committed this atrocity. Please go and remember the people who were killed there.

Moving Memorial. Created by film director Can Togay and sculptor Gyula Pauer, the Shoes on the Danube memorial honors the Jews killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen during World War II. On January 8, 1945, the victims were pulled from a building on Vadasz Street rented by Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg in order to hide and protect them. They were marched to the bank of the Danube, ordered to remove their shoes, and shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away.Sixty pairs of shoes — men’s, women’s, and children’s — have been cast in iron and affixed to the stone embankment where they somberly remind all who stroll along the beautiful Danube of the horrible tragedy that took place here during World War II.

Very moving. Its is located right on the Danube. The story beyond the shoes is moving. Something if your schedule permits see it. It is a short walk north along the river form the chain bridge where the river cruise ships dock. So sorry the story behind the shoes!

A Sad Part of History. We visited here on our departure day. It is a place that will make you think, make you try and understand the fear, torment and desperation that must have been serging through these innocent victims. So very heartbreaking to see small children's shoes, usually next to ladies shoes of which would of been their mothers no doubt. A sad part of history.
Stirring tribute. A reminder of the dreadful things that went on during the Second World War. One can hardly believe the inhumane treatment of the Jews, was glad to see this memorial.

Touching Tribute. This moving memorial pays tribute to the Hungarian Jews who were told to remove their shoes. They were subsequently shot at the rivers edge with their bodies floating down the river. The shoes left behind leave us a reminder of the horrors of WWII. It is an easy walk along the river between the Chain Bridge and Parliament. Very humbling.

A must visit. This is such a moving tribute to the Jewish people. It feels like they have just left their shoes on the banks of the river.There are no sighs to the shoes just follow the riverbank a little way from the chain bridge.
Moving. A very emotional experiience, but although one of the 3 plaques is in Hebrew, no mention is made that all of the Hungarian murdered people were Jews. Shot and dumped in the frozen Danube.

Breathtaking. Impressive memorial of people who were executed by the Arrow Cross militiamen. Some of the shoes were surrounded by candles and fresh flower. One can never forget this recent history. It's walking distance from the Budapest Parliament building and a must see in Budapest.
Such a sad reason for such a beautiful memorial. It leaves you speechless. We walked a long way to see this and it was well worth the walk. Very moving.

Lest we forget....... This is an amazing memorial to those who died by the side of this lovely river. We must not forget the horrors that were carried out and this memorial is a very touching reminder.

Moving. Came across this memorial on a recent walkabout in Budapest with a group of friends.
Neither I or my friends had any idea what it actually was until later, and having now read up on it, it makes the memorial all the more poignant.
Worth a look...

Humbling Experience. The previous posts outline the history behind this modern memorial so I won't repeat. However, I would recommend taking the time to visit this memorial as it is very moving and humbling.
Relatively central in location so easy to get to.

Very simple yet moving. This memorial can be visited while taking a stroll along danube from parliament towards chain bridge.The shoes on danube memorial is a very simple but still effectively let one imagine the horror tales of jews killing. There are different styles of footwear made out of cast iron but looks so real. The different styles reflects the killing was irrespective of gender, age or profession. A must visit.

Moving. Nearing sunset, I visited the shoes. So moving to see the little shoes, next to the Mama shoes and think in your mind of what had happened. Moving and thought-provoking. May this never, ever happen again.

historical importance. not too far from the parliament, so can easily be fitted in when visiting parliament and going to the pest side. The shoes have a deep historic importance so suggested as an attraction.

Shoes on the Danube. Visited the holocaust memorial Shoes on the Danube to honour Jews killed by Nazi Fascists during World War -2.The Jews were told to remove their shoes and shot by the edge of the Danube with their bodies being carried over by the river.Just their shoes were left behind. This memorial was created by film director Can.Togay with collaboration by sculptor Gyula.Pauer to honour these Hungarian Jews
VERY moving memorial. Just opposite Parliament and on the banks of the beautiful Danube, this Memorial is so worth the visit.

Very Strong!!!. Seeing this moving tribute to the memory of the Jews who were shot and left to float down the Danube is simple, effective - and something that you are not likely to forget. It's as if they just stepped out of their shoes (an expensive commodity at the time), then disappeared off the face of the Earth. A MUST SEE in Budapest.

Simple but moving.. Well worth a stroll along the river to see this. Very simple but effective and moving. Seeing the shoes on the river edge remind you of the history and horrors that this river has witnessed.
Nice memorial . Right outside the parliament building, should be impossible to miss. Worth a quick stop just to remind you of the history of Budapest.

soul drenching. tear jerking,heart breaking. couldn't control my feelings. makes you search ur soul-if it happens now,what would u do in such situation?
World-NEVER AGAIN.

Sad Sight. This is a memorial to those Jews who were executed at this very place. They were made to strip naked, were shot at close range and their bodies dumped in the river. The shoes were kept because they were much valued. There are 60 pair of shoes, made of cast iron, in various sizes and styles, to show that women, children, businessmen, paupers, were executed for being Jewish. It is a very moving memorial located on the banks of the Danube.

Chilling. A reminder of the horrors that took place here. Visitors should make an effort to learn about the horror perpetrated by the Nazi and Communist authorities. This memorial doesn't explain the events, but it is a simple demonstration of what was lost.

Eloquently simplicity. Such a simple and moving reminder of how crazy humans can be.What caused those shoes to be there. Who thought this was going to make anything better. Where is this happening today?

Extremely moving. This very understated memorial is incredibly moving. We stumbled across this by chance as it was not mentioned in the walking tour. There is a plaque giving details but it is worth researching the history of the event to understand the full horror.
Sad.. but not much of an attraction. Sad reminder of the sordid past.. But in terms of attraction, probably worth that obligatory picture.

Basic but effective and moving. Firstly, it is a little bit hard to find as no sign indicates its whereabouts . It is appx 300 meters from the Hungarian Parlament House ( behind the Parlament ) towards the Chain Bridge on the river bank. Once you are there you feel the emotions and horrors those people - young and old - must have felt when they had to make that march. Some people said that the shoes looked worn out but of course as they meant to look like that to show that they were marched probably for hours. I went with my two children ( 9 and 11 ) and it was a good intro to talk about the terrible things that happened during World War II. While you're there say a prayer or a few kind words silently and put a small pebble in or around those shoes!Definitely worth a short stop!
Thought provoking. A very simple tribute to one of the darkest events in history. Its free to see and is just down from the parliament building.
Lovely little sight. Really quite enchanting and captures some of Budapest's wonderful history. Definitely worth a visit, only a short walk from the bridge so you may as well give it a go!
Moving. Beautiful tribute to all who died at river's edge. A solemn, fitting memorial,l and well worth the walk
Heartbreaking. This was the most somber experience on our trip. So sad to see the children's shoes... A must see in Budapest.
A must to see. Every visitor to this city must visit this small but very significant sight-a reminder of a grim past
Moving Tribute to lives lost in the war. this memorial remembers all the jewish people who were killed and thrown into the river. it is worthwile visiting this site.

Worth stopping by. Along the bank of the Danube, about a minute walk from the Chain Bridge is a bunch of shoes lined up by the river. It’s a memorial to remember the Jews murdered by militiamen, and the victims had to remove their shoes because of their value. The memorial was created by Gyula Pauer, Hungarian sculptor, and his friend Can Togay in 2005. It contains 60 pairs of iron shoes, forming a row along the Danube. Each pair of shoes was modeled after an original 1940’s pair. It’s a very powerful memorial reminding us of the horrors of hate.
Very moving. This is a very thought provocking peice you will need tissues and there were plenty of candles left and flowers

Reminder of Tragedy. An understated by dramatic memorial of Man's incredible inhumanity on the banks of the Danube in the majestic city of Budapest. While a painful reminder of past events a must visit for all to pay their respects. This must never happen again.
Heartbreaking Memorial. The Shoes on the Danube memorial to the Jews killed and thrown into the Danube by the Hungarian Arrow Cross Militia is heartbreaking.

A touching Holocost memorial. The memorial is near the Parliament building. It is a sculpture of empty shoes along the banks of the Danube River. It is a tribute to the Jewish people murdered by the Nazis in Budapest in World War II. People were lined up along the banks of the river and shot, allowing their bodies to drop into the river. The monument was smaller than I thought it would be and at ground level it is less than a foot high. It would be easy to miss from a tour bus. You really need to visit this monument on foot.
A very moving Holocaust memorial. A must see for anyone interested in learning about the Jewish holocaust during World War II. You will come away very moved.
Budapest trip. Well worth a visit sad though found it quite moving very easy to find near the parliament buildings on the pest side of the river

This is a must-see!. Budapest is beautiful but it has a very dark history that cannot be denied. I've never seen a Holocaust memorial quite as chilling or affecting. It's right near Parliament. Be sure to read about it first to understand what you're seeing, but DO NOT MISS THIS!

Thought Provoking. One of the reasons we wanted to visit Budapest. We were not disappointed (if you can say it in this way). Everyone should make a visit to the Shoes on the Danube and remember the lives that were lost and still being lost due to war and conflicts. May all their souls rest in peace.
Uniquely Touching Memorial. Nobody can see this memorial without being moved. It's simplicity is it's beauty. Access it quick, the memorial is free and is a must-see in Budapest.
Poignant. Brought tears to my eyes to see these random positioning of all shoe styles and types left by the river's edge
HAUNTING. This memorial commemorates the horrors of human evil. Located on the east (Pest) bank of the Danube, it is a haunting reminder of the Holocaust.

A poignant reminder of the suffering of the Jewish people of Hungary.. Dozens of shoes and boots from toddler shoes to grandad boots line the path by the River Danube. Flowers, little toys and single roses had been laid on the shoes which had been coated in what looked like bronze to preserve them.

Thought-provoking memorial. We found out about this memorial from an excellent tour at one of the Jewish synagogues. We walked along the Danube river until we were nearly level with the Parliament building. It is chilling to think of those who stood there over 70 years ago. A very effective memorial,

so moving. Having visited the memorial in Christchurch NZ to those who lost their life in the earthquakes, I didn't think this would move me. However realising that one was a natural disaster, but the reason for the shoes is man's inability to live with other peoples views, I came away quite emotional.

highly effective unique memorial. although the imagery is a bit abstract, the message and the impact are loud and clear. a quick walk down the east bank of the danube from the main bridge and parliament is just nearby -- this is a must for tourists in budapest -- the memorial honors the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank.

Sombre. Seeing this memorial conjures up the images in your mind and the thoughts in your head as to what it must have been like to live and die in those dark days of oppression and persecution. The image of those shoes will stay with us always.
worth a view. Very nice commemoration for the Holocaust. Imaginative and sad at the same time. Poor people in the WWII :-(

Mixed feeling. I was looking for this particular site and while it is by the water and not difficult to find, one could also easily miss it. I had a mixed felling when seeing these shoes lying there. Some sort of sadness and melancholy ...
Beautifully Evocative Tribute. Simple but very moving tribute. Visit at sunset (or sunrise) to capture beautiful light of the Danube.

A simple and moving reminder of a true horror. To appreciate fully the meaning of the shoes, you need to know the dreadful story of the treatment of the Budapest Jews by the Hungarian fascists towards the end of WW2.

Remarkable memorial. Thought there would have been more shoes when we arrived but the balance was enough to get the point across.Just a crying shame that the memorial had to be there because of what another human could do to a fellow humanWell worth the visit and definitely worth the photographs as both a memory and respect

Stop and take it in. This is a moving tribute to the innocent people who lost their lives it's still hard to believe that people were treated this way. Walk along the river past the parliament building and you will see it by the river. I have been to a few holocaust sites and this one is very well done. Stand for a minute and think life is for living some people never got the chance.

Heart wrenching. We walked along the Danube to this site. Knowing the story it was difficult for my wife to stay very long. Emotions run very high. Everyone should spend a little time at this memorial when visiting this city.

Very impressive. It's a remarkable way to think about the horror that of course also happened in Budapest. Would recommand to read into it before visiting, or taking a guide with you. It's a true loss if you, like many other people, stumble upon this sight, not knowing what it is about.

Makes you think. If you have this this memorial should be visited as a reminder of what happened during the Second World War. It's about a five minute walk by the Danube from the Chain Bridge on the Pest side

Emotional.. Simple but effective idea, very well executed.
Very emotional, must see. people are leaving even their real shoes.

Stops you in your tracks.. We came across this memorial while walking alongside the river. At first we did not understand what it was. After a few moments of looking around it became clear why the memorial was there and what it was telling us. How such a simple work of artistry can convey a picture into your mind of what terrible events took place on this spot is a perfect example of the good and the bad things we can do to each other.

Simple and Moving. We visited Budapest in July and I'd heard about shoes on the Danube, however we struggled to find where they were, it was only after doing a walking tour we were directed towards the shoes. We then walked from parliament along the river looking for them. They are on the river bank between parliament and the chain bridge. I think it's a simple but moving memorial to what happened during the war, however I do think for those that know nothing of the history there should be more information at the site, as at present just three stones on the floor give a brief explanation of what took place.
Memorable. A must see when in Budapest and a touching part of history. So some reading prior to your walk would be recommended, in order to enjoy it and appreciate it even more.Highly recommended.

Moving memorial. This was such a moving memorial to tge Jews who lost there lives to the arrow cross melishia during 1944-45. They were lined up in front of the Danube and shot, the shies represent the various social classes and ages of those that lost their lives. The memorial almost opposite Buda castle on the Danube and close to where the dinner cruises peer is.
History. Small memorial to help remember the many lives lost during the Holocaust. It is an easy walk along the Danube, must see!

Moving memorial. We were aware of the history of the Jews in Budapest but not of this memorial. We sort of stumbled upon it walking to the parliament. It was very moving and beautifully laid out. Very poignant. It is important to never forget what happened.
Monument to Insanity. This small memorial tells it all about the nazis and their total lack of humanity. It should take your breadth away

Haunting Tribute. During the reign of the Arrow Cross party (1944-1945) in Hungary thousands of Jews were brutally shot along the banks of the Danube. The memorial shows shoes from every walk of life,young, old, poor, rich, male, female depict that no one was beyond their murderous ways
Emotional & Moving display. It was very sad and touching to see this display of bronze shoes on the bank of the Danube...especially those adorned with flowers or momentos or notes left by visitors.
Touching tribute. My husband and I really enjoyed seeing this memorial. Highly recommended. We went on a rainy day which added to the ambiance.

A poignant must see. We would have missed this as our local guide did not have it on her walking tour itinerary, but I had read about it in the Insiders' guide. In fact we found she was reticent to talk about it. We realised why when she finally explained that it was Hungarian Nazis who killed the Jews who were forced to leave their shoes there before being shot and thrown in the river at the end of World War 2. It is on the river front near the Patliament building so easy to find and a reminder of a troubled past, but which should not be forgotten but kept alive as a reminder to the rest of us.
Very moving. We walked along the river looking for this memorial and I would say its about 10 minutes slow walk from the centre. A touching tribute to those who lost their lives

Take some time to study the history.. I had read about the shoes prior to arrival and it is in my mind one of the more moving reminders of what happened during Nazi rule.We had seen the concrete memorial in Berlin and the empty chairs in krakow, but this is by far more poignant than the others.
'Shoes on the Danube'. I'm not Jewish, but this memorial would be one of the most touching tributes I have ever seen. Man's inhumanity to man knows no bounds.
Memorable. Everyone needs to know this story. These deserted old shoes give witness to how cruelly mankind can treat one another.

Another reminder. This is a small memorial to the Hungarian fascists killing of the Jews in Budapest. The shoes are a reminder of the shoes left on the bank as the fascists shot the Jews and threw them into the Danube.
Moving. You need to know the history of this memorial. It is moving, simple and terrible (because of the history).

A Lesson Never to be Forgotten. Throughout Europe, particularly Eastern Europe, there are memorials, statues, etc. that honor those who had been murdered in the Holocaust to help us feel and understand the credo "Never again!". This particular memorial, however, is heartbreakingly moving as it represents Jews who weren't "lucky" enough to make it onto a transport to one of the concentration camps (remember, few really knew what was in store for them at the end of these horrific train rides) because the Nazi's and Arrow Cross Party could not transport them fast enough due to the volume of people being forced out of Hungary. Instead, they marched these innocents to the bank of the Danube River, made them strip off their clothing and shoes and summarily shot them in the backs so as to push themselves into the river. The atrocities are horrifying and heartbreaking, and this quiet little monument will leave an indelible mark on one's memory. This monument is directly across the street from the enormous Parliament building along the bank of the Danube. So small it can be missed if you don't pay close attention. Very touching, HIGHLY RECOMMEND.

Very Powerful Simple Memorial. Along the Danube is a simple memorial of shoes of victims of the holocaust - actual events of tragic inhumanity that occurred right on banks of the river. It's powerful and sobering and hopefully reminds people of human behavior that should never be repeated.
Very Emotional. This was the most moving memorial we experienced during our time in Europe, brought us all to tears to think of what the poor people must have gone through.

Worth seeing given proximity to other sights - but its a quick one. Its worth seeing since its not much of a detour from other things you are likely to be seeing anyway. But that being said - it takes about 1 minute to see.... so while poignant - don't get too excited.
powerful. One of the most powerful reminders of the holocaust I have ever seen. Commemorates the death of jews who were shot and pushed into the river.

No words, only goosebumps.. It is easy to overlook this monument, just a couple of shoes. But when you stand there and look at these shoes, you can almost see the men, women and children. Impressive.....

So sad. We stopped by this monument both with our tour guide, then separately after touring the Parliament and again at night. Both my wife and I were moved by its history and the city's design/remembrance of the events.
Moving tribute. We saw these shoes from the boat and walked along to see what they were. Monument to those killed in the uprising and a very simple but effective memorial
Take a look and ponder. Worth the time walking past and having a think about the meaning of the shoes, really quite a moving experience.

Unusual, thought-provoking memorial. If you visit this unusual memorial to the murdered Jews of Budapest, you'll never forget it. Taking a walk from Parliament to the Chain Bridge will take you right past this memorial.
Harrowing. It's a beautiful place but so sad at the same time. Go at night time if you can as during the day it gets very busy.
Never again. The shoes are a reminder of the horrors of war and what people will do to each other. One stands in reverence and solitude although surrounded by others. I was there Aug 2014
Poignant and heart-breaking. A haunting memorial of a very troubled time in Hungarian history and a fitting memorial to the live lost,
Moving. On the Pest side near the Parliament Building you can't miss them if you are walking down the promenade. Very touching when you know the story behind this modest memorial.

Must read up on the history. The art display of bronzed shoes of people who died at the end of WWII is a lesson in history, at least part of the lesson. It is for the viewer to be curious and read further, all sides of the stories, as there are monuments and memorials if this type all over Europe.

A very unique memorial. This memorial on the banks of the Danube river is located near the south end of the Hungarian Parliament Building within walking distance of the tram stop at the Parliament Building. It is a very unique, artsy and touching memorial depicting all that remains of the Jews victims of the World War II fascist militiamen that took their lives. A must visit!

Provactive memorial. Seeing the bronzed shoes along the river and learning the story of the executions that took place there makes one step back and realize that this beautiful city and country has only recently shaken off the mantle of darkness. Very moving!
very moving. very moving the shoes on the side of the river. made me stand and reflect for a little while. On the river next to the parliament building and easy to find
What is it?. We just happened to come upon it but didn't know what the story was. There was no immediate information in English. We found out later from some fellow travelers.
Thought provoking... To learn why these shoes are here really gives you a sense of the history here. This is a sombre monument, definitely worth a visit.

Heartbreaking Memorial. The shoes of the Danube are bronze moulds of the shoes of the Jews that were shot into the Danube River in WWII. The Jews were made to remove their shoes before being assassinated. A very touching and reflective Memorial.

No Words to describe the power of this memorial. Just a few hundred feet along the Danube is site to remember.Budapest has had several hundred years of terror, invaders, multiple rulers from different countries and in recent times during the Communist regime, the abolishment of religion and imprisonment and brutal murders of people of all religions (See House of Terror.) In the middle the Nazis killed the Jews ruthlessly, taking possessions and property with no remorse dumping bodies into mass graves including the Danube where many Jews were shot and dumped. This memorial serves as a never ending reminder of a terrible time in our recent history.Several thousand others where shot and dumped into a mass grave at the Great Synagogue (Also visited and reviewed,) For the sake of humanity, stop and say a prayer for the dead, regardless of your beliefs and thank G.. your family doesn't have to suffer these atrocities. Only remembering and acknowledging history can prevent it from happening again.

A Nice Tribute to a Relatively Unknown Part of History. I would never have known about this place from any of the guide books or locals, but a friend had recently come back from Budapest and told me to visit. It was very touching to see this unique memorial to the Jews murdered along the Danube during WWII. But when you read how they were shot so they strategically fell into the river, men, women and children, it breaks your heart. Even though the inscription is in Hungarian, there is no need for a translation.

Very touching memorial. This is one of the most touching WWII memorials I have ever seen and is situated beautiful next to the river and near the big parliament building. There are flowers and candles and at night is beautiful and sombre.
So interesting and yet heartbreaking. A must see piece of art in Budapest but I did find it a little eerie. The story behind the piece is amazing and so interesting but also so heartbreaking.
Sad. Very poignant reminder of what occurred and what should not be forgotten. Only a few minutes walk parliament and I think it is something everyone should see

Impressive memorial. A very impressive memorial, although the information on the ground is in Hungarian, it isn't hard to understand what the shoes represent. The beautiful background gives the memorial a strange contrast.

Make you really wonder..... Didn't knew at the beginning when I saw them what was the whole story about them so I took pictures but I saw many shoes with candles and flowers left there from people I really got shocked later when I read the story I understood....make really think why????

Original but not impressive ... but you are there anyway. The huge and magnigicent parlament is 20 meters away. And its a must. So you cross the road and there it is. Different sizes of shoes of all shapes and form. A reminder to the not so gloriest past in regard of jews being pushed to the danube. Its original.
Powerful. It is a powerful way to show the brutality that was demonstrated to the Jewish population during World War II.

Moving and emotional. The shoes are places on a pedestrian walk in Pesta, beside the Danube, right across from the Parliament. It's a sad and emotional reminder of what people can do to other people when fueled by shallow reasons and in such a modern age.

A POIGNANT REMINDER OF WHAT WAS. The shoes, all shapes and sizes, boots and high heels, are rusted, made of iron and set into concrete of the embankment of the Danube River: They are a poignant reminder of the atrocities of war and a memorial to the many Hungarian Jews who, in the winter of 1944-1945, were shot where they stood, lined up, on the banks of the Danube River by the members of the Arrow Cross Party: the installation on the Pest bank of the Danube River was completed in 2005. At three separate places on the memorial, cast iron signs read in Hungarian, English and Hebrew: "To the memory of victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944-45." it's a very sad reminder of the cruelties of war.
Poignant memorial. This very simple idea is exquisitely executed right by the Danube. It is worth a trip to see and there are good views over to the castle.

Shoes besides the bank. We were walking besides the Danube bank and suddenly saw the shoes. There was not anything signs or information about it and I read about it in wikipedia at night in the hotel.

Sad reminder. These are a very touching reminder of what happened when the Jews were shot on the banks of the Danube in WW2. To see all these shoes, cast in metal, makes you think of how things were then. Very moving.

Poignant . Very poignant attraction in Budapest. Created in memory of Jewish residents that were killed/dumped into the Danube.A reminder of some of the attrocities that the City has witnessed over the years.

Moving memory . When I first saw the shoes on the bank of river, there were just some random shoes means nothing to me not until I read about the history behind the shoes. It has a visually impact on the scene of the men, women and children facing the river, took off their shoes before they got shut down by the Arrow Cross. Very provoking.

Sad reminder. I was surprised at how much Europe remembers the Nazi era. There are many such memorials to Europe's lost Jews. The Nazis lined up Jews along the river and shot them in the head, but not before telling them to remove their shoes.

Shoes on the Danaube River Walk. It's a very basic memorial--but very thought provoking. When you first arrive you see metal shoes on the river walk. After learning the history of what happened here you start to realize the symbolic meaning these shoes have. I found the memorial to be excellent and thought provoking. It's an easy walk from downtown / the Marriott. It's close to the Parliament building.

Heartbreaking. I have seen many sculptures/monuments etc, but none have touched me as much as this one. To see these shoes it is really emotional and the artist was really able to get his point across. A must see.

a moving tribute. This thought provoking tribute to the Jews who were shot on the banks of the river moved me to tears. It looked as if they had just stepped out of thier shoes, that was all that remained of them.
Moving. this is a simple memorial for a terrible history. The shoes are scattered along the pathway by the river. People have tied ribbon or added pebbles in memory of those who died here during WW2.

Sobering. The display of iron shoes representing the shoes of the Jews that were massacred by the Nazis in the second world war is a mark of respect so we should never forget the atrocities that were carried out then

A stunner!. It is impossible to believe what these shoes represent. Far from protecting ourselves or our children from what happened here, I believe we owe it to the memory of those poor souls to share their story and take a moment to acknowledge that they lived and died brutally. An indelible story of man's madness and cruelty.

A Reminder. We were walking to Parliament and came across these shoes. We had read about them and the event that they represent. We would not have sought them out but it was an opportunity to take a few moments to reflect.
Sad. I feel sad to see all the shoes, after my husband explain the history about this memorial shoes. But We like to see it . It was nice , beautiful around the river
Very poignant . A touching memorial very sad . Well done without being patronising. A small area but enough said with no words . Respectful.
poignant and moving. this memorial to the poor people thrown into the icy Danube - so sad but not to be forgotten. take a moment to say a prayer.

Don't miss it while walking by the parliament. I think it's a very original and touching memorial. Always lot's of tourists taking pictures here. A very interesting concept. Don't miss it when you're around.

Poignant memorial.. On the pest side of the river Danube is a row of shoes to commemorate the Jews of Budapest who were killed at the end of the Second World War. The saddest part is the pair of boots belonging to a child.
Simple but very Powerful Memorial. On the Danube a simple and very powerful memorial. A must visit. Just takes a few minutes and your strolling along the Danube anyway...

Very effective memorial. This is a simple but moving memorial. It would have been good if there was a plaque nearby with more information, as without having done research beforehand, it is too easy to miss.

Thought provoking . It may only provide a short diversion on a trip but it is worth finding near Parliament.
It's only small memorial but it is very poignant. It coveys the loss of the Jewish citizens well.

Touching Memorial. If you're ever taking a stoll along the river or near Parliament, you can't go past the shoe memorial without feeling something. Representing just some of the Jews that were killed during the Nazi occupation; they were grouped together, asked to take off their shoes, shot, and then pushed into the river (if my memory serves me correctly), as shoes were considered very valuable.Please take a moment to remember.
Fascinating. Stumbled upon these by chance, So sad when you read the history. I thought the artistry in making this was different, poignant and made you think. Glad we found them
My fav. spot. go in the eve!. beautiful pictures of the Castle along with the shoes.... very delightful and good spot

Very Powerful. We had been on a river cruise from Poland to Hungary and included a tour of Auschwitz. While that was a moving experience, nothing prepared us for the shoes along the Danube. It brout tears to the eyes to think of the fate of these people.

Very moving dedication. This moving dedication is riverside near the Parliament Building. Sixty pairs of bronze shoes to commemorate those shot into the Danube by the Nazi's. Flowers are often lovingly placed in the shoes and this display really touches the heart. Well worth seeing as you walk along the Danube. There is no fee.

A very evocative tribute. A poweful tribute to human suffering. This sculpture of dozens of pairs of abandoned shoes strewn by the Danuble evokes images of the final moments of their murdered owners' lives without the need for further explanation. Unforgettable & well worth a visit.
Moving Sight. Wasn't sure on what this would be quite thought provoking, walk along the river on your way to parliment
Sad shoes. As you would expect, it is thought provoking...... Rather sad with people setting down candles nearby. A clever monument.

Shoes. A serial experience very moving
A must to visit you can walk along the Danube and take in the lovely views , but have to stop at the shoes to think of all the deep history

Thoughtful. I made sure I found this memorial based on the other reviews. I found it simple and thought provoking. There was nobody else there at the time so could just think about the whole epriod in history and the events in Budapest around this time.

Powerful reminder. Shoes on waters edge are a reminder of the horror of times past when Jews were shot on this spot & left to die. This is on a walk back from parliament. You will probably not want to linger
very thought provoking. very poignant ,stood awhile and thought so simple but so fitting don't walk by stay and think , in a lovely city when you look upon this tribute you just relax and ponder ....

Another reminder of the dark side of Hungarian modern history.. A very simple, sobering display which relates to the shooting of people by the side of the Danube. They were required to remove their shoes before being shot and their bodies pushed into the river.
Poignant - must see. A very moving memorial to the victims and incredibly touching. A real must see for when in Budapest.
memorable. It was a memorable experience, not to be missed. Do not leave Budapest without a visit. Get off the bus / tube / tram at the Parliment building
Poignant and very moving. Dont miss an opportunity to view the shoes...They are easy to get to and seeing them is a very moving and reflective experience
history is important. makes one sad to know the reason for this.... near parliament buildings.. so can visit when you walk towards town center from there
Very Moving. This is one of the many memorials throughout Central Europe that causes one to contemplate the horrors of WW II.
Thoughtful, Impactful. Excellent small memorial with outsize impact. Beautiful setting. Easily accessed near the Parliament and a crosswalk near Kossuth Lajos tér.

Choked up. As you are walking back towards the heart of Budapest from the Parliament building, do so along the Danube so pass this. It is only about 150-200 yards away. It honors the Jews who were ordered to take off their shoes, shot at the waters edge so their bodies fell in the river and carried away. It is so moving!!! I did not expect to be so impacted by this but just thinking about it and seeing that the majority of the shoes were women and children, which is also what got to my husband, and what makes you realize that this people were not intimating or harmful. This is free.

Gripping and disturbing. An art exhibit of bronze shoes portraying the spot where Jews were tied together to save bullets. One was shot and allowed to fall into the Danube. Their weight pulled the others down with them. Such a sad memorial of disturbing events. The saddest part was the pair of children's shoes.
Very cool memorial. Very nice memorial for a horrible time in history. Simple yet powerful. Easy walk from downtown and very close to the Parliament building.
Emotional. Whilst walking along the Danube , heading towards Parliament we came across the Shoes on the Promenade . Very sad and emotional .

Never knew it existed. We were driven by the shoes on the wall and somehow never knew what had happened or the story behind the bronze shoes cast and placed on the edge of the Danube river.As the story goes some of the Jews in the country were taken to the river and shot, then pushed into the river just before the Nazis were overrun the Russians. A very nice area for reflection what happened durning the war. A couple of minutes walk from the white bridge.

Poignant. This is not hard to find, but very understated in its simplicity. Children's and Adults shoes - what were people thinking when the events this commemorates happened? Poignant, but when we were there it hard a lot of detritus over it, and people had added ribbons and flowers and some personal momentoes. Is that taking away from the memorial or showing that the memories and hurt are still raw? You decide.

Shocking and impressive interpretation of the dark history of Europe. Worth a visit to remember... But get ready to explain the kids why? Really shocking and impressive interpretation of the dark history of Europe

A Shoa memorial in Budapest. The shoes on the Danube promenade was raised to remember of the people (mostly Jews) were shot into the Danube in Budapest by the Hungarian Nazi groups in the final period of the 2nd World War. On the other hand, the fact that the shoes have been demaged couple of time evidence that Hungarian people still couldn't encounter fully their history. From touristic point of view it is easy to find, the shoes are behind the building of the Parliament.
Sad. The monument is very nice but sad, captured by a very interesting and emotional way. It's a little bit hard to find
Frightening. A shocking symbol of the horror experienced on the Duna bank during World war II. To see and shortly stop to think about it.

Tears!. This simple memorial brought tears to my eyes. Along the banks of the Danube were pairs of shoes in bronze. Apparently, shoes were valuable during World War II and the Jews and other "enemies of the state" who were going to be shot had to remove theirs. Then they stood at the embankment and were shot. The shoes commemorate their lives. There is no charge to see this memorial. Just stroll down the river bank on the Pest side. Touching.
Don't miss this!. Probably the most meaningful and moving piece of artwork that I saw in Budapest. I had a local explain the meaning of the sculpture which helped.

Thought provoking.. Rosie, my wife, wanted to see the shoes. They are just across the road from the parliament building. Having said that we did manage to walk past them! As with all these Jewish monuments it is very thought provoking. Worth seeing.

Know the Story Behind the Shoes. It makes it better if you find out yourself rather than me writing a summary here. The shoes are a very poignant piece of what happened in Europe in the last century during the war.It only takes a few minutes to go see them.If you are on a river cruise, you will probably be anchored nearby at a dock within walking distance.
Evocative shoes. Well worth a visit especially if in that area of Budapest it's near the Parliament building of if you are waling along te banks of the Danube.
Moving. Bronze shoe castings are placed on the river's edge concrete - making the spot where Jewish (others, too?) children and adults were forced into the Danube by the Nazis.
Touching tribute. I found this simple but moving. The view across the river (of Castle Hill) is really nice here, too.

Take Your Breath Away. 60 pairs of rusted period shoes cast out of iron. It will not take you long to view this memorial but what you will see will conjure thoughts in your mind of the atrocity and brutality of the Arrow Cross militia as they shot people in the back and the bodies fell into the Danube to be washed away. The shoes depict children, women, businessmen, sportsmen and others. Do not miss this memorial even though small and to be seen in a short space of time.

its just shoes.... There is a lot of meaning behind these, but it is just a small amount of wall with some shoe sculptures. Not worth travelling out of your way to see, but if you are passing, stop and appreciate its meaning
Sobering reflection.. It's humbling & disturbing to stand looking at the shoes and contemplating man's inhumanity to man. We haven't learned much from the past.

Beautifully Simple. This perhaps used to be one of the least-known memorials in Budapest, but it is thankfully gaining in popularity. In short, it is a memorial to the Jews whom the Hungarian Arrow-Cross party (Nazi-affiliated) killed by shooting them on the edge of the Danube river. The shoes symbolize the fact that the soldiers made them remove their shoes first, so they would not go to waste in the river. Visit at or after sunset, as there are often candles and small flowers placed in and amongst the shoes.
So sad. An amazing tribute to those killed here. The scene tears at your heart. This is right outside the Parliament on the shores of the Danube. so go there before or after a tour of Parliament.
worth a look. Take a look at this memorial located to the right of the chain bridge when coming from the Pest side of the Danube.and take note of what a timely reminder this is of what hate can do.

Moving memorial. Just pairs of shoes to commemorate the loss of Jewish lives here during the war. So simple and yet so moving.The memorial is between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament building. And you have to be on the road below the Parliament to see it. Well worth the walk to see it.
Moving tribute. Worth visiting this on the side of the Danube. A tribute to Hungarian Jews killed by militiamen during WW2 - their bodies falling into the river to be washed away.....
A moving experience. On the edge of the Danube a sobering reminder of war time horrors. The shoes facing the river, very poignant....
Moving. What a thought provoking tribute. We came across this by accident when visiting the Parliament building. A must see for anyone in Budapest.
Humbling. This memorial is to remember the Jews that were killed by the Nazi party during WW2 is utterly humbling. A very subtle memorial that remembers the atrocities during that period in time.

A small exhibition that brings out man's inhumanity to man.. As we walked along the promenade to tour the Parliament Building, we came across a line of shoes, men's, ladies and children marking the location of Jews executed by the Nazis in late 1944 and early 1945 along the bank of the Danube, left to fall into the river. It really gives pause for self reflection on what cruelty we have imposed on each other throughout history.
Hungarian Holocaust the public cannot forget. Hungarians can never forget the Holocaust, because this memorial is cemented into a popular walkway along the Danube River.
Do visit it. A very beautiful memorial place in Budapest based on a very sad periode of Hungarian history. It feels like you are in the middle of it.

Stirring memorial. Stirring and moving memorial to jews who were made to stand along the river at the end of the war, tied together to save bullets and then unceremoniously shot in the back to fall in the river and drown. Definitely worth a visit. It is very close to the Parliament Building along the river.

A Moment to Reflect.... A lesson is history which brings us to many of the issue which are currently affecting the world. One should research the "shoes", visit the site and pause to reflect. It is moving....

what can you say. I came upon this memorial by chance, had no idea what it was. I learnt the 'shoes' are to honour the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the Danube and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank, apparently shoes had some value!Worth a moment of quiet reflection on just what we're capable of inflicting on each other.
Powerful. Powerful and a reminder of a terrible time. Do not let this happen again.It broke my heart to see the Childrens shoes
Worth seeing. A very simple but emotional tribute by the side of the river. Not easy to find, no signposts at all. We walked along the river from the Parliament building.
Simply moving. Bring you close to tears, the simplicity yet meaning behind it is just incredible. A must if in Budapest
Moving Memorial. It was very moving if you know the story that this represents the Jews lined up and shot left to fall into the river. Woth the walk to see it.

The Shoes on the Danube is an excellent history lesson.. An examination of the horrors of December 1944 and January 1945 that took place along the banks of the Danube. A must see for a true experience of the history of Budapest. Study the event in detail before you go.
Shoes on the Donau. This is a moment you watch and think of the people that were victimes in a war, a war they did not ask for !!

Interesting memorial. Interesting memorial and, but you can easily miss it.
It's quite a side story, but these a great place for meditation and reflection.
A Must Visit. Very Sad & Touching with a chilling atmosphere but makes you stop and think of the terror that happened here. A must visit as it is in the centre and easy to get to.
TOUCHING MONUMENT. A very touching monument nearby the river which give you the willies. It's incredible how harmul people can be!!
Came upon this by chance. I had read about this & just happened to come upon it by chance. It is very poignant & stops you in your tracks & makes you think of how things must have been at that time.

Sad & poignant memorial. A very cold but poignant tribute that just makes you stop & think. It's sad but it's part of the history of Budapest, a very fitting tribute to the memory for the souls that lost their life's

Something you can miss. Not really a great monument, in fact it does little or no justice to the countless other groups marginalized during that same time, but it has the prime real estate so it must be something.
Eerie and thought provoking.. We visited this at night so was reasonably quiet. A must see and just a short walk from the pest side of the chain bridge heading towards parliament.

Impactful memorial. There is something about these unique, haphazardly placed shoes that evokes individuals and the horror they must have felt right before they were killed. The children's shoes - that their mothers likely helped them remove - are the most horrible. Take a few minutes out of your travels to stop, remember and honor.

Most unusual and poignant memorial. This was the most unusual tribute to the victims of the WW2 Holocaust I've ever visited. As one looks at the shoes lined along the riverbank, we can barely imagine the horror and awfulness of what was inflicted on victims here. Some visitors have placed flowers in some shoes in memory. Others had night-lights in them. Unfortunately we didn't have time to at visit at night, whenI'm sure the scene would be even more poignant

So Sad. This is a very moving tribute to the Jews who were killed by the Nazis. These are Jews who for one reason or another ( to try and get needed food or medicine) escaped the ghetto, only to be caught. Before they were shot and thrown into the Danube, another indignity had to be foisted on them. They were forced to remove their shoes.
sad. the idea as a memorial is good but a very sad one, how can you rate is as good. it make you remember the woes of war

A serious site for reflection. Please go here if you have a conscience that respects the suffering of others. Please do not go here if this site is just one more place to check off on a list of "must see's" in Budapest. I met two Jewish Hungarian friends here in October, 2014 ( I am Catholic). It was a bittersweet meeting: we saw the remains of German Nazi evil, and the message from the shoes that life goes on. And so we did. This site is a must see if you are invested in making the world a better place. If not, pass it by.

A very, very sad reminder of Budapest's darkest moments. We were in Budapest on a Viking River Cruise and were docked very near the Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial. A painful reminder of the thousands of Jews who were executed before the Russian Red Army took over from the Nazis. Far from being true liberators, the Bolcheviks "overextended their stay" by many years, driving Budapest and its people to ruin and misery.

shoes on the danube. A poignant yet powerful sculpture in memory of the Jews who were ordered to remove their shoes before being shot and their bodies thrown into the Danube river during WW2. The memorial was conceived by film director, Can Togay, with sculptor Gyula Pauer to honour the Jews who died. I would classify this as a 'must see'
A beautiful memorial. One of the highlights of Budapest. Standing there, viewing these shoes and hearing the history was very emotion.

Small but big. In a city with such impressive and grand architecture it's amazing that something so small and insignificant captures the heart and mind. The shoes on the Danube are a memorial to the Jews killed during WW2. Jews were lined up and asked to remove their shoes and stand and were then shot so that their bodies fell into the river. The monument pays respect by way of the shoes left behind. Its very close to the Parliament and hence can be viewed on the same trip.
Interesting way to get people to think. A nice few minutes stop to remember how badly humans can treat each other. the shoes are located very near the Parliament building.
Quite an ingenious idea. It's a simple, yet meaningful monument to visit on your way to or from the Parliament. Only shame it's so dirty and the city doesn't seem to care about it at all.

Haunting. Such a simple piece of artwork but an enormous tug at your heart strings. The sad path of those tragic souls gives us a haunting glimpse into how terrible it was for those Jews who lost their lives due to racism. It makes you ask yourself if something this horrendous can happen in todays world. How can things go so far wrong when people think they are in the right.
Shoes Memorial. Very touching and emotional scene along the Danube this is a must see experience . We were surprised how stirring it was

The saddest scene.... Heart-wrcnching to see the reality of these shoes and to visualize the people who wore them as they were shot and fell into the Danube. You cannot look at these without feeling an immense sadness.
Moving Memorial. Very moving memorial to the victims who were shot into the Danube, we visited whilst there were no tour buses were around as I imagine it could get very busy.

Moving Memorial. I have been a docent at the Illinois Holocaust Museum in the Chicago area so I have visited and have knowledge of many Holocaust memorials. This memorial is the most moving and impactful in my memory. These shoes are placed on the shoreline of the river where Jews were murdered. The thought process that the Nazis implemented - take off your shoes so we can reuse them - and then place yourself in a position so that when we shoot you/you then fall into the water - easy disposal. You can actually visualize this as you look at the memorial. I was moved to tears. It's a must see while you are in Budapest!!

Poignant. This is worth seeing if you're in the area, certainly if you're going to see the parliament building. Not an easy thing to get your head around but a beautiful way of sharing a complex part of Hungarian history.

A simple but moving memorial to some of the dead of the Second World War. Sitting on the edge of the promenade along the Danube, as if left yesterday, these well-worn shoes were conceived by the film director Can Togay with sculptor Gyula Pauer in remembrance of Jews who were ordered to take off their shoes and their boots and then were shot so that their bodies fell into the river and were washed away by the tide. Today the shoes remain, some elegant, some tattered, some rough boots and some of children. A poignant and simple memorial.
Touching. When I visited the monument my heart was saddened. There were even children's shoes. A simple monument of a terrible events.

u may visit if u have time. nothing so special unless u have interest and u love history. located just beside the river. easy to find out. if u r around u can walk down and see. well the history is painful. u will surely feel sad for these helpless people who died here once u r around this place.
Moving. Very simple monument, requires little explanation. Very moving in a beautiful spot. Definitely makes you think. Especially the tiny pairs of shoes, it has such a huge impact.
Nice memorial. When I went to Budapest (2006), this one marked me for what it means.It's a must see when you visit Budapest, near the beautiful Danube river.
Simple and Moving. It's amazing what a bunch of bronzed shoes can do to put war in human terms. The story behind the shoes is heart-rending.
Metal shoes on side of Danube. Just came across these walking the Pest side of the Danube. Not sure what they are for as there was no board to tell you. Will look it up later.
Sad . It is a sad place but everyone has to see. Bu it can be more better and living. Itis close to parliamant and chain bridge so everyone can visit by walking easily.

Extremely Moving. The simplicity of all these shoes....from women to men to little children....sitting on the wall right next to the river really brought your thoughts to the horrific crimes that were committed at this very spot.

Interesting, Sad, Emotional, Unusual. I've used this same title for a review elsewhere but it is so appropriate for this "attraction". It is actually a sculpture, albeit close to the ground, consisting of a number of 1940's style shoes. These represent a number of people who were lined up, shot and pushed into the Danube during the Hungarian Holocaust. There are men's, women's and children's shoes; the little children's shoes are especially poignant. It is easily reached on foot (go toward Parliament from the Chain Bridge) or by tram (take tram 2 along the front).
Sightseeing. The overall impression of this of this piece of art is really good. It describes amazingly the darkest hours of Budapest during the 2nd World War. Remarkable place!
Touching Tribute. Highly recommend a quick visit to this tribute! It's to remember the Jews killed on the bank of the Danube during WWII.

Sad Story, Amazing Preservance. Near the parliament, this monument is on the banks on danube. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank. It is located on the Pest side of the Danube.

Sad reminder of times past and questions for the future?. We walked along the Danube to get to Margaret island and came across this sad and simple tribute to the memoriesof Jewish people who lost their lives there. It also made me think of how Hungary sadly are now treating the refugees today, have we learnt anything?? We found all the hungarian people we met to be the most beautiful people and what is happening there didn't reflect on how we were treated. A strange world isnt it?

Municipality of Budapest could and SHOULD have done with more explanation. A sad but moving memorial to thee poor victims that were lined up and shot on the banks of the Danube I looked around for some sort of explanation. If there was one, I missed it. The Hungarian government and the Municipality of Budapest could and SHOULD have done with more explanationIts so
touching reminder of a difficult time in history. It was an emotional experience to see these shoes set along the edge of the river, and imagining the event that occurred on that spot.

Sad memories. In case the visitors don't know what to make of this. During the Nazi years, Jews were regularly brought to this area and machine gunned into the river. But since shoes were an expensive commodity they had to take off their shoes first.
NEVER AGAIN!!

Simple, shocking, moving. Never heard about this memorial before, literally stumbled across it walking past the parliament back to my hotel. Prompted me to look it up. Quite shocking but a most fitting memorial to those dreadful events.

Promenade walk. This promenade is right beside the Danube river and is a beautiful walk. We did it on a Sunday and listened to the church bells ringing. The "shoes" are poignant and heart rendering but in some way a beautiful sculpture. You can see some great views of the buda side and there are great eateries the pest side of the Chain bridge.

Shocking. It's hard to give review on that place dew to awfull crime that was done in world war 2 to jews by hungarians. But the work of sculpture is shocking and deliver in most real way the tragic event.

Very Moving. The Shoes on the Danube memorial is a 5 minute walk from the house of parliament towards Chain bridge, and I actually visited prior to going on a tour of parliament which I also highly recommend. Once at the memorial you can expect to see 60 pairs of rusted period shoes cast out of iron in various styles and sizes representing those victims of the arrow cross militia (Hungarian Nazis), who in 1944-1945 were lined up by the Danube and were executed by firing squad so that they fell into the river and were washed away. A very moving memorial to these Holocaust atrocities, and definately worth stopping at these shoes to reflect on what was a dark part of human history.

Must see. One of the most important historical places in budapest. The place where the nazis killed jewish people and threw them to the danube river. In the jewish comunity people say that the danube river is red and not blue. Red from the jewish blood

Deeply moving. I guess every visitor to the city sees this sculpture / monument at some point. We did a bit of research after we saw it and you have to wonder at the barbarity and pure lack of humanity of any group who would carry out acts that lead to this memorial. The contrast between our visit on a bright and sunny day and the experience of the people being commemorated is very sobering.
An emotional memorial. This really makes you think of the atrocities, worth the visit, situated in front of the Parliament Building.

Deeply moving, five starts, 3 minutes walk from Parliament, combine with reading. This is one of the most unusual and moving monuments I've seen in many years. It's 60 pairs of shoes, cast in iron, lined up along the river.It recognizes the horrible behavior of a Hungarian Nazi-sympathizer group that lined up thousands of Jews toward the end of World War II on the banks of the Danube, and shot them. Sometimes they tied people together and shot only one, so that they saved bullets but all three fell into the river. The site is immediately next to the Parliament building and requires only a 3-4 minute walk from the Parliament to see. It's a wonderful/moving example of how art can convey and produce deep emotion. I strongly recommend this monument. My only slight quibble is that there is not much of an explanation of what happened. You can go to various websites to learn more about what happened. TA prefers not to include links - but if you do a google search for Shoes on the Danube Memorial, you'll find several short, helpful discussions. Taking 3-5 minutes to one or more of these brief explanations. I'd urge people to visit this along with memorials to people who HELPED SAVE Jews, which you can find in the formerly Jewish ghetto district.
Certainly worth a visit. The piece is simple, yet really drives home the atrocities suffered during war time. It is certainly worth a visit.
Moving. This was a moving experience and well worth the time spent here. I would recommend this to anyone visiting Budapest

A moving piece of art. I don't recall ever being moved by a piece of art as I was by this memorial. The simplicity and the realism of the shoes reminds us of the poor fate of minorities in this part of the world just 70 years ago.
Moving tribute to innocent victims of hate. Simple display of "bronzed" shoes memorialize Jews who were murdered on the banks of the Danube during WWII. Worth taking the time to visit and reflect.

Striking . Really striking memorial - and generally a stark reminder of all the conflict this city faced in the 20th century.
As a lighter aside, it's worth mentioning - it can be quite tricky to cross the road to get down to this memorial. Take care.

A memorial to inhumanity.
