I regret that we only got to see the memorial from our tour bus although it was only a short distance from where our river cruise ship was docked on the Pest side of the Danube next to the Chain Bridge. It memorializes the site where during 1944 and 1945, approximately 20,000 Jews were forced to take off their shoes before being shot by the Hungarian Iron Cross Militiamen and falling into the freezing river. The memorial itself consists of 60 pairs of iron sculpted shoes. Very moving for such a simple memorial.

Very Touching. The Nazis made the Jews line up. They were running out of bullets so they tied 2 people together. They then shot one dead and tossed them both into the Danube letting the live Jew drown under the dead Jew's sinking weight. These shoes are the memorial to the souls that died at the Nazi's hands in this manner.

The most moving piece of art I have seen. Easy to find on the banks of the Danube in front of the Parliament, this sculpture of the shoes Jewish Hungarians who were shot by the Nazis on the banks of the river, so their bodies would fall in and be washed away is so moving. I could no stay long, too upsetting & I am not Jewish.
Shoes by the river. While the shoes may be feeling the effects of the weather, the message behind them is still as strong. Such a memorable place. An easy stroll from the parliament house

A momument that makes you quite. A remarkable piece of art, which represents the cruel acts of war against the Jews. During the second world war, they made the Jews stand in line here and take of their shoes. Afterwards they were executed and their bodies would fall in the Danube. This momument is for those who lost their lifes in this unhumane way.
Awful. This is a kind of attraction Im not keen on. Bad history comes to ones mind and makes you feel sad..

Best memorial in Budapest. This is by far the most inspired and moving memorial in Budapest. It commemorates the Jewish victims shot into the river by members of the Hungarian (fascist) Arrow-Cross party in 1944.

Never Forget. A moving tribute to the Jews who were gunned down and forced to leave their shoes behind for others. We must learn from history and not make same mistakes with other groups of people. So sad.

Very sad.. This has a very sad story behind it but is a must see for anyone in Budapest.
A strong reminder of the past and history of the Danube.
Very touching.
A very haunting memorial. This is a great memorial because of its ability to make you pause and reflect on some of the terrible events that have occurred in Budapests history.

Monument moving by its simplicity - close to Parliament. A collection of shoes made of metal, serving as a monument to the Jewish victims of a lynch party right there by Hungarian fascist party, just before the fall of the city to the Soviet Army.The Jews that were executed often fell into the water losing their shoes, which explains the set-up.(small print: one of the little girls that were shot survived and was helped out of the water at the next bridge)Walk along the Danube from the Parliament direction city centre (Vörösmarty tér), or vice versa.

Walk past atrocities...recall the evil of the past...and hope for the future.. This takes only a few minutes to view, but rather a long time to comprehend the significance of these empty brass shoes lined along the river bank. Read, comprehend and appreciate their significance before you stroll past a part of history.
Symbolic landmark in Budapest. The site has little to offer purely from an artistic viewpoint. However the history and symbolism behind it makes a visit worth it.

Same Same Different Name. Seeing the shoes left behind by Jews who were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away, makes you wonder what has changed in our world - from the murders of innocent people by ISIS to the tragedies of civilians dying on the shores of the Mediteranian, fleeing Syria. Je suis Charlie...

Reminders of WW2.. The fanatic arrow partymembers eliminated the poor jews in the last minutes of the war in this shameful way that is a black mark for ever.Remember this killingsand learn the lesson from it.

Needs Explanation. I happened on this memorial by accident while walking along the bank of the Danube. I looked around for some sort of explanation. If there was one, I missed it. A check of Google when I got back to the hotel, told a moving story that I wished I had known while on my walk. Once you understand it, the memorial is moving in its simplicity.

Fun photos. Unique. Free to view. Walk along the Danube just in front of the beautiful parliament building near the yellow bridge.Shoes of different kinds from kids to men's to ladies. Made of steel? Stuck to the ground so don't think of lifting or moving it. Very interesting, unique and different.Nice at sunset with shoes in foreground and water and church in background.
Lasting memorial of the holocaust. Moving display of metal shoes to commemorate Jews shot then pushed into river during WW II, in only a few months.

Beautifully done memorial , shoes on the Danube. Poignant , and beautifully placed . Albeit a sad piece of history .You will still see candles and flowers being placed . Nice memorial , not crowded , with a bit of reflection .

Shoes on the Danubue. I checked out the shoes early in the morning before people came along -- basically walked along the Danube and it is located just before the Parliament building.well worth visiting and the early morning visit gives you time the time to reflect
Sole Survival. A sad but moving memorial to thee poor victims that were lined up and shot on the banks of the Danube.
Nice view of Buda from Pest. This is a great tourist area. An interesting attraction in the heart of Budapest. Nice view of Buda from Pest.

Very moving. It's difficult to get to since there is a major road between the Parliament building and the Holocaust memorial. But it's worth nabigating. About 100 meters up river from chain bridge or just next to the river side of Parliament buolding.
It's hard to see. It's hard to see but it really "must". Very strong memorial, we need to visit it in order to remember our history.

memorial to the victims of WW11. Cast iron shoes facing the Danube as a moving tribute to those who lost their lives in WW11 at the time of the Nazi occupation. Interesting place to visit but does not take long as you pass it on your way while walking beside the Danube close to Parliament.

Though provoking and emotional.. We visited in Sept 2015, they are bronze/copper shoes bolted to the Pest side of the promenade, a strong reminder of those that lost their lives. The shoes represent the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. Strongly worth a visit to honour and respect them.
Touching. Very touching place , the weather was gloomy when we went here. Respect to all the lives who died sadly during the war. A must visit while in budapest

Must see in Budapest. When a lady in broken English suggested we visit the shoes on the Danube I had thought I was heading off to find a shoe store!! Not sure, but rather this intense memorial of copper shoes. Well worth the visit
Budapest sights. Pleasant walk beside the river and the bronze shoes are there on the bank, really makes you think about what they represent!

Very well done. This was a series of metal/iron shoes along the river bank- close to the parliament. THey were all different shapes and sizes. I thought it was very well done and well worth a visit if you were passing.

Very moving memorial! A must see!. I read about this memorial on 100 things to see in Budapest. I was looking forward to seeing it but the effect it had on me was very moving and I burst into tears. People have put little poems, tributes and candles inside the shoes, others have just tied ribbons around them. It's very moving to see and spend a bit of time reflecting on the poor souls who died.

Visceral and thought-provoking. If one imagines the scenario represented by the shoes next to the river, it is heart-wrenching. Worth a visit to give perspective on stories we've heard about the horrible things that happened during WWII - you can almost feel it looking at these shoes by the river.

Very surreal.. I saw these shoes out of the window of the tram #4 that runs along the Pest side of the Danube. I was not aware of what they were until I read about this later. It was very poignant and peaceful. Worth getting off the tram to walk along past the shoes.
Humility. This memorial is very impressive. It is amazing how impressive seeing these shoes can be. The shoes of children make the cruelty even more tangible.

Poignant and thought provoking . We had done some research on budapest before we went and we both wanted to see this. When you visit in the evening people light candles in the shoes which looks lovely. People leave flowers to remember the poor people who lost their lives. Very moving. The only downside is there is no sign posts or anything to show where they are. Well worth a visit

Solemn yet beautiful memorial of Jewish history. No need to book to visit, this memorial is placed on the Pest side of the river and is a short walk from the bridges and piers. This was one thing we really wanted to see and it did not fail to make us realise and think about this part of Budapest's history. Although it was quite busy, we managed to study each pair of shoes at leisure and think about who it might have belonged to, and their story. Don't miss it.
You can't take this in and not cry. The history of Budapest is rich, passionate, and violent. For decades Budapest has had me in tears of joy and happiness, this tore my heart out-

Definite Stop and Rememberance. You will just walk by this as you walk around Budapest. A very simple, moving memorial to the victims of the Holocaust. Definitely stop by and take some time to remember.
Moving. Very moving and poignant! If you are already in the area then this is worth a visit but I wouldn't travel there especially.
Important Memorial. This memorial is very touching. Words to sum up this tragedy are difficult to think about. It needs to be here. People need to learn or be reminded of this horrific tragedy!

Nice history. Amongst the many such statues and features you get to see all over Europe this one has to be the most iconic for its historical background and preservation of history. A must see when you come to Danube promenade .
This is a must see!. Thanks to Rick Steves, we learned about this extremely touching tribute to the brave souls who lost their lives during the war. So poignant!!

Fantastic monument . Found this fantastic! Such a solum places for where so many people lost their lives. A true mark of respect to all those Hungarians who fought through some very difficult times over the past few decades, to give today's people the freedom they so much enjoy

Simple but moving tribute. We happened upon this memorial accidentally as we walked along the river. We had read about it but enjoyed just coming upon it. Later when we were in Berlin it was one of the Holocaust memorials pictured at the Berlin Holocaust Memorial.

Haunting!. This simple memorial speaks volumes that no words could do! Shoes denoting the very young through to the very old are placed on the river banks where thousands of Jews were shot into the River Danube! Tourists stand in almost complete silence with their own thoughts on what the memorial means!
A place for a few minutes thought on the cruely of man towards fellow man. Very very sad. Again a memorial to those who were murdered during the Second World war, by Hungarian Nazi members

A very well conceived memorial. Just beside the Hungarian Parliament, A beautiful and touching memorial of those Jews who perish in the Danube at WW II. It's a simple monument, but very, very touching place. It's stays there to remember those who died there.

go pay your respects. This is very sobering place, the shoes are here in memory of the poor soles (no pun intended) who were shot and died in this river.take a look at the child's shoes the last thing they saw was the opposite side of the river. humans can do this to each other, where will it end.for Gods sake love one another.
Poignant & thougth provoking. In front of parliament there is a poignant reminder of people being shot and falling into the Danube in 1944. We didn't see any signs so you have to look out for them.
rusted. come on.. the shoes buried in rust! some polish would help. it very close to the Parliament but very disappointing.

Worth a walk by. It wakes you up to remind you of the history and killings that happened here. I'm sure this scene of terror was just one of many. It's not just another memorial, it's a legitimate reminder that people were robbed of their shoes, on that mark, then shot execution style, even children. It's chilling to think about.

Very moving and emotional. We visited here after seeing it was one of the top things to do in Budapest but had idea how moving it would be and how emotional I would feel. It's so simple but so moving, definitely go see this.

Beautiful and emotional memorial. This memorial is rather simple but still so powerful. It's a bit chilling to stand there and think that in that area the Jews were lined up, ordered to take off their shoes, and were then shot into the river. The memorial is well thought out and created. Definitely a must see when in Budapest!

Poignantly moving!!!!. I would rate "Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial" akin to the Anne Frank House in Amsterdam by way of deeply felt emotion. It most definitely pulls at the heart strings and must be visited. I was overwhelmed with fear as the historical facts behind this memorial were recounted on my walking tour of Pest. I cannot even begin to imagine how the Hungarian Jews must have felt in those last few moments!!!!Please add this to your site visits while in Budapest.
The place to think . it is not a tourist sight, but it is a place to come and think about. It is a history of people. Just come to memorise the Jews, there families, all the victims of Nacies.
Simple but extremely powerful. A must see when visiting Budapest. The memorial speaks loudly in a very simple way. We stopped by after crossing the Chain Bridge.

So moving. This very simple art installation is nonetheless a very powerful and moving tribute to those people murdered by the Arrow Cross party. Each shoe conjures up an image of the person who wore it. Not to be missed
Try putting yourself in their shoes.. A must see to try to understand how far we have come in accepting that we are all human and we should celebrate our differences not despise them.

Moving, emotional experience.. What many people seem to think is that this commemorates Jews killed by the Nazis. In fact, it commemorates Hungarian Jews shot and thrown into the Danube by the Arrow Cross militia, a Hungarian Fascist organisation, in 1944. A simple, poignant monument to the Worst of human nature. If you go to Szabadsag Ter ( Liberty Square), only a few hundred meters away, you will see the monument put up by the present Hungarian government blaming the Nazis for the persecution of the Jews, but also the people's protest to this rewriting and sanitising of Hungarian history, when it was the Fascist Horthy government which collaborated with the Nazis in deporting Jews to the concentration camps. The mementos to loved ones here are even more moving.

Thought provoking memorial. Such a simple yet powerful memorial to the murdered Jews shot on the banks of the Danube. Just 300m south of the parliament building, a visit to this site should be on your list of things to see while in Budapest.
Poignant. Poignent memorial to the happenings during Nazi times. Not well publicised but well worth a visit if walking the Pest bank of the Danube

Beautiful, sad. A beautiful memory of a terrible historical moment...it is always full with candles and flowers. It's really sad that people are -according to the news- keep stealing the shoes from there.
Lovely memorial. worth a visit if you are visiting budapest, was very busy when we visited and people had left flowers and lit candles.
Incredibly powerful in its simplicity. Very simply put, it gets to transmit all the tragedy that swept the city during under the time of the nazi regime..

Poignant. Very Poignant.Worth having a look as you stroll along the Danube om the way to the Parliament building.Many people had left flower tributes in memory to show their awareness and took the time to reflect.

A Memorial to visit on the Pest side of the Promenade. This is a very moving memorium to the Jews who were shot here and thrown into the Danube. One of the best such that I've seen. Understated but, oh, so, heart-rending!

Punch-in-the-abdomen view from Tram #2. That's what it felt like when we first saw it from Tram #2. Absolutely heart-wrenching. Seeing it for the first time in its entirety from Tram #2 as it passed Parliament Building, touched us to the core immediately. I had tears in my eyes imagining the final moments of those (mostly Jews) who were killed there. The memorial is profoundly haunting in its simplicity. Shoes were more valuable than human life, hence the taking off of the shoes. We walked along the promenade for a closer look and stood for a moment in silent prayer for those who lost their lives here. In my opinion, it is a memorial worth seeing both from a distance (as from Tram #2, sitting on the side with the Danube on your right) and up close and personal. From a distance, the whole haunting image of the memorial is captured. One can easily imagine the people who stood there because the shoes look so real at this distance. Close-up, you can see the detail of the shoes of that era and how visitors to this memorial have 'interacted' with it by placing candles and little knickknacks as tributes to those who lost their lives during the Nazi era in Budapest. A definite must!

A great memorial. A thought provoking experience and a great tribute. However considering the importance of this memorial it was not very well kept and there was a lot of litter surrounding the shoes.
The shoes almost looked real. I found the memorial a moving memorial...I am glad I took the time to look for it. I was especially moved by the children's shoes.

Very moving. We felt it was worth our time to make the walk down the steps below the Parliament building to this Shoe Memorial. There is a plaque in the sidewalk explaining it. It was quite moving to stand there and realize what others went through at this same spot. Made me want to cry.
A touching memorial. I had read about this shortly before my trip to Europe, and realized my tour would enable me to see this memorial. It was a touching sight to see , knowing the story behind it.
A moving experience. This is located right along the river right by the parliament building. We would recommend a visit to this memorial as a reminder of the atrocities that occurred during the war.
Moving memorial . This is a memorial which makes you really think about the terrible things which happend. It's simple but very moving.

A very moving memorial. Seeing these sculptures lined up along the river was a very moving experience for me, this was the first time I had really seen the horror of the Jewish genocide. Later in this trip I would visit Auschwitz, but this memorial is also a significant location to commemorate the Jews who lost their lives on this bank. Some of the shoes were so small, and they are so detailed you could easily mistake some as real.

One of the Most Maningful Holocaust Memorials. This memorial was a short walk from the Intercontinental Hotel and past the Chain Bridge. It is stark in its simplicity and effective in making one think of what happened here in 1944 and 1945. It does not, as one reviewer said, commemorate the suicides of people jumping off of the bridge, but rather the fact that the Jewish victims were required to strip naked and take their shoes off before being shot in the back of the head and pushed into the Danube. When you are with a child of a Holocaust survivor, it makes the experience more emotional and surreal. Along with the wonderful pastries and sights of Budapest, this stands in sharp contrast to other sites in Europe which have seemingly made the Holocaust a tourist attraction. It is spare and absolutely worth the short time it takes to visit.

A Simple - But Must See Memorial. If you're a tourist in Budapest, odds are that you will visit the Parliament building. This memorial is a few short blocks from there and won't require much time to view. That said, as we saw the first few pairs of bronzed shoes, my husband and I both had tears in our eyes. We could easily picture the men, women and children who wore those shoes and were victims of the Natzi takeover in Hungary. It was actually one of the most moving experiences during our 2-week trip. If your not familiar with what happened to the Jews in Hungary, a visit to the Jewish quarter would be worthwhile as well. There isn't any kind of tour here ...just a viewing of the memorial.

Touching memorial. This memorial is so simple but yet so moving. I think everyone visiting should take the short walk along the Danube and have a moment of reflection, remembering the poor souls who lost their lives.
touching. fantastic site near the river, just next to the parliament.very moving sculpture and really detailed!worth to see and contemplate.
A Moving Memorial. A moving experience in this quiet place that is a memorial to the inhumanity of man. A must-see when in Budapest.

Heartbreaking. Just days before the Arrow Cross was defeated, with the Red Army close by, Jewish people were lined up on the bank of the Danube, steps away from Parliament, shot and shoved into the River. Memorial stones, flowers and candles are placed in remembrance of the lost. Little baby's shoes are heartbreaking, no less than the lady's or men's. How valueless the victims. How without values, the perpetrators.

Simply compelling.... It takes real creativity to translate horrible moments in history to clear, simple and compelling stories that are devastingly impactful. That's why this memorial works so well. No artifice, no trickery, but images that translate in any language and evoke imagined faces and families of the men, women and children who wore such shoes one day, and were gone the next. Worth seeing for yourself.
Moving site . What it represents is moving. It's not very impressive though. I wouldn't put it as a must but it's just on your way from Parliament to the Bridge.
Shoe Memorial. This memorial is very moving, but is beautiful and makes one take a moment to reflect the horrors which went on.

Moving, must-see.. Beautiful, moving memorial. Would advise travellers to do their own research into the background/meaning of the memorial since there is no English text accompanying the memorial (which is as it should be, the starkness and intimacy of this memorial is what makes it so poignant).We are glad we went to the House of Terror Museum before coming here.

Powerful and sobering. Walking along the Danube after a visit to the Parliament building you come across this row of shoe sculptures which is representative of people having committed suicide off the bridge. A very sobering and powerful monument.
Adventure Budapest. This is a very sobering reminder of the Jewish lives lost during the war. Simple and yet unsettling. Worth the time.

Brought Tears. Very moving experience to visualize the shoes and to only imagine the horror of the past. Left us feeling very sad, however it is a monument to visit on the way to the Parliament building.
Very moving. This is a very moving sight to walk by in Budapest. Remembering those who died for freedom. You got the feeling of knowing who the people were by the shoes that were displayed.
Past events memorialized. Interesting history and sad reminder of past events. Walked to this from our hotel. This is on way to Parliament building.

Touching, but needs more care. Nothing bad to say about the monument itself, it just seems to have a bit too much rubbish around it to be acceptable. For something so touching it should be cared for more.
Powerful Image. This was a powerful and moving tribute to those whio perished. It made the Holocaust so real and personal.

Somber and to be remembered . We visited September 14. This is a strong reminder of one of the most gruesome times in history. It should never have happened, but our weak world and country leaders stuck their heads in the sand.
Must see
History of the shoes. It was a very moving experience as our guide had the experience 1st hand - a child from the holocaust. So read up on the dark history otherwise there is no explanation on site

A moving tribute to the horror of events in history. We were very moved and at times overwhelmed by the history of this city and especially this site. Easy to find, very close to the Houses of Parliament on the Pest side and a short walk from the Chain Bridge.

A sad reminder. A sad and moving reminder of the WWII atrocities suffered by the Jews of Hungary. There is always a crowd but if you're in a moving vehicle, you may be past it before you realize it as it's not very big or long
Moving tribute. Understated brilliant memorial along the Danube. Read about the origins and significance before walking along this sobering reminder of past intolerance. It is a moving tribute.

Never let us forget!. For many reasons, the Holocaust really touches my heart and walking to this sign in Budapest is moving and the story behind the shoes is heartbreaking and needs to be remembered!

Horrible and Beautiful. This is in front of Parliament, so don't miss it. It's in the foreground of a beautiful view down the Danube including Buda Castle, the Chain Bridge and Gellert Hill. That this place should have been where people were machine gunned into the river during the latter stages of World War 2 is almost beyond belief.The contemporary shoes are moving and haunting for not showing the victims, only an impression that people were killed there. It's not something that should be forgotten. The story should be better known. It could not be more respectfully commemorated.
Poigniant. Well worth searching out so as not to forget the messages that history can teach us. A poignant reminder of Nazi atrocities.

Very thought provoking. This display is very emotional to recall how many people of the Jewish Faith and other minorities were treated and killed during the Second World War by the Nazis and their compatriots.

Take a moment . I recommend visiting the shoes representing the Jews along the river, it is a beautiful setting and it is really important to remember Budapest's history. The shoes make it so personal, and it does evoke a lot of emotion. A must see if you want to see the real Budapest. However it would have been nice if there was an information board about it. We just looked it up before, but it seems a shame there is not more.

Worth visiting as a landmark. I am glad we walked past the Shoes on the Danube between other sightseeing locations - it was worth visiting. I would have liked to have seen an information board nearby.
"must go". This is probably one of the best memorials dedicated to the atrocity suffered by Jews, It isn't magnificent in size or In-your-face loud, but a very subtle reminder of the history.

Definitely worth a view. If you are walking along the Danube between Parliament and the Lancid, you might not know what this monument symbolizes. There are no signs or other explanations. The anonymity is part of what makes it a powerful remembrance.
Moving. In a whirlwind city break this gives you time to contemplate the past. All the more poignant at the present time.

Very moving. I can't see how you can be fail to be moved by this simple but poignant memorial. I assume that the negative comments are written by people with short memories or from those that need constantly to be entertained. This is not some reality show but a memorial to a terrible event that should never be forgotten whatever your religion.
Touching . A sad story behind the shoes of the Jewish who lost their lives but a fantastic way for their memory to live on
A eeminder. A sobering reminder of the history of Budapest. A good opportunity to reflect on what I'd learned about the city and its people
Sad but recommended. It is a sad place but should be recommended to all visitors to Budapest as it is the history of this city.
be sure to remember. A must see walking along the shore line from the parliment buildIng small memorial but you understand the cruelty involved but the world never learns

Very touching tribute . We walked along the river to find this memorial and both thought it was very poignant and a good way to remember, found some people very disrespectful by smiling and taking selfies which I thought was very inappropriate.

Emotional tribute. This was a truly emotional tribute to those whom lost their lives here along the Danube. Take a little time to observe the different types and sizes of shoes including those of women and children.

Powerful. My great uncle was one of the 20000 or so Jews rounded up in late 1944 to early 1945 by Arrow Cross members, forced to strip, and shot into the Danube. This thoughtful memorial honors their memory in an eloquent and compelling way.

Shoes of all sizes. We walked here knowing that it was between Parliament and the Chain Bridge, but I wish there had been some signs to explain more about this exhibit. Thankfully I had googled it ahead of time, but I imagine that many people wonder why there are shoes of all sizes and no explanation for it. It is a well kept memorial to the Jewish people who were killed during WWII.
Memorial place. A poignant memorial to a terrible event, worth stopping for a few moments to ponder. Free to visit..

A powerful reminder of cruelty. Everyone who visits is likely to feel sadness when them imagine the victims of this cruel act. It takes only a few minutes to visit and it is something you will never forget when you read the memorial plague.

Never forget. I read about this Memorial and made a point of seeing it. I was out on an early morning walk with "the ladies" and I asked them to head in the direction of the memorial. They had not heard of it but were willing to tag along with me. It is very simple but very moving. It hard to believe the suffering that took place at a point where we are sightseeing. It's a must.
Very important to visit. Very close to the parliament on the Danube An important story to tell or read in the internetAmust for any human
Worth the stroll .... Poignant and thought-provoking. Not a widely-known sight, just in front of the Parliament down by the river.
A beautiful and sad monument. A beautiful monument. So many shoes...On the walk from the parliament to the chain bridge, next to the Danube. DON'T MISS IT.

Why all the hype?. Because of all the high ratings, World Heritage Site and the rest we were expecting much more than some innocuous brass shoes stuck in concrete. The Hungarian people and especially the German people also suffered greatly in World War 2, from Hitler's craziness and not just certain religious groups.
Sightseeing. Touching monument, steeped with historic background. Well kept and visited. Some sign-age in English could provide better understanding for those passing by.
Worth a look.. This momument is about 300 meteres to the left of Parliament facing the Danube. It is a reminder of past events and rather sad.

Near the Parliament Building. 60 pairs of rusty, iron 1940s style shoes set in concrete on the edge of the Danube as a memorial and a monument to the Hungarian Jews who in 1944-1945, were shot on the banks of the Danube River by the members of the anti-semitic Arrow Cross Party.A moving and powerful sight.If you are near the Parliament building, it is only a short walk away.
Makes you think. Very moving - make sure you take time to remember what happened - man's inhumanity to man. This memorial makes sure those who perished at the hands of the Nazis are remembered.

Sad reminder. A must-see memorial to the 15000 Jews rounded up and killed just weeks before the end of WWII, the arrow cross group, tied three people together then at the bank of the river, shot one who then fell pulling the other two in to drown.

Hidden and shameful history. Across my stay in Budapest and sadly arriving in complete ignorance I read more and more about the shameful atrocities done by man onto man. I walked the city several times and the grandeur, food, culture and beauty of a former great empire stood out. What didn't stand out was its shame. I walked through the Jewish Quarter oblivious to the fact that 70,000 were enslaved-left to starve or be killed if they attempted to leave the ghetto and somehow it felt like it is hidden from view-likewise the liberation of Budapest was one of the most brutal of WW2 yet again to the ignorant such as myself -it didn't happen-So I ended my trip with the sense of a City in denial of its past evil. I looked in a few book stores to read more but nothing was there. 300,000 Hungarian soldiers and more than 600,000 civilians died during World War II, including among them at least 450,000 Jews and 28,000 Roma- but apart from this memorial and visiting the synagogue the passing traveller would be none the wiser.

Visit at night. After dinner, we walked along the river-- One of our best experiences! We started out as the sun was going down and got great pictures of the chain bridge at dusk and continued walking to the Parliament Building. By the time we got there, it was dark and all of the lights were on. As we continued to walk, we stumbled up the “Shoes on the Danube” memorial that our guide told us about earlier in the day. The Nazis took Jews to the edge of the river and made them take off their shoes, and then shot them so their bodies would fall into the river. I found it moving to see the shoes at night and hearing the water hitting the river bank. Because this was near our hotel, we went again during daylight. I'm glad I saw it both times, but I think seeing it at night, made more of a lasting impression.
Sad. A verytouchy place. So sad... nice view on the Danube river but the senseof what had happened here is very sad.
A simple and moving memorial near Parliment and river cruis dock. Take the time to see this memorial to the useless killing of the innocents. Simple but moving.take a few minutes to visit.

Chill up your spine. This is a sad reminder of what happened in the Second World War and what the Nazis did. It sent a chill up my spine as I saw the display of shoes cast in metal. Shoes abandoned by many people before they were killed. I found it to be a very moving and emotional display. I stared at the shoes for a long time and I could almost feel that I was there in the Second World War. The memory of these shoes will remain with me for a very long time.

A must see of a time that shouldn't have been!. Very touching and truly memorable. Along this promenade, you will come across 60 pairs of cast iron shoes in remembrance of those shot during the Arrow Cross terror in 1945.

A fitting tribute. Sobering thoughts that fellow countrymen could kill 60 of their own just because they were Hungarian Nazi's and they weren't!!A fitting tribute made out of bronze, to commemorate the 60 gunned down as they fell into the river.

Don't miss this moving Monument. I read about this on Tripadvisor and felt I just had to see it. Its heartbreaking and moving at the same time. The little pair of children's lace-up boots were very sad to see. With the backdrop of the Danube, its beautiful and ever so unique.

A SAD MEMORIAL!. This is one of the most moving memorials that we have visited in Europe. Hopefully I can do it justice in the few words expressed here. Many Jews were forced to strip naked on the banks of the Danube and face the river; a firing squad then shot the prisoners at close range in the back so that they fell into the river to be washed away. This was a common practice that occurred during 1944-1945. This memorial is in front of the Parliament building on the edge of the river. There are 60 pairs of rusted cast iron shoes. Different sizes and styles reflect how nobody was spared from the brutality of the Arrow Cross militia, including men, women and children. Behind the sculpture there is a stone bench where at three points are cast iron signs, with the following text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. This should remind all of us of how blessed we are!

Befitting, but a little bit overrun. The Shoes on the Danube Memorial is dedicated to the Holocaust victims that were shot by the bank and/or thrown into the river. The shoes, of both genders and all ages (infant to adults), is a befitting and solemn memorial. However, the memorial has been a little overrun, and looks worse for wear. It is still a recommended stop.

Very very moving. We visited this today very moving and very sad if you do one thing in Budapest visit this The Shoes on the Danube Bank is a memorial in Budapest, Hungary. Conceived by film director Can Togay, he created it on the west bank of the Danube River with sculptor Gyula Pauer to honor the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank.
Shoes on the Danube side. A memorial for the Jewish victims from the second World War. It is right behind the Parliament and makes you think again of all the cruelty...

A visit of respect. This is not a very obvious "attraction" and you probably won't find it just walking around. It's on the Pest side of Budapest, on the promenade of the Danube a little before the parliament.It's a very chilling reminder of what happened in Budapest years ago.Go ahead and visit it in light of paying respect to the Jews who were shot, falling into the river in Budapest, during the WW2.

Haunting to visualize those who died in those shoes...... Random shoes strewn along the bank of the Danube.....in memory of the Jews who were shot and drowned in the Danube during WWII, just steps away from the majestic Hungarian Parliament. A simple remembrance of a horrible event 60 shoes for the 60th anniversary.... stays in your mind long after you've returned home

Moving display. A moving experience and fitting tribute to the many Jews who lost their lives here. Reflection is food for the soul. The ground around display needs to be swept clean. Worth your time.
Moving. Well worth taking the time to visit this moving memorial. Take the time to research the meaning behind the artistic installation.

Odd, and probably more significant than is obvious.. Could have done with more explanation, as with many sites in the city - lacked detailed explanation, but again as with many things around, seems to be a memorial to people who died.

Poignant memorial to a dark time. Beautifully done. One cannot help but feel for those who were murdered on the bank of the Danube. This could be easily missed but easily seen if you look for it just outside the parliament building on the Danube

Shoe Memorial to the Jews. In close walking distance to the Chain Bridge. We walked across from the Buda to the Pest. It is really only a short to key shopping and other historical sites. Worth the visit as a reminder of the horrors of war.
nice memorial on the danube. Take a walk along the river and visit this memorial site. Its about 400m from the chain bridge as you go upstream.

Touching memorial. Touching, very emotional visit, while you see all kind of shoes including women and small children, that remember you, the thousand of jews that were killed during WWII, not only in concentration camps, but also by drowning them in the Danube.

Memorial to those who were shot and pushed into the Danube River. We were able to see this as we drove past as part of a bus tour. The brief view with the description was so moving. It is a very simple, stark memorial, but very touching and illustrates what happened so clearly. This tells a part of the Jewish story in Budapest.
Haunting. We almost walked pat this except a friend said look at this. It is haunting and a stark reminder of all this wonderful country has been through.

Very touching. It always amazes me when I hear about such atrocities and this memorial is very touching if you know about it before hand. Not massive but we went to show our respect. People had lit candles and taken flowers.

A chilling, sobering must see!. What happened here seems unimaginable and yet it happened! The bronze shoes line the Danube in front of the Parliament Building as a memorial to the thousands who were taken to the river's edge, told to remove their shoes and then shot so they would end up in the river. This sobering monument has 60 pairs of rusted period shoes cast out of iron. Different sizes and styles reflect how nobody was spared from the brutality of the Arrow Cross militia. "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45"

Everything a Memorial Should Be. This is the best and saddest memorial to Jewish people I have ever seen. Thanks to the brilliant collaboration of film director Can Togay and sculptor Gyula Pauer. Solemn and moving.

A kept secret. I had read about this very moving memorial and wished to see it. We asked the guide and she said it was too hard to get to. As a result I did not see it.Also some said they did not know where it was... Its is on the embankment in front of the Parliament house I believe.

Budapests Holocaust Memorial. Budapest's Holocaust memorial is a very moving sculpture in iron of shoes embedded in the concrete quayside to honour the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944. The story goes that they were instructed to take off their shoes then shot into the Danube - a poignant and chilling reminder of man's inhumanity to man. The Shoes on the Danube memorial affords stunning views across the river towards the castle and is also just next door to Budapest's magnificent Parliament building (make sure you walk right the way round). We completed our stroll along the waterfront with a memorable quayside lunch at Dubarry's restaurant which is just along from the Intercontinental and within easy walking distance of both the Shoes and the Parliament

Moving. This moving memorial is well worth a visit while in Budapest and to understand the history that accompanies it. It is a short walk from the Parliament building on the river. A monument to the the ability of mankind to reach the lowest level of humanity. Hopefully it will be a reminder never to repeat history.
Shoe Memorial. These are bronzed shoes placed along the wall of the Danube near Parliament as a memorial to those lost during WW II.

You need to see this!. The most moving memorial I have seen .The shoes say it all . The Nazis lined up the people, tied them together and shot one so they would all drown in the river . There are shoes from women, men and children.

Spirts of the past. Most memorial are some kind of abstract or so big in size that the meaning is lost. But those few steel shoes on the bank of the Danube moved me. It all seems so real, I kept wondering how could such a thing have happened? No other monument has had the same affect on me.

nice to visit. walking distance. nice walk two. nice open space. drinks and packed lunch was nice on the chairs there. nothing special though, so if lack of time, not sure I would go. But as it was on the way walking to one of the great buildings close by, we stopped for a few photos. It's nice to know the background to it as well. interesting

Very moving. This simple, small memorial will bring tears to your eyes. In your mind you can actually see the poor prisoners standing there on the edge of the Danube, taking off their shoes and then being slaughtered and their bodies thrown in the river to be carried away. Very emotional, very touching, don't miss this.

Shoes ..... Went to see the shoes on the Danube ,it's just a short walk along the river bank from the parliament building .was an unusual memorial unfortunately ( and I realise some people wish to respect the dead in this way )there were a lot of dead flowers strewn around which I thought made the memorial look a bit untidy , very glad I went to see it , interesting story behind it .

A Moving WWII Memorial. This memorial, situated on the banks of the Danube, was created by sculptor Gyula Pauer to honor the Jews killed in Budapest during World War II. According to the guide on the Jewish History walk, they were selected from the Jewish Ghetto for extermination, told to strip (to assure that the men were Jewish) and tied in threes. They were then ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water. To save bullets, only one person in each group was shot, and when he fell the others also fell into the river and were carried away. The sculpture represents their shoes left behind on the bank. It helps to know this story when viewing the memorial, otherwise, the significance may be lost. There is little explanation at the site itself.

Very Moving Memorial. The Shoes on the Danube is a small but very moving memorial right near the Parliament Building. It is so small that it is frequently missed by tourists that are searching for it.That being said after seeing it I can't seem to get it out of my head.

Powerful in its simplicity. Very simple but yet powerful to see. Many shoes of Jewish people who were brutally killed by the Germans and Arrrow Cross Nazi supporting Hungarians. A reminder to mans inhumanity to its fellow man. Very simple layout along a beautiful point on the Danube near the Parliment building.
A sobering memorial. Very humbling experience. I have to say I wasn't actually aware this had happened until we visited but once I knew I had to pay my respects
Moving Memorial. Another reminder of the horrors of World War II, and Hitler's attempt to eliminate the Jews. Many lost their lives here.

Good to see. Really nice memorial but read up on the site before visit due to there being no information boards at the edge of the river,perhaps visiting on a guided tour would've made our experience better ,due to our own lack of knowledge ,still beautiful part of the city.

Poignant and thought provoking. This memorial on the banks of the Danube is to those Hungarians who were murdered by the Arrow Cross Fascists in 1944 and 45. They were told to take off their shoes before being shot. The poignant simplicity of the memorial highlights the horror of the brutal events of those years.
metalic memorial. A fairly recent memorial to a wartime slaughter. A quiet thought provoking memorial to the men, women and children killed for being Jewish.

Thought provoking. We visited this and found it to be a moving thought provoking exhibition. There was a plaque noting dates and what had occurred but i would have liked to discover more about the events of this tradegy and further information would have been welcome.

So poignant.. We visited this site in August on one of the hottest days of the year, which only added to the poignancy of the site. So understated but speaks volumes of the suffering during the second world war, and there are very touching modern messages put inside the shoes. The way the shoes are placed is exactly as if they have just been taken off and left on the banks of the river whilst their owners take a quick dip. So tragically far from the truth. This was one of the sites of Budapest we were determined to see, and took the Hop On Hop Off boat and got off at the Houses of Parliament. The Shoes are located about 600m along the banks of the Danube from the Parliament building. A must see.

Very tough Memories. Scaring memories but must visit this place to realize the History of people being shot at this location just outside the Parlament. The most emotionel part is when realizing that they demanded the people to take off their shoes before they where brutaly murdered and fell dead into the river Donau.

Touching, delicate, special. There's no much to say about this. You are walking down the Danube and you stumble over a pair of shoes, then over another. This place is full of sorrow - it's right not to forget.

A Memorial to the Past. It was a very emotional experience for me to see this memorial of the Jews who lost their lives here. It is very simple, yet very hard hitting. You should read up on the history of what actually happened at this site. Very powerful.

Really moving place to visit!. These shoes were a really moving places to visit to commemorate the Hungarian Jews who were shot into the Danube River. My only criticisms was that there had been a memorial there with flowers and candles possible a few weeks ago as all the remains were left making it look untidy!

A Moving Experience. This stop is very close to where the cruise ships are lined up. Seeing these shoes lined up as you drive by is an emotional experience. The story about is that Jews were rounded up, brought to this spot, told to remove their shoes, and were forced to drown in the Danube. The actual shoes were the models for the permanent bronzed or concrete shoes that line the embankment.
Moving place to visit... a few minutes to contemplate. Seeing these shoes on the river wall brought all the horrors of World War II out. So simple... so moving.

Read up on it first. A sobering Holocaust memorial that you should seek out if you visit Budapest. I recommend reading up on the history of this monument because there is no plaque or explanation at the site.
Worth a visit. Chilling artist rendition of the atrocities of WW II. On the Parliament side of the Danube, just north of the Chain bridge.
Thoughtful and moving. Read up on Wikipedia or Tripadvisor for the details - a very moving and thoughtful memorial, especially at night.

Week in Budapest. Free to check out. It is another reminder of some of the history that happened here. It is just interesting to see. It is located near the parliament building so if in the area, stop by and check out!
Very moving. It was very eerie seeing all those shoes on the side of the river and a harsh reminder of what those poor people had to endure. Well worth visiting

Powerful Memorial. The shoes are located on the back of the river and represent the shoes taken from shoes where they were shot and tossed into the river. It is very powerful and is a picture that stays with you.

Jewish rememberance. It's on the banks of the Danube (Duna). There are three plaques commemorating the lost lives in the Holocaust, Hebrew, Hungarian (Magyar) and in English.One can't help but think about the inhumanity of men when visiting the site!

interesting.. very nice to see iff you are having a walk along the Danube river.its a exhibition of many different kind of shoes made out of iron glued to the ciment along the river.its free and very nice to see and to analyze the great hand work off this shoes
Very thought provoking. Just seeing the shoes lines up really hits home the sadness of what happened during the Holocaust to the community.
One of the bucket list at Budapest.. If you visiting Budapest, take a bit time when walking on the bank of the river. This place is close to the Hungarian Parliament Building.
Thought provoking memorial. I knew very little about the history of Hungary in the war, but this little, extremely poignant memorial really makes you think about the atocities of war

Beautiful site. interesting place to walk along the Danube. Lots of tourists present but could do with a little clean up and picking of litter and cigarette butts. Also, good luck if you need a washroom.
Uncomfortable history.. Very emotive. Shoes represent people 9mainly Jews) lined up and shot so their bodies just fell into the river.
Must visit. Worth a trip, thought provoking but spoiled by too many dead flowers and candles, it takes away from the actual sculpture.

Very moving. Exceptionally poignant and moving memorial to the many Jews killed by the Nazi sympathising Hungarian Arrow Cross in the latter years of the war. Not marked on many tourist maps and with little detailed information at the site, it can be found right on the bank of the river immediatley in front of the Parliament building.
very moving. A simple but poignant memorial that is a true impact on the suffering that was caused. Easy to get to and well done.

You will see this walking to the Parliament building. Seen at night while walking to the Parliament. This is one of many Holocaust memorials. All make you think and this one shows the cold blooded cruelty of the Arrow Cross regime. These sculptures are covered in flowers and candles.

It Deserves Better Attention. This is a very poignant memorial to those innocent inhabitants of Budapest who were murdered by members of the Arrow Cross Party by shooting them on the edge of the Danube into which they fell. The shoes look real as if they were abandoned only a short time ago. However, some of the shoes are filled with dirt and pebbles while old dead floral tributes lay about the site. It is such a pity that this public art work is not looked after more carefully. It deserves better attention.
Moving tribute. Look up the history of this memorial online before you visit, puts things into perspective. Standing on the edge of the water you can almost sense presence of ghosts of the past

Worth a visit. We walked along the canal and stopped by this Jewish memorial and I have to say that it is effortlessly done and has a beautiful effect on passers-by. It certainly made us stop and look!

A memory to remember on the pain of war. Worth visiting to understand what it was we fought for in the Second World War and the suffering during that period. Brings a tear to the eye, very well done work of art too.

soul serching memorial. several pairs of shooes sulptured (Ithink it is about 60) at the edge of the Danube river opposite to the parliament building. It is told that people were rounded up and brought to this palce and shot from behind by arrows so that they fall into the river during 1944-45. You are forced to sit and soul search the poverty of human feeling to the fellow human simply because he belong todifferent clad.
Let's not forget. Part of the Jewish experience. Memorial to the Hungarian Jews shot into the Danube at this spot. Very close to the parliament.
So sad. So sad and so beautifully done! A wonderful tribute to some of the darkest days known to mankind. A must stop and seeBObk
Stunningly sad. Seeing all of these shoes by the river bank and thinking of the poor people who were standing there knowing they were going to be killed was a moment of great sadness for us.

Each sculpted pair is modeled after actual shoes of the time.. "Shoes on the Danube", by Gyula Pauer and Can Togay, 2005, is a tribute to Hungarian Jews who were killed by the river at the hands of the Arrow Cross Party in the 1940s.Victims were asked to remove their shoes before execution. Each sculpted pair is modeled after actual shoes of the time. If you are lucky enough (just as I was) you can find them covered in white roses, at times. It's really touching if you get there during the sunset. Too bad it's not signaled wherever.

Very Powerful. The memorial is just to the south of the parlament building at the edge of the Danube. It takes a little walking to get to. While there is not much to it, when you consider what it represents, lining people up at the rivers edge to be shot and have there bodies fall into the river to float away, it can be a very emotional experience. Yet another example of how cruel human beings can be toward one another.

Touching your heart. It is a very important place for all of us to remember what happenned during the secong world war. Jews were shot into the Danube; even children and women. The bronze shoes remind us of them.

You should go. Easier to find than I had expected from reading other reviews and hard to get a good photo. I think reading up a bit about the history would help before visiting, although there is a plaque nearby to give you some information.

Emotional. The shoes memorialize the Jewish inhabitants who were killed by militiamen in Budapest. They had to take off their shoes and were shot at the water's edge so that their bodies would be carried away.

Puzzled. We came across the shoes and had no idea what they represented. We thought it must have related to a shipping a shipping accident
Consulting Mr "Google" we learnt if was a remberance memorial in relation to one of the many atrocities carried out during the war.
Kayjohn
Good for a photo and that's it. I just saw it while travelling on the bus and it didn't seem spectacular but it was ok. A different touristic spot and an interestingly peculiar one indeed.

Simple and elegant tribute. As much as we think we know about the Holocaust, it is had to express what an impact such a simply-done monument can have. To quietly stand and look at the 60 pairs of bronze shoes which represent the Jews who were ordered to remove their shoes, shot on the spot, and dumped in the Danube River. This is a quiet place of reflection amidst the hubbub of the river's sidewalk.
Budapest on your own. A memorable visit to Budapest definitely do the water bus city tour a unique experience on the Danube
Don't miss the Shoes!. Don't miss this small section of the Danube.Very powerful especially after visiting some of the other museums and learning more about the Nazi and Soviet occupations.

Not a Dry Eye. Do not miss this poignant tribute on the Pest side of the Danube. You cannot help but be moved. If you have visited other memorials to jews killed during WWII you must not miss this one representing the shoes left on the bank when the jews were shot at the rivers edge so that their bodies would fall into the river.
Simple and elegant. When in Budapest you must make time to see this simple and elegant memorial, to a terrible historical incident
Very Moving. A reality of the city's history. A tragedy but very well presented. The site is on the edge of the Danube near the Parliament.

Holocaust Memorial. The sculptors Pauer & Togay have created a moving memorial right in front of the Hungarian parliament to the Jews who were rounded up by the Ant-Jewish squads during the 2nd world war,killed & their bodies thrown in to the Danube river.The memorial shows pairs of old rusted shoes cast out of iron.The different sizes & styles of shoes convey how nobody was spared of the brutality of the squads.Behind the sculptures there is a long stone bench with the text in Hungarian,English & Hebrew "To the memory of the victims shot in to the Danube in 1944-45".A moving memorial indeed.
research the meaning before you go.... A touching memorial to a very horrible time in history. Just walk along the cruise ship dock towards the Parliament Building and you'll find it

Poignant.. We made a point of visiting a series of memorials and museums during our time- and this simple monument was definitely the one I found most moving. Many of the other monuments were a little contested, history is almost always open to interpretation, but this was a frank and incredibly effective memorial to such a horrific and tragic event. In front of the grand Parliament building it was a small and somehow very personal memorial.

Moving tribute. We knew this was here and walked and walked to find it which seems appropriate- it is a very moving an quiet tribute to so many who were lost during the war. It is one of the best memorials I have seen.
Just impresive. An impresive place, dedicated to the people shooted by armed militia in 1945 and throw away in the Danube... gives you goose bumps...

Feel history. this is a remarkable monument and when you stand next to the shoes, you can really experience history. Better than a statue and very impressive. All city noises float away when you're here.....

Very Moving. A must visit in Budapest, I rarely get moved by exhibits but this one really brought home the horrors of the Nazi occupation. Its very easy to get to see as it's on the shore of the Danube and well worth the minimal time it takes to see.

A moving experience. This memorial was dedicated in 2005 to the Jews who were shot and left in the river by the Nazis during the WWII occupation. Actual shoes were found during work on the retaining wall. The Budapest Historical Museum has them in a case documenting the killings. It is very moving and worth visiting even though there is scant info at the site and nothing in the DK Eyewitness Travel guidebook. It is very close to the Parliament and only accessible on foot.

A Simple Statement Profound & Tragic & Ironic. Very moving . 60 pairs of bronzed shoes belonging to Jewish men, women, and children who were murdered by the Hungarian Iron Cross and their bodies tossed in the Danube. The comemorative plaque, written in Hungarian, Hebrew & English that accompanies the memorial, doesnn not state that the vicitims were killed because they were Jews.Located on the Pest side of the Danube, this is a very accessible monument.

A glimpse of histort. Powerful sculptures that remembers people of the brutality of Hitler. It was saddening and touching to see so many Jews, from men to women to toddlers being shot and thrown into Danube.

A deeply moving reminder of dreadful events near the end of WW2.. The killing of so many Jewish men, women and children at this site was yet another inhuman act. You have to imagine, and it is so hard, how people could commit such barbarity. We had visited the main synagogue in Budapest and this site reinforced our horror and sadness at what occurred here and elsewhere during this terrible time.
Shoes. Very moving experience to see these bronzed shoes in commemoration of the Holocaust. Location is right on the Danube (a lovey walk made even more poignant by this Memorial.

The view of these shoes is touching. As soon as we reached the place where the shoes are we were thinking how these people felt when they knew that they were going to die. How humiliated they were. The history of Hungary just a step from the Danube.

sad little sculpture on the Danube. we had heard about this beautiful work but we couldn't find it. we finally stumbled on it by accident and it is not just a touching and moving sculpture, but the people viewing it gave it added dignity and meaning.

Sombre and meaningful. This is located very near the Hungarian Parliament. It's worth a visit to look and think about what happened. I suggest pairing it with the House of Terror visit - gives an even better context.
Poweful....jews shot by countrymen.... Powerful memorial. Jews shot to death, leaving only their shoes on the bank. Shot to death by their own countrymen...!

moving memorial. a really moving memorial of such a terrible thing. definitely worth a visit. It is right in front of the parliament building which is also worth a look. I would recommend going there at sunset as it seemed to be the most appropriate time.

Simple and Simply Moving!. I find the purpose and power of memorials is not to forget. I will not forget the memorial and I doubt I'll stop imagining the horrors that it recalls. Well done and must see!

Very touching and important site. Very significant, touching and sad monument, representing a sad prt of Budapest's history. I think there isn't enough information near the monument describing or detailing the story behind it, and that's unfortunate because people don't understand completely where they're. Definitely one of the important places to visit while in Budapest.

Emotional Sculpture. A thought provoking sculpture by the Danube, it represents the murder of people by the Nazis and dumping of their bodies into the river. A must visit if only to spare a thought for the victims and those of current atrocities.

Thought Provoking. I don't know if I'd call this an "attraction", but it's something worth taking the time to see. I would strongly suggest reading up on it before you go - without real context the impact of it's meaning can get lost and it might appear to be just an interesting art installation, but understanding that it represents the many Jewish men, women and children marched to the edge of the Danube by the Arrow Cross, forced to remove their shoes, then shot and pushed into the river gives it a depth and weight that will make you take real pause, especially when you look at the beautiful view around it. Note that it's very small and it only takes about 5 people to make it feel crowded, so you might need to wait a few minutes to get any personal time there, but it's worth it.

A stark reminder. A simple memorial - no board, no story, no banners - just 60 pairs of metal shoes, including children's shoes, placed right on the bank of the Danube. My guide book only had 4 lines on this memorial - but that is all that is needed to make you think, just for a few minutes, of the horrors and unimaginable cruelty this beautiful city has endured in the past. All around are grand buildings, the majestic river, beautiful bridges - then this simple collection of shoes reminding us how inhuman man can be to man. Take a moment to stop and reflect as you pass on your way.

A simple memorial with a extremely complex and important message. A small ragged line of bronzed shoes in front of the very formal Hungarian Parliament building. But the story they tell is anything but small and ragged. The winter of 1944 - 1945. The 2nd world war is almost over. The German troops have fled Pest and moved to the hills of Buda blowing up the bridges over the Danube. the Hungarian Arrow Cross Party began rounding up the remaining Hungarian Jews who were provided shelter in embassies and embassy homes throughout Pest. The men women and children were all dragged to this spot at the bank of the Danube, shot and thrown in the freezing cold river. A black day for Hungry, brought about by those who knew nothing but pure hate.

Something to See in Budapest. The display of shoes left on the bank of the Danube represents the Jews who were killed and bodies thrown into the river during the days of WWII and after. Very touching memorial!!!!
Moving. Don't miss this outdoor memorial, on the bank of the Danube and very near the Parliament building. So moving, and such a fitting memorial.

Immense sadness. Both my wife and I felt immense sadness when our courier told me how the German soldiers made the Jewish men, women and children remove their shoes before machine gunning them into the Danube

Simple yet mesmerising - a must see. I was glad that I knew some of the history and the meaning of this memorial. It can easily be found walking along the river, right before you get to the Parliament. You'll probably see a lot of people hanging by the river and see the shoes lined up. Thinking of the atrocities and the way humans have treated each other gives the need for reflection. It's important for us to remember the past so we do not make similar mistakes in the future. It was a beautiful and simple reminder.
lovely views along the promenade. I recommend walking down the promenade at night. there are lovely views on the other side of the city

A powerful, moving memorial. To truly appreciate this memorial for all the Jews that we're shot at this very spot you literally have to put yourself in their shoes at this very moment and this was so well captured by having their shoes amazingly recreated - there's so much emotion and movement in this simple but poignant art piece - definitely worth a visit while you're walking along the Danube en route to the Parliament.
Moving.... You can not help but be moved by the memorial especially when you catch sight of the children's shoes. It brought tears to my eyes.Go see and remember...

The Silence is Deafening ..... It's so simple but so touching. And while the shoes look real they are actually made of metal.
We all make a mark in this world. They left theirs and their haters, not seen but in the invisible void, theirs.
Inhumanity is so ... inhumane.

Poignant ! Lest we forget!. Having the story of shoes told to me , I could not resist an emotional moment there. Be warned - I was not! One can not imagine what it must have been like to be marched to that point because you were Jewish , told to remove your shoes and then be shot so that if you were not dead, you drowned in the Danube?
Nice exhibit . The location of this statue is very close to the center. I looked for at north to the parliament. Building, big mostake. It was eazy a little bit to the south.
Great. It's a great monument. And it's sad, and moving. Really beautiful how they created these shoes, all sizes.

Take your kids. For me, if you cannot make the other sites in Europe that take about the evils of the Nazis you must visit this site where Hungarian Jews and other "undesirables" were thrown into the freezing river. Very sad.

shoes on the danube. very moving experience, particularly if you go with a guide who can tell you the story about the shoes, and how the Hungarian Nazis shot the jews and threw them in the river, when they could not send them to the death camps due to the oncoming Russian army

Very moving sight. We were just strolling along the bank of the river after visiting the Parliament building when we came across this memorial. It was very sad to see the shoes representing all the people who had been lined up and shot and their bodies thrown into the river. It was especially sad to see children's shoes and to think that they had perished too. It had much more of an affect on you than just reading about it on a plaque for instance.
Sad. If you blink you will miss it. Was moving but would have benefited from more information at the site of the memorial and better directions.
Very Emotional experience. A memorial consisting of empty shoes commemorating the Jews who were greeted down to the Danube, told to remove their shoes, then shot and fell into the river.
Lest we forget. You would have to have a heart of stone not to be moved by this simple but stunning memorial to one of the Blackest periods of modern European history.
Trip in Juily 2015. Thoughtful monument for Jews killed during 2-nd world war. Never seen this idea. To be seen! While the water moves down towards the see, these petrified shoes stay pu.

Very Moving. Very moving memorial to those who lost their lives when the bridge was bombed. This is very close to the Parliament Building and if you go there you will not regret it. Especially touching was the children's shoes.
Moving. A simple but poignant memorial. A must see. Do not go to Budapest without seeing this and remembering.

A moving spot!. Very moving and touching! A must see along the Danube River in front of the Governmant Building near the Chain Bridge on the "Buda" side of the city. Don't miss it and spend some time reflecting on the incident.
Such a simple but very moving memorial. These sculptures of empty shoes are a very simple way of making us remember the terrible events. Take the time to sit and show a bit of respect.
Pay respects. This memorial is so touching. The shoes are beautiful and so relatable. It evokes an incredible sense of loss. Candles and fresh flowers are still left to honor loved ones.

Stop here, if you pass by!. If you are walking through Danubio river and you find this place yoy should take some pictures, ut represents very important memories, but if you dont see them, you'll not regret.
Worth a visit.. Worth a visit to see this memorial. Go and stop and think a while for the people murdered here.The shoes are near the Parliament building just down by the river edge.

Simple but so moving. The first time I saw this, I was shocked. The second time, I was moved to tears. It is so appalling that this could have happened. A beautiful tribute to those who lost their lives.

Look up history before visiting.. As we waited for the guided tour at Parlament, we decided to look at the shoe monument. There are a lot of monuments dedicated to the millions of casualties during the Nazi regime. However, without the knowledge of the history of the terror commited, the monument itself is not that impressive.

A must see. I liked how one comes across this while casually walking along the Danube behind the Parliament and then you see this powerful memorial to those who were thoughtlessly lost their dignity and lives during World War II.
Some may not like the obviousness of it, but I liked how it was understated.

Poingnant. I didn't know about these until we wandered up to them while walking about. We did not do much research into the city prior to our arrival as we were there for a Triathlon - but reading up about them afterwards left a deep impression, and I am soooo glad that I saw them and had a moment to reflect.
A must see. Truly breath taking to stand amongst the shoes and look out. A great way to remember, a lot of the shoes had ribbons tied to them or candles placed inside.
Very moving. Worth a visit. . Really interesting and moving memorial on the river. It is located just outside the parliament building. Worth seeing.

A time to stop and reflect. This is a very thought provoking sculpture and makes you think about the devastating life these people must have had during the war. Made me realise how lucky we are and not to take for granted the wonderful life we all have today
WWII Memorial Site on the Danube. Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial is a moving, understated exhibit. A bit more textual information explaining the site would enhance this striking memorial.

danube shoe memorial. it's sad to see so many shoes lying on the edge of danube river beside the parliament building in budapest but it reminds us of how one person's belief, hatred and power could take away so many lives during WWll that I hope that thsi will not repeat.

Moving memorial. This memorial is remarkable in how unremarkable it is. The bronze shoes lining the river wall are so very unimposing but represent so much. It is hard to stand there and not picture the men, women and children who filled the shoes depicted there. A wave of grief overtook me.
Interesting found!. Didnt know what it was at first. Turns out its a monument for the WOII victims. Beautiful next to the river and the view on the hill.
Memorial Site. This memorial is important to see and for part of the people in the group it was very moving definitely worth the visit.
Visualization in your mind is difficult. Seeing this really put perspective to one of the darkest times in world history. You start visualizing what took place here many years ago.

Moving. If you do one thing walk along the river and look at the shoes by the Danube
No charge
No show
Just a beautiful and moving tribute to a very sad time
Well worth a few minutes walk

Unplanned visit but glad I did . I wasn't aware of the location of these and was just strolling down the river looking at the lit up bridges and old town at night when I noticed the shoes on the floor. After reading about it and realising what it was I initially was impressed at how realistic they were then it hit me what they represented and I think it's a very powerful, well thought out memorial that really makes you think and feel deeply. It's heartbreaking.I'm glad I saw it and would recommend looking out for it, even if you're just passing.

poignant monument. It is a simple yet poignant monument to the time when humanity lost the sense of right and wrong, when people were consumed by hatred and fear. May we never go back to that place in the history. May we never forget that we are our our brother's keeper.

Danube promenade. Walk along the riverside and you will come across this simple but very moving tribute to the Jewish men and woman who lost their lives during this horrific and shameful period in our history

When small objects carry a tremendous emotional message. A series of bronze shoes in different shapes and sizes that represent those killed during the holocaust and shot on the River bank after having their shoes removed.Although some interpretations were that it was because of the scarcity other interpretations mention a last humiliation as the real cause.It filled us with great grief while we sat there for a few minutes.A couple who we accidentally befriended at the hotel told us that they alsofelt exactly that.Do not feel afraid of your emotions in this modern and digital world where everybody has a cell phone and nobody can communicate.Give yourself time to visit this site of remembrance and communicate in peace with the past and your soul .

This is very sad!. I was there at my trip in budapest, this is very sad that there is children's shoes, a lot of people died there!This is one of the best memory about the jews.I reccomend that place.
Shoes. This is a very moving tribute to the lost souls. It is easy to get to by walking just north of the Parliment building.

Memorable in Its Simplicity. So simple and yet so meaningful. Located along the Danube a short distance from Parliament this monument should be on your list to see in Budapest. You can imagine the women and children standing there, removing their shoes and then being shot and falling into the river.
Shoes Sculptures by Danude River. Interesting memorial sculptures. A short walk from the Chain Bridge. The sculptor is Gyula Pauer to honor the Jews who were killed by fascist.

Poignant. This is a heartbreaking monument of World War II atrocities. It is located on the Pest side promenade of Danube near the Parliament. Sculptor Gyula Pauer designed 60 pairs of iron shoes and affixed them on the stone embankment. This monument was the brainchild of the film director Can Togay. During WWII the authoritarian Arrow Cross guards took some of the Jews to the waterfront, ordered them to take their shoes off, fired at them and let their bodies fall into the river and float away. The interesting thing about these shoes is that they appear to be very real and belonging to the 1940,s.There are plaques, near the Shoes, stating,"To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005."

Poignant and incredibly moving. A very powerful symbol of the terrible atrocities, made more moving by its simplicity. One cannot possibly imagine the terrible sad and tragic stories behind the owners of these shoes and all the innocent people they represent. Must see.
Shoes resembling lives lost. Very sad and thought provoking place. You should visit as we all need reminding of the atroscities of the war. This should remain in the for front of people's lives.

Poignant reminder of the Holocaust in/for Hungary. This is a place to sit, reflect and contemplate on what happened to the Jewish diaspora in Budapest (and of course wider Hungary) during WWII. Take a moment on a quiet morning or evening to have a think about the souls who passed this way. If you have been to Auschwitz, you will understand how rapidly the Jewish community was transported from Hungary, and done away with. Not a happy location of course, but worth a moment or two of your time
