Pay close attention. They are not so easy to find, after all they're just shoes. It's a nice way to remember the victoms of the war since it's small and sober. However it manages to catch your breath once you learn why they are there. To bad we arrived alongside a bunch of amateur-photographist and had to wait quit some time before we could take a picture.Added bonus: the view on the Budda site!

Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial. Very close to the parliament, very emotional, we saw it at sunset, some people put lit candles inside the shoes, the creepy event commemorated in this place makes you feel very sad
Very moving. No cost to visit. A unique and moving monument. Read up about it before you visit as there is no information at the site itself.
a solemn experience. Visiting the shoes was very thought provoking, it is hard to understand how humans can treat one another.

A walk along the Danube. While walking Budapest in a sunny afternoon, close to the Parlieament we reached this place. Touching, poetic and original. Do not miss this monument. Always remember what men can do!
Great. Amazing monument, only thing is that's literally what it is just shoes on Danube they could make a whole museum on how they got there and reasons

Simple yet Dramatic. We made our way down to the Danube on Sunday morning just to see this memorial and it was worth it. Stopping to reflect at the memorial with the beautiful views afforded by the Castle, Bridge, Cathedral and Parliament was well worth it!

Unexpected moment on a Danube walk..... Happened upon a very powerful WWII memorial of shoes along the river bank from 1945. Nazi firing squad murdered Jewish men, women and children facing the Danube - their bodies fell into the river. A haunting reminder of the tragedies Budapest endured during the war.

A memorable moment to reflect.. A powerful image of the terror of the time which helps the visitor to feel an aspect of the wartime history of the city rather than just see the thoroughly refurbished city.

Interesting way to remember, much more impressive if you know the historical background. This place is for the memory of the holocaust. It is much more impressive if you know the historical background, read a little bit about it!
Without that knowledge it looks only like a great copy of lot of left shoes.

Moving tribute. Very moving and you cannot help but be drawn to the children's shoes. Somehow this brings home the horror more than most monuments do.
For our teenage daughters it made it very real
sobering thought. Easy to find when you know where to look. Go to Parliament building then onto river side and turn left.

Reminder of a dark history period, touching experience.. It's different kind of a memorial since it is basically not a statue or anything. Budapest is filled with reminders of the holocaust, and this is the easiest one to visit for anyone, since it is free and very easy to find.The experience is very touching. Before going to the memorial, get to know of the story of it and imagine the event it's resembling when you are at the memorial, so you'll understand it's meaning. It is not just a collection of iron shoes.It gets crowded at times, so visit it for example early in the morning to have the best experience.

Memorial for a dark time of Europe. The Shoes are located close to the Parlament ad the Danube river. Here you can find 2 plates with hungarian and jewish (hebräic) text. The shoes remember to the year 1944/45 were nazi killed jewish hungarians - have stolen the behaviors and dropped the shooten bodies to the river.This monument is only one of more memorials in Budapest, to remind you to the jewish life in Hungary during the 2nd world war.You should also visit the "Terror House" and the Jewish Synagoge.
Touching place. It's a bit hard to find, and there are no signs to help you out.Sad, considering the history behind it.Could use some directions to get to it, but a must see.
Heartbreaking.. We have been to so many memorials but this was so sad and haunting. It is not much but what it represents is an atrocity. To see even the shoes of children breaks your heart.

Point of remembrance. The aim of the artist designing the memorial was to make people remember the victims in an unusual way. It was overachieved. You are walking on the beautiful bank of the Danube, enjoying the view of the historic sights and suddenly you see something on the pavement. You draw closer to examine what it could be and suddenly it hits you... Shoes of those who have been shot dead into the Danube from this very site. And that makes it so close and so much human that it leaves you speechless. Must see. But shocking.
Incredibly moving. This is a must see! It may seem small and insignificant but it's such a poignant memorial, incredibly moving and beautiful. Make time for this when you visit!
Moving memorial. Memorial to those WW2 Jews who were forced to leave there shoes behind and jump to their death into the river.

Moving. This maybe a very simple memorial but we found it very moving. I think it was the fact that you could imagine the scene and your imagination can be a very powerful tool. We can never forget what happened here. I would recommend this as a must see if you are in Budapest.
Pleasant walk. A very emotional place to visit, yet the surroundings for the memorial are perfect, with beautiful views of the river and gorgeous buildings.

Painful memory. Conceived by film director Can Togay, he created it on the west bank of the Danube River with sculptor Gyula Pauer to honor the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank. It is worth to stop there for a while!

"Chilling". Walking along the Danube heading towards Parliament you come across the memorial of shoes left on the footpath, remembering those that were killed and thrown, some still alive into the water, during those horrendous times of violence towards humanity. It's quite a moving experience.

Wonderfully descriptive memorial. The shoes are those which were fasionable during the War and tells the story without any explanation of what these poor people went through. The child's shoes tug at the heart strings

Truly haunting. A must-visit for Budapest. It is truly haunting - tragically beautiful. Just don't be one of those people we saw posing and smiling pulling peace signs - we found this really disrespectful.

So simple, yet so powerful. This memorial is by the banks of the Danube when you walk from the chain bridge towards the Parliament building. It is thought provoking and moving, and another inhuman act which is difficult to comprehend.Well worth a walk to find it and to stop and think how fortunate some of us are.
Stop, look, think. Not much to say about this. Stop for a moment and contemplate what these shoes represent. Somehow, the way all the shoes were different and ordinary was especially touching.

Very moving. This was something I knew I wanted to see when I visited Budapest and it did not disappoint. Very emotive to see all the different types of shoes and the tributes which had been left in them. Just in front of the parliament building so easy to get to. Definitely recommend.
Emotional. Right on the water's edge and easy to get to by foot. Very busy when we visited. People have left ribbons and flowers in the shoes, very beautiful.
A Breathtaking Experience. It is hard to describe the depth of feeling that this very simple memorial evokes. Suffice it to say please go and be prepared to think and feel.

Interesting. The shoes are interesting on the river. If you walk along the river from Chain Bridge to the Parliament Building it's worth a stop and picture.
If you like antiques, just past the Parliament, there is a street with many antique stores. Just a note, the stores are closed on Sunday.

A Must See Site in Budapest. Seeing the shoes, especially the children's shoes is enough to send a very bad feeling in the pit of your stomach. Knowing more is even worse. Not wanting to waste bullets they tied three people together, shot the one in the middle and watched all three fall into the Danube. These were not the Germans doing the killing but the Hungarians.
Nice place. So emotional moment ! Here is staying a terrible part of our humanity history. You should go by night, some candles are lighted

Puts a face (so to speak) on human suffering. This is best appreciated when strolling along the harbor wall. Easy to miss but it serves as a reminder of those who were torn from their homes and made scapegoats in a war for which they had no responsibillity.Each pair of well-worn bronzed shoes tells a sad and tragic story of men, women, and children. One can only imagine their despair.
Stop and think.. Makes you re-evaluate your values, what a moving experience. Well worth a visit to give you food for thought.
A must see Tribute. A very moving tribute. I believe a must see when in Budapest. You can see this on foot or from the water on a cruise or boat ride.

Very Moving. Had read about this interesting memorial and was moved by the starkness of the empty shoes. Had just visited the famous synagogue and saw the memorial to the hundreds of thousands of Hungarian Jews killed during the Nazi invasion. Very moving!

Really tugs at your heart!. This simple collection of shoes on the edge of the Danube speak louder than any of the grandiose monuments in Budapest. The story of the Hungarian right wing fascists' treatment of the Jews before the Nazi invasion is horrifying and the result heartbreaking. Not to be missed!

a Bomb Straight to Your Heart. a touching memorial site that blows a bomb Straight to your heart. a must visit memorial, on the sidewalk near the danube.
we arrived through Kossuth Lajos tér Metro Station and walk some hundred meters to the danube.
Moving. Everyone who visits Budapest should visit this memorial along the Danube. What a touching reminder of the horrors of war.

Powerful Memorial. A touching and powerful reminder of the horrors faced during WWII. There was no plaque or explanation, which I think added to the poignance of the memorial.
It was a real shame to see people taking smiling selfies next to them, maybe these tourists needed educating in why the shoes were there.

Chilling reminder. Sets of bronze shoe replicas in life size as though occupants just removed them. This depicts an actual event when Hungarian Jews were shot and pushed into the river. While the candles and flower tributaries are fair enough the shoes get full of water and used tea candles which could damage the sculpture so I hope they are regularly cleaned out

Terrible tragedy and a poignant memorial. This details the sad history of the Nazis marching Jews to the Danube at the spot they were shot and killed. I only wish there were more things around the area detailing the history and some back story. The shoes lined up on the Danube were very sad. My daughter commented that there were even childrens shoes, a sad reminder that no age was left out of this horrible time in history.

Touching. When we visited there we had the feeling that some tourists have absolutely no behaviour, because they made "thumb's up" photos with smiles on their faces right next to the pair of shoes. Innovative idea for remembering the jewish victims and really touching!
Beautiful tribute . A moving, simple and effective tribute. It was lovely to see candles and flowers inside the shoes showing that those who lost their lives are still very much remembered.

A sad reminder of "Man's Inhumanity toward his fellow man.". It's a simple memorial as memorials go but a powerful one in it's simplicity. Sixty pairs of iron cast shoes laid along a memorial promenade. The shoes representing Jewish people murdered by the Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest between 1944-45. Told to take off their shoes, they were shot and left to float down the river. The promenade is near the Hungarian Science Academy on the Peat side along the river. It was erected on 16 April 2005 and was inspired by film director Can Togay and artistically sculpted by Gyula Pauer. It made me sad that genocide is still going on today as I write this review.

Thought provoking.. I wanted to go to see this-took time to locate-signage not too good-and there was some re building work going on-so fencing obscured initially being able to find it! I am however, glad that I saw it-reminder of how cruel humanity can be and atrocities are never far away. If you get a chance-do see it.

Poignant and powerful. Just down from the Parliament building there is a memorial to represent jews who were murdered by militiamen in 1944. These Jews were made to take their shoes off before being shot at the river bank, their bodies falling into the Danube and carried away. The shoes are expertly placed to replicate this act and it's a powerful statement. For a busy stretch of path and river, we were silent, no one there spoke, haunting, humbling and a stark reminder at how ugly the human race can be to each other.
Very Powerful. Monument along banks of the Danube with the bronze replicas of the shoes of those executed thre in WWII Thinking about it for a moment becomes very powerful

Haunting.. Just standing here and thinking of the terrible things that happened here just over 70 years ago makes you realize how lucky most of us are to live in the civilized Europe of today. Give this memorial your one minutes silence.

Unexpected and Moving Memorial. This memorial was incredibly beautiful, simple, and unexpected. During World War II, Hungarian Jews were lined up here along the Danube River and shot. The bodies fell into the river and were washed away. The shoes memorialize those that were executed at this spot.

Simple yet so moving . Such a moving tribute. We were walking from Parliament to the chain bridge and even though we were looking to see the shoes and were aware of them we were still stopped in our tracks by the sheer power of the image. Tremendous.

Shoes remind sad memories. We were in Budapest in last Easter holidays and on 3rd April 2015 we started our tour in the morning. After seeing Basilica and Parliament we came to this spot which was very easy to find. It was on the bank of Danube and 10 mins walk from Parliament .  This is a memorial to those who were shot and their bodies were dumped in the Danube towards the end of second world war. 60 pairs of iron shoes are kept on the bank as a memorial.Luckily, when we visited, there was less load of cruise boats and the place was almost deserted.
honor the Jews. It is very emotional Monument to honor the Hungarian Jews who were killed by fascist Hungarian Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during WW II.

Beautiful. It's a beautiful walk near the Danube river. A few people don't know what these bronze shoes represent (which is a shame). It is near the parliament and in front of the shoes, past the river, there are many other tourist attractions.

Poignant. This was a very poignant memorial to all the Jews who had to remove their shoes and then fell into the Danube as they were shot. Budapest has some very unusual memorials around the city, all of which make their point quite clearly.
Stunning Budapest. A simple but very poignant commemoration of an atrocious act - one that should never be forgotten nor repeated.
Shoes on the Danube. Incredibly powerful memorial. We noticed that Budapest was very good a memorials that were very much to the point. One glance and you get the entire story.

Very sad memorial that is eloquent in illustrating the fate of the Jewish people during WWII.. Worth a quick stop- makes your realize how tough it was for the Jewish population during WWII. The poor people had to take off their shoes and stand along the edge just before they were shot and fell into the river.

Stunning view. I was really excited to go see this site. It may have been a little more hyped in my mind. I couldn't get into the actual place I was standing and what happened. I think the idea was great and the view by the river is amazing. You are right by a lot of beautiful buildings. I guess I wish I knew more of the history. I did read a little before going.

Very Moving!. This memorial is dedicated to the Hungarian Jews killed during the war. It is a heartfelt representative of men, women and children who lost their lives in wartime. A very sombre and moving monument to their memory.

Impressive Memorial. Impressive memorial at the Danube quay. This memorial is on the Pest side.It's impressive when you read the story about this memorial. When you see the shoes (mainly the child shoes) you can imagine what terrible things happend here in the past.

Somber reflection about man's potential for inhumanity. We were not looking for this; but, are glad we stumbled upon it. The simple sculpture of shoes along the Danube River memorializes the location where Hungarian Jews were killed by the Nazis after they were forced to remove their shoes on the shore. Standing at the site of this World War II atrocity left sadness in my heart and a feeling that this type of thing should never happen again, even though it continues. It is said that we are destined to repeat history if we do not learn from the past. Travel should be an experience from which we learn from both good and evil, so good can be replicated and evil can be avoided or prevented.
Poignant and moving. Very poignant memorial to victims of the Hungarian Nazis in WW2. It is on the apest side of the river.
Nice memorial but no plaque. Nice memorial but no sign post or plaque nearby to describe the shoes in more detail. Luckily I'd done some research beforehand.

Interesting quick stop. Intesting to see and hear the story behind; however it doesn't take long to see. We sat by the river near the shoes for about 15 minutes and got our fix. Its right near parliament so its really easy just to stop by and look.
Moving Reminder. This is a moving reminder of a time when these atrocities took place. When the clothing on the backs was more valuable than the lives of the Jewish victims.

Great Reminder to Never Forget. This memorial is very interesting idea to help remember those that were killed during WWII. It was a very hot day when i went but there are some benches under some trees if you need to get out of the sun.
I found this to be very a sobering experience but reminded me that we can never forget what happened.
A very beautiful and poignant memorial. On the banks of the Danube, just a few steps from the Parliament building, this is one of the most simple yet most poignant monuments in Budapest. Very moving.
a must see.. very emotional, an incredible depiction of a horrible time on our planet. it is a brief stop, but one of the most moving Holocaust memorials.

In Bronze Shoes they Sink Fast. This memorial represents a frightful example of bigoted human behaviour. On the hot afternoon of my visit numerous young people were milling around and that in itself gave me hope for a better future. After all, if the young don't take an interest who will protect them in our present society where reports of religious unrest are almost the norm in everyday news reports. It's gut wrenching to think some people had such a low regard for everyday people going peacefully about their own business. You can also do a walkabout of the Jewish quarter and in there is a square which was used as the Jewish Ghetto. Don't miss this historic memorial situated on the pest bank of the Danube and easily reached on foot.
Take the time for a moment of reflection. A moment of reflection in a busy cityBut for most of the tourists just another scenic viewI missed some information nearby
Sad but interesting. A solemn , interesting but sad place to take a moment to reflect on of the sorrowful part of Hungary's history. It is a history lesson all should know.

Beautiful honor and stunning night view. You should definitely visit this sad and beautiful honor to those who were killed during the second world war. This is also a great spot to just take some time to appreciate the danube and the view in the evening.
VERY MOVING. This is a very moving experience, extremely thought provoking. When you see the baby shoes among the others it brings a tear to the eye.

Strange but good monument. A monument to remember the victims of WW2 who were shot into the Danube, the shoes are very well sculpted and gives the right effect, good little thing to walk by and remember the lost souls

Heart -wrenching . A simple, honest tribute to those killed because of their peaceful religion. A place to show your respect.
The world needs these kinds of memorials to keep us mindful of the evil that still lives.

sad but a must see. having never being to any kind of war related memorial i was surprised to find myself with a lump in my throat looking down on these shoes wondering what it must have being like for those poor souls having only seconds to live, really sad but worth the sadness just to sit and reflect on life.

Exciting and touching memorial. One of the most touching memorials to victims of Holocaust.
Must see spot during a visit in Budapest.
You will not miss it if you walk along the promenade to the Parliament.
A very touching monument. An incredible monument from WW II, very beautiful but also scary, and very telling. Another place you should visit when you are in Budapest.
Must see. This is a very moving experience which after understanding the reason and history will definitely bring a slight tear to the eye.

Simple but moving. Having read about the memorial we had to go and see it. It is a moving memorial to the many that died there. There are baby size shoes to remind us that no one was too young to be included. Some of the shoes hold candles and fresh flowers which suggests it is still visited as a true memorial site and not just a tourist place to go.

Shoes on danube. A must visit . Spend time to reflect and pay respect to all lives lost unnecessarily. There are seating nearby. Its besutiful srea looking back a across to bund.Near parliament building.

Very moving!. It took us a bit to find it at first (there was a lot of construction). When we reached the memorial, we were both so touched. a beautiful little lady was standing there crying and her family was hugging her and holding her hand. The whole history behind the memorial was just so sad. Hungary has been through so much and stands so tall now it is incredible. Seeing the little bitty shoes and the mens boots and ladies high heels just there on the bank of the Danube was heart wrenching. Definatly a must see!!
Beautiful Art. Moving and beautiful historic art. A must see when in Budapest. We happened upon it by accident. ..glad we did.
Beautiful Memorial. This is such a moving place where the Nazis forced people to take their shoes off then shot and threw them in the Danube it's near the parliament building
A must see statue. One of the most iconic attractions in Budapest, not much to see (only the shoes that you see on the photo) but it means a lot...

Moving Memorial. This was a very moving memoial to those Jewish people that were murdered in the dark days of Nazi occupation. It bought the story of those people to life. It must not happen again. A must place to visit in Budapest
Shoes at the promenade. Really worth going there. It is near the Parlement so you might walk along it. A strong monument to remind us of something terrible..

Remember the past to ensure the future. Breathless stay everyone who sees that, even if one is young enough and (probably) doesn't know much about the Second world war. Evils are always evils, and the scariest thing is that some people seem to forget about it.
Remembrance. Helping people to remember the horrors och nazism, an important memorial. Things like this are still happening today in the world.
it's our shoes. Creative and inspring place to visit. you will be triggered to take off your shoes and enjoy the beautiful view.

Moving and simple. A beautiful and moving tribute to the many Hungarians who were brutally murdered during world war two. I lit a candle which had been left in one of the shoes and took a moment to reflect on the horrors this country endured for so many years. It was a poignant moment and one I doubt I'll forget. Looking around I saw some people crying and many solemn faces. Couple this experience with a walk around the parliament building and neighbouring streets. A charming, peaceful part of the city well worth an evening promenade. An essential few minutes of any trip to Budapest to honour those so tragically lost.

A sombre yet worthwhile activity.. Very solemn and thought provoking to be reminded of the horrors that took place here.Worth having a guide here to talk you through the events and gain a little understanding of the Jews plight in Hungary as well as other places in Europe.
Don't miss it!. A very solemn and powerful memorial - a tribute unlike any other. The shoes are worth a thousand words and speak for the victims in a very personal way.

Very moving. Not to be missed. They were placed at the spot where the Hungarian police actually stood up to the Hungarian Nazis who were about to kill Jews who had taken sanctuary in a location that the Swedes had declared an embassy. Close by is a small underground museum dedicated to the 1956 uprising against the Communists. Also worth a visit.

Beautiful memorial. A simple but impactful memorial to the victims of the Holocaust.
It's very easy to get to, and it is also a beautiful place to watch the sunset over Budapest.
Very touching. Very discreet, this sculpture might easily be missed when you're walking along the Danube on Pest side. However, it is very symbolic and worth looking for.
Brought tears to my eyes. A must see when your in Budapest. Take a walk along the Danube, just before reaching the Parliament building.

Heart wrenching. Though heart wrenching to see and somehow feel what may have gone through the hearts and minds of those whose shoes were removed here, this is a piece of history that should not be forgotten.

moving. This is a simple but highly effective and moving memorial to the Budapest Jews who were shot by the fascist arrow cross party during World War II. It is just south of the parliament building along the Pest side bank of the Danube.
Sad reminder of man's cruel capabilities. A reminder of man's ability to be cruel beyond believe to his own kind. The danube of Johann Strauss will never quite be the same again...

Worth a quick stop, but don't go out of your way for this. The story is better than the actual site. Too many tour boats blocking the view when I was there to get a great picture of the chain bridge and Castle Hill. Im sure without the boats its a stunning view.Don't go out of your way for this, but if you happen to be strolling down the Danube on the Pest side, definitely worth a quick stop.

You Must Visit this Memorial. This is an easy memorial to find, right along the Danube on the Pest side near the Parliament building, but a hard place to walk away from to return to the present. I read about this memorial and heard about it from a number of our tour guides, as well as from tour books, but being there was incredibly moving. Many people have placed memorial candles in the shoes, as well as pebbles or stones in the shoes, as one does on a memorial stone. The shoes of the children were especially upsetting, thinking of the fear these young children had to experience waiting to be shot, or watching their parents, siblings and friends die. Make time to visit this quiet place and remember those who could not walk away.There is no signage telling you what you are seeing or the meaning of these bronze shoes, they tell their own story.
Moving...Let us NOT forget.... A wonderfully creative memorial of those who were senselessly shot on the shores of the Danube river.
Very moving. We went on a walking tour using our pre-purchased Budapest cards. It was quite moving to hear the story of Hungarians losing their lives under the Nazi regime.

Very moving. When you are walking along the banks of the Danube on a visit to Budapest, don't forget to visit this memorial to people shot into the river during the Second World War. It's simplicity powerfully remembers the victims of that dreadful time.

So moving. I knew about this 'sculpture' from family and reading, but I couldn't estimate what the impact of the visit would be. So sad, so moving for my colleague and me, that we were unable to speak for several minutes.
Worth seeing if nearby. This is a quite simple but effective memorial to the people who died. I wouldn't have come far to see it but when walking along the Danube it was worth seeing.

Very touching, must see!. Not much to add. Very emotional. I watched the shoes. There were pair of shoes and a few single shoe. I cannot imagine what those people and children felt that time when they were shot in the Danube. Very sad but a must see.

definitely worth visiting. This is a wonderful memorial tribute to the people who were murdered during WW II and the holacaust. I sat there for quite some time to just think about all the pain the people must have experienced during those horrible years. It was a great fitting tribute. I was taken back by the smallest of shoes. It was really moving.

Cruise on the Danube. This is a historic monument to jews people killed on the Shores of the Danube during the Second World War. It is very sad to see and remember what happened here but at the same time it is amezing to think that someone kept those shoes so they can do this monument on their memory now.
Very touching memorial.. Not much to add to all others have said about this understated but poignant memorial. A must visit if only to honour all those that this seeks to remember.

Never forget.... This is a memorial over the Jews that were killed during WWII. They were forced to take off their shoes, got shot and fell into the river Danube. To stand there so close to the shoes is strong. Your are looking at the same view as the poor people who got shot. Don't miss this, it has to be experienced.I didn't find any sign that explained the shoes. You can access the shoes by going down to the riverbank from the Szécsenyi square on the right side of the chain bridge or from the left side of the Parliament and then down to the riverbank.

A poignant memorial. This memorial literally took our breath away as we were taking a stroll along the Danube. It is simple and effective and brings on tears. Budapest is filled with so much history, and I appreciated the memorials to the Shoah, and the statues to thank Raoul Wallenberg amongst many other things.

Poignant.. Emotional.. Do not miss!. I had read about the Shoes on the Danube Memorial and I was moved... but there was something about being there and actually seeing the shoes of all types and sizes that brought a lump to my throat and tears to my eyes.. We arrived at dusk which added to the solemnity of the visit. It's hard to explain how the noise of the traffic and other city sounds receded to the background as I looked at these tiny shoe sculptures and reflected on what they represented.

I cried for Children and thier Families. A very touching Memorial and an important reminder to all who visit. The Memorial is close to the Parliament Building and serves as a reminder to those in government of the importance of this never happening again.

Moving and beautiful. . We visited here on our last day after doing a couple of audio tours. The story behind the monument is horrific, but the monument is touching and reminded me to be thankful of the things I take for granted.
Poignant. On approaching you are not quite sure what it is, but as you get closer and then read about it, it becomes a fitting memorial.

Powerful and moving. This is such a poignant memorial to jewish people shot and dumped into the river, after being forced to remove their shoes. The bronze casts of shoes bring this alive and the flowers, candles and notes left in the shoes are so moving.

Shoes on Danube Memorial. Very moving tribute to those murdered during WW2. Took pix to remind me of man's cruelty to others. Took stairs, next to shoe memorial, to get a Danube eye view. Very, very sad.
Worth seeing. Worth a visit if in town,however it is only a small monument as it is only shoes on the banks it is bronze shoes on the banks of the danube and quite hard to find without a map

Impressive, though beautiful. South of the parliament on the riverbank of the Danube (Donau) you will find an impressive monument which remembers the people who where shot death by arrow cross militiamen in Worldwar II.
There are sixty pair of shoes sculptures of men, women and children.
A nice monument to see but also to remember the horrors of WWII.

Worth a visit. Worth a visit if you're interested in WW2 history. I went at night which was interesting because people had lighted candles in the shoes. Also you will also see beautiful views of buildings lighted up during the night.
Moving. Lovely tribute besides the Danube river. Especially the children's booty's were very moving. Easily combined with a visit to the Parlement.
Moving.. Absolutely breathtaking when you know the history. Go down to Danub and take a look. It cost nothing. I thing this was a great way of showing what happened. A special monument.
Poignant memorial. Simple but poignant memorial. Close to the parliament building so worth the quick trip across the road to view

Don't waste your time. We read about those and we were curious to see them although they were not high on our priority list. We ran into them and they were are very sad looking site. Glad we didnt waste time looking for them.

Moving Tribute. The shoes are a moving tribute to those who lost their lives in the Holocaust. This is where people were loaded into boats and hauled away. It's sad, and in such a peaceful stretch along the river. It makes you think.
moving memorial to Holocaust victims. These shoes are a simple but eloquent memorial to the men, women and children who were executed on the bank of the Danube during World War II.

Brutality of war!. Shocking monument trying to point out the brutality of war! Jewish people leave their shoes to pass across the river Danube in order not to be caught by the Nazis. Really emotional.
Boring. The river bank is charming. Take a stroll on the river bank in the evening. It is very pleasant. Don't just go to see the shoes. They did not appear poignant to me.

Nice to see. Okay, it's very small but it's nice to see it. Also a very nice view to the city. Tip: rent bikes, bike via vaci street to the parlement and then back through the promenade, you will see the shoes along the way.

A moving memorial. Located between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament Buildings this moving memorial commemorates the lives of Jews who were killed during world war 2 and their bodies pushed into the Danube.

A Moving Memorial. It is easy to walk by and miss this memorial on the banks of the Danube a bit south of the Parliament. And yet it left one of the strongest impressions of all the sights I saw in 5 days in Budapest. I also must recommend an evening stop, after dark, when some people place small candles in the shoes, making for an even more moving, and haunting experience.

Simple yet heartbreaking. On the river bank just before the parliament building, you'll find this memorial to the many, many Jewish people sent to their death from Hungary. These are certainly shoes you do not want to put yourself in

Don't miss it. This is the most moving memorial that I have ever seen and shouldn't be missed. It sums up the horrors of the second world war in a simple but incredibly poignant memorial. Absolutely brilliant. It wasn't too straightforward to identify at first but it's between the Chain Bridge and Parliament
Thought provoking. A beautifully simple monument to those who lost their lives to tyranny. Best experienced with a few moments quiet.
Moving experience. Such a beautiful and moving experience to stand quietly at this site and reflect on what happened to people here in Budapest. This is an emotional place to visit.
shoes on danube. felt saddened by the sorrow of realizing that these shoes once belonged to human beings having had to suffer a great deal
The most touching memorial I have ever seen. Very touching. I think all people visiting Budapest should see this memorial and may be the world be a little bit better with less agression....
Very touching. A very touching memorial to those who lost their lives here. The shoes are so realistic, and some even have ribbons tied in remembrance as shoelaces.
A touching memorial. Vey nicely done. Very touching and poignant. Says a lot by doing less. Should be seen. Within easy walk of the Parliament.

A Very Moving Memorial!. This was one of the main things that I wanted to visit on my trip to Budapest. It is so simple yet very hard hitting and I am so glad I got to visit it. You must pay a visit here as its a valuable bit of history that everyone should see.
Must see. Must see place in Budapest, it is located next to Danube not so far from the building of Parliament, you can drink beer with many young people
Dignified, moving memorial. Dignified, moving memorial to the people who died here. No one seeing it can be unaffected by the emotion expressed by this.
A touching tribute to a dark history.. After learning the history that the memorial pays tribute to it is something that everyone should see.

A simple yet valuable memorial. A poignant memorial for those who were killed in the holocaust. For those who are unaware, the shoes represent those of the jews who refused to march and be transported to concentration camps. They were subsequently shot and their bodies pushed into the Danube, not before having their shoes taken off as they were valuable during this period. Brings some flowers or candles to place in the shoes or light. The bronze shoes look almost lifelike

A moving and important tribute. This is a moving tribute to the Budapest Jews who were murdered on the edge of the Danube during WWII. Don't miss it. However, the city could certainly do a better job of providing access to the monument and with explanations at the site. Read about the site in your guide book before visiting.
Moving memorial. Make sure you read up on the history behind this memorial to appreciate it. It's a short walk from the chain bridge just before parliament building.
Not an ordinary memorial. Incredibly moving memorial, really makes you stop and think. We came across it just by chance as we walked alongside the river.
Moving tribute. Try and read about the thoughts that made this memorial. It's quite moving when you see the shoes and think what happened here during the war. It's a short walk.
Very poignant. Brought home the terrible crimes against the Jewish community, so sad seeing the little children's shoes.
Very moving, but a must.. Very moving place to visit, it's a must. You cannot imagine what these owners of these shoes suffered. We must never forget.
Simple and powerful . A poignant reminder of the awfulness of some moments in European history and why keeping Europe together now is so important

Sad story of the Shoes. A little out of the way, but worth the stop. As you stand there in the quiet and look at the old shoes, your heart hurts for the Jews they represent. Although Hungary didn't have Jews sent to concentration camps, the end of Hitler's reign pushed the occupiers of Budapest to herd 400 Jews to the Danube and shoot them with arrows and push them into the river. Why?
Touching memorial with stunning views. This is a very simple but effective symbol of remembrance right on the River Danube. Worthy of a visit
promenade shoes. we were very moved by the shoe memorial such a simple memorial but it says so much about mans inhumanity

A dark day in the history of Budapest. The shoes memorial is very moving. It clearly illustrates the brutality of the Red Arrow..the group that persecuted the Jews during WW2. This group later joined the Russian terrorists.

A Must See : One of the Most Powerful Memorial of the Holocaust. These shoes bear witness to a past that cannot be forgotten.
This is a must see for every one visiting this beautiful city.
They help us remember the atrocities that were committed on the very banks of this scenic river.
There are no words strong enough to express the emotion they instill.

So moving!. This was a very emotional experience for me. Do,walk,around and see how the shoes were sculpted in terms as they were left as the Jewish residents were made to drown themselves in the river. It was especially upsetting in light of the last beautiful view they had of their,city. Do walk around and read the plaques as well.

Subtle but incredibly moving. This is a subtle memorial that you could almost miss except for the numbers of people gathered there. The brass shoes, so real looking, are artfully arranged to appear as if a group of people all decided to go swimming, But the somber tourists coupled with the small flowers next to some pairs makes it clear something very different happened there.
Moving. This is a subtle, but incredibly moving monument right next to the hustle and bustle of the city and along the beautiful danube. Plaques explaining the memorial are worth a read.

Sad yet beautiful. This memorial to those shot into the river is a very touching one. They have done it so effectively it does make you reflect what took place here. It is a great representation of the scale of those shot, men, women and children of all back grounds. Still to this day people like candles an lay flowers in remembrance of famiky members etc. They are located close to parliament. If you walk along the Danube past the chain bridge they are located just before you get to parliament definitely see this

Thought Provoking!. The Shoes on the Danube Bank is a memorial to honor the Jews who were killed by a certain fascist in World War 2. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. The memorial represents their shoes left behind on the bank. Its a must see for all people, especially visitors like us to get an understanding of the city's atmosphere 50 years ago
Check water levels. The first time I was here, there was a flooding of the Danube and these were all under water, so check the levels, but do make sure you see this.

Very powerful. This memorial speaks for itself (I think more then some modernistic Holocaust memorials we have seen in other European cities). It is not like visiting Auschwitz in Poland, but definitely a stark reminder of the tragic events.

Very moving. What really got the group was looking at the children's shoes and knowing that these kids were shot and thrown into the water. The group noted that the memorial was to the victims of the Holocaust, but never specifically mentioned the killing of the Jewish people.

Thought provoking memorial. 60 pairs of cast metal shoes to commemorate the 60th anniversary. It remembers those Jews who were stripped of their clothes and shoes, shot and dumped in the Danube. Very sad.

Moving Shoes Memorial on the Pest side of the Danube. A poignant memorial on the Pest side of the Danube River just about 100 meters past the Chain bridge when going towards the Houses of Parliament brings about a moving and emotional reminder of the victims of the Holocaust during the second world war. It represents the shoes of the Jews shot at the edge of the Danube by the fascist Arrow Militiamen in Budapest. A number of the original shoe sculptures has been stolen over the years, but quite a number still remains.

unique memorial. After visiting the Holocaust Memorial Center the Shoes Memorial is even more significant. In the memorial center there is a very informative explanation of the history of the period. The Shoes themselves are a heart breaking and dramatic testimony to the suffering of individuals and families

A brief pause to time while you stand here. It is a moving, thoughtful memorial to a terrible tragedy, and a reminder of an atrocity still within living memory that some people still seem determined to forget.

A moving memorial. Take a walk, near the parliament bldg, you'll notice the memorial along the banks of the Danube. There is a distinct hush among the crowds gathering to take pictures. A very moving tribute.
Touching and sad. I was shocked to find out about the history behind this monument. It's important not to forget about human cruelty in hope it will never be repeated.
Wow. Emotional. Take time to seek this out (on the Danube, just near the front of parliament. I just stood and reflected. 15 minutes in the early morning. Never forget what this memorial is about.
Stark reminder. This is a small tribute to the Jewish people who perished in the war. The description on the plaque says it all and reminds us of humanity at its worst

No words can express ..... how moving this memorial is. I found it almost too much to bear. This is not something you can rate "excellent" because it is borne out of so much suffering and heartache. If you need a "short, sharp, shock" as to how good your life is now - take a look at this, shed a tear, or several, and count yourself very lucky indeed.

Poignant living memorial. This is a small, artistic memorial to the Jews murdered by the fascist Arrow Cross Militia during World War II. I think it's unfair to judge it, as some reviewers have, for not being a big exhibit with a lot of signage - that is not its purpose. There are plaques in the pavement explaining its significance.The shoes are not full of "rubbish," but rather are treated as a living memorial by Budapest's active Jewish community. The candles, stones, ribbons, and other items are left as part of ongoing memorial practice.If you're looking for a big tourist attraction or museum or monument, this isn't it. It is a moving, thoughtful memorial to a terrible tragedy, and a reminder of an atrocity still within living memory that some people still seem determined to forget.

Touching reminder. This memorial touched my heart. It was sad but important to see. I recommend taking a few moments of silence here in remembrance of those who lost their lives, it's a sobering experience.

moving memorial. This memorial raises an awareness of what happened. The shoes look so real you would think they were leather and original. Very sad to know the cruel way the Jews were treated. A moving visit makes you reflect on the past
So sad. Was on river tour and passed theses shoes on the edge of Danube, the guide explained the reason behind them, Was so sad but interesting

A humbling experience. The shoes on the Danube Promenade are almost too easy to miss, as the Memorial is a very humble site. Yet, the shoes, which people have filled, for instance, with candles, are very powerful. Somehow the stone shoes make you think of the people who they could've belonged to. A very humbling experience.

Impressive. One of the most inspiring and moving memorials I've ever seen set in a beautiful location. A walk on the Danube promenade is definitely a must-do if you visit Budapest, it will only take a few minutes to stop and admire this beautiful monument which is also only a few meters away from the Parliament building. The memorial itself is wonderful, however I also loved and admired the items that visitors and relatives of the poor victims left upon visiting such as bunches of flowers, wreathes, candles, flags of Israel and even their own real shoes :)
Moving. Well worth a visit, if only for 15min. A very emotive piece of sculpture, and made us really think about how the Jews were treated during World War II.
Memorable. A very poignant reminder of some of the terrible things which happened during the war. I'm pleased we visited this memorial. It's just in front of Parliament so easy to find.

Powerful Statement. This is a must see along the Danube. This is where Nazis had Hungarian Jews take off their shoes and they shot them where the stood. The memorial has models of the various shoes along the riverbank and they are so life-like. A place to see, remember, contemplate and honor.

Sad and impressive. Danube shoes is one of the most impressive and saddest monuments I've ever seen. It will affect you deeply for sure. For a couple of minutes it seriously takes you to the scene of the WW2 and makes you feel this deep sorrow truly. It is located at the Pest side on the right side of the Chain Bridge (when you look at the river from the Pest side) very close to the parliament building. Before having fun in Budapest you should definitely see Danube shoes.

Very moving. A simple, but very moving experience. Just 300 metres from the parliament building on the shores of the Danube. We saw it by day and night and we preferred it at night, much more atmospheric and seemingly more meaningful. Still good by day but much busier, although not on a regular tourist route. A must if you visit Budapest. Read up on the history before your visit.

Holocaust Memorial. Holocaust Memorial , a memory , a place to remember the terrible tragedy of the Second World War, these are brass shoes, of men , women and children, randomly placed near the river, symbolism . Makes you think and remember.
Sadening. Get the story before you go.The actual brass sculptures are not kept clean which is a shame - a lot of rubbish around when we visited

historical. 1/4 of the Jews died at the concentration camp during WWII were from Budapest. After the Nazi came to Budapest, more were executed along the Danube River. BUt because shoes were very expensive, they asked people to put their other valuables inside of the shoes and then were pushed into the River. So the shoes are the commemoration of those who lost their lives there.
Very powerful memorial. This is a beautiful concept that really makes you think. Make sure you read up on the history first, so you understand exactly what you are looking at!

A touching reminder of the not so distant past. We visited this site as part of a Jewish Heritage Tour sponsored by AMAWaterways. It was a short walk from the bus parking area. Our guide provided the historical context for the site and it is a very powerful memorial that is not to be missed. If you go on your own, do a little web research ahead of time to properly appreciate the events that this site memorializes.
Shoes. Something to think about. Second best holocaust memorial I've seen. Really makes you think what happened to people...
it looks real.... It was appeared unexpectedly on our way along the river and we could gess why it was there -long line of people memories. Touching deeply

A few shoes with a big story. The story behind this Memorial on the Danube is very fun provoking and silvering. Made to commemorate the souls who were around it up on a winter's night, shot and thrown into the river by Nazi sympathizers. I hope that the city doesn't let this memorial deteriorate anymore than it already has.

don't miss. A very strong memorial site. a must see for anyone visiting the area. I couldn't see an explanation about it in the site (it was very crowded with a large group) so read a bit about it before you go there.The strongest part was the little shoes of a small kid with his parents shoes beside. don't miss it.

Great memorial. It is a moving memorial to view. It gives you a feeling that you do not get talking about it. Its something that you should see if you are going to go there. Would recommend this. Its not something that will take you awhile to see, and its not a big memorial, but moving. Makes you think.
always remember. To think that so many died because of hatred and this was done by the fascist citizens, not the Germans. I will always remember this graphic display. See it for yourself.

Simple, effective and thought provoking.. A place to pause and reflect on some of the relatively more recent history of this city. Using this imagery is a simple but powerful reminder of past events and taken as a piece art it is well executed. Some of the shoes/boots contain tea-lights and flowers.

walk along the path .. The shoes on the Danube is a memorial to the Budapest jews who were shot by arrow militiamen between 1944 and 1945. The victims were lined up and shot into the danube river, they had to take their shoes off, since shoes were valuable belongings at the time. Interesting history and when i visited it was some kind of anniversary so they had people making paper boats, lighting candles and sending it off the river with their prayers . It was so beautiful and emotional at the same time to see the Hungarians remembering their ancestors.Its a must to walk along the rivers, sit there for sometime and just enjoy the scenery . The chain river connecting two Cities :)

Unplanned and unforgettable. As we walked along the Danube my eyes focused on this memorial and my brain searched for a reason that shoes would be left along the river. The subtle vision was no longer simple once I realized that it was a memorial. This was a meaningful and memorable tribute that should not be missed. The vision of the children's shoes has not left me.

Shoes that tell a story. Man's inhumanity to man is beautifully and artistically presented by these bronze shoes lining the Pest side of the Danube River promenade. The many pairs of shoes are worn looking mens, womens and little childrens shoes. It compells one to ask the question, "What is this about and why are they here"?. For those who do are unaware, it graphically tells the story of the Nazi SS Comandos, who during WW II, one night, rounded up the Jewish people of Budapest, lined them up alongside the Danube, ordered them to remove their shoes, and then proceeded to shoot them like target practice, causing their dead bodies to fall and float downriver. This is one of the most moving Holocaust memorials in Europe. When in Budapest, in addition to the weeping willow tree memorial at the Doheny Synagogue it is a "must see". It is a strong reminder of the senseless consequences of hatred, anti-semitism and ignorance. It appeals to us to exercise tolerance and human kindness. goodness
Small but sobering.. The memorial honours Jews who fell into the river after being lined up along the river bank and shot. Just a small World War II memorial but worth the walk along the esplanade.

A Moving Visit. We went to see this not really know what it represented.I found the memorial very unique and moving.It's just a shame that there isn't a sign or something explaining the meaning behind the shoes.
A moving tribute. A moving tribute to the Jews who were murdered on the west side of the Danube by the Arrow Cross Militia.

Emotions!. One of the top emotional monument I have ever seen. I stood on the corner and started thinking about the story of those shoes holders. Of course you won't miss it when walking across Danube river in to the Budapest, but if you read the story first, I think would be better.
shocking memorial on the eastern riverside. Thoughtful memento near Chainbridge for those thousands of mainly jewish people, who were shot into the Danube in 1944

too hidden away but very touching monument. this delicate and powerful monument is worth stopping by and reading about since it said nothing on the spot besides the artist but this is a memorial for hundreds of thousands of people murdered during the second world war - Holocaust Jews and others shot and thrown into the Danube. worth stopping by and learning more so we never forget...

Chilling. The memorial is just a short walk from Parliament, and well worth it. Some people were quite disrespectful (maybe they are unaware of the meaning behind the memorial?) but I was very impressed by the installment.
Simple and Solemn Tribute to World War II Victims. The shoes are a simple and solemn tribute to the poor unnamed souls who lost their lives on the Danube at this spot.

Sadness. As we roamed around the city on our first night we came upon the shoes placed on the cement embankment along the Danube. I had heard about this memorial to the victims of the Nazi's. You will see all sizes of shoes, but when you come upon the shoes of little children the horror of it all is overwhelming.

Very moving. The metal shoes (60 pairs)add up to a very moving memorial. In memory of the victims during the 2nd world war who were shot into the Danube but had to leave their footwear behind. Worth a visit.
Moving. Our only disappointment was that the shoes were behind a 10 foot fence put up for the redbull Airshow. We would have liked to experience differently.

Impressive memorial. The shoes along the Dunabe remind everyone about the horrors of Holocaust. People are gone, disappeared in the Danube, but their shoes are a constant reminder of our tragic history. This memorial is very similar to the one in Moscow, showing people going to the fire and leaving their clothes behind. Scare scenes both here and there. Will never forget.
Incredibly strong!. This is probably one of the strongest memorial of all, in all its silent beauty. The sight of all the empty shoes makes the cruel murdering so tangible. I will never forget it.
Very touching memorial. Based on the riverbank behind the parliament building, a wide variety of bronze shoes in memory of the Hungarians shot into the river during the second war. Very moving

Very sobering. This give you pause for thought and brings home the suffering endured by so many people. Very emotive.Easy to find, about 10 min stroll from the chain bridge on the Pest side, almost opposite parliament building.Well worth a stroll along the river after you've done Castle hill. Just walk across chain bridge & turn lefy, keep walking till you see the shoes.

Bronze shoes. These shoes are on the bank of Danube River on the Pest Side, 300 metres south of the Parlament. During world war 2 the Jews were ordered to take of their shoes, then they were shot and their bodies fell in the river.

Pause to reflect on who might have worn those very shoes.. A must visit site along the Danube. A touching memorial to victims of the Holocaust along the Danube literally in the shadows of the breathtaking Parliament Building. As you view each set of shoes, you pause to reflect on who might have worn those very shoes.

A somber memorial. A friend told me about this memorial to the Jews who died in Hungary. It is right by the parliament building and is worth taking some time to see. All the different shoes are very thought provoking.
A must when you are in Budapest. This is a must see when in Budapest. Easy to find, more or less in front of the Parliament building on the riverside. An excellent, suitably simple memorial
A must see - very eye opening. A real experience to see all the shoes and be able to understand the story behind them. I would definitely recommend visiting these as it truly is eye opening.

Simple, Yet Haunting. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial is not a grand display. That's what makes it so moving. The simple theme of shoes remaining from the victims of the Holocaust is touching. The memorial is very close to the parliament building and is worth the short walk.

You can feel multiple things by watching this monument!. It's a nice place to go and see, feel the history and understand some things about Budapest.. Go there and take some pictures of this srange shoes and enjoy the silence for a while..

Views Amazing but Terrible History!. The views along the Danube are amazing and well worth a stroll along the banks on either side of the river. However, the history regarding this area of the river bank is horrible.It was towards the end of the 2nd World War and a large number of Jews were rounded up and herded down to the river and lined up on the edge and stripped naked .they were then shot in the back so they fell in the river and were washed away. The shoe sculptures on the bank "Pest" represent what was left as a memorial of this terrible crime....very moving.
Must see. Very interesting and sad. We went from the parlament building on the Danube and saw the shoes. Inside people put lights and flowers. Everyone took pictures and it was silent no talking.u
Heart wrenching. the area was filled with other photographer, but it is worth seeing this sad, sad display from the grim past if Hungary,
Shoes on the Danube haunts.. Haunting, depressing and terrible what was done here. At least someone is taking responsibility for the past.

Be sure to take a look. A moving memorial this is certainly worth a stop whilst in Budapest and is just a short walk on the river to the left of the Parliament. We were in Budapest during the red bull air show so could not quite reach the river bank but was still more than worth going to see.

Thought provoking memorial. If you are visiting Parliament during your trip to Budapest, then you should definitely take the time to visit this thought provoking memorial along the banks of the Danube towards the Chain Bridge.The simplicity of the random collection of abandoned shoes somehow makes it all the more poignant. Some in neat pairs, most just an odd assortment, in all sizes and styles from young children to high heeled 'Sunday best' and tatty work boots, the bronze casts are eerily realistic. Some are filled with flowers and stones.The memorial is unmarked, but there is a respectful ,reflective atmosphere and a few seats for those who want to stay a bit longer and remember.

Novel Memorial to a darker time of the 20th Century. 60 pairs of shoes to commemorate those killed by the fascist Arrow Cross militia in 1945. A poignant reminder of the history of the second world war, and the atrocities that went on.
a must. I first saw these on a windy May day in 2014. The most simple but moving memorial I have ever seen. Try early morning or late afternoon to avoid crowds.
Shoes on the Danube. It was a very emotional and heart wrenching experience to imagine hundreds of Jews shot and thrown into the river from this place.

Very moving memorial.. A display of bronze shoes along the Danube river where Jews were shot. The shows are of different sizes, some clearly being childeren's sizes. They are filled with memorial candles and stones left there by visitors in memory of the victims. A must.

A sad memorial men's inhumanity. It's not sign posted, you come upon it walking along he bank of the Danube. It's a low key memorial to those Jews killed by shooting them into the Danube around the last few months of WWII by the Hungarian Nazis - not the Germans.

Fitting Memorial. Poignant remembrance of Jews murdered by Nazis at the Danube River. Incredible testimony to Nazi brutality. Poignant remembrance of Jews murdered by Nazis at the Danube River. Incredible testimony to Nazi brutality

Airshow Took Away from the Experience. I'd wanted to go to this memorial since deciding to come to Budapest. When we went, there was an airshow going on so they had the memorial fenced off. I can appreciate that they did. I stood on the other side of the fence and looked through. I got some descent photos but I didn't get to experience the memorial for what it is. It was a carnival type atmosphere with the airshow going on. Maybe next time it will be a bit more peaceful.
Needs more info. Very moving but could have had more explanation of what lead to these people being shot and who they were

A modest but poignant memorial.. This memorial was definitely on our must-see list. We walked along the Danube promenade past Parliament House, the shoes are between there and the Chain Bridge. Not much info there, yet still a nice place to appreciate and reflect what the shoes represent

Brief Tour. This sight can be seen from the Danube tour boat but I would suggest actually going to see these shoes up close and in person. These are located right by the Parliment Building, along the river.
An unnerving sight. Shoes are displayed on the banks of the Danube River. It was here that the Nazi shot Jews so that they would fall into the river. They left their shoes behind.

Simply Shocking. This memorial is stark in its simplicity. It commemorates the murder by shooting and drowning of some of Budapest's Jews. It is a story told elsewhere that does not need repetition here. The memorial has no narrative: no inscription. Yet it is deeply evocative. A simple array of shoes on the bank of the river recalls the horror of the murders. To me, it evokes irresistibly those other heaps of shoes, spectacles, suitcases and all the other detritus of human misery that marked the Death Camps. The monument is located slightly down-stream from the parliament building beside the No2 tramtrack. It deserves a moment or two of silence and "the passing tribute of a sigh."
Cool tourist spot. A nice place at the side of the river. It was good to get some photos there. There are plenty of restaurants nearby and boat tours on the river are available.

simple yet moving. this memorial is simple yet powerful, it is located just in front of the Parliament building with little advertisement or fanfare yet was one of the most memorable things we saw in Budapest.

Only if you're already in the area. The memorial marks a solemn time of oppression and injustice. The shoes represent people shot out the shoes and into the Danube for being the wrong race. A creative way to remember them, of course, but the memorial is not kept up or well-marked with signage. If you're in the area, cross the street and pause to remember the victims. If not, other more noteworthy memorials and museums are available in Budapest.As far as taking children....this memorial is set on the sidewalk above the Danube with no fence or guardrail. Steps down to the water are also nearby. Keep this in mind when taking little ones.
Very moving. We may never forget what happened in history and what we are all capable of. It's a bit of a search, but it's on the banks of the Danube just beyond the Houses of Parliament.
Extremely moving. Very moving tribute to those executed during occupation of this lovely city. Seeing the shoes displayed and the realization of what that means is striking to first time visitors.

Touching. Simple and good. We stopped because of all the shoes and found it very emotional when we understood what the memorial were about. Sad to see pieces of junk that people put in some of the shoes.

Poignant reminder..... I found this so moving.
Here we are on a fabulous trip and yet here we are where such dreadful atrocities occurred.
You cannot help but be moved.

A sad reminder. This had personal meaning for me...a friend from home was lined up along the Danube with her other and sister; they were spared from being shot. I could almost feel her standing with me telling me her survival story. I was surprised that the memorial is not labeled...it is just there and could be missed.

Poignant and breathtaking. Incredibly poignant. There is not a lot you can say when you see this lasting reminder of the unnecessary cruelty inflicted upon innocent people persecuted because of fear and ignorance.
Moving tribute. This is a moving tribute to a terrible time in history. A very simple monument. Too bad some people put trash into the shoes. Walk along the shore of the Danube towrad parliament.
Easy to see. It is very touching memorial, and is well worth the walk along the River. There are several personal memorials along each set of shoes and candles are lit at night.

Rich history. The history of why these shoes are here is just sad to think about. It wasn't that long ago that these were real people's shoes and real people that were thrown over. The display is just amazing!!
Very Moving. A touching reminder that though the war has been over for over 70 years........Jews are still not fully embraced here.
Moving memorial. It's not well marked or large, but very moving. Please make sure to stop and spend some time on the banks of the Danube and see this memorial.

Visitor. This was a very moving experience walking along hte Danube viewing this amazing display and tribute to the ones who lost their lives during the holicost. Take time to conteplate what the true meaning of this memorial represents. It was interesting to note how many local people gathered along these banks.

Very moving. A very sad tribute to those killed during the Holocaust. At first I thought the shoes were real until I got close. They are permanently attached....men's, woman's and children's. Never forget!

Creative memorial. Don't know why people had a hard time finding this memorial. It is located right on the Pest side of the Danube, on the bank just south of the Parliament building. It's a nice addition to the bank.

I was filled with emotion when I heard the story behind the shoes.. This is one of those uncomplicated monuments that has so much feeling that when I heard the story behind those shoes, it became one of the most poignant experiences on this trip. These shoes represent the people who were shot on this spot and thrown in the Danube.

Harsh Reality. This memorial gives one cause to think about how inhumane man can be to his fellow man. The bronzed shoes of different sizes make one think of how cruel it was to line up mothers and children along he riverbank before executing them
Sobering, must-see.. Fantastic, moving experience. Must see.Very sobering experience but please be respectful when taking photos i.e do NOT lay on the floor and take photos next to a shoe.

Very emotional, not to be missed. Missed this memorial on our last visit but so worth going to see. On the bank of the river near the parliament building.
A memorial to the Hungarian Jews who has to take their shoes off and who were then shot and fell into the river during WW2

Prominent commemoration!. Located just outside the Parliament building, this memorial deserves everyone's attention, both for what it commemorates but also for the artistic sensitivity that has gone into creating it. We accessed it by walking from Castle Hill, towards Margaret Island, crossing Margaret Bridge and walking back towards Parliament. It was an enjoyable walk and a peaceful spot to reflect on humanity!

Shoes on the Danube. This is confronting and the story shocking. Sad to see very small shoes lined up Hungary has had a sad historyof war and communism but the people are trying so hard and are succeeding
Moving tribute. Worth a visit but would recommend reading a bit of the history behind the memorial before going there, lots of candles and flowers left there.

Thought Provoking. This is a truly simple tribute to those who lost their lives during the second world war. As others have said the memories it provokes has a strong effect. It can be difficult to locate though as not all guide books mention this memorial for some reason but head to the Parliament Buildings and as long as you are by the river you will find it. There are no candles to be bought at the site so if you want to light one then you will need to take your own,

Worth a look and a photo. All sorts of shoes from baby shoes to adults. Very moving when you know the story behind it. It is on the edge of the river just along from the chain bridge. Check out the history before you visit it so that it is more meaningful.

Extremely poignant. This is not publicized and it took a bit of time to find it. The shoes of men, women and children are bronzed on the riverbank and as is custom amongst Jews (we were told) small stones and pebbles were placed in them. No dry eyes.
Shoes on the Danube. A must see. Very moving- learn the history before you visit. Takes a few minutes to see but stays with you for a very long time!
Shoes of memory . History and memory is fine, the view from here is price less. Excellent place to spend an evening along the banks of Danube.

A chilling reminder to the cruelty of mankind. This unique memorial made by sculptor Gyula Pauer , so dimunitve, has a very strong effect. You see just about 40 pairs of shoes, old style (from about 1940) made of iron. Those symbolise the pairs of shoes that the Jews were ordered to leave on the edge of the Danube before being shot by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45 and die falling into the Danube.
Sad. It is a sad reminder of how cruel people can be. And also a great reminder that civilization can not go back to intolerance and hatred
Thought provoking. A very simple but meaningful display that causes you to pause and face the reality of those who suffered during those terrible years.
Humbling. Spare a moment for those the city has lost. A moment of calm in a busy day.It's not quite where the maps puts it but walk along the river and you'll find it.
An interesting way to deal with the recent history. Showing the shoes without the owners of these shoes is a very interesting approach to the darkest part of the recent history.
Touching. When you are taking a walk on the margins of the Danube, this memorial to the Jews may come to you. Is very simple, powerful and moving.

Special impression. I had read about it, but suddenly saw it on a walking tour. It's a meaningful peace of art, which makes you think about mistakes of the past and how terrible that should have been.

If you are near by, take a look. This memorial is a reminder of those who lost their lives because the state decided they were a danger to society. It should also serve as a reminder to us that hate has no place in our society. if you are near by then go and have a look, it is a small but poinent memorial and worth visit.

This is a heart wrenching display of what happened in Jewish history.. This is a must see to totally grasp the horrific war crimes and cruelty that the Jews endured. It is somber but necessary to see.

Poignant. As you wander along the banks of the Danube you may come across this understated, small monument to the Jews killed by the nazis on the banks of the danubes. The empty shoes are a quiet reminder of lives lost and the heavy cost of war.
Powerful memorial. A free exhibit that commemorates the murder of Jews along the Danube. Very moving and self explanatory visual exhibit.

Very Moving. I have visited many Holocaust sites in Germany and Poland, and the bronzed shoes of Jewish victims placed on the banks of the Danube is as moving as any memorial. It was here that men, women, and children removed their shoes before they were shot by the Nazis and their bodies pushed into the Danube. This is a simple, yet highly effective and artistic memorial.

Holocaust memorial. Unique river-side memorial to Holocaust - 50 pair of metalicized shoes at site where Nazis in early 1945 shot victims who fell into the Danube. located about 300 meters from Chain Bridge on Pest side (but difficult to get too because of traffic patterns)

Poignant and So Sad But It Should Be Seen. During the Holocaust Jews were lined up here and shot so that their bodies would fall into the Danube. Because shoes were so precious at this time they were removed before execution. This memorial is a recreation of the actual shoes, placed along the walkway of the river. It gives you chills.

Moving memorial. An iconic memorial, despite being unwell on the day, I wanted to visit the Shoes on the Danube on our last day in Budapest. It was a short walk along the river and on an early misty morning it was atmospheric and touching to see in person.I was only disappointed at the limited directions to get there, and at the lack of information at the actual memorial. Most of what I knew about it was what I had searched for on the internet before & after.

Powerful. There is no admittance fee or special route to the place as this is bronze installation spread along the coast of Danube easily catchable while strolling through the areas. Many are seen paying homage while others taking amble pictures. The story and the history behind these installations are very touching and is also a tragic part of the history.
Very Moving Sight. The story of the "shoes" is one of the more moving/emotional of the holocaust story. It is worth the walk to see.

eye opening. a must see with a deep and soulful meaning. once you realised people where lined up and killed here by the Nazis you have a very different idea on the sculptures. The river suddenly becomes more of a place of memorial.

Stop here as you stroll the along the Danube. The river walk along the Danube is beautiful and this memorial also makes it poignant. If you have a travel guide ( I used Rick Steves') it will explain the significance of the shoes. This is a ten minute stop but a good reminder of how many countries were affected by the holocaust.

A moment to reflect. Sit for a moment and reflect on the fact that of the 600,000 Jews deported from Hungary, 300,000 Jews were sent from Budapest to Auschwitz during the final weeks of the war. Several thousand were killed and fell into the Danube at this spot. This memorial is a poignant symbol of what happened to real people during the Holocaust.

Striking and sobering. Budapest is full of gorgeous public sculptures, all of which I loved, but the "Shoes on the Danube" holocaust memorial was by far my favorite. It is a beautiful, fitting and chilling memorial to all who lost their lives so brutally. I visited at dusk as the city started to light up and the Danube looked calm and pretty.

Shoes on the Danube Bank. Very sad memory of the persecution of the Jewish population that were rounded up,shot and pushed into the Danube.Congratulaions to the Artist and City of Budapest to immortalize this horrific event that surely is a constant reminder of never again.....but it still happening in other parts of the world now.Worth walking along the Danube from the Parliament to view this great work of art despite the history.

Emotional !!!. How do we explain this memorial ?? SO much emotions surface when you observe the simple but HUGE impact that a few pairs of "everyday" shoes can extract from a person... stand there and just observe... think what "man" can and did do to his fellow "man".. and you will NEVER forget what they have done !! I won't........ EVER AGAIN........
Sad but must see. Read up a little about this site before you visit. The memorial candles and flowers in the shoes will take on a different meaning.

Very moving memorial. This is a very moving memorial to the Jewish men, women, and children who were killed here. It is a place to sit and reflect on this sad and horrible part of history.
The memorial is easy to find by taking the yellow 2 tram or the red subway line to the Parliament stop.
Pause for thought . Just a five minute walk from the Chain Bridge towards Parliament is this moving memorial. A moving memorial to stop for a while and reflect.

Poignant and memorable. These shoes along the Danube are in memory of those Jewish victims, taken to the riverbank and then executed. May we never forget how cruel we are capable of becoming to one another. This memorial was deeply moving for us.
Moving. This is a very moving and original memorial for the Jews who were killed here. However, the sign does not mention that the victims were Jewish.

A VERY MOVING MONUMENT. I knew we were close to the location on the Danube riverfront & had seen photos of these sculptures, but I was talking to my friend, distracted, and then suddenly we came upon them. So the impact was shocking, as if the event memorialized had just transpired. Powerful.
