a true reflection of history. Shoes of men women and children which are made from copper, line up along the river in memory of the jewish people who were shot at this point into the river. Some shoes also have candles in them to light in memory.

Brought me to tears. This very poignant and touching memorial is one of the things I will remember most about Budapest. It honours the memory of the Jews who were shot and tossed into the river by the Nazi's. They were forced to remove their shoes before being killed because shoes were expensive. It is a lovely tribute and something everyone should see while visiting the beautiful city of Budapest.

Thought provoking and sombre. This simple poignant set of small shoe sculptures is heavily symbolic of the genocide during the Holocaust. It reminds you of the cruelty of man to his fellow beings. And it is a reminder that this should never happen again.

It's the lost souls that matter. This is one of numerous street installations in Budapest honoring significant events or people in the city's history.As a unique memorial to the many who were slain on this spot, it is a simple and poignant provocation for us all.You do need to read up on the details, though, because there is no plaque on location.

Melts your heart. Upon seeing these shoes along the River Danube, I could not help it but was very emotional reflecting on how the Jews went through their ordeal. It is very significant in human history of how mankind could be so cruel to another.
Very moving and sad. It made me cry to think of all the souls and the anguish of knowing you were going to die. This memorial is as touching as any could be

History in real life. This is the real life history, in some how its interesting and in a mother hand it's so terrible to just stay there and see where innocent people was killed
without any resent. It's so real and you can almost feel how it was when they stay there and waited for the shoot.

Shoes. We came across this after visiting the parliament building, and whilst the story behind this is very poignant the monument itself seemed a little lost...
Worth a look to pay your respects but in all honesty add it to something else you plan to do that day.

Very somber experience. This is a very heart wrenching and somber experience but a must visit. The empty bronzed shoes bring reality starkly into focus about the immense human toll of the Holocaust.Stay, linger leave a stone or flowers, light candle or say a prayer. The location is a short walk down the river from the Parliament so do not miss this when so close.

very moving. This exhibit is very moving. The shoes have been metallized and are on the side of the Danube just as if their owners stepped out of them. They were worn and sometimes in pairs, sometimes alone. It is too bad there was no explanation. However, they were filled with little rocks and candles from people who came to remember that Hungary killed a lot of Jews.

Interesting & sad. we went looking for this place & was quite sad looking at them. Very close to the parliament on the bank of the river .many tourist come to see it ,many locals don't have a clue ,we asked for directions from two individuals they were clueless . It's a nice memorial to the Jews that were killed during the 2 nd world war ,but there are several other stories about it too .
Striking memorial . In memory of the Jews who were shot on the Danube banks. I found it very emotional. I read about the place before I went on holiday and am glad I visited.
Monuments of Budapest . The shoes on the bank of the Danube is a beautiful, effective and simple tribute to Jews killed in world war II.

Interesting display. I chanced upon the rows of shoes by the Danube one evening and found the display interesting and after I read about it did I realize how it tells a horrific story in such a simple manner. It is worth a visit for sure
Haunting Memorial. Amazing how images of shoes can evoke feelings of incredible sadness. Fortunately or unfortunately, people are using the shoes to burn candles in or to leave flowers in.

Somber experience.. A friend told us about this memorial and we wanted to make sure we found it. If you walk along the Danube north of the chain briidge on the way to Parliiment, you will happen across the Shoes on the Danube. These represent the shoes of people shot in WWII and dumped in the Danube. It is a very somber experience to see. Very humbling to remember some of the atrocities during WWII.

Tribute to the People who were shot and Killed. This moving memorial sits at the foot of the Danube. It is for the people who were killed and bodies landed in the river. Very sad sight but an important time in history. Lest we not forget that Hungary was the beginning of Anti-Semitism, not Germany. It took this trip for us to understand this.
Touching your heart. There is not much to write about -you must see it and the feeling will come to you and get you-it doesn't allow you just leave without feeling despair and a bit of sorrow...

This is a very Moving Memorial.. When we look at this memorial, cold shivers went through our bodies.Such a simple construction, rows of shoes different sizes and Genders. BUT OH MY WHAT A MOVING AND THOUGHT PROVOKING MEMORIAL.!!!!!!

Stirring reminder. A small, but moving memoir to the human sacrifices that the city saw during the second World War. It is just a couple of steps away from the Parliament, on the Pest side of the city. Must visit to pay tribute.

Shoes on the Danube. Pity the memorial doesn't refer to the fact that the victims were Jews who were murdered after the war was ended and the Ghetto was liberated .They were murdered by members ( Hungarian Militia )Arrow CrossTherefore guide make up a fictitious story

A curious memorial that speaks loud. Once more I chanced upon something strange, yet fascinating. A collection of cast metal shoes on the edge of the Danube. After a few bemused exchanges I discovered that these symbolised many Hungarian Jews massacred by Hungarian Nazis in the last days of the War. First removing their shoes, to what end I know not, the Nazis then threw the Jews into the freezing Danube whence they perished. The memorial remains a moving remembrance of those who came within an inch of surviving the terrors of those times.

Very moving memorial. We read about this unusual memorial, so were keen to see it. The metal sculptures of various shoes, from WW2 era, realistically depicted the styles of the time, and the broad range of ages of Jewish people who lost their lives at the water's edge. A truly moving memorial to remind us of a tragic time in the history of this beautiful city.

Though Provocking. Poignant display of shoes left from Jewish citizens murdered in Budapest during WW2. Caught peoples attention as they walked past. Close to the Parliament building so can combine the visits.

Moving but not sure it's enhanced by trinkets . We visited by arriving on a river taxi (part of our hop on hop off bus ticket) which stops just outside the Parliament building and 50 yds from the shoes.This was on our list of must see items whilst in Budapest & there is no doubt it's an incredibly vivid tribute to those who died on the Riverbank & as a piece of dramatic art its exceptionally well done. Our only discussion point was over whether the trinkets, candles & ribbons, albeit we understood why people put them there, somehow spoilt it & made it look tacky. Wonder if it should have been preserved as originally designed.
Very poignant reminder. Simple but powerful reminder of events that happened in World War II. Simple but powerful. Makes you think about what targeted people went through in the war.

Very moving site. Toward the end of WWII, shortly before the Soviet army liberated Budapest, the Hungarian Nazis captured a few hundred jews who had been hidden by local churches. The Nazis tied them together, took off their shoes and threw them into the freezing Danube river, where all perished. Today, there is very moving memorial to these souls consisting a collection of shoes (made in metal) set along the edge of the bank of the Danube. It is worth a few minutes during your tour to stop and experience the shoes and what they mean.

A place for silent reflection. A quiet place on the quayside to stop and ponder the atrocities that mankind has carried out during times of conflict and war.An unusual but very fitting memorial to those who were killed.

Nice Memorial, but very small. The experience of walking along the Danube in Budapest is amazing. You will come across many great sites such as Parliament, Gresham Palace, Chain Bridge, etc. If you blink, you may miss the Shoes on the Danube memorial. I expected a large memorial. However, the site was very nice. I will say the memorial with all of the shoes lined up on the Danube makes you think about all of the countless victims of the Holocaust. It is way worth it to pay your respects and visit.

Hardly worthy to be the 4th top site to see in Budapest but still interesting. The atrocities inflicted on the Jews of Hungary are not well known. Aside from the Nazis, the Hungarians were a close second on the evil list. This memorial is the site were Jews were thrown into the freezing Danube river to be killed. Amongst the shoes are baby shoes which is very moving. There is nothing really here except for bronzed shoes attached to the walkway. If you weren't paying attention, you could pass right by it without noticing it. Our river cruise was docked just a few steps from this memorial so we saw it. It is very close to the Parliament building as well. Hungary does a pretty good job to try to forget about the Holocaust. This little memorial is one of a few scattered reminders of Hungary's dark past. Certainly worth stopping by and taking in the enormity of evil that took place at that very spot.

Solemn Monument to one of the world's worst calamities. This is located between the chain Bridge and the Parliament on the Pest side of the Danube, and it is a solemn monument to those that were killed and threw to the river in 1944 and 45, I think that words are not needed to explain what a moving monument this is. My recommendation is to take an hour to walk along the river from the Parliament to the Chain Bridge and visit the exhibition.
The silence said it all. Well worth visiting especially when you realise that the shoes represent those of the unfortunate Jews who were shot and then fell into the river.
Simple and profound memorial. Would recommend a visit to the memorial, it is simple but profound. Easy to get to as it right in front of the parliament building.
A touching memorial. Cannot say much about it, as the shoes speak for themselves and for the people who suffered indescribable injustice. Beautiful and touching memorial. Take a moment there.
Big impression. This is a simple memorial that give big impressions.It's at the riverbank in front of the parlament.

Sad..... This is a quite moving memorial dedicated to the poor people who were shot and their bodies left to fall into the river to float away.....it would be nice it it could be maintained and the old candles removed...

Very moving / somber exhibit. It only takes a few minutes to see this memorial but it is worth it...as it makes you reflect on what happened. The shoes vary from adult to baby...so very sad to think about. It is on the edge of the Danube and very easy to miss. It is on the same side as the Pariliament building. Make sure you know the exact location before you go so you don't miss it.

Needs to be cleaned. This is a very moving installation however there was so much rubbish around the shoes it was quite off putting. Surely the old candles and dead flowers etc could be cleaned up every day? This was detrimental to the moving experience provided by the shoes and their historical significance.

EMOTIONAL MEMORIAL. A must for all visitors to the city. Sculptures of shoes made from metal placed along the edge of the Danube to commemorate the deaths of jewish people who were shot from behind and their bodies allowed to fall into the Danube. However, before being shot they were told to remove their shoes as these could be sold.
Emotional memorial. This is a simple but very powerful memorial to all the victims of the brutality which occurred at the Danube river during WWII.

Found this by accident. we had read about this and said we wanted to visit it but hadn't planned it into out short trip. we were walking along the river from chain bridge to the parliament buildings. Very humbling to see especially when you now something of the history behind it!

Simply very moving .. This art work is situated on the promenades not the Danube near to the Parilment building.Very much worth your time to visit this sad side of Budapests history of the Jewish people that had their lives sacrificed in the Danube during WWII.We was lucky to get there and no one was there, and it was a peaceful time to collected feelings and appreciate this soulful peace of art.
A poignant way to rememer. Having read about this piece before travelling we particularly wanted to see. It's a simple reminder of a terrible event I found it very moving
One of the most tragic holocaust memorials of Budapest!. Brass shoes on the bank of the river Danube, on the Pest side, dedicated to those who had been shot to the river during the second world war.

A verry interesting monument. It is a terrible reminder of the horrow of the seconde world war. It is a statue that shows all kind of shoes ; children's women's and other shoes of people who was thrown to the river during the war.

Poignant and thought provoking. Close to the Parliament building this monument to the Jews that were shot into the river during ww2 is a subtle reminder of what happened. Worth a visit as you'll probably be near by at somepoint in your visit to Budapest.

Poignant and beautiful piece of art. This can be found close to the Parliament building and can be factored into a walk along the river front to between the two bridges on either side. The shoes seemed to be very popular with tourists when I was there with everyone taking photos. If you're lucky enough you might be there on your own to enjoy them in peace and quiet and reflect on what these shoes represent as we'll as admire them for their simple beauty.
Never forget. Very moving, but not enough information onsite. Had to research before and after visit. It is a walk, so do not expect public transport nearby..
Very Moving. . Very simple memorial, yet deeply touching. How such savagery can be carried out amidst such beauty is incredible. Well worth a visit.
History. This was a somber site, but well worth the visit. I had read about it and we are glad we took the walk to get there. If you enjoy history, don't miss this as there is much impact.
Amazing memorial. As sad the reason is for the shoes to be there as well done it is. It shows you don´t need big to remind people of bad things done but just emotional and thought through.
Moving simplicity . Moving simple memorial to hundreds of Jews who were simply shot on the banks of the Danube by the Hungarian Nazi government, rather than shipping them to concentration camps.

Touching Tribute. These shoes on the Danube evokes so much emotion, remembering that horrible time for the Jewish people. The simplicity and profoundness is amazing. This is a must see while touring Budapest.

Who would have thought?. Such a simple yet moving memorial. Who would have thought that bronzing shoes on the river bank would be a memorial to the ones who died there? Find out the backstory and you'll certainly be moved!

Poinient memorial for WWII. Very simple yet effective memorial to those who were killed. Amazing how many people walk past or don't understand what it represents. Then again there isn't an explanation as to what it actually represents so is easy to miss. Worth a walk down the promenade anyway and a nice place to stop and think.

A "must see" memorial..... More and more visitors are coming to Budapest recently. I am proposing them something different from those sights which can be seen from the board of Hop on - Hop off buses. It needs some walk and entering into the history, too. While you are approaching this memento of those Jewish people, who were shot straight into the icy water of the Danube in 1944-1945 you can have an immagination of "missing someone". Yes, we miss them, who had weared these shoes, boots and sandals...Shalom to all of them, forever...
Vert simple but very moving. Just down from the Parliament building, right on the river side, you will find this very simple but moving memorial. Well worth a visit
A moving memorial. A very moving and beautifully done memorial, remembering the Jews who were killed during the Holocaust.

Moving memorial to inglorious history. A short walk from the Parliament, this was a very moving site on the shore of the Danube. There were no markers to indicate what we were looking at, but we had read about the memorial and no words were necessary to describe what we saw.
moveing. I thought it was very moving to see the shoes...especially the children's shoes. When you are near Parliament, just walk down to the edge of the Danube to see it.
Sad statement. A grim reminder of WWII but you must see this, also a must see is the Museum of TERROR, an excellent history of Budapest during the war.

Shoes on the Danube. A little tricky to get to but very understated, moving Holocaust Memorial. I cannot imagine the terror of lining up waiting to be shot. A terrible time in the History of Mankind..

nightwalk. My students were exhausted, though they asked for a nightwalk in Budapest. It was worth enduring their moanings all through the walk because when we arrived they were speechless. They still mention the spot.

Stirs the Emotions. Subtle and not that easy to pick out, the group of bronzed shoes is at the edge of the Danube between Parliament and the chain bridge. Having visited the Jewish Museum, the pain felt by surviving family and friends is evident in the shoes. I saw it when out for my morning run along the Danube and suggested it to my husband, who also visited it.

A poignant and moving memorial. A beautiful, simply, moving and poignant memorial. Simple and appropriate, it makes you think about the challenging past the Budapest residents faced and brings the realities of war very close to home (especially coupled with a visit to the Jewish ghetto and the House of Terror.)
Very moving.. Walk along the promenade from the Chain Bridge then you don't have to cross a busy road. Make sure that you have your camera with you.
cute. We saw it on our bus tour , its mostly bronze shoes and well done, the walk along the river is a nice walk

Extremely sad. 50 bronze shoes Mark the place where on Hungarian Nazis shot to death Jewish Hungarian citizens whose bodies fell into the freezing cold Danube River. The last thing these people saw was the beautiful Budapest Castle on the other side of the river... So very sad.

Chilling. Stumbled upon this walking from Parliament to Vaci Utca so was not 100% sure what it was until I researched it. Never seen an instalment like this before and it is quite chilling. Many candles placed in remembrance too. Worth a visit if you want to check it out on the way to Parliament.
must visit. It is located between hungary parliament and chain bridge. Its is WWII memorial and thus get some time for little silence.

Silent witnesses to the tragedy too many suffered during WWII. A sad & graphic reminder of the terrible fate suffered by many Jewish men, women & children at the hands of the rabidly barbaric Arrow Cross Party members. To think these men so thoughtlessly and brutally shot & killed so many people here, such a short distance from Parliament, is mind blowing. Take a moment to reflect on what took place here. It is very sobering.
Simple, but very moving....... A simple sculptural representation of a dark chapter in Hungary's history.... easy to overlook.... but pause and take it in.....

Words can't express it. Such an emotional place to see, imagining the people, even small children who stood there at one time right before they died in such a horrific way. And for such senseless reasons. A place to reflect on life

Important history but picture is sufficient. This is a heart wrenching story but the picture of the shoes is it. Read about it and look at the picture and you will have the whole story. I am not dismissing the importance of the history but it is not a lot to see.

moving but impprtant tribute to innovent me,women and children. having just been on the the jewish heritage tour,we had to see this moving tribute to innocent people murdered just for following the wrong faith.we just stood totally speechless,there are no words to describe the horrors carried out here and across europe by the evil nazi regime,we must never forget and it must never happen again.
Goose bumps. There are no words to describe what I felt when I saw this memorial, especially when you know how this country suffered throughout history. Beautiful and worth a visit.

Graphic Illustration of Human Tragedy. A piece of performance sculpture that documents a sober piece of the country's long history of tragedy.
One negative is how little the town has marketed this important statement of man's inhumanity.
Very emotional . A very heart rendering tribute to the poor people who lost their lives in such a vile way....I would recommended going to see it.

Words cannot say. When you see this memorial, you may be speechless. With the
thoughts in mind of what happened, one cannot begin to imagine the many tragic things of that time period.

This is such a moving tribute. Easy to find, just a short walk from the Chain Bridge. Make sure you go there in person to get the full effect, we drove by on a tour and it goes by so quickly you don't get the full impact. Very moving when you stand there, next to the little shoes.

Very Moving. Barely visible from afar, just a short distance of the Parliament, and a reminder that Hungary lives with very dark past. It was not the Nazi's that killed these Hungarian Jews. Stop and reflect on brutality of one person to another...and it still goes on.

A must visit Budapest. A easy walk from the Chain Bridge pass the boats along the river
one of our highlights in Budapest. Also visit the Hungarian Parliament Building, also known as the Parliament of Budapest above this memorial. Might have to book as we did.

Worth seeing. Pop by on your walk from the Hungarian Parliament to the Chain Bridge - it's an interesting choice for a memorial. There isn't much to see except for the shoes and a few items left by people such as candles or flowers, but being there is what it is all about - to put yourself in their shoes, so to speak, and imagine what the tortured people went through.
Emotional. This is a very emotional place. A memorial to hundreds who died here. We had seen the pics on a website but seeing it makes it so real. A must see if you are in Budapest.

Very heartbreaking. Touching memorial on the bank of the Danube. It's a lovely riverside walk to get there, although if travelling with a stroller be prepared - a low quality one with small wheels (like our travel one!) might struggle with some parts of the walk!

Poignant and Incredibly Moving. This instillation is very sad- it commemorates a number of Jews who were lined up on the banks of the Danube and shot during the Second World War.It consists of various metal shoes, which look very lifelike, almost as if the owners of the shoes have just dived in to the waters below.It's sad, but a good reminder of the evil that existed at this time and how it should never return.

A place to remember. During WW2 the Hungarian Nazis took over the power in Hungary. They "collected" the Jews and one of the methods to kill them was - to shoot them into the Danube. This shoes are on the Danube Promenade to let remember on those who were killed by the Hungarian Nazis.
Surprised by it. At first we didn't know what this was about. But it was very moving and sad when we did. Starkly effective.
Touching. We only saw these from the tram, but the memorial concept is inspired, and a touching reminder of Budapest's turbulent history. Great.

Highly Emotive. Metal shoes that look like leather. But what they mean brought tears to my eyes. During the last years of WW2 the Nazis invaded Hungary. While many Jews were shipped to extermination camps other methods were used as well. Lining Jews up on the banks of the Danube and shooting them was but one of many horrific approaches. These shoes symbolize that. It is a site where the viewer can imagine what it must have been like. Thinking about the extermination of 6,000,000 Jews is difficult. This site helps make the number real.

Heart rending. A very unusual and cleverly conceived memorial to the Jews murdered by the Arrow Brigade following the Nazi occupation of Budapest, as WW2 neared its end. 10,000 were made to strip at the water's edge, were tied together in threes and then, to save bullets, one of each three was shot in the head and pushed into the Danube, pulling the two tied to him in with him, so that the other two were drowned. A most appalling piece of history and a heart rending monument if you stop and imagine the men,the women and the children whose shoes are represented here...

Haunting and heart-wrenching. I had heard about this from searches on the internet, and knew it had to be on our list of things to see. The history of this city during the war is pretty well documented, but this is a heart-wrenchingly graphic thing to see. So simple when you just hear about it, but when I saw it - I had tears in my eyes just thinking about the reality of what happened here. So many shoes, some with candles set in them as tribute, some with little flower buds. Budapest is a fantastically beautiful city, but it does us all well to remember what they went through and how they came to be where they are now. It's just steps from the Parliament buildings, along the lovely promenade on the Danube - it can be pretty breezy - but well worth searching out in my view. We must never forget history - and this is part of theirs. From the Parliament, facing the river, head left on the walkway. I think it's well worth some time.

Poignant memorial. A very touching and poignant memorial to the victims,of the Nazi's atrocities. Very low key, but if you know the story, it really can hit home how absolutely depriaved people can become. The memorial is right across the street from the Parliament building.

60 pair of bronzed shoes. When you see this place, with its 60 pair of bronzed shoes and all the candles to memories the dead, you can't avoid feeling a bit sad and respectful toward the history and the loss of these people.

Moving, simple expression of true horror. Thoughtful way to remember the victims of the Hungarian Nazis who were among the worst of the worst at the end of WW2. You will not soon forget seeing these shoes and unlike memorial museums you are standing at the place it happened.

Original. Very original and good idea! This monument is very particular and if you see it you'll never forget it. There's only one problem: I don't care anyone can forget the 27th of January, but everyone forget the other victims of injustice! This is only my opinion.
Touching review..... Shoes of the Danube was a remarkable memorial. We had seen many memorials, but the history attached to this one and the explanations were even more touching.

Only if you're nearby. You'll probably be at the Parliament building, so it's worth the 50-step walk to check it out. But don't make any detours just to see it, unless you do have some strong connections with the history behind it.

Heart wrenching. To see this memorial and hear the story/history is a heart wrenching experience. Brought tears to not only my eyes but so many others in my group, men and women of all religions and ethnic groups.. If you are visiting alone be sure to read about this before visiting to fully understand what your are viewing, not just bronze shoes along the water front -- unbelievable inhumanity happened here.
Peaceful Memorial. Its a memorial for the people who were killed by Hitler communist government at the world war time. one must visit this place when in Budapest. Its a very peaceful palce to go.

Thoughtful treat. We walked here as it was close to the Parliament building on the map. It was windy by the water in March, so we brought jackets and windbreakers. We didn't spend long there, but in the silence we could sense the solemnity of the sculpture. It's definitely worth a visit.

Shoes, a memorial. Always interesting to see an unusual memorial to honor political a who lost their lives. It makes you think, and want to learn more about the terrible times throughout Hungarian history. Glad I saw it.
The saddest part of Budapest. I found this to be heart wrenching - it really brought home to you the horror and cruelty of war. These poor people who lost their lives in such an evil situation.
Emotive. Really amazing. Make you think. Very emotive ans special. You cannot leave Budapest without see it. .
simply moving. the simplicity of this memorial is so moving: more than 20 pairs of shoes mark the spot where Hunagrian Jews were made to remove their footwear, then shot and drowned by the Nazis.
Very touching. What a lovely but very touching story of how and why the shoes have been left on the quayside. Good history lesson for all.
Memorable memorial. We will never forget this moving experience. We came upon unexpectedly and are so thankful that we did.
Very poignant memorial. A beautifully simple, poignant memorial to the Jewish people killed in The war, very glad that we walked along to the site just in. Front of the Parliament buildings.

Every visitor to Budapest has to see this.. The iron shoes memorialize Jews killed by Hungarian Nazis of the Arrow Cross organization during World War Two. The victims were lined up, forced to strip and then shot so that they would fall into the Danube. The scene is so gripping that my first instinct was to start snapping pictures. The shoes demand reflection, however, and I realized that silent contemplation is more important, sometimes, than getting the shot to remember. The day we visited, a couple with a young child was accompanying an elderly man. He began to sob as they walked along the row of shoes. That is our important memory of the Shoes on the Danube. On the Pest side, between the Parliament and the Chain Bridge.

Moving. I think this is a very moving memorial to those murdered by the militia. What I didn't like was that it is not signposted or mentioned on any tours or guide books. A memorial is just that! We should remember them.

Memorial to be seen. Shoes on the Danube is an emotionally moving memorial to the atrocities perpetrated upon the Jews. It saddens me that this had to happen...and continues to happen in our world. Its a great teaching moment for all children.

A very moving experience. These shoes represent the thousands of Jewish people who were tied together and then pushed into the fast flowing Danube River by the Germans to what was a certain death. When you stand there and contemplate this unspeakable horror it bring tears to the strongest of us. A place to remember the horrors of war, for what?
Very Moving. A very moving memorial to the Jewish people, when you know what happened to them. A simple but very appropriate memorial.

Had to see it. I had heard about and seen pictures of this memorial and definitely wanted to see it myself. Glad we did !! If you know what they are and why they are there you don't need any explanations. If only they weren't there !!

A 'moving' experience. Heard about this by chance. Situated on the 'Pest' side of the river between the chain bridge and Parliament building. Very moving, especially if you can find out about what it is there for. You need to research this online as there is no information plaque at the site.
Must see. Take a walk down the Danube and be sure to spot the emotional memorial of shoes on the bank. Probably my favorite memorial in all of Budapest.
Memories. Great way of remembering and get more into the past.Good picture in black and white by the Danube river.

first place we went to in Budapest. It's simple, it works, it hurts.
(Go here, not to the huckstering Great/Central Synagogue/Nagy Zsinagoga.)
Sad place, nice memorial. Located in the river front of the Danube, between the parliament and the Chain bridge, these bronze shoes it is a memorial of horrors not to be forgotten.

Heart breaking. Scattered bronze shoes of all ages and gender mark a spot along the Daube where thousands of Jews were shot so they would fall into the Danube. An aching reminder of the fear and horror people faced because many crazies were bent on racial or religious cleansing. Well worth a visit.
Very moving. We went to see the parliament building and passed by the shoes inside each one was a candle which could have been a light the night before. It was very moving

fun, wish I could have tried them on. not really but a great place to go and watch the sunset. not too crowded but some others there for photo opportunities like me. enjoyed my time there and had a great conversation with some brits.

Powerful. Powerful memorial to the Jews who were systematically murdered by the Hungarian Cross and pushed into the Danube. No reading, pictures or videos, just the wharf and cast shoes of the victims. A must see.
very touching. This is a memorial to the Jews who were thrown into the Danube by the Nazis during the 2nd World War. It is touching in its simpllicity. Bronze shoes along the bank of the river.

Such a touching memorial!. This brilliant memorial is a must see!! I don't think a memorial has ever been so fitting. Names on a wall, or states in a park don't quite do it for me. This was brilliant! You get the sense of the lives that were truly lost there and that all that was left behind was there shoes.
Really amazing!

SO impressive and sad!. Very impressive memorial to honor Jews killed during World War II. The victims were ordered to strip and then were shot in the back in order to fall into the river. There are 60 pairs of cast-iron shoes of all sizes, even children's, women's, businessmen, etc. No one was spared! Very moving!!
Easy to miss, but very poignant.. Worth a visit, on the Eastern side near the Parliament buildings. Nice views of the castle and church on the Western side of the Danube from here.

Nice walk on the river to see a touching memorial. A nice memorial to those that were killed by Arrow Cross Milita in 1944-45. They were told to take off their shoes first, since shoes at the time were very valuable. They were shot and then either fell or were pushed into the river.

Just spend a few quiet moments here .... In a city that really faced the true horrors of the holocaust this is a powerful place to visit. Just walk down from the Houses of Parliament to the river and head for the chain bridge and you will come across it. Having come from London we are aware of the holocaust but I have never been to a city that experienced it so fully. 600,000 Jews in Hungary died during this time. Thank you trip advisor as I wouldn't have known about this site unless I read it here.

Very emotional. The display of these shoes, to me, was very emotional. It is a quiet reflection that I had as I saw these shoes displayed on the river pathway. It is a sad reminder of what happened in the past.The memorial is done with grace and respect for those who lost their lives.
Makes You Think!. We had only a very short stop at this memorial while touring. But it is quite moving. Actually quite sad! Hope it never happens again.

An evocative, transcendent historical marker. If you would like to pay homage to memory, culture, and history, please visit the Shoes on the Danube memorial while in Budapest. On the Pest side of the Danube near the Parliament of Hungary, the Promenade reveals a dark stain from the past. The memorial is a disquieting but important work that rises from the banks of the river in a fashion similar to how the Viet Nam War Memorial rises from the mall in Washington DC.
Moving faster than the water. Such a moving tribute, simple in concept, deeply moving in reality...... if in Budapest a must see. It's easy to find just walk along the river towards parliament

Sobering and honoring. Never been to Auschwitz but it is on my go to list but shoes on the promenade speaks volumes to the horrors endured by the Jewish people in Budapest during WW11. Wonderful memory to the departed.
Creative, cleverly done, most unusual monument.. Haven't touched anything like this in all the world. Another sad remembrance of man's inhumanity to man.

A poignant memorial. Located just outside the Hungarian Parliament building on the bank of the river Danube, there are sixty pairs of shoes cast in iron that commemorate the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen during World War II.

What a horrible memory... You cannot imagine someone doing what happened here. But it did. It is a nearly sacred place with an appropriate artistic tribute to the murders that occurred on this bank of the Danube. You should go in the evening, light a candle and pay tribute. The only thing this place lacks is the complete story written somewhere near there. Look it up before you go.

Very emotional. We were walking around the area with my husband when we ran into this display; because of the fact that they have recently celebrated 75 years of the end of the WWII, there were a lot of flowers and written messages.I was very touched by this display, could not add one more word to describe the horror and sadness this people might have gone through!
Sombre place. This site is a tribute to the thousands who were drowned in the Danube, during the war. Vey poignant and moving place to visit.

The sad truth :(. The place is just near to the budapest parliament.Well you can see almost whole budapest city from this place. the real story of those are very sad. But its better to keep those as a memory. thank you
Emtional. Very emotional especially as there was flowers and candles I have read and watched many programmes on the holocaust but had never heard of this until I looked up info on Budapest

Makes you appreciate how lucky we are. This is an somber display that makes you contemplate what it must have been like for the people, some only children, who were marched down to that spot and moments later murdered in cold blood and tossed in the river. It really brings home the horror and brutality of war.PJ Barker author of the novel Changing Pillion.

Sobering. If your only mental association of the Danube River is with the "The Blue Danube Waltz", then come here. You walk along the Danube right below the Parliament with romantic historical echoes of the '50s musical type humming in your head. Then you come across these shoes. Men's and women's shoes setting mutely on the banks of the river. What are these you think? You pull out your guidebook and read the alternate history of this sad, troubled land and realize that the memorial commemorates the atrocities committed by fascists and Nazis on these very shores within living memory. You pass on; hopefully, moved by these silent witnesses.

Reflect and live life to the full in their memory. This is just a simple and thought provoking art installtion with significant beauty. You know just how important having comfortable feet is. Our shoes tell a tale, whether you choose Jimmy Choo or recycled flip flops. We are just so lucky to have that choice.This memorable image is with me daily as I have a distressed leather shoe made in Hungary on my key ring. If ever you feel your day is not going well... just remember that you are here & they are not, through the fate of being in the wrong place, at the wrong time.. respect the memory and live life to your potential.Anyone visiting Budapest must visit this, especially poignant at night.

Make you Think - an important attraction to visit. Go and see. Think and you Will be emotionally touched. Difficult to understand how Hitler's men asked Jewish people to take of the shoes, shot them and just let them Fall into the river.

A beautiful memorial. A stunning memorial that everyone should see regardless of nationality, race or religion.
The perfect place to reflect on the past and look forward to a prominent future.

Moving. In December and January of 1944-1945, the Hungarian Nazi Party increased it's aggression against Hungarian Jews. In the early mornings they would pull Jews from their homes in the Jewish quarter and march them to the Danube River, have them remove their shoes, then line them up 6 deep and use one bullet to shoot each line, letting the bodies fall into the Danube. Not everyone who was shot and fell in died, and Nuns and monks from nearby monasteries climbed onto the bridges and banks of the river and tried to rescue as many people as possible.This installation consists of 60 pairs of cast iron shoes as a remembrance of those who lost their lives. Visitors leave flowers, coins and stones. If you come, please remember that this is a monument to one of the many horrific acts against Jewish citizens of Budapest and be aware that some visitors may have lost family members during this horrible time.

Must pay tribute to this memorial, so sad.. Bronze shoes of all sizes shapes dotted along the river memorializing the innocent people, women, men and children shot into the Danube during WW II for being Jewish.
Powerful. This moving, heartbreaking memorial will bring a lump to your throat. A small pair of child's shoes next to mother's communicates a powerful message.

Very moving, try to walk down and see it. Was very moving and a different memorial to people who were victimized during the Hitler regime. My husband didn't think it would be worth seeing and afterwards posted pictures and hasn't stopped talking about it. It is a silent memorial that speaks very loudly.
Sadness and humbling . Made me stop and pause on the bad things we do to each other and how can we find peace and learn to be a kinder gentler human race.

Moving memorial. Thought-provoking memorial on the Danube. Only found the location when passing on the river cruise, it is shorter than expected and off the road so you do need to go looking for it. I would have liked some more information, I'm not sure all of the visitors appreciated what it was and were not overly respectful, but with more detail to appreciate the horror of what the shoes represent that may not be the case.
Such a sad place but important. I cried when I saw this but it is important to see it. It is a shorter walk if you start from the Parliment end.

Very moving, very simplistic, never forget. I was walking alone down by the Danube and ran across the memorial. Took time to read and learn the story behind the meaning and it was truly moving. History should never be forgotten or we will be doomed to repeat, many times I am shocked by the atrocities throughout the world, but glad someone chose to honor the victims. Not over the top and very easy to visit due to its location I would highly recommend a visit. Say a prayer while there.
A reminder. A very simple yet moving memorial to the tragic events of 1944. The size of some of the shoes shows how young some of victims of the Nazis must have been.

Humbling. We stayed for a while looking at the shoes. How the Jews suffered in the war shot and killed and thrown in the river only their shoes remained very sad. Take the time to absorb what the shoes mean and don't look at it has a tourist attraction but a poignant reminder we can never go back only move forward.

Moving Experience. This is a very moving site on the banks of the Danube. The shoes can be found on the Pest side of the river and are between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament building. This memorial is in remembrance of Hungarian citizens who were executed by fellow countrymen during World War II. The executers were Arrow Cross men who made the victims remove their shoes before shooting and dumping the bodies in the river. It is a very moving experience just standing there and imagining the fear and terror that the victims must have experienced.
Very Moving. An incredible yet very simple memorial to the horrors of the Second World War. A simple yet emotional place to visit in the shadow of the history around you.

Moving. Moving tribute to the Jewish men women and children of the Budapest ghetto who were marched to the banks of the Danube shot and dumped in the river by the hungarian facists the arrow cross. Can be found half way between the Chain bridge and the Parliament building on the Pest side of the river.
poignant. unfortunately it was pouring with rain so we did not stop as long as we wanted. Certainly makes you think. The shoes are incredibly realistic and all shapes and sizes worth seeing.

Too much litter left behind. Some visitors fill the shoes with stones and pebbles , light candles or place fake flowers as a tribute . There should be some form of maintainence or daily removal of those prayer objects or it will mar the exhibits and make them look like litter instead.

Poignant. We've visited many of the concentration camps in previous years and had no idea of Hungary's involvement in World War II. We were disgusted to read how they shot the Hungarians at the river's edge. The poignant memorial was well done.
So touching. Simple and affecting monument. Very poignant to take a moment to reflect on what happened here. Take a stroll on the banks of the Danube and find it.

Emotionally Moving Memorial. Row of about 60 iron shoes were placed along the bank of the Danube River to memorize murdered Jewish victims. Before the Arrow Cross militiamen shot them, they were ordered to remove their shoes. Leather shoes were valuable, however, Jewish lives were not considered valuable by the Nazis.
It makes you think. Heavy place, difficult to see without any emotions...it brings you to the World War II time and imagine how awful and horribly it was...

A poignant tribute. This understated and very touching memorial is a sight that few who see it will ever forget. We lingered for a while and reflected -- a good thing to do when you are in a rush to see everything you can in a new city.

Simple, but very moving. This memorial is located just a block or so south of the Parliament building right on the river bank. It is a collection of 60 or so pairs of shoes that men, women, children and babies would have worn during WWII. They are dedicated to all those that were marched to the Danube River told to remove their shoes and then were shot and fell into the river. The memorial get the message across very effectively.
It makes you think about what life is worth. This very striking memorial shows that their shoes were worth more to the nazi's than the people were. It's very moving. Make the effort to see it please.

This is one of the most evocative pieces of scupture that I have ever come across in my life. Don't just take a picure for your holiday snaps and please do make sure you read the plaque about the motivation for this being here in the first place

Overwhelming sadness. How can 60 pairs of shoes along a river be so moving? To think thousands had to remove their shoes before being shot into the Danube to float downstream! A poignant reminder of how awful we have been. And to avoid going there again
Homage.... Touching sight, reminds the catastrophic results of Nazism and its crimes. In the memory of those who were killed in front of the river.
poignant tribute. This memorial is on the river on the Pest side of the city. It is very simple but poignant and makes you think of the horror suffered by the victims of the Holocaust.

A must see in Budapest. We were very moved by this installation. We wished we had some flowers or candles to light in memory of the people who died here. A painful reminder of what happened to innocent people in a terrible time.

Moving. Very simple but moving. It seems like it just happened. The way the laces are undone. The shoes fallen to one side. The little child's boots are so thought provoking.A fantastic memorial to make people think so these people aren't ever forgotten and this never happens again.

A simple, powerful memorial. A memorial doesn't get much more simple than this, but once you know the story, it doesn't get much more powerful. As I am sure has been written many times before; during WWII the Nazis lined people up along the shore, told them to remove their shoes and then shot them, dead, into the river. Why they had them remove the shoes, I don't know, but the simple memorial of shoes really helps to drive home the idea that people once stood here, just before their death.The memorial is a bit worn, corroding away and filled with debris, etc... It would nice to have it updated.

Moved to tears!!. The 60 pairs of shoes that comprise the Danube memorial to the Jewish Hungarians murdered by the local Arrow Cross Militiamen are so powerful that they emotionally draw you back to that moment when the shoe laces even from the children's shoes were used to tie the hands of family members together so that only one bullet was needed to dispatch them to the freezing waters below. The shoes stolen and sold on the black market. I have never before been so strongly moved by a memorial from any war. It stands on the very edge of the river about ten minutes walk upstream from the Chain Bridge towards the famous parliament building on the Pest side. During the winter if 1944-45 the Danube was known locally as the Jewish cemetery. A somber but unmissable artwork. Spend a little time to think and remember these poor souls.

Very Sobering. We visited this sight while walking along the river. This is quite touching, making it easy to imagine the horror the Jews, Gypseys, and others suffered during the Holocaust. The is a memorial sight, deserving a somber approach, and many people were taking goofy pictures of themselves next to the shoes which struck me as rude. This is a memorial and tribute to those folks who perished during Nazi rule. Definitely worth the walk from the Chain Bridge, on the Pest side.
takes you buy surprise. how real it all looks like it happened yesterday startles you at first then impact of it all comes across

A sombre reminder of Nazi atrocities.. A touching and emotive tribute to the Hungarian victims of the Nazis. We saw it on a clear sunny day and it was very touching, tastefully done and organised. Please visit and let us never forget.
Poignant and stunning. The power of art marking the terrible murders. Stunning memorial. Not to be missed. Stayed with me long after my visit

I couldn't stop sobbing. First I have to mention that I'm Israeli and Jewish .so this memorial really thouched me personally.There were more viewers about.so I felt I had to hide my face under my hat because my tears were flowing uncontrollably.This memorial is deeply.moving , only a real genius in my opinion could create some thing so simple.yet so powerfully moving . .
A place of horror !. We read about this in our guide. Close your eyes and remember what happened to those innocent people .....

Shoes can speak volumes. These simple shoes cast in bronze are a stark reminder of the atrocities suffered by the people of Hungary during WWII. These shoes stand as testament to the murders committed by Nazi-affiliated militia and speak louder and clearer than many of the more famous and larger Holocaust monuments. The site is located near the Parliament building along the Danube and the monument includes a plaque in English, Hungarian and Hebrew that describes the history and significance of the shoes. It is well worth a walk to see these ghostly shoes face the river and imagine what it must have been like so many decades ago.

A very heartbreaking memorial. It is unbeleivable, how cruel and coldhearted the russian soldiers was, just kill men, women and children, and let Donau take away their bodies, only leaving some shoes....My father and our family succeded to escape in 1956, lucky me, it could have been my shoes there....

"This monument is one of the freshest, most moving, and subtle memorials of the Holocaust anywhere in the world.". Commemorating the months at the end of WWII when Jews were herded by the Hungarian Arrow Cross from buildings where they had been concentrated (not all in the ghetto; many were in the 13th district), brought to the banks of the Danube, told to take off their shoes, and shot into the icy river -- sometimes with family members tied together to make swimming more difficult, in case anyone happened to survive.This monument is one of the freshest, most moving, and subtle memorials of the Holocaust anywhere in the world. Designed by Gyula Pauer, it is a work of tremendous vision as well as subtlety. Highly recommended for all visitors to Budapest. It is also a chance to get right down to the riverbank, which surprisingly is not that easy to do in the city, since in most places roads have been built there. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoes_on_the_Danube_Bank

Don't Miss The Shoes. A somber reminder of the history of Budapest under the Nazis but one that should not be missed. It is something that should be seen by people of all ages including younger ones to explain what happened.

Don't miss this little known but moving memorial remembering an event in WW2. My travel agent mentioned to me about the "Shoes on the Danube Memorial" before we left Australia for our Budapest to Amsterdam river cruise. We are so glad she did! It would have easily been overlooked had we not been specifically looking for it. And as she rightly commented that there are people living and working in Budapest who don't know about it!  Anyone who decides to walk along the edge of the Danube from the Chain Bridge up towards the Parliament Building, will come upon it, and as others have rightly commented, there are 3 paving stones written one in English, one in Hungarian and one in Hebrew explaining what one is seeing. As others have rightly commented, it was very moving to see 60 pairs of shoes, representing men, women and children mounted in the pavers permanently set into the pavers along the edge of the Danube.........."60 pairs of period shoes cast out of iron. Different sizes and styles reflect how nobody was spared from the brutality of the Arrow Cross militia (the shoes depict children, women, businessmen, sportsmen etc.). Behind the sculpture lies a 40 metre long, 70 cm high stone bench where at three points are cast iron signs, with the following text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005."This is a quote from 'Shoes on The Danube by Phil Watkins."We visited in August, and there were no floral tributes, or anything around the shoes whatsoever, so it may be that others who commented in May, would have had the remnants of tributes left on the anniversary of the event?If you are in Budapest, on the Pest side....take 1/2 an hour and walk along the Danube and contemplate on the moving tribute to those Jews cruelly murdered over 70 yrs ago. It is one of the few tourist attractions that will cost you nothing, but leave you with an unforgettable poignant memory from your visit to Budapest!
Beautiful memorial . Visited the shoes on the Danube on a sunny beautiful day and there was a chill here, such a sad event to remember but a beautiful memorial to those murdered here

Worth a visit. Without the shoes, the walk itself up the danube, usually from Margit Bridge to the Chain Bridge, is always worthwhile, being on the side of central Pest you can always walk deeper into the city and find places to sit down, eat and drink. As for the shoes, it's very moving and especially if you're aware of the history and significance, worth going to see. Regardless of your beliefs. Another upside is that it can be visited year-round

Tugs on your heart strings. We came upon this more by accident and didnt understand what it meant. After asking the significance, my insides lurched and I felt very emotional. The array of shoes including those of small children is so touching

Very special. This memorial was just below the aprtment we had rented and took time to walk along to see the candles visitors had placed in shoes, lots of visitors came to see this memorial on the river side just before the Parliment building.
Heartbreaking. the memorial is simple yet poinient. A lasting reminder of the horror of war and Mans inhumanity to Man

Very Powerful & Moving. I was walking along the Danube and came across these shoes. Wondered why they would be there. Then discovered a metal plate on the pavement describing what this memorial was for. It was moving. Just to be in the spot where so many innocent lives were taken. Even children were killed. You could tell form the children's sized shoes.Makes you wonder. Has mankind everl earned anything from this?

A very moving scene. Words can't express our feelings when we first saw this from a tour bus in Budapest. We were on a Viking River Cruise from Amsterdam to Budapest on the Rhine, Main & Danube Rivers in Sept./Oct. 2011. It moved us enough that we took a walk after dinner on the boat which was docked not far from this spot. Budapest is a beautiful city but so very sad that this happened there.

Worth the walk to find it. Very moving and sad as others have said. Struggled to find it and had to go back a 2nd time as it was close to Parlement and we didn't find it the first time. Well worth the walk.
Must see. This was one of the most creative and striking examples of the brutality of WW2 and Soviet occupation. A must see reminder.

No Words. This was the most moving thing I have ever personally seen about the Nazi occupation of the eastern block. When we were there, there was a group of young Jewish kids, one was singing the story of the shoes. Even though I didn't understand the language, the message was universal. So moving. So heartbreaking.

A reminder of WWII brutality. A tragic memorial at the Danube promenade on the Pest side. 60 iron pairs of shoes form a kind of a theatrical stage. It's not a coincidence that the memorial was inspired by a film director, Can Togay, who, together with the sculptor Gyula Pauer created this complex to - as it's written on 3 plaques in Hungarian, English & Hebrew - the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944-45. The details of this sad story are above imagination. They gathered the Jews, ordered them to remove their clothes and their shoes and stand at the edge of the Danube bank. Then they were taking shoestrings or ropes and tied them, two or three together. They were shooting and killing one, who fell immediately into the water together with the living ones. In case someone was still alive, they were using him as a live target! The Danube River turned red and sometimes it was called the Jewish cemetery. The memorial was erected in 2005. There are always a lot of flowers and lit candles around the shoes. Men's shoes, women's shoes, children's shoes.. Inevitably you imagine the owners of these shoes. How they looked like, what kind of profession they had. What kind of dreams they had. As a humble homage to them, you close your eyes and make a promise. Whatever your religion is, whatever your nationality is, whatever your social status is, as long as you live, you won't let this happen again, if you feel that you belong to the human and civilized species of this planet.At least this is my way to honour the anonymous innocent victims everywhere on this earth.
Very moving, worth the walk to see. This memorial is so moving. There are many notes, ribbons candles and other additions that passersby have added. This is a "must-see" for any traveler in the area.

A moving memorial. A timely and sad reminder of how Hungary treated its Jews. I was a little disappointed top find most of the boots and shoes full of candles and flowers. I found it more emotive without them - I have seen them once before.

Moving. This was so moving, worth taking a walk to get to this to take some nice photos by the river. Didn't notice but it would have been nice if there was some information about this attraction to read near the site.

Very moving. We saw this in a guide book and went along the river to see it. It was a very moving experience as a memorial to all the people who were killed and then thrown into the river. Not well publicised but definitely worth seeing while in Budapest.

A must see in Budapest. Not much to add to all the reviews of this monument. Go there, sit for a while and reflect about the cruelness that has been and unfortunately is still a part of the World as we know it.
a beautiful memorial. we came upon the shoes while walking along the Danube on the Pest side ....very emotional to see.....a lovely memorial to a terrible historical event

this is sad but worth a look. This memorial was mentioned to us by another travellor on our visit to the synagoe, no mention of this in our guide book. It really touches your heart when you see all the shoes and especially the childrens shoes, and imagine how that must have felt. This should never happen again.
Simple but moving. A small, simple and unusual memorial to those who lost their lives in the war and whose bodies were disposed of in the river.

Very moving. We had this on our list and found it by accident when walking along the Danube.
It is a very moving memorial to the city's tragic past.
Must be on any tourists list. The shoes are located very near to the Houses of Parliament on the Pest side of the Danube. I enjoyed visiting this memorial and reading about the history behind it.
Too much pollution. This is an interesting monument, but unfortunately most of the feeling is lost as there is quite a bit of garbage around (and in) the shoes

Very moving, once you realise what it is.. Not very well marked at all, it could easily be seines idea of art, but once you realise what it sybolizes it is very moving. Along side the vast flowing river, it's a lovely setting to remember those affected. Maybe the lack of signage was to keep it simple, but I think it's worth a little more notice.

Uniquely avant garde yet poignantly moving memorial. This memorial remembers the Hungarian Jews who were killed during World War 2 by a local paramilitary group who collaborated with the Nazi occupiers. The victims were made to remove their shoes before being shot, their bodies inevitably falling into the murky waters of the Danube River and swept away. The memorial captures a poignant moment when all that's left behind at the scene of the killings are the shoes the men and women had been wearing. Rather avant garde but rather effective at evoking the horror of the times. The memorial is located roughly midway between Parliament House and Chain Bridge. If walking here from the Parliament building or from Kossuth Lajos ter station, be careful when crossing the road facing the memorial as traffic, while not necessarily heavy, can come flying around the nearby bend.
Overwhelming. Everyone should see this simple yet powerful memorial. Simply heartbreaking and left a huge impact on us. One of the most amazing memorials we have ever seen.

A must see. This memorial succeeds to convey a strong message to future generations about where hatred can lead us. Looking at the shoes you can imagine the horror as you look at the Danube River. This is an important reminder of what happened to Hungarian Jews during world war two.
very moving. This is a real reminder of the terrible ordeal of the Hungarian Jews during WW 2, I is very moving on the river

Not your average monument.. These bronzed shoes on the side of the Danube, memorializing mostly members of the Jewish community shot on the side of the Danube in 1944-45, managed to convey lots of emotion. Bravo! Lest we forget.
Emotional reminder. An emotional reminder of war attrocities. You will see these bronze shoes as you walk along the promenade near the cruise ship's docking stations.

a moving memorial. we walked to the shoes on the danube, it's on the river bank just up from the parliament building so quite easy to get to.
I found this a moving memorial in quite a peaceful place on the river.

Chilling.... I really liked the simplicity of this monument. It is simple yet evocative. I wasn't looking for this place but accidently came accross it on the Pest side by the water right next to the Parliament. I didn't like the attitude of some of the other tourists. Many people seemed to disrespect the situation or perhaps they were just unaware of what it represented. It left a very powerful impression on me.

Chilling reminder of the Hungarian past. One can only try and imagine what those people must have gone through. Great effort by the director who decided to take the initiative of putting the shoes on the bank. As far as tourists go, they should learn to be more respectful and realise the shoes are not for them to try.
Must be seen. You have to see this memorial to the jewish men women and children who were shot by the Danube its a fair walk along the Danube by the parliament building.Its a very moving experience.
very touching. it Looks very inconsiderable when Walking by - but it is very moving and it makes you think about what happened there.very tastefully done!

Poignant and moving. Some Hungarian politicians have tried to whitewash history by pretending it was the German Nazis who invaded Hungary and did terrible things. Not so. Hungarian politicians invited and welcomed Nazi's in, and were complicit in all actions especially the final destruction of the Hungarian Jewish community.The empty shoes say it all.
Moving tribute. Take a moment to sit and reflect. Moving experience not to be missed while strolling along the river. A sad and poignant memorial to all that perished

To the conscience . Permanent reminder of a very sad chapter in Hungarian history. I would only wish the site is not perceived by the visitors as a "tour activity" but rather as a memorial for those who lost their lives there.
A beautiful memorial. It's lovely right there by the river. and to think what happened there to so many innocents. All the bronze shoes, men, women, children. We must remember. Never again.
Make the time. Poignant. Just a short walk from the Parliament Buildings. A simple but moving way to pay tribute to yet more lives lost at this time.

Budapest's simple memory taking responsibility for their Nazi murders. The Shoes Memorial remembers the killing of Jews by the Hungarian Nazi Party after the German Nazis had left.
In Budapest, the influence of Jewish Hungarians is very clear on their main boulevard and many other places. The clarity of what happened made me respect the citizens of Budapest more and encourage me to come back for another visit.

WOW! Summed up poignantly the Hungarian Jewish experience of WW II. As a second generation Holocaust survivor, I was moved by the sight of the shoes of various aged souls who perished at the hands of the Nazis. It was a moving tribute that was a stark reminder of that horrible time in our history that should never be repeated. It was also a great way to end a day in which we first visited the Jewish quarter.

Chilling reminder of the ravages of War. One can not help but experience a strong emotional response to this unique memorial to one one of the terrible tragedies of World War II. How could anyone live with themselves after taking part in such a henious crime. A stark reminder of how life can be treated so cheaply by fellow humans. I had intended on a quick visit but stayed for 30 minutes it is so moving to witness.

Stark reminder of history. You literally just walk up to these bronze shoes on the path walkway to parliament riverside. The shoes are set out over a small area of the embankment and are self explanatory in meaning

Thought Provoking. Most memorials I have seen around the world are nice. Few have ever spawned feelings that really made me feel and think. When I came upon the shoes during a walk along the Danube the energy surrounding the area drastically changed. Somber is the only word I can come up with. This is a beautiful tribute to the horrors of Budapest's past. Simple in its arrangement yet powerful at the same time. two weeks later, every time I look at a picture of these shoes my heart aches for the souls who were put through such horror. Take a moment during your journey to Budapest and spend some time reflecting upon it's history. You won't regret it.

A simple but most poignant memorial. This memorial of the deaths during the second world war is brilliantly simple, but hauntingly evocative of the terrible events in which so many people were killed. It doesn't take long to see it, but it lingers in your memory.
Sad, but poignant reminder. This is a poignant artistic work depicting a very sad part of Jewish history. A must see for remembering some of the tragic past of Budapest.

Unusual. Unique. Worth looking at.. There were several adjectives popping in my mind. It'sa) simple - no complicated structures, just shoesb) perfect - shoes are made of metal, but to very tiny detailsc) terrifying - if you imagine what exactly happened there and why shoes are what was left (especially those tiny ones)Tip: make sure you read some history related to those shoes before visiting, otherwise they will be just shoes...

Unique Memorial. In the waning days of WW II, members of the Arrow Cross militia took Jewish people to the banks of the Danube, had them take off their shoes, then shot them so their bodies fell into the Danube. Two Hungarian artists created this memorial in their memory, consisting of 60 pairs of shoes (made from iron) placed along the banks of the river.

Stunning in its simplicity. Located on the riverside, just before the Parliament building, this holocaust memorial is powerful in its simplicity. We are not Jewish but my wife and I were moved by this understated tribute. Shoes of all shapes and sizes to emphasise that no-one was spared, cast in iron and fixed to the promenade, mark the place where Jews were forced to stand, remove their shoes and turn to face the Danube. A firing squad then shot them at close range so their bodies would fall into the river and be carried away, to save the bother of burying them. There are no large signs to indicate the location of this tribute, just simple plaques inlaid on the pavement. You must see this when you visit Budapest

moving.... A moving tribute to Jews killed in the Holocaust, on the Pest side of the river. There are dozens of pairs of cast iron shoes, representing men, women and children who were forced to remove their shoes at the water's edge before being shot so their bodies fell into the Danube and got washed away. It's a place of real sadness and represents something that we should never, ever forget. Definitely worth a visit.

Very unique memorial. We came across this Jewish memorial on our way to the thermal baths. This moving memorial is dedicated to the Jews who were shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen during World War II. It was very unique as it's all 1940's style shoes made out of iron (about 60 pairs). You only need about 30 min here to reflect and remember (more if you like to take photos). I recommend coming at night since it's all lit up. Nice views of the Danube and Buda castle as well.
Profound experience. We just loved the way this memorial was devised: its almost as if you have to stumble over the shoes to see them. Definitely better to come and see them around dusk.

A moment to remember. It's a simple concept, but while there the harsh reality hit us all. To see the shoes, women's, men & children's.It's something that I would advise everyone to do. Just a few minutes to remember.

shoes of sadness. this memorial on the banks of the Danube relates to one of callous cruelty during WW2. the concentration camps were so full that prisoners could no longer be accepted and therefore prisoners of all ages including women and children were marched do the edge of the Danube ,made to strip and shot so that the bodies fell into the Danube and were carried away by the tide. The shoes of the victims remain as a reminder to all today of the futility of war. A sad but must see experience and perhaps take a moment to remember all the victims of war.

A Poignant Reminder. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial is a poignant reminder of the Holocaust atrocities that occurred in Hungary in 1944-1945. Thousands of Jews were rounded up by the Hungarian Nazis called the Arrow Cross Militamen, taken to the banks of the Danube River, stripped naked, and shot in the back so that their bodies would fall in the river and be washed away.This should be a must visit for anyone visiting Hungary.

Simple but so moving. We visited this memorial while in Budapest. It is such a simple but evocative memorial to the victims of an era of horror. The positioning, styles and condition of the boots and shoes tells us more than words could about the huge range of people who were caught up in the holocaust. There are no barriers to the memorial, it is possible to put e.g. flowers, small pebbles and notes in the shoes. Some are smart, stylish shoes, some small belonging to children while rough old boots show evidence of hard labour and poverty. All were in close proximity to the very edge, one shoe was right on the very lip of the bank. It was interesting that while there were several people there when we were, there was no talking, just standing, thinking, sighing - and in one case quietly crying.

Makes you stop and wonder.... ... what must have been like in those days of the terrible war and reminds you how precious peace is. There were flowers in some of the shoes which was very touching. A must see.

War is horrible. Really sad that people can do this to each other. The thought that people arr rounded up, told to remove their footwear and are then shot, their bodies dumped into the Danube. So sad.

Wish I had gone back for a closer look.. We had read about this poignant artistic exhibit before leaving home. We saw it out the window, right beside of our tour bus as we returned to our Viking River Cruise ship. We simply got too busy to come back for a closer look, however. Too much else to see!

Please don't miss this - very moving. We walked by the Shoes on the Danube and loved the simplicity of the tribute to the Jews who were slaughtered in 1944 and 1945. This is something that everyone should see when visiting Budapest.

One of the most moving exhibits ever. So subtle, the metal copies of the actual shoes removed by the Jews who had been taken to be shot on the shore of the Danube, their bodies to fall into the river. Such a simple but so very moving memorial..Budapest has several memorials done in very imaginative ways

Moving and Poignant. Wonderful memorial to a sad time in Hungary's history. The shoes are so realistic and so the terrible events are made real again so that we cannot and should not forget the lives lost.

Simple and moving artistic statement. Every visitor to Budapest should make this trip to the Pest shore of the Danube to be reminded of the horror,that took place here during WWII. The image of the shoes will remain with you long after you step away.

Jews were murdered by the NAZI and dumped into the Danube.. What happened then can happen again, Genocide is now in progress in territory controlled by ISIS. Why are people killing other people because of what that person believes? Speak out against it.!!
Moving memorial. This was one of our favourite places. It is such a moving a subtle memorial of a really important piece of history, we think the location and the memorial itself were very beautiful.
Poignant reminder. A stark reminder of others suffering in WW2. Quirky,a modern approach to tragic circumstances. Easy to locate and see from the bank or the river.

Not to be missed. This memorial of 60 shoes represents the Jewish people, men, women and children that were forced to take off their shoes and clothes before being shot & dumped in the river. It was their final humiliation before being murdered. This is a must see, not to be missed. We should never forget this happened so it doesn't happen again. Place a rock next to one or more of the shoes in remembrance of those that were brutally killed. This is close to the Parliment Building along the river.
Sombre and moving. Every visitor to Budapest should take 5 minutes to visit and pay their respects. The Memorial is simple but moving. Easy to find along the riverbank near the Parliament building.

Moving. Very moving to see this. The shoes represent the men women and children who were made to line up here and be shot. It is moving to just sit for a while and think about them and pay your respects.

The shoes of time.. Although a somber reminder of how savage mankind can be to its own, no trip to Budapest would be complete without seeing the "shoes along the river". Take a few minutes out of your day to pause and reflect. We found the experience to be a very moving one.
Sad truth. There sculpture of shoes on the edge of the Danube are just in front of parliament. They are to remember the Jews who were shot then thrown into the river. Very sad and but true.

Interesting memorial. Very unusual and interesting memorial with a sad history behind it. The are all these shoes or what looks like actual shoes, but they are made of iron and they are randomly place to be like the shoes for people to jump in the river, but they represent Jewish people who were shot and fell into the river.

We took a cab there.. It was worth the cost of the cab awaiting us!
It was a very emotional experience.
The area is very bare, however it accentuates the tragedy of war.
Hopefully it may never happen again.

A touching tribute. Despite knowing that we wanted to take a look at the shoes on the bank, we stumbled across the memorial before we had gone looking for it as we walked down the river.In a busy and loud city, there is a strange sense of silence around this area and it really does make you think about the horrendous event. Also shocking to think that this still happened well under a century ago...
Thought provoking. Very simple memorial but brings out your emotions as it should. It's simplicity is its attraction. Things like this should not be forgotten.

Moving. We struggled to find this initially but found them just along the danube at the back of the parliament building. There was plenty of people and very little sound, some in tears, it was very moving to see the shoes and the way they have been immortalised in remembrance. You need to see things sometimes to realise the sheer brutality of war.

A Reminder. A reminder of the grim past when a group of Hungarian Jews (1944) were shot and thrown into the Danube. This line of shoes is a simple and highly emotive tribute. The girl's fashion shoes, the work boots - but for me it was the child's shoes that brought the tears. Not easy to find - it is on the Pest side, and a walk along the embankment from Chain Bridge.

Thought provoking. These bronze shoes sit silently on the riverside as a reminder of the atrocities that the Jews experienced all those years ago. This is a location for quiet reflection and worth a visit.
