Lets not forget. One needs to meditate, how low a human being can fall without basic morals. How can a human being be so barbaric to treat a fellow human, irrespective of his race, colour or religion in such a way? With a little morality, the world would be such a better place. Live and let Live!!
Shoes and Soa. If you would like to learn a little about the Soa (Holocaust) in Hungary then you must go, and try thinking about what happened there, but it's impossible to understand.
We must never forget them. We don't know what hard times are when you see the tragedy that others have suffered . We must remember so this never happens again !

Sad Faces And Tears. The placement of the shoes of those Jews who were murdered in 1944 - 45 by being shot into the Danube off the quay is an extraordinarily moving way to bring home to us the horror of those days. Few people can see those shoes, of men, women, and children, and not feel a chill and shudder at the horrendous acts by Arrow Cross and the Nazis. If you visit Budapest, you certainly should walk along the river and see this place. It's very near Parliament.

Poignant..... A very moving experience and one that really shouldn't have to be. You gaze at these shoes and are reminded of the pain and despair of these poor men, women and children whose lives were ended for being Jewish....

Must See Site. Very simple, yet very moving tribute to the Hungarian Jews who were shot and then thrown into the Danube by the Nazis as the war was ending. It is commemorated by having the shoes representing those who were killed at this site, just sitting at the edge of the river.

Powerful. This is such a simple memorial yet serves to remind visitors of the Jewish atrocities that took place. Here, they were lined up and were told to remove their shoes (which were in short supply) before being shot and dumped in the river.
nice place to visit. A sad place and just one more nice place to visit among the other places in Budapest. it is in center and easy to visit but also it is easy to miss it.
shoes. powerful, powerful, powerful, powerful, touching, important monument to see, learn the history of Hungary in WWII.
Sad. So sad to see really, but im glad as it is there i did see it and you can think about and say a silent prayer for all of the people that died
Touching. A sad but beautiful war memorial dedicated to the unfortunate souls both men and women, children and aged...

Commerate the loss of life by fascists in WWII. in memory of the Jewish people shot dead to fall into the Danube by Fascists during WWII. 60 pairs of shoes that were left behind. ordered to take off their shoes. then shot and gone with the river. sad sad sad and also very impressive.
Very touching. Very well done but a plaque explaining all about it should be obvious to all who stop look wonder and photograph. Only now do I fully understand the significance.

Simple, but touching. The shoes are placed here as a reminder of the jews killed and thrown into the icy Danube river in late 1944 and early 1945, during the Soviet siege of the city. When it became clear the city is lost, the German soldiers marcher the remaining Jews from the ghetto to the Danube and executed them. Before their death they were ordered to remove their clothes, hence the choice of shoes as a monument to commemorate their deaths. It is remarkable how an installation as simple as this can cause such a chilling effect when you learn the story behind it.
Shoes on the bank. A sobering memorial like the holocaust. As you looked at these pairs of shoes, it is difficult to comprehend how the Jews were stripped naked and pushed into the river Danube.

Grim reminder of a dark period of humanity. I chanced upon this place while walking along the Danube. Once I understood the relevance and symbolism attached to this exhibit, I really found it moving. It was really touching to see candles and prayer notes placed by family members of the victims. After so many years the wounds have still not healed. The simple way of conveying the story of a horrific past is really powerful and impactful. It is also a reminder that we still have not learnt the lesson from our past and the world can again witness something like this. I hope not!
Powerful and sad memorial by the river. This was not in the tour book of Budapest which had I bought.I searched the internet to get more detail of what happened here.
A must. You just have to see this memorial. Simple but makes you think what happened here. On a night it can be seen from the other side of the Danube with all the candles lit!

world master traveller in central europe. this memorial sums up the pleasures of travelling the world like i do, i passed by this row of cast bronze shoes not having a clue what was going on, as i was just ambling along the towpath of the riverbank. Only now, a few days later, seeing this review, i know now what was going on. it works perfectly! I did think they were just a row of, very uncomfortable shoes, looking to see where their owners were? cooling off in the river below, from the heat of the day? Now i know they hadn`t been seen for over 70 years!! chills you to the bone. been the son of a British RAF serviceman who served all the way through WW2, just one generation apart!!

Museum-wrong location to place it. it's a very small permanent exhibit it shows the models of shoes of the Jewish kids in the past and also grow ups it is write next to the Danube in between the chain and margin bridge and near a pedestrian oath so it is quite visible to see it from afar.

Very moving. A powerful sculpture in a city that loves it's sculpture.The shoes are a memorial to the Jews who were lined up against the Danube and shot. Look up the basic story of Budapest's Jewish history and this artwork will move you even more. It's understated and unpretentious, and I found it moving and strangely beautiful.Well worth a visit as you explore the city.

Thought Provoking.. Well worth a walk along the shores of the Danube, especially in good weather, to see this small but touching tribute to all those who suffered under the Nazi regime during World War II. Sit for a few minutes and think about what these people endured. The more people who remember, the less chance there is of such a thing happening again.
Touching, solemn tribute. Visible for all to see and remember what these people endured. Research your guide book for the story.
Emotional Shoes. When in Budapest, this is a must see experience...the memorial to innocent lives lost in the midst of unjust affliction.

Shoes on the danube. This place is close from the parliament, my friend take us here after we visit the Parliament. I did some resesrch before come to Budapest, so i know about the history. From here you can also enjoy some beautiful view of sunset..
DEEPLY MOVING. I sat quietly staring, unable to hold back my tears, what a moving memorial. We must never forget how much people suffered.

Touches your soul. It was a sunny day when we were there and visited this memorial. When I saw the shoes, I felt deep sadness. It is nice that the city of Budapest have made a memorial to the victims who were shot to death here in 1944-45. It will break your heart and especially when you see the shoes of a little kid. I saw by chance a sign on the pavement near the shoes what is this for. This is just right outside the Parliament building.

Not very interesting. You can go there, if you find a way, i think it is not intended to be visited by tourists, as there is not a way to get there, nor signs pointing to it.Be careful not to trip on the shoes and fall into the Danube, water seems freezing cold, fate has a strange sense of humour and you don't want to be the guy killed by a holocaust monument...

Shocking and moving. During World War 2 groups of Jews were led to the Danube and shot in the water on a regular basis. They were ordered to take their shoes off for their executioners to collect them after the shooting. This is what this memorial is about. The sculpted shoes on the shore of the Danube send chills down your spine. It feels like those people have been shot just a minute ago...

Don't know what the monument was for. Actually we walked by this monument but I didn't see a sign or a plaquette or something with info about the monument. Pity, because I like history and the deeper meaning of these things...
An historical place!. A place that restores the story of Jewish people that killed... A place that is close to the bridge and is easy somebody to visit!!
A somber memorial. One can't help but feel a tightness in the throat and a tear in the eye upon seeing and imagining what it must have felt like for these unfortunate people.

Shoes on the Danube. It is something you must see if you are there. It was sad to see children and adult shoes. The tour guide had family members that lived there and she told a few stories. Her grandmother was a swimmer. She was the lucky one, who survived. She was grazed by a bullet and fell into the icy waters. She swam until someone helped her from the freezing waters and cared for her. Such sad stories about true events.
Sad Past. It was nice to find the shoes by the river and to know the background to the story.Yet another sad time from war times

Powerful. A simple but very powerful memorial to the Jewish victims killed in Budapest during WWII. I stood in awe thinking of how many innocent Jews died and we're just dumped into the Danube. They must have been terrified as they removed their shoes, knowing they were about to be killed.

Haunting. Unnerving. Powerful. . 1944-1945 Jews were stripped naked, lined up at the edge of the Danube, & shot in the back -- at point blank range -- by Arrow Cross militiamen. Each mutilated body would topple into the river & be carried away by the crimson current as the terrorists looked on between the barrels of their smoking guns.The 60 or so pairs of period footwear, cast in iron, are chilling reminders of the boundless cruelty exhibited by the Arrow Cross. The variety of shoes represent the men, women, & children violated by those ignorant savages. This memorial was absolutely worth the nearly 2 mile walk from my flat. I'd highly recommend strolling along the Danube Promenade any day.
Nice. A few metres from the Parliament, along the river. People were leaving candles and flowers which is a very nice gesture

"Make the time on your visit". You cannot visit this memorial without being moved. One can only imagine the site filled with the real shoes of the Jews who were murdered here. I am glad I was able to visit and pay my respects to those who lost their lives.

Moving tribute. A simple but sobering memorial to those that were shot and thrown into the Danube by the Nazis and nazi sympathizers. Our guide told us that to save on bullets, often two people were tied together and only one of them shot. Amazing to realize that these atrocities werent that long ago...

Beautiful & poignant . One of my favourite places in Budapest. Such a beautiful monument. From the chain bridge walk towards parliament staying close to the river and you will find it. We were the only people there when we went. A very special place to reflect.
Simple reminder of horrible past. Google it and then stop by to pay a visit. A sobering reminder. It is free and only takes a few minutes to see.

Very poignant was worth the visit.. Heard about this tribute to Hungarian Jews who were shot and thrown into the river through Tripadvisor.
It was worth the visit.
Since the day was cold and windy it added to the atmosphere.
Please do go there. if you are in Budapest.

Poignant and Sobering. A subtle reminder of the atrocities committed by the Nazis at the end of WWII. One might think that reasonable people would not commit murder of so many innocents...but then, perhaps the Nazis were't quite reasonable at all. Just another example of unleashed evil. It's a pity that the beautiful Danube has born witness to so many needless atrocities and deaths over the centuries.This simple collection of the bronzed shoes of Nazi victims should be on your list of things to see...and contemplate in Budapest.

Very moving reminder. This is a very moving memorial o the Jews who were shot and pushed into the Danube during the Second World War by the Nazis and their sympathisers. A very thought provoking memorial as well as being instructive as we knew nothing about what had happened here prior to visiting this site.
simple but elegant. beautiful but simple memorial to the jews that were killed by the fleeing Nazis. Very easy to access from Parliament. Strewn with coins or flowers or tea candles.

Very touching and sad. The history of the shoes on the Danube is very sad. We had read about this prior to going to Budapest but as sad as it sounds we went looking for them. If I thought reading about them was sad, actually being there seeing the shoes was even more sad, very very touching to the point I felt a bit upset thinking of what these poor folks had been thinking while standing by the River Danube knowing what their fate was going to be. Can't describe in words what my feelings were, I am glad we went and yes, we did take photos but still so so sad, especially seeing childrens shoes :-(
Visit. Simple setup, strong message. When you walk along the Donau, it is a nice thing to pass by and become silent for a moment.

A piece of history. Very simple memorial, but is worth a visit, as well as know the history of how Jews died on that place. The place has a nice view and it is a piece of history to reflect, as well as this memorial.
Extraordinary!. A most unusual monument but highly effective! Not easy to access but worth making the effort. Hard not be moved!

Thought provoking.. the shoes on the Danube is a very simple memorial. But is worth a visit. It is right by the parliament building on that side of the river. I would recommend visiting the parliament building then walking down the river to the chain bridge. That way you walk past the memorial and get to see three different Budapest attractions within a short amount of time!It's not a long walk 15 minutes maximum.
moving tribute. The simple memorial on the edge of the Danube was an eloquent memorial to the Jews who were brutally murdered in 1944 and 1945. It was so much more personal than a monument or plaque.
Moving!. Well worth a visit when viewing the Parliament from the river in the early evening sun. So many Jews lost their lives in Budapest during the war.
A sad sight. A sad sight but a good reminder as to what happened in history here. Those people will not be forgotten.

Small but Sobering. The Shoes on the Danube is one of the smallest attractions you may ever see but it should be on your "must-see" list. It is sobering to reflect on the horrors of war and particularly the atrocities inflicted on the Jews. I hope and pray that we do not simply say we learn from the past, but that we actually do learn and make the changes to make our world a better and more loving place. Do not forget to bring a few tissues to wipe your tears.

Haunting. Amidst the glorious history that is Budapest through the ages, this memorial is touching in its simplicity and eloquence. Marking the site along the Danube where Jews were murdered in WWII, it illustrates the tragic legacy of that era. Visit on a walk along the Danube Promenade.
Very moving. There's not a lot to see and that's why it's a must see in Budapest. You stop; you think; you begin to realise what this beautiful city has had to overcome in its History.

Hollocaust memorial. Very moving 'bronze shoes' on the bank of the Danube representing the victims (adjacent to Parliament building). Not easy to get to (walk down from the river cruise dock) but simple and silent reminder of those lost of all sizes ages and sexes.
memorable. The location of the memorial is peacefully set along the Danube. When you come across the shoes, you can't help but pause and remember the victims.
Make sure you read the history. Very moving and sad tribute to the Jewish people who were murdered by extremists. They are situated just in front of the parliament building and are well worth seeing.

Thought Provoking Display. Plan to see the memorial as part of a longer walk along the banks of the Danube on the Pest Side. Perhaps combine it with a visit to Parliament or before or after a memorable meal at Spoon restaurant.The memorial is a simple but stark and poignant reminder of a sadder era in Budapest. I have visited this spot when I want to be reminded that I live in what was the epicenter of a horrific war. You can be taken back to that time, too, especially if you are in the right frame of mind when visiting it. Look around you at the river and the elegant bridges which span it. Now picture it with bridges destroyed and with them the hopes and dreams of hundreds of thousands of people trapped in the hell of occupation and war.It is a worthwhile addition to your travel experience to Budapest and your memory bank. The helplessness and desperation of the victims is in contrast to the comparative opulence and freedom that is Budapest today.

Shoes of Danube. This is a very moving place to visit. During the Holocaust, Jewish men, women & even children were made to take off their shoes before they were shot into the Danube. I shed a tear especially when a saw a pair of shoes belonging to a very young child.It is very near the Parliament & from here you can easily walk to chain river, which will lead you to the funicilar.

Sobering display. Read up and learn the history behind the exhibit and then see it... It is worth taking the time to find it and view it. It is sobering when you think about what happened in that place. It is easy to find, just walk along the river on the Pest side between the Chain Bridge and the Margaret bridge.

Moving tribute to a horrific time in history. It was a bright sunny day and the bronze shoes monument to the jewish men woman and children who were murdered in Budapest is very sad and moving. It is a soulful mournful installation that pulls you in. Imporant to see!

Somber & Unforgettable. The bronzed shoes are right in front of the parliament building where the Jewish victims perished. It was moving and a sight that will stay with me. This sight is what I will take away from my trip to Budapest. It is at the end of the tram 2 line and along the Danube River.
Minimal and touching. Shoes in front of the river in memory of the people who lost their lives. Very minimal and touching memorial. Worth a visit!

Read about it before you go. I wish I'd read something about what they were before I went as there is no plaque or any information about them there. It was only when I went on a boat trip that I found out the sad story (one of many I heard about Hungarian history)

Thought provoking and beautifully done. Situated between the chain bridge and Parliament on the Pest side, I really wanted to find this, and wasn't disappointed. The shoes are so well done, and I was glad to see people are respectful of them. Just so sad to believe this happened, it almost doesn't seem possible in somewhere so beautiful. Definitely worth finding.
worth the trip. if you're on your way to parliament it's worth heading to the river side to have a look at this sad yet beautifully simply memorial.

Very real memorial. I thought this memorial was one of the best memorials. It wasn't just a story you read but you felt what it was like to stand there along the Danube and face their death. It was my favorite memorial to see. Definitely go visit!
Thought Provoking. Just a place that you have to go to.....just to stand and be quiet and remember what happened. Really makes on think!
Makes you think. Good artistic representation of something horrendous the Jews went through, it really makes you sit and think

Very hard to find. Very important monument regarding the jewish hungarisn faith while being thrown to the Danube in World War 2. Nevertheless it is very hard to find the monument and the Hungarian even did not put any sign telling what is thr story behind this monument.
Very nice memorial. Very nice memorial - was nice to see that there are still flowers and other things that people come and place there. Amazing view of the river and Buda side.
Πολύ συγκινητικό! Very moving!. I found this monument accidentally. I knew the story of the Jew's execution. It is an alive piece of the history.

A very simple, moving tribute. Bring the tissue paper if you are planning to visit this unique tribute in Budapest. It is very well done and very simple. However it is pretty sad too. It will really make you think. Kudos to Budapest for this first rate memorial to a sad time in our planet's history.
Beautiful tribute. The shoes are in the bank of the Danube river in honour of the Jewish people who were lined up and shot here. Beautiful tribute.
A sad reminder. Well worth a visit. Set on the Danube across from the parliament building. A poignant reminder of the atrocities of war.

Moving. A simple memorial for all the Hungarian Jews who were killed during the Holocaust. If you're not looking for it, you might walk right by. It is always important to remember the history when you're traveling through such cities. Beautifully done.

A simple yet moving memorial. This is a very simple memorial to Jews killed in Budapest during WWII, but it is incredibly moving and somber in its simplicity. The location is easy to find along the Pest side of the Danube between Parliament and Chain Bridge. I agree with other reviews that you need to stop by/walk by and reflect on the memorial, driving or cruising by does not cut it.

A sad story. As we walked back from the Parliament along the banks of the danube I saw these pairs of shoes sitting on the edge of the river . As I walked closer I realised they were made of metal and that some of them had flowers or tealights in them. I saw the plaque and read it."To the memory of the victimsshot into the danubeby arrow cross militiamenin 1944-45"Those empty shoes of adults and children were very moving and thought provoking. What a very fitting monument to those poor souls
Powerful Art Installation. A very tragic reminder of the carnage during the Second World War. Take tram 2 to get there, right beside paraliment.

Poignant. Very inspiring and moving - the memorial is simple and subtle, but powerful. Budapest's history during this time was unpleasant, but this acknowledgement and representation is brave and beautiful.

what we all should remeber...... This is hardly and Attraction but rather a monument. No matter which religion or nationality you are. It is so sad when you come to imagine how all this was. Terrible.On another note - what stiked me on the Embankment near the Parliament is that there are NO FENCES along the embankement - one can easily step down on slippery road or during night walking or a kid can run down or a wheel-chair! How reckless and irresponsible from the local authorities perspective. The sharp rocks below some 6 meters deep will break bones as minimum with a high possibility of fatal outcome! Definetely should be taken care of! Local municpality should be informed about it.
Sobering. Took a while for us to find the shoes but I am glad that we persevered. They are a sobering reminder of the atrocities that man is able to inflict on fellow human beings .
A moving scene. A moving scene for all that understand and a must see when in Budapest. The bank of the river isn't to busy so a good photo op.

Incredibly moving . How anyone could say that this was difficult to find, I do not know, turn left standing on the Elizabeth bridge (Pest side and facing Pest) and walk for 10 minutes. The shoes were incredibly moving. It is important that everyone who visits Budapest sees them. If the plaque isn't enough, research it. Although I feel it is pretty self explanatory.
So sad. This landmark is a must see. Visit the House of Terror first then visit this and reflect on all you have learned.
Unique Understated Holocaust Memorial. The row of bronze shoes are evocative. Read about it to understand the history. Right by Parliament, but walk there. A drive-by or cruise-by is not adequate.

everyday objects can be so moving. Seeing a row of shoes stuck on the river bank and thinking it was someone's shoes, and that someone was kidnapped and killed because of racism, that's worth the visit. It's 5 minutes from the Parliament, on the same side of the Duna river

amazing walking down the Danube Promanade in the night. totally safe even for 13 ladies like us, we never feel uncomfortable. the view and the lights of the city is just amazing. You can easily reach there by foot from the Chain Bridge in 5 minutes.

truly touching.... difficult not to be moved from this!. Monument in commemoration of jewish people shot and pushed in the river during the second world war timeline.
it is really touching because You can fell the brutality and the pain of these people... almost abandoned as these shoes.
really worthy and really intense

Very sad art exhibit!. This is an art exhibit on the edge of the Danube. It consists of many shoes: men's, women's and children's shoes - all of which have been bronzed and placed on the edge of the river in the location where the Jews of Budapest were lined up and forced to remove them prior to toppling into the river after being shot!
Very sad memorial. Makes me very glad I was born where I wasA very sad and poignant memory to the Jewish people who were killed here

A thought provoking memorial on the banks of the Danube. My family and I visited the Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial. We actually found it by chance as we walked along the banks of the river. We found it thought provoking and left the site wanting to know more....

The Horrors of War!. This is a very emotional sight. You don't need words, the sight tells the story of the war. Children, women and men lined up on the bank of the river and shot! The Hungarians created the memorial well after the war. The shoes all in a row, now to tell the story.They are all lined up on the bank of the Danube, a touching memorial to those sacrificed to Hitler.
Sad occasion. Didnt know what the relevance of the "shoes" was. Took a few pictures. Read inscription. Very sad place.
thought provoking. Very thought provoking memorial, where people had lit candles amongst the shoes. Easy to find if you head towards Parliament buildings they are just on the water edge.

found it. No one to avoid a challenge, I set out to find this memorial. We were watching out for it from the cruise boat on the river and once we located it went for a closer look. Very moving.To find it go to the Pest side of the river and walk towards the Hungarian Parliament building along the bank of the river. The building on your right before Parliament is a Bank, the shoes are on your left at the river side. They are made of metal and nailed to the edge of the promenade. Well worth a visit.

Know the history. The shoes simply and powerfully tell the story of the killing of the Jewish people by the Germans. A reminder that they were not only killed but beforehand stripped of even their clothing and shoes.

Simple Yet Thought Provoking. I would recommend doing your research on this memorial before visiting as there is very little byway of a plaque to explain what the shoes represent. Once you understand the connotations of the shoes, it's very moving and we would highly recommend taking some time here to reflect.

Not To be Missed. Budapest is a wonderful city full of beautiful buildings - great restaurants and bars and the most welcoming of people . Take a moment to reflect how lucky you are by paying your respects at this memorial . It won't ruin your holiday it will enhance it. We should never forget

Simplistically beautiful. These little shoes are meant to commemorate Jews who were often chained together and shot into the Danube during the second World War. Really sad, but also really beautiful. Some people have left little trinkets in the shoes. It's a very serene place - too bad there's a main road right behind it!

so sad. At first they look like real shoes and then you realise that they are made from metal. it would have been much better to have a board explaining why they were there. Apparently the Germans lined up Jew/Hungarians and shot them so they fell into the Danube So sad
Simple but beautifull. Commemorates the Jews how were deported to Auschwitz or killed in Budapest during the second world war.
powerful. Simple, small sculptures with a lot of meaning behind it. The Danube as its background. It felt very emotionally and everyone admired the memorial in silence.
Thought provoking. Take the time to find out the story behind the shoe memorial as it is quite emotional once you know the history

Very Touching. This was a very touching experience for my family. The flowers, wreaths, and other ribbons placed around the shoes for remembrance is a great remembrance that they are never forgotten. Great historical lesson!

An original memorial. We were a bit disappointed with this memorial - perhaps because the shoes were surrounded by old flowers and candles etc. Worth walking by as you admire the Danube and the views but not as moving as I expected.

Simple memorial very thought provoking. I knew this memorial was a part of the city and on an afternoons walk along the Danube we almost stumbled across this memorial. It's a very simple and well thought out memorial to the Jews killed on this spot.Before walking in to the memorial my boyfriend and I were chatting and as soon as we saw the shoes we fell silent and took it in. It was thought provoking and interesting. There was no information at the site that I could see to tell you the background to the memorial which may be good for some people who do not know what happened.

Memorial site for a tragic episode. Shoes sculpted on the promenade along the banks of the Danube as a reminder for those who were mercilessly killed during World War II. It is a site that depicts one of the many tough times Hungary has been through during the wars.

A moving moment. I've been lucky as I walked there in a sunny afternoon.
It has been really moving, something highly recommended!

Memorial Site. This is a really good Memorial to see and should be preserved better. Alot of people over the world have left old candles and little things that has left the area looking a bit messy and unkept.The trash didn't take away from the story at all however it did make it a bit of an eye sore.
Powerful Simplicity. This monument is powerful, so simple yet full of emotions, by the Danube it reminds us the past, our history and alerts us sillently for our future...

Definitely should see. This was a very well done memorial to the Jews who were shot at the Danube. It was simple and very moving. I went early in the morning and later in the day and each time there were not alot of people there which was good.

Very moving. Very near to the Parliment building on the bank of the river. Just stayed a few minutes to reflect on the actions that caused the deaths of so many. Many people had left flowers and candles as a mark of respect.

emotional. had a stroll down the Danube and came across this...not much information there, but the 1944/45 victims were told to take off their shoes and then were shot into the Danube...when looking at the childrens shoes and the various sizes etc, its very moving
shoes. I had to come to Hungary to see that. It is the most touching tribute to the holocaust victim that I've ever seen. Take a moment there, feel all the emotions that arise!
so moving. .. A must to visit, close to Parliament building. So moving and sad, glad we made the effort to find out about the history.

Incredibly moving . . . .. We visited this monument to remember the atrocities that occurred here. What a tragedy -- these people were asked to remove their shoes because the shoes were valuable, but not their lives. We must remember these events and prevent them from being repeated.

Poignant reminder of the Jewish Holocaust. Along the waterfront just before you reach Kossuth Sq. And Parliament is this simple and poignant tribute to the Jewish victims of fascist oppression There is a row of 60 pairs of shoes of Jews who had been thrown into the Danube by members of the Hungarian Arrow Cross party who collaborated with the Nazis in 10 months of 1944 in killing and deporting up to 450000 Jews in Hungary. The shoes were recovered from the river, cast in bronze and embedded in the concrete and scattered in a random fashion. Very moving.

So Simple, So Powerful. What an excellent concept. Simple yet very effective. All the little brass shoes are so lifelike. Certainly triggers the imagination, yet can be fascinating for children without being ghoulish or triggering "difficult" questions. Very pleased we saw it.

Monument for the Holocast victims. It is a throw-back to the atrocities of the Hungarian ArrowCross (Nazi) party when they herded the jews to the bank of the Danube by the Parliament building, made them remove their shoes(valuable commodity during the war) and then shot them, falling into the Danube. Very moving simple memorial for jews and non-jews alike.
moving, lovely tribute. quite hard to find but so glad we did. Lots of pairs of shoes with so much meaning behind them - perfect

Moving. I had seen photos of the memorial online and was most curious about it. I was very pleased to see that it was drawing quite a steady crowd of visitors. Interestingly, our tour guide never mentioned the memorial and I had to ask. Quite a moving tribute and worth the effort to see.

Beautiful. Such a nice place, so picturesque. A must do when in Budapest. They aren't that easy to spot, you've got to be looking for the to find them, you won't just bump in to them accidentally.
Truly beautiful memorial
Nice. A lovely memorial and nice place to sit in memory of the people who lost there lives in the war. Worth a visit :)
Moving. Just a stroll down the river from the parliament building is this small memorial, it's very moving to think what happened here and how these people must have suffered.

History. If you are in Budapest it is worth to visit this (sad) Historical place. Although you have to have the knowledge or read about what happened here before you visit this place.
There is no information table where you could read about the place. If you have the Budapest visitor's book then you are fine :)
Thought provoking. This is such a poignant sight. Shoes along the river bank. A reminder of the men, women and children who were shot into the river during the atrocities of WW2.

Shoes were worth the walk. From tripadvisor saw these were worth a visit, however, none of our friends who had visited Budapest had seen them. We found them very easily, getting off the Big Bus at Chain bridge, and then walking to the right for a few hundred metres. Terrible to know what happened here!!

Simple, sad and a stunning memorial. Of all the memorials to victims of oppression this is the most simple and the most sad I have seen. Based on a real event which saw many people shot and pushed shoeless into the Danube the sculpture has created the shoes of men , women and children and placed them on the very edge of the river.

A very touching memorial of war time atrocities. A very touching memorial of war time atrocities. Iron shoes are placed on the River Banks displaying what it would look like in real life. This is definitely worth a visit, and the walk along the river is very nice.

So Moving. As you leave the Parliament building opposite the Danube, take care as you cross the very busy road to the bank of the Danube and turn left. After 8-10 minutes walk you will see this moving memorial. New shoes, old shoes, children's shoes, all made of bronze. The footwear that Hungarian Jews were forced to take off, on the orders of the Arrow Cross during WW11, who fired at women, old people and children, people from all walks of life, before throwing them, lifeless, into the Danube. So moving and so, so sad.
Very Moving. While the setting is beautiful, this serves to remind us of how terrible life can be even in such settings. It is definitely a place for reflection and remembrance.

What a memorial!. To think this Memorial represents, people shot and pushed into the Danube by the AVO, was just incredible; I understand other reviewers who don't like the flowers or candles but for us it didn't detract from the emotions the memorial evoked.
Very moving memorial. We all fell silent as soon as we saw the memorial. It's very sad and very moving. Definitely worth seeing.

Bad. It's a wonderful memorial, but it's very degraded. There are lots of stuff that people put inside the shoes and they're all very dirty, guess they should clean it more often. It makes you think about all the things that happened there, but it should be better preserved.
A must see!. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade Memorial is a real must see! I cannot explain the emotions that will come over you. It is one of most moving memorials you will see.
Melancholy. This really was quite a sad exhibit. Beautiful with the river glistening in the background but really quite sad.

Speaks for Itself. You don't need a tour guide to tell you anything here, this monument is breathtaking, you can feel the history. Yes it is small but it definitely means a lot. Very disappointed it is not on the tourist map, thankfully we knew about it before walking around.
nothing to see. I walked around but I didn't notice them, the Danube view and the buildings around are dominating all the scene there
Very moving memorial. We didn't know this was there as we made our way to the parliament building. Worth stopping and contemplating why it was put there.

Reminds us to be thankful for each and every day. I do not think that anyone would fail to be moved by the sight of this line of shoes on the bank of the Danube. Surely the little pair of children's boots brings a tear to any eye. This memorial to a dark period in Hungary's history reminds us of the failings in humanity.
Emotive. Stunningly effective memorial to the jews who were shot on the Danube's bank by the fascist Arrow Cross Millitiamen during WW11 - truly haunting
visit. very sad to see but worth a visit, outside the parliament building. people leave candles inside the shoes the is a mixture of adult and children's shoes

Very Moving. As part of a guidebook walking tour, I wanted to pass by this memorial. Very moving and touching.. makes you contemplate the not so distant past history..you can sense this amongst all the visitors and by the flowers they are leaving for the victims. I had earlier visited the Great Synagogue, and the tour there really gives a good framework and reference for what has transpired with the Jews in Hungary. Requires that you go to the edge of the Danube down from the Promenade. A sobering contrast to the the freedoms we have today as traveling visitors to such a lovely city

One of the most profoundly moving holocaust memorials.. It is hard to imagine someone not being profoundly touched looking at these shoes and realizing that thousands of people had been made to remove their shoes before they were shot and tossed into the Danube river. Looking at the shoes you can see that these people came from all walks of life. There were elegant women's shoes, little children's shoes, worker's boots and everyday shoes in the style of the 1940's. It broke my heart to look at these shoes. It is a simple and moving memorial to these victims of the holocaust.

Moving testimonial. The line of shoes bronzed in place indicates their hasty removal. This memorial to Jewish victims shot and tossed into the Danube is more a shrine than monument. Flowers, candles and stones left in silent reverence for the victims add to the solemn recognition of the lives these shoes represent.
Very moving. Went to view these after seeing a replica in the Jewish synagogue was so moving to think why these shoes were there

Worth a visit. The closest stop to this memorial if travelling on the red line is no 15, from here it is approx a 6 minute walk along the Danube towards St Margaret's Island. There are no signs or plaques - you just literally come along these shoes. You cannot help but be moved by the significance of these cement shoes. Make sure to read up on them before you visit.
Very emotional. A sad and moving memorial to Jews murdered by the Nazis. It brought tears to my eyes. It was one thing I really wanted to see and didn't disappoint and really humanised the history.

Not so moving or sad. We were told to visit this place by friends who'd previously been to Budapest. In my opinion it's not worth the effort. We have previously been to "Another Place" on Crosby Beach - statues looking out to sea by Antony Gormley - and I found it very moving and a wonderful experience. So, it's not that I'm heartless or not moved by this sort of thing, just that this didn't "do it for me". Everyone's entitled to their own opinion.

Touching. Great attraction commemorating the Jews killed along thr river during WWII. Candles and flowers are placed in the shoes giving the site a more heartfelt appeal. It only takes a few minutes to see this sculpture, which is close to the Parliment blds.
sad and harrowing. a must visit in Budapest -- a sad and harrowing memorial to the holocaust. It is by the river in central Pest

Moving tribute, sadly spoiled. It may be me, but why on earth do people think that this moving tribute is enhanced by filling the shoes with tea candles, or more incredibly, using a shoe as a flower pot for a daffodil, is a good idea.Worth a visit.

Remarkable!. No words can describe the feelings one can have when you walk on the banks of Danube where these shoes are found. I am imagining the owners of the original shoes...there's lots of jewish memorial in the area if you walk in the inner part of the city away from the Danube. However, they are very pretty to look at and also interesting (that is, if you push the history to the side for a moment). It was bittersweet!

Very Moving and Sad!. As my Title says it is both Moving and Sad and a "must see" if visiting Budapest! Helps if you read up about the killing of the Hungarian Jews in January 1945 before you go ,to fill you in on the background!

A moving memorial. We walked here after a visit to the Holocaust Memorial Centre. These 2 visits suitably go together and not far to walk from each other. This was 2mins walk from the Parliament. It was particularly cold when we went, but harder still to imagine the -27oC condition when the Jews were stripped and shot into the Danube River. A moving piece of history that cost nothing to visit and pay a tribute to all the Jews who had died under such tragic circumstances.
a amusing line of metallic shoes by the Danube. When walking from the Parliament to the Erzsebet Hid, one can see a line of about 20 pairs of shoes on the border of the river, on the Pest side.

Nice Memorial. Very simplistic yet very clever! Worth visiting, does not take long to see the memorial, though we sat for a while and soaked it in. There are two plaques in the ground, one in English and one in Hungarian. Situated between the Danube and Parliament a good setting for some dramatic photographs as well!

Heartbreaking!. This modest memorial brought me to tears. Visit in respect of the victims!
Time for reflection so things like this never will take place again!!
Emotive. You must see this, it's an extremely emotive and poignant memorial to those whom lost their lives, sweet innocents.
Very fitting memorial. This is such a simple memorial but very poignant and thought provoking. Just take a moment to reflect on all the lost lives.

Touching -- worth a visit. A really powerful memorial. We sat on a bench for several minutes to look over the river.
I think I expected more of an exhibit, but there is a plaque in the ground next to the shoes.
Definitely worth the visit, especially if you are near the Parliament building anyway.
Thought provoking. This monument to European Jews was so moving! The shoes were so effective in their message of the thousands who died during this shameful time in history!
Moving and poignant. Free to all and such a powerful testimony to such a dark part of Hungary's history. Incredibly moving.

Cool Memorial. We were walking towards the Parliament when we stumbled across all of these shoes lined up along the river. It is not labeled to provide content information or draw attention. However, if you know the history of the Jews who were shot into the river during the Holocaust, it is really powerful. It is against quite a beautiful backdrop with the castle on the other side of the river. If you are in the area during the day, it is definitely worth checking out.

Touching location. A monument memorializing the dark side of Hungarian history. The life-sized shoes, especially the child-sized shoes, were very touching. People leave flowers here to remember the dead.
Real history!. This is real history! The scene is that shocking, but if you know the story you will feel the impact of this monument.
Tribute. might not be a major attraction, but a very good and important historical venue paying tribute to the Jews who were killed during the war...
Different. An interesting and thought provoking memorial reminding people of a what a cruel world we live in. Worth a visit, if you can find it!

A must-see. This is a lesser-known attraction among Budapest sights, but an incredibly important one at that. The memorial honors Jews who were made to strip and then shot into the Danube, killed during the Holocaust. The memorial is incredibly touching and beautiful. In any season, the Danube and the beautiful sights such as the castle on the other side of the river offer a pretty backdrop to this horrifying yet also very still scene. Sadly, the markers are not at all obvious so some people who happen upon the shoes think them more amusing than anything else, not recognizing their meaning and significance. That is perhaps the one downside of the site, it is so nicely embedded in its surroundings that you can almost miss it and not appreciate it for what it is.The area is a bit hard to access, but worth the trouble. I recommend approaching it from the south near the Hungarian Academy of Sciences at the Széchenyi István tér. At the north end of that square near the tram stop (Tram #2, very convenient for accessing this area) along the Danube, you can take a crosswalk over to the river bank and walk north. The tricky part about approaching the memorial from the north near the Parliament is that there is not such an obvious spot to cross the street and walk south.

Somber. After we toured the parliament, we went out the doors of the visitor center turned left and walked for several blocks along the Danube River. There are sixty pairs of shoes made out of iron in the style of the 1940's. Some are men's, women's and children's shoes with messages, votive candles and flowers tucked inside the shoes. The memorial is to the Hungarian Jews who were shot in the winter of 1944-1945 by members of the Arrow Cross Party. During that time, the Germans terrorized the Jewish people. Shooting the Jewish people by the river occured so there would be no evidence. Sometimes the victims were told to remove their shoes before they died. It is a moving memorial
Worth a stop. Lovely little momument, quite sad when you think what it's for but a lovely note to their history. Worth a stop if you're up that way.
Very Emotional!. Not like your average memorial if the past. These bronze shoes fixed to the side of the Danube really gave you a insight to what took place here. Amazing!

The most beautiful memorial i ve ever seen. I loved This place. It was so dramatic. We went there to see the sunset. It was amazing to see the sun going down with the parliament on our backs and the shoes by the river. The memorial makes you rethink everything without Being so literall. My favourite sight of budapest

Not so easy to understand. You should read before arriving about the Holocaust of Hungarian Jews during the Second World War, in order to understand this unique monument. Close to the Parlament, a dark side of hungarian history. Should be visited after visiting the Holocaust Memorial Museum at Pava Street.
Haunting. A wonderful tribute to the poor souls that were shot and pushed into the river during the war. Very well done. Worth a view.

A moving tribute to remind us of the horrors of mankind.. What can I say! The bronze shoes placed just outside the stunning House of Parliament and on the banks of the River Danube, are a stark reminder to show us of just how cruel mankind can be. Very sobering indeed.

Simple - but so moving. We had heard about this - but nearly missed it as we were walking to visit Parliament. My husband brought my attention to it - and we both felt so emotional. We cannot understand anti-semetic hatred - and to see the discarded, empty shoes at the point where these Jews were slaughtered made you want to weep. The simplicity spoke volumes..... We are so sorry....

Really moving !!!. The shoes on the Danube Memorial is truly moving, but only if you know the story behind the shoes before seeing them. There is no sign or memorial plaque to tell the story. One needs to do a tour of the Jewish Quarter in order to understand what the memorial is actually about. I knew the story and visited on an icy day with a cold wind blowing, but not nearly as cold as the day the people to whom the memorial stands were thrown into the Danube, stripped of their clothes in -27 C. weather. Really something to see. It's near the Parliament building, so do it together.

So evocative. This is such a simple idea but so powerful. The shoes were left by the Danube by Jewish people murdered by machine gun and their bodies disappeared into the river. Yet they are not forgotten, amid the bronze shoes are real shoes and tea lights and stones brought by people who are reflecting about the tragedy and honouring the dead.It is near Parliament but it is much safer to walk from the Chain bridge onto the riverbank as the embankment road is busy and fast.
very sad. What can I say loads of shoes on side of river very sad to think what happened to the people who owned them
Must See. If I were visiting Budapest and only had time for one attraction I would have to see this. Very heartbreaking but necessary to remember what took place here.

Impressive and shouting to heaven and to the humanity kind. I think , this artistic perforance of shoes, i am not so sure, that it can be called a sculpture , is one of the most expresive enviromental works of the Hallacaust subject, in my oppinion. It tells directly the story, which took place on that beautifull bank of the Danube in one of the most tragic moments of history. The only thing you can do, looking to this masterpiece is to stay silent and think of what happend here and why. It is a sad moment,in someones visit, but it is full of respect in the honour of the cca. 600000 jews , who had been deported from Hungary during the W.W.2 to the detrermination and working camps by the nazzi forces. You see hundreeds of inocent men, women and children, executed by evil powers and thrown, barefeet into the huge river ,just for being jews...It is a moment of prayer in the .memory of my grandies, aunts and uncles, half brother and sister and many - many potential relatives, my parent's friends, neighbours and thousands of my people.
Moving. A simple memorial to the Jews murdered by Hungarian Nazi's. Very poignant. The shoes make you see the human cost.
very touching. One of many Holocaust memorial around Europe. This is an understated and very evocative piece which all can relate to. Just be careful not to get too close to the edge..
Moving. Seeing the shoes lying at the waters edge is very sad knowing they signify such death and horror. Found it very moving.

Thought-provoking, touching. Only a few metres from the Parliament building you will find a collection of shoes made of bronze commemorating Jews who were killed just because of being Jews. If you do not know the background, the shoes may seem a bit ridiculous, but knowing why the shoes are there you start thinking about the mankind, about what the man is able to do ...... Touching, gripping, moving. Worth stopping for a while and asking questions about us and ourselves.

Desperately sad. A very visual and memorable reminder of the appalling way in which so few decades ago Hungarian Jews were lined up beside the Danube, shot and pushed in. So very, very sad. We must never do it again - yet it happens again in so many places to so many groups identified as "the enemy".

What a feeling. My boyfriend and i wanted to take a walk on the bank of Denube, when we saw these shoes just standing there! It was night so some of the candles were lighted!We found that monument very interesting, so we took a few photoes! But i didn't quite understand what they represent until some passengers explained to us, that all of these people were killed and thrown in Danube! And i can tell you one thing, there are shoes of rich and poor, of men and women, children and elderly! I am not a sensitive type but that view frost my bones! Definitely the best monument of ww2 i ever saw!
A MUST.. Very sad and eye opening, but definitely a must to go see. Walk along the river and its near parliament.

To understand.... it requires few minutes, but a stop there and reflect on the past facts... it´s a very touching place. You will understand cruelty of the man and try to imagine what happened please..
Powerful. Its easy to see while walking along the Danube on the Pest side near Parliament, so you might as well go see it. It is a powerful reminder of the atrocities of the Holocaust.

Worth the 10-15 minutes you'll spend there. This memorial consists of a line of bronze shoes of various sizes and styles comparable to those worn by the Jews who were lined up along the Danube and summarily shot for being Jewish or Jewish sympathizers. It is thought-provoking and beautifully done. You will not regret pausing as you walk down the river-front path to consider those whose lives were cruelly lost on the banks of the Danube. It is haunting and touching all at once. It is on the Pest side of the Danube River about 100 m south of the Parliament Building.
Moving tribute. A moving memorial due to it's simplicity which portrays the totally unnecessary loss of innocent lives in an unhuman way perfectly.

Thought Provoking Memorial. This memorial was one of the top sights on our trip to Budapest. The emotions and thoughts evoked by the simple sight of empty worn shoes waiting for their owners still haunt me. In terms of reminders of the cost of war and the atrocities committed during WWII it is right up there with the Anne Frank House. Everyone should see this and read the story behind the history.

Impressive work of art. Walking around you can't miss it. It's along the river and i believe it is to commemorate the victims of war who were executed there. Very strong symbolism to have these shoes standing there.

Definately worth the stroll. Just walk along the Danube and pause for a moment. Very clever and moving piece of public art. you'll find it on the Pest side just between parliament building and chain bridge.

Moving. A simple but effective reminder. To see this memorial with all different types of shoes is very moving having read the detail of why they are there. The most moving was that there were a pair a young child's shoes included in the memorial which I did not expect and also did not think would affect me so much. As said this is a simple but very effective memorial to the unfortunate people who suffered unimaginable suffering

Excellent piece of art.... Excellent piece of art by the Danube side...
The artist "caught" the idea....
Unfortunately very few can understand...
Just pass by there, worthy to see this " monument " ....
Shouldn't be missed. Moving tribute to all those unfortunate souls butchered during the war. Will only take up a few minutes of your time but will surely leave an impression

Very moving sight to see. I came across this site by accident as I was waiting for a streetcar that runs parallel to the Danube River. It is not a very large display but gets the point across. It was very moving and makes one think of all the horrors that went on. Put this on your itinerary when in Budapest.

Nice moving experience. Although iyllmprobably take you longer to get there than the actual time you'll spend there, it's still a memorial you just can't miss whilst in Budapest. It's filled with sadness and emotion and makes you want to enjoy life even more.

Interesting. You don't have to spend much time here unless you feel like some reflection. Sobering reminder of history and events that occured not so long ago. This is just ouside the walk up the river to the Parliment Building.

A time for reflection. These shoes had quite a profound effect on me. We sat and watched the power of the river and thought about the horrors it had witnessed and hidden over the years. No doubt also bringing solace to those suffering beyond endurance. The small personal gifts and plants left in the shoes gave them life and meaning. How fitting this sculpture is to show respect for those gone before.
So moving. This is a must see, incorporate it into your walk along the river. The friends we were staying with told us about this installation and its meaning.
In memory of millions....do not miss.. A very strong experience.Located on the banks of the danube within walking distance of main hotels area.Do not miss

Powerful . This is a beautiful tribute and well worth a visit. We hopped on the tram to find it, got off at the parliament building and headed to the river. It is a powerful display and you need a few minutes to take it all in and remember those poor souls.
Pause for thought. Tiny and easily missed. It's a telling reminder of the inhumanities of WW2. Read up the story before you go, it's worth it.

Very moving - a must see. I, like I suspect many others, was unaware of this very small but very moving memorial before I arrived in Budapest. In memorial to the Jews who were shot and then thrown into the Danube, this very plain but poignant memorial is a must see during your time in the city. It is about 200m from the Parliament building, on the east bank. It was one of those moments when you think "I wish I had read up a little more on this before I came here". A reminder of mans inhumanity to man and of the evil that some are capable of.
Very moving if you read up about the history. Read up about the reason the shoes on the Danube are there. Very moving storey. Shame there is not a description why near the shoes.

Quick attraction on the way to Parliament. I like the idea for the memorial but there were not a lot of signs describing the event. It's best to just walk by this memorial on your way to the Parliament building, snap a couple pictures and move on.
A moving place. The shoe monument on the banks of the Danube not far from the Parliament House is very poignant. It reminds us of how fortunate we are. We should not forget other people's sacrifices.

Dont forget to visit the shooes on Danube. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade is a memorial to the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. Just passed the chain bridge on the way to the Parliament buildings you will find the shoes on the side of the river.It is a simple and very piognant holocaust memorial - very haunting and touches the heart.must see in Budapest

100% History. Once you visit it, you will learn more about history of the region than from dozens of lectures. Please go there and give you ten silent minutes to remember. You will never forget the moment.

Had to Include This On Our Trip. Luckily, I had read about this memorial while researching our trip, because no one in Budapest was offering it up. Several tours of the city failed to mention it and I received spotty answers to direct queries. We finally hopped off of the second tour and said that we'd find our way back to the hotel. It was a pleasant walk through one of the Christmas markets to the banks of the Danube. Once we arrived at the river, we had to decide which way to turn. It's on the Pest side of the river just below (south of) the Parliament Building. My family thought it a bit cold to go off on a wild goose chase, but were in awe when we got there. It's akin to the silence one notes worldwide in proximity to such thought-provoking monuments. This one was showing a little age and could stand some TLC, but I wouldn't have missed it for anything.

Worth Going To See. A sad but very moving memorial. It's interesting to see, but hard to understand the cruelty of human behaviour. A place to think and reflect. The sculptures of the shoes are beautifully done. Not difficult to get to. On the Pest side across from the Parliament building. On the banks of the Danube. I felt it was worth taking the time to see this.

Simple but moving. Just passed the chain bridge on the way to the Parliament buildings you will find the shoes on the side of the river. There is a plaque on the ground in English explaining why they are there. It's nice to see some flowers and candles have been left and not rubbish.

Very moving and poignant memorial. This memorial is comprised of a collection of bronze life-size shoes lined up on the Pest bank of the Danube. It memorializes European Jews who were ordered to remove their shoes before being shot and dumped in the river during WWII
Poignant reminder. A short section of river wall with shoes stuck down. By the size of the shoes they were chilrens shoues. A reminder of chilren lost during troubled times
Such a poignant and fitting memorial. Budapest is full of sculptures and this is a very poignant memorial to the Jews who were shot into the Danube during the WWII.
Very Emotional. This is essential viewing these shoes are a poignant reminder off the awful times the poor people of the city had.

Moving. definitely hits your emotions!
Worth a visit
The best memorial I have seen due to the impact it gives

Moving and poignant. Where the Nazis have been is usually marked by cruelty and unnecessary suffering. Here are shoes in memory of those shot by the local Nazis and left to fall into the Danube just after Hungary was invaded by the Germans - after joining the war on their side. As I said, poignant and unnecessary..

Brief Visit. Walked along the river in the evening - this is on the Pest side just along from the Parliament building (away from Margaret Island). Definitely worth visiting - really good sculpture and a moving story.

So sad !! Worth seeing !. We walked miles to see the shoes ...but so glad that we did, it was so sad !! We were really touched by it ! It is well worth seeing...beautifull to see how people still put flowers & candles..and sweets in the childrens boots in remembrance!
Simple but striking. A simple but striking row of sculptures along the river as a reminder of Jews shot and killed at that spot. The pair of baby shoes is particularly poignant.

Thrilling, exciting, a punch in the butt. We could not leave the place, so minimalist yet so meaningful
We could imagine the thousands of Jews standing on the Danube side, being shot and thrown to the water
Family memories remember the water turn red...
We lit a candle and prayed for those victims souls
A must !!!

The most moving memorial. Everibody has to see it to feel how important thing the humanism is!!
Take a little time to thinking about and against the most hateful human misdeed!!

Very emotive. We were walking along the bank when we came across the shoes and at first did not know what they were. We read the information and saw that they represent the people who were lined up against the bank, told to remove their shoes, and then shot by the Nazis. The installation is thought provoking and deeply moving in a subtle way.

A thought provoking memorial. Went today to see Shoes on the Danube. It is based in a beautiful location but the simplicity of the memorial had a huge impact. To see all the shoes including those of children was very moving. It made you think about what the people may have been thinking in their last moments by the river. We visited the Holocaust Museum yesterday which made this even more thoughtful for us.
Makes you think. Very moving. Makes you think about what happened in the war to the Jews and this brings it to life. Everyone was very respectful.

A living reminder..... This is a good but sobering reminder of mans inhumanity to man. This is the site where Jews were tied together -one was shot and both we're thrown into the Danube. One eventually died from the gun shot or drowned and the other just drowned. Best time to visit is first thing in the morning to avoid the crowds for a few moments of quiet reflection.

Very moving. knowing what the shoes symbolise and thinking about what people must have gone through, it was a moving sight. I was surprised at how many there were even those of young children. I'm glad I visited this memorial whilst on my trip to Budapest.

Beautiful. A really thought provoking tribute to those that were shot into the river. The memorial is framed with the chain bridge on one side and parliament on the other leading to many beautiful pictures being taking. I found the memorial got quite busy with other tourists so it might be better to visit early in the day.
Poignant reminder. Rarely can such a simple memorial conjure up so strong an emotion. A chilling and poignant reminder of man's barbarity
Very very moving monument. It is hard not to be affected by this sad memorial to many brave people. With events in Europe at the moment all should see this

holocaust memorial. can you imagine that hundreds of Hungarian jews were shot in the Danube by Hungarian soldiers end of 1944? they were forced to take off their dresses and shoes before they were killed. visit this memorial of those many and think of them in silence for a moment

Unique. Riverwalks are usually amazing but Budapest has done a better job and made it interesting - especially for photographers by installing cemented shoes on the sidewalk. If you are in the center of the city, you might need to make some effort to get here but it is worth it. For the views and for this unique concept. The history attached to the shoes will obviously fascinate the war buffs. It is a place where you can sit and introspect for an hour or two.

A moving experience. I knew the shoes were in Budapest but stumbled on them by accident while walking along the Danube. Reading the history and seeing how well these shoes represent such a horrible time in European history was a very moving experience for me. It is simple, yet powerful.

Not To Be Missed. This memorial is very simple, just some bronze shoes (men's, women's, and children's) seemingly randomly placed along the waterfront, but it was probably the most creative and moving 're-enactment', if that is the right word for it, of one of the many, many tragic events committed against the Jews during World War 2, that I have experienced in my travels. There are a multitude of memorials now, in Germany and other countries where Jews were persecuted and systematically murdered, and they all are powerful and unique in their own ways. And, of course, a visit to Auschwitz or the other death camps, or the Prague ghetto, among others, is a very painful reminder of the criminal and inhumane treatment of Jews that sadly continues today. Other reviewers have done a great job of describing the shoes and the setting along the Danube, so no need to repeat it, but I can't stress enough how vital it is for EVERYONE to experience it. Hopefully it will change you for the better.
Truly historical. Historical memorial of the holocaust, one of the jewish highlights of Budapest, I am happy to have been here along the river Danube.

A thought provoking memorial. Its not often when you see a memorial that it directly relates to something that happened.....an artists interpretation on a memorial is usually beautiful and stylish not directly representative. This is different. Its hard not to imagine the people standing on the banks of the Danube being told to remove their shoes. Its both thought provoking and genuinely touching.

Shoes no the danube. It was a very emotional experience to see the the shoes on the Danube. The istalation is so simple and at the same time so forceful. It was so upsetting after 70 year to hear of what and how the Hungarian Nazi party treated the Jews of Budapest just before the end of the war.This is a must for every human being to see and remember what some people could do to other human being.

Poignant. Near the Parliament building by the Danube is a collection of bronze shoes and boots depicting the foot ware of executed Jews who had to remove their shoes and boots before being murder and their bodies dumped in the river by The Arrow Cross Movement a group who modelled themselves on the Nazis. Very sad that such a beautiful country endured like many other, unbearable horrors.
beautiful and sad. I felt sad just thinking about the people who died there,we where sitting there and could just cry...but definitely must see.

Poignant Memorial. I've read some reviews here which can only be described as cynical. I do not know what some people expect to see but often the most simple of tributes are the most forceful. This is one. It takes a heart of stone not to be moved by this

Very moving. I only had a few hours after business and decided to pick just a few sights. So after visiting St Stephen's basilica I made my way to the Danube and to the sites where the shoes are. It was a sunny day but not too busy and I had time to sit and contemplate the fates and stories represented by the shoes on display.

A thought provoking memorial made more real by the use of something we can all relate to. we had walked past this memorial on another day because there are no signs to point it out. Found it today and the use of such mundane items to represent the poor innocent people who were made to leave their shoes before being shot and falling into the Danube make this a brilliant memorial. I personally felt humbled,sad and angry all at the same time and can't understand the people standing amongst the shoes "smiling"! It seemed somehow disrespectful. A must see if you are in Budapest but obviously not a happy place.

Moving memorial for a sad event. Yes, you have to understand the history and the purpose for this to have any meaning. Budapest has had lots of tragedy; and this is good memorial to remember the autocracies experienced during WWII as the shoes were valued more than the people by the Arrow Cross.
A powerful memorial. This is a powerful memorial and reminder of another time. Distance in time, but yet very crucial in how we should behave towards each other.
Very moving. Such a moving Memorial to go and see. Its hard to take in what happened to the Hungarian people during the war.

Must see and remember. I really wanted to see this, as have just read a book called "the Danube Ran Red" which tells about this time in WW2. On the day we saw them it was snowing I think this added to the whole feel, just to try and imagine what it was like!!! Very touching.
So moving. A powerful and shocking reminder of the not so distant past. It really does make you stop and think.

Unique and clever memorial. Admittedly this isn’t an ‘attraction’ as such but a memorial, created in a unique and interesting way. As such there isn’t a huge amount to see but despite that it’s hard to agree with any of the negative reviews. The memorial of metal shoes manages to convey the message and sad history very well and especially when there isn’t a large amount of people about is quite hard hitting.It’s located on the bank of the river almost directly opposite the Parliament building. Make sure you cross the road to the river side much further south though else you’ll be faced with the near impossible task of running across a very busy road and jumping the crash barrier! It’s about fifteen metres long in total so isn’t totally obvious but worth spending a little time appreciating the message and sitting on the wall admiring for a short while. Even if you don’t ‘get’ it at all it’s a chance to watch some boats sail by.
Nice memorial. Nice walk on Danube with some to think about . . . No matter where You start at the Parliament or At the ChainBridge, walk pass by these and stop to remember, please.

Simple and powerful. Walking towards the chain bridge, this simple memorial to those killed simply stopped me in my tracks. It vividly brought to life what would otherwise be statistics on a page. Take the time for some thoughtful reflection on your way to look at Parliament or the castle district in Buda.

Remembering the past. This monument is along the water- you can see shoes from different people, ages and genders.. It makes you reflect on what happened and it is a great representation of that part of history.Sad but also hopeful with flowers coming out of the bronzed shoes

If just to reflect, and remember. We started at the chain bridge and went over to the castle at Buda. Once we were done on that side we came along the river bank to St Margaret's bridge and along the Pest side of the river to the shoes. This creates a lovely circular walk. The shoes themselves are beautifully poignant. Each pair or oft times a single shoe representing people from all walks of life. ... male, female, child, infant ... rich, poor, scholarly or uneducated. A sad and heart wrenching reminder of history at it's worst. A place to stop for a minute or two to reflect and remember...
so very poignant. This is a very sad and touching reminder of the atrocities that took place in Budapest and many other European cities during WWll, well worth a visit.

Danube memorial shoes. It is great reminder of past if hungary and not only and idea of shoes memorial is nice,but by the view of tourist it is nothing special and could be made as your extra attraction after parliament visit.not worth to visit if your only target are these shoes.

Powerful memorial. The Shoes on the Danube is a site not to miss. Make sure to understand the meaning. Budapest is full of meaningful statues. Best to hire a guide to help find them and get the story of each. Makes a fun afternoon.
Poignant. Worth visiting. Located by the side of the Danube by Houses of Parliament. A sight to take in and remember the victims of the nazis in World War II. Not to missed.
Chilling reminder of the past. This monument was a beautiful tribute to those who died. The shoes are so well done that it takes you a minute to realize that they haven't just been left behind.

Merciless Killing. The artist did a great job in depicting what happened to the innocent Jews who were told to take off their shoes on the river bank, and then shot so they would just fall into the river and be swept away. It was a very sad sight, I regret including it in my list of places to see in Budapest.

emotional tribute. Bronze shoes lining the bank of the Danube, all sizes even children, A stark reminder of WWII when the Nazis lined the Jews up on the banks of the river, made them remove their leather shoes, then shot them so their bodies fell into the river.
Emotional. This memorial is one of the most moving Holocaust Memorials that I have seen because of the simplicity of its message. The impact is greater if you first hear the story.

Moving & a great work of art!. Found the shoes when walking along the prom one evening & returned the following day, beautiful workmanship but more importantly make you stop and think about Hungarian history & indeed the continued suffering of many around the world today.

Quietly moving. Its very small and understated, on the banks of the Danube just below the Parliament building. It needs some context and I would strongly recommend seeing the House of Terror beforehand so you can understand just how awful things were.
A powerful symbol . A poignant reminder of the treatment of Budapest's jewish community. A good place to remember value the life you have.
Very Moving. wasnt expecting this sort of sculpture as we walked toward parliament, when the realisation of what it represents hits you, its quite heart wrenching

Good. Nice to see the memorial to the Jews who were killed and bodies dropped in the Danubee.
There was little sign posting however it was interesting to see and is a lovely place of remembrance of their lives.
Powerful statement. A good reminder of what people are capable of doing unto each other. Silent but powerful statement on the banks of the Danube.

Thoughtful tribute. I accidentally marked 2 stars in the quick rating. That is not at all how I feel. This humbling display of shoes is thought provoking and moving. We came upon the display as we were walking along the Danube. We stopped in silence and stayed for a very long time remembering those who died. Upon our return home, it seems to be a memory that continues to live on with us.

Poignant memorial. A very special memorial with understated power. Such a sad story and lovely to see so many people pay appropriate tribute. If you are near Parliament building, the shoes are almost in front of the building, along the river bank.
Tearful reminder of horrors of war.. Makes you stop and think of how terrible people can be and how we folks collectively must insure that these things never happen again.
Humbling. Moved me to tears, a quiet place of remembrance, a lovely view across the river too, we sat and watched people coming and goin.

Unique memorial. The shoes on the Danube was definitely on my list of things to see while in Budapest - literally stumbled across them while waking along the side of the Danube. I was surprised that there was no signs or anything to tell you any information but luckily I had researched before I visited Budapest. It's a really unique memorial and quite moving to see candles, ribbons and wreaths amongst the metal shoes and to think about the Jews who were lined up and killed there. Definitely worth a visit
So sad. To see the shoes of all shapes and sizes was very moving. But there should be a sign or an explanation . We didn't see this on any publicity
Unique idea. Its a place where the people were thrown into the river bank. its a commeration for their death. Its unique. Worth visiting when you come to visit Budapest.
Visit and think!. Time for quiet reflection and a commitment to fight the rise of the right! Would suggest this as must see.
wedding anniversary trip. it is a memorial which shows what happened should never be forgotten It is very poignant. Sad and really makes you think.

Moving Monument to Humanity. So simple, yet so profound. Located on the bank of the Danube a short distance from where our long-ship was docked. It gives pause to the bustle of one's everyday life. Let us always remember the horror of hate.

A schoking historical monument.. Shoes on the Danube Bank is a memorial dedicated to the victims of fascist hungarian war criminals who threw innocent Jews in the deadly cold river of Danube, in the last years of the Second World War. The monument itself consists of metallic shoes 'left' on the banks of the Danube river, as a remembrance to those who were thrown directly into watery death.
