The sight of it is very difficult to describe, because you are overwhelmed with negative emotions and the dreadfull image of people who suffered with no reason.One appeal to foregin tourists, please don't throw coins into shoes, because it's really inappropriate and disrespectful to the victims.
Must to visit!!!. Give this memorial site couple of minutes... It worth it!!! Simple in a way... But you certainly get moved by those shoes....

Haunting!. This sight of these shoes lying abandoned at the edge of the river made the hairs on my arms stand on end - especially the ones belonging to children. Brilliantly thought provoking and sombre memorial.

Something Everyone Should See. I didn't know about this attraction until our tour guide told us about it. After the guided tour, my wife and I walked from our ship to the memorial and took several photographs of all the shoes, individually and collectively. It's hard not to be moved by the sight of the children's shoes, and when we visited, several of the shoes had flowers in them. Just another example of human inhumanity to people not like themselves. When we were there, there was virtually no one else around. A must-see if you're in Budapest.
Chilling reminder of the past and fitting tribute to the victims.. What a simple way to remind us of the past atrocities committed during WWII and an appropriate way to honor the many victims.

Blown away by this memorial. Earlier in our day, we heard the story about how the Jews were walked from the Jewish Quarter to the river so when we so this memorial it really came to life. Try to get here when there are not as many people because it's during those quiet times when you realize the sense of loneliness that the citizens of that time must have faced.
Extremely moving. I have been to several Holocaust Memorials, but none have moved me like this one did. The memorial is very simple and very horrific at the same time. I do recommend it.
Thought provoking!. Sad to see the range of ages that were murdered here...including children! Good memorial for these Jewish lives. Though provoking.

Something different. On the way to the Parliament we found this monument!
Very interesting but I think that this area at night is a little spooky. Lights must be placed and a stand with the history of the spot
Understated and moving. A very fitting memorial in its simplicity and as a reminder that this is what remains of the people it represents. A quiet place by the parliament where you can sit and think.

If you don't know what this, just go!. This is one of the most unforgettable sculptures anywhere. it captures in iron on stone the day in 1945 when a desperate Germany lined up Hungary's Jews and shot them dead into the Danube. It is best seen by day, early in the morning, or at dusk, but is even visible after sunset, and Ive seen it at all of those times. some people leave their own memorials with the sculpted shoes, which represent the shoes that Jews had to leave on the banks when they were shot.

undedrwhelming for what it represents. This landmark is easy to miss unless you are looking for it along the river. It is the place where the Germans shot the Jewish citizens of Budapest and pushed them into the water of the Danube during the second WW. Nostaligic and takes time to fathom what really happened unless you are up on the history of the area
Shoes. Majestic and creepy memorial! It's not considered just like shoes, it makes us not to forget the horror of genocide.

Impressive. Touching. This is not a big place. Just metal shoes on the embankment you come across when walking. But the meaning is immense. A reminder that kind of recreates events that happened a while a ago but should never be forgotten. The monument that makes your heart clench and you stand there in a minute silence. Against the peaceful and magnificent background of modern Budapest view, this reminder of genocide is especially moving.

Very sad but must see . It's a walk up the Danube river and was very cold walking alongside the river at this time of the year.Candles left for memorial.Must see if your around.Surrounding streets are very silent

worth to visit. this jewish victim memorial statue located at danube promenade,visited this particular area last year,situated along danube river,great view ,you can walk from parliament ,the best time to visit around sunset time,when the city lights are on.

Very moving. A touching memorial on the river bank near Parliament. It honours the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen during WW2 - they were ordered to take off their shoes and were shot at the edge of the water so their bodies fell into the river and were carried away.

Extremely moving. Such a poignant visual reminder of the atrocities that took place hear. Very simple display of bronze shoes to depict the events during WW2 where Jewish victims were lined up on the bank of the Danube, ordered to take their shoes off, and then shot.

Very poignant, easy to miss. The monument is down on the banks of the river a little along from Parliament. We almost missed them as they are quite hidden. When we went there were lots of wreaths and flowers across the shoes showing this will never be forgotten.

Be sure to look. This very special memorial is located on the bank of the danube river near the parlament. It can be difficult to locate since there are no signs. The only thing near it is a plaque on the floor, only in Hebrew. I wonder if it's because the Hungarians are ashamed of their history ... It's a must visit for every Jew visiting Budapest and an important history lesson for everyone. Be sure to read about it beforehand because as I mentioned, there is no multilingual plaque or other form of explanation at the site. It's a very powerful sight.
Visit. If you are visiting Parliament, make sure you take a few minutes to visit (behind the Parliament building, to the left)
Interesting to see. We were looking for this place for some periid of tine. Interesting idea of such tragedical episode. Sugest to visit
Very poignant. Once you know the story of this tribute to the horrors of war a visit is a must. The horrors and the suffering of those poor souls is unimaginable

It is a sad memorial, but you need to know the history behind. To understand this memorial, background history will need to be learned first.It is a sad moment indeed to sit down there and try to replicate what happened in the past to the shoes owner.This place is very close to the Parliament by strolling the river's bank to Chain's Bridge side.

Moving. We went here on the last day of our trip, it was just a short walk away from the Parliament so wasn't our of our way at all. I didn't know what to expect but what I saw was truly moving. Filled my head up with thoughts and images.
breathtaking. it just brings the message home, of all those people who died. Kind of touching to see kids shoes as well as grownups.

Jewish Memorial. This was an emotional memorial to see. Cast Iron shoes on the bank of the Danube dedicated to the memory of jews who were shot in 1945, their bodies tossed in the river. I found it touching to see shoes of children.

Moving Memorial. I was really interested to see this memorial and once we found it I wasn't let down. Found on the bank of the Danube just by Parliament, this is a moving and beautiful memorial to all the Jews who tragically met their end here. So simple and yet so effective.
moving. we thought this was the most powerful tribute to the jews who died. it was very moving and it was a time to stand in silence and reflex on our past.

Almost missed them. I had read reviews about these and really wanted to see them but unfortunately it wasn't until we were walking to an evening boat trip down the Danube that we came across them. I found it very moving seeing them there and knowing what they represented. They are also very skilfully done so a work of art in their own right.
Shocking Story. The story behind the shoes socked me the most...! unbelievable...! if you go just for the story then do it...if not then it is just iron shoes at the promenade...

a poignant memorial of the lost. An assortment of pairs of shoes of all types and sizes,the well- worn to the highly fashionable one the river bank in a haphazard line.As if their owners had decided to go for a paddle in the river.These shoes will never be put on again, for those who removed them were murdered . Merciless men shot them in the dawn light and their bodies were carried off in the caress of the river Danube.
MUST. I think everyone should go there and see it, it's history and heritage. you feel the pain when you see it. but must visit
Powerful. Such a simple and powerful way to remember the country's terrible past. Very accessible and free, of course.

Sad history and gives a good feel about the past. Somehow the sad atmosphere can be felt at this attraction, with many flowers still observed as a tribute to those victims. Shoes were made in many different styles, shapes and sizes which implied a strong message of how victims regardless of ages were killed then. Per the history we read, shoes were asked to be removed before they were killed, because it was an expensive item to own in those days.
Poigniant. A small but poignant memorial on the bank of the Danube. Worth taking in on a walk either to parliament or the Chain Bridge.

Where thousands were murdered. Yesterday was bitterly cold, appropriate for visiting this stark but moving commemoration to the thousands of Jews who were murdered here, their bodies tossed into the Danube. The memorial is haunting, with the beauty of the Chain Bridge and Castle in the background, one has to contemplate how such horrors can happen.

poignant. I had read about the shoes before we reached budapest but somehow missed seeing them and forgot all about them we were sitting by the riverside at the restaurant on the last night and it suddenly struck me that I missed it .... so we asked the waiter and set out after dinner dispite being a bit tipsy haha .it was a good 15 minute walk and a bit dark ,which surprised us as it should have been more lit up in my opinion it felt really sad to see the shoes ,really depicts the mood of the time ,especially the little kids boots fantastic representation but then budapest is full of these little surprising statues all over the city ...love it

Pictures and reviews cannot describe this memorial - you need to see it yourself. Our Program Director Diana from our Viking River Cruise ship Odin recommended that we see this memorial. There is not much that you can say about this memorial - you need to see this for yourself and let your mind try to absorb the atrocity that occurred here. it is a must see when in Pest. To see the various period shoes - men, women and children - and hearing the story behind is sobering. This a few minutes walk from the Chain Bridge and you must see this memorial.

Fitting Memorial. This small memorial should not be missed. If you go to the Parliament, walk on the Danube side as you leave going toward the Chain Bridge and you cannot miss it. Read up on the history of the city before you travel and you will understand why it is such a moving memorial.
excellent piece of art with symbolisms. I liked the realism of the sculpture. The walk along them was a bit surrealistic. The view of the Danube and the hills of Buda puperb

Tug at your heart. The shoes on the banks were a visible reminder of what our ancestors endured. To see them lined up along the Danube was a tug a your heart strings and something you would not want to miss.
Ken Kleins' Review "Shoes on the Danube". This is a sad story but worth a visit. It will not take long have your guide book with you so you will know the story

Haunting.... Lest we ever forget .... On the banks of the Danube, near Budapest's beautiful Chain Bridge, Can Togay and Gyula Pauer have collaborated to create one of the most haunting, poignant memorials to the Jewish victims of WWII fascism -- the Shoes on the Danube Memorial. Sixty pairs of period-correct, mens and women's shoes line the promenade, a display that might be described as "beautiful," if not for the horrific story backstory: During WWII, members of the Arrow Cross Militia marched Jews from their homes to the banks of the Danube; forced them to remove their shoes; and shot them in the back of the head. Their bodies fell into the river and were swept away in its current.When you're in Budapest, near the Chain Bridge, be sure to take a few minutes to stop here. There is no charge to view the memorial. There are no queues to endure. Just take your camera and plan to take a few minutes, in the midst of the city's beautiful architecture and bustling commerce, to remember those innocent souls whose voices were silenced so many decades ago ... Haunting ...

expanding human understanding. The experiences of people during the Holocaust is like nothing we've experienced in the States, yet it affected tens of thousands in Budapest. The Jewish tours and the shoe memorial are remarkable.

Don't miss this. Very moving to stand there and feel what really went on.Walking along the bank of the Danube with the cold wind blowing, we could see the shoes along the riverbank where Jewish people were thrown to their death every night. Chilling

Deeply moving. The monument is meant to capture the shoes of holocaust victims who were tied to one another with a rope. The first person was shot and their dead body pulled every other person into the Danube. The cruelty and callousness of these murders meant to save on scarce bullets is very movingly depicted with the bronze shoes of the victims along the shores of the blue Danube by the chain bridge.

Simple and very moving. After all the huge incredible buildings of Budapest when you walk from the Chain Bridge towards Parliament the sight of the cast iron shoe moulds on the edge of the Danube brings everything into perspective - It is so simple but says so much about how cruel mankind can be. Do put it on your list of visits - it won't take long but will stay with you as something to remember

Very poignant. This is a very clever reminder of the horrors that happened here. The shoes are cleverly placed, many filled with pebbles by visitors, and are a very thought-provoking sight. Worth a visit as you walk along the riverside.

Saddening. Sad to look at, as are all war memorials. We didn't plan on visiting it as we were not sure how to get there but stumbled across it. Nice if you know how to get there, but not worth going out your way to see.
very moving. memorial to all the Jews that were murdered during the war. very poignant. its near the Parliament building and we walked past it in the evening. definitely worth a visit!

Poignant. The Arrow Cross Party was an extreme right wing movement which led a government in Hungary known as the Government of National Unity in the last months of WW2. During their time, thousands of people (many of them Jews) were murdered and many thousands more were sent to their deaths in Auschwitz. The memorial of iron shoes fastened to the Danube's embankment near Parliament House commemorates the people who were murdered at this spot. They were first ordered to take off their shoes before being shot and their bodies swept away by the Danube's fast current.The memorial is simple but moving and we sat near the site for a time to contemplate how terrible it must have been for those knowing what was about to happen.
Moving. This is such a moving memorial to Jews told to remove their shoes before they were shot dead into the Danube

So touching and evocative of wartime happenings.. So poignant - this incredible memorial to the Jewish people, young and old, men, women and children who died in the Danube at the hands of the enemy. It is peaceful here now, near the Parliament building on the Pest side of the Danube - no cries, no pleading - just silence.It is hard to imagine the happenings and who would want to really. I certainly would not want to be party to the thoughts and experiences of those poor people there by fault of birth. Some shoes have flower heads in them placed by visitors. There are also Hebrew graffiti carved into the curb.The artist who designed this must be commended for such a simple but very powerful remembrance to them

Moving Memorial. My mother in law remembered hearing the gunshots of Jews being shot into the Danube. The beauty of the surroundings today being such a contrast to those events makes this a truly moving memorial
Such sadness. The shoe's give you such a feeling of sadness. I am glad that we managed to see this as I had heard a lot about it from people in the hotel.
Non-ordinary shoes. A really touching site specific intervention that makes you think of many people that lost their lives there.
Simple but provocative. The memorial is on the Pest side of the Danube. Although is quite simple, makes you think about its message in a really effective way.

Well worth looking for. We nearly missed this but am really pleased we didn't. As others have said you need to know the story as to why it has been constructed but a very powerful memorial. We read it was outside the parliament so went straight from visit here to the riverside but had to walk a little way towards chain bridge before we came across it.

Thought provoking. We were walking along the Danube when we came upon this monument of shoes and were puzzled as to what it was, however there is an explanation set into the pavement. A very simple and moving reminder of WW2 and the atrocities that happend.

Riveting Memorial. Many horrible things happened here in the 40's. This cuts you to the core to see that men women and most tearfully, children were murdered here. Shoes that the Jews were wearing were more important than their lives. This is easy to find and well worth seeking out. Don't just pass by on a bus. You have to go there.

Shoes by the Danube. Anyone not expecting this will be intrigued and then perhaps a little disturbed. It's great that the city should construct such a poignant reminder of less pleasant times. The number 2 tram stops close by this little memorial but it's best seen via a walk along the Danube taking in the bridges and the Parliament buildings.

Great memorial. Simply done but very provocative. Reminds us of the brutality of ww11.very moving.really great representation of the cross section of people brutalized with just the shoes that they wore

Simple and Moving. This is a superb execution of a memorial to the Jews who were killed on the banks of the Danube by the Arrow Cross. It's well worth a visit and easily combined with a trip to the Parliament building. From the Parliament Visitor Center use the exit facing the river and cross the street. Then, walk south until you arrive a the monument. After you are finished either continue walking south to the Chain Bridge or reverse direction and walk back towards the Parliament building until you reach a pedestrian crossing at the southern end. Then, walk up the stairs and you'll see the M2 Metro stop in front of you.

Make sure you know it's meaning prior. Make sure you know it's meaning prior to seeing it or else it will have little significance to you. Or if you are getting a tour that will show you, then you're all set. Seeing this can take 5min, no cost. Right next to the Parliament which will take an hour, or 1.5 if you take a lot of pictures outside of it. Make sure you get tickets to Parliament early in the day and it closes at 4, you can't go in without the guide
Moving. So simple, yet also so moving. Close to Parliament and worth looking out for. We were there early on a very cold and crisp morning with hardly anyone about.

Must see!. On the Pest side of the river, come over the bridge (from Buda) and turn left, you'll come across this art installation along the side of the river. It's one of the best things to see in Budapest. It's emotional, thought evoking and totally blew me away. These shoes alone provide an amazing insight - seeing is believing. Eerily quiet there, as anyone visiting seems to feel the same.
A must see. This memorial is near the parliament building. Some shoes look like someone literally stepped out of them. Makes it very real.

Almost missed it. Our tour bus guide had to point out the shoes and provided a short narration of this moving display. I would not spend time searching this out, and without the story (do your homework) you won't really get it.

Awesome. The "shoes" were just a short walking distance from where our viking cruise docked so was able to walk there. Incredible memorial. I was not prepared for the emotion that this display would have on me. Everyone should make every effort to see this memorial and vow to not forget these people. We have to find someway to stop and prevent these things from continuing to take place.

Shoes on the Danube. Surely the most poignant memorial in Budapest - a line of shoes cast in iron and facing the river bank. The shoes commemorate Jews who were shot and thrown into the river. Very moving to see a very personal memorial.

Incredibly touching reminder of the atrocities of WWII. A very creative and touching war memorial. Well done, different and, judging by all the other people around, effective. My two children and I chanced upon this as we walked down the eastern river bank from the House of Parliament. The children asked many questions and I used the chance to give them a little bit of a history lesson and a reminder of past atrocities.

A haunting memorial. A haunting memorial to Holocaust victims who had to remove their shoes before they were shot and their bodies fell into the Danube. These are bronze castings of victims' shoes and serve as a poignant reminder of those who tragically lost their lives.
Moving memorial. Well worth a short visit, very moving and scenic right on banks of Danube. Very close to Parliament buildings

As someone else said - Remember. Behind the Parliament building down along the Danube is a memorial to remind of us of some of the horrible things done to men, women and children in Budapest not that long ago.

Moving memorial. We walked all over trying to find this memorial. We ended up seeing it from the River boat cruise. Learning the history the memorial represents makes this a very moving memorial to see for anyone and all ages.
Remember!. This is a very touching memorial to the Jewish people who were shot here. A must see for all ages! It is located not too far from Parliament.
So sad, but we sould never forget.. In memorial of the victims of Nazi. Human is the greatest beast on the planet. Never forget the crimes of 2nd world war. Everyone must visit.
Very touching memorial. You should definitely see this if you go to Budapest. It was very touching. The only down part is that its right by a quite busy road which was quite disturbing.
Nice. It's nice to see, and has its own share of history... It's not too far off from the town centre.... We accidentally stumbled onto this sight during a stroll on the Danube

Takes your breath away.. Impossible to keep your eyes dry at this memorial. Small, but so meaningful. Amazing how such a small memorial can just grip your heart strings. This memorial should not be missed. Flowers have been left in some of the shoes and add just a splash of color for amazing pictures.

Striking Memorial. I was very keen to visit a number of the memorials in and around Budapest during a recent trip, including the Shoes on the Danube, which I had read about before my trip.It was very easy to find, and we enjoyed a lovely winter walk along the river before coming upon the memorial, and it was very striking.The shoes are laid along the edge of the river to symbolise the lives of those lost, and previous visitors had left roses within a number of the shoes which added even more to the symbolism of the memorial.A must-visit sight in Budapest.

Didn't work out for us.. We (a couple) tried couple of times to visit this place and always failed to do so. Sometimes, we found something more interesting on the way there. Sometimes, we were accidentally passing it by. So after many fails to see the memorial, we completely forgot about it until one time, when we accidentally faced the place. It was very crowded by people, who were trying to make "artistic" pictures while almost dropping in the water. Some other people were trying to be sad and failed to do so.Because of the atmosphere created by crowd, we didn't have a mood to stay any longer and quickly left the place without taking a shot. It just didn't work out for us.

Enotional. The visit to these shoes was very emotional and it helped you to understand the hellish ordeal that these poor people will have gone through. It gave us chance to pay our respects and remember them. The little child's shoes brought tears to our eyes when we saw that people had left money and sweets, candles and wreaths especially at this time of year.

Meaningful experience. My wife and I visited this memorial while in Budapest. Standing in the cold wind with a light rain falling, the chill kept me from the water's edge. I couldn't help wondering about the last thoughts of those poor souls as they were led to the river and stripped of clothing, possessions, and finally life. I agree with another reviewer; there should be a memorial sign in multiple languages. The solemn purpose of the memorial and memory of those people should not be tarnished by ignorant tourists posing as if in a fashion show or by debris left as they pass on their way to the next "thing to see". This is an experience you won't want to miss.

A chilling and must see memorial to the vial deaths of Hungarian Jews during the Holocaust by Hungarian Nazi sympathizer. The day could not been windier, nor more chilling early Sunday morning to view this important testament to the incomprehensible slaughter of the Shoah.
Unique & unmissable. This is a unique and very moving memorial to the men, women & children "disposed of" by the Nazis during WWII. Definitely worth a visit.

A timely reminder. There didn't appear to be any plaque explaining the memorial but the guidebook told me what I needed to know. A poignant reminder of the fragility of life and the persecution of the Jews during WW2. Worth passing by as you explore the area.

Very interesting concept. Well since it was already dark, I initially thought that these are some left over shoes !! Closer look revealed that these were made with lots of planning and effort. Gives a surreal feeling to see the abandoned shoes as it were. But worthy of a visit as you take a walk along the Danube from the Parliament to the Chain bridge.

The exact location of the place is between parliament and chain bridge, just 50-100m far from parliament. . Important place especially for Jews. Newer forget the past, do not allow to re occur again. Do not return back without seeing it.

Never forget. This monument is on the Pest side of the Danube, near the Parliament. It's beautiful to see how empathic people are, it's nice to leave some roses or anything to rememeber those who were shot at this place.
Very moving. This is a poignant very moving tribute to the world war two fallen. Dont miss it , close to the fabulous parliament building
Poignant reminder. Thought provoking, incredible little statues,beautifully and tastefully perched on the edge of the Danube.

A moving experience . While walking along the Danube we saw these shoes and were unsure what they meant. However we knew and could feel that there was a real poignancy about them. At the end closest to the parliament there is a plaque which states the meaning and with my group of friends we took a moment here.
Must see. One of those simple yet evocative memorials you have to see to comprehend. It's out doors so a good day helps. Better seen during the day or early evening.
Poignant tribute. A simple reminder of the Nazi atrocities during WW2. It is not "advertised", but you will find it near to the Parliament Building if you walk along the Pest side bank of the river

Touching memorial. A very poinient memorial set on the banks of the Danube spare a few minutes to reflect at this spot thiscisceasybto miss and not sign posted just walk along the Danubevfrom the Houses of Parliament towards Castle hill
really sad, but a must see. This is a very sad site, knowing the people lost their lives in a place that I now love so much. But, it is something to see, to learn about and always remember.
Extremely moving. Most definitely worth a visit when you find yourself in Budapest. It brought tears to me eyes to realise how cruel the human race can be to each other 😩
Moving experience. A must see for everyone. Brings home how awful war can be. The walk along the river bank to the memorial is lovely

Wow, what an impact!. A very simple, yet emotional tribute to the men, women and children taken to the edge of the Danube, told to remove their shoes, then shot and thrown into the river by the Nazi's. You literally walk along the Danube near the Parliament and come upon these bronze shoes pointing to the river as if someone had just stepped from them. Really brings home the horrible things that happened.

Very moving demonstration of Jewish and others who were murdered by the Nazis. The striking memorial of the shoes that were left behind when the victims were shot and fell or were thrown into the river during those terrible days during WWII was an emotional moment.

very moving. It is a memorial for all of the Jews killed by the Nazis and the Hungarian Nazis called arrow cross. The killed the Jews and threw their bodies into the Danube and all that remained were their shoes.

Take a few minutes to reflect.... There are many remarkable experiences in Budapest but, if you know anything about the history of the Jews/Nazis in WW2, you will find this simple monument very moving. The fact the Jews were shot by crossbow is especially haunting. The monument didn't appear on our tourist map but just stroll along the river bank on the Pest side between Chain Bridge and Parliament.
Thought provoking. A grim but necessary tribute to those who lost their lives as a result of the haulocaust. Easy to find on the Danube promenade just up from the Parliament buildings

Simply moving .... We struggled to find the shoes at first but they can be found on the Pest side, top of the promenade, next to the Parliament building. 60 pairs of cast shoes representing Jewish adults and children murdered by Hungarian Nazi's was a very moving memorial. Some shoes are filled with stones, an ancient Jewish scustome of rememberance - You need to take time and reflect and not simply take a picture and move on
simple and moving. stand and reflect on the history while staring at the Danube--so moving. Its the essence of the horror of Nazi behaviour.
Night spectacular. Informed see the castle and monuments are also used to gather up the perfect place for the night while Budapest castle defense dikket views attracts...
Poignant experience. This really is a most moving monument and tribute to the Jews of Budapest who were shot, falling into the Danube.
Emotive. No trip to Budapest would be complete without visiting here. Not well signposted. We had to ask people where it was but certainly a time for reflection when visiting.
worth visiting! . When you get off the Parliament take some time for walking along the Danube and have a look at this moving site. It will not leave you like you were..

Interesting and very moving. Beautiful Danube, spectacular views... and then this reminder of the bloody history of Hungary. We did not know about this and stumbled across the site. A very moving and emotional site
Moving Memorial. A very stark and vivid memorial to a dark piece of history. While confronting it is definitely not to be missed
very moving,. A sculpture of brass shoes alongside the danube, remembering the victims of ww2 who we.re shot into the danube.

Empty Shoes bring tears. Quite impactive display of bronze shoes alongside the Danube River made me cry. Amazing what we humans can do to one another, and this serves as a reminder of what NOT to do. Take the time to seek out this place, it's not terribly well-marked, and if you're walking, be mindful of construction in the area making it more difficult to find.

The silent horror of the Danube. Last week I visited this horror monument!The shoes are the silent evidence of the jews who were Brutally killed by the Nazis and their Hungarians assistans- the party members Arrow Cross. Babies, women, young and old people, all of them were forced to take their clothes and shoes before they were shot!Killing method included tying together several victims, while only a few of them were shot to save bullets!!! Surprisingly the access to the memorial is hidden and can be only through the crosswalk near the parliament.....And the only sign which exist there, is barely visible and lying on the concrete doesn't mention the Jews and the Holocaust!!! it just says: "In memory of victims who were shot and killed by the Arrow Cross on the Danube in 1944-1945 sages....לזכר קורבנות שנורו ונרצחו ע"י אנשי צלב החץ על שפת הדנובה ב-1944-1945 זכרונם לברכה

Thought provoking. My husband told me the syory of the shoes on the banks of the river - I had no idea what they were there for. Aparently, the shoes were fished out of the river some years ago. They were the shoes of Jewish people who had been pushed over the edge into the water. This was a very moving experience and also a little chilling.

Very sad. I am glad that I went to see this striking and moving memorial for the victims of the German Natzis and Hungarian Fascists.It is on the same side of the Danube as the Parliament anda few hundred meters from it.The memorial is an appropriate way to pay respect to the victimsof those atrocities.

So poignant. We visited this sad place yesterday in the beautiful sunshine. It marks the place and moment when some of Budapests Jewish residents were lined up along the Danube, told to remove their shoes and then shot into the river. This was 1945. The little metal shoes are a memorial to this horrific event. People have placed floral tributes, ribbons etc on them. A sad but worthwhile visit.
Emotive memorial . A very emotive memorial which helps us remember just how low we humans can go. These shoes really and very simply tell the story of NAZI murders.
Nice to see. Stumbled across these little metal shoes at the harbour...interesting bit of history attached to them - especially if your interested in the nazi occupation
Poignant Memorial. Very fitting way to remember victims of the Holocaust. You don't need much time, but this is certainly worth the visit!

Memorable. Our river cruise ship was docked just down the pier from The Shoes so I made a point of going there while the light was still good. When I arrived there 5 min. later it was like getting kicked in the stomach. The impact of all the shoes was unbelievable. So much so that people were crying openly about the atrocities that had occurred & the memories of those who suffered. This memorial is on the Pest side of the Danube near the Chain bridge. We went back once the sun set & the image was even more powerful but on a smaller scale as we couldn't see the whole memorial of shoes. People left flowers & notes in some shoes. An image we will never forget.

Wow. It takes no more than 5 minutes of your time to visit this memorial but it is a great one. There are many 2nd world war memorials around in memory of the holocaust and the dead in general but this one is so subtle and beautiful that it makes you stop and think. It does not try o be more than it is and I found it to be one of the best memorials I've ever seen.
Very touching. Excellent way to remember what needs to be remembered. The shoes were of different sizes and for bot men and women. Brings home the point in a quiet way.
Moving. Really great tribute, shame some of it has corroded a little but great to see regularly placed candles and flowers still by local people.

Unusual tribute. This is a very moving tribute to Holocaust victims. They are represented by iron shoes on the sea wall of the Danube in the middle of Budapest. The most poignant pair are a child's shoes.
2nd world war monument. Must see to remind what evil people are capable of. The monument was built with real size bronze replicas of shoes. Impressive.

I cried. This was way more emotional than I expected. I was walking in driving rain thinking about mans inhumanity to man. The Bridge itself which I walked part way across was lovely but the death that the bridge and the shoes stood for was overwhelming.

A sad reminder, but a must.. Made a point of visiting this memorial alongside the Danube right in front of the parliament building. A memorial to the horrors of war and evil people. The shoes tell the story so simply.

Need to See. The shoes are in front of the Parliament Building are a short walk from the Chain Bridge. Take time to reflect on what the shoes represent. This is a beautiful memorial to the people who lost their lives. Well worth spending a few minutes of your time in Budapest to see this memorial.

Thought provoking. Felt very emotional coming across these shoes on the shore of the Danube. What brought it home more was the children's shoes. Hard to believe human beings could be so cruel to others and be able to be brain washed into doing anything. Still happening today, sadly

Memorial at rivers edge. If you are in the area go have a look it is down on the banks of the river to the left of the parliament building. its a couple of minutes to remember what people went through.

Sad but insightful. Saw this on wikipedia and felt compelled to go. We had a long but pleasant walk along the Danube but it was worth it. The shoes looked sad. The story behind the historical inspiration for the art/ memorial was even more sad. The water as a backdrop was unusually calming and peaceful.
Very Poignant. It is a simple but Poignant memorial which is just along the riverside and it is worth a visit too don't miss the chance too visit this memorial
Unique and Moving. Understanding the history of this memorial is crucial and a bit chilling to visit. Certainly worth spending a short visit on your way to the Parliament.
A moving tribute. Close to the Hungarian Parliament building, this memorial is simple but poignant in its message. Worth a visit. Stop and reflect.

Very unique memorial. A simple and yet very strong way to remind us how easily and shameful people were killed. You need to read about this memorial before because the explanation on site is very poor.
Very moving. A very moving memorial to the suffering of the Jews - never let such things happen again. Such a simple idea, you can't help but be moved by this memorial.

Moving. What a beautiful tribute to the people who lost their lives on the banks of the Danube. Our visit was slightly marred by a group of people who showed no respect for the memorial whatsoever by laughing and shouting and trying to put their feet between the bronze shoes. Well worth a visit.
Very moving. Caught Tram 2 going South. Alighted especially to see this very moving memorial. The memorial meant even more after visit to Terror Museum so we went there again.

Amazing memorial. This is so sad to see but brings home some the horrors that the Hungarian Jews were faced with. The story behind this memorial is heartbreaking but has been so well constructed and is a very apt tribute to those who perished.
Poignant. Poignant but necessary lest we forget. It was not obvious at first until our guide explained the purpose. The past cannot be changed but we can at least be mindful for the future.
Jew's Monument. Nothing so special about it. It is free to explore. It is on the river side next to the Parliament building.

it gives you goose skin. really when you are there and looking carfule on the shoes and what they simbole you can not be indifferent,you feel you are back in time.
go there and let this reminds us that it should never happen to anyone man women or people.

Disappointing! . Walked a fair way to find this spot.
No signage, no historical write up.
Just ok.
This could be made into some more.
Not what we were expecting.

Disappointing! . Walked a fair way to find this spot.
No signage, no historical write up.
Just ok.
This could be made into some more.
Not what we were expecting.

Haunting Reminder of History. This is a heard rending reminder of the history of the Jewish side of the World War within Hungary & Budapest.
The shoes just seem to have been left there like it was yesterday.
This is a monument that needs more prominence than it has so that more people visit here.
Simple but oh so effective in its meaning.

Tears to fill the Danube. In Budapest on our return trip to our ship our guide pointed out lines of many empty shoes of adults, babies,children and elderly left empty on the rivers edge. This was a concrete replica of a terrible history that took place along side this beautiful river. We were told the horrific story that during the comunist reign so many locals were herded to the river's edge - told to remove their valuables and place them in their shoes. These men, women and children of all ages were then shot and fell into the Danube. As we silently returned to our ship no one could hold back the tears at seeing this sad testament of man's inhumanity to man.
A Holocaust Memorial. A very touching display of men's, women's and children's shoes on the banks of the Danube at a spot where Jews were killed and dumped into the river.

A chilling reminder of days gone by. Another must see spot, near by Parliament House, get up early, go for a walk and find your self here at a memorial of countless souls lined up along the wall and shot in the back during the war. A reminder of the past and warning for the future.
Sad history. It is really hard to imagine that people suffered that much in ww2. It is educative to visit this place and remember what people can become with bad leadership......
Touching. Very moving and simplistic but with a strong message. Surprised it wasn't lit at all in the evening.

Simple and Emotional. Why would an assortment of bronze shoes bring tears to the eyes of people seeing them? Simple shoes they are, but they remind us in touching simplicity of the loss of innocent Hungarian Jews who were murdered near the end of WWII. Herded down to the bank of the Danube, lined up for execution, those innocents (young and old) were asked to remove their shoes because footwear was in short supply. Then they were shot and dumped into the beautiful river. This memorial will be more meaningful if you watch the movie Walking With The Enemy before your visit. Produced in 2013 and starring Ben Kingsley, it depicts the tragic tale of Hungarian Jews during WWII. If you come to Budapest, be sure to visit this memorial.

Moving Experience Along the Danube. At the conclusion of a Viking River Cruise we spent a few extra days in Budapest. One of our musts was learning more about the Jewish history of Budapest. One of our first stops after hearing about the story of the last Jews in Budapest in WWII was to the Shoes on the Danube. Such a simple exhibit but oh so moving..Seeing those 64 shoes lined up along the Danube brought the history of the area to life! A very memorable experience.
Poignant. I could see this sculpture from the apartment window. It depicts the shoes of the Hungarians who were shot at the edge with their bodies falling into the Danube.

Moving in its Simplicity. I cried when I came upon the memorial. At several spots, people had put fresh flowers in the shoes; along with rocks, as is Jewish custom. Knowing that so many Hungarians died right as the war was about to end, is so terrible to contemplate.

Moving . Situated on the pest side just before you get to the parliament building
Made me want to know more about the history of budapest, very moving tribute.

Please see this!. A beautifully rendered tribute and memorial to those Jews who were
shot and thrown into the Danube in 1944. Also part of a lovely walk along the river.
Never forget. A very moving memorial to the Jewish lives lost in the war... heart wrenching reality of the sheer acts of madness and cruelty.

A very important memorial. This memorial helps us remember the countless victims who were shoot into the Danube by the Hungarian Cross and Arrow thugs during WWII. They were the militant arm of the Hungarian ruling party after 1944. They would herd their victims to the riverbanks, make them take off their shoes and clothing then shoot them in the back and let the river carry the corpses. The memorial is really close to the buildings of Parliament. Why not take a flower and leave it in one of the shoes to pay tribute?
Emotional. One of the most evocative memorials I have ever visited. No words are needed. So simple but says everything, particularly since it was Hungarian Nazis who did it and not German Nazis.
A moving memorial. By it's every day reflection of life it really brings you up short and the flowers left recall how recent the history is.

A striking and moving memorial. The Shoe memorial to victims of the Holocaust is a striking and emotional piece. Located on the Pest side of the mighty Danube river, near the Parliament building, the shoes - scattered and unevenly paired- are a haunting reminder of past wrongs.

The talking shoes. If you wish learn about the dark sides of this beautiful city, don't miss this unique monument. Almost hard to notice, the abondned cooper shoes alongside the banquet of the Danube, reveal the tragic story of the Hungarian Jewish people. The small statues stand without their owners, who were shut dead into the Danube. In 1944. A strong call to remember that beauty can turn into blood if we don't say couraeusly NO to what should never ever happen.

Sad and Interesting. Set between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament on the Pest side of the Danube the small memorial is certainly worth a visit. Very thought provoking and got me researching into how the Jews were treated towards the latter part of WWII. We had walked down Vci Utca then decided to walk towards the Danube and back up the riverside towards the parliament.

Spend some time here.. Read about the significance of this sculpture and spend some time here. Go early in the morning when the mist os over the river and remember those murdered in cold blood, by people that should have protected them. I did.

The shoes. Those shoes of men,women nd little children are mementos to the jewish people,whom the hungarian nazis shot into the water.Thousands of them!
Many people go to pay tribute to the martyrs, stop for a moment, put a flower into the shoes.
These like these should never happaen again!

Abandoned shoes on the Danube Promenade. The composition entitled 'Shoes on the Danube Bank' gives remembrance to the jewish people shot into the Danube during the time of the Arrow Cross terror. The sculptor created sixty pairs of period-appropriate shoes out of iron. The shoes are attached to the stone embankment, and behind them lies a 40 meter long, 70 cm high stone bench. At three points are cast iron signs, with the following text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005.Caution!Shocking scene!

A heartbreaking memorial. This holocaust memorial is located on the Danube shore, conceived by movie director Can Torgay and sculptor Gyula Pauer. It honors the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank.
Moving Exhibit. This exhibition of shoes to commemorate those who were forced to drown themselves in the Danube shows how the leather in the victims' shoes was worth more than their lives.

Lovely art.. Visited here in June, you can't help but see this as you walk past. A powerful piece that really makes you think. I wouldn't recommend going specifically to see this. There is much more to do around the city.

A must visit.... This memorial is a must visit! Heart breaking, beautiful and peaceful...A sad part of history but honored and remembered well here. We visited in the evening, it was quiet and beautiful along the river.
Holocaust Shoes Memorial. It was moving to see the shoes along the riverfront near the Parliament building. There were flowers left, including a pink rose left in a baby shoe.
Moving and Poignant . Really moving. Considering the bile churned up by certain British newspapers about East European immigration, this is a great reminder of wher such propaganda can lead

a stirring reminder. These 50 pairs of bronze shoes stand as a memorial of the wholesale killing of Jewish popupation by the Nazis--the are high heels, children shoes work boots--and though not a joyful visit a one worth taking--would couple it with the House of Terror museum. Note in the room with the table settings there is a film where you can hear the splash of bodies dropping into the Danube where they were shot so they reflect each other

Powerful and yet moving. As other reviews state this is a memorial to those poor victims of WWII. Unbelievable really for the lives of the poor souls, but yet something I believe to look at is very moving indeed.

I think this is the most heartbreaking of memorials. So often memorials are monumental in size, but this one is small and intimate. It is life size which makes it all the more powerful. When you look at the shoes, you are reminded that real people, real families were killed. Not millions, but the individuals that make up the horrifying totals. I can't explain how impactful this memorial is to me, but it really is. It is just so powerful in its simplicity.
Moving memorial. We took photos of this simple but moving memorial to those who were shot and dumped into the Danube in WWII,

Powerful. This is one of the most powerful memorials I have ever visited. The simple statement made by the image of the shoes left behind by the Jews who were killed in Budapest in the closing year of WWII drives home the evil that men can do upon each other.
Shoes on the Danube. A very moving exhibition all the more poignant given that the weather was quite miserable during our visit and the area where the exhibit located quite bleak.

Moving memorial. This memorial is quite easy to find- it's near the massive, imposing Parliament building. I've been to a number of Holocaust memorials and museums, but I found this one particularly moving. You see these bronze shoes lines up along the river on an icy evening, and are struck with the tragedy of it all- that just a few decades ago people were lined up and shot at this very location, their neighbors perhaps looking on through curtains from the buildings behind you. As you will probably be in the area anyway, and it doesn't take long to appreciate, I think this is a must-see in Budapest.

Very Powerful Memorial, Worth Spending Quiet Time There. We were surprised by how moved we felt as we spent time quietly taking in the meaning of this memorial on the banks of the Danube. Partly, it was the simple design that evoked the murders that took place near this very spot; partly, it was the gentle lapping of the river against the banks; and partly, it was the location of this memorial, on a cobblestone quay close to the national Parliament building. For us, the juxtaposition of the very public center of government overlooking the very poignant memorial was very effective -- a powerful way of saying that the lives of those who were killed near here are still very much a part of the nation's collective memory.

Very moving. You need to go when in budapest this is a wonderful way of remembering the Jewish who where shot into the river Danube in ww2.it was very moving and sad to think so many lost there lives.these are positioned nearer the parliament building on pest side of the Danube as most street maps are not quite correct.

Moving way to pay tribute to Holocaust victims. We were lucky to came across this accidentally, strolling along the Danube one night. This is very moving memorial, and compared to other grandiose illuminated monuments, this stood in the dark, almost unnoticed, but what you feel when you look at all those shoes is the great sorrow and sympathy with the victims.

sad. Very important piece of history, very sad but you need to see it. Notice that the little kids' shoes are full of rocks. It is the custom in Jewish culture to leave a rock/pebble when you visit a cemetery (even tho this is a memorial).
an original way to remember a miserable event. original though being a very sad remembrance prevents me from enjoying it. the empathy is greater than the admiration.
So moving. So little says so much it is impossible not to be moved by such a profound memorial. Trip advisor asks me to say more but there is no more to say go and see it
Moving tribute. Found this sculpture very moving and thought provoking. How lucky I am to have been given the life I have.

A touching memorial. This Budapest memorial is easy to reach, along the Danube River, near Parliament. It is one you should not miss seeing, saying a lot in silence with its remembrance to those who perished in the Holocaust.

more info at the memorial prob needed. this is a memorial very disturbing what happened there all those years ago if your passing take a look its very close to the parliment building next to the river
its not on the sight seeing maps
thought the memorial would have had more information there tho

I cried!. The Shoes on the Danube is a simple yet very powerful memorial. Dedicated to Budapest Jews who were killed by the Nazis as the war ended, it is a sight that will forever stay in my mind and soul. Shoes scattered about, as if waiting for their owners to return and continue their day, many with flowers and trinkets left inside. Once seen, you will not be the same.
nice memorial. very thought provoking worthy of a visit especially as it is next to the parliament and close to other attractions

Impressive. The Shoes on the Danube Bank is a memorial in Budapest, Hungary. Conceived by film director Can Togay, it was created by him and the sculptor Gyula Pauer on the bank of the Danube River. It honors the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank. Definitely, you have to see it yourself.
Very moving memorial. When in Budapest you should take few minutes to go and see this moving holocaust memorial.It is not well publicised but on the river bank very close to the Parliament.

A poignant reminder. When my friend said she wanted to see the shoes by the river, I didn't want to go. She's a teacher in Ohio and had been studying second world war history with her students. Knowing it was important to her, I helped find them (they're not easy to spot).I was blown away. The imagination works overtime looking at the tiny children's shoes, men's boots and women's high heels. I guess my reluctance was knowing it was going to be a painful connection to the past, but I'm so pleased I experienced it.
Nice. We walked from hotel Helia to the center of Pest and found these shoes on the brinks of the Danube. A nice place to take a pause and think for a while.

Extremely moving and well done.. It's not exactly a destination, but it's well worth planning to pass this if you're walking from the Parliament to the Chain Bridge. Visit the House of Terror in Budapest to fully appreciate the meaning of this memorial. The sculptures themselves are very well done, and unsettlingly lifelike.

Indescribable. It is such a simple display yet has such a deep meaning. It is a bit hard to find because of the city being split into Buda and Pest, but it is on the side where Parliament is, about 100 feet from Parliament.
Very moving.. Very moving if you know the back ground of the shoes memorial. It is a memorial that reminds everyone of the bad times that the Budapest people went through,

Not an Attraction but a Must. I am deeply saddened every time I see this monument. Hard to comprehend what went through these people's mind as they waited for their inevitable end. Especially moving on a cold, foggy damp day...not something to cheer or entertain but something younger visitors should experience.
tragic remeberence. a nice waterfront Danube River stroll to this location just a short distance from Parliament building. A quiet tragic remembrance of those innumerable lost souls.
Very Touching. We did not realise that it was 11am when we visited on 11.11.2014. A number of people were visiting and a fitting memorial to a very sad time in our history.

Beautiful memorial to lost lives. I found this memorial to be one of the most simple yet moving memorials to lost lives I have ever experienced. I have travelled the world yet I have never stumbled across such humanity as is found in this simple yet profound memorial. Take a moment to sit on a bench and take in the lives of each person that filled what are now empty shoes - it's worth the trip and puts some perspective into the value of human life.

Very moving, do not miss. This simple elegant memorial is heart wrenching and stately. Thought provoking, and well worth a visit. Along the shores of the Danube. Lovely spot, somber and yet hopeful. Hungarian people remember, the world should too.
Sad story. It's a nice form to remember those who lost their lives in Budapest during the World War II... It´s close to the parlament and you can make a nice walk in the river side

small but powerful. This is a memorial to the Jews who were shot and fell into the Danube after being told to remove their shoes. It is on the Pest side of the River and very near the Parliament building.
Haunting. This artwork is a haunting memorial to the victims of the arrow cross. Not be missed on a visit to Budapest and right next to the beautiful Parliament building.

This is a memorial to the ladies that were pushed into the Danube during the German invasion. This memorial is heart wrenching to see the ladies shoes on the bank of the Danube indicating the women that had been killed by being pushed into the river during the war.

A very moving memorial. A very moving memorial, you couldn't help but to feel raw emotion as you walk along looking at the different shoes that include those of children. Candles and flowers are left to pay respect to the dead. It's on the river bank just down the stairs from the parliament on the side nearest the chain bridge, you can't miss it. It's a memorial that makes you think and remember the history of the country, definitely worth a visit.
so sad. Its near the waters side of the parliament and its just so poignant . If you were not looking for it you would miss it

A simple memorial to those who were murdered by their fellow citizens. This collection of brass shoes on the Pest ( Eastern bank ) of the Danube just downstream from Parliament and before the Chain Bridge commemorates the hundreds of Jews who were murdered here by their fellow Hungarians in 1944-5 , made to strip and then shot and thrown into the river. Their shoes were left behind for decent Aryans to wear. The murderers were members of the Fascist Arrow Cross party, also responsible for deportations of Hungarian Jews to Nazi death camps, whose leader was later caught and publicly executed in Budapest. Stop here for a while if you are walking by, and say this to yourself : " Never again ".

Very moving experience. The Shoes on the Danube are a series of bronze shoes representing the sad moment in history when the Nazis simply lined up Jews along the Danube then shot them and dumped their bodies in the river. It is a must see to remember those awful moments in WWII and the inhumanity of some towards others.

Emotive and teary eyed. I am a big history lover and I think it is important that noone forgets what has happened in our past. So touching to see the recent poppies and flowers that have been laid as a mark of respect.

Subtle but lovely. This is a very nice memorial on the banks of the Danube. To get there, go to the Chain Bridge and walk down to the river bank on the Pest side. Head north and you will come across it. Not only are you going to see this very important memorial, but you will also get a nice view of the Buda side of the river. Don't visit Budapest without stopping here to remember the past.

Jewish memorial simple yet profound. Just walked down to this memorial which was only a block from our viking ship. Not well marked but worth seeing as the 60 pair of bronzed shoes represent just a few of the hundreds of Jews who were tied together and thrown into the Danube . Very sobering.
Emotional. an emotional sight but part of history which everyone should see, located on the riverside near the Parliament buildings

A thought provoking memorial. This moving memorial is situated between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament building, right on the banks of the Danube. I find it hard to choose a rating for this type of attraction, given the horrific events which caused it to exist. However I would encourage any visitor to the city to spend a few moments for quiet contemplation. There are information boards which explain the significance of this memorial.

must see, must not forget. Very moving and makes it more real than reading about it or watching it on t.v. it only takes a few minutes to get the feeling of how horrible it must have been for these precious and innocent peopleJust a 5 minute walk from the "chain bridge" God help us all!

Easy to miss moving memoral to Hungarian Jews. This memorial made up of rusted metal sculptures of shoes denoting Jews who were lined up, tied together and shot along the Danube River during the second world war in 1944. The memorial is on the east side of the river along the promenade, just south of the Parliment building. There are signs in Hungarian, Englsh and Hebew honoring those who died here.

Sobering Sight. The walk along the Danube is so beautiful. All of a sudden you will see a series of shoes on this promenade. These shoes are a reminder of the real shoes of Holocaust victims who were told to remove their shoes before being shot and falling into the Danube. Among all the beauty of this amazing city, it is a sobering reminder of the sad history of this place.
Very Moving Memorial. I found it very moving to see this memorial in remembrance of the Jews who were removed from the ghetto and shot into the Danube by the Nazis

moving. Along the banks of the Danube near to Parliament bdg you come across the shoes left on the banks by the Nazis after murdering jews and pushing their bodies into the river. An eye opener, very moving.
On the backdrop of the Castle District. I came across this by accident whilst walking to see the Parliament buildings. Its very easy to walk past the memorial, so keep your eyes open!
A Moving Experience. What a moving experience. Right next to the Parliament building. Many poeple died here, this is their memorial.

Subtle and Poignant. This city is filled with history - both good and bad - and this memorial is one part of that history that you should take in. It is understated but remarkably effective. There is no entrance fee, no tour and no gift shop. Just go.

Memorial to Jewish people shot into the Danube. Very moving. We came upon it unexpectedly when walking from the Chain Bridge to the Parliament Buildings. The various pairs of bronze shoes represent some of the people, old and young, shot into the river.

Moving memorial. We took the #2 tram from near the chain bridge to the second stop at the parliament. We picked up our tickets and had time to spare. We walked towards the Danube. Found a pedestrian crossing. And started around the front of the building on the river. I knew this memorial was on the Danube but wasn't sure exactly where it was. It was an easy find. This is a very thought provoking memorial. The shoes are apparently castings of their owners shoes. The victims were asked to remove their shoes first. You can stand next to them and feel the terror that the owners would have felt. Right in front of a beautiful parliament building.

Take time to visit this memorial.. This memorial is heart wrenching to see and should not be missed. It brings an era back to your mind where many people would like it to be gone and forgotten. I agree a daytime visit and a nighttime visit touch your heart in different ways.
Very Sad. This is a very moving memorial to the Jews who lost their lives turning the Danube red. A very picturesque walk along the boardwalk to Parliment house.

Must see, at night. This memorial is very well done. It is particularly effective after the sun goes down when the shoes are eerily life-like. If there were any doubts about the necessity of such memorializing, you might want to know that some Hungarians who objected to the piece placed pig bones in all of the shoes just a few years ago, in 2009.
So Poignant. Only small but for us a must and its a great walk along the Danube for good measure - a reminder how inhuman we humans can be

Simple and poignant. We just happened to pass by this memorial along the banks of the Danube on the Pest side by accident. I later read about the significance of the memorial, where Jews were shot and dumped into the river in 1944. Apparently, in order to save bullets, the victims were often tied together with only the first being shot, then dragging the others into the freezing water to perish. Tears your heart out.
small but must see. So moving. Ask for history telling about the shoes. The shoes were left on the river bank when Jews were thrown off. Shoes were the most valuable thing.

Very moving memorial, not to be missed. The shoes speak for themselves...the artist has captured the sadness and the simply chilling atmosphere, enhanced I think by the dreary rainy morning we visited....it's particularly striking in terms of the location near the Parliament, as the Hungarian Government willingly participated in rounding up and deporting its Jewish citizens.This site is very near other places to visit, so please take the time to go, it's really not out of your way, and you will be glad you did.

Striking. Not in the tour books that I have. Had to ask people taking photos what the shoes were for. Was told it was where they pushed the Jews into the Danube during times of Hitler. Tour guide explained out of 600,000 Jews, 460,000 were killed
A must-see. The shoes on the Danube are a simple, but very effective and moving memorial. Worth taking the time to find them.

A subtle and moving memorial to walk by …. This series of real shoes, now cast in iron, that line a small portion of the Danube tell such a story of the inhumanity of man. Jews told to remove their shoes, then shot and dumped into the river during WWII. I am so glad that cities that were ravaged by the Holocaust make thoughtful memorials to those lost, such as this. Take a few minutes and look at this shoe memorial when walking the banks of the Danube in Budapest. A must-see.

Simple shoes with a big story. Bronze shoes on the promenade marking the area where Nazis asked Hungarian Jews, men, women and childen, to take off their shoes and then shot them so they fell into the Danube and their bodies were carried away by the fast flow of the river. A simple display but the shoes really made you think of the horror of it. My only dissapointment was that on a boat trip earlier in the afternoon the place was not even mentioned by the commentary as we sailed along the river.

Touching. If I had the option i would go twice, once during the day so you can see the daylight and once at night because the city lights make the location beautiful. it is impossible to go there and not be moved by what happened, I think this kind of places needs to be visited so we can remind ourselves of what happened in the past.

Beautiful. Possibly one of the most poignant representations of the holocaust I've seen in terms of statues/installations.The human consequences of one of Europes most sickening and tragic pieces of recent history. I'd easily rate it above the Kinder Train installation in London's Liverpool St Station despite being on a much smaller scale.Really touching.

On pest side, a bit north of Parliament.. Our guide shared that at the during WWII, shoes and coats were so valuable the Nazis would make the vitcims remove items prior to being murdered. Along the Danube, the victims would be tied in groups of 3. As bullets were scarce, one bullet was used to kill one of the three. Then the dead were used as weight to pull in others into the Danube and drown the rest. This makes the shoes even more poignant.

Moving. Heart Wrenching.. There were flowers and candies and toys placed among the shoes. It makes you think about the heartlessness of man. There were a few children's shoes besides adults' shoes. Probably the parents'. I know these are not the real shoes, but it really makes you wonder about the lives of the people who died here.
Touching. Sad reminder of the terrific events that took place during the WW II...Worth seeing if you're nearby.
Sad display but very memorable!. These are shoes on display of those who were lost during the second Word War to the Holocaust. It really hits home when you see the display.
How do you rate this?. How do you rate such things? A moving and thought provoking vision. Visited it at night with the lights of the Castle and the Chain Bridge in the background...makes you think.

Must see :). It took us awhile to find this but it is so worth it. Just keep walking along the promenade from one end to the other and you will find it. Such an emotional memorial. Shoes cast in bronze sitting on the waters edge, so poignant! In the hustle and bustle of a very modern Budapest it is a sobering experience. Go take a look you will be touched :(

Poignant Memorial. Very simple yet deeply moving memorial to Holocaust victims who were slaughtered at very sight. Many of the shoes have flowers in and around them but most moving for me was the set of toddler shoes that someone filled with candy.

Walk in silence...... The view of this memorial was quite sad and moving. In order to comemorate the Jews killed on the bank of the river Danube, during the Second World War, the sculptor Gyula Pauer "designed" this place, very close to the Parliament, as one of remembrance of the past and "never forget" the history. Just stay in silence and watch the Danube while this place tells you its story.......
walk along the danube. While enjoying the walk along the danube, we passes along this after the parliament house. Very impressive
very moving. Definitely worth visiting. Very moving memorial along the bank of the Danube close to the Parliament.
Thought Provoking Memorial. Very poignant memorial to the Jews who were murdered on the banks of the Danube. Located just in front of the Parliament.

A moving memorial. A moving war memorial to the Budapest citizens killed towards the end of World War 2. The particularly poignant aspect was to see the shoes of small children amongst those of adults and their parents.The shoes look almost lifelike despite being made of cast iron.

It's shoes on a river. Yeah so it's basically what it says on the tin, shoes on a river bank.If shoes interest you and the Jewish heritage stories behind it then you'll love it.If you're after some excitement then I'd probably go elsewhere..

the best and somber memorial to World War II. It is close to the Parliament, nice walk next to the Danube. During WW II Jews were shot and pushed into the Danube. They need to leave all valuables behind, including shoes/clothes. A very somber reminder of cruelty.
very thought provoking. I'd read about this memorial whilst in Budapest so wentto see it. It is great that they cast the shoes but it is very sad. Very thought provoking.
Very moving. To think that people could become so morally low to take innocent people to the Danube and shoot them. The acts of the Holocaust must never be forgotten

Poignant reminder. A small display of shoes - men, women and a child's pair - just past the Parliament Buildings - visitors have placed candles, flowers and even some badges/mementos - in recognition of those who suffered - as well as those who are left behind with their sad memories.
thought provoking. very thought provoking, and somewhat emotional, the shoes really make you think, especially the childrens' ones
So sad. I had read about the memorial found it very emotional and sad seeing the shoes and hearing about the past. Budapest itself is gorgeous

A very moving memorial. It doesn't look like much until you hear the story behind this memorial, of the 40 Jews who were told to take off their shoes before being lined up against the Danube and shot. The artist"s simple sculpture captures the moments after their death in a very surreal, and emotional, way. It's easy to miss, but well worthwhile to pay your respects to these victims of WW II.

Moving. Came across while strolling and soaking the beauty of Danube. The metal shoes all along the path is very impressive and carry a great weight in terms to the history the place carries. The shoes are placed and spread in a way that looks lifelike and reflects the circumstances where people were shot dead into the river Danube. You need to know the history behind the place to appreciate the value and sentiments behind this memorial.

Very sombre. This memorial was not highly promoted in anything that I had read about Budapest but I stumbled across reference to it when I checked Tripadvisor for attractions in the city. I walked to the memorial from our hotel and it was very moving to stand there on the banks of the Danube with the cold wind blowing from the river and think about the people those shoes represented.
Interesting and...emotional. I have read about them and finally got to see them. Interesting, emotional (there were flowers in the shoes!) and surreal.
Very sad and creative. Definitely something to see. Very sad and meaningful. When we were there someone had left a "real" Piaf of shoes next to a pair of child's shoes.

The Holocaust made Personal. These shoes, representing 40 people killed by the Hungarian Fascists of Arrow Cross, remind us that each of the millions killed by the Nazis were individuals; people whose tragic deaths should be remembered. The memorial is easy to find and very close to the (gorgeous) Four Seasons Hotel at Gresham Palace.

Spine chilling. This was a sombre moment in the hustle and bustle of the city. The memorial to the Jews who were murdered at the hands of the government is very moving. The shoes clearly show children through to the elderly who were forced to stand on the edge of the Danube as they awaited their execution.
Beautiful fitting tribute. Haunting, sad but beautiful tribute to these poor lost souls makes you think about how cruel mankind can be!

Budapest Holocaust sites. In June this year, I took part in a study trip to Budapest. The most moving sites I visited included the Shoes on the Danube memorial, marking one of the places where men, women and children were murdered. It is not insignificant that this memorial is very difficult to access, given recent historical events in Budapest. It is interesting to contrast this with the current memorial at the construction site of the controversial new War Memorial in Budapest, where local people continue to add photos, candles and testimonies to those deported or murdered, not by Germans but by Hungarians. Both memorials are incredibly moving and within easy walking distance of one another. While the three main synagogues also remain and function as museums, these simpler memorials poignantly convey past and present suffering in Budapest.

Don't miss the shoes memorial. The shoes memorial on the banks of the Danube River near the Parliament building is very sad and moving. I visualized people, both young and old, falling into the river after having been shot by the Arrow Cross.

A must visit in Badapest. There is nothing more confronting than standing here and seeing what many Jews saw just before they were shot. The shoes that represent those of the Jews are thought provoking and incredibly sad. I don't mind admitting it brought a tear to my eyes. It is a timely reminder that we as people should do everything we can to avoid war. I highly recommend this site.

Shoes on the Danube. Honestly best encountered on a morning stroll - rather than making a special trip to see. After viewing the Terror Museum on the previous day, I was already emotionally drained by what the Hungarians endured - and what they occasionally participated in.

A nice memorial. Its not very exciting, but its not meant to be. If you are on the Pest side of the Danube its a short walk to have a look at these. The shoes represent a sad story, there are shoes of the rich & poor and childrens shoes to show that at the time they did not discriminate on who they killed.
Very moving.. Its being added to all the time. An eclectic collection of stones shoes and memorabilia. Wonderful, poignant and moving.
Amazing Story. Another amazing example of incredibly interesting history throughout beautiful - so poignant! Definitely worth seeing when you are visiting!

A Must-See. Incidentally, although the memorial should have been easy to find, I recall us having some difficulty. I believe we were instructed to walk in the opposite direction and found ourselves on the wrong end of the bank, unable to walk any further. Luckily we got help from a local. The memorial turned out to be behind the Parliament building, where we had already been!The display was quite emotional for my husband and I. Somehow I expected it to be bigger (more shoes? more prominence?) given what the shoes represent (the brutal murder of Hungarian citizens because they happened to be Jewish). However, perhaps the size is appropriate. The shoes seem so ordinary, in contrast to what they represent. They were strewn about in a disheveled manner, likely mimicking what had happened in life. I liked seeing candles and flowers placed there as tribute. It would have been nice to have an upright statue or sign in addition to the plaques placed in the ground, so that the memorial would be more visible from further away. Note: We were actually in Budapest in December 2011; TA doesn't allow you to select dates beyond one year in the past.
Very poignant. Didn't know about this until in Budapest, but what a sad history! The shoes are a very poignant reminder of some of the atrocities the Jewish people of Budapest have endured.

A touching memorial. I had read about this memorial and made a conscious decision to go and visit it, although being right on the bank of the Danube you can't help but stumble across it.Touching and thought-provoking, the shoes are a real reminder of the men, women and children who died here. It was also lovely to see plants, flowers, coins and even sweets placed inside the shoes by other visitors.
