Sad. Having been told the story about this memorial and knowing what happened to all these people that was killed and this point on the Danube which is located at the back of parliament building. You can only feel for there loss.

Simple, but moving. Sometimes things can be moving in their simplicity and this monument is one of them. It is a monument to Jews who were killed (shot right on the river) during WWII. There is no big plaque explaining this monument too much but the location is wonderful. It is right on the river walk area close to the Parliment building. Sit for a little while and refelct while enjoying the view!
good reminder. This is a very powerful reminder of the cruelty bestowed on the people of Budapest. The display itself is very simple but it certainly hits the message home.

Sombering memorial. I noticed this while I was on a motorbike tour of the city. It is a very small but moving memorial. Sometimes it is the simplest of memorials that make the biggest impression on someone. Thought provoking.

Good. I liked seeing the memorial but felt that it could be sign posted. We nearly walked past it without seeing it! I also thought that there could be some information about the memorial as a couple of fellow tourists didn't know what it was for. Other than that it was a good memorial.

Hauntingly memorable. We had heard about the "Shoes on the Danude" memorial from others. Having been to other Jewish memorials in other parts of the world as well as Auschwitz we were very keen to visit. It was a deeply moving experience to walk along beside the Danube and see these "shoes" lined up along the river bank and to imagine how those poor victims must have felt when these atrocities took place. Do visit this, but be prepared to shed some tears.
Touching memories. With simple elements, you can think about the people who lost their lives here.We must never forget the atrocities that happened in Europe just about 70 years ago.
Touching. A tribute to all the jews that lost their lives here worth a look while walking on the banks of the Danube a lot of candles and flowers left with the shoes

A very moving tribute. This was a very moving tribute to those that were killed during the 2nd World War. It was clear that this was a well respected tribute that people still went to and laid flowers and lit candles for those that lost their lives. A place very worthy of a few minutes of your time whilst in this historical city.

I defy anyone not to be moved by this simple but poignant memorial. I came across this memorial when I was just strolling along the promenade after visiting the Parliament building. I had heard about the memorial before visiting the city but coming across it, rather unexpectedly, made me gasp and tears stung my eyes. My advice if you visit Budapest, is please visit the Shoes on the Danube and take a moment to reflect on the sad, incomprehensible events which took place there.
Moving. Simple and effective. Just along the Danube from the science academy though doesn't seem to be signposted.

Shake your world. This small memorial along the Danube promenade is a sobering miracle akin to the Vietnam Memorial in D.C. It provokes instant tears and the memory sticks with you, most likely forever.

Emotional. A simple but effective memorial to those who took their shoes off on the banks of the Danube before being shot and falling into the river. It is evocative and poignant. A "must see" on the Pest side of the river.
Memorial. I think it is terrific. Lots of shoes to remember Budapest Jews killed during the world war 2. Take off you hat and remember.
Very touching. This is a necessary stop for tourists who are interested in the Holocaust. The families of the victims but the victim's bronzed shoes in the sand on the riverfront.

Must see. I would say that this place is one of the must see in Budapest because it has an important historical meaning. It's a nice hommage that has been made to this horrible facts. I would suggest to do it after the synagogue visit! (If you're going to the parliament, it might be a nice stop by sight)

Must visit.. Very impressing. It is difficut to stay there for a long time, because you still can feel all the tragedy in the air. Sad place, but everybody should remember the past for to have successful future.
Sadness. worth the visit to simply experience man's inhuman treatment of his fellow man. The shoes are by the river where the executed bodies were dumped into the danube.

innocent heroes. a moving but silent tribute to unarmed ,innocent men , women and children at the hands of evil men ,their spirit lives on thanks to the creative art of this film maker who placed it here

Remember and never forget. Real and chilling monument, On the banks of the Danube River
It is recommended to arrive during sunset
Very poignant.. When the simplicity of shoes on the edge of a river brings about silence and shake of the head you know the horrors of war will not be forgotten.
Moving memorial. There is not much to this (simply shoes on the edge of the Danube), but worth visiting as it is a moving memorial that gives a sense of what happened through a very simple idea.
So real, so sad. A quiet reflective spot on the river which everyone should take time to visit. Hard to imagine especially when one sees the baby's shoes. Quick walk from the Chain Bridge.
Memories. Nice if somebody wants to know more about Hungurian History. Specialy at night the view its perfect.
A Haunting Memorial. This memorial is well worth making the time to view and ponder. It is near Parliament, and easy to find.

There are many monuments and plaques in Budapest ..... There are many plaques and monuments in the city but if this had been one of them, people, including me, would read it and move on however seeing these shoes made us realise that the group of citizens that were so cruelly slaughtered were people - individuals and families, people who mattered. Go and spend a few moments there, just south of the Parliament buildings.

Very sobering memorial. Everyone needs to be reminded of the horrendous events of the 2nd world war, and seeing the shoes on the Danube sums up the horror of what happened to the Jews. The childrens shoes really make you reflect on the atrocity. We sat in silence and reflected, very moving indeed

Compelling testament to atrocities in Budapest. This is a compelling monument to the Jews murdered by Hungarian fascists in World War II. People were ordered to take off their shoes, and place them on the banks of the Danube River in Budapest. Then they were assassinated. Their bodies fell into the river. The monument of metal shoes represents all those killed. It is a somber way to spend a few minutes thinking about all those killed by the Nazis and their accomplices.
A very poginant memorial. Take a walk along to this memorial, it is a beautiful memorial. This is a lovely spot to see stop and take a break. Wonderful views of the Danube

Very Important Work. Powerful reminder of Hungary's role in the Holocaust. The memorial is a reminder of a very specific moment in which the Arrow Cross militiamen murdered Jews - asking them to remove their shoes first, by shooting them so that they fell into and were carried away by the Danube. The sculpture features 65 pairs of bronze shoes (in the styles of the era) mounted along the promenade. Terribly sad and important work. A must see if you visit Budapest.

Good Memory!. It is definitely very sad to look at this memorial spot, but at the same time, I am glad to have read and seen it. Reminds you about the tragic things that has happened and still continue to happen in the world.
Thought provoking. We saw these before visiting the Holocaust Museum. Very poignant and thought provoking.....on the Danube on the way to see Parliament.
Touching. This is a small memorial with a powerful story and an emotional impact. Its simplicity is all the more impactful.

fitting memorial. we came across this by chance and guessed that it must have been a memorial to people who died in the second world war. very well done memorial as shoes are in the style that was in fashion at the time. Might be interesting to read up a little on this before or afterwards as we did.

A sad, sobering and beautiful memorial.. Here are 65 pair of brass shoes, memorialize get the Holocaust victims who were murdered on this spot. You can't see this without reflecting on the atrocities that happened here.

History buffs and WW2 in Budapest. The memorial is simple and telling, and should be one of the many "musts" on a trip through WW2 Budapest, along with the Synagogue on Dohány utca and other areas. Read a bit about the history of the Jewish Quarter of Budapest to be better informed.

heartbreaking. It is a small patch along the river bank, on the side of the Parliament building. You may miss it, if you do not look out for it. We walked from the chain bridge towards the Parliament, and found it on the way. A lovely tribute.

Moving and interesting. This is a strong monument and moving. The Danube is the heart of Budapest and every tourist who arrives to this city takes a walk along it and gets to the parliament.The monument gives you some chills, because give you the idea of what happened and how the country chooses to remember World War 2 and the killing of Hungarian Jewish. Still they can had some more information.

A very poignant memorial. I hadn't even heard of this 'statue' until my friend told me about it. When we found it close by the Parliment Building, it was an incredibly moving memorial to the horror that happened to the Jewish people here.

Very moving. We had heard about the Jewish shoes and found this to be a poignant memorial and very moving. It is a short walk along the Danube on the way to the parliament building. Worth the effort and have taken some photos which we will make into an art photograph for home.
important place. The monument is really powerful and meaningful but as a jewish I think that there should be more explanation about the tragic death of the jews next to the danube.
Moving. Very impressive and poignant memorial especially as we came across it unexpectedly after visiting the Parliament.

Very moving important reminder. This simple memorial has empty shoes representing the shoes Jews were forced to leave behind as the Nazis made them remove their shoes, then shot them in the back and had them fall into the Danube to carry their bodies away. The horror of this is a powerful reminder of what can happen when a terrorist group overtakes a country.
Thought Invoking. A thought invoking Memorial. Stunning piece of work. Along the walk to the Parliament House by the Danube River. Do not miss them.
Very moving. A moving memorial to the past horrors of human suffering in the city, set on the edge of the Danube.
Emotive. This is a simple memorial speaking a thousand words. One needs to take time to reflect on the atrocities of war and just what it represents. The setting is very humbling.
Very emotional place to see.. It's scary to think something like this happened here. The monument is is to get to and is eorth seeing.

Powerful!. We have now lived in Budapest 18 months and recently visited this memorial. We have read much of the history associated with the monument but were still somewhat unprepared for the powerful impact the monument actually had. The monument itself was powerful but what also struck us was the small items (a note, a flower, a trinket) placed in many of the shoes. We wondered about the connection; a relative of one of the victim's, an apology from someone, or condolence?The monument is reached best by leaving the visitor center adjacent to the Parliament Building. Exit the center on the Danube side and turn left and you will arrive at the monument in 3-4 minutes of walking. The busy street is on one side and the river (with no fence or rail) on the other. Be aware of this if you have children since there is a drop off of several feet to the rocks along the river. We left with a different perspective of the history associated with this monument.
Poignant and sad. Very moving memorial to the victims of the Arrow Cross. Especially when seeing the littlest shoes stuffed with candy...
Poignant. A very simple but graphic memorial to those that were killed so callously towards the end of the war

History revealed in Budapest. In a city with such delightful diversions as inexpensive restaurants, magnificent churches and palaces and health-giving spas, it's easy to overlook the dramatic, confronting and at times embarrassing recent history of this great city. During Nazi occupation in WW2 and with the complicity of the then Hungarian puppet government many of the 200,000 Jews of Budapest were persecuted, rounded up in the Jewish ghettoes, had their property confiscated and in the worst cases were slaughtered or sent to concentration camps as part of the holocaust "Final Solition". This memorial on the banks of the Danube, quietly,elegantly portrays that awful time when Jews were lined up in the Danube's edge, shot and their bodies thrown into the river. You cannot see this without feeling tremendously sad and angry that such a thing could have happened just over half a century ago.
Very moving.. Saw it and was thoroughly moved and impressed by the artistry and the detail out in to maintain authenticity.

Very touching. Unfortunately, signs gives misinformation.. We agree with all other reviewers. This is a very touching tribute for the people who paid with their lives for the freedom we enjoy today.Personally, we didn't like the signs stating something like: for the memory of Arrow Cross victims. Sounds like something bad that some strangers named Arrow Cross did to their nameless victims. Who were the Arrow Cross? Who are the victims?We tend to think the vague text is intentional.So, here are the facts:Arrow Cross = Hungarian party who ruled the state for a shot period and made a pact with the Nazis.Victims = mostly Jewish citizens of Hungary.In our humble opinion, these signs are a shame.
Only silence. I was very choked up when I passed by the shoes on Danube. Poignant statement. Excellent memorial. Could indicate it is a jewish holocaust memorial on the sign perhaps.

A touching memorial on the banks of the Danube.. My husband and I looked for this memorial as we walked from Margit-sziget to our apartment near Szent István-bazilika. I wasn’t prepared for the emotional response this simple monument would have on me. I was so profoundly touched by this memorial that I actually cried while I was taking photos. I was overcome by a deep feeling of sadness, as I sensed the despair that the men, women, and children must have felt when they were lined up along the Danube in their final minutes of life. Well worth a visit, though it’s haunting, poignant, and heartbreaking.

It does leave an impression. This is on the river near the parliament library. It does get you thinking about what the Nazis did to the Jews and people that disagreed with them. That stayed much the same through Communism.
Striking. I had not heard of this memorial before we stumbled upon it. It takes your breathe away when you realize what it is. So simple and so poignant.
A poignant memorial. This memorial certainly makes you think about the people who were made to stand along the Danube and then killed ..... Very sad.

A moving memorial. Easy to find. Very moving memorial to the victims
Easy to find on thfe Pest side of the Danube. Very moving me,oral to the victims of the Nazi occupation.

A must see. Its not funny or amazing but its very good for everyone to see this in Budapest.
In front of the beautiful Danube you can really think of the past and realise how great your holidays and how lucky you are to not be there 70 years ago
Feeling Sad!. It's important to remember those who have paid a high price for our freedom. It's important to have places of rememberance to pay our respects.

Poignant. I am unable to say I liked or disliked the memorial because of what it stands for, but the simplicity allows you to reflect on your own personal thoughts.
I would recommend a visit

a subtle and low key reminder. the memorial is a very understated reminder of the brutal history of Budapest. as one stands by the Danube,sobering thoughts of peoples' inhumanity to each other go through ones mind.we need to always remember that we are all created in gods' image.

Emotionally moving. Amongst Budapest's sometimes tragic history, for me, this was the most moving monument in the city. If you do nothing else, I recommend that you go and spend even 10 minutes, and just think about how mankind can act like animals. It's so sad to think that these terrible things happened decades ago but somehow we still don't learn. Whether it's Ukraine, Palestine, Syria or Iraq, poor innocent defenceless people are suffering because of warmongers.
Very moving. Emotive memorial, very simple idea but a fitting reminder of the horrific experience of these people.

A bit sobering. The bronzed shoes are just down the river from the Parliament building on the Pest side of the city. Easy to add to your walking tours. The shoes are a sobering memory of the brutality of national socialists and communists that overran Budapest in the mid 20th century. Many of the shoes are very lifelike, despite being sculptures. Some contained candles, flowers, and pictures. Don't be a dumb tourist and inconsiderately place your feet in the shoes!!
Chilling. A simple and small memorial that makes you consider the history of Budapest. Worth seeing to just to "be right there".
Speechless. I visited this memorial twice during our stay. It's a small, but significant monument. Totally worth the short detour from the Chain Bridge.
Cool Memorial, Sad Subject. A powerful reminder of the fact that like most places there are dark days in the history of this country as well.

A Moving Tribute to the cruelty of Mankind. A wonderful and moving tribute to the Jews who were killed and tossed into the Danube during the second World War by local militiamen. It consists of lots of pairs of metal shoes of various shapes and sizes on the bank edge of the Danube. If you walk along the Pest side of the river towards the Parliament building you are sure to see them.
A moving memorial. A moving memorial to the Jewish people executed by the Arrow Cross Party during 1944-45 on the banks of the Danube.

Very moving. Well worth a visit, if you have any interest in the Holocaust or WW2 it's a moving insight into what went on under Nazi occupation. Easy to get to as well, it's right by the Chain Bridge, and no cost.

Moving Memorial. During the war, Jews were lined up along the shore of the Danube and shot, their bodies dumped into the river. On this spot a memorial has been set up with bronze shoes lining the concrete wall beside the river. It is easy to miss, because it is just shoes on the wall, but take the time to go see it. A moving memorial.

interest memorial. honors the Jews who were killed by fascist during war world II.Jews were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water. Very sad memorial that leave an overall impression of mankind.

Not much to see but historical significance. What you basically see are shoes on a protective wall (Promenade) along a stretch of the Danube. There is a historical significance to this however, as it honors the Jews who were ordered to take off their shoes and then were shot at this location during WWII.

Very moving!. Bronzed shoes to commemorate the hundreds/thousands shot and dumped into the river. Flowers in some but just a row of shoes....We were told that just before we arrived some shoes had been vandalized/stolen. A sadness heaped on a tragedy!
Unforgettable. This memorial will stay with you. Looking at the empty shoes makes this very real. You feel what happened as if it was yesterday.

Very fitting memorial. It's a very fitting memorial to the Jews who were shot into the river without any shoes. It's a simple memorial, but yet so powerful. One cannot help but reflect back on history.

Very thought provoking. It is exactly what the title suggests. A row of different sizes and styles of shoes, including childrens to reflect and commemorate the horrors that happened here. It's on the Pest side right on the waterfront. You come away with more questions than answers.

Walking around Danube. We didn't know this place and it was a surprise for us.
This memorial is a good way to remember about the war.

Moving memorial. This is one of the most moving memorial, I have ever seen. It is so simple and it is so easy to pass by it without noticing it. I always makes me think and reflect upon what happened back then.
mans inhumanity to man. Very haunting, people place flowers in some of the shoes and the pair of a small child's shoes was especially moving.

Moving experience. Very moving experience but even sadder when you see tourists posing next to the shoes smiling. Let's just hope they aren't actually sure what the meaning is.
This experience is very good with the city walks walking tour maps that they handed out at hotel reception
solemn. talk a moment to remember and see this moving tribute to those who died...it was a 5 minute walk from where our River Cruise Boat docked (Viking)
reflective. Very thought provoking, unmarked and it did make one think. Do spend a moment or two there.it would be easy to pass by wothout seeing.

Breathtakingly sad and an essential reminder of the danger of racism. Beautiful - the Danube, Parliament, the chain bridge - Budapest has so many pretty sights. It's easy to be swept away by the tourist attractions.Torn apart by many wars, occupations and invasions, Budapest has been a city of struggle and survival which is why you must see this memorial to understand the courage and strength of this city.This is sobering. It is important. It is simple and yet it is powerful. Less than 100 years ago, shoes were removed from the feet of Hungarian Jews and thousands of them (40-60% of the jewish population) were killed. Let's pray that something like this never happens again.

Sad memorial in Budapest. A sad reality as to what the arrow cross militiamen murderers did to Jews in Hungary. Before being shot into the river they were told to remove their precious leather shoes! The shoes belonging to men, women and children were then sold, traded on the black market. They are unique replicas of what would have been worn during that era. The shoes almost speak to you, imagining who wore them, their fate that day, their horrible death after removing them. People lie single flowers among the shoes and at night you can see candles lit around the memorial. Very moving! Close to Parliament on the Pest side of the river.

Simple yet powerful. It's nothing incredible or giant, but I think that's the point. It's a strong reminder of the terrible things that have happened in the past and how much we should appreciate our lives every day.
Memorable and Moving. Only a 5- to 10-minute stop, but well worth it. A poignant reminder of man's inhumanity and an unforgettable sight.

A Very Moving Exhibit When You Understand the Origin. Hungary lost 600,000 Jews during the Halocaust and this small memorial (60 pairs of bronzed shoes attached to the pier overlooking the Danube) is a chilling reminder of what can happen when mad men are in control. It's difficult not to be moved when you realize the victims were standing virtually on that spot when they were shot and pushed into the river.

Very Sad - Stop Think and Remember. We only recently found out about this memorial not really mentioned in Guide Books. It is situated on the riverbank just by the Parliament building. There are three plaques in the ground, English, Hungarian and I think the third is Hebrew reminding people that this memorial is for the Jews that were killed by the Arrow Cross Militants in 1944-45. They were marched to the riverbank, made to remove their leather shoes (which were valuable in those days), then shot into the Danube and left to float away. The metal shoes on the bank of the Danube are to remind us of this - there are mens, women's and children's shoes. Some have candles in them. A very poignant reminder of those days. We stood there on the riverbank for some time trying to imagine the horror these people must have felt knowing their fate as they removed their shoes. It is such a sad memorial which makes you remember these horrific things which must never happen again. Do try and see this when you are in Budapest.
Very moving experience. The view of bronze shoes of every size facing the river was very chilling when I thought back to the reason they were there. Definitely see it.

Poignant tribute. This is one of the most moving memorials that I have ever seen - shoes of all styles and sizes scattered along a section of the Danube. Empty shoes that are a reminder of an horrific part of all our histories.

Shoes to weep for. A memorial all the more powerful for its simplicity. That said, the nearby plaque gives minimal detail of the story behind the memorial and yet it is much needed. Insight's pocket guide to Budapest says "The victims were bound together and tossed into the freezing river" (p.41): no mention of shooting.

Hard to find but worth the effort. This is a very moving memorial and well worth going to see. Unfortunately it was not on our tourist map so we struggled a bit. Go the the parliament, cross the road to the edge of the Danube and start walking towards the chain bridge. Follow that and you can't miss it

Worth going to see!!!!. I had read about this art installation and so grateful we walked along the Danube to see it.Do a Wikipedia search on it before going so you understand the story, it is so moving and something we will never forget

Very Moving. DIRECTIONS: there are no sign posts, but it's incredibly easy. Find the parliament building. Get on the river side (there's a promenade). Walk downstream. You'll come across them in minutes, right by the water.They're a beautifully moving, sad, understated tribute to an important event. When the Germans could no longer "evacuate" Jews to the death camps from Budapest in late 1944, the Hungarian fascists took it on themselves to bring people to the Danube and machine gun them into the water. The empty metal shoes are a poignant reminder of this.To anyone saying that it's morbid or asking "why mark this?" - you're an utter idiot and should try engaging your brain. Imagine this had happened to you, it your family or your friends and you can see why the world disagrees with you. It's not one of the obvious big attractions in the city, but it's more than worth a quiet visit out of respect and remembrance.
A must see of you are in Budapest!. it does help if you read up on this story BEFORE you visit it. However, you should visit this site, part of Hungary's dark history...

A testament to the Holocaust. A heart-rending memorial to the horrors of the Holocaust, these bronzed shoes on the bank of the Danube in front of the Parliament pay tribute to the Jews who were murdered in Budapest by the Nazis.

A vivid reminder of another lifetime. The bronze shoes are strategically placed along the stone shoreline of Pest. What makes it so compelling is that the people were lined up, executed against the back drop of beautiful Castle Hill. It is an intimate memorial to the Jewish people.

Needs more explanation. I knew the story of this exhibition, testimony to one of the saddest chapters in Hungarian history. The bronzed shoes lined up along the Danube near the Parliament commemorate the murder of Jews by local Arrow Cross fanatics in 1944. They were shot, and their bodies fell into the Danube, but only after they were stripped of their shoes, which were scarce during the war. If you came upon this scene without knowing that, you might wonder what the shoes represented. There are two plaques set into the ground, one in English and one in Hungarian, but they scarcely explain what happened and are easy to overlook. A fuller explanation is needed.

A very strong message. The historical relevance of the place is in itself pretty overwhelming and the whole place is reminiscent of a dark history in the country. A whole lot of people actually pay homage at here and I think it intensifies the realty and experience of the place. Spread along the lines of Danube, this is a pretty striking and impactful place to visit.
sobering. The shoes remind you that millions of people were displaced and murdered during the Nazi years. They left and were not heard from again. We must not ever let this happen again
Heartbreaking. A memorial the the efficiency of the Nazis and a reminder to all of the rising tide of antisemitism in Europe today.

An eerie reminder of the horror that occured here. We had read about this memorial to the jews murdered in Hungary during the Holocaust. We spent a while sitting on the promenade along the river imagining what horror it was to be brought to the river and murdered only because of your religion. One can almost hear the splash as they feel barefoot (the shoes had value, the people did not). I was particularly moved one the soles of one pain, on the far left. They showed the wear pattern associated with osteoarthritis of the knees. I care for patients with this malady and I could imagine this being one for the patients or a loved one. It made the deaths seems more personal.

Interesting monument. We stumbled upon this monument by misstake. We were on our way to margaret island on foot and choosed to walk by the river. It was an odd piece of work but after we googled what it was it made a lot more sense.. We ended up staying there for about 30 minute just to pay our respect to the passed.

Great memorial - made you think & remember.. I had seen pictures of these shoes so I had an idea of what the mmemorial would be like, but the actual memorial was so much more moving that just the picture. Whoever was the creative spirit behind these shoes was an artistic genious. Some were rusted out like real leather would be and some had flowers or candles in them.
silent volumes. we were rendered unable to speak words at the great sadness and story behind this memorial ..... can not describe the emotions felt, a must see for all who visit Budapest.

Sad memorial. This memorial is a must see for anyone visiting Budapest. We were staying very near to the Parliament so passed this memorial several times while strolling around. Its so simple but very effective.People had placed single roses inside some of the metal shoes and it was heart wrenching.We should never forget...........!

Very emotive. It's really worth walking along the bank of the river to see this - it's a few 100 yards after the bridge towards the Parliament. The sculpture is very emotive and moving, really makes you think.
A 5 minute stop along the Danube. A memorial to the Jews who lost their lives in the river. A poignant and unusual reminder to us all.

Very moving experience. This is a free memorable experience. Slightly hard to get to as you must cross the street a little way from the actual site. Easy to see when you visit the Parliament....if you are on a walking tour.this is a terrible chapter in the history of the world
The shoes. Heart-wrenching but very prolific and tasteful tribute to the Jews that were hauled off to the Danube to die by gunshot or drowning. The synagogue is a must see, as well/
Do not miss this. Small tribute but very moving right along the river near Parliament. Powerful and kind of personalized what happened.
History Lesson... worth a visit!. With the few bronze shoes, it describes the painful memory of Holocust. You need to spend few moments beside those shoes and try to feel them.

Must see. Very moving to see the shoes by the Danube. It really makes you think about all the people who lost there lives in this city. We should never forget. Every visitor to Budapest should take the time to visit ..
Got to be done. Exceptionally humbling and quite a simple yet so effective memorial. Best we remember and learn from the past.

Take Your Children. I took my two kids (ages 10 and 14) to this memorial before going to the synagogue the following day. It gave me a chance to talk to them about the millions of people who had lost their lives during the Holocaust and helped my kids focus on the individual victims. Each pair of shoes is a different size, shape, and style -- just like each of the victims was unique. Sometimes kids are overwhelmed when they learn about the incredible atrocities committed during the Holocaust and they lose sight of the impact on individuals and families. This memorial made all of this feel very personal, an experience I'm sure they won't ever forget. I know that I won't.

Poignant reminder, or a lesson in history. There are so many holocaust memorials, and many people don't want to see, or be reminded. That is why I thought this was genius. A tourist in Budapest walking along the Danube will come across this simple memorial and will stop to read the plaques, written in several languages. It will either be a reminder or a lesson, depending on how much history you know. Moving indeed.

Gut-wrenching.... Budapest as a city has had its fair share of both good and bad memories I suppose. The latter aplenty during the period of the second world war. One such incident is the shooting of innocent people who fell victim to the anti-semitic atrocities of the Arrow Cross execution brigade - it is this incident which has been so poignantly captured through the "shoes on the Danube".60 innocent people were forced to take off their shoes and face the Danube on one cold winter in 1994 when the barbaric fascists then shot them in cold blood - forcing them all to fall dead in the Danube - while all that was left behind of them were their shoes on the river banks.The art installation on the Pest side of the Danube river on the promenade lies between the Parliament building and the Chain bridge - its not that well marked or lit - so you can miss it if you aren't actually looking out for it. For people taking the number 2 tram line its a short walk from the Chain bridge stop - or otherwise from the Kosuth Metro station as well.The shoes made in bronze/iron - look like real worn out shoes and serve as a sad reminder of the times, it also is a moving tale of the fact that how so many of us complain about the banalities of life when in all fairness we should be thankful for every single moment of joy we can afford - not many have had that luxury either.Its a must see just to relive the horror of those times and to remind ourselves that come what may we should never stoop to such levels again.

Unique and moving memorial. Having been to Auschwitz where one is overwhelmed by the enormity of the Nazi terror, this memorial hits you with its pure simplicity. Many Jews and others were thrown into the freezing Danube at this location and the shoes are a simple tribute to them

Bronze shoes. This simple monument speaks words. During the Nazi period (apparently Hungary invited them in) Jews were terrorized and murdered, some pushed into the Danube at this spot. Unfortunately, due to construction, it was difficult to access the area during our visit.
Memorable. Can picture the horror of it all, since it is at the actual site of the murders. Goes with a visit to Terror House.
Emotional. The memorial is really touching... It's simple and at the same time expresses the depth and awfulness of the event and entire period.
Poignant memorial. It is very sad to see these shoes and made me think.I think they are iron life-size replicas, so the fragility of the originals and that of their wearers comes strongly through.

Moving Sight. Incredibly sad and moving Memorial. All the more tragic that the Hungarians did it to their own people. Among them in particular were Jews. This is where many people who disagreed with the regime or had no choice, were thrown into the Danube alive in freezing weather. Particularly emotional is the sight of a little pair of shoes obviously belonging to perhaps a three or two year old. Tragic and so very sad.

A profoundly moving memorial. Nothing could bring home cruelty and killing so eloquently as these shoes, which look as if the owners have just stepped out of them. The shoes look 'lived in' with the creases and marks that we all make. They commemorate some Jews who were shot then dumped in the Danube. A fitting and lovely tribute.
Powerful Memorial. A unique memorial that honors the Jews who were killed by fascist militiamen in Budapest during World War II. Truly moving and worth a visit.

Poignant reminder. I had heard about this memorial, but, interestingly, our personal guide did not include it in our day with him. So we went ourselves the following day. It is a little tricky to find, and I wonder whether the current Government likes it that way!The simplicity of the discarded shoes cast in bronze is very dignified and incredibly moving. One could not help but imagine if those were your loved ones in those shoes.This atrocity was committed by the Arrow Cross, the Nazi allies in Hungary, who I am told, shot 90,000 Jewish people into the Danube in 1944. A sobering reminder that this must not be allowed to happen again.
History. It's so easy to get to along the river .....People sit and look and remember what & why it happened.I like to be one of them to sit & look
Nice Memorial. The shoes on the danube are in front of Parliament building. This is a moving tribute and worth visiting
powerful. Hstoric scene showing the shoes left by those pushed into the Danube. Solemn yet dignified. it is a sad reminder of the cruelity.
Moving. What a wonderful way to remember those who died into the Danube during 1944/45. Very moving.Take the walk along the river on the Pest side and you come across the shoes.

Sobering and affecting tribute. ...not only the bronze footwear but also the flowers placed in some of the shoes. Since it's away from the center (nearer Parliament) and inaccessible to the bus tours, it was tranquil enough to let the meaning sink in. Reminded us of a moving display of victims' shoes at the National Holocaust Memorial in Washington, DC.
A poignant reminder of the atrocity of war. We happened upon this small, but very effective memorial as we walked South along the riverside down from the Parliament visitor centre. Very poignant.
Impressive. Impressive place of historical significance.   I wish there was a clear explanation about the sad history of this monument represents you.
Scene from the past. A very touching and sad scene, but a necessary part of the \Budapest Scene. Lots of history to be seen at this stop.
Very Moving. The view along the river is spectacular and then you would walk up to the shoes and remind you of the terrible years of the Nazi times.

Powerful reminder. This place really makes you think and appreciate the life we are leaving in. this is a reminder to different things were not that long ago, and how people can so easily be influenced to do terrible things to other people. go there, have few moments for yourself, respect the people that lost there life there and in many other place in Europe during those dark days.the location is right on the Danube bank. when you walk from the Chain bridge to the parliament on the Pest side you will find it.
Poignant and touching. This is a touching and gentle reminder of an horrific episode in the city's past. It is worth the walk to the end of the promenade to see it

Powerful monument. The promenade along the Danube River near Parliament House is quite lovely then you spot something along the waters edge of the promenade. It is bronze (I think) shoes that might have belonged to children, teenagers, women and children (Jewish) who were lined up along the Danube and shot so that their bodies fell into the river. This is one monument that you will never forget.

We should not forget..... An interesting way of bringing the tragic story of the Holocaust alive. As a memorial to Jewish people from Budapest - some 25% of the population who were shot and thrown into the Danube during the WWII, there are approx 60 pairs of bronze shoes fixed into the paving on the river bank just outside the Parliament building (towards the Chain bridge side). It is a shame that there was not a little more visible information about this memorial, the only thing being a metal plaque in the pavement. It could have benefited by being much more informative and perhaps reduced the tendency of some of the less well informed visitors just to look at it as a photo opportunity with them standing in front he shoes!Well worth a visit.

Interesting (and Surprising). As I walked along the Danube promenade toward the Houses of Parliament, I was surprised to see what looked at first like a collection of discarded shoes near the river. Looking closely at them, I realized that they were cast in bronze and constituted a most unusual memorial.

Stunning-must see sight!. If it hadn't have been for TripAdvisor, I wouldn't have known about it! Thank you, TripAdvisor! Of course before I left on my trip, I consulted here where to go. I was amazed about this. No one I knew had heard of it. I also goggled it so I would know the story. My husband and I loved Budapest and decided to save it for the last day. It is close to in front of the Parliament and well worth spending a few minutes there to remember those that were treated so unbelievably cruel by the Nazi. This is one of those stories you don't hear about - and yet, MUST hear! I also did some reading and found out that one child managed to get away and hide. She watched her parents go into the river. She wandered around in town and a kind couple took her in when she told them what happened. Well, worth going to see this incredible and moving display of shoes.
We saw the shoes. They were of boys who committed suicide next to the parliament.We saw those shoes and wondered what they were doing.this was during the communist period when all the boys drowned

Thought provoking.... Just finished reading the poor and terrible reviews for the "danube shoes". I knew it was a long the river thus crossing the busy street was not an issue. It is not difficult to get to, if you just walk along the river...you will find it right before the parliament bldg. To describe it as underwhelming and paltry is ridiculous...a tribute/monument does not have to be large to be thought provoking, nor to have an emotional impact. As for complaints there is no signage, in this day and age that is a nonissue with computers, phones, i-pads! It is definitely worth seeing...no doubt about it!

Heartbreaking in its symbolism. If you travel to Budapest, after learning the story of the "shoes" I would highly recommend stopping at this tragedy filled spot, seat on a nearby bench, stare out at the Danube, and reflect.
Very moving. Our river boat moored up about 200mtrs from the shoe memorial.We stood and looked silently with others and I wondered are things improving in the world ????? people need to see it.
Poignant. On your walk along the river to see the parliament (right in front of it on the river), or on your way to Margaret Island

A simple but beautiful memorial. This is a monument to the people of Budapest who were shot into the Danube. It is simple but leaves a lasting impression. For those using the trip advisor app to help locate sights, I think I have it marked for location. It is located not far from parliament along the Danube - if you are facing parliament it is to the right.

Shoes on the Danube. A very moving tribute to the many Jewish People killed at Budapest during the Holocaust. Particularly move moving if you have been through the Jewish Quarter and seen the museums etc.

Overall it's in a strange location, but the thought is there. This is just to the left of the Parliament building (as you look from the Pest Side, towards the Danube)It's a terrible thought, but this marks the crimes of those in power after the Nazi's, who had such little regard for the lives of others, tossing them into the powerful river belowThe shoes are those of men, women, and children, along with a plaque, in the ground. Worth going, if for no other reason to ensure you remember.

Very moving. A set of about sixty pairs of boots and shoes cast in iron (I think?) and seemingly strewn on the banks of the Danube near the Parliament building. A memorial to Hungarian Jews who were shot, during WWII and their bodies thrown into the river. A very moving piece of artwork.
Please wear comfortable shoes. I had a long walk through the city by the area only pedestrian very convenient and less stressful. good shopping.

Sad poignant tribute to a dreadful episode of history. This outdoor installation is a reminder of the horrors of war. Very sad but worthwhile spending the time walking along the river towards the Parliament building and spending some time in contemplation of the suffering of these people. A story that deserves to be told despite the confronting nature...

Nice. These monument is in honor of the Jews who were killed in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. I was amazed by how realistic the shoes seemed to be, although they were made of iron. Looking upon them you feel kind of sad.
Moving. Very moving tribute to the horror that happened here. Good to stop and remember the inhumanity, so we don't let it happen again

Poignant reminder of a tragic past. This is well worth finding. It's near the Houses of Parliament, and it is a very poignant reminder of the tragic events surrounding World War II. People often leave flowers amongst the shoes. I was glad I was able to see this touching monument.
Moving tribute. Located next to the Parliament building next to the Danube, this is a moving tribute to those murdered in WW2. Worth visiting and reflecting.

Touching Memorial. We had particularly looked for the memorial and when we found it it wasn't what we expected. It was a very touching memorial and it gave me chills.
The people putting their feet into the shoes and having their photo taken was a little disappointing though.
An understated, but powerful exhibit. The exhibit is an easy walk along the river heading toward Parliament. The shoes are a quiet, but powerful reminder of the inhumanity of the Holocaust.

A Must to see in Budapest. This is a very moving place to be at. During the Holocaust the Nazis made Jewish men, women and children take off their shoes before they shot them into the Danube. It is behind the Parliament and it needs to be seen.

A sad memory. As I heard the tour guide explaining the existence of the steel shoes, I can imagine the row of ladies, children, men taking off their shoes before being shot down. What the devil were these gunmen -killing their own kind.

Graphic Picture of What happened to Lots of the Jews Living in Budapest. Along the shore of the Danube River there is about a two hundred foot section of shoes cast in metal. The shoes illustrated what happened to many of the 25% Jewish population living in Budapest during the German occupation. There were so many Jews to kill that the occupation forces lined up many of the Jews along the shore of the Danube River. They shot them, then shoved them into the Danube River. This was an excellent reminder of an evil time in history.

History. This is right on the Danube. It is to remember the Jews who had to take off their shoes before they were shot and fell in the river. Shoes were expensive and the murderers didn't want them wasted
Moving. moving place to visit and quite annoying watching people disrespect the area by trying on the shoes and posing for photographs ..

So sad. When we first came across this, I will admit I was not sure of the full story. However, after also visting the Holocaust museum too, it made this memorial very touching and emotional. People also place flowers in and around the shoes which show how much emotion this tribute has.

Very moving memorial. This was not easy to find but well worth the trouble. It's also worth visiting, for the sake of contrast the controversial sculpture of a (German Imperial) eagle snatching away Budapest's innocence created by the government this year - the shoes and other memorabilia also left in front of the new monument suggests not everyone agrees with the idea that Hungary was a completely innocent actor in WWII.
Very moving. A very moving & unusual monument to those who were murdered. You are bound to be taken past this if you do a tour of Budapest which I highly recommend.

If you want a definition of poignancy, here it is. I've been to Yad Vashem in Israel and Anne Frank's house in Amsterdam. This simple little display is up there with them in its expression of the horror of war.

Must Go, Small but Powerful. Just a few minutes walk on the riverfront from the Chain Bridge you'll find the Shoes.
It's an emotional experience to know what happened here, but more importantly we must vow to never let it happen again.

Moving tribute. Don't miss seeing this moving tribute to those who were shot there during WW2. It makes you stop, reflect and think how lucky we are now. It is located very close to Parliament just before, a short 5 minute walk from chain bridge. A bit of history kept alive worthwhile seeing.

Memory. A very strong reminder about what happened to the Jews of Budapest, by Hungarians, during the last months of WWII. It's so important to know history, not to rewrite it, and the memory also helps to value the present free and democratic Hungarian nation.

Emotionally Charged. We researched this prior to going to Budapest and had it on one of our must see items during our 3 days. We had a problem finding it at first because we expected it to be marked better. We also expected it to be right outside of the Parliament. Fortunately, we found people to help guide us to the way and were pleased to see it. We were also surprised to see a few tourist making light of the monument. They were playing around the shoes as if they had no idea of the meaning. Perhaps if someone would place a marker in different languages to describe the monument, it would eliminate people being what I saw as disrespectful. We are happy we were able to see this first hand. Very emotional.

Emotional Experience. A very poignant tribute in memory of the thousands of Hungarian Jews killed during the war. As described in previous reviews, this site is an emotional experience for people of all faiths. I found it especially heartbreaking in light of current events affecting many ethnic groups worldwide. Unlike some reviewers, I did not find it at all difficult to locate on the quay just down river from the Parliament.

Shoes on the Danube. This is a small monument of shoes representing the Jews who had died there. They're on the same side of the Danube river as the Parliament, in the direction towards Chains bridge. Its not very noticeable as its not big but worth a minute to stop and reflect.

Chilling, moving.. This modest, understated monument is reminder and a warning to us of where bigotry, blind hatred and intolerance can lead us. Never forget.The monument is on the banks of the Danube, 2 minutes walk from the Parliament building.
very important. Painful to look, but must see. For the memory - anyone should go. It gives you very strong feelings - good memorial
Respect for this memorial. There's no nees to 'review' this place. It's awfull what happed to the Jew's and it's good to take a moment and respect this place.
Shoes on the Danube. Although this is a small exhibit and sometimes difficult to find, it is very moving and worth the look!

Moving monument from nazi atrocities. The monument stands testament to the horrors the nazis inflicted on Jews during world war 2. The sight of the shoes brings us back to what truly transpired and the monument is proof to see daily.

Stop. Look. Reflect and Respect.. Don't say a word, just offer a moment of your time to respect the lives that once filled those shoes. This is an extremely poignant and emotionally charged experience. Don't miss the opportunity to reflect.

A moving experience. We sought this site out after visiting the Parliament building. It is a very moving experience seeing the representation of Budapest citizens that were murdered and their bodies thrown into the Danube during the Second World War. Take the time and be prepared to shed a tear.

poignent. Really the only word to use, poignent... says it all
This small monument on the banks of the danube, really makes you stop and think
the things people are capable of....
worth a visit

Pity about the inaccurate plaque.... This is a most moving memorial to those Jews who were shot in cold blood on the edge of the Danube river and whose bodies were allowed to just fall into the water. The group included men, women and children, and the artists have bronzed a series of old shoes of various descriptions to symbolise the people who were shot here and who had to leave their shoes behind.However, sadly, the plaque talks only about 'victims' of the Arrow Cross perpetrators,and not Jewish victims, despite them all being Jews. This seems to be symptomatic of a Europe-wide trend of locals not wanting to admit their own culpability in the slaughter of 6.000,000 Jews.

Pause for thought. Heart breaking to think what happened on the edge of the Danube. Worth seeing to learn more about Hungary's past especially when sections of the current government are denying that they sent Jews to concentration camps.
Surprisingly moving. A remarkable monument to the horrors of the holocaust-going to the holocaust centre later in the week just rams it home. Spent time there paying our respects

Moving experience - nearly. The Shoes on the Danube is an installation to commemorate the extermination of Jews snatched from a Wallenberg safe house in Budapest by the Hungarian Nazis (Arrow Cross) towards the end of WWII. The simple memorial sits at the point where they were lined up along the Danube, made to remove their shoes, then shot in the back of their heads to fall into the river. While the 60 pairs of period shoes, cast in bronze and including a child's pair of boots, are very moving, the two commemorative plaques are embedded in the ground and set back from the memorial so easy to miss (they look like drain covers). They also don't mention that the 'victims' were Jewish. Why ever not? Without clear signage/explanation, lots of tourists thought they were just a fun art installation and it was disturbing to see them 'trying on' the shoes and posing for holiday snaps.

Poignant. Having been to many Holocaust memorials, I found this one a unique way of bringing the tragic story of the Holocaust alive. As a memorial to Jewish people from Budapest who were shot and thrown into the river during the WWII, there are bronze shoes fixed into the paving on the river bank just 50 meters outside the Parliament building (towards the Chain bridge side). The texture of the worn metal makes them look very similar to the worn out leather boots the victims must have worn.
History not forgotten. This is a very moving memorial with sad history that hopefully we will never forget! Immediate;u at river's edge in Pest.

Very touching. These are shoes made from metal. They represent those people, mainly Jews and those who helped them, murdered at the tail end of the war. They were taken to the Danube and had to remove their shoes before being shot. Sometimes they were tied in threes and only the middle one was shot but they were all pushed into the river. When i visited there was evidence that people still leave flowers there today

Beautiful simplicity. Simple yet beautiful memorial for the victims of the holocaust. Just down from the parlimemt, youll find the bronze sculptures layed out with a few flowers hoding in some if the shoes.
Haunting and time for reflection. The story behind the shoes leaves you reflecting on how we could allow this sort of thing to happen.
Worth a visit. Very sad to hear the history but great that what happened in those times is at least being recognised.

Very moving.. These are shoes modelled from metal. They represent those people, mainly Jews and those who helped them, killed towards the end of the war. They were taken to the Danube and had to remove their shoes before being shot. Sometimes they were tied in threes and only the middle one was shot but they were all pushed into the river. People today still leave flowers there.

One of the most emotional monuments ever visited. This display was heart wrenching. One can't help but be overcome with emotion to think what actually took place in the not so distant past. It still brings tears to me eyes when I look at these pictures.

Sad thoughts about humanity. A sad reminder to Hungary's darkest years during wwll. The symbolism of the deserted shoes is overwhelming if you just try to think that beyond them were live people. People who have been cold blooded murdered and thrown into the Danube.

historical. its a touching memory, for the victims of the war, very clever, unique, and although i knew about it it was a surprise when i fall over it walking beside the river, of course its an attraction and everybody wanted to take a picture, its impressive that the artist made so many different kind of shoes, boots male and female, it wortths to see it

"Moving Memorial". The replicas of the shoes on the edge of the Danube are a must see. They represent a strong sense of what happened to the Jews here in the past. Easy to find along the Danube near to the Parliament building.Worth standing and looking at for just a few minutes as a mark of respect if nothing else.

touching memorial. Sad memorial to the brutality of the Hungarian Arrow Cross militias, who shot Jews into the Danube in 1944 & 1945. The bronze shoes are poetic and touching....people sometimes add flowers, ribbons, or written messages alongside. Go at sunset, when the light is golden.

Somber Holocaust monument - worth seeing. The Shoes on the Danube consists of 50 pairs of shoes signifying a memorial to the Jews who were killed by shooting them and letting their bodies drop into the Danube. It's a sad reminder of our history and definitely worth visiting. It is on the river promenade and can be accessed near the Attila Jozsef monument by the Parliament. By accessing the Shoes this way, you do not need to walk across tram tracks and it is fully handicap accessible.

A must see.. I had not read or seen this advertised anywhere before I went and discovered it upon chance. A very moving sculpture of shoes lined up along the river. In case you don't notice, there is a plaque on the floor close by explaining it.

Moving. I read about the memorial before i travelled to Budapest ,so i woke up early and went for a run from the city center to the parliament and back. I saw the memorial on the way. It was early so the place was empty got a good look and left ,but the simplicity of it and the memory behind it will last forever in my memory .

Sober Reminder. The metal replicas of men's, women's, and children's shoes are a stark reminder of the Nazi cruelty inflicted on the Hungarian Jews. Summarily, Jews were marched to the Danube, told to remove their shoes, then shot and thrown in the river. Nothing need to be said as you ponder this sight.

Poignant Memorial. I had never read or heard anything about the shoes beside the Danube in the beautiful city of Budapest so when our tour guide pointed them out, the tears came quickly. To think that the Jews were made to leave their shoes beside the river (so that someone else could use them) before being forced to jump in and subsequently be shot was heart-breaking. It really made this awful period of history painfully real. These metal shoes look so leather-like and are displayed so realistically that the meaning behind the monument is very clear.

Emotional. The sight of the "shoes" placed at the edge if the Danube as they would have been when the Jewish people were shot and dropped into the river is very emotive, especially the representation of a lair of child's shoes. To think that this happened within living memory is quite disturbing

A tribute to the departed. A tribute to the Jewish victims who were shot and drowned in the river.Some maps point to the location but it can be wrong so it's a little confusing to get to. It's located by the riverside between the Parliament and the Four Seasons Hotel (Gresham Palace) so get off the tram by the waterside across from the Gresham Palace and walk along the waterfront to find it.
melancholy place. Forget history if you don´t want to cry... binding site of passage and if possible know the history.50 meters shoes of various types for various ages and both sexes ...

A silent memorial. Very emotional memorial and should be seen when in Budapest. It is not well marked so it does take some investigation to find it. Walk along the Pest side of the Danube south of the Chain Bridge just before the Parliament is the memorial. Very sad and brings out emotional with its silent tribute.

Get there early. If you want to see the monument and get a photo, I would recommend you get down there quite early. It does get very busy around that area and difficult to get a good photo without hundreds of posing tourists around (which is exactly what I was!)

this shoes aren't made for walking. visiting this beautiful city just stand still, see and feel, remember this dark page of history. This 'monument' is turned down to the essential: the shoes left by those who where shote down into the Donnau. It's this simplicity what's make it so strong

Emotional. We had read about this memorial before travelling to Budapest. We were surprised to come upon it while out walking along the river. It is just there with only a plaque in the sidewalk as an explanation of the meaning of the memorial. It is very moving to stop and think about the poor souls who died in such a violent way.

As most memorials it was moving. As most memorials it was emotionally moving, however it was somewhat difficult to find. Words were not necessary to get the full effect. A simple reminder of many needless deaths in WW2
Nice to see it!. Very nice memorial, beautiful and impressive. It is a must see, and you can do it "on the way". It would be nice to have more information about it...

A Kind Remind from Past. While strolling a quite Danube Promenade looking at boats and ships newly moored to the pier, you suddenly stuck by the emotion of shoes seen at the edge of a river-bank. And 2 minutes passed until you realize the meaning of this installation : remembrance of Holocaust victims.

Poignant reminder. Shoes on the Danube is a very beautiful and touching memorial to victims of ww2, it can be found just near the parliament on the river bank of the Danube, walking towards the chain bridge. It's beautiful, and well done, and worth a visit whilst you're in Budapest,
Very Moving. Very touching to see the shoes - especially the ones that people have placed flowers in. A sad reminder of all of the poeple who perished.

A moving tribute to the fallen. Viewing the shoes all lined along the edge of the Danube was a somber experience. Knowing why they were there and the horror all those innocent souls went thru is so very moving.

Sad story mad beautiful. It is a very sad story about how the jews took of their shoes and then got shot and fell into the river. But it has been made beautiful, and people leave flowers in the shoes. It's close to the parlament.

Subtle and powerful. You can't be unaffected by this simple exhibit and still be breathing. Something pointed out by the bus tour guide but we did not stop. On my own walking tour I went back. Highly recommended.

Jewish Monument. This touch my heart. I don't know how people could be so cruel and try to destroy a people. They lined women and children along side the Danube and the Germans shot them where they stood. They fell into the Danube and the shoes were all that was left. I looked at this with tears in my eyes, and sorrow for those who vanished.

Small but Powerful!. My opinion is that this is one of the smallest memorials I have visited but paints the biggest picture in my mind. Men, women and even child size shoes left a lasting impression of the past on me. I believe the past shapes our future but sites like this leave me torn. I think it's a powerful memorial and so glad that we visited. It is close to Parliament so it is not out of the way to visit if you are in the area.
Heartbreaking. One of the most powerful monuments to the holocaust that I have ever seen. Simply heartbreaking story.
interesting memorial. Saw this memorial while on a lunch cruise on the Danube and wondered what the shoes were about. Now I know. more interesting than a plaque at the site.
Moving. Moving visit, horrors of war & human destruction shown with art & respect. Makes you think about how humans can be so destructive. Must see place.
Moving Memorial. But don't go out of your way. The memorial is just south of the Hungarian Parliament building which makes it easy to fit it into your travels though so its worth checking out.

Thought provoking. Not the most impressive monument you will ever see, but perhaps one of the most thought provoking. Definitely worth a visit, and I would recommend doing this after going to the Dohány Street Synagogue.
Deeply Moving. One of the most profoundly moving memorials to the life of jews in Budapest, who were exterminated almost entirely in just a few weeks.

Small Visually, Huge Conceptually. For a few shoes like this to have the impact that they do is strange, they don't look much as you approach but once there a solemnness seems to come rolling into your very soul like a cold fog. You can almost feel the lives that were shattered, the suffering, the deprivation and death. Although some felt it was in order to take 'selfies' there which is a little strange to say the least.
nice walk. It is an easy site to visit and close to the parliament building. Make sure to visit the museum of terror as well.

Sobering and Sad - yet beautiful. Walk down and see this monument. It's sad and sobering, but also quite amazing. While in Budapest we walked down to the river to see this and then walked around the area by the parliament as well. It's definitely something that's worth taking the time to see up close.

Moving and important. I avoid Holocaust memorials - I have lived with it all my life and going to see one is usually not on my list - this is different. It paints a picture in a very simple way. The shoes represent the Jews who were forced to remove them before they were shot and ended up in the Danube. I won't debate the Hungarians role with the Nazi's - let's just say there is lots of room for discussion. However this is a reminder that of the cost in human life in a way that you can understand instantly but not like the displays/museums in many other parts of the world.I recommend you go - this is suitable for children and all ages.

Appalling.... ...unless you're into the whole "let's make the Hungarian people as ashamed as possible constantly". All while not considering that they were the ones who resisted the Nazis the longest and Hungary was the last refuge in central Europe for the Jews.I'm not saying this event didn't take place, it's just that this place isn't anything I'd recommend anyone visiting under normal circumstances, even less so while on holiday. Most of all, it isn't an attraction.

Most moving and poignant. Seeing these shoes that were broken, odd/not pairs or even the same size and some were so tiny... And knowing they represent people who were killed at this point in WW2 is emotional and painful but, we must not forget.

Poignant memorial. We enjoyed a pleasant stroll along the Pest side of the Danube towards the Parliament, with the aim of finding the memorial. It is a poignant and interesting monument. We also did the Synagogue tour and so this fit in well with that. Worth a visit!
Shoes. What a wonderful way to depict people but such a sad story and one we don't appear to have learnt from!

Riveting and Devastating. This memorial to the Hungarian Jews shot at the edge of the Danube at the end of WWII is shattering. They were taken to the edge of the river, asked to remove their shoes and were brutally executed by Hungarian state police (Not Nazis).
Holocaust victims memorial. We just happened across this by accident on our way to the Parliment building, but I highly recommend seeking it out while you are in Budapest. Simple but very poinient.
Don't miss this. If you are not moved by this work of art, check to see if your heart is beating. It gives you a real perspective of how the Jews suffered under the Nazis.

A simple but powerful exhibit, read more for a second one not far. It is almost just behind the parliament on the river bank, easy to find. A very sad remembrance but very important.It is interesting to notice that such a remembrance exhibit is now developing on Szabaság Tér (Freedom square) where the controversial memorial monument has been erected. Instead of brass, it is made of real shoes and souvenirs and it's a live exhibit because it is growing day after day.

Unique art. This symbol is found on the river bank between The Chain Bridge and The Parliament Building. You can even notice it when heading north on Tam #2. The shoes symbolises all kind of victims, old and young, rich and poor,...

Brings tears to my eyes. One of my favorite memorials ever. The story behind it is so sad... it's about the Jews who were killed in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank. Above all, one small group of tourists was standing and quietly singing next to the memorial, and after that I saw some of them crying. That was a very touching moment for me, a bunch of different emotions. Symbolism that I see in this memorial... you don't have to actually walk in someone else's shoes to feel compassion for his pain and misery but these shoes can be timeless reminder that all people are the same and that everyone should be treated with equal respect, regardless of nationality and religion (or gender, education, sexual affiliation, age...) :(

Moving. Would recommend anyone in Budapest to have a look at this, research it before on Google as there is isn't much about it there just a plaque in a few different languages. It moved me and the people I was with to tears.
Powerful. This was a simple but powerful and thought-provoking artistic memorial. Really a must see for art and history appreciators.

Beautiful in its simplicity. It's easy to miss this moving monument to the victims of the Arrow Cross, but I highly recommend you do not do so. Visiting only takes a small amount of time but will impact you for a long time after.

Incredibly moving...... Iron shoes along the Danube.... they show where Jews were shot and then thrust into the river by the Arrow Cross. Incredible monument that everyone should see. We were moved to tears.

A thought provoking piece of public art.. This piece of art work is a row of shoes made from cast iron on the banks of the Danube. It was created as a memorial to the Jews who were taken to the banks of the Danube, executed by gun shot and pushed into the river. They had to remove their shoes before being executed.It is a thought provoking piece of art though some tourists didn't seem to get the massage, taking their shoes off and putting them amongst the cast iron shoes and photographing themThe majority of folk did treat the artwork with respect.
horror shoes. This is a line of steel shoes in the memory of the hungarian jews executed in butapest in the 2 world war.

Thought provoking. Is really thought provoking and a bit eye welling, 20,000 Jews were murdered, shot at the edge of the Danube, but then you think of the atrocities of Isis in the last couple of weeks, will us humans never learn?
Moving Monument. Just a short walk south of the Hungarian Parliament, it's a simple but moving monument. Just go out the Parliament visitor center Danube side door and walk a few blocks south.
A sad memory. Although it is a sad memory behind those shoes but the artist did an amazing job here.All those shoes looks like made in leather not bronze.
Makes you think!. For quite a small scale landmark, this really hits home of what happened to the Jews all those years ago. Worth taking a look.
Moving tribute. Free…just walk along the Danube and you come upon these shoes. What a feeling! So sad to look at and memories just make you gasp!

So sad.... A memorial to the Jewish people and others who were shot and killed at the Danube during WW II. Every time I took the tram to the downtown area I passed these shoes and was reminded of some of the history of Budapest and the sad things that happened here.

Blood-curdling homage. To the Hungarian Jews. The Jewish Hungarian population had suffered discrimination but their fate had been more positive than other European Jews. At the end of WWII, unfortunately, this changed and thousands of them were killed. A particularly macabre method was to kill them and then, throw them to the Danube. This piece of art consists of several iron-forged shoes, which appear to be "forgotten" by their owners. It´s a minimalist, humanistic piece of art that shakes your spine and makes you think of all those people whose lives were supressed just because of stupid and fruitless violence.
Moving. This eloquent tribute to those who were rounded up, shot and pushed into the river is sobering. Once can see the men, women and children in one's mind's eye.

Sad Times. A tribute and reminder of the terrible crimes committed against the sick, poor, and helpless . These poor people were lined up at the river, made to remove the shoes, then shot ! There bodies floated away to the Black Sea.

Moving. A bit tricky to find. If you head to the Parliament and approach the Danube from there, it will be approximately 250m to your left.A few shoes were missing or worn down badly, need a bit of TLC but a wonderful memorial with perfect simplicity.
Very Moving. I came across this memorial while touring Budapest. It has stayed with me. One of the most moving, disturbing, haunting, touching memorials I have ever encountered.

Moving. Moving reminder of the terrible act that happened on that spot. There really should be a plaque or notice at the site, this would perhaps inform those who visit, the reason for the shoes being there. This may stop people trying to put the shoes on which I found slightly disrespectful, only my opinion.
Emotionally Impactful. My wife did research and we needed to see this important sight along the Danube. The shoes represented the all the humans that were killed along the river in World War II.

A sad but beautiful sculpture. This is such an amazing sculpture it just expresses the loss without having to know the background story. The attention to detail texture and the use of old shoes..... Beautiful.
Moving Memorial. Different than any other Holocaust memorial. On the bank of Danube and free. Five minutes is all you need. Check it out before or after taking a Danube River cruise.
Contemplate on the story!. Definitely worth a visit! It's moving through its simplicity! It's better knowing its story before visiting.

A Magnificent Memorial. At this site in 1944 the Arrow Cross fascists of Hungary took about twenty thousand Jews to the Danube and shot them. The sculptured empty shoes is to remind everyone of what happened there.
Moving Memorial. Out of many memorials that I have seen, I believe this one is the most unique for the subject. It is so simple, yet so moving that one cannot help but stop and reflect.

Beautiful reminder. Apparently this site is not so far from the Parliament, it's even shown in my guide map, and I found it unintentionally. It's a nice reminder of what happened in this river to the Jews. Make a short stop here if you are in the area!
Very sad. It's a nice walk along the river, sad exhibition of shoes Of killed people with flowers in them and little candles.

So moving, so detailed. A simple idea: the shoes left behind of those shot and thrown into the Danube during the war. Yet the shoes reflect the individual, an echo of a person's life .. Cut short. Mesmerising and moving.

heart wrenching. We drove by this monument before knowing what it stood for and it was thought-provoking and haunting even then. When we understood the meaning of the shoes everyone was silent. Very effective memorial. I will leave you to find out more about the shoes on the Danube.
A sombre remindner. Located at the Pest side of the Danube, this a sad reminder but well presented of the murder of Hungarian Jews, a must to visit.

Emotional. Although it did took us a little time to find this, when we did it was a very emotional experience, it really makes you think that people could be that desperate that they would jump into the freezing water. A must see for all visitors

A must if you want to learn about Budapest during the 1940 war years in their treatment of the Jews. It is one of a kind of monument no where else in the world.
Try to read up on it before you go, so you can fully appreciate the meaning. Take tissues

Shoes on the Danube Embankment memorial, Budapest, Hungary. This very eloquent memorial to Hungarian Jews killed by the Arrow Cross militiamen is one of the most moving monuments I've ever seen. If you come across it by accident as you walk down along the Danube (about 10 minutes from the Hungarian Parliament building), as I did, I think the impact will be all the greater.

A moving remembrance. The shoes stretch along part of the Pest side of the Danube bank and commemorates the Jews who were lined up along the river, ordered to remove their shoes, and shot by fascist arrow cross militia men. There are no big notice boards, only small metal plaques at either end, but the memorial is no less moving for that. The metal casts are really lifelike, from men's shoes and workbooks, to women's heeled shoes and even some smaller ones for children, and it is all to easy to imagine the fate of the owners. Some flowers and notes left in the shoes show that this is is seen as a place of remembrance, and the people there when we went were silent and respectful.

A very moving monument!. This monument consists of shoes of babies, adults, old people, etc. along the bank of the Danube. It is a poignant reminder of the terrible killing of the Jews in Budapest who were lined up at the edge of the river, made to disrobe and then shot in the back so they would drown in the river. The Hungarians have put a tiny plaque on the ground indicating it is in memory of victims of the Nazis. They neglect to mention that the Jews were the victims. ( In fact, they neglect to mention that at the Raoul Wallenberg Memorial as well.)

Very moving. It's hard to say you loved the place associated with death of others, but Danube Promenade memorial was very moving. Except for some tourists taking smily pictures with the shoes in the background.. not the place for that..

Somber & unforgettable. First of all, until trip advisor uses my report to change the location, it is wrong on their off-line APP/map.
