I have attached a screen shot, it is on the "Pest" side, midway between the Margaret Bridge and the Chain Bridge. This is a fantastic memorial. You have to read up on the history first, because as many reviewers mentioned, there is a basic plaque, which I actually think is a perfect compliment. It forces you to learn about it before or after, either way, to use your curiosity. Erected in 2005, the sculptor knew full well that future viewers would access the internet to learn about it, or ask locals.A full plaque would diminish the point of the sculpture.According to Wikipedia:"It is located on the Pest side of the Danube Promenade in line with where Zoltan Street would meet the Danube if it continued that far, about 300 metres (980 ft) south of the Hungarian Parliament and near the Hungarian Academy of Sciences."
A sad reminder. WE had read about the shoes on the Danube and why the memorial is there, but nothing prepared me for the emotion of seeing the shoes. Just go and see it for yourself.
sad. inbetween chain bridge and parliament building along the side of the river, a reminder of those who were thrown into the freezing Danube,very sad.

Moving and an important reminder.... Very important to remember, even now.
The Jews were shot by the Facist Arrow Cross mob that sympathized with the Nazi activities in Budapest.
It's important to note that the Jews were betrayed and shot by their neighbors, not the Nazi's.
A very sad history for Hungary and for us to remember............

Shoes. If you know the history it's quite moving, we stumbled upon them on our way back from the parliament building, was nice to see... No plaque but someone had put a little sign saying it was where Jews were shot into the Danube
The Shoes of the Danube. A very somber experience. A must see for all Budapest visitors. It's important that people remember the atrocities that were carried out in the closing days of WW2.

Painfully nice memento of a terrible period of human existance. It's nothing but a very simple "statue collection" on the bank of Duna, very close to the Parliament. Makes me cry whenever I see. Even from the car window. But depends on your sensitivity. Take your time.

Very moving..... Of all the things I saw in Europe this memorial was the most moving and heart wrenching. You feel such sorrow for the men, women and children that were executed. 'Shoes on the Danube Bank' honors the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen (who were in sympathy with the Nazis) in Budapest during World War II--1944 to 1945. The Jews were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It was created by film director Can Togay and sculptor Gyula Pauer on the bank of the Danube River in 2005

Moving Tribute to Hungarians Killed During Nazi Occupation. The Shoes on the Danube in Budapest Hungary is a moving tribute to all those of the Jewish Faith who were massacred by the Nazis during the occupation in WWII. No words or explanation needed, a time for reflection.
Very poignant. Such a simple yet highly impactful memorial to victims of the Holocaust. These empty shoes are so stark yet remind the visitor that real people were murdered.

Emotional . when u look at the women, men and children shoes and u imagine what happened in that scenery...you can't help to feel a mix of beauty vs sadness... u just have to go there. It's a unique experience...and the photos are so incredible taken here.

Shoes on the Danube Promenade. Check out the shoes on the Danube Promenade while you are taking a nice walk along the river-bank. The shoes mark the spot where many Jews were shot into the river by the Nazis. The artist(s) have done a great job and it is an appropriate yet confronting image. There is no fence along the river bank but people don't seem to fall in.

Moving. This sculpture on the bank of the Danube is simple and well done. We came across it by accident, but had read about it and took a moment to observe and reflect. Incorporate this into a walk by the Parliament house and along the river.
City tour . We stopped here on a city tour. It marks the place where the nazis shot Jews into the river, leaving their shoes behind. Very sad and moving.

Educational. Not very convenient to get to due to some construction but worth it. Our trip included an excursion to Auschwitz which could be overwhelming. This relatively small piece of artwork/sculpture seemed to say it all. My children seemed to begin to understand the terrible nature of the holocaust when they understood the significance of the shoes on the Danube. It's relatively close to the US/Russian Embassy and statue of Reagan which was a bonus for us. From here you can walk across the Szechenyi Bridge so it would be easy to incorporate other places to visit. It was very moving and there weren't a lot of other visitors at any given time so no crowding.
A grim reminder.... An all to vivid reminder of the loss of life at the hands of the Nazis. An entire population was devastated during the programs.
Beautiful and sad. Sculpture itself is very beautiful and made very original. But when you read what it is dedicated, it becomes very frustrating

Moving. Everyone should walk along the banks of the Danube and marvel at Budapest and its history. The shoes are just so so sad, even on a lovely sunny day when all was well with the world it brought tears to my eyes.

special memorial. Definitely worth seeing but very sad story. 60 pairs of shoes is a memorial for Jewish people tied together. This murder happened as the war was ending by tying a group together with a rope. As one person was shot and fell into the Danube the rest fell in to the river drowning. horrible murder that I will never forget.

Moving Experience.. The display of shoes by the river is a very moving experience as each shoe seems to have its own story to tell you.When my Wife and I visited here there were a group of 20 or 30 Jewish people on a education visit to the site. At the end of a presentation by one of the Leaders they formed a circle and began singing a lovely song which started with a few people and more and more joining in. This moved us very much and I could not believe seeing a single shoe floating down the river as they sang. A moment we will never forget.
meaningful to say the least. The austerity of the exhibit is fitting tribute to the tragedy marked. Very well done and worth a visit and reflection.

Fitting memorial to a VERY tragic part of world history. One cannot help but feel a "personal" connection to people one never knew; not related to; nor anything else BUT the tragedy of what EVIL can do in the world.
As you walk along the Danube, STOP and reflect at this location for 5-10 minutes.
NEVER AGAIN !!

Very Sobering Site. This is a very sobering site - it commemorates the killing of Jews in Budapest during WWII. Victims were brought to the river's edge and had to remove their shoes before they were shot and their bodies dumped into the river. The shoes appear as if they were just recently left there. It is easily accessed along the promenade. There is also a tram line that runs very close to it.

A place to reflect. This simple memorial is very effective on making you reflect on how intolerant people can be to others. It would be a shame not to visit this place on the river between Parliament buildings and the Chain Bridge when in Budapest. It is not visited on the free walking tour.

Beautiful historical location. This monument to Jewish murders is both sad and beautiful. I recommend seeing some of the other Jewish sites before this one, or at least reading a travel book to understand the significance of it as there is no plaque that I saw. In WW2, a facist hardline group won power and killing of Jews was their mandate. In particular, many were shot at the river's edge, often tied together so that those who didn't die would be drowned when they fell in with the shooting victims. This sad monument is iron shoes at the edge of the river. Hungary is lovely but has a dark history worth understanding.
Shoes!. It's very moving, very pointed. just the pluck could be more informative and better placed for visibility.
Shoes stop you. The memorial of shoes reminds us of the Second World War history, the decline of democracy, and the value of human rights. The shoes really stopped all the passersby.
Shocking. How can one human be so cruel to others. This was one of the most poignant trbutes to those who died at the hands of the Arrow Cross Militia. This is a must see for everyone.

Moving.... Very close the the parliament building, this is a WWII memorial to Jews who were forced to remove their shoes then shot at the edge of the river so that their bodies fell into the Danube. A very moving tribute.

Heartbreaking, but not to be missed. A display of bronze shoes, singles and pairs, womens', mens' and childrens', just at the edge of the Danube River, looking for all the world like they were left there moments before when their owners, Budapest Jews, were shot and literally fell out of their shoes. One of the best memorials of World War II atrocities that I have ever seen, this display made me cry.

Poignant reminder of the fallen Jews. This is located along the Danube just after the chain bridge on the Pest side. Its a very fitting tribute to the fallen and a rather unique way to remember the way the people in the city suffered.

Mooving monument. The bronze shoes are set on the banks of the river just down from the parliament building in a quiet area suitable to contemplate the deeds they represent,my only criticism is that some of the shoes were left filled with dead flowers and burnt out candles from past tributes making them a bit scruffy.Definately worth a visit.

Respectful, compelling. We had read about this memorial along the Danube in the heart of Budapest, but pictures don't do it justice. No, it's not grandiose, in fact, it's rather small. The whole sculpture along the river is perhaps100 feet long and no more than 2 feet wide. I'll leave it to you to research the depth of the meaning for this venue. It's easily accessible when riding one of Budapest's trams (please buy an all-day pass. they are dirt cheap.) If you have young people in your group, this might be one of the important stops for you to explain the horrors of Hitler's actions. I do recommend a visit. It's free.
Sad place. Israelis was important for us to get to it. And laconic simplicity of this symbol speak without words. You can not sit back and laugh nearby.

unique monument. This is a unique monument commemorating the killing of Hungarians by the Nazis. Nazis lined up prisoners, shot them, and pushed them into the Danube at the spot where the shoes are embedded in cement next to the Danube.

Shoes. We stumbled on the bronze shoes near the Parliament house. We didn't see a plaque written in english but we were told that this was the spot that the Nazi's lined up Jews, shot them and threw them into the Danube. It was very moving.

Very sombre reminder of a ghastly past. The Shoes on the Danube promenade is a memorial to the Jewish people shot by the pro Nazi Hungarian forces. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. The memorial symbolizes the shoes they left behind. Very touchy.
So simple yet so moving. The little bronze child's boots made me have a lump in my throat, especially as someone has stuck a little flower on them
Heart Wrenching. This display of shoes of all sizes and styles was heart wrenching - both in its meaning and its simplicity.A stark reminder of ghastly inhumanity.
very touching scene. makes you think how fortunate and blessed we are. makes you think what people had to endure in those years and hopefully we will never see again
Poignant. This is a memorial to the Jews shot into the Danube by the Nazis. It is very moving and well worth seeing. Tie this into a trip to Parliament.

a very somber experiance but a must. knowing the background into the shoes brought it all to life and i do feel sorry for anyone that visits them not knowing what it is for. one of the only parts of the trip which brought a tear to my eye, as it just so the realism of it all

Heart breakingly appropriate. I wish we'd had time to stop, but even driving past the shoes tells a story. This is a memorial to those killed in the holocaust of WWII and consists of empty shoes along a bank of the Danube.

Beautiful memorial and remembrance of a horrible time.. The shoes on the Danube memorial is sobering and for me a must see. We walked from the Hilton Castle District by taking the Funicular down the hill then a nice walk across the Chain Bridge. Then stroll down the Danube until you see the monument across from The Parliament Building. It was a good way to start our day walking to the Museum of Terror. The memorial is simple and succinct so google it and read about it because the signage is probably not in your language. Highly recommend!

An unusual sight. Although it is just a line of small 'statues' of various style and size shoes and boots, it makes a nice unusual picture. I had to lean close to the 'figures' in order to check if they are not actually just shoes. Not sure it is worth a special trip but is fun if you come across it walking along the Danube on the Pest side. The walk itself is also quite a treat.

Sobering Memorial. There is now a way to cross the highway (different than some guide books tell you). Face the shoes, head down the stairs and to the right a few yards away is a crossing signal. We did it the hard way first, then returned this way.It is at the base of the Parliament Building, so take Tram #2 over there. It's about a five minute visit, unless you want to linger and study each pair of shoes more intently. I saw pebbles, candles, and some momentos which makes for a more meaningful visit.

Powerful Reminder.... ....of man's inhumanity to man. It is not the easiest place to get to, but compared to what these victims of Nazi oppression endured, a walk along the Danube is nothing. The visual image of all these empty shoes should serve as a reminder that this should never be allowed to happen again.

A very moving memorial. Please make it a point to go visit this memorial. Very moving. Iron shoes depicting the victims of the massacare that took place once here. Spend a few minutes there and pray for those who were shot . It's close to the Parliament and city centre

Don't Miss It. A remarkable image to help remind us of Nazi rule. There is no parking close to the shoes, instead, take the time to walk the promenade on the water and discover this memorable location.
Nicely done. Doesnt cost anything but worth a visit if you feel sympathy for the Hungarian Jew victims. Spectacular view to the other side of Danube river.

Powerful and Moving Sight on the banks of the Danube. It is sad to think that humans can treat one another with such distain. But perhaps memorials like Shoes on the Danube Promenade will help us to pause and remember the horror of the past and help us to prevent such tragedy in the future. Well worth a short (or long) visit to think about our History and our future.

Moving. We made sure that we found the spot along the Danube where this memorial lied. We had read about this, and the realisation of actually seeing all the shoes was simply moving. One doesnt need to say anything, have notice boards telling you what this is all about, etc-one just needs to look, listen, and sympathise with the individuals and famalies that suffered such attrocities. A memorial that is different to what you may be expecting, but a must see on your walk along the promenade on the river banks.

Monument to the dark times. If you are near the embankment, do not miss it - it is closer to the parliament and after seeing auschwitz, we could not help but feel the pain of the people that suffered during those times

Lost to the River. The Shoes are located just a short walk from the Chain Bridge on the Pest side. An unusual piece of art, it is a moving reminder of the Jewish citizens that were brutally murdered in such a beautiful place.

Very moving and melancholy.. When we stopped to look at these shoes the other day one had the flag of Israel inserted with a small bunch of flowers. Sadly while we were looking at it the wind took the flag and flowers and blew them into the river just like those good people back in 1944/45.
Thoughtful. Very sad place, a must see though, makes you appreciate what you have and where we are today. Everyone should take a while and visit this lonely place on the Danube.
Such devasting but important history. This site is well worth seeing and a good reminder of how unkind mankind can be to each other. Very poignant.

history. You don't have to be a Jew to visit this monument on the Danube.If you don't look for it 'you will not find it/You have to walk on the river side,otherwise you miss it.You will not see it from far,and the sign lies on the ground-you have to look for it - sign in several languages-hebrew, english and hungarian.The shoes of the victims that survived the holocaust near to the end of the war,were "pushed" to the river to their death by Hungarian fanatics.It is a must.Such a minimalist monument,yet such a strong experience.For us to learn and never experience it again.

Simple but emotive. In front of the Parliament building, a simple line of bronze shoes - men's, women's and children's - in memory of the Jews who perished here. People obviously leave flowers in and around the shoes - a simple but moving reminder of man's inhumanity to man.

Simple, but affecting. As a labor saving device (!), undesirables, especially Jews, were lined facing along the Danube so that when they were shot in the back, they would fall into and be carried away by the river. But shoes were valuable, so the people about to be shot would be forced to take them off first.To commemorate this horror, this simple monument consists of sculpted shoes lined up and facing the river - all that was left of the victims. The pairs that brought me close to tears were the two pairs that belonged to a man and woman, with the shoes of a child between them.Three plaques on the ground, one each in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew, give a short explanation of when and what occurred.

A memorial sculpture not to be missed. This is, as other reviewers have noted, an outstanding piece of sculpture designed to commemorate the 100,000 Jews tied together and shot on the banks of the Danube by Hungarian fascists called the Arrow Cross AFTER the Nazis had fled the city. It is Hungary's own antidote to the denial it routinely practises, and to present-day antisemitism. Yet it is so positioned that unless you happen to walk for several kilometres along the banks of the Danube, you have to take your life in your hands and cross two two-lane highways to reach it. (An accident? I wonder...) That's what we did with our local guide, and it was worth the risk. Others have lost far more. We stood in silence and contemplated the bronze shoes, frozen in time, but bearing testimony to Hungary's grim and often distorted history.

Moving...after being confused. We didn't know what this was all about (there are no signs in English nearby explaining it), but when we found out later appreciated the simplicity and beauty of this memorial.

Thought-provoking, highly unusual sculpture..... After touring the Parliament Building on Sunday 5/11, my wife & I walked south, back to our hotel along the east bank of the Danube, specifically to visit the Shoes sculpture. The cool, rainy weather seemed to add to the mood of the artwork. It's hard to describe one's emotional reaction to the many types of sculpted shoes - men & women, young & old, rich & poor - that cumulatively evoked harrowing images of countless Jews who were shot & dumped in the river during the Holocaust.By all means take a few moments to visit this singular piece of searing, provocative art.

Whose shoe?. Sad items to be seen on the banks of the Danube River. The memorial is one that leaves you with the sadness for the era the Jewish people had to flee their native country. At least one can never forget through these images

Very touching place. It is a very thouching place, we visited on an evening promenade and we were very impressed. If you take a walk along the Danube it' s worth visiting this place because it' s special.
A Place of Sorrow. It moved me to tears to visit here. Very emotional. Can't say too much more without welling up in tears. Please, do take the time, and effort, to visit here.
Surprising art. It small and discrete - yet draws a lot of attention. If yu go for promenade, take a few minutes there. We liked it.

Very moving. Many people seem to walk past this without realising the significance of the shoes.In late 1944 early 1945 Arrow Cross militiamen, a fascist group lined up Jewish men,women and children, had them remove their shoes and shot them leaving them to fall into the Danube.Everyone passing this should stop and think for a while and remember.
tough. The simpleness but yet the emotion of this memorial make it worth going to see. I can't say I enjoyed it, because of what it represented, but I was glad that I saw it.
A stark reminder. As you walk along the Danube and come to this memorial you can't help but feel sadness. It is a reminder to us all of the evil acts of the Nazi's who shot innocent jews here.

Overlooked piece of history. Until we went to Budapest I didn't know the story. It's always thought provoking what happened on that very public spot. Looking around at the beautiful sights, you wouldn't believe it. The children's shoes are the most haunting. Hungary has a number of unique historical memorials.

A very moving sight. When seeing this monument, dedicated to the Jews who were shot and killed along the Danube during the Nazi era, you can only be profoundly affected. The shoes are those of men, women and children which makes even more of an impact. Several of the shoes held flowers. This is relatively easy to find, a short walking distance from the Parliament building and not too far from where many of the river cruise boats dock. If not familiar with Hungarian history during WWII, I would strongly suggest visiting Budapest's Holocaust Museum beforehand.
simple but powerful memorial. A highlight of a walk along the Danube, this memorial is simple, understated and very moving. Take some time to pause and reflect when you get to this spot.

Bronze shoes on the Danube. I was effected by seeing the shoes representing the Jews who were shot and died at the of Danube by the Nazi's. One can imagine the people who died. The shoes.....well it brought it to a different level of evil.

Poignant. Beautiful setting overlooking the Danube and beauty of the Buda castle district with a backdrop of the parliament building contrasts the terribleness these shoes symbolise.The shoes don't differentiate between levels of affluence, gender or age. All cross sections of Hungarians suffered this terrible fate towards the end of WWII.A simple but hugely emotive memorial.
Go at dusk. Its not about the quality of the art, but the meaning behind it. See it in the late evening then watch as the castle and bridges light up once it gets dark.

Moving. What a heart wrenching experience to see the shoes of all these holocaust victims. To know that these people removed their shoes and were shot and their bodies were dumped in the Danube is horrifying. This is a great memorial to those people!
Emotive. It can give you chills to think and imagine why these shoes are here, but it's worth it to be there and think about it so it doesn't happen again.

moving tribute to wartime deaths. The line of cast bronze shoes, seemingly just discarded by their owners range from business men's brogues to tiny baby shoes. Making it a poignant reminder of those who lost their lives through brutality during WW2.

Moving simple remembrance to victims of war. A touching memorial to Hungarian victims murdered by Arrow Cross militiamen (Nazi allies) and subsequently dumped in the Danube.By the waterside close to the parliament building.

Poignant. This tribute to those Jewish people shot at rivers edge is simple and poignant. The only issue is that it is hard to find. Access the river bank at the cross walk just south of the Parliment building. Then walk south a bit.
Very moving. A short walk from the Chain Bridge on the Pest side heading towards Parliment is the Shoes Memorial. Very simple and very moving and the shoes say it all
Danube shoes. Such an interesting thing to see and just makes you feel so sad for what the hungarian Jews had to endure. Nice that they erected a plaque for this.
forgotten people. Moving experience to walk past realizing what had happened along the river. Not the place for posing for photos like some were doing.

so moving. Walking along the Danube and you happen upon a series of shoes made out of bronze. They represent the Jews who were murdered there, then their bodies thrown into the river. Most touching were the children's shoes. They are filled with stones, or candles, or flowers...what people have left as a reminder that they were there. So very sad.

Understated and moving. Possibly one of the most understated Holocaust memorials in Europe, this monument is very easy to walk past and dismiss, which is probably the point. A salutary reminder that is so easy to dismiss reports of prejudice and hatred, and even easier to walk past without realising what is going on. Take time to have a look at these shoes, remember what happened here all those years ago, then take some time to look at what is happening in the world today, and hope that we can stop others being treated in the same way as the owners of the shoes.

A stark and simple reminder of the holocaust. We found this by chance on the way back from the Parliament. We noticed a large group of Jewish people congregating here and placing flowers at the spot.It is very sad and one cant help wondering about these Hungarian people who were murdered here. A sombre atmosphere.

A tearful remeberance. A very sobering memorial to those victims of this heinous atrocity. The sculptures are so simple but so compelling. Seeing the shoes was a personally moving experience, and the setting provided a natural place for reflection on the inhumanity of the war and the suffering it brought to the people of its time.

a minutes silence...... a very touching symbolism of the black history in the 1940's. These shoes could have belonged to anyone - there were all sizes, including children's sizes. They remind us to never let these atrocities occur again.

What a breathtaking spot to visit.... There's nothing to dislike here, being at the memorial, its just a poignant spot to pause an take a breath and acknowledge the sacrifice of those who went before.Being there had me appreciate my life, what I have and those whom I love.I'd highly recommend a visit here.

A sad must-see location. During the last year of WW2 most of Hungary's Jews were shipped in cattle wagons to Auschwitz and gassed there. But the Hungarian Nazis kept a "local enterprise" as well. They gathered thousands of Jews, men women and children to the Danub's shore chained them to each other shot them into the river. The monument of the shoes is a moving reminder of the atrocity. One cannot stop the tears when you see the tiny shoes of an ifant.
So moving. This is a very moving memory of the fallen. Read about it before you go or if you come upon whilst walking alongside the river look it up after.

A lyrical and poignant reminder of the city's history. The bank of the Danube has its fair share of romanticism and mythology. It is precisely against this backdrop that this installation becomes especially meaningful. The past, the violation of humanity, the larger canvass of beauty and our capacity to heal and reflect collides in this beautiful and inspirational piece of work. This is a quiet but powerful reminder of suffering and cruelty. It brought tears ... .
Very sad site. One of the things left in the concentration camps were shoes. They collected them and have placed them alone the water front. Men's, women's and children.

View of a christian. I visited the site of the Shoes by myself. It was one of the most moving experiences for me having grown up with many Jewish friends. To think, a brutish army/militia could march innocent beings down to the river, tell them to take their shoes off and then shoot them, looking at them in the eye is beyond words.

HOME GROWN KILLERS. This is a powerful and evocative memorial to the Jewish victims of Hungarian Fascists who dragged fellow citizens from their homes and took them to the Rivers edge, made them step out of their shoes, shot them in the back and threw their body in the river.A moving must see for anyone interested in the real history of Hungary and The Shoah.

An easy walk from Chain Bridge. The walk along the Danube is pleasant by itself and the memorial is meaningful. It is unfortunately not well kept and the signage is not aging well. If you have a sense of the atrocities committed during the late 1930s and early 1940s it will be worth your time.

Touching. Be sure you have a guide to explain the story, or at least a good guidebook. It is touching and strong reminder to be certain nothing like this may ever happen again. It brought memories of the Holocost Museum in Washington, D.C. But this is stronger because it is the very spot that it happened. Make time to stop. It only takes a couple of minutes, but you will remember this spot and beautiful view of the River.

Haunting and disturbing!. This is a very powerful monument to remind all humanity of how horrible and twisted the nazis were during WWII. I won't sugar coat my review of this monument....it will affect you. I would not recommend bringing children to this monument as having to explain its significance would be very difficult especially since there are children's shoes displayed as well :(

Soles for Souls. We passed this landmark memorial to Jews murdered at that spot during WWII twice while in Budapest. Once on a bus tour of the city and secondly on our way to the Viking Cruise ship Embla upon which we would voyage the Danube from Budapest to Bucharest. A moving tribute to the Jews murdered at that spot During WWII. One may read more about the memorial online.

Sad reminder. The shoes are a poignant reminder of the atrocities of war and genocide. It was very humbling to look at the individual pairs of shoes and imagine the person who would have worn them. What was most troubling were the shoes of children. I can't imagine how or why anyone could take the life of an innocent child. You leave the memorial realizing how much we can be grateful for peace.

Have to see. If you miss this it would be a shame. The first time we were in Budapest we did not get to this so when we came back we had to go. To think that someone would actually do this to humans is beyond comprehension. Thanks to the person who preserved this in bronze

Not an easy find but a very moving must see. I would recommend everyone take the time to see this simple yet powerful memorial. I also recommend you do a little research to develop an understanding of the horrific story behind the "Shoes on the Danube" - A simple sculpture that is very moving.

A stunning visual memorial of a sad chapter.. Central Europe has many memorials to the holocaust, each one an artist's attempt to create a lasting vision of an almost indescribably horror. This one in Budapest is as memorable as any. It tells the story without words of an event in which Hungarian militia as Nazi henchmen took Jews from their homes, marched them to the banks of the Danube to be "relocated," had them remove their shoes, then shot them and dumped their bodies in the river. The artist has made a statement louder than any speech could. It should be seen as part of anyone's first visit to Budapest.
A moving memorial. We had to search for the installation next to the Danube near the Parliament Building but it was worth the effort. The concept is superb and deserves a must-see rating.

A Must See site that is poorly presented. This is a beautiful site, however it is poorly presented and you must look for it. The exhibition itself which is on the site of the massacre is haunting. I don't know why the Hungarians choose to hide this exhibition.
Thought provoking. Look out for these, they are on the side of the parliament building, walking from there towards the bridge. Very thought provoking and a reminder of the past, very sad.
An emotional memorial. The stark reality of human evil confronts the viewer as much as any memorial I have seen. Access is not easy, but every visitor to Budapest should make the effort.

Very thought provoking. We have walked by this each time we have been in Budapest and stopped for some time to contemplate what happened. The sculpture is so simple yet so very moving. For all those interested in Budapest's history or the war it is worth seeing.

Heartbreaking display of life lost. It is not easy to find this touching display of the sad history of Budapest. We found no direction signs, nor is there a clear explanation of what happend to the shoes owners or to those who placed them there. Yet, the shoes are there and so is the history of the Jews of Budapest who were murdered in groups and drowned in the oh-so-peaceful river. It is a sad place for humanity and is well worth a special trip, a stop and a moment of silence.

Very moving. Lest we forget this is a reminder that we must never let this happen again. Truly unique and it touches ones emotions in a way other memorials do not. Every visitor should try and spend a few moments here .

Perspective. Please make sure you read what happened here. It is right in front of the parliament building along the Danube. It is a different way to appreciate WWII history. Reflect on the reality while you are there.

Worth the walk. Several years ago we visited Budapest and I didn't find out about this Holocaust tribute until after we got back. I was determined to see it on our recent visit. It is very moving because it is on such a human scale. The shoes are placed so you can imagine people stepping out of them and then falling/jumping into the Danube. The shoes range from workbooks to dress shoes to tiny children's shoes. Some people have taken to placing tiny stones into the shoes in tribute. There is a simple plaque (in several languages) that explains the memorial, although while we were visiting some people seemed to be completely unaware what they were viewing and were taking tourist shots posing next to the shoes. Hungary is still coming to terms with the war and the fate of the Jews. Across town, there is a proposed memorial about the fall of Budapest to Hitler that has attracted quite a bit of controversy, as some feel that Hungarians were quite complicit with the Nazis. There are many homemade tributes, photos, shoes, eyeglasses, and protest letters that have sprung up there to remind people about the fate of their loved ones who were killed/transported to camps. As the generation that was alive and remembers slowly dies out, you feel the sense of urgency that they have to make sure that the history is remembered accurately.

A Very Somber Moment. The shoes and placement speak for themselves. Please make sure you take a moment to see them. Budapest has experienced some serious hardship and these shoes paint a perfect picture representing those times.

Sad Reminder of the Past. If you walk along the river on the Pest side, you can't help but see the many pairs of bronze shoes scattered along the bulkhead. There is a small plaque describing the reason for the shoes being there. Take a moment to reflect on the unfortunate men, women, and children who were pushed into the Danube.

Sobering. I am not sure that "attraction" is the correct description for this very special place in Budapest.Some have made note of the fact there is very little information located at the site and as such they provided lower ratings. Personally I think this is one of the more sobering and touching memorials to the history of the Jewish population in Eastern Europe that I have seen. The beauty of the memorial is its simplicity and when you stand there, looking over the beauty of the Danube and the city beyond, and see those shoes, it makes you stop and quietly think about what those people endured and what ultimately happened to them. Hopefully the memorial serves as never ending call to not forget what happened here.
Very poignant. Brilliantly done and very moving. Not far from the parliament so if you are there just cross the (busy) road. As you look at Parliament from the Buda side it is to the right.

Very moving and makes you think. The memorial is very touching, the problem is the vage explanation of what this is actually... The written sign beside the memorial, is very short and talks in General, without explaining that this is for the 150,000 jews that were murdered by the nazies armi

Wow. As other reviewers have pointed out, it could use some interpretation and better access, a good cleaning, and perhaps a way to route the bike path around the reflection area. Nevertheless, its important to pause here, consider the universality of the poignant shoes, and consider how we treat those around us.

A poignant memorial. An extremely touching and original memorial to the Jewish victims of the Arrows Men militia during the Second World War, who were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It can be found on the Pest side of the Danube just past the Parliament building.

A touching tribute. After visiting the Parliament building, walk back towards the Chain Bridge and see the Shoes on the Danube installation. These are shoes that have been dipped in metal as a memorial to all those killed and thrown into the Danube. The tiny children's shoes often have bunches of flowers amongst them. It would be nice to have some history printed in several languages to give people some idea of what happened here. A lot of tourists looked mystified.
A sad reminder of the war. The shoes are a reminder of how Hungarian Jews where treated. Lined up and shoot then watching their bodies fall into the Danube
Simple, but strong. This simple sculpture brings a powerful story and message of man's inhumanity to man. One of the best pieces on the Holocaust in all of Europe. A must see when in Budapest.

Very moving installation. The Shoes on the Danube is a very moving installation that commemorates those lost to the horrors of the Arrow Cross henchmen. Be sure to look up information about the site before going as the information presented at the piece is very limited.
Impressive. This is a very touchable place. It´s hard to combine a place with such nice views to the cruel killings, which happened there.

Over rated installation Art, but since it's on the Danube.... A very poorly prepared and installed art memorial , that could have been a major attraction point in Budapest, it's just a thing to do if you feel like taking a walk on the Danube anyway.
Nothing to see. There's nothing there but some metal shoes. Yes, the history is dramatic, but as a touristic attraction, there's nothing to see.
Not to be missed. The shoes on the Danube is a very powerful exhibit/memorial not to be missed. There are a lot of other things in that area to see.

Sad, but so important to remember. These shoes tell the story of many people who were simply shot dead on the banks of the river and disposed of after leaving there shoes. Today these brass monuments serve as a reminder of the atrocities that must never occur again and should not have occurred then.

Little known piece of Budapest history. This is a memorial to those Hungarian Jews (men, women and children) who were taken by force from the Budapest ghetto by armed Arrow Cross (Hungarian Nazi collaborationist militia) to the bank of the Danube, forced to take off all their clothes and shoes and executed. The bodies fell into the Danube. The memorial consists of iron cast shoes placed along the river edge. What is dissapointing is that this memorial, as well as others in Budapest, do not mention that the victims were Jewish. The usual term used, is the all inclusive term "victims".
Chilling. Not easy to find and no explanations on hand but serves as a chilly reminder to the city's past. The shoes can be found on the embankment a few hundred meters from the parliament building

Very moving to consider what the shoes represent!. Moving tribute to those Jewish Hungarians shot and killed right here on the banks of the Danube during the Nazi reign. Quite a sobering memorial. Can be accessed from the steps near the Charles Bridge.

Pretty Interesting. These shoes look very much real unlike their bronze statues status. These shoes represent the jews who were shot and dropped into Danube river the fascist phase of the country. It will come across as you proceed to the parliament and about at the chain bridge entrance. The place actually holds a very powerful sentiment. You could incorporate it into your parliament visit

A simple memorial with a huge impact. We had read about this memorial before we went to Budapest and we had it on our "must do" list. There were initially 60 pair of iron shoes from the the 40s. There were children's shoes to workman's boots, to a woman's worn heels to one sling back shoe. According to the story, the political party Arrow Cross came into power in 1944. This group made nightly raids grabbing Jews and political adversaries. 10,000 to 15,000 victims were marched to the rivers edge, forced to remove their shoes because the shoes were valuable, then shot and pushed or tumbled into the river. This memorial is so touching because the shoes were more valuable to the Arrow Cross party then human life. It makes one think both at the memorial site and later on in quiet moments.
It stays with you. This is a simple yet powerful memorial. It really makes an impact and does so in a unique way. The shoes really humanize the victims, especially the small ones.

Strange but worth to visit. It san memorial. Unfortunately too many people take it as another visit site, and take selfies with it. Its little bit of the paths so if you are really interested than go but if you are tourist who looks for good fun than miss out on it, it will be best for you and the place

Moving Memorial!. Stark and full of impact, the Shoes on the Danube Promenade is a memorial honoring the Jewish victims of the fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest. The shoe sculptures themselves represent those left by the Jews when falling into the river, having been shot during World War II.I crossed this moving memorial both day and nigh and saw fresh flowers and candles from love ones laying nearby. Takes only a few minutes. You can cross safely in front of the Gresham Palace. Note: If you are too young to truly appreciate the freedom you currently have, please have the decency to NOT place your bare feet into the shoes for your photo op! It is very disrespectful to what actually happened here.
A must see. A reminder of a different world. Every one should visit this part of Budapest and remember. Within easy walk of the chain bridge.

So moving!. What a moving monument to the Jewish victims shot and dumped in the Danube in the 1940s. To see it, go to Chain Bridge entrance on the Parliament Building side of the Danube and head toward Margaret Bridge along the waterfront. You will pass it near the Parliament Building.

See and weep. I would not miss this site. 10 minute walk, at a brisk pace, from the Sofitel Hotel. So sad to see all the shoes that will never be filled again. If you are looking for a great big monument, this is not it. But I felt it was a very holy place. Leave a stone to let someone know you have visited. The shoes are styled from the era and are left in place as if someone were shot there. That is what happened in the area.

A Reminder. I agree with other reviewers, a very powerful reminder. I really enjoyed seeing the shoes...they look so real i thought they were made of leather not metal. It is not one to go miles out the way for but well worth seeing when passing to see Parliment. We walked down here twice by day and I wish I could have seen it lit up at night...would love to go back and see that. Please let me know if this is useful information and I will write some more.

A wonderful stroll. We really enjoyed our stroll along the Danube. The shoes monument is extremely moving, but it also combines with the overall feeling of Budapest and it's buildings along the Danube, the view across the river to the Buda side, and the outdoor cafes. All this makes one feel the richness of the history of this city.

Moving memorial. This is a very moving and powerful memorial and definitely not one to be missed. As others have said, it’s a very small and subtle memorial but well worth a visit. If you walk south along the Danube from Parliament, you can’t miss it. Very touching and impactful.
Good to see. Good to see for the sake of seeing. Wouldn't give it more than ten minutes as you stroll past down the edge of the Danube.
Sad but a must. Suck a sad story and place to visit but when the sun is out it is nice to sit and think. Lots of,people visit this area I just wish someone would take away the dead flowers!

Sunset stroll. One of the best experiences in Budapest was taking a stroll during sunset from Parliament to the Chain Bridge. It is amazing feeling to witness lighting up of the city: Parliament Building, bridges, Castle Hill on the other side... And the iron shoes on the banks of Danube gave a special weight to this experience too. Just amazing. I highly recommend you take this special stroll at the sunset!

A very poignant memorial. Along the side of the river Danube there is a line of well worn very old shoes. They have been cast in bronze. It is a memorial to the people who were shot by the militants and pushed into the Danube. 1944-45

Moving. Just a small memorial, but still powerful. I sought out this memorial on my trip and made it a point to not leave until I saw it. I enjoyed that family members still made a point to come to the memorial to pay their respects, including placing flowers.

Moving memorial. Along the path from the Chain Bridge to the Parliament Building you will come across a small memorial to the Jews that were shot near the Danube. Look for pairs of bronze shoes and prepare to be moved by their poignant beauty.

Poignant Reminder. Situated on the anks of The Danube nnear the Hungarian Parliament his monument to Jewish people who were sent to their deaths in the cold waters of The Danube in WW2 simply tells the story of their plight.

Interesting history, not much to see.. Bronze shoes of the jews who were shot by the arrow cross puppet government of the Nazis. I wouldn't go out of my way to see it. There isn't much here, but if you're walking by parliament its real close.

A somber reminder. I saw this memorial as i was getting from the Chain bridge to the parliament. I did not know their story so i searched it on the internet. Very sad and vivid remainder of what took place at that era. A must see!!!!

Never forget. This exquisite, simple site resonates in our memories of the horrors of hatred and evil. It is a magnificent tribute to the Jews executed by the Arrow Cross militia and within its stark simplicity shouts, "Never Again". This should be a mandatory visit for all who travel to Budapest.

A somber & chilling reminder. A simple, but magnificent tribute to the Jews executed by the Fascist Arrow Cross militia. Look for the signs with the text To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube . 1944/1945.
Moving. Seeing these shoes a few minutes walk from our river cruise dock was quite something ... a reality check of the brutal history of the Nazis.
Shocking and stark reminder.... We came upon this memorial quite by accident. It is a stark and beautiful reminder of what happens when mankind is not so kind to his fellow man.

sad memorial. This was a memorial to some Jews who were shot on the banks of the Danube but made to remove their shoes first as they had some value. The models of the shoes are very poignant and make you feel very sad about the atrocities carried out during the Nazi occupation.

Unexpectedly powerful. Thought a trip by this would be worth noting but didn't expect to feel so profoundly moved. The monument is new (2000's) but care was made to find all period-accurate/vintage shoes from the War Era to symbolize the Jews that were shot on site and left to fall into the river. The baby shoes will really put a lump in your throat. It reminds you that where your standing is significant. If you're walking near the Parliament please take the 3 minutes to walk by and give thought.

Very simple pogniant memorial. You just come along this little memorial as you walk along the Pest bank of the Danube either just before or after, depending on which direction you are walking, the very impressive Houses of Parliament. There are 3 plaques, 1 in English, 1 in Hungarian and the other in Hebrew to explain and, again these are very simple and factual. The simplicity of the whole thing really leaves the rest to your imagination, which I found very powerful.

Makes you stop and think. This memorial is very close to the Parliament building on the bank of the Danube.A collection of shoes along the quayside, at the spot where fascists executed Jews and dumped the bodies in the river. Simple and moving
Very sad. I visit there after visiting parliament accidentally and it was so sad and remind people that dark part of history that people suffer a lot.
Very sad. The shoes have been preserved really well and it is nice to go see them. Would be nice to have a plaque explaining about them though.

loved the thought of this - very poignant. You can't help but feel moved when you visit the shoes, just past the parliament buildings. They are beautiful and v cleverly done... reminding us all of the wars and people lost!

Simple but touching. This is a memorial to the Jews who lost their lives being shot and their bodies thrown in the Danube. The shoes are of all different sizes, men, women and children. Very simple and powerful. I was greatly moved. This memorial does not appear on the Hop On/Hop Off bus maps but really should be visited.

New access for the Shoes on the Danube Memorial. This is one of the most moving memorials to the Jews who lost their lives during the Second World War. Recently, the government has made some very good improvements to the area so that it is more easily accessible, has a wide promenade, and easier to see. It is well worth a visit when you are in Budapest. It's just in front of the Parliament building on the Danube. If you visit the House of Terror Museum, the museum which documents the history of Hungary from WWII and beyond, you will understand why this Shoes on the Danube memorial is so important.

Reflective ................ Not too well signposted... but persevere !Just a short stroll down from the Parliament Building along the water front you will see the " shoes ".... right at the waters edge, poignant, powerful, evocative ...... they tell their story !!! This is truly a powerful visual concept that will stay with you forever ... take the time to visit !
Touchingly Sad. We learned of this monument when we toured the Synagogue. This is such a touching tribute to the many Jews who lost their lives in such a violent and inhumane manner

Simple, Yet Powerful.. This simple, yet powerful memorial is on the Pest side of the Danube. The various shapes, sizes, and styles expressed the everyday lives that ceased to exist with a prejudice belief and a pull of the trigger. It was something I had to see, and I was not disappointed.
Moving. A moving "sculpture" reminding how innocent people were killed and thrown into the Danube.We knew that it was there but had to ask exactly where...
Takes a bit of finding. No signs to this, but it is on the banks of the Danude just down river from parliament. Thought provoking and poignant
Simple, eloquent, moving. It's just that: simple, eloquent, and moving. If you are near the Parliament building, make sure you see it.

Great...Once We Found It. We knew it was near the Parliment buildings, however we weren't sure which side. We ended up walking down the wrong side..ugh! The Shoes are located between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament on the Pest side. If you walk from the Chain Bridge, the Shoes are located about 5 - 10 minutes, right before you reach the Parliament. Having found it, the Shoes were sad and thought provoking. The saddest part way seeing women's shoes next to a pair of small child's shoes. There were other children's shoes there, they appeared to be about 10 - 12 years old. It was definitely worth the effort to find this and pay my respect to the innocent people who lost their lives through no fault of their own. There is also a place to sit behind the shoes and take in the Buda side stunning views.
memories not to be forgotten. I couldn't help thinking about the suffering and fear of all those who were about to be killed. Won't we ever learn?

Sad.... This monument means a lot... during the holocaust jews were taken to the border of the Danube where they were stripped off all their clothes shoes and belongings and then they were shot and thrown at the river.

Heartbreaking. We saw this memorial from the river. It looked so forlorn and poignant. We talked about it for a long while afterwards. It really brought home the viciousness of the Nazi's and the horror of the Holocaust. It makes you realize what can happen in our time, and thankful that we did not have to live through it.
Beautiful..... And very thought provoking. Definitely worth a look while you're in Budapest. Easy to find near the Parliament building.
Poingnant Memorial. Although my knowledge of the history of this memorial is limited, it was poignant in it's simplicity. Worth a visit, and on a nice day a nice walk along the river to find it.

Sad.... This memorial won't make you indifferent,unless you are heartless person.It's very sad,and good reminder of how evil are humans.Artist send us very strong message here.You should see it,especially 'cause you'll probably visit the Parliament and memorial is close to it...

couldnt find them!. i seriously felt like i had walked for miles to find these and for some reason i could not locate them anywhere which was disappointing! the only problem with Budapest is that they don't signpost anything! i must of stopped short off were they where or just didnt open my eyes properly

Pay repect. Read a little about this place before you go, so you get an understanding of what went on here. As you wander along the riverbank, stop at the shoes and give some thought to the folk that lost their lives here. Some people lay a flower or two, others take pics - but everyone quietly pay's respect.
How sad. I read about this in travel book but was not expecting it to be so sad. a visit to the history of Hungary. Dare I say I enjoyed seeing this tribute.
Moving. We stumbled across this memorial on an evening walk. The presence of those shoes - men, women and children - is particularly haunting and meaningful.

Very moving. It doesn't feel quite right to review this as good, bad or indifferent. It is a very moving memorial on the promenade of the Danube to all the Jews in World War 2 who were made to take there shoes off at the edge of the river before being shot. A very apt memorial is all I can say and very touching.
A must see. If in Budapest do visit this holocaust memorial. It is a very moving and thought provoking experience.

A moving sight. Just wish that there was some form of information board giving details of the history. On my first visit came across the shoes by chance and had to ask at the hotel for some background information. Many other tourists were in the same position.

Monument delivers a strong feeling. The holocaust slaughter happened in this spot is one of the most horrifying and the story behind it makes you shiver. I think standing and looking at the shoes is worth a lot more than a thousand words.

A Sobering Experience. If you walk along the east bank of the Danube from the centre of Budapest north towards the Parliament Building you will come across this permanent work of art, paying homage to the Jews executed during the holocaust.This is well worth the visit as it brings home the harsh reality of Europe's past . Whilst not intended to be part of a couples' getaway I strongly recommend that you visit this site.

Compelling memorial. This memorial is poignant and moving, especially so because of its minimalism. It easily and jarringly led my thoughts and emotions to the Holocaust; to those who experienced and suffered during this period. How it was caused, its lack of humanity, what we can do to prevent such events now and in the future; a must see.

A gripping reminder of the personal impact.... If you're any where near the Danube in BudaPest, make sure you take the time to experience this display. There is something so moving about seeing something as ordinary as the shoes we wear bronzed and lined up along the banks of the Danube and remembering that there were human beings who's lives were regarded as so meaningless that they were shot and dumped in the river.
Touching - a must see!. Take the time to see this monument - you will be moved. Right on the river front, just cross the road outside parliament building.

A must see. This is a stunning area to visit and to reflect on all that has happened in this city. The shoes are so poignant, they convey so much with their worn heels, placement, size and shape. The poor poor people. It's definitely one of the most moving memorials I have visited.

Very moving. I was very interested in visiting this site. It was a very different monument then the ones I have been to regarding the Holocaust. There are sixty pairs of shoes in reference to the 60th anniversary of the Holocaust in Hungary (according to our tour guide). We were there at night (so my pictures are not so clear) and it was just days after the Holocaust Remembrance Day; there were still flowers on the shoes. Also, if you are visiting on May 1st (as we did) there will be fences on the rive due to the events in the city.

Wish they would have posted more. Amazing tribute to such a difficult time. The still setting next to the Danube allows you to reflect on the atrocities that happened during World War 2. My only wish was that the city put more information on the time period, or offer some explanation as to who the people were etc.
Important place to see. A very moving monument of the Jews holocaust ...Very important for anyone who would to stop racists and hate around the world...

Rememberance. This somewhat non-descript testament to the Holocaust, when you step back and take in the entire view of the sculpture, you then realize the powerful message of the horror of it all. A vibrant people, women, men, children, families, mothers, fathers, brothers, sisters, all lost, as if thrown over the abyss of being sent to the concentration camps, never to return. And FOR WHAT!?

Striking simplicity. The simplicity of this memorial spoke for itself. It gives such a strong and touching vision of what happened during the war, and really enables the visitor to imagine what the atrocities at the Danube may have been like.
Must to see. A lesson to the humanity. About what happen and what we have to learn from this.Its not just a piece of "art". Is to remember a very horrible crime committed by the Hungarian Fascist.

Poignant and moving. This is not a spot you'd spend more than half hour at. Just sculptures of shoes representing those who had died. It is moving and hard not to stop and think.Since there is always a wait before entry to Parliament, this is one of the good spot to visit as you wait.

Simple but so moving. Heart wrenching and thought provoking! You can just imagine the Jews standing there waiting to be shot. Would like to take my children there - it's far better than any book could explain.
Very moving. Time for peace and quiet reflection, shoes are very personal so it was an exhibit that really awakened your emotions.

A must see. Despite knowing roughly were this was located we found it hard to find, with no signposts and a bit of a tricky crossing. Found it very moving, especially when we saw the shoes of the children. Unless some research has been done, this could be missed.

Great Promenade. We walked the promenade from Liberty Bridge up to parliament. The views of the Danube, the buildings, the bridges, etc. were excellent. The foot path was paved for the most part. Be aware that in places it is loose sand and dirt; if there is a significant wind and you are wearing contacts, you will need to protect your eyes. The highlight of the walk was the shoes on the Danube. We understood that it was a memorial to Jews (and perhaps others) who were killed and thrown in the river during World War II. We were sad for those thoughts but were glad to be able to pay our respects to those who perished. As some other reviewers have noted, no signs are posted, explaining the significance of the shoes. I think that signs, information, etc. would actually have been distracting; better to let the place and the shoes speak for themselves. In any event, we knew what to expect from having read some reviews of things to see before we left for Budapest. So do not miss the promenade and, especially, the shoes.
Heart warming. This is a must see, makes you think back of what happened, Truly makes you take a long look of your life and how easy it can be changed.

Very Historic and meaningful. This is a real stand out to me to see Hungary pay homage to the Jewish history. The shoes are located right on the Danube and seem to be made from brass. The only negative is that there not not much information in English or at all or that matter.

Sobering and simple. There is an elegance in minimalism and leaving just the shoes of those Jews who were gunned down on the edge of the river because they couldn't ship people out to death camps fast enough is as moving an example as you are likely to encounter.It is a bit tricky to access but if you are walking south along the side of the river from the parliament building you will encounter it without difficulty.

Must not miss if you go to Budapest.. Its a strange feeling coming home from a great weekend away and feeling like this was one of my favourite things I did. Its simple and exactly what you would expect it to be, honest, understated and thought provoking.

Impressive. You can't say it is beautiful but it is a symbol in the memory of killed hebrews in the WW2.The shoes look like real shoes made from lether but they are statues decorated with flowers, stones and candles by people who pass by.
Thought provoking. This takes only a few minutes to see and yet stays in the mind for so much longer - definitely not to be missed on any trip to Budapest.

So moving and appropriate. As I am reading "The Book Thief" at present and hearing the dreadful stories of pathetic overpaid footballers being so stupidly racist, this very moving set of sculptures serves to remind us of the cruelty and inhumanity which prevailed and sadly still remains with us.Let us never forget! Let us respect ALL humankind!
Excellent ?. I struggled to say whether this is terrible or excellent, it is certainly thought provoking.Very simple sculptures but extremely powerfulGlad I saw it.
Horrifying!. Thrilling exhibit, mute testimony presents a terrible and terrifying story; the story of Hungarian Jews that were tied to each other, shot and thrown into the river. Incomprehensible!

Heartbreaking!. The shoes from victims that were shot and fell into the river, cast in bronze. We had visited the House of Terror museum earlier in the day. So emotional to see childrens shoes, woman and men . A beautiful depiction why war should never happen!!
moving reminder. A very sad and poignant reminder of the past. I found it very moving to see how such a simple memorial really honours the victims of a tragic event in history
a moving experience. The shoes on the promenade represent the shoes left behind by the Jews who were pushed over the edge into the Danube. Very difficult not to get emotional here.
Sad View. About 60 pairs of cast iron boots and shoes, a tribute to the Jews who were rounded up, shot, and dumped in the Danube. Sad
Very moving tribute. Very moving tribute to the atrocities of the committed by Hungarians at the end of WW2 when their own home grown fascists executed Jews on the river bank.

Really Poignant. We were walking along the Danube and came across many pairs of shoes on the bank. It turned out that the shoes were metal and this was a piece of sculpture to memorialize a number of Jews who were shot and left to fall into the river. A poignant and stark reminder of their history.
So Sad. This Place makes me very sad, we must nerver forget the history behind this Place. And we must work together so it won´t happen again.

10 minutes walking from the Parliament. Can be easily reached from the south west corner of the Parliament.
Walk down to the Danube and then walk south along the river for about 100 meters.
No construction work going on now.

HOPEFULLY NEVER AGAIN. I missed seeing this on my first two trips to Budapest so I was determined to get there on this recent trip. The artist captures the horror of what took place all those years ago. Just look at the picture I'm attaching.

Takes One's Breath Away -- with a Tear. Walking along the shore of the Danube River in Budapest is a truly beautiful site -- but then we came upon the "Shoes on the Danube. "This artist rendition of a very sad time in European history stops a visitor in their tracks as one tries to comprehend the reality of what happened "during the war" and how many lives were lost in this area.Candles and flowers adorn the shoes (made of steel) as a memorial. Folks stroll the area in relative silence as they pause to reflect on the travesties of lost lives.

A piece of history on the Danube. A nice art work in the memory of the Jews that were murdered in the holocaust. It's really special and surprising to see it there.
It's on your way traveling budapest, so there's no reason that you miss it.
Go there. I just don't think that is a nice place to take happy pictures like tourists use to do. It is a very respectful place, where a lot of jews were killed

A must see that is hard to see.. Very moving. I personally know two people from Budapest who are Jewish, were sent to the camps and survived. Very hard to see this sculpture and to think of their reality.
surreal. i wanted to see these asid heard about them and it was so facinating but a bit surreal a little sad but really interesting

Short visit. I think it is worth a look. There are not so much to see. You can see some shoes from some of the people who died here. You can also hear about what there happend at this place.
I would say you should visit it
- Simon

Sad memorial to the victims of Hungarian fascism. Beautiful low-key way of remembering those thousands of Jews who were lined up and shot by the fascists in 1944 without feeling. Shame that some of the locals still try to deface it.

A calm area in a busy city. We went to see this small monument as it had been recommended to us. It was a very calm area with music playing where you could contemplate and remember. The candles and roses show that the people who were killed there are still remembered everyday.

Emotional. The shoes, boots, children's shoes are a reminder of what happened to some Jews, in Budapest, just before the end of the war. Read about this memorial, visit this memorial and be prepared to be very emotional. A number 2 tram will take you past the shoes so get off at the parliament building and head to the river.
Neat bit of history. I enjoyed seeing the shoes just as an art form and memorial. I enjoy history, so this was neat for me, plus the backdrop of the castle and chain bridge are pretty amazing.

Thought provoking.. This landmark is located to the right of the parliament building. It is yet another poignant reminder of the atrocities of war. It gives you a real sense of ordinary people being lined up on the banks of the river and then shot so that they fell into the water. Quite upsetting.

Worth a look. This is a small but poignant monument to those who were killed here. Thought provoking. Many candles and tributes are laid among the shoes and there is a plaque telling you what happened.
Very moving tribute. A beautiful tribute to those shot into the Danube, shame there was lots of broken glass around though.

Humbling. Viewed this sight with my daughter that has been abroad studying in Budapest. Upon here recommendation, I found this riverfront walk filed with others spending time contemplating the fate of the individuals who once stood.
Moving and beautiful. In a great spot within view of chain bridge right on the edge. A moving tribute to the victims, there seems to always be people around here, candles, notes and several tributes.
worth a look. bit of a eye opener of what went on in the history of hungary, quiet a poniant moment think of the fear felt by the people there at the time

Must visit!. This monument is so powerfull that it really helps you understand the horror of world war two murders.this monument is small but so huge in its impact that you really should take time to stroll by.almost in front of the parliament on the danube bank.
very powerful. If you know the history of Budapest and the Jewish people living there during world war 2, you will find this very powerful.
A surprise encounter with the ghosts of Hungary. We were not aware of this memorial. As we came to the water's edge it was a most poignant tribute to those who lost their lives.

A Historical Reminder. It is a sight not to be missed, a reminder of Man's inhumanity to Man. The monument will take just a couple of minutes to view, however, you may be compelled to spend a little more time looking at the shoes of the men, women and children that were left as they tumbled into the river. A very moving experience, just one of many in this city of history lessons as well as great beauty.
very moving. Another reminder how cruel war and hatred scar mankind. Stop and sit on the curb nearby and reflect on what these people must have gone thru.
You should see this.... It is a very moving, and thought provoking memorial to the awful atrocity that happened during the war. Nothing more to say.
So moving. Be sure and go see this! It is in memory of the many Jews that were lined up and shot in the head! They then fell in the Danube! A memorial was set up with their bronzed shoes!
Very moving. I came on this by accident but it is well worth visiting to remember many people killed not just on the banks of the Danube but right across Europe during the Second World War

Goosebumps!!. Before you visit that place have a look at the history behind it as only then you will be able to acknowledge it! Visit it during sunset when the lights from parliament, palace/bastion and the bridges are switched on and pay some respect to these victims!
Very sad must see.. Take a few minutes to walk here as it's a worthwhile sight to see. It's not far from the parliament building. A very sad story. Lest we forget...
Very touching. Visited on a cloudy winter day - Got goose bumps & my eyes swelled up.. Very appropriate, very touching. Can never forget
A moving tribute. The view across the Danube to Buda is lovely too. The Parliament is also close by and a must-see sight.
must see. If in Budapest you must stop and see if simply for the historical remembrance. Go to the Horror Museum first then here.
Touching. Pitty that it is not easyily reachable. The memorial is very thoughtful and touching, worth visiting.
shoes on the Danube. quite moving, very sad but a beautiful idea (memorial piece). not easy to find as road works going on but head towards parliament square from gellert hill

So Touching. This is one of the most impacting holocaust type memorials that we have seen. My whole family, ages 6-40 were impacted by it and understood the gravity that the memorial was displaying (as opposed to a wall memorial w names listed). The artistic work on it and details are gorgeous--hitting home so much even more so.

Moving and Memorable. We knew of the existence of this memorial and went looking for this area specifically. The story is sad and disturbing and highlights man's inhumanity to man. The shoes are so realistic that it makes this memorial all the more poignant. Previously we visited Dachau but we found this memorial more moving .... maybe because the shoes personalise the tragedy.

A thought provoking visit. This is a poignant reminder of the terrors of war. A fitting tribute to those who needlessly died. This memorial is on the banks of the Danube close to the Parliament building.
Interesting. I didnt know these were here, but my friend had seen them on googled site, very thought provoking, a place to site and contemplate.

Huge impression. Must attend. simple but genius monument...with few flowers, candles and sweets left amond shoes...you would hardly keep tears.
Place for contemplation.

Wish we'd known about this before.... Came across this quite by accident after a visit to the Parliament building and although I immediately looked in our guide book, could find no reference to it have only now learned the meaning behind this very moving memorial. Thanks T/advisor and reviewers.

Moving memorial. The Shoe Memorial on the Danube (Duna river) is a moving memorial dedicated to the Jews who were killed by the Arrow Cross military during 1944-1945. Thankfully, I did research before arriving in Budapest or I would not have known the significance of this memorial. There is a plaque but personally, I don't think it gives enough details to enlighten anyone. Hopefully, people will see and ask questions or do a little research... either way this memorial is brilliantly crafted.

Sobering Memorial. A memorial to the Jews who were shot on the banks of the Danube and for whom the river is their only grave. A creative and poignant reminder of the brutality of the Nazi era. Definitely worth a stop as one visits the nearby Hungarian Parliament.

thought provoking. I couldn't find these very well but eventually headed towards the parliament building on the very edge of the Danube and we came across them. We went at night too which made them look so dramatic. good to see and actually research about them. such sad story but lovely memorial.

A touching memorial, worth visiting. A really touching memorial, worth visiting and spending a moment reflecting. I personally felt it was a shame that some people who went to see the memorial did not seem to engage with the sad meaning underlying it; I found it a bit odd when some people were putting their feet in the shoes.

a special lesson of dark history. It seems surprizing when you go by the shore of Danube and suddenly see many shoes, many people don't understand the meaning of it, but if you read a bit of history, you learn a lesson. It is a very beautiful idea to commemorate the Jewish people who died in such tragic manner.
Pause for a moment of prayer. I found it to be a very moving experience which made me reflect on mans inhumanity in wartime. I would recommend every to take time to visit this memorial.

A must visit!. Very moving and horrifying place that must visited. So simple but so strong message. Human shoes of the Jews who have been shot by the Hungarian Arrow Cross Party in 1944-1945.
For shell we not forget the horror and the murder of the Hungarian Jewish people.

Unknown History. We are lay history buffs and found this site on T.A. We would have never known about it or the story behind it and glad we went by. As so many things in this part of history, this site makes one think of the inhumanity to man.

A touching memorial to the Danube. The Shoes of the Promenade, sculpted by Gyula Pauer, is a touching memorial dedicated to the Jewish people murdered by the Arrow Cross during WWII. It is located along the Danube Promenade not far from the Hungarian Parliament building. Here you can see 40 meter long stretch of the promenade with a 60 pairs period-era shoes made of iron and attached the promenade. The shoes present the victims who were marched to the river and asked to remove their shoes prior to being shot. Their bodies would then fall into the Danube to be carried away. In the end, the Shoes on the Promenade memorial is a sobering reminder of the atrocities committed during the war. It is well worth making time to see when visiting this part of the city and can be easily seen before or after seeing Parliament.

Moving, if you know what you are looking at. The shoes on the Danube Promenade are no doubt a very touching monument of the Holocaust. Since the neighbouring Kossuth Square was renovated, they also became easily accessible from Parliament, with a crossing and traffic lights. The only problem, and that is why I don't give it a five, is that there is hardly any explanation, and many people who come there, just think it is funny that somebody put a row of bronze shoes along the river front. So, to tell the story: Jew were brought to the Danube by the Hungarian Arrow Cross, had to take of their shoes, and then they were tied together in groups of three, the person in the middle was shot, and the others fell with him in the river to drown. At the end, only a collection of shoes remained.

Shoes on the Danube promanard. If your into your history of the Jews & the holocaust this is worth a visit a moment to take time to sit back & reflect back in time to 1944-45 & what these poor souls went though. Emotional thing to see" or simply to some " just shoes " so read the facts behind the art.
Reality check. Puts life into perspective when you see the stark reality represented in such a simple form. Makes you realise how lucky we are that we live in a more stable and free thinking world.

A Sobering Experience. The Shoes on the Danube, representing the Holocaust victims from Budapest, is a sobering encounter with history. Look closely at the shoes...they are real! It created a haunting impression of the forlorn outlook of those lost.
Very moving. Seen many memorials all over the world, but they have never moved me as much as this one.A very simple design but very dramatic.

Very emotional. We had been to Budapest before and never knew of this memorial. This time we found out about it and took a walk down the promenade to Shoes on the Danube. Very emotional as you see children's shoes, all kind of men's and women's shoes. Some people place flowers on the shoes.
Very poignant. Took this small pilgrimage under cloudy sky's with a chill wind blowing, can you imagine what those people felt ? Very moving, really appreciate the way it's done

Recommended. We made sure to see Shoes on the Danube during one of many long walks around Budapest. Once you know the story behind this memorial it's a powerful, emotional and very worthwhile site to visit.
