Lovely memorial. This is a simple yet lovely memorial to those who suffered. It is only a short walk from Parliament and it is worth taking 10 minutes out of your day to just sit and have a little think.

Surprisingly Poignant. Despite there not being much in the way of on-site info or signposting, we had done our research and knew we'd find the memorial on the Pest side of the Danube, near to Parliament.
One of those monuments that just makes you 'stop and think'.

Very Emotional. The shoes on the promenade were a very emotional sight to see - memories of the holocaust and imagining the tiny little feet that fitted into the shoes before they were shot and fell into the Danube.

Poignant Reminder. This is probably the most poignant reminder of what humans are capable of that I have seen - simply sets of shoes lined up on the bank of the Danube near the Parliament building, representing those who were shot into the river by the Hungarian Arrow Cross in 1944-45.
I found this memorial very fitting.

emotional and important. unlike huge impressive monuments - this one touches you in the deepest way. a good spot to sit by and let the feelings come up. cry over the Inconceivable cruelty, racism, and how poinless wars are.
so gentle yet so powerful.
SAD BUT SO VERY REAL. This was a very moving experience, to see all those shoes placed there from the time those people were shot and fell into the Danube, privileged to have been there.

Awkward to get to but worth a visit. Quite difficult to find. With lots of construction work it was awkward to get to. You have to access it from the chain bridge tram stop and walk along the river not by the parliament tram stop as suggested by many maps. Once there it is quite a moving experience particularly when you see the smaller children's shoes. Well worth a visit and reflecting what happened here.

Tough to Get to, But Worth the Walk. Right now there is a lot of construction on the promenade which means you have to cross the Tram-2 tracks down by Chain Bridge and walk up the promenade to see these but it's worth it. Hungary had a very bad last year vis-a-vis the Jews during World War II and since then there's still a lot of antisemitism so it's nice that this is here. Very understated and moving memorial.

Moving and well worth a visit. Located just before the Parliament building on the banks of the river, this memorial to the Holocaust is very moving and brings the reality of the loss of men, women and children, to mind. Well worth a visit while you are taking a stroll down the Danube.

Moving. These shoes are located on the riverbank near the Parliament buildings. There were building works ongoing when we visited and you had to go down to the riverbank a way down from where the shoes are - but worth the short (10 minute) stroll.
A silent moment to remember. If you are into WWII history or have a jewish heritage don't miss the site. A unique but sad memorial. Close tot eh Parliament so very easy to get to.

Worth a short stop to think about others for a moment, but you'll need to research the spot before you visit. There are some who won't want to be reminded of the horrors that Hungary suffered during World War 2, but this is a poignant and very effective reminder of what previous generations went through. I have no family connection with anyone from Budapest who suffered at the hands of the Nazis, but I was sorry that I didn't have something to leave at the spot at my own salute to the victims remembered here. To people who have posted negative reviews about the spot, have a word with yourselves.

Worth a visit whilst you're exploring the river. This was a very poignant reminder of the atrocities that took place in Budapest during the Second World War. As a history buff, it was definitely worth seeing.

You Owe a Visit to Those Who Died. A simple, haunting memorial to the Jews shot and thrown into the Danube. I usually write long reviews -- there is nothing more to say than it is important you visit, it is a five minute walk from Chain Bridge, you can spend one minute there, find the time.

Awkward to get to but worth the effort. This is a simple but very moving reminder of past wrongs. Due to the extensive building work being undertaken around parliament it is awkward to get to but really worth it.

Poignant. Even though I'd seen pictures of this monument on the web it still doesn't prepare you for how you feel when you see itThe shoes could so easily be yours or your friends or familiesI've read a lot about the holocaust and visited lots of monuments, this defiantly for myself was one of the most moving probably it's it's simplicity

Moving. We had been told in advance about this memorial, which was fortunate as it wasn't mentioned in our Guide book. It's simple, moving and meaningful. There are dedication plaques in the paving written in English, Hungarian and hebrew, but I agree with some other reviewers that more explanation would be helpful. If you intend visiting, look it up on Google in advance.

A very poignant memorial. I know that there are other reviews here which mention that it's a shame not to have a sign to show what the meaning is of these shoes, however, I think that it would detract from the meaning behind them if there were to be a large explanation next to them.Part of the meaningful part of this memorial is that you can just stumble upon it without warning and research to see what it is about.Based just opposite the parliament building, this is definitely worth a visit whilst in Budapest. It's great to read the story of how these shoes came to be there before you go to Budapest and to spend a quite time in memorandum for the number of Jews killed on the banks of the Danube.

Something different. Thankfully we had read about this display as otherwise you'd stumble across the shoes and not know what they were. There is not even a sign to indicate what they are there for, which is a shame. It's nice to have something a bit different to see, and that's why I've rated it four stars. But for anyone who hasn't read up, good luck!

Peaceful. Easily reached by walking directly from the chain bridge towards the parliament. It is a peaceful place to sit for some time and recollect about the past. I was told about the Jewish history on the free walking tour I did in the morning. One could ask more questions or read ina dvance to understand the importance of this place.

I think. It's a very important display and a remembrance of the jews who were murdered there. It's to bad no one thought of explaining the meaning of this dsplay nor even writing a memorial words near it.
Something different. Although only a quick stop while we were on our tour, nonetheless a great little memorial stretching into the distance along the shores of the river.
A memorial like no other. This was a very poignant memorial to all the Jews that died by shooting from the Arrow Cross party (worse than the Nazis)

Thought provoking. Like most things here, very badly signposted and we stumbled across it by accident. It is a lovely little memorial, very thought provoking. This really should have more information near it though
Very moving and interesting. Me and my friend walked down the river looking for the shoes on the danube memorial bridge. Was most definitely worth it, was very moving and interesting to see.

Beautiful and unique. Really liked this memorial in the form of a number of pairs of shoes to commemorate the Hungarian Jews along the Danube just in front of the parliament building. Not greatly publicized but definitely worth a visit - a lovely and unique memorial.

a moving memento worth seeing. These shoes on the northern shore of the Danube are a poignant reminder of Jewish people killed by the fascist Arrow Cross party installed by the Germans to rule Hungary at that time.
poignant. Hard to get to from kossuth lajos ter metro. Need to get right by them for best experience/perspective. Thought provoking. Very sad.
Very moving display. Every tourist should visit here to reflect on the horrific ordeal that people went through in WWII. Very sad, but worth a visit. A poignant display.

Take time to pause and think about the horror man can bring on man. This simple display of bronze shoes - male, female, child - looks interesting, and it is. But when you realise that these stylised items have a story of murder behind them, it is actually quite distressing.It is a poignant reminder that evil things happen in war. There are two ground mounted plaques - in Hungarian and Hebrew - but nothing else to inform you of what happened.
touching. We walked along the Danube, it is on the seashore close to the Parliament. A remainder of human cruelty and a sign of human artistic sensibility

Painful memories. This place makes you sad. I was on my Honeymoon trip last month with my wife and that’s the reason I did not quite want to visit this place. However my wife is a history lover and wanted to visit the Shoes on the Danube Promenade badly. The several bronze replicas of Shoes lying all around the banks of the river Danube oozes out painful history of how the Jews were shot and drowned in the river by the Nazis. My wife kept staring at the shoes, probably recollecting the fragments of history she had read in History. The place is located just south of the parliament. The cab driver who drove us to the spot was with us all along and narrated some of the myths associated with the place.
Fabulous. Our tour bus drove by the shoes and we decided we wanted a closer look. We walk back later in the day and we were happy that we did. This is a wonderful memorial with great meaning.
Very thought provoking. It helps us to remember what has happened and ensure we all do what we can to make sure it does not happen again!

Very moving and sad place to visit. Me and my sister were looking for this site for more than 30 minutes but it was so important to us to visit the place and pay our respect to the people we were killed there during WW2 that we were willing to walk in circles until we found the place and it was worth the long walk and being there in bad weather.lSeeing the shoes brought tears to my eyes and made me sad to think about what happened there during the war.It is very important that people will keep visiting the site and remember the horrible things that happened during WW2.

beautiful and haunting. This is a brutal and essential reminder of the horrors of war that fell upon the city and pays respect the thousands of Jewish people who lost their lives in unimaginable circumstances. It's a stunning and thought provoking monument that everybody should take time out see and consider.

Very moving. We managed to find this by climbing down a makeshift ladder from the main road due to ongoing construction works in the area.Once there, it was a very moving sight to see the exquisitely crafted shoes reflecting the sad events at the end of the Second World War. It should be an essential stop on your trip, to be able to reflect on the atrocities of war and oppression.

Very sad. Only a short walk from the parliament building, the bronze shoes that symbolise the loss of life during the holocaust are set out. This is very upsetting to see but a definite must when in Budapest.

Very moving. Very moving monument of old, much used shoes in bronze, at the place where jews were shot into the Danube during the Holocaust.
It is on a prominent part of the shore, near Lanchid or in English Chain Bridge. Dont miss it if you visit Budapest.

A very moving memorial on the banks of the Danube. This simple and thought provoking memorial is not to be missed. It is sad to see the shoes from all ages and realise the fate of those who stood on the river bank so many years ago. It is a short walk from the Parliament and we all should take the time to visit and giving thought to those who lost their lives here.

One of the most poignant monuments anywhere; don't miss seeing it.. A painfully sad reminder of man's inhumanity to man, this understated monument commemorates the victims of the White Star and Nazi thugs who lined up civilians on the riverbank before shooting and drowning them in the Danube.A row of bronze shoes on the quay wall speaks more about this awful period than any great statues or large-scale monuments. This image will stay with you forever.

very moving. This small memorial wasn't far out of our way but even if it was it still would have been worth it. The amount of Jews taken from Hungary in the Holocaust is astounding, and these pathetic little shoes really remind you that while it is a big number, they were all individuals. This puts a heartbreaking personal touch on a black period of history. Just walk along the river on the Pest side, away from Chain Bridge towards Parliament. They are right on the water pretty much in front of Parliament. Many of the guide books don't cover that.

Touching. Its not marked on the maps but can be easily found on the river bank just before you get to Parliament building ( walking from Chain bridge towards to Margareta inland).Very touching if you know the history...

Very moving. Definitely worth a visit, this memorial was simple and very moving, very sad. Just south of parliament on the river, it is easy to find but not signposted, and worth a few minutes of your visit.

Just stop and think and remember.... Very moving if you know the history. Well worth getting to, if not so easy, but cross to the river at the Chain Bridge and then walk up as acess from Parliament is impossible. Amazing that all this was so recent.
Touching. Touching - a big reminder of human nature and where it can goes... My wife and myself really liked it, as much as you can "like" such a sad thing.

Shoes Along the Danube. Touching sight and the little shoes broke my heart. Such a sad time in History; however, it is important to know the story behind the monument as there were some young folks walking along the wall that stopped to view the shoes and laughed at how funny this was and cute the shoes were. This represent nothing funny, but instead a very solemn representation of History. Make sure you know what the monuments represent prior to viewing if for no other reason than to show the proper respect.

Really makes you think. While it is not a major attraction we wanted to see the shoes. As other have said they are doing building work so they are hard to get to. But it really does make you think standing on the bank of the Danube and looking at the shoes.

Incredibly moving. It's hard to find as they're doing lots of building work to the Parliament building, but it's one of the most moving memorials I've seen. The flowers left by passers by in the boots are heartbreaking too. A place to sit and remember before moving on.

sad, so sad, but necessary. lest we forget...
in Jan '14 the area was under re-construction, so we did not get very close, but certainly got the idea of the extent of the tragedy this sculpture represents.

moving tribute. its very hard to find, but look for this momument thats on the side of the Danube. Learn about them before you go as there is no real plaque to explain this is a memorial for all the innocent Jewish victims pushed into the Danube to die. Park across the street and you'll have to make a run for it but moving

Very beautiful. This was a nice spot to visit. We went at night time which was nice because its along the waterfront and the city was all lit up which added to the beauty I think. It is also quite moving. Definitely worth a visit!

A simple but poignant memorial. Is what it is. Sculpted metal shoes on the river bank that provide a very poignant reminder of the extent of the atrocities of WW2. Worth seeing if you're planning to walk a lot anyway - perhaps not worth going entirely out of your way for. Personally I found the experience quite touching.

Simple, stark, and sobering. A long display of cast replicas of shoes on the edge of the Danube wouldn't initially sound like a compelling display to visit, but when you know the history behind the exhibit, the incident it represents makes the simplicity of the exhibit sobering. Make sure to look up the history before you view it - there isn't much about the display at the site itself. We relied on the information in a walking tour guide book we brought along. Check out the article on Wikipedia which is helpful.

Must See in Budapest. There is so much to see in Budapest but if its history and human values you're interested in then the shoes exhibit is very important and moving experience. Located on the Danube promenade close to the Parliament building, it commemorates one of the darkest periods in Hungarian history and has moral value for today's generation.

Poignant. Thought provoking memorial for a shocking period in the history of Budapest and fitting to remember those lost souls whose last terrifying view on earth was of the Danube from this spot.I have seen many Holocaust Memorials in a lot of cities and the shoes remain etched in my mind as one of the most poignant.....a place for quiet reflection indeed...
Don't miss it. Very simple but strong and deeply touching sight. Hope the construction work at the Parliament house will be done soon, so it will be easier to reach it

Takes Your Breath Away!. When you look at the shoes lining the shore, it literally takes your breath away, when you consider what these people went through. It is a site that make one fully appreciate the freedoms we have in this country and we should all we can to protect those freedoms. It is a site that inspires quiet meditation.

Stunning and moving memorial. Brilliant idea for a memorial. Was very moving and well thought out, it really emphasised how people were mercilessly killed just for their race and is a memorial that just tugs at the heart strings.

Poignant reminder. I had found out about 'The Shoes on the Danube' a few months ago and when heading to Budapest on a river cruise I made sure it was something I visited. As the river boat I was on moored near the Chain Bridge on the same side as the shoes it was very easy for me to get to - about a 5 minutes walk along the waterfront. When I arrived there was just one other person by the shoes so I was able to get a good view of them. And knowing the story associated with this memorial made it a very poignant moment. In all I spent around 15 minutes by the shoes. It's a must see if in Budapest.

Heart breaking. It really hits you hard of the events that took place on the bank. I got really sad after visiting that place, but I support fully, all the people killed there deserve this kind of respect.

Shoes on the Danube. Very powerful tribute to the Jews who were killed here. Currently there is construction blocking the view as you walk along the Danube. However you can still get a good view from a river boat cruise.
stark, surprizisingly moving. Really brings home what happened. Standing there on a cold day looking at the empty shoes and the rapidly moving river.

A free tribute to the fleeing Jews on Pest that should not be missed.. This is well wortht he stroll along the Danube towards the Parliament building to see this moving tribute to the Jews who were trying to flee. You won't fail to be moved to see the tiny child's shoes bringing home just how desperate these poor people were.You really have no excuse - its FREE. We visited near sunset & it makes for some lovely photos.
Just nice. As said.. it is a very important memorial... but with no explanation on it whatsoever. If you happen to be in the area, sure. But I wouldn't go out of my way to see it

Powerful and under construction right now. We were not able to get up close or take photos due to the construction barriers but we could see the monument. Read up on the monument before you go. It is incredibly moving and simple. If you are on a Viking River Cruise and docked under the Chain Bridge, simply turn left when you get off the ship and walk abut 5 minutes down the river - you'll come right up on the monument along with lovely views of Buda.

Powerful memorial. This utterly simple memorial for the hungarian Jews who were killed - more specifically shot into the Danube - by the militia Arrow Cross during the II World War has a very powerful effect on its viewers. It is a sad reminder of the devastating effects of war and ignorance on the lives of normal people, and the message it gave me was as simple as the monument itself: we cannot let this terror happen again.
Simple. Simple but important part of Budapest. Makes you think. Sadly we went when there was a lot of work going on in the area which took a little of the magic away.

Simple but powerful. Read about the significance before you go to get the meaning behind this simple monument. Wirth the stroll along the Danube on a chilly day. In mid-December, construction was occurring at the site with a chain link fence abutting the shoe ledge. If you angle your camera just so, you should be able to snap a photo of the shoes and the Danube, missing the fence.

Makes you think. The simple monument of shoes makes you think of the horrors that the people of Budapest went through.I was not aware of this atrocity until I visited Budapest.For this act to be followed by years of repression under the communist regime you would think the population of Budapest would be miserable not on your life.friendly and inviting.we should all think a little before we complain about England!!
A MUST. do not miss the place as we all need to see and remember. we have been there taking a walk through the danube.

Shoes to Remember. One way of remembering the people who have passed away during the world war is offering prayers. A great way of doing this is creating something extraordinary from meaningful events like the film director that thought of materializing the Shoes on the Danube Promenade in Budapest. A lot of tourists like me had their pictures taken on the shoes displayed on the edge of the bank. The shoes were a symbol of the Jews who were brutally shot during the war by a mad man. It was touching that people offered flowers on the shows and some said silent prayers on the bank to bid farewell to those that have suffered. I did the same thing as I was deeply saddened by the facts about the beautiful artwork. My friend and companion during that trip was my tour guide as well and she let me in on the story behind the Shoes on the Danude Promenade.

"Thought provoking". This memorial can be found just a short walk from the last stop on the tram 2 line close to the Parliament Building. A very simple but moving tribute to the victims of the Holocaust.

Why my 5 stars review. The place is beautiful, the reason of the shoes in there not. However, I admire BUDAPEST because they are not hiding their history, they have learned to live with it and showed it to the world so WE can LEARN. This is just a reminder of what we have done (HUMANS) to us, humanity. So it is worth to be there, see those shoes and remember that we need to spread more love in this world.

Very moving. I walked along the waters edge in the fog to see the shoes. Sadly the construction around parliament means you cannot get very close from the chain bridge side. Nonetheless the sight of all those shoes scattered on the ground was very sad. Everyone i passed was similarly moved.
Very strong and powerful. Sixty pairs of iron shoes on the bank of the Danube River exhibit seemingly small but very strong and powerful. We were very moved.
Moving. Deeply moving experience, and a reminder of the huge cruelty the people of Hungary have been subject to. Situated on the bank of the Danube just downstream of the parliament building.

SOLEMN MOMENTS ALONG THE DANUBE. This is not part of the walking route that the tourist maps will bring you to. Together with my 11 year son and wife, we walked from Chain Bridge along the concrete edge of the Danube for about 10 minutes to see the replicas of shoes of men, women and children at the edge of the river. These shoes somehow help us imagine how the victims - their only crime was being a Jew, were told to remove their shoes before being shot. It was a time of reflection of such senselessness and and respect for those who lose their lives in this horrific fashion. Sad to say, we still cannot stop atrocities of similar nature being pepetrated elsewhere in the world up to today.
worth a quiet visit. very emotional sight to see shoes of various ages - the fear these poor people must have had very poignant.
Striking memory. A vivid reminder of the not so pleasant past. A line up of shoes along the riverbank is a memorial to the Jews killed in World War 2

Thought provoking. Made you stop and think.Very near Parliament but due to works around the Parliament area you have to cross the tram line near the Chain Bridge to get safely to the promenade otherwise you would have to try and cross a very busy road - not recommended.

Heart-wrenchingly beautiful. I was so worried that I would not be able to see this place. I had come a long way so I decided to take a solo walk from the hotel through small streets on a quiet, chilly Sunday morning. Due to the construction work behind the Parliament, I had to take a long way around to get to the stairs going down to the banks of the Danube. It was a great way to see the city! And I wasn't alone because there were plenty of other tourists getting happily lost too!I took my time to see every pair of cast iron shoes along the river and think about how those people mist have felt knowing their inevitable fate.So heartbreaking. I'm glad I braved the cold morning to see this. If you are in Pest, try to go down by the river and visit. You will not be sorry.
Upsetting, but a must visit. The history to this 'attraction' is upsetting and tragic, but we felt we should pay our respects while in a Budapest.
Thought provoking. Simple idea which really conveyed the awful thing that happened. Certainly made me think of how it must have felt to stand there and wait to be shot. Has society really moved on??

I almost missed my flight just to see this.... ...but it was worth it. There was something so simple and moving about the Shoes, that you will almost feel the grief. There are no signs, no explanations - just a silent understanding of what the Shoes stand for.

A reminder of the desperate measures taken to survive by the Jews.. Stumbled across this memorial on the walk down the Danube ... Very moving and thought provoking . Well done to Hungary to show a reminder in a different way ... Worth a look !!
Make sure you go.. Very poignant and with a beautiful backdrop on the other side of the river. Unfortunately there's nothing on-site to explain why it's there.
Poignant. Must see this sad memorial to the Jews shot into the Danube - brings it all very close -shoes of all types, could be yours or mine!

Powerful monument. Excellent photography scene. Strong and haunting monument, yet so peaceful and beautiful in it's own way at the river Dunya. Amateur photographers should check this place out at sunrise or moonrise for some nice shots.

Thoughtful memorial. This is a very moving thoughtful memorial which is better visited after the Holocaust memorial or the Hospital in the Rock as it makes more sense then -if sense is the right word for such an awful thing
Memoriesd of the second worldwar. Those shoes are memories of the massacre in last days of the second world war, making you stand minutes of silence.

Very moving monument. A slightly haunting, yet fitting monument well worth the walk down the river Danube. My friend & I combined this with a tour of the Hungarian Parliament; which is only a short walk further along the river Danube. The only downside was the lack of English information advising as to what the monument was about. While there is a plaque on site, the information is limited. Thankfully, I'd read about it prior to visiting - thank goodness for TripAdvisor!

Heart breaking. This is an exceptionally powerful memorial to the Holocaust in Budeapest, which occurred 70 years ago and which some Hungarians would like to forget. It is challenging to get to and from this site, but there are road renovations that may make it easier.
Shoes on the Danube. This monument was very moving! I think it's a must see while in Budapest. It's located within an easy walk from the many of the River Cruise Piers.

Very moving. It's worth a visit despite it took us a while to find a way to get down to the promenade where the shoes are. It's so sad to see despite of age (in this case I refer to children's shoes) men can so prejudice against someone because of who they are. I thank the artist who brought this memorial so we will always remember.
A reminder of the darker side of humanity. The location is not advertised but other than the shoes its a time of reflection on how long you stay
Emotional impact. I stumbled upon the shoes and was not prepared for the emotions I felt. I have give an excellent rating, but nothing excellent of this appalling act which took place in the war.
Moving.. What a brilliant memorial. So telling and moving, and sums it all up so well. If only all the tourists paid it a bit more respect.
Lovely area for a stroll. Easy to find your way around despite language difference. Great views, restaurants, shops, parks, and architecture.

Sad tribute. Shoes on the Danube I heard of through tripadvisor so thank you fellow travellers as it was very moving. Overlooking the beauty of Budapest from the ‘pest’ side of the river not far from parliament house, you sit near the shoes which an artist has made to commemorate the Jews [& other targets, apparently] who were shot & then pushed unceremoniously into the river. I cannot imagine the fear or how horrifying this would be, & looking at children’s shoes or worn couple’s shoes sitting together at the river’s edge was particularly poignant. Sadly many people down there did not seem to know what it was as I saw some teen girls laughing & trying to step into the shoes, or other people looking a bit puzzled [there is a plaque on the ground but it is small & only on one side]. Overall very moving & if possible nice to have some reflective time there & think of the victims, which is obviously the whole point.

a silent moving reminder. This memorial to the Jews who were brutally murdered during the Nazi occupation of Budapest during WWII is a stark and silent reminder of the horror. Unfortunately the only plaque is in Hungarian so foreign visitors who don't know what they are seeing do not know the historic event and its significance.

Man's inhumanity to man. We first saw these bronze replicas of shoes on the quayside at dusk after a wonderful afternoon guided trip around the Jewish quarter. The sight is just along the quay from the wonderful Parliament building.The sculptures have been placed there to commemorate a group of citizens who were marched there, ordered to remove their shoes before being shot so they fell into the Danube in winter towards the end of WW2. The shoes belong to men, women and children. The sight is heartrending to anyone with a conscience.

Shoes on th eDanube Promenade. This can be a very moving experience if you have the full story. Suggest you visit with a guide so you can understand the full impact. Visit is not included in all tours. A group of Arrow Cross Hungarian guards broke into the Swedish Embassy one night, near the end of WWII, pulled the men and women down to the river. They were ordered to remove their shoes and shot into the water. These were people who were hiding under the protection of Raoul Wallenberg, the Swedish Ambassador. The monument was erected in 2005.

Very moving. This was sad and moving monument. I was very glad I walked down to the promenade to find this. It is a sad part of history but one that needs to be shown so the next generation can learn and remember what happened..As soon as I found these shoes, I was touched. The shoes were left in 'situ' and I'm glad I took the time to find them.

the silance ,the Herror. a strong expression of the artist.an important gesture of the Hungarians to the nearly 600000 Jews that were deported within a record time of a few month to death. The location that is very exact if I may use this expression ( the shoes represent the people that were shot dead, as they were forced to stand at the side of the river in world war 2) Nevertheless, it remains unclear to me , why did the authorities that allowed the location of the statue in this location few meters from the fence surrounding the Hungarian Parliament , didn’t arrange a legal safe way to reach the place- there is no way you can park a car or a bus and walk to see the statue. We went to see it at night and again during the day and in both visits we had to risk our life to cross a high way and illustrate a way in and out of the site.

Wonderful. This is a very modest, silent memento. However, this is the one that you cannot forget once you have seen it and makes you think how could things happen which seem to be impossible looking back after moe than half of a century.

Touching monument but not well indicated. We only happened to stumble upon this monument. In order to understand what it meant we googled the meaning afterwards as it is not really described at the location. It is touching after learning the history but it not of grand nature.

Simple but moving tribute. Shoes on the Danube evoke a darker time in history. A pleasant walk along the Danube from the Chain Bridge toward Parliament brings you to this simple but moving tribute. Roses and other tokens are often seen in or amongst the shoes.

A thrilling scene. I came from Israel,and watching the shoes promenade gave me a thrill. I was standing there for a while .could not stop the tears trying to see in mind the Jews that were murdered there. The Hollocost is very meaningful for me as many of my family members were killed in Europe.

Touching tribute. This memorial is a very touching tribute to the people who were killed here, makes you think about the individuals rather than a mass of people. I thought is was a bit disrespectful that a parent was letting her child try on all the shoes but they perhaps didn't know what it represented.

A very moving urban sculpture. During World War II many Jews were murdered on the bank of the Danube, their bodies tossed (or falling) into the river. Today a series of shoe sculptures mark the spot in a way that is moving and ultimately sad

Hard to find but worth it. Come after visiting the House of Terror in Budapest and this memorial will take on a deeper meaning. All it is is some shoes lining the Danube, but standing where the shoes are, you can see and hear the rush of the Danube, and to a very minor extent feel what the Jewish victims must have felt at the time. The little boy's shoes was heart-breaking.This place is a bit hard to find. It's on the Pest side. Basically you have to walk along the Danube (you can get there from the Chain bridge or right across from the tram stop) and go all the way until you hit construction/Parliament.

a simple symbol of the missing. This is a simple, wonderfully moving monument by artists Can Togay and Gyula PaueIt to honour those Jews who were stripped of everything before being shot on the edge of the river by the fascist Arrow Cross militia, and their bodies left to disappear forever into history
Deeply moving.. This exhibit is right along the banks of the Danube.It is striking in its simplicity and tells a complete story of those poor victims of the attrocities of the Nazi movement.

Simple but moving. An easy walk to this spot and well worth spending a moment here to take this in during a quiet time. The shoes are a reminder of the Jews that were lined up here and shot to fall in the river. After visiting here it would be good to go to the Synagogue the next day.
So sad. Very moving memorial. Best approached from the Chain Bridge (otherwise access is across a very busy road). South of the parliament buildings.

Poigniant. Read about this memorial on Trip Advisor before going to Budapest, it is not well known, speaking to someone from Budapest on flight out who didn't know about it. There are lots of roadworks at the moment which can make it difficult to get too. Walking from the Chain Bridge towards the Margit Bridge you reach it just before the Parliament building. Looking at the shoes along the promenade with the river flowing by you can imagine how terrifying it must have been to be asked to take your shoes off and be tied to someonelse waiting to fall into the river. What a touching memorial.

Impressive memorial on the Danube boulevard. This monument of shoes of people who were later killed really made a big impression - would recommnd to visit Terror Ház (Andrássy út 60) first, that makes the impression even more complete

Moving. I saw this on Tripadvisor and glad I did as it is not advertised anywhere. Just a simple memorial to those who died during the war. Walk down on the river side (Pest side) and it is close to the Parliament which is on the opposite side of the road.
Reminder. What a reminder of the cruelty that was endured by the Jewish people by those oppressors, may we never forget how the Jews were so inhumanly treated by fellow so called human beings.

Nice!. It was a little bit hard to find the place because you can't see the shoes from a long distance, but when you find them you have an interesting image. Although a description on the meaning of thoese shoes doesn't exists there it's a must in Budapest.
Sad. A very emotional experience. knew it was in Budapest but came across it unexpectedly when out walking

emotional. This was a bit difficult to locate but when we finally got there I was moved to tears. 64 pair of bronzed shoes in tribute to the Jewish individuals shot and thrown into the river. The small child's shoes that people had filled with pebbles in remembrance was so heart wrenching. Well worth the search.

Very Moving Memorial. 64 pairs of iron shoes set to represent those shot and killed and thrown into the river by the Arrow Cross Fascists. The sad fact is that this was Hungarian's shooting other Hungarian's. It was a very moving memorial to a sad time in history.

Moving Holocaust Memorial. Small memorial of replicas of shoes of Jewish victims who were marched down to the Danube, shot, and then thrown in the water. Very horrifying and moving. One of the most heart-rending Holocaust memorials we saw on a trip to Prague, Budapest and Vienna.

Holocaust memorial on the Danube. Very moving memorial to the Jews that were executed there on the Danube .Shoes cast in copper ,all sizes ,from children's boots to elegant ladies shoes ,a reminder of the terrible suffering these people endured , worth a visit .

Lest We Forget...... This was a place we wanted to go to but didn't get the chance to. As per other reviews if you are in the area then pay a visit.Even from the boat the tribute / memorial is quite moving, to think what happened here and else where brings home how lucky most of us are.After all this you would think we couldn't still do harm to each other.

Use the view to think. This monument to the thousands of killed jewish by the WWII is pretty simple but goes dee into your hearth. It reminds the jewish's shoe, left on the bank of the river at the episode when they were shot dead. The beautiful view will feed you thoughs.
Poignant, but only visit if you're in the area, not worth a trek. Very poignant and understated. Go if you're in the area. Nice walk along the river and views of the bridges and castle hill.

Beautiful tribute. If you don't like history don't go there, you will find boring. If you love, you must go!!!
Take you time, sit down and reflect on the horrors of war, to never happen again!
Highly recommended!

Very poignant yet subtle monument. Spent some time contemplating the atrocities that took place here. Great spot to view castle hill and the chain bridge. Not easy to cross the busy road so make sure you walk along the river bank from the chain bridge

Sobering, excet for the hoards of tourists. Metal reproductions of shoes of all sizes, sexes and ages that represent the ones that were left behind as the Nazis machine-gunned hundreds into the cold Winter Danube. If t for the crowds it would have made me cry.
Moving tribute..... Just a small, simple and moving tribute to those who died at the hands of the Nazi's... don't miss seeing this ... right on the quai near Parliament building.
Deeply moving experience. This very simple statement on the bank of the Danube highlights man's inhumanity to man. It's a must see when in Budapest.

Very moving and sad exhibit.. A bit difficult to get to but really worth it. Read the story before you get there about the exhibit, since there isn't much explanation at the site. This is a very sad part of Hungary's history.

Very touching.. The best way to get there: Tram No. 2, station: Széchenyi István tér. Cross the street to the promenade, and go to your right, untill you arrive.Short distance walk + great Buda & Danube view.The problem with this monument: a lot of people arrive, and nor realy understand what its all about. Therefor they put their legs "in" the shoes etc.Read on Wiki a bit about every place you want to go.It will enrich you, & i believe that youll be more satisfied.
Poignant, and chilling. You need to hear the story behind this, or research it beforehand, to understand the significance of the shoes lined up along the promenade.

So moving because its so ordinary. Difficult to find due to the carnage of the renovations, a very, very simple memorial. Just a bunch of steel shoes. But look at them, stop and think. Ponder the stories that they tell, each one an individual tragedy. Look at the sorts of shoes that are there - and experience the cold chill when you notice the little child's shoes. How could people do this to other people? And then remember that this is within living memory and feel that cold chill all over again. You may need to cross to the riverside walk at the Gresham palace and walk up towards the parliament due to the aforementioned works. A must see.

Haunting, simple and raw. 600,000 Hungarian Jews were murdered by the Nazis, most in Auschwitz and Dachau concentration camps, but several thousand died by gunfire, being lined up by the Danube and shot...often tied together so the number of bullets lost would be minimized, with the first victim falling in the river and the rest being dragged in with them...mothers, fathers, children...haunting sculpture of "rusted" looking shoes, so evocative of those lost lives...and even more compelling as you look around you at the proximity of the homes and the many windows whereby residents watched and certainly heard these murders occur. A must see.

Very moving memorial. A very moving memorial to the Jewish who died because of their religious beliefs by the Arrow Cross. Too bad they don't have more than a small marker to describe what took place here. It is also VERY hard to get to, they are working on the road, but either way you had to cross a VERY busy highway and climb over a rail. Really a shame they don't have this better located.

Worth a visit. To echo another review, definitely do your homework before going. There is a plaque on the ground, but I didn't see any explanations in English. It is important to understand the reasons why a memorial using shoes was created here. I witnessed people snapping photos and then quickly departing the memorial as if it were another attraction checked off the list. However, this is a memorial that deserves attention and reflection.

Must see!. Very unique and very emotional. I tried to get a book with information on the artist, sculptor, history but was unable to find anything except a three-page inclusion in a 300-page book on Budapest attractions. Men's shoes and boots, women's shoes and boots, baby shoes and boots. You could look at the shoes and relate to their economics. Rich, poor, middle-class. All murdered on the banks of the Danube by Hungarian Nazis - at least this is what I was told.It is not the easiest place to get to, because although this memorial is across the street from the Parliament, you cannot just cross the street, walk down some steps and get there. No. You have to walk to a bridge, get down to the river level and then walk a distance to see the "shoes".But worth it. Big time. An incredible memorial to those who were murdered for their religion.We need to remember what was done and learn from this inhumanity.

Shoes on the Promenade. A very sad reminder of what happened during the WWII to ordinary people, children...... Very touching. Even though Hungary came through that terrible war, it was then invaded and controlled by the Soviets for another 40 years. Sad, sad.
Moving. This is a very moving, albeit simple, "attraction." There is nothing there so do some homework prior to going to get the most out of it.

Different type of tribute. Although what these shoes represent is extremely sad, the tribute is unusual and captures your attention. These shoes are the memorial of those who were required to take them off, then were shot and pushed into the river by the Nazis.

Somber, serene walk. This is an artist's memorial tribute to the Jews who were paraded to the Danube by the Nazi's, forced to remove their shoes, then shot into the River. The bronzed shoes are a stark reminder of the Holocaust and the horrors faced by the Jewish people across Europe. The memorial shows the power of the simplest artistic forms. Stunning.

So simple but so moving.... You can approach this simple tribute from the river bank on the Pest side near the Parliament buildings. As they are doing so much renovation work around here it is quite hard to get down there from the city. But it is well worth the walk and the search to have a quiet few minutes and think about what happened there. Very, very moving - especially the tiny pair of children's shoes. There were several small bunches of flowers placed on and in the shoes - also small piles of stones which people had brought there. I liked the fact that it wasn't heavily sign posted and pointed out but it maybe needs a little more direction - this could probably be done once the renovations are finished.

A Unique Memorial. We were alerted to this memorial when our Big Bus drove by. We were inquisitive, hopped off and wandered down and took in the scene. These reminders are an amazing way to remind us of worse times gone by, but they were done very genuinely and sympathetically as well. We hoped that something as horrible an incident as this would never be repeated.

moving. We were determined ti visit this memorial after reading about it in the Lonely Planet, but found it difficult to get to as there was construction work happening along the riverfront and no locals seemed to know about it (or maybe we just asked the wrong ones!). Finally arrived and found it to be a very moving statement commemorating a very sad event in history. An excellent place to prompt reflection on life.

Unique and Chilling Memorial. This is a memorial to victims of the Holacaust. It consists of bronzed shoes of victims that were lined up on the shore of the Danube, were asked to take off their shoes and clothes and were shot, causing them to fall in the river.

Poignant. I approached from too far up the Danube and had some very busy streets to cross, actually very dangerous. So it is important to approach as directed in the travel books. The shoes are silent, mute reminders of the evils of anti-Semitism, the Arrow-Cross, inhumanity. Sometimes these shoes are 'decorated' with pig trotters--a sign that anti-Semitism is not dead. They were simply there on my visit, with flowers tucked inside as kindnesses.

Very moving. We saw this at the end of the day...very moving. Sat on the benches watching the sun go down which provided me the opportunity to sit back and think about what was lost by those who weren't in "the right mold". It made me appreciate how lucky I am. I have thought about those shoes along the Danube quite a bit since seeing them. A must see to pay respects and think about others.
Very poignant. A very moving site - a had read a lot of information about the massacre before I visited which made it much more of an experience. A pleasant place to contemplate and remember.
Must see. Very touching. We went to see it by ourself , since it was not included in any tours. Must see it when in Budapest

A small but moving rememberance. Could easily have been missed but was informed of the shoes on the Big Bus tour. This is not just art but a very moving remembrance to the second world war and you have to understand the history to appreciate the shoes.Not for me to be the historian but read about it and stand in the spaces and think what this means.

Shoes on the Danube Prominade.. A poigiant reminder of human depravity, this time it was the Nazis (German), but later there were the Russian Comunists, ok they did not murder Jews but they murdered Hungarians.

One of the simplest and evocative reminders of a great tragedy.. I live here in Budapest and often pass by this simple but heart wrenching memorials to mans cruelty.Other reviewers have told the history of how the shoes became an iconic memorial to those that were killed in that very spot...A walk along the river front from the Chain bridge towards the Parliament reveals the simple memorial.I notice that a few of the bronze shoes are missing..One wonders at the insensitivity of people who could deface such a site...Do visit and remember as one takes in the beauty that is Budapest..

Thought Provoking and Poignant. Very moving installation, on the banks of the Danube where rows of Jews were tied to each other with their hands and feet tied together, they were instructed told to remove their shoes due to there value at the time.In order to save bullets the person in the middle was shot, as he fell into the water the others were pulled in with him and drowned! Such a sad and tragic part of history that should never be forgotten and this art installation is both thought provoking and poignant.This was not in any guide books that I brought with me and was fortunate to have found this after finding it on Trip Advisor. If you were to walk past, you probably wouldn't even know what it was but when you know the story, it really blows you away.The easiest way of finding this, is to walk down along side the Danube at the Chain bridge and head towards the Parliament

Poignant place.. I noted this on other Tripadvisor reviews and determined to go, altho' it sounded awkward to find. In fact it was easy, one evening we walked to the Chain bridge to see it lit up and then wandered along the embankment towards the Parliament building and there were the shoes! Probably nore effective in the daylight, but still evocative at night, some had little posies of fresh flowers in them. We had heard a harrowing description of how people were forced to undress, in freezing temperatures, and in some cases break the ice themselves, before being forced to jump in to their deaths. This is an understated and effective reminder of man's inhumanity to man. Please go , see and reflect.
Very Moving Holocaust Memorial. This is worth seeking out as a reminder of the effects that the Holocaust had on this city. It's near to the Parliament on the bank of the magnificent river.

Very moving. This very simple monument, which might be overlooked by passers-by who do not know what it represents, is dramatic and moving. It is a series of shoes -- a hundred or more pair -- lying haphazardly along the river bank. It represents what is left of Jews who were shot and pushed into the river, leaving only their shoes behind. It is impossible not to feel the horror of that moment.

So poignant. We came across this memorial completely unexpectedly - and it was all the more powerful for that. The sight of so many shoes, cast in iron, spread along part of the promenade, looking as if their owners had just left them, was a dreadful reminder of those Hungarian Jews who had been shot and thrown into the Danube by the fascist The Arrow Cross Party, Some people had left fresh flowers in a few of the shoes, which made the contrast between their colours and the harsh grey of the shoes even more poignant.

Makes you think. Makes you think, the shoes are a memorial to The victims men women & children, they were told to take off they shoes then they were shot into the Danube by arrow cross militiamen in 1944-45. There is plagues in different languages in the cobbles near by the shoes if you not looking for them you may miss these. Worth a visit near the Parliament

Creative artwork. My friend and I walked there along the coastline after visiting The House of Terror. As such, we felt heavy after seeing these shoes and could feel the blue in the city.We spent like 5-10 minutes there.

Very sobering, sad reminder of terrible times.. It is a very thought provoking display/exhibit. Because of the construction, it is a little hard to get to but worth it. Very simple bronze display, very powerful message that hopefully will "Never Again" happen.

Moving sculpture. We visited this sculpture depicting shoes left by Jewish people before they were murdered and pushed into the Danube by the Nazi's during WW11. Very moving, especially seeing childrens shoes. Its not very well signposted and quite hard to access unless you are right on the promenade. Access isn't improved by all the works happening at and around the parliament building. Best way to get there is to go down the steps beside the chain bridge and keep walking upstream until you get to it about 400m along.

Just wishing for a bit more information. The tribute was eerily beautiful as you look at the shoes with the passing boats on the Danube. But since Budapest, in general, seems anti-explination on any monument, although we weren't expecting anything, a bit more would be useful. There is a huge renovation in front of the parliment however, so if this is still going on, the easiest way to see it is get on the Danube walk right after the Chain Bridge.

Moving. Truly one of the most moving and visceral monuments to the barbarism of the Holocaust I've seen. Bronzed shoes of the victims, who were tied together and the--the first--shot so the others would be dragged into the water and drowned.
Beautiful and touching. This simple memorial was very very touching and well done. To walk along the riverbank and see the shoes really causes one to stop and think and reflect. Don't miss it.

Powerful. Powerful tribute to those who lost their lives in the Holocaust. Simple is best, but a few sentences of explanation would add to the experience. You have to know this is there and go looking for it.

Lest we Forget. The Shoes memorial was definitely on my Budapest bucket list, but had been overlooked until someone mentioned it on our tour of Parliament. The memorial lies on the banks of the Danube quite close to Parliament between Roosevelt Square and Kossuth Square. An enormous amount of work was being done in the area when we visited and it was not easy to get to, but the small amount of effort and back tracking is really worthwhile.The 60 pairs of bronze period shoes pay tribute to the people shot into the Danube during the time of the Arrow Cross terror. All shapes and sizes, including small childrens this is a special place to remember the victims.

Okay. I was really interested in viewing this tribute and had to persuade my friends as it was a little out of the way. I was hoping that there might be information boards to learn more and get a feel for the situation these people faced but there wasn't. All in all it was okay. It may be that I am comparing it to other WW2 related things that I have seen for example Auschwitz and monuments in Berlin which are more poignant.

Sometimes simple is best. This is a small, powerful, elegant tribute to the Jews who lost their lives at the Danube riverside near the end of World War II. We walked to it on a cold, windy, rainy day. Most appropriate to the stark and striking nature of this monument. Pairs of bronzed shoes lined up along the river's edge, just as the victims were told to remove their shoes before they were to enter the water, and be shot by fellow Hungarians. It is a harsh reminder of evil, cruelty, abuse of power to which desperate people can fall. That it has such a prominent place in this historical city is testimony to human resilience.
Touching. It was hard to reach, but it was worth the try, because it's very special. It's really worth visiting and you have a nice view of the Danube.

touching. We read about this monument, and went along the Danube bank to see it. The best way to get there (by foot, a short pleasant walk) is along the bank itself, from the chain bridge towards the Parliament building. Actually we strolled along the other side of the road, and expected to see some signs of the monument. We didn't see any sings, and we might have missed it if we didn't know what we were looking for.
Unique. Various sizes of shoes of men, women and children made of metal. It is a reminder of Jews being marched to the banks of the Danube and excuted by the Nazis
Amazing. Clever design memorial of the victims shot into the Danube in 1944_45. Erected in 2005 and really worth visitng .

A touching tribute. Due to many works going on, this was hard to get to, but if you go off the chain bridge and walk towards Parliament House you will be rewarded with a moving tribute to those who killed during the tumultuous past. Well worth theceffort

Worthy of a Visit. Definately worthy of a visit. Cross the Danube from Budapest and turn left. Walk along the river. The memorial is a short walk from the bridge. Sobering memorial. I am hopeful the city's historians will find a way to better explain the memorial than with a simple plaque embedded in the sidewalk.
Touching. A very thoughtful and unique reminder of the brutal murders of the men women and small children of Budapest.

Such a nice tribute. Too bad its a bit of a hassle to get there... Budapest was undergoing some construction work, so walked all the way over there to realize to get there you have to get to the promenade from the bridge...

Very powerful. I think this very simple and understated memorial is a must see for any visitor to Budapest. If you are standing in front of Parliament, it is to the right along the river bank about 100 yards.
understated. There is a plaque which tells something of the story-but not enough. Combined with the Terror museum and you know what the Red arrow was and how sick this is.

Moving!. Hard to get to, what with the construction near the waterfront/around the Parliament, but hugely moving. Check with tourism officials to ascertain the state of the construction in the area, and use the tram to get to there.
Moving. I found the shoes on the Danube to be a very moving piece of art for remembering the tragic events which happened along a beautiful stretch of water.

Poignant. It's a lot smaller than expected but nevertheless a very poignant monument to the horrors of Holocaust. Shame on Budapest for mislabling the plaque and not admitting that it was Jews who were killed on that day.

A Holy Place. The cast metal shoes are a memorial to the Jews of Budapest who were marched to the bank of the Danube by the Nazis, asked to remove their shoes and then executed. Seeing such a common everyday symbol of humanity is a reminder that they were not numbers, but sisters, brothers, mothers, fathers and children.
Poignant. We saw the shoes whilst on a boat trip. As I say poignant but must be even more so to walk by them.We were all taken aback for the reason they were there.

Mesmerizing. One of the most provocative memorials I've ever seen in my life. It is indeed a very sad sight to see. You cannot access it from the Parliament now due to the construction and the tram tracks; you have to walk along the Pest side of the Danube. It pays tribute to the 600 thousand Hungarian Jews that were massacred during WWII. There's about 50 pairs of shoes in different sizes and shapes-a vivid reminder of the concentration camps. You can sit on the rails and take some time to reflect on this period of history...

Definately worth a look. We spotted this on trip advisor and searched it out.Very poignant and quite moving. Definately worth a look.You cant get down to the river by the parliament so best to walk up from the next bridge. It eill pnly take 5 minutes and you get good views of Buda as you ho.

a difficult task. We tried hard to get to the spot but was difficult with all the barriers and excavation work going on. We could spot it from far , there is the tram line , barricades etc. one could skip off this visit unless of course you have the time.
Impressive. Due to its realism this momument makes you silent. We should never forget how the Hungarian population has suffered for decades under Nazi's and Communists.

A sad piece of history. A short distance south of the majestic Parliament Building is a humble tribute to the Hungarian Jews that were forced to remove their shoes (a commodity), before being shot into the Danube River by the Arrow Cross (a local Nazi party). Although difficult to access due to the tram tracks and a busy roadway, this is a sight worth visiting. The bronze shoes are in various sizes representing those men, women and children killed. The location is approximate to Szechenyi Ter (street) and Kossuth ter (street) on the river bank! We visited this sight during the pouring rain which added to the dramatic affect.

Another very sad story. Here on the banks of the Danube a row of people were tied to each other and their hands and feet tied together. In order to save bullets the person in the middle was shot. As he fell into the water the others were pulled in with him and drowned! Sad, sad, sad history.
A wonderful experience any time of the day or night. Walk, enjoy the view and the lights, eat, and do not miss Peter Pan. Spend at least 24 hours, or you will feel unsatisfied.

Simple and poignant. Well it was tricky to get to it, especially with all the building work going on at the parliament. However with a tram line and major road to cross its always going to be tricky. I recommend you cross down by the chain bridge and walk up.The views are good, as they are all along the danube here. Then you remember this is the last view some people saw before they fell in the river leaving their shoes behind.

This place deserves more attention!. It is a really important place. You feel the sad history of the second world war. But the problem is it's so hard to reach to place. Before we passed much time close here but we haven't seen any information. At night also there was no illumination, so dark. They need to organize better for tourists. Anyway good idea!

Moving Memorial. Moving memorial by the Danube near the parliament building. It would have been useful for it to have been signposted, especially as the current building work around the parliament impedes access to the river front.

Great memorial. We almost accidentally stumbled "over" the shoes when we tried to get to the next bridge in the late evening and stopped for a moment to look at them. It's such a great, simple memorial and that one could walk past so easily and then notices them in the corner of one's eyes makes it even more powerful in my opinion. While the memorial is obviously great, right now there is some construction work being done right behind it, so we had to walk all the way back to the Charles Bridge afterwards, to continue on our way, when we actually wanted to go into the other direction. That's why it's only four points.

Very emotional place!. Just to remember... Just to not forget...60 shoes to commemorate the Jews killed in Budapest in 1944-1945. They've been asked to remove their shoes before been shout at the edge of the river.Very impressive and emotional place.Just next to the Parliament, on the border of the Danube. You have to stop here.

poignant. My travelling companion had read about this and I really wanted to see them. Such a simple symbol of something so devastating in Jewish/European history. It certainly provided us with food for thought.
moving. Because of a marathon in the neighborhood, we had to climb down a wall to get to the shoes, but it was worth it. What a moving scene.

Very emotional and touching. This is a must visit on a trip to Budapest, especially if you are into history. Although it is very understated and not much of a monument, the simple arrangement of the bronze shoes that represent the men, women and children that were thrown into the river by he Nazis is very touching!
Memorial. Very effective memorial to one of the many atrocities of warfare. Set on the banks of the Danube next to the Parliament
Very Moving. This needs no words...just feelings. See it. It's near the Chain Bridge, so it's on your way to anywhere.

So simple and so moving. The shoes are a simple and hughely moving tribute to those killed at the river in such a horrible and cruel way. We were told about the bronze cast shoes whilst on a bus tour of Budapest and went back the next day to see them for ourselves. There are no signs up or anything else other than the shoes which makes the tribute even more effective. I found it extremely sad and when I found the child's shoes that was really very emotional. An excellent and understated commemorative to those who lost their lives.

Simple but meaningful. You will probably need a tour or someone to explain you the history behind this little salute, but once you know what's it about and think over it for some minutes in front of the calm waters of Danube, you will be moved for sure. This is one of those small things that reminds us the horrible events that took place. Don't miss it.

The Shoes Memorial. A heartbreaking memorial to the 15,000 Jews who were executed on the bank of the Danube. It was a reminder of the evil that exists in the world and how the Jews were slaughtered by Hungarian Nazis

Moving tribute. This was an extremely touching tribute to those Jews shot and pushed into the Danube during the Holocaust. Bronze cast shoes of all shapes and sizes, mens, women's, and children ..are permanently adhered to the sidewalk where they were forced to take their shoes off, face the river, were shot and pushed in to be washed away. A must see..so moving in its simple and powerful message.
Heavy feelings. It truly is a memorial that is heavy on the heart. I recommend you see this just before sunset, as the view of the river on that hour is magnificent.
What a beautiful way to represent the lives taken. Essential viewing and proof that art can still be evocative. View and then read up to realise you have visited such an important sight.
very thought provoking. A very simple but Inspiring piece of artwork. My photo of these will stay on my wall for a long time.
Very sad. A most impactful representation. We did not stop at the Shoes, but the tour guide gave us the complete history of what the shoes represented.
Simple but effective. There's not much to say, as it's a very simple monument, but it's effective, providing a poignant moment to think about how so many people were treated.

A poignant memorial. What is more human than wearing shoes? Protecting feet from damage. This memorial brings the attention to the most simple of things-the shoes on our feet. In this case iron shoes stand alone, next to the river Danube where the owners of them were shot by arrows into the water below. This is one of the most moving memorials I have visited. The shoes that are sat by the waters edge represent those who wore them, their journey and their final destination. For so simple a visual image the shoes represent all the victims were and the holocaust to which they became victims. A marvel. Truly.

Simple but touching. It's a very simple tribute to the Jews who were murdered by the Fascist regime in Hungary during WWII but it's also very moving. A must see in Budapest where you can take some moments to think about the victims and the brutality of some humans.

a powerful reminder. well worth the walk down to see this simple but very moving memorial which gives a powerful reminder of mans inhumanity to man. Due to the building works its easiest to approach from the Chain Bridge and walk towards the parliament and then retrace your steps back the same way
Thought Provoking. Beautiful, understated monument which really makes you stop and think about what happened. Worth a wander along the water for.

A must see. A sight that just reminds you of mans cruelty to there fellow man.
The shoes are so realistic it really gets to you.

Moving tribute. Worth a look while strolling along the danube. This memorial to the fallen Jews is well worth a look and to take a moment to think about the victims. Its simple but quite moving. Just in front of the parliament building but at the moment there are renovations going on at the Parliament building so you may find it hard to get to. You can get close enough to take a look though at the end of the tram line. While youre in the area take a look.

memorial sculptures. It was a very moving experience. The sad part is that they left out the most important fact from the memorial inscription. It only says it is in the memorial for martyrs who were victims of this horrible act with out saying that these victims were Jews only.
Touching. The monuments in Budapest are memorable and this one is no exception. It's well done and worth a look.

Worth a visit. Although difficult to find this is well worth the effort. It was very poignant and thought provoking.We found the easiet way to get here was to walk along the river from the Chain Bridge towards the Parliament on the Pest side
Very Somber. I had read the reviews and wanted to sign it for my self. Very well done to make you stop and think.
Intense and thought provoking. A beautifully done, stark reminder of what people went through in Budapest's dark history - take a trip to House of Terror for further knowledge of life as it was.

Very Haunting. We passed by this monument to the Jews whilst on a city bus tour and had to go back and see them close up. They really hit home, how badly people treat each others. It is a very simple tribute but very haunting at the same time

what a heatbreaking monument. One of the most memorable places in Budapest. Hope the shoes are not washed away by raising waters of Danube and the memory of the Holocaust stays with people. It is so easy to forget.

Very powerful and moving. This is one of the best memorials that we saw on the whole of our Euro trip. The simplicity is even more powerful than you would expect and portrays the horror of the event effectively.
Shoes on the Danube. A very nice memorial to a terrible event. It is a poignant story remembered in a simple but very effective way. There were not many people visiting this site when we were there.

Shoes on the Danube. It's not that well marked, and the only entrance to the promenade wasn't that close to the monument. We were lucky that we took the stairs that we did, because I think the others were near Parliament, which was under construction.

A nice tribute.. There is nothing fancy a out this monument, it is what it is. A simple way to remember a terrible thing.Well worth a visit as it is just down from Chain Bridge. When I visited, there seemed to be a fair few people sitting there 'relaxing' amongst the shoes. I found that a little inappropriate but each to theri own I guess.
Tragic. Not much to say about, it's just a nice monument but with a horrible story. Good place to take pictures!

moving memorial. I visited on a Tuesday afternoon, there were a few people about but not so many as to be distracting. The simplicity and human normality of the empty shoes was very powerful, they highlighted what was not there and felt more personal than a list of names. To stand where those poor people did, looking at what was their home and their city in their last moments whilst their fellow country men turned against them was a humbling and moving experience.

Very moving experience. Was a little difficult to cross street to get to, but glad we went. Very touching memorial to those who lost their lives in this tragic way. One could only imagine what was going through their minds the last moments of their lives. Just stood there silently, saying a prayer.
Mournful sight. Fitting memorial. A perfect memorial to the Jews who were killed by the Nazis on the river bank and allowed to fall into the water. You can almost see them.

Thought provoking and harrowing. This was difficult to find with all the work going on and you have to walk quite a way to find it but it is worth it. It is a beautiful piece that hits you with such force once you stop and reflect on what actually happened. The small child's shoes brought a tear to my eye. Very harrowing.

No 2 Tram affected by building works in front of parliament. Worth a visit but you need to get off the tram before it reaches the building works as otherwise you have a long walk to get onto the promenade Get off the tram just after the Margaret island Bridge and walk along the promenade - not too far - you are then able to see the Parliament from the River Bank

One of the most moving Holocaust memorials we've visited. The simplicity of the memorial and the story behind it is very moving. The children's shoes really brought home the horror of what happened. Certainly well worth a visit. Take the opportunity to sit quietly and reflect.

Heartbreaking and poignant. This is a very easy monument to find as its located right on the banks of the River Danube. You could spend 5minutes here or an hour, it's quite nice to just sit there with your thoughts and reflect on those who lost their lives. The detailing on the shoes fascinated me as it seemed that no two pairs were the same. It's difficult to walk away without a tear in your eye.
Shoes on the Danube. Excellent but poignant representation of fate suffered by Hungarian Jews and other groups during WW11, The sculpture is brilliant and they look like real shoes.

If you do nothing else in Budapest.... I found out about this online, otherwise I'd never have seen it. It's very close to the Parliament, but it's not easy to get to if that's the direction you're coming from - you have to sort of cross a busy almost dual carriageway type road and hop over a barrier to reach it. It's easier if you're coming along the river from the centre of Pest towards the Parliament. I found this to be incredibly touching - the sight of the shoes, from men's work boots, to women's heels to, worst of all, children's shoes, makes more of an impact than a fifty foot memorial and list of names ever could. The victims were shot on the bank of the Danube and thrown into the river, after first being made to take off their shoes. I visited this memorial twice: once in the afternoon, when there were a lot of people there, and once at 7.30am on a Saturday morning, when it was deserted. I'd recommend viewing it during quieter hours, if possible, it really is the sort of thing to make your throat ache.
Very moving. Walk along the Danube to see the shoes - a reminder of the Jews who were lined up and shot into the Danube River during the Holocaust.

Sad and touching reminder. The iron shoes can be seen from the big bus and the commentary tells you about, from the bus it looked very interesting, so we got off and it's an easy walk from either bridge.The smaller the art work makes it all the more poignant if you stand and imagine what happened there. We thought it well worth a visit.
Touching. Very touching monument. Take your time and find it, it's located between the Parliament and the Chain Bridge.

Just see it. We thought it would be something you could easily miss but it's actually fairly prominent. I'm very glad we found out about it on TripAdvisor as, really, you could see it and not understand the context or why it was put there.We found it extremely moving, and sat by the shoes reflecting for a short while.Definitely worth seeing as you only need to just have a short look at it. I tried taking photos but very hard with tears in my eyes! One of the most moving sculptures I've ever seen.

Heartbreaking. Between chain bridge and the parliament you find this realistic looking memorial of jews who were shot and/or pushed into the river Danube by Hungarian fascists during WWII. Difficult not the feel a grip in the belly at the sight.

Strange feeling. We have seens those shoes just after the visit of the great Synagogue. So it was really strange to see all the shoes, especially the smallest. For the person who are not going to see the Synagogue: in each shoes you can see little rocks put by the visitors ; it is a kind of "hommage".
Something to see. This is a very sad and eye opening site to see however you should go. Easy to walk to however, the area could be cleaned up a little better to make it more tourist friendly

A poignant, moving memorial. Stumbled across this by accident as it was near where we were staying, and due to all the works going on at the Parliament, it's quite a feat to reach it. But, I'm glad we did. A very poignant and interesting memorial located on the river bank. It was incredibly moving to remember the tragic events of this beautiful city and it is very touching. A little more information might be nice, I saw a lot of puzzled expressions on the faces of tourists, and some slightly disrespectful photo opportunities...
Moving. A moving memorial. We visited about 9:30am and there were no other tourists.This is located between the Chain bridge and Parliament on the Pest side.

Shoes commemorate those who were shot. Very close to the bank of the Danube are a series of shoes attached to the pavement. They appear to be bronze, worn, and in a fairly old style. Without realizing what they represent, these shoes are an interesting item to view.However, look for the plaques in the sidewalk near the upstream end of the shoes, and you will know why they are there. This is quite a moving monument to those who suffered only because they were Jews.

Moving but difficult to reach at the moment. A simple but moving monument. Well worth a quick visit, but as other reviews have said, it's difficult to reach at the moment due to the extensive building work which seems to be afflicting much of Budapest. To get there, head down to the river edge from the Chain bridge, as you won't be able to get nearby otherwise without hopping down quite a high wall.
Sad reminder. I really enjoyed the memorial. It definitely serves as a reminder of Hungarian history and the choices that they made during WWII

Very moving. A bit of a struggle to get there, as there are major building works around Parliament, and the authorities seem to have neglected access to this popular monument. However, moving and disturbing.

“Holocaust Memorial, Danube Promenade". I found this place accidental when I'm looking for nice place to visit in Budapest. I saw some pictures of this place also some helpful review and interest to visit. This place wasn't mentioned in the official city map and guide books I got from the tourist information. The shoes here gives remembrance to the Jewish people shot into the Danube during the time of the Arrow Cross terror. It's located in Pest's part, closed to the Parliament and nice place to take a break and enjoy the view of Buda's part. Many people visit this place with friends, family, couple or even alone.
