A moving memorial. This is something that you should look at when you are in Budapest. It is a moving memorial to people executed during WW2.
Profound Reminder. A must see. Poignant memorial. Be prepared to be moved. This is an important and necessary sight to see. It needs to be more heavily promoted.
Moving memorial. Stumbled onto it by accident. Very sad and touching. Worth a visit. Might be a good idea to google it before the time so you know what it's about?
HEART BREAKING. These shoes were reminders of the holocaust and the tragedy of the Jewish people. Did us good to remember.

No explaination. I know this is a memorial but with no explanation it seems just random. They need a sign describing the thought behind it and the meaning. I do feel it is in a great location for what it represents, very quiet area leaves you alone to think about why these shoes are here.

Sad reminder of Hungarian nazis. For those who are interested in WWII issues, the stretch of the Danube in Hungary in front of the Parliament building is worth a visit.Along the cobblestone bank are shoes in all sizes - men's, women's and children's, commissioned from artist Gyula Pauer, to remind the public of the virulent antisemitism of Hungarian Nazis, one of the most enthusiastic antisemites of all the East European nations, when they rounded up Jews indiscriminately one night and shot them on the river bank, to fall into the Danube. They are beautifully made and have an air of such pathos, juxtaposing the horrors of racism against a backdrop of beautful architeccture and a city full of charm.Notmuch has changed, sadly, and recently a Jobbik (neoéNazi) memeber of parliament asked for alistof all Jews in Hungary, since he asserted that they are a threat to National safety!

A piece of monumental art with historical background. The metal shoes of various sizes for men, women and children are placed along a promenade a short distance from the Parliament building. They remind people of the bitter past. Very moving!

How to rate such a memorial?!. 'The shoes' - belong to the history of WWII in Hungary, in this case more precisley to Budapest.The shoes commemorate those killed by the membor of Hungarian Arrow Cross Party. People were taken there during the night, they had to take off all their clothes, shoes and then they were shot...This sight should be part of a remembrance walk of the Holocaust victims, but also survivors, helped by Righteous People.It is not easy to access the memorial :( Either you have to walk on the bench of the river from the Chain Bridge (it is a further and the path is covered with gravel) or You can go from the direction of the Parliament but there you have to cross the road without a crosswalk.
Powerful piece of art. Worth going down to the river to see this simple, powerful art. The sign provided gives very little information, but our guide book had background on the purpose.

Very Poignant. Very poignant. And a brilliant idea. We actually stumbled across it accidentally while on an evening stroll. My wife at first thought they were real shoes left by bathers in the Danube! I then recalled having read about this memorial.
Natural looking shoes. While the shoes are bronze, they are placed in a way that really makes you feel they were left there by those executed. Nice installment.

Touching and Nice. A simple reminder of a tragic time. Go in the evening and have a nice walk. Simple and touching, although it doesn't take a long time. Just one of many things to see in a great city.
Shoes on the Danube. It was a very moving picture with the shoes of men,women and children on the side of the river near the Parliment.

Moving. We struggled to find this, it wasn't mentioned in either of our guide books or the bus tour we did and if not for a friend telling us about it we probably would have missed it! Especially difficult with the repairs being done to the Parliament building blocking many walkways. The monument itself is very understated and makes little mention of what happened but is very moving.

Simple and thought provoking!. A very poignant and moving memorial to those Hungarians who were murdered here in 1944. The memorial is a recent addition and the cast metal shoes of male and female and children provokes thoughts in all who view them.The fact that this is a Jewish memorial only comes to light when you read the last memorial plate in line.Walk along the promenade up from the Chain bridge, an easy access.

Shoes on the Danube.. You have to try hard to find this, especially difficult with the repairs being done to the Parliament building blocking many walkways. The monument itself is very understated and makes little mention of what happened.
So moving. Everybody should view this memorial. One should explore the meaning of the tribute and perhaps take away an important message from this.

A good place to take a break from the crowds and do some thinking. Aside from being one of the few peaceful spots I found in Budapest, I was also very impressed with the monument itself. I think that this is a very meaningful way to honor those who were executed by the Arrowcross Party.

Harrowingly Beautiful. In a city full of the bustle and noise of modern life, I felt as if everything had be quieted and slowed as every traveller to a one walked quietly and pensively arround this poignant memorial. Especially painful was the sight of the tiniest pairs of shoes. A poignant expression of those precious lives.It should be noted that TripAdvisor couldn't point us to the right direction. If you are on the Pest side facing the Danube, it is just to the left of the Parliament on the banks of the river.

Time for thinking. I could face the shoes at the Danubys river. Its sad and made me think about the II world war deeply. I was sad, since I could see some children's shoes... God, how could they did it?

Moving and Sobering. Initially we did not realise the significance of this memorial but once we heard why they were there we found it extremely moving, and a grim reminder of the horrors of persecution during the war.

Moving experience...... This is quite a dramatic memorial to the Jews that lost their lives in yet another atrocious manner. I hope this is not overlooked by travelers who do not know that it exists. It really gives one pause to contemplate the past and to hope that we learn from inhumane acts such as these.

Shoes at Donau Danube. My cousin didn't know about the shoes, but he alreay sensed something happened there. This modest 60 shoes monument represent the shooting of Jews at the Danube. After 1 minute of respect, you have to kneel and make also a photograph of 1 pair of shoes in close up, following the other ones behind...
Impressive monument...

Shoes on the Danube Promenade. This was, perhaps, the most dramatic sight during our entire trip. It is a memorial to the Jews who were shot, after removing their shoes, by Arrow Cross Militiamen in 1944-45, and who fell into the Danube Sad and touching and a strong reminder NEVER to happen again.
emotional experience. The statue is very touching and the proximity to the parlament who is governed by a racist party adds to the symoblism of this monument.

Touching site!. Go there to see this but also to think about the war atrocities! It is easy to find, just walk the Danube's Parliament side from the Chain Bridge to the Parliament and you'll find it!
If you have difficulties finding it, here are the GPS coordinates: Lat: 47.50139. Long: 19.04550.
Incredibly moving exhibit. To hear the story - just heartbreaking. We only saw it briefly from the bus - wish we had more time to visit.

Holocaust Memorial, Danube Promenade, Budapest. A fantastic and very unique memorial to both a specific event in Budapest's history, as well as a very poignant and moving image of the impact of the Holocaust as a whole. The shoes look almost real, and the flowers and candles scattered throughout the memorial give a real pang of how recent and perhaps still present this devestation was and still is in the minds of the people of Hungary. A beautiful and peaceful memorial.

Very moving. Because of the construction near the parliament we reached it from the Chain Bridge side, just go down to the river and walk in the direction of the parliament, you can't miss it. The memorial is very poignant and touching, it brought tears to my eyes. There's a plaque in Hebrew and another one in English. The English one only says that it's a memorial to the Arrow Cross regime, while we all know that it's really a memorial to the Jewish victims of the Nazi regime. I found this very disappointing.
A thought provoking monument. The 'Shoes on the Danube' is an excellent monument to those who lost their lives and something that should not be missed on a trip to Budapest
Moving Monument. Make sure you read up or have access to wikipedia when you get there. There is no description on the monument other than the shoes.

Worth the walk. Very moving. I am writing this review in retrospect. Budapest was my first East European city of many. The history and reality of WW2 is evident in so many places, but for me the historical journey started here. I have to thank tripadvisor for leading me here, as I researched for things to do and this came up. I had 3 failed attempts at finding this site. Hot tip if you reach the Danube from Pest old town, turn right and keep walking along the bank towards parliament just past the Chain Bridge. This was a film makers tribute to the Hungarian Jews that were forced to take off their shoes (a commodity in that time, worth more than innocent peoples lives.) before being shot nto the river. That's heart breaking to gasp. You don't need a tourist "guide", billboard or the like. Just stand here and remember how lucky you are to live in a time when you are not forced to face a fateful death at the hands of one mans insane ideals.

A worthwhile visit. It's a shame to see some of these shoes missing, but the memorial is worth seeing just to take in the location of where this happened, right in the centre of the city with views of most landmarks. Not many people seem to go up this way either, since the building work currently going on at the parliament means it's a dead end.
A Moving Tribute. I was moved by the significance of this tribute to the souls lost during WW II. We should never forget what happened in Budapest.
Touching ... Spare a thought for the people affected, Difficult to reach when Parliament is rebuilt, easiest from the Chain Bridge.

A very touching tribute. Shoes on the Danube is located just before the Parliament and it is a very apt tribute to the Jews who were shot on the banks of the river and the bodies left to float away in Danube by the Nazis. The Jews were insignificant to the Nazis, but since their shoes had second hand value (as they could be sold in the market) they were made to remove their shoes before they were shot into the river.The memorial has dozens of pairs of shoes made in cast metal shown as if discarded by the river. It is a very touching tribute and since there are no plaques / sign boards to explain the same, it is recommended to read a little before visiting.The views of the place are amazing, especially in the evening when the Parliament building lights up and both the bridges light up as well.

Moving tribute. This is a must see when in Budapest. It is such an understated and yet profound tribute to the local Jews were murdered here. It is very easy to find along the river bank just before the Parliament house. It is one of the most memorable memorials I have come across in Europe. There is no information at the site though so its important to research it to understand its significance. There were some people playing around with their feet in the shoes which really irritated me! Perhaps they did not know it was a memorial? A plaque at the site explaining the memorial may stop this future. Please do see this beautiful place but please respect its significance as well.
Touching tribute. Very moving and disturbing to know that many people were shot and thrown into river in front of their neighbors and the church.

A moving tribute. We visited the Shoes on the Danube after we'd been to the Synagogue and Jewish museum where our guide had explained to us about the shooting of local Jews who were marched to the waterfront, shot and their bodies left to float down the Danube. Whilst their lives had no value to the Arrow Cross (the local Nazi party) who killed them, their shoes had second-hand worth and so they were made to remove their shoes before they were shot. The Shoes on the Danube memorial commemorates the river bank killings with dozens of pairs of cast metal shoes standing as if discarded on the river side.As memorials go it's quietly understated. You won't find big plaques explaining what happened, just a small one inset into the pathway written in Hebrew. Some of the shoes have pebbles inside, the traditional way in which people mark a visit to a Jewish grave. Others have wilted flowers placed inside them. You can find the shoes on the river bank just to the south of the Parliament building.

Profound and touching. Located right by Danube before the Parliament House. I found the sight of it both artistic and very moving of what it symbolized. There is hardly any description there though so would recommend some background reading beforehand to better appreciate it.
Moving. Very moving to see the shoes on the river. Right down from the parliament building. A must to go to.

More info please. The location is easy to find at the moment as the no. 2 tram stops adjacent to its location due to the works on Paliament House making it the end of the line. The story about this site is quite moving but there is nothing at this site to give a detailed explanation about its significance. I have had to "google" the information following my visit. It is only a short walk from the Parliament so hopefully the authorities will put some notice boards up in the near future when thy finish their works. It certainly deserves more information in Hungarian as well as other languages.

Shoes on the Danube-- a must see. In 1944-45 thousands of Hungarian-Jews were shot and thrown into the river by their fellow citizens. The monument has 60 pairs of iron shoes, forming a row of 40 metres. It is dedicated to the victims of the Hungarian fascist Arrow Cross party. The victims had to take their shoes off, since shoes were valuable at the time. Our guide said that Jews were tied together with a long rope and every 4th person was shot and the rest pushed into the Danube to drown. This is never taught in the Hungarian schools. No Hungarian Government apology has been made. Monuments to wartime Hungarian fascist leaders are being built today.

thought provoking mystery. our guide book suggested we should seek this out and we did after walking along the dusty pavement close to the Parliament and water's edge. Pity there was no plaque or tourist guidance about this site as I am sure its history was worth further explanation.
Very Moving. A very poingnant memorial of the Holocaust. The shoes reminded us how innocent people were executed just for having different religioud belief

worth a view. Well worth the walk up the Danube to see the site a must visit , ther eis a little plaque near by which gives you some small info but worth buying a guide book wot find out more. Beautifully done

Moving. My husband had heard about the memorial so we looked it up on the internet and found it on our own but no one in the hotel had suggested it as a point of interest. There should be a proper sign up at the site explaining what the shoes are doing there...
Worth the detour. Construction made getting there a little frustrating in the heat, but it was worth it. Sometimes the simplest things can make the largest statement.

A moment of reflection. On viewing this memorial you must forget you are a tourist and become a human being. This is a monument to those Jews shot and killed on the Danube banks by anti-Semites.It is plain and simple and so moving.A vibrant culture was almost destroyed in 1944.Take a picture but do not put yourself in the frame- that would be unseemly. Be thankful for 70 years of relative peace in Europe.

Very Moving. We specifically wanted to see this monument but due to the work being carried out by Parliament we had to walk from Parliament to Chain Bridge and then back to Parliament, however, it was worth it. Very moving.
Thought Provoking. Just near the houses of parliament nd well worth a visit. It is a unique memorial which is very thought provoking

overrated. I expected more.At least if there was a sign with some information or any additional value, it wouldn't be so disappointing.Ok to see if you're already walking in the area, don't go especially

Poignant art installation. While strolling the east bank of the Danube, just south of the Parliament building, tt's well worth stopping by this poignant art installation commemorating Jews killed by the Nazis on this site. A fine example of a meaningful use of public space to make a statement with art (in this case, bronze shoes on the edge of the riverbank).

Very poignant and a reminder to treat our fellow man wth dignity. Heartbreaking to see the childrens shoes. Liked the thought behind the monument but loath the acts that inspired it. A must see sight to reflect on

Very sad. We read about the shoes on the Danube and my wife wanted to see them ........ it is very moving to see this memorial to a despicable act where several people were shot at this place and fell into the Danube. There is extensive work going on around this area and it was quite difficult to access it.
Shoes on the Danube Promenade. Touching tribute to Budapest Jews killed by Nazis. Shoes of various sizes lining the promenade along the Danube River in Budapest, Hungary.

Very worth the effort to find, such a moving tribute. I've been here twice, the second time bringing my partner with me - who was moved to tears by the story of the Jewish men, women and children who were ordered to take off their shoes and stand by the edge of the Danube Promenade by Hungarian national socialists, shot into the river so that the fast moving water would sweep their bodies away. It is a little hard to spot, walk down to the promenade by the Hungarian Academy of Sciences and follow the edge towards Parliament - you should find it about half way along. The visit won't take you long, costs nothing and is guaranteed to leave a very lasting impression of how even in a city this beautiful, the horrors of war are never far enough away.
Very tragic, but worth thinking about. This small exhibit is powerful because it captures one single horrific event during the holocaust and now serves as a memorial shrine.
Haunting. The collection of shoes next to the Danube are a stark reminder of the innocent people who perished during the war. It can't help but bring tears to your eyes. Very sad reminder.

touching installation. is a touching monument and a very nice installation.Generally the town has many sculptures full of history.the shoes are situated near the parliament,but is easy to loose the spot.pay attention!

Very Moving. We did manage to get to this, but the area is under a little construction. One way to get there is to take the number two tram all the way to the end stop by Parliament and take your chances of crossing the busy road to the embankment, which is what we did. My guess is that eventually there will be a crossing zebra installed right there, which would be a very good idea.You could walk down the embankment from one of the nearby bridges as there are pedestrian crosswalks there.
very moving. a must to see and take time to reflect. Very clever sculpture to show that rich or poor young or old, all were persecuted.

a must to see. it does not matter if you are Jewish or not it is a must to see. the number 2 tram (last Stop) will take you there, or you can walk along the Danbue. it is a part of histiory and must be seen and the story must be told so it does not happen again. we saw groups of schools learning about the :shoes: it is a heart wrenching part of our history.

poignant. simple but poignant memorial, fortunately got to see it the day before they disappeared under the flood water, worth dropping by and spending a moment to contemplate the evil they were subjected to!
you will cry. Sad history of Budapest nazis executing Jews in to the Danube 1944,war was almost over.With current flood they may be covered by high water of the river

Breath taking. This is both sad and amazing. It really puts all the history into reality for me. Standing there and thinking what those poor people endured is heart breaking. As a history buff I'd say do not miss this amazing opportunity. Plus it's free. With the road works it was hard to get to. Walk down from the main green bridge along the river. Do not try and cross that motorway!
Emotional. Well done! Simple yet moving. Pulled at the heart strings. Easy to find within walking distance of other attractions.
understated yet powerful. Very moving memorial, small but full of meaning. Not as hard to find as others stated, just walk along path besides the water between chain bridge and parliament.
Deeply moving. In our stroll along the Danube we came across the "shoes on the Danube." It was one of the most profoundly moving experiences I have had. Definitely worth seeing.

A Visual Remembrance.... This is a war memorial that is very different from any other I have seen in the past. It represents those that died at the hands of the Nazi's at the end of WWII. The site of these shoes, especially the kids, will remind you of the terrible things that took place here years ago.

Small but poignant. Glad we went and found it. Not easy to find at the minute with all the construction around parliament. We took tram 2 as far as it would go and it stops right next to it. Will only take 5-10 minutes to visit it. If you are going to Parliament make sure you stop and see it.

So very sad, but an important part of history. We visited this site and while I am 50 years old..my mother fled Hungary in 1956, therefore although not of Jewish decent, this touched my heart, there were also others there with tear filled eyes.

A salutary diversion. The shoes commemorate the Jews who were shot and forced into the Danube after the German invasion of 1944 - knowing a little of the history of the Jewish community in Hungary makes this a poignant reminder of what can happen when the worth of every human being is disregarded. With its memorial lights, the site is rather untidy, but this does not detract from its poignancy. Worth the short walk upstream from the Chain Bridge - a pity it is inaccessible from the Parliament side of the road or from the nearby tram stop.

Moving. Difficult to access because of the building work at Parliament so I would recommend walking along the Danube rather than accessing from the side streets by the tramline. The road is extremely busy and it took a while to wait for a gap in traffic, there is no crossing.No English text, so read about it before you go. Worth the effort.
Moving. Simple, but says it all. Worth of visit. You might need a tissue for your eyes. At least we did need one when walked by this memorial.

Very emotional. The simplicity of this display is wonderful. This is one of the memories that will linger with me of my stay in Budapest. A horrible time in history with so many lives taken, both adults and children. There does need to be a larger plaque telling about the memorial because not everyone does research before a trip or is with a guide. Take time to read about this before you visit!
poignant and tragic story of the jews. part of the jewish heritage,as well as the synagogue see why there are shoes close too the danbue here...during the second world war...
interesting. interesting especially when someone explains the history behind this . these were tragic moments. We saw these from the Viking ships as we cruise by

Poingnant and moving sculpture. I read with incredulity,the reviews written by fellow travellers about this wonderful display and feel they have missed the point completely or is it me? I was moved to tears by the sight of the shoes which WERE worn and were of all sizes,and type, small childrens,ladies shoes once worn with elegance of the time with broken straps ,mens shoes and work boots with laces missing worn within inches of their viability... it serves as a reminder of the barbarity of man in times of war,that they made people regardless of their social status, remove their shoes before shooting them,shoes which carry us about our daily lives and carried these people to their death,shot in cold blood and dumped in the river!Murdered because of their race and religion, shocking and moving! Yes it needs remembering because it was the tip of the ice-berg and because these people had committed no crime! That such a simple object that we use every day could be used in such a powerful way is a credit to it's creator. Do not miss it! Take some tissues.
Moving. A very moving reminder of a terrible time in the history of Europe. It an be hard to reach but is worth the effort

Throat-lump inspiring. The shoes monument commemorate a really dreadful event in second world war Budapest when Jewish folk perished in Danube after there shoes were removed for further useThe cast bronze shoes look designer footwear instead of hard worn shoes and boots that would have been worn in war years

Worth your time. If you enjoy walking along the riverside, then divert a little to this moving memorial. We were able to take photos with no one around, and that added to the moving experience. Just standing there in silence imagining the fate of these poor people. There is a small plaque on the floor to accompany the sculptures, but I feel the history deserves more explanation.
Simple, Moving. People in power forget that power is fleeting. History can be a harsh judge! If you are nearby you should visit.

Simple yet very moving. A small and simple monument to the war that is very moving. Shows the true horrors of what happened to the Hungarian Jews (ones who can often be over looked in typical teaching of the holocaust) in a way that everyone can relate to. Moving contrast of beautiful views of Buda to the death of innocent people.Sadly the shoes are slightly rusted away so hopefully this will be repaired!
Definitely worth walking by.... This monument isn't big, but it carries a lot of meaning. Certainly worth a visit as part of your walk along the Danube.

Powerful and moving. We walked beside Parliament and along the river to witness the shoe sculptures beside the Danube. We spent a little while contemplating the shoes, the river and the history. Tragic to think of what once occurred in such a beautiful city in the crimes of War. Worth a visit to contemplate the history when in the area visiting. It's not a big sculpture, or even grand, but does leave a lasting memory when you think of the people that might have worn them and how and why they died.

Small but powerful memorial. I came across the Shoes on a run by the river and was a little baffled as to what they signified. The placque is not very helpful unless you know more about Hungarian history including the terrible things the Arrow Cross party did. After going home and doing some research, I thought it was a very powerful and permanent display of the struggles and tragedy the Jewish people in Hungary faced.
Morbid. Very easy to miss and yes....is very morbid!!! The whole world was in that war and there are every where reminers of it....do we need to celebrate it now???

moving memorial. I highly recommend visiting this memorial on the shores of the Danube. It is an easy walk from the center part of town. Just be sure to take the path that is directly along the water-easily accessible near the chain bridge and several other areas. A sober reminder of a very dark time and a very effective and moving memorial.
Very emotional!. When you know the history behind everything here, you can't help but be amazed at the Hungarians amazing attitude on life and they love Americans

touching. Very original and nice monument dedicated to the many Jews, who were killed during the Second Worldwar; the observer is touched deeply watching these left shoes; in this way this tragedy should never be denied

Beautifully sobering memorial. Beautiful in its simplicity the dozens of pairs of shoes or those formerly paired are a clear reminder of the horrors of the past. The children's shoes are the hardest to imagine being worn by some terrified child before his or her untimely end. Worth the walk, near the Parliment House just to the left of it right above the Danube.

Danube shoes. This was a beautiful tragedy to experience. Very moving and an amazing piece of art at the same time. Although we live not in the past, this is a great reminder of how far we've come and those who were taken to get us to where we are.

Great idea and implementation surrounded by hypocrisy.. Certainly this is a place with a high emotional, intellectual and psychological load. Nevertheless it is less a monument set on the Danube promenade for (Jewish) Holocaust victims than a reminder of the Hungarian hypocrisy in regard to its longest surviving fascist "Weltanschauung" and political movement in Europe and the world: Horty, then Arrow Cross and now Jobbik ...The monument was placed on a site that is easily accessible only for young athletes, elite commando soldiers and suicide candidates. It really is set as isolated as a ghetto, separated from rest of the world by a heavy traffic transit road with no opportunities to cross it in a safe way for at least 1/4 of a mile, both to the right and to the left.Don't tell me it wasn't done on purpose ...And then: on the site were only JEWS murdered. But the writing at the monument only talks of "the victims" (no nationality, religion, etc.) mentioned. Quote: "The sculptor created sixty pairs of period-appropriate shoes out of iron. The shoes are attached to the stone embankment, and behind them lies a 40 meter long, 70 cm high stone bench. At three points are cast iron signs, with the following text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45"" Something that makes people with lesser historical background to simply miss the direct and exclusive link to Hungarian fascist murdering Jews. One could believe that some militiamen of indefinite origin (German? Soviet? Hungarian) belonging to an "Arrow Cross" have shot some Hungarians "into the Danube".Me, I visited and left the site with very mixed feelings. Thanks to the artist team, but full of resentment for the official Hungarian hypocrisy under MP Orban and his Jobbik helpers. And harsh criticism Budapest and Hungary officials for the poor accessibility & visibility of the memorial.

Very Easy to Miss. We almost missed this memorial. Very difficult to find with all the construction going on in the area. Definitely take a walk along the Danube in front of the Parliament building and view this memorial. Very simple and moving.

Learn the history first. Unless you can read the marker in the ground written in Hebrew, I would recommend learning about the history fist. A good tribute that should have a little more indication about what it means (i.e. signage).

A simple but sobering monument. On the banks of the Danube, close to the National Parliament, you realise unspeakable horrors took place in such a peaceful location.Worth a visit for a period of reflection.
Moving Monument. Easily found on the banks of the Danube, this monument to the Jews murdered by the Hungarian Arrow Cross during WWII is simple, yet moving.
Interesting Not in Guides. Very poignant, put things in perspective, eerie, having been to the Holocaust Centre made sense, Hungarians were a split people.

very moving. Please don't miss this wonderful piece of art/rememberanceThese are cast iron shoes to serve as a reminder of the people shot on the banks of the Danube during the war, they were made to remove their shoes (a valuable commodity at the time) and to save ammo some were bound together in fours and two shot and then the others left to drown.A place for some reflection. Hard to find as not in many of the guides but it is on the Pest side on the waterfront near the Parliament buildings.

A simple yet effective memorial. Many reviewers have complained about finding it however we had no problems. It was less than a 10 minute walk along the river from the Chain Bridge which was an enjoyable walk both there and back. The road over to the Parliament Building is busy but you don’t have to access it that way! Although there is only a basic plaque I don’t think you need info on the events the memorial represents, there is a museum for that and you can also look it up for yourself. This is purely an emotive memorial to remember those who died and it’s well worth taking the time to see.

Sad, but a must see. This attraction is along the Danube River. I found it easy to find. If you are coming across the Chain bridge you turn left follow the river path and you will run into it. It is very moving. If you move along the shoes towards the end of the row there is a plack to your left. It will explain what the shoes mean. It's a horrible event, however the homage to the event is beautiful.A must see in Budapest!

Very important to see. Despite being along the river, it can be difficult to get here - the main walkway is higher up so unless you make the effort to be right by the river further down when walking south-north, it can be tough to get across to as the paths to get down to the river walkway are limited. We were actively trying to get here though on our way up to the Parliament, and were very glad to have made it to see this very moving memorial.

Expected More. The shoes are located along the banks of the Danube between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament Building. Unless you know what to look for, it just looks like a row of shoes left along the bank. I believe that the significance of the shoes warranted a bit more of a display, but I'm not the one who should judge.

Historical sight. This place is quite easy to find as its just behind the parliment building. However you do need to cross a very busy road to see them.Makes you feel very humble to see such a sight and to know the people who wore those shoes are no longer with us. I would def say go and see this it will make you stop and think

very moving. These are located just before parliament when walking from the chain bridge end. Not sure what I was expecting but it definitely wasn't as many pairs of shoes as there are. All shapes and size from boots to children's. Definitely worth a stroll along the river and some time to contemplate what actually happened at that point.

Very meaningful!. Worth the time to find this monument (just be careful crossing the street over to the Danube). Simple but profound! When we visited, the shoes were filled with and surrounded by flowers and candles.

Very sad. This is not something that is widely publicised. It's situated in front of the Parliament building but as there are roadworks going on you need to walk a fair bit to the left to cross the road but it's worth seeing. It's a memorial in honour of the Jews who were lined up on the wall front, told to remove their shoes and were shot into the river. From babies shoes to adults it was very moving and I can't imagine how horrific this was for innocent people.

Thought provoking experience. This memorial is located very near the Parliament building, on the Danube Promenade. (At the moment It is a little difficult to get to because of the construction work being carried out in the area.)This is a very simple and emotional tribute to those Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. Indeed, a very powerful reminder for us all to ensure such atrocities never happen again.

So much more than a simple memorial. It's so simple, but really makes you think and feel. I agree with fellow reviewers that it's moving, and that one focuses alot more on the children's boots. Really well-done memorial. My suggestion is to print the map before trying to find this place for the first time. It's not well-marked and it's separated by crazy highway traffic. We heard that they'll build some better pedestrian walkways to get there soon, but we actually ended up on the wrong side of the river! and it took us a good hour to get to this memorial, but it was well worth it
Very touching. The shoes are reminders of the persons who lost their lives along the Danube to members of the Arrow Cross, many were Jews or Roma. They were shot and fell into the river.
Very impressive. Visited the monument last year and is very impressive. Food for thought! The shoes look very sad and so they should be. Beautiful monument!
Sit and Reflect. Then look at the size of some of the shoes. Then feel very lucky. Then just sit and reflect. Then go and have a drink.

Make you stop and think. We took a walk before breakfast and did not stop until we came so far we could see the shoes. We do not regret it . It was a moving sight. There were candles and flowers among the shoes. We noticed especially the small childrens' boots.

Every human being should visit and remember. I stood on the bank of the danube, looked at the shoes holocoust monument, and my heart cried.A line of shoes, with the people wearing them missing, represent the inhumane mass murder that took place on this place by the Nazis and the hungarian cooperators. The shoe monument give a strong feeling of the horror, suffering, and the owefull end of the victims.
A moving experience. To sit and look at the shoes, you can only imagine how horrified the people would have been knowing there fate.

A moving tribute. On the edge of the Danube is a simple memorial of shoes (metal replicas) from youngster to adult placed on the promenade. They are a memorial to the Jewish people who were shot or pushed into the river as part of the WW!! genocide. It is very simple, but quite moving. Just downriver from the Parliament Buyilding on the Pest side.

Brings history to life. If you don't find this historical installation moving beyond believe, check your heart. The Hungarians who we spoke with said that Hungarians for the most part take their responsibility for their part in the Holocaust and are shamed by it. To see the children's pair of shoes next to what are clearly a woman's pair is heart-rending. Take the time to walk along the river and see this--you will not be disappointed.
moving. This small and often overlooked monument to the Jews who were pushed into the river by the Nazis, is a must see while in Budapest. Bronzed shoes line the waterfront to mark the atrocities.

Compelling tribute. How could this have happened? Be sure to visit the shoes of Jewish victims, including those of children forced to remove them, before being shot by fascists and dumping their bodies in the Danube. Take pictures, never forget.

Very moving. The shoes on the Danube are easily found more or less in front of the Parliament building at the very edge of the Danube. This memorial of 60 pairs of shoes (made from iron) represent 60 lives lost when in 1944-45 they were lined up at the waters edge and shot. There is a small memorial plaque and some shoes had flowers in them. Quite a moving and somber visit.
Moving. Simple. Powerful. An elderly man was placing flowers. I asked permission to take a picture. When I showed him the picture I took, he said,"Mein Bruder." My brother.

Memories. Very poignant, simple row of empty shoes pointing out toward the Danube just below the House of Parliament. Remembering the Jews who lost their lives in the Holocaust. The pair of very small shoes belonging to a child no more than 5 years old brings tears to your eyes.
Do in daylight hours. We had read that this attraction was good at night. I disagree. It is poorly lit and we could not see the shoes adequately. i would recommend seeing this during the day.

Very moving. I would recommend that anyone visit here, only a 10 minute trip but very poignant.
Great photo opportunities against a backdrop of the Danube.

Silly photo op or place to reflect?. When we stopped by the shoes, there were hundreds of candles places among them -- perhaps for Holocaust memorial Day, or because of the impending World jewish Congress. It detracted from the stark reality of the display.Teenagers were laying on the ground taking various photos of the shoes and their friends; some just sitting and texting from the memorial.But if, like me, you lost family in a similar fashion, this memorial can be very moving. as one local described it to us, the hungarian Nazis were very efficient. No need to waste one bullet per person. Tie people into groups and shoot one or two, and push them into the water. everyone will be dead.Eventually.The Shoes are what you make of them. A silly group of metal objects or a deeply meaningful display of mankind's ability to destroy itself

Very Moving.. This is a very moving memorial, and is one not to miss. I would recommend that you read the story behind the memorial before you visit, as that will make the memorial that much more moving.
Poignant. Came upon this by chance strolling along the river, and was baffled by the line of what seemed to be old shoes left by the river, so had to learn more. A simple and poignant memorial.

Touching. The first time I went to Budapest, I didn't find those shoes, but this time I did. They are on Pest side of Budapest, near Margaret's bridge. It is a really touching sight, it reminds us of how war makes monsters of men, when many innocent people were shot into Danube. It is a very strong reminder of what should never happen again.

Moving, but meaning unclear. This is a very moving memorial, dating from 2005. We were there on an anniversary, so the 60 pairs of shoes were lit by memorial candles. It commemorates a dreadful incident where many Hungarian Jews were murdered by their Fascist compatriots during the winter of 1944-5. Unfortunately, this is not so clear.Let all remember that it wasn't just the Germans who participated in mass murder..

Budapest. This is one of those sad reminders of war and how awful it can be. The shoes are a memorial to people who were shot here and their bodies fell into the river. Sad, but still good to be reminded.

Read about the history before you go!. Really stunning attraction on the waterfront if you know what you are looking for and what it signifies. Lots of people walk by it without even knowing! Don't make that mistake.
worth visiting. asad memory but worth visiting - at the chain bridge turn right at the side of the Parliament and move towards the Parliament and there you will find it
Impressive. I found this place a taft and impressive symbol of world war. People were thrown in icy danube and let die in this way. Some shoes seem real.
Not to be missed. a poignant reminder of such a depressing event. Walking the Danube is a must so it's easy to find as well.

A sad reminder. We stumbled across this when walking near Parliament. It's only a small memorial but very poignant and certainly makes you think! The pictures shown are pretty much what you will see when there but certainly worth a look if you're nearby.

Lovely. Too bad there wasn't any signs to explain what the shoes were, but it was a lovely place to visit, with such strong history.
We even saw some kids shoes, which was sad =[

Never again.... My wife and I walked from our Viking Cruise ship to the site of the shoes...almost immediately we were unable to speak as we focused on the shoes and thought of those who were slaughtered at this point...the whole setting is one of beauty with some of the great buildings of Budapest visible in every direction...did they weep as they witnessed the unspeakable horror that took place on the beautiful Danube? We prayed that such evil will one day be only a remembrance and that all implements of war and torture will be beat into instruments of peace that better the human condition...idealism? Perhaps! Yet, still our prayed for reality.

incredibly evocative. This was a very moving experience and is definitely worth visiting. The other people there were quiet and respectful. It can be reached by walking north from Szechenyi bridge or south from Margit Hid along the waterfront. The approach form Margit Hid is longer and not suitable for anyone with mobility problems owing to the roadworks. As others have said, you can't access from parliament because of the roadworks.

A Moving Experience. Just seek out the shoes by the Danube and spend a few minutes in quiet reflection.Seems strange to describe it as an attraction but it is certainly a poignant reminder of man's inhumanity to man.
A Stark reminder of the past. This is a stark reminder and a lasting monument to the attrocities of the war, time for quiet reflection, candles placed at night

Memorial of Jewish massacre. We accidentally arrived at the Danube when a large demonstration of Roma citizens also came and the event was televised. We were given white or red roses to throw into the Danube in memory of those shot during the war by the Nazis.
Paid our respects. The sight is a grim reminder that humans have not really evolved all that much. The memorial is a silent tribute to suffering humans can inflect on one another.

Brilliant representation of the horrors of war. The artist's whole family was murdered during WWII. Looking at each pair of shoes makes you think about the individual women and children who were lost because of the cruelty of mankind. I typically do not go to "sad" memorials, but I had to see this one.
Stark Reminder. Well worth visiting and pausing to ponder what can only be described as one of the darker events in Hungarian History.
Shoes on the Danube. Very thought provoking and just to see many were the shoes of women and children really brings home the brutality of man against fellow man.

Great at Night. Located on the waterfront, between Chain Bridge and the Parliament.Memorial to the Jews killed by the Nazi's. They were lined up on the promenade, made to strip naked, then shot and their podie pushed into the Danube to be washed away. What remained on the promenade was their shoes, hence this piece of artwork. Bronze shoes of different sizes/styles, inc childrens shoes.Good to see in daylight, but at night candles are lit by each pair of shoes which makes it very moving.Be warned - major roadworks around Parliament (April '13). Don't get the metro to Parliament, but instead, walk along the waterfront from Chain Bridge / Marriott Hotel.
Very atmospheric. We came across these by accident, whilst walking along the river bank outside the Parliament building. Such a poignant reminder of human tragedy.
A must, for all people!. To constantly remind us of how cruel people can become and why a Holocaust must never happen again, anywhere in the world.

Please make the effort to visit.. This is not an easy place to find as not many locals could not even direct us to it. However it is right on the riverbank south of Parliament and below the no.2 tram stop. Due to road works and other such we had to climb a fence to get down or walk nth from chain bridge direction. No signs, no information, just shoes. So moving to think of the terror these poor people must have felt. Men, women and children just gone. Terrible sad and well worth a visit. Take a few moments to reflect on the lives of these lost souls.
Moving. Beautifully done monument, however the fact that the victims were Jewish was not mentioned. Our group had a member who told her mother's story at this location made it unforgettable
Very emotional. A beautifully made sculpture on the banks of the Danube, made to remember the plight of the Jews in Hungary, well worth a visit.

thought provoking without being depressing. it is quite sad to think about the murders of these people and seeing all the shoes is quite confronting but having said that it is a fitting reminder and says it all
Pause for thought. Very poignant, sitting in the sunshine looking at all those shoes and trying to imagine what it must have been like

Simplicity. The row of empty shoes along the Danube says it all. Men, women and children shot and thrown into the cold, fast moving Danube by the Hungarian Arrow Cross in 1944-1945. A strong reminder of the devastation of the Holocaust.

Moving Tribute to Hungarian Jews. We visited this in the late evening, so it was very atmospheric and moving. The bronze shoes were lined up just as if their owners had stepped out of them and jumped into the Danube.
Sad but uplifting.

I don't understand any negative reviews on this memorial!. This memorial is a beautiful tribute to the Jews who were so close to making it through the second world war, but were sadly marched to the Danube and killed by the Nazis. Not much information about it at the location itself, but it should definitely be read up on, as it's such a sad story, with a moving memorial.

impressive memorial. Very impressive to see this, and a good reminder to never let such atrocities happen again.Right now, difficult to get to from the north, as the houses of Parliament surroundings are being done up, and you have to either walk further south or risk crossing a very busy riverside road and step over guard rails.But a good photo opportunity in combo with the Danube nd lit buildings at dusk.

Very touching tribute. There is no description of this installation nearby so people who stumble on it may not know what it is, but thanks to trip advisor we knew what it was about and it was definitely very moving. It is a simple tribute to a lot of people who lost their lives in the city.

Makes you think once again-The world needs Peace!. It is a very touching experience,I should only tell that go there and feel it.I spent there half an hour looking the shoes and Danube....In the reviews it is mentioned that the place cannot be found easily actually after chain brigde just keep walking to the Margirit bridge(but just near the Duna because there are some construcation areas so that you cannot cross the road afterwards).You will see them just very close to Parlemet building.
Timely reminder. A very timely reminder of the attrociaties that took place on the banks of the Danube. There is not much to the location but the shoes say a lot.
Beautiful. Very poignant walking along here, and thinking back to what this memorial is all about. Really does make you think back to that awful time.

Makes you think. There are currently building works around the parliament building, but if you stick by the river, walking from parliament towrds the chain bridge can't miss it.
One of the smallest and apparently insignificant memorials, it make you think about the inhumanity suffered all those years ago.

Heart breaking memorial to a tragic time.... Such a simple, yet painfully poignant, reminder of a horrible time in Budapest. Historically, this has been a bit hard to navigate down to (the easiest thing is to drop down at the Chain Bridge and walk up towards Parliament). However, I think the new contruction will complete a water walk by August 2013.
In any event,

Very moving. The shoes on the Danube is worth seeing. A little difficult to get to but it is in walking distance. It is on the Pest side. It is a permanent reminder of what happened to the Jews when they were lined up and had to take off their shoes and then were shot down and fell into the Danube, making the river the 'river of blood'.

Sad place. Not really an attraction more of a memorial for what was a tragic time for the Hungarian Jews at the hands of the fascists.We only visited it after reading about in on trip advisor,and it was worthwhile as we spent 15 minutes remembering the victims .We did the city bus tour ,hop on hop off and cannot believe this was not mentioned on the tour.
A grim reminder.... There was some construction work going on, so we saw them only in passing. A grim reminder of a bad period in Human history.
Worth the walk. A tour guide told us about this tribute, very sad and a little disturbing but at the the Hungarian people have acknowledged this sad time.

Lesson to be learnt - for a better world, world peace. I watched about Shoes on the Danube in one of Lonely Planet series on telly few years ago. It somehow captured my interest, but then after that I totally forgot about it. Until I visited the National Museum, where I found a postcard with the image of the Shoes on it, and with the guidance from the shopkeeper, I made my way to the place by foot. It took me about 25 minutes or so from the museum to reach the place. The Shoes sculptures really move my heart. Spend few minutes there, enjoy the sceneric view of the Danube as well as Buda from Pest. Went there almost towards sunset, beautiful view!!

Well worth the time to see. Very small attraction on the river bank. There is no indication of where it is other than the shoes on the concrete so it would be hard to find unless you knew where to look for it. There is one plaque set into the concrete at one end of the memorial stating why the shoes are there and when it was created. I would have liked more the history but it is still worth the time to go and see it and spend some time reflecting on what happened there so it I's not allowed to happen again.
Shoes. I would like there to have been a plaque so i could have read about the history of the shoes as i didn't know about the history about them. The front of the river is a little disappointing.

Super easy way to find them. From Margaret bridge take Tram no. 2 that runs along the Danube. On your right will be the Parliament, just past it look over your shoulder and there they are!The construction work acts as a distraction but keep your eyes peeled, just as the tram goes around the curve (past the Parliament) you will spot them! We were able to catch a glimpse of them from the boat cruise as well as we cruised past the Parliament.So there is hope. I didn't think I would be able to cover it with a 4 yr old in tow. To my surprise, I could catch a glipmse the very first day and following day as well. It was a very moving moment!
Emotional experience. This was a very touching scene for me. I felt there must have been great fear and grief here surrounding these shoes and they express this well.

A Sobering Experience. We learned of the shoes on our Big Bus tour; otherwise I don't think we would have even known about it, as it wasn't in our guide books. It is quite poignant, with the bronze shoes of men, women, and one child poised on the edge of the river. This display is just down from the Parliement Building.The shoes represent those Jews that were made to stand along the river, take off their shoes, and were executed by the Hungarian Fascists by being shot, their bodies falling into the river and carried away. There are small rocks in some of the shoes that have been placed there in memory, as well as some small candles. It is very sad to think about the circumstances these people were in; it is a terrible example of the inhumanity to man during WWII, and shows the struggle the Hungarian Jews had during the war. Please be respectful if you visit, and know why the shoes are there. Some people that were there, I don't think knew about it's story, and were laughing and putting their feet alongside some of the shoes and taking photos; VERY disrespectful I thought. It is not a place for happiness and laughter and taking photos of your friends; it is a place for quiet introspection, almost like in a church, so treat it as such and show respect for those that so tragically lost their lives that terrible day.

A memory of the past for reflection. It is not always the big and most prominent memorials who makes the biggest impression. The abandoned shoes at the Danube riverside close to the Parlament reminds us of the Jews shot by Arrow Cross militiamen and taken away by the river in 1944 and 1945, after they had taken off their shoes.
Heart wrenching. very heartwrenching, made you think. Very cleverly done looked very real. Walk along river then you dont have to cross the busy road.

Great visual symbol of terrible event. I'd never heard of the Arrow Cross before I visited Budapest and now feel I know too much about them. They were the Hungarian nazis who shot Jews so that they fell into the not-so-blue Danube in Budapest. This is the poignant reminder - there is a stretch of iron shoes in pairs and a single one - I found myself looking in the water for it so well realised is the sculpture. Close to the Parliament building - visit it.
A Shameful Reminder. This is a heart wrenching reminder of man's cruelty to man. To add insult to this beautiful piece of work, others try to destroy it often.

Budapest2. Poignant memorial, simple and sad when you realise that people treated others so badly. Ties up with the disturbing exhibit in the Terror Museum where there is the sound of a splash every 10 seconds.

Touching. I only knew about this attraction and what it was about because of what I had read in guides and actively looked up myself.If you happen across it you wouldnt have any idea what it is about which is disappoint but if you visit the house of terror you will have a much clearer understanding.A touching tribute but in desperate need of a plaque.

very touching. Those are the shoes of the victims during Nazi occupation. Nazis made the people took off their shoes and shot them in the cold water of the Danube. It is very touching to see the little boots next to a pair of man and woman shoes, probably a baby victim gave his last breath along side of his parents :/
Less is more.. This was one of the simplest, yet most moving, memorials I have ever seen, honoring those Jewish Hungarians killed by facist Arrow Cross militia men during World War II.

Nothing special. I honor memory of people who perished in WW2, but from tourist point of view there isn't much to see... on the other hand it's right on your way if you take a walk from Parliament back to the chain bridge

Very Moving.. Such simple art, but it speaks volumes. It's very under oublicized, which is actually kind of nice because it would be incredibly difficult to get good photos if there were a ton of people around. Please do nt miss this! It's really very beautiful and impressive, and subtle. A very ingenious memorial as well, different than the usual statue or monument.

impossible to rate this memorial. after travelling to krakow and prague and seeing the affects of the holocaust it was important to see this memorial which has so much poignant history to budapest. to me it was moving, but could understand how people would find it a disappointment because it is so understated

Very moving. These are not publicised anywhere. We stumbled upon them by accident whilst walking along the Danube to the parliament building. They are a line of 100 shoes (cast in bronze?) of jews who had been lined up on the banks of the Danube, told to remove their shoes, then shot and pushed into the river. It is a very moving memorial to them and worth seeking out.

definitely something to see. This monument to those slain and thrown into the Danube is a must-see. Unfortunately it is difficult to get to; it is about 200 meters south of the Parliament building but there is a lot of construction near the building and can be tricky crossing the road. If you head straight for the river from St Stephen's Cathedral, go along the dirt path beside the river heading north and you will find them. What a poignant reminder of the tragedy -- it left us speechless.

Poignant. It was not easy to locate but it is on the Parliament (Pest) side of the river and just a little north. It was a cold day when we went and the thought of these people shot into the freezing cold river late at night was a reminder of how evil people can be.
Touching. It was a moving experience to see the replicas of the shoes that were worn by men, woman and children who were executed on the Danube River.

Shoes along the Danube. An immensely moving memorial in its starkness and simplicity, yet so evocative of the horrors visited upon the Jews on Hungary in 1944. A must see while visiting Budapest to glimpse some of the shadows of the complicated history lingering here. It is viscerally gripping and emotionally overwhelming.
Overwhelming. Very emotional since they're representing the murdered jews before, very nice to take pictures At dawn , be creful and watch out the riverside tip

A harrowing experience. This monument was constructed over 7 years ago. The day we visited, it was blowing rain and a work crew had partially blocked off the already-narrow walking path. We made the mistake of approaching from the Parliament side. As other reviewers have mentioned, there is no safe access - no bridge nor pedestrian crossing. Just take your life in your own hands, run across a busy roadway and jump over a metal barrier. A safer but longer approach is walk from the road near the Four Seasons Hotel Gresham Palace. It's about 400 metres from there.The metal shoes look so real, as if people had just removed them and left them there. We sat down on the bench nearby to take the whole scene in. Trying to imagine the victims and the horror of the event.I hope the city government improves the access to the monument. When visitors have to risk their own lives to pay tribute to the lives of others, it detracts from the importance and significance of the memorial.

A humble, touching memorial. Shoes on the Danube is a humble yet touching memorial to the Jews shot into the Danube. It's one of the few references to WWII and its Jewish victims that you'll find in Budapest, which tends to focus much more on the city's Soviet occupation. The memorial is small, but encourages you to spend time with and contemplate it. The shoes of children were particularly touching, as they remind you that no person was exempt from Nazi terror.

why is there no access to this site?. how can you get to this site without getting run over on the highway? There should be a bridge, or even a crossing. The nearest crossing is almost a kilometer away, and there is a high wall that seems to hide it from public view. It is such a perfect memorial to the almost 20,000 Jews who were shot on the banks of the Danube and pushed into the river. It shouldn't be hidden as if it hadn't happened!

A humbling experience. Its not signposted, but just in front of the parliament buildings. Its to honour the 400 jews shot into the Danube during the war. Its very moving and brought me to tears-take tissues with you.....

Very simple and beautiful memorial.. Very simple but beautiful memorial which is located just before the parliament on the danube promenade.Worth a visit as you can take in the great views and panorama as u do.
Very moving. Nearly missed it as its a very understated attraction. Very moving simple memorial to what man can do to other men.

Moving tribute to Jews thrown to their deaths in the icy Danube. This was a moving tribute to the Jews thrown to their deaths in the icy Danube, who were made to remove their shoes. Some of these shoes have been kept there. What I disliked was that there was no explanation for what actually happened, except for a plaque in Hebrew, plus it is awkward to get to as one has to go under barriers to have a look. There is also no mention of these shoes on directions to sights, and without Trip Advisor you wouldn't know they were there.
Take a tissue. This place was a little hard to find, but, when you see the shoes and understand what happened here, YOU WILL CRY.
Watch the traffic!. Very difficult to get to right on the river bank near to the Parliament but there is no pedestrian crossing and it's at a junction where roads meet.
Thought provoking. No song and dance, just calm and quiet. So simple yet so moving, not statues, monuments or plaques just shoes. Heartbraking.

A place to remember. It took a litle to find this place but when you arrive to this place a lot of ideas come to your head. How many people died in that place leaving his more valuable ítems on the Riverside: their shoes.

Very moving. Walk along the Danube toward the Parliament and you will see the "shoes" lined up at the edge of the river. It was sad and very moving to reflect upon the people who stood in those "shoes" not so very long ago and the horror of that time.

Poignant. Well worth a visit whilst in Budapest. You won't notice this monument until you reach it but essentially it's not too far away from the parliament. This memorial is simple but highly effective in remembering the individuals who lost their lives.
Thought provoking. Very simple, no elaboration and therefore so powerful. It makes you think of the depths humans can sink to persecute others - will we never learn.
VERY TOUCHED. Went there on a white smoggy day. Very touchy memorial that remembers the jews that were asked to leave their shoes before being shot and throw to the Danube.

Take time to honor the victims. Your heart will surely skip a beat - this statue leaves not much room for words.
The victims of the holocaust have an eternal perpetuation site at this point.
poignant. went for a walk along the river and found this memorial, it is an effective reminder of what occurred and keeps it in your memory
Feelings of great sadness. Very simple but very evocative and very imaginative, it produced feelings of great sadness, particularly if seen on a cold wet and windy day.

moving and worth a visits. This memorial is hard to reach form the parliament -- you have to climb over a street barrier. But the bronzed shoes of people who were killed -- round up and shot into the beautiful Danube-- by the Hungarians/Germans during WWII is among the most moving of memorials I've seen.

Take a minute to reflect. A place to meditate over the things we do to others. It feels so real that you can imagine the horror that took place.
A beautiful memorial to those that suffered the act of others and to remind us of what we should not become.
A moving tribute. the metal shoes on the banks of the Danube are a moving reminder of the shame and atrocities that the Hungarian Jews had to contend with in the last World War

other's titles are hauntingly accurate. My friend had told me about this site from his previous trips to Budapest. WE stumbled on it by accident on an overcast chilly morning in March as we wandered to the edge of the Danube during our explorations. Quiet, somber no touristy trappings. Probably best to visit during dreary weather since it is not meant as a pleasant experience.Plenty of people wandered by but an eriee silence hung over the place probably out of respect.simple memorial but if you go you will be surprised at how something so simple can be so moving.
Reminder of human nature. It is very touching and humbling standing among these shoes. A silent reminder of the cruelties people are capable of and the sad history.

Humbling. This is so humbling. So glad we were able to witness such a memorial. It will bring tears to your eyes just thinking about what they went through. A must see for Budapest! It is near the Parliament building but you need to get down to the waters edge as soon as you see an opening bc it's not easy getting across the road barriers.
Moving.. The place is very moving, something to make you think about the nazi terror. Definitely a must-see when there.

To symbolise a massacre of 60 Jews In the war. Came across the shoes accidentally whilst walking along the sea front on Pest side. 60 pairs of shoes in different 1940's style made in brass and secured to the promenade. Unfortunately no information explaining what and why they were there. We looked it up on iPad on return to hotel and they symbolise the massacre of Jews who were lined up on the seafront told to remove their shoes and shot so their bodies fell into the Danube so that the tide carried their bodies away.
Chilling reminder. Probably one of the most poignant memorials I have ever visited. A real reminder of how fortunate many of us are. No more needs be said.
Very moving. A very moving tribute to those whose lives were so cruelly taken from them. Everyone should visit this memorial. It's very realistic and beautiful.
Very moving. Found out about this on Trip Advisor - so glad we didn't miss it. Up from Chain Bridge walking toward Parliament.

Really moving. Shame that it isn't more well known.. Due to the ongoing roadworks in the area we found it a little tricky to access the memorial, but managed to find it by walking down the side of a road ramp. Surprisingly moving for such a simple memorial, a side of Budapest that you don't see anywhere else really and a part of war history that isnt as well publicised as others. Well worth visiting.

Very moving monument. This was very moving, tribute to those who were shot, after being told to remove their shoes (as the army needed shoes). Very sad time in history. there is construction as the road by it, we were able to pull over and hop over the guard rail to see it.

Moving. I saw this aspartame of a little walking circle I did: The Soviet Army monument/American Embassy/Reagan statue, Parliament, Shoes on the Danube, and St. Stephen's. It's right on the water (duh) just south of Parliament. I was the only one there. You'd never stumble on it; you have to know what you're looking for. It's a poignant memorial to a terrible example of man's inhumanity to man.
very touching. it was a very touching tribute - to see all the shoes and know they only represent so few of so many. Very near parliment buildings so you can visit two things together

A moving sight, easily overlooked. It was thanks to the Trip Adviser App we happened upon this place as it was in neither of the guide books we had taken with us. What a moving sight once the App had informed us of what we were looking at. A moving monument to the lost.

Simple, yet powerful. Extremly powerful memorial, yet so simply made. Reminding us about the horrors of the Hungarian fascists that lined up Jews on the bridges, shooting them and letting the Danube carry the corpes away. In spring 2013, it might be a bit difficult to find, due to construction work on the Danube side af the parliament. Go down the car ramp just before the parliament (having the Chain Bridge in your back).
Sad. Just give yourself some time to think and remember others. The main road to get to the shoes is a little dangerousness take care

Almost overwhelmingly poignant.. Almost as unbelievable as Auschwitz these empty shoes bear witness about man's inhumanity to man - not to mention women and little children. It takes a stony heart to stand amongst this extremely effective work of art that screams out silently at the horror and injustice of the past without shedding a reat. An absolute must see.
Moving. This is a memorial for the Jews who were shot between 1944 and 1945. The victims were lined up and shot into the Danube River. It is a very powerful homage for the victims of the Holocaust.
Thought Provoking. Simple but certainly makes you think about what happened here. Find it just by the parliament buildings. It's not signposted.

Shocking yet stunning memorial that shouldn't be missed. Shoes on the Danube is an excellent and very shocking memorial honouring the Jews killed during WW2. There is more info on wikipedia regarding the history of this memorial: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoes_on_the_Danube_PromenadeI would recommend a visit as it's a beautiful memorial and there is a lot of detail. The memorial can be found on the edge of the Danube near Steindl Imre Utca which is not far north from the Szechenyi bridge - you can actually take a tram and hop off and cross the road and wander down to the edge of the river. Plus it's free!

I had a tear in my eye. This is quite difficult to get access to, you have to cross a very busy road or take a lengthy walk to an appropriate crossing. If you need help walking or are slow on your feet it might be worth taking a taxi. I am not Jewish, I was born after WW2 and I know Budapest very well. But to me this is the most moving monument in this fine city to victims of the Holocaust. In this case it commemorates those who were slaughtered at the hands of the Arrow Cross (the Hungarian Fascist movement) towards the end of WW2. They simply lined the people up on the bridges, forced them to strip, shot them and let the Danube carry the bodies, dead and alive, away. The majority were Jewish women and children, the men having been conscripted to work as slaves to aid the Nazi war effort. The reason why they were not taken to the camps were because at the ending of the war there were no trains to transport them. Ironically after the war the Communists recruited many members of the Arrow Cross into their state security apparatus and other roles though some were prosecuted and executed for war crimes. I must admit, knowing the story beforehand, I was moved to tears when i saw the shoes.
Shoes on the Danube. A moving tribute to those who died at the hands of the Arrow Cross,walk back from Chain Bridge towards Parliament and you will find this monument
poignant. Bleak weather and works at the neighbouring Parliament building did not improve it, but worth a visit if nearby. Shame there were no obvious explanatory plaques.
Emotional & moving. A must see in Budapest! A very moving holocaust memorial site, and quite emotional at the thought of what happened there!

Very moving memorial. I really wanted to find this memorial and it wasn't easy! The work on the Parliament building made it hard to get down to the banks of the river safely. We had to dodge the traffic in the snow to get there. It was heart-wrenching to finally see the shoes, especially the tiny pair of children's boots. How can people be so cruel to fellow human beings? The way the shoes are perched on the edge of the riverbank casually made it all the more moving. Go see it ......and never forget what happened.
Very sad. We'd read about this so had to go and find it..... Very sad to see all the shoes at the side of the Danube, unbelievable to understand how cruel human beings can be to each other.

Amazingly simple but so powerful. A must to see in Budapest.. This piece of sculpture is not well advertised, but it should be seen by all. It is horrendous to think that Hungarians did this to their own Jewish people. The Arrowcross took their coats, jackets, scarves etc. and gave them to their own members to wear. They were then told to take their shoes off and lined up along the riverbank at this very spot, and shot. Men, women and children. All that was left from those shot and left to fall dead in the river was their shoes. This is a chilling reminder. This is a must to see when visiting Budapest. Just next to Parliament

Simple but moving. This sculpture was made to remind people of the Jews who were shot by the Arrowcross Militia. Before they were killed, they were asked to remove their shoes. To avoid having to bury them, they were shot by the Danube, their bodies allowed to float down the Danube. So simple but so sad to see the line of shoes.
A Simple yet and poignant monument. The shoes are so beautiful, as they are full of detail. We stumbled upon them by accident, but am so glad we did. Such a lovely monument for those who suffered.

touching. Simple but Touching tribute to all the Hungarian Jews who were brought to Danube's Promenade, and after being forced to take off their shoes, were shot to death by the Nazis and their bodies were thrown on the river.

HAVE TO VISIT THIS. We all have to visit this . I got the goosebumps from the shoes but it reminded me too , to all the people who found the death . So i will walk there again and will say a little prayer for them .

Very thought provoking. This memorial would be easy to miss unfortunately. We read about it online at TripAdvisor and made a special effort to find it.As other reviewers have said, it's along a scruffy path to a part of the bank if the danube not far from the parliament buildings. Not much information present when you're there so read up before hand if you are someone who likes more info when you're looking at something. All in all, if the weather's kind its a nice walk and worth making an effort. Be careful to approach it upstream from the 'Intercontinental Hotel' side of the bank as access to it from the otherside is restricted and involves crossing a major road with no pedestrian crossing.
Simple. Simple, Poignant and emotive. A must see. We had hoped to visit the Synagogue and Jewish Museum also but got there too late in the day

Worth a visit. This may only be shoes by the river but we made a special walk to see these as we had missed them the day before. Strangely they didn't feature in either of the guidebooks we had taken but it really puts the sad story into perspective when you stand next to them and see the children's shoes amongst the adults. Could have benefited from information near them to explain the background for those that don't know it.
Hauntingly beautiful. A lovely memorial to the Jewish people which would maybe have benefitted from having historical info just to put it into more perspective.

Seems to be easily missed!. These shoes are a holocaust memorial and are quite striking. They are on the pest river bank near Parliament. I would recommend a stop to see this memorial on a walk up to Parliament

Shoes on the danube a great way to remember the sad history. Great sight with chairs by the water to remember the people by. Had some fresh fruit and sat by the danube afterwards realising how lucky we were.

Easily Overlooked. With difficult access and scruffy path to view from this poignant and moving memorial could easily be missed. Make the effort and share a moment of reflection. Route from Parliament currently closed due to renovation work.

More to think about than to see.. When you stroll past the Danube, you'll come across these shoes. They make you think about what happened here. If you're totally not interested in (WW II) history, this small and simple memorial might not do too much to you. But... for most people a must-stop. Combine it with a Danube stroll.

Makes you think. To be honest i can see how some would just think "just a bunch of metal shoes" but if you get some background info before you go then it makes it so much more heart wrenching. If you go to the Great Central Synagogue first and take a tour then you can get some info there.

Haunting. Read up on the history first before you visit it will make for a more poignant experience. I feel my knowledge on WWII is ok but was unaware of this travisty. Visit the house of terror and the holocaust museum in conjunction with this and the true horror of what happened during these times will come to light. We visited in the snow which only added to the atmosphere. A must.
Good to visit if you go to Hollocaust Museum. On the River Danube, near to the Parliment building towards the chain bridge. Worth visiting if you are in the area.

Thought Provoking. We visited the site on a very snowy day, you could barely see the shoes but just being there and thinking quietly for a moment was moving.
