After previously visiting 2 concentration camps in Germany (Dacau and Neuengamme) I felt I should visit.There is no easy to get to the promenade from the Parliament, we had to dodge a few cars to get there as there is no crossing

Very harrowing. If you can go visit this art installation definitely do. You have to know the history behind it yourself but once you do it is incredibly moving. The tea lights inside the shoes were a lovely touch.

Touching. It is worth viewing this site if you come to Budapest. Literally ripped at my heart. It is a must and makes the mind think..... It's located right across from Parliament on the Danube river. There is not a cross walk that goes over to it so you may have to dodge some cars...That's how we did it. The shoes of the children grip at your heart.....So sad.
Poignant. We walked down the side of the Danube looking for these and they are just a short walk down from the Parliament. Such a lovely monument for what took place here. Very impressed

Breathtaking. This is a memorial honoring the Jews who were killed by Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. The victims were lined up and shot into the Danube River. They had to take their shoes off since shoes were valuable during that time. Can you imagine that? Takes my breath away... If you download the Trip Advisor City Guide, it is not difficult to find at all. The city guide will ping your location to show you how far away or close you are to your destination. This memorial is a must visit.
Very emotional place. It was one of the most emotional places we've visited in Budapest.Thinking about the past, and what happened there...

Heart Felt. Like every said before, the location for this spot is kind of difficult to find but its a MUST see. When my wife and I went to there was a lot of construction work happening around the Parliament Building which made access a little harder. But to make it easy, if you take the Tram 2 line to Parliament and walk south towards the river you wont miss it. Trust me, we did it in the dark.The site itself is heart felt, looking at the individual shoes and wondering if the people knew what was coming. The way the shoes are presented it looked as if nothing was changed, such as placement of shoes, shoes missing pairs, and then the sad one that made my wife cry; the shoes of a child next to some heels.
Sad but true. Incredibly touching, poignant and simple memorial. A must see for anyone visiting Budapest to pay their respects.
impressive and sad. impressive and sad to see those shoes and imagining the people they are meant to belong to... even little children shoes were there... :-(

Shoes on the Danube. These are a few minutes walk from Szechenyi Bridge along the promenade at the Pest side of the Danube.
Very emotional seeing these. Especially the small shoes of children. They are a memorial to the Jews who were brought to the Danube, they took their shoes off and were shot. Their bodies then floated away down the river !

Can't get the image out of my mind!. I visited this site in the quiet of the early morning on January 1st (New Year's Day). The streets were silent, and daylight had just occurred. There was a light fog and midst over Budapest that morning, and I was so profoundly moved by the imagery behind this memorial. I literally cried when I saw all these bodiless shoes on the bank. To see shoes of varying sizes, even down to what was obviously children's shoes next to their parents, it evoked so much emotion and sadness, I think I will be forever changed. What a thought-provoking site!

Jewish Shoe Sculpture. Very eerie and sad. Hungarian right wing militia in collabaration with the Nazis during WW2 shot and killed Jews at the river edge. This sculpture shows the shoes from the men women and children that were left at the edge

Touching. At first, people think that the shoes are real, and it is only until someone explains the story, or reads the plaque in the ground that the story comes to light. Definately need to have prior research knowledge for this site. I had a moment when I discovered a mother and child's shoes together. Very touching and moving.
Very moving. Go and have some quiet time. Read the article on wikipedia before visiting. Walk from the south of the city as it's a bit hard to get to from the Parliament.

Moving history come to life. This is not an easy attraction to find, but it is an art installation that tells a tragic part of Hungary's past. The 60 pairs of iron shoes honor the Jews who were killed by the facists during World War II.At that time, victims were marched to the banks of the Danube and ordered to take off their shoes. They were shot and their bodies fell into the river, leaving only their shoes behind.
Very moving. Very moving but could do with some signs explaining what happened and why and in English. Worth a visit.

So moving. This site commemorates the killing of Jews on the banks of the river. There is a row of very realistic cast metal shoes lined up along the promenade, all types and sizes including childrens. Very moving to see this and reflect on events at that time.

Strong feelings. It was such a strong experience to visit this monument. The feelings for this crime commited by Nazis are only sad. The monument describes this crime in a perfect way. It can be found across the street of the Parliament, on the Pest side of Danube. Mind the high traffic street.I suggest combining this monument with the Jewish quarter in order to have a complete view of Jewish tragedy in Hungary.
Moving story. Very moving display on the edge of the Danube. Very easy to access and worth the effort to go. You can take photos and the area will also give you some great shots overall the water.

Very Moving Memorial. Sad memorial that is worth seeing and remembering. It's just South of Parliament. As others have said, not sure why the city of Budapest makes it so hard to reach. You do have to cross a fast moving, crowded riverside road without a crosswalk. Then you most likely will have to hurdle a couple metal road barriers on each side before traffic descends upon you. There are no signs pointing you to the memorial. I really don't think the city of Budapest is trying to hide this memorial. I just think cities sometimes overlook landmarks and sites that they do not capitalize on with entrance fees, etc.
Must see. Every visitor should ensure this is on their tour list. It won't take long to visit, but it will stay with you. Very moving.
A sad reminder. Our longship cruise boat was parked right near these shoes. It was a sad reminder of the horror that occured in Budapest for the Jews in WWII.

A poignant memorial. Whilst on holiday in Budapest my boyfriend and I stopped by the Shoes on the Danube Promenade.This is a really moving memorial to honour the Jewish people that were victims of the Arrow Cross Party. If you have time in Budapest then spare some time to see this.It is worth going to the House of Terror prior to seeing the Shoes but not essential.Be careful when trying to get to the shoes as there is a really busy road next to the Promenade.
awesome. A very moving touch to remind today's population of the Holocaust years and their traumas; it was well worth the walk from the city centre totake in the atmosphere
Very impressive.. In all it's simplicity this monument is very impressive. More than other war memorials, it touches you deeply.

An important memorial to the Hungarian Jews who were killed in WW2. This memorial is powerful. Luckily for us, we brought here by our Jewish tour guide who explained the meaning behind the shoes. The story is sad and very thought provoking. I think there should a more detailed sign explaining the details behind the story of the shoes.... it's not enough to say that people were murdered during WW2. The information should have said that innocent Jews were murdered by Hungarian Nazis during WW2, but first asked to take off their shoes, were tied together and then pushed into the Danube to drown.... This is a part of Hungarian history that should not be ignored. It should be addressed to the future generations to make sure it never happens again.
The shoes were left by the jews.. It was interesting to see how the jews were mis-treated in the second world war. The shoes gave us many thoughts....

Sad, but great to see. When walking on the Danube Promenade you will pass the shoes. We did not understand what they were doing there initially, but the little plaque helped. It would be great if there was an information board at this site.

Artistic reminder invokes reflection of Jewish persecution.. The comments at this memorial, which is located along the banks of the Danube river near the Parliament buildings, do not mention that those killed by the Arrow Cross Facists were Jews. Do your homework before visiting this memorial so that you know what happened and then it will mean more to you. 64 pairs of iron shoes set to represent those shot and killed and thrown into the river. The tour at the Great Synagogue includes the museum and provides good information about the Jews persecution. A sad part of their history is that the Arrow Cross Party Facists were Hungarians who sympathised with the Third Reich and so you had Hungarians persecuting other Hungarians.

Simple monument but very powerful.. Simply done piece of art/monument, but very powerful. Visiting this first and then the Terror Museum really put in to perspective the horrors faced by the people of Budapest during rule by the Arrow Cross and then the Soviets.

Underwhelmed. Whilst I liked the idea of this memorial and thought it was done with sensitivity and style it was nonetheless a bit underwhelming.It could be to do with the positively freezing wind blowing off the Danube that morning which made it most unpleasant to get to.Worth a detour if you are visiting Parliament, but I wouldnt make a special journey

A place to reflect. We fell upon this without knowing the symbolism behind them (we could guess, but didnt know the exact details)…….., maybe a plaque or something to advise tourists? However, later in the day whilst on a Communism tour, we asked the guide who went on to explain the full meaning of these shoes.......a very thought provoking remembrance to an era i hope we never return to. A place to sit, shopw respect and reflect on the past of the city.
Interesting and provocative. Subtle but powerful reminder of man's inhumanity. Easy access with places to sit and reflect. nothing commercial to distract from the moment.

Terror reminder. Shoes on Danube are reminder of terrors of II world war. You can find this monument in Pest, across the Parlament, on river bank.All the shoes are replica of original ones which belonged to victims who were killed and thrown in river.
Stop and think!. A place to stop. Think,. and then relect on mans inhumanity to man, and hope that this will not happen again, but regretfully, we do not learn from our past.

A beautiful and very sad memorial. A short walk from the parliament along the Danube, the iron shoes serve as a memorial to those executed here, directly referencing orders to the victims to take their valuable footwear off first.

Sobering. This is a profoundly simple and incredibly powerful monument to the people killed there. It is worth visiting to understand the history and the fact that women and children were killed along side men.

Poignant. I had been told this was a must see and can agree it was. The shoes are a haunting reminder of what happended there to 60 people, men women and children in world war II. It's quite easy to find. Just 100 yards or so, right, from the Chain Bridge on Pest side.

Solemn Memorial. Just a walk on the Danube between the Chain Bridge and Parliament. There isn't really anything that points it out. I like that about it though. It's simple and haunting and needs really no explanation.

60 pairs of shoes directly by the water, thrillingly realistic. Particular monument, which was inspired by a traumatic event. The shoes are thrillingly realistic. 60 pairs of shoes directly by the water, 60 people were executed here in the Second World War, at the pictoresque bank of the Danube... Between the Kossuth and the Roosevelt Square, accessible by tram 2.
Poignant. ...like all the statuary in Budapest, discovering these then going off and finding out about the story behind them was magical.

Simple memorial but impactful. This memorial was one of the most impactful ones I have encountered in my life. Seeing the shoes on the floor, from adult shoes to children's shoes, was impactful, it made you think of what happened here. It is so important to read about these memorials before visiting them or at least read them as you are there. IMPORTANT ON HOW TO CROSS: this is a busy street. Be careful and before you cross, look for the opening of the rail so when you cross the street you don't have to fend for you life. This is key, if you can do this it is an easy cross. We took the stairs that are in front of the Poet's statue and we went right. There is a sign that says "Tourists stop". If you are not savvy crossing the street, then do stop, if you are careful then just remember: look for the opening, don't just cross the street!

Very moving and worth the time to see it. We were on a river cruise and docked just past this monument, so it was easy to access. It was perhaps the most moving holocaust memorial I have seen. The shoes look as if someone literally stepped out of them and into the icy river. Chilling.

Worth a look if you are nearby. The shoes are a very simple monument and worth seeing if you are in the area. They are a few minutes walk from Parliament and so if visiting there, it is worth going over to see the shoes and lovely views of the river.
Sad Reality. The view is beautiful, the history is sad. Worth seeing to take artistic photos of the shoes with the river.
Great memorial. A beautiful sculpture of a disgusting act of war. Worth seeing, and definitely makes you appreciate all we have now.

very moving..... It's a 'simple monument' but very moving. It won't brighten up your day (close to tears while visiting) but is really worth visiting. Also visit The house of terror in order to understand more of the history of this city.
Moving. We found this a very moving memorial to those who were killed during WW2.Very simple momument but conveys the powerful message of what occurred.
Nice memorial. Interesting and worth a visit, but if you are in a hurry you may want to skip.It's a bit far from the mains attractions and it's something quick to see and take some pictures..

..... That's something which does not need feedback andcomments...I completely disregards with negative feedback on it: I've been early in the afternoon, it was not busy at all (nobody) and the way is not dangerous if you wall the pedestrian walk under the main bridge. Regarding the indication, yes, it's true, you have to find by yourself but it is just beyond the main bridge on Danube so it does not need any signal.

Worth finding. I learned about this spot from my mom while on the vacation as she wanted to see a picture. I am glad I took the time to track it down. Best to go early or later in day when lots of people are not around so you can get a good photo.

The very sad place. The idea is genius to make a monument in memory of Jewish who were shoot here on a bank of Danube. By looking at these shoes: old fashion, different styles,man's, women's children's you suddenly realized why the shoes were used to memorize these people. Because nothing was left .

Moving memorial with a view!. We sought out this memorial and weren't disappointed. Easy to get to from metro and located on the Danube only one block from the Parliament building. View on map before you go because there are no signs. Make a stop here if you go to the Parliament. Great view of Buda and the chain bridge from this location! Use caution with children as there are no guard rails to separate from the embankment from the river.
Time to remember. Time to reflect on the past, very moving. Not for those with walking difficulties as you need to negotiate the road

Poigniant Memorial. This is a very small and unobtrusive piece of sculpture which is tucked away on a quiet, not easily accessible part of the Danube's bank. However, this gives it a certain eerie quality that brings through the tragic meaning. Its not something to brighten up your day but it is worth seeing to just remind you of the city's troubled past.

very moving. It can be difficult to find. We had been to Parliment building walked round the front of it and down the steps there is a very busy road to cross but the drivers stopped for us. Turn left and keep walking along the water frront it not very far. It is a very moving thing to think of all those people and their children.
touching place. it's hard to locate - it's located on the northern side of the Parlament (the easiest way to arrive is by tram no. 2)
Moving memorial. This small sculpture honors the jews killed in WWII. Worth the walk along the beautiful Danube. Quite moving and in a lovely location.
Strong and exciting. It's very hard to get there (having to cross the main road just in the middle, no signage directing to the place, no signage explaining wjat it is all about next to the place)

Poignant.. This 'simple' memorial is heart wrenching. Numbers such as 250 thousand, 600 thousand, and six million lose something in their enormity. But to see a sculpture of an untidy row of real shoes representing real people on the actual spot where they were cold-bloodily murdered and fell into the Danube puts you at the actual scene at the time of the crime. Not just a memorial- a site where you become witness to the horrific history of inhumanity.
startling. When you see these shoes and realize what it represents it can be very emotional.Leaving these shoes as a lasting memory is something one cannot forget.

A moving sight, especially if you learn about the history by visiting the Holocaust Museum. It is eerie to see shoes along the Danube, representing those killed by the fascists before the end of WWII, as if their owners had only just been massacred and that was all that is left of them. This fitting, simple and effective, monument ensures that their memories live on,
Impressive. Really liked the artists impression of the tragedy that took place here. Being here was a poignant experience.

So eerie. This was a most moving monument. We have so much to be thankful for in the U.K that we were spared the excesses that others suffered in the last century. The child's shoes will make you weep.

The shoes do not tell the whole story.... This is a memorial site which deserves more story and historical context. It is a wonderfully illustrative piece of art, but they avoided the simple act of declaring the men who killed people here what they were: antisemitic fascists. Bravo tot he artist, but the story needs more telling.
Humbling. Walking along the Danube you suddenly come across this humbling, profound memorial. So elegantly and simply done, yet so meaningful.
An emotionally moving monument. Truly a special piece of art which translates simply a powerful story. Close to tears whilst viewing this. A mist see to undertand the history of the city.
Incredibly moving. This was difficult to locate, but walking the banks of the Danube made it worth the trip. This is an unforgettable displya

Shoes on the Danube. I agree with some before that it is in fact hard to access this installation unless you have advance warning of precise location. Having learned it was near the Parliament building we approached from that end and it is very dangerous. The fast, busy road across to it and the small barrier to climb do make it the wrong way to access it. If visiting after dark, as we were, even more so as English speaking policemen and others at the Parliament building amazingly did not know what we were talking about and we had to find it on our own. The only safe way is to walk up from the Chain Bridge and even then watch out for uneven ground at dusk and later - 2 of our party tripped! Once there the sculpture is moving and does make you think about the inhumanity of it all and how anyone could carry out such monstrous acts even under orders. It is a fitting and moving tribute to those unfortunate victims.
Poignant. Sad - but a piece of history that should not be forgotten. It is worth walking down by the river, to pay your respects to those who lost their lives in such a terrible way

A bit difficult to get to. Quite moving, but we did not find it easy to get to and from. There were flowers laid out which brought it home that it is a memorial. They day we visited was very cold and took a long walk along the bank to get to them, but was worth a visit.

Don't miss!. Other reviewers have said it was difficult to get to this memorial. It actually is easy to get there: just go to the Pest side of the Chain bridge and walk upriver along the Danube. There is a fence blocking pedestrian access just beyond the memorial so you can't walk any farther. We followed directions from other reviewers and crossed the Chain bridge & then had to cross back.This is an important memorial. It keeps alive the history of the evil done to the Jews by the Nazis. Unfortunately, the signs explaining the shoes are no longer there. Jews were told to take off their shoes, then they were shot and their bodies fell into the Danube.
Haunting. Something we felt we had to do, very moving, shame that the hungarian government have no plaque acknowledging their part in the murder of these holocaust victims

Nice, but far out.. It was a lovely memorial, but it was hard to get to because there were constructions going on. This meant crossing vicariously a busy national speedway road! But there were good views and if coming from parliament, its worth a detour as its so close! But it would be nice if there was more information leading to the shoes and more information about them.
Well worth a visit. A very moving place in view of what happened here. A little difficult to get to if you are coming from the Parliament building.

A must see!. It was incredibly moving to see the "shoes" on the Danube Promenade. The Shoes on the Danube is a memorial to the Budapest Jews who were shot by Arrow Cross militiamen between 1944 and 1945. We had heard about it and my husband really wanted to view this - and when we saw it we were just amazed... the memorial contains 60 pairs of iron shoes, forming a row along the Danube.
Jewish Memorial. Would not have found had I not previously researched Budapest. Very surreal to see the brass shoes along the Danube and realize what took place there.
It is worth going there.. This is a sad story, but it is importnt that you go and see it, and stop for a while. It is very touching, and makes you think. It is worth going there.
Emotive. A simple statement is made with this emotive installation. I cant really find words that do this subject justice.

Very poignant experience. Perhaps 'liked' is not really a very good description of how I felt when I saw this very sad reminder of innocent people who lost their lives at the whim of others. May this monument long be a reminder of what 'man can do to man'!!
Holocaust. This was very sad - we saw the shoes from the river ride and then went to see them after our ride. It was a very poignant moment.
poignant reminder. amidst the beauty of the buildings there has been tragedy and this touching tribute highlights that fact. candles and flowers adorned the shoes when we were there
Very moving. A very thought provoking experience, it's definitley worth reading up on the background to this memorial before you visit.
Thought Provoking. Hard to describe this as an attraction,However it is something not to be missed in Budapest.and stand in quiet reflection

Modest but moving memorial. Thanks to reviews in Tripadvisor we visited Shoes on the Danube Promenade and found it easily. We walked along the waterfront from the Liberty bridge all the way passed the Chain bridge (it was quite a walk and the weather was windy and chilly) but we're glad we found it. Those sixty pairs of empty shoes spoke volumes. Kudos to the two artists (one who sadly died just last month) for creating this small, modest but very moving tribute to the thousands of victims who were cruelly murdered during the last few months of World War Two.
Powerful display - a must see. This is one of most touching displays I have come across in my travels. The shoes are a potent reminder of the atrocities committed against the Hungarians by the Nazis.

Very moving. I admit my ignorance of modern history, it is not something I know much about or have ever had much interest in. But even for me this was a very moving memorial to the suffering many people have felt and the brutality of humanity. This is not a tourist attraction to be entertained by so I am confused by some of the negative reviews on here. It is a reminder to us all that we live in a fortunate era of peace for most of us. A truly emotional and somber experience.
Profound. This sculpture of a row of shoes along the bank of the Danube captures the horror of death as the Nazi's carried out plans to exterminate millions.

Powerful. This is a very powerful reminder of the atrocities that occurred during the second world war. A side note - this is a difficult place to find as there is little to no information about it and even more difficult to get to safely if approaching from the parliament.

Moving Memorial. This memorial certainly makes you think about the people that stood there years ago, defaintely a very moving place to be. However wasn't that easy to find so if you would like to visit this memorial you should go to the Chain Bridge on the Buda side and walk to your right along the river bank towards the Parliment building and you will find the shoes on the waters edge.
Off the beaten track but worthwhile. A bit of a walk but so worthwhile because you don't see this sort of reminder very often. Can compliment a leisurely walk along the danube.

A bit of a disappointment. After reading good reviews I made sure we sought this out, but was pretty disappointed. There was no sign or information about it, and an incredibly busy / dangerous road which we had to walk for ages to the crossing to get over to the bank. A nice memorial but it didn't leave any impression despite the meaning behind it being so important. Wouldn't have minded giving it a miss altogether.

Memorial - please show respect. This is a holocaust memorial depicted by adult and childrens shoes left by the Danube. There were no notices but the candles placed by the shoes should have easily indicated the significance of the place. Most people were showing respect, but I noticed one man toss a candle out of his way for a better photo, then he and his girlfriend posed for silly shots in front of the memorial. Although I have no personal link to the shrine, I felt very offended.As another reviewer noted, there is no easy access to this site from the Parliament. We walked along the road and took a chance to run across the highway as there were no crossings. Coming back, with the build up of rush hour traffic, we had to walk back to the Chain Bridge to find a way back.
Stroll down the river from your cruise ship. and take in this moving sight - bronze shoes representing the dozens of Jews who were thrown into the Danube River at this sight.
Very sad. A moving memorial to those who perished in the holocaust, we saw it from the boat trip but didn't have time to revisit it.
Must not be forgotten. One of those very touching, emotional memorials of the holocaust tragedy. Great idea how to express the emptiness after the devilish actions in WWII.

Past is alive in this place. If you hear about the story of the Jews that were there and see these shoes, you will understand that sometimes past seems to be alive. It's worth visiting and taking some photos, because it's a part of the city's history.

A real tear jerker. This was a 'must see' though very upsetting place to visit. Having read all about the history behind the significance of the shoes it made one realise how badly treated the Jews were. What a cruel world we live in.

very moving. There is no easy access to this site from the Parliament as there is a no pedestrian access fence and construction happening along the river bank. You need to walk along a road and then take your life in your hands to cross the road and there's no crosswalk. Or you can approach the site from the bridge and walk toward Parliament along the river.
A Powerful Moment. It is worth the long walk. I really was touched to realized this is where innocent people were shot and fell into the Danube. It is a sad legacy to be sure.

A moving tribute. This sight is very poignant, striking in its simplicity and a very touching memorial. We visited the sight both in the daytime and at night, when lots of the candles were lit, which added to the sad setting. It is not difficult to find - it is almost directly in front of the Parliament Building - but you do need to take care in crossing a very busy road junction, with no obvious pedestrian crossing on view. We did not see any notices in English at the sight, but if you have done your homework in advance, you will understand completely what the memorial represent.

Very sad testament.. This site can be viewed on the edge of the Danube just a little bit removed from the Parliament building. Can be seen when driving by if you can not stop for a clear look. Such a sad vision of mostly women and children' shoes left behind when shot and thrown into the river.

Such a sad sight!. Very difficult to put into words the feeling of seeing the shoes on the Danube promenade.I fell into silence, and felt lots of pain. Adult and childrens shoes left by the river bank and left just as they were forced into the Danube to die. Very moving, so SAD, What a cruel world.
Moving. This was our last stop on Sunday afternoon. It brings home the attrocities of war and how inhumane we can be.

Very moving. Easy to find - walk along the banks of the Danube towards the Parliament Building. Cast iron shoes, replicas of the shoes left when local Jewish men, women and children were taken to the banks of the Danube by fascist Arrow Cross Militiamen in 1944/45, told to remove their shoes and shot in the back so that their bodies would fall in to the river.Take a candle to light, or a flower, and tissues - it is very emotional.
Thought provoking. I came across this simple memorial by chance, I instantly knew what it commemorated without any sign or guide book. Spend a few silent moments there with your thoughts.

Simple but very touching. This memorial is not easy to get if you come from the Pest side like the Parliament Building. You have to walk a lot to be able to cross to the Danube river side and walk everything back to be able to see it. The view along the way and the Memorial are worth the walking though! The Memorial is so simple and yet very touching! A good point of our trip to think about all the bad things that were done in the past...I could see that even today people stop-by and leave fresh flowers, candles and many more things to honor those that lost their life in such a tragic way.A must see and think!
Incredibly moving. The simplicity of this memorial lets the harrowing story sneak up on you and leaves you emotionally devastated

very moving. took a while to find! Its near the parliment buildings across a really busy road(run!)We went just after memorial day so there were lots of wreaths and candles very sad walking/looking at them. I wish there had been some information about them or some directions however guess that is on purpose as at the time anyone passing after the event may not have known why the shoes were there either. Either way its a very eiry place but worth it!

Challenging symbolism through art. To see cast bronze examples of the shoes left by people as they prepared to be shot and thrown off the banks of the Danube River, brought home the terror of world war two.
Human life is precious. Very moving reminder. Stark in it's simplicity. We must all learn to respect each others differences. War is hell Kindness and respect is a touch of heaven.

Stark reminder of city's history. This is not the easiest to get to (across busy road) but is a good point to reflect on the city's past. There isn't anywhere to sit and take it all in, and like many things in Budapest there isn't an English translation of information about the shoes, but it is still a striking sight within this beautiful city
Simple but very poignant.. Sometimes the simplest things can have the deepest impact. Very poignant reminder of Europes saddest time and the shocking horrors that humans can inflict on one another.
wow so sad but interesting. not much to see here but represents so much. worth stopping for a moment of reflection of how the past was so brutal and how humans can be so inhumane

Simple and elegant. A moving tribute to an awful time. The saying less is more has never been so true about this. There isn't a huge plaque telling you about everything that happened, it isn't an area bustling with tourists, just a simple memorial, that makes you think about life as we have it today.
Certainly a place to see and ponder.
Very sobering, but wonderful.. Neat stop along the Danube. Difficult, but important to explain to my 5 & 8 year old. Would recommend to all.
Creative memorial. My favourity memorial in Budapest bearing testimony to the members of Budapest's Jewish community who were brutally shot dead into the Danube. Definitely worth a visit.
Saw it from no, 2 tram. This tram rides the banks of the danube from the parliament to central market, passing many sights along the way. Good to save walking!
Unique. Saw this briefly from our tour bus during a short city tour.What a unique,effective and poweful display seeing hundreds of pairs of shoes!

Left an impression.. While this memorial may seem small it left a huge impression on me. It is the most memorable part of my trip. While wondering among the beauty that is Budapest it is easy to forget some of it's dark past. The simplicity of the shoes left behind still haunts me.
a good reminder of great tragic. seeing little chid's shoes canmake you choke on the inside... convenient walk from the parliament. Should not miss it, quite a landmark.

Sombre experience. This is something that you have to go and see. OK, it' just some shoes on the side of the bank of the Danube but the meaning behind this monument speaks volumes. It was very moving and if you tie this in with a visit to the Holocaust Memorial Centre and it will give you some idea of what atrocities occurred during the 2nd world war.

Shoes on the Danube. This was a very moving exhibit. However, it was extremely difficult to get to. It was necessary to walk along a highway and cut across it to reach the exhibit. It is definitely worth seeing.

Without words. Powerful, disturbing message, emotion and a heartbreaking pain.A simple idea, but neither was supposed to be something else.All the flowers in the world, all the candles and all our tears.We will NEVER FORGET what happened those years and WON'T FORGIVE.

Great addition to a trip to Budapest. This is worth a viewing when you go to Budapest. It is not marked on all maps but is relatively easy to find once you realise that it is on Pest side really close to Parliament. There is a busy road to cross to get to it. Once you understand the history behind the shoes memorial, it makes the experience of viewing them worthwhile. Definitely recommend a trip if you have some time!

Look and weep.. If you don't have time to see the Shoes on the Danube Promenade then your priorities are out of whack. Shoes of all sizes, from childrens shoes to adults shoes and boots. Sit and ponder for a long time. Take your pictures. Imagine the piles of clothes, the humiliation, terror, gun shots and the splashes. Evil reigned for a period of time but thank God in Heaven that that chapter came to a close. And thank God that He is just and He has appointed a day of judgment from which no one will escape. To see the Shoes is not a fun or pleasurable experience but it is life changing. And to think I know people who knew people who were victims of such arrogance and evil.

It is not an attraction, it is a memorial. Understand the story of those that lost their lives at this spot on the danube. It is not an attraction to be seen. It is a memorial to be understood, visited, and respected so that we may never forget the loss of life for such reasons.
well worth a visit..... certainly well worth taking a stroll just infront of the parliament building, very poignant to see...

A very moving experience. A very poignant reminder of the terrible things human beings can do to other human beings. Created to remember the jews who were killed by fascists during WW2, the shoes remind us that the victims - men, women and children - were forced to take theirs off before being lined up by the river's edge and shot into it.Because the day we visited was grey, cold and rainy, and because some of the shoes had tea lights flickering inside them, and because it was only a few metres away from Budapest's magnificent Parliament building, it made it all the more sad.A very moving experience

A very moving experience. A very poignant reminder of the terrible things human beings can do to other human beings. Created to remember the jews who were killed by fascists during WW2, the shoes remind us that the victims - men, women and children - were forced to take theirs off before being lined up by the river's edge and shot into it.Because the day we visited was grey, cold and rainy, and because some of the shoes had tea lights flickering inside them, and because it was only a few metres away from Budapest's magnificent Parliament building, it made it all the more sad.A very moving experience

Poignant. I had read about this sculpture and wanted to see it for myself so made a quick detour on our way home. I am really glad I did it at the end of our stay. We did visit the great synagogue but not the museum of terror or the Holocaust Memorial Center (kids too young) so this was something they could see, without horror images they don't have the maturity to deal with.

Easy to miss. This memorial is next to the Danube near the parliament but you should walk down to it from the chain bridge since the way from the parliament side is blocked probably due to security reasons.

Understated Holocaust Memorial. Even Tripadvisor doesn't know what to call it. It is a Holocaust Memorial and is by the river near the Parliament building on the Pest side (between Chain Bridge and Margaret Bridge). No signposts, no wordy explanations, just shoes and a plaque with Yiddish writing on it. The fools who give this 2 out of 5 score 2 out of 5 themselves for not joining the dots and knowing the background. This is challenging art. How could it be otherwise? If you need the facts go to the Terror House.

Nice memorial. Is a very touchy and sentimental memorial if you know the history not only of that particular event but the whole story of the Hungarian Holocaust – different than in most of the Europe.

Shocking Sadness and Truth.. To think of innocent people, including children, shot and thrown into the Danube... is testimony to man's inhumanity to man.Seeing those shoes frozen in time tears at your heart.
worth a visit. Nice memorial. North of the Chain Bridge by the Danube on the Pest side. Crossing the main road was dangerous!
shoes on the Danube. heartbreaking to see the shoes. A place to remember what happened to so many men. hopefull this never happens again

What a shame. A very moving memorial is poorly labeled and very hard to get to. You have to cross a very dangerous high speed highway with no traffic lights, overpasses, etc. It is almost like the Hungarians don't want you to know about this event and the memorial.
Shoes on the Danube. Sit down on the huge stone seat and think of what happened here. The baby shoes were very thought provoking.

Very moving. This is right by the Parliament on the edge of the Danube. It has a plaque in English and Hungarian on the ground. We went when it was around sunset, so we got a mixture of people reverently looking at the shoes and taking pictures, and Lovers coming to kiss as it's near the Danube and seems romantic. We also went on a weekday so we were also right by the evening traffic and the headlights from that.

empty shoes. Looking at the empty shoes of the Jews who were shot on the banks of the Danube so their executioners would not have to go through the trouble of burying them is very gripping, no matter how many times you take the time to look at them.
moving. Difficult to find as not signposted by worth persisting - very moving. Wish there had been a plaque with more information about it.

The most poignant memory of Budapest.. This memorial should be on the list of main things to see in Budapest. Of all the other historical buildings, museums, castle etc, this simple memorial was the most poignant. It is not advertised anywhere, there is no memorial plaque to explain why these shoes are along the bank, nothing. I thought that was odd. I had read about it before we went so knew where to look. It is on the Pest side of the river, between the Chain Bridge and the Parliament Building, but beware of the busy road.

very moving place to visit. Jewish monument with a huge impact. One of the places where you can literally touch history.One thing I found very disrespectful is that there are tourists who seat themselves between the shoes (IN the monument) to eat their lunch and take pictures. Incredible appalling.
Not to be missed. Situated just near the Parliament building on the banks of the Danube this is definitely not to be missed. It's a very poignant reminder of Budapest's past
Chilling. This is a simple, stark, chilling reminder of mans inhumanity to their fellow man. If one doesn't learn from history, one is destined to repeat it.

Take the path closest to the water to reach this. This was harder to find than I thought - I walked on the road close to the water but then had to cross a busy street to get to the shoes. Read about it before you go- there's a plaque that describes it, but I didn't see it when I was there.
Poignant. Of all the memorials to the holocaust that we saw in a three week trip to Germany and Eastern Europe this was the simplest and yet had the most impact.
Heart-wrenching. The shoes are a Holocaust memorial to those who were shot and dumped into the Danube. Can anything describe the cruelty more poignantly?
Very moving. Very moving site, just be careful crossing the road. They really need some kind of crosswalk here and it's difficult to cross this busy road.
Strong message. Nice to see, delivering a strong message and gives you to think. A very sad setting if you know the story behind.
Simple & Moving. A very simple memorial which invoked feelings of sadness. What can anyone say about this horrible period in history?
Impressive. When you walk along the Danube towards the Chainbridge, you comne across this monument. Very impressive.

The memorial shoes for grief. It is located on the Pest side of the Danube Promenade in line with where Zoltan Street would meet the Danube if it continued that far, about 300 metres (980 ft) south of the Hungarian Parliament and near the Hungarian Academy of Sciences.The Shoes on the Danube Promenade is a memorial created by Gyula Pauer and Can Togay on the bank of the Danube River in Budapest. It honors the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. It represents their shoes left behind on the bank.

Well worth seeing. We saw this after visiting the House of Terror and the Jewish Museum. I recommend doing it this was so that you feel the full impact of this monument as it is intended. Only problem is accessing the site since you have to walk up river from the Chain Bridge towards Parliament, rather than cross the horrendously busy road right next to it.
Good thing to photograph. The Shoes on the promenade are there to make you remember the deaths caused by the nazis on the jews during the 2nd world war.Thought provoking.

Such a poignant memorial!!. Personally I fail to see how you cannot be moved by this. It is a memorial to the Jewish that were shot into the Danube and shows shoes for men, women and children. To me this is a simple but incredibly powerful reminder of the atrocities that happened here and a very visual message that there was no mercy regardless of age or gender. I did find this difficult to get to as there is a very busy road in front of it but if you walk down from Parliament towards Chain Bridge you'll come across some steps which take you to an underground. You'll then need to walk back on yourself along the Danube. It was well worth the trouble though!

Not easy to find or easily accessible but worth going to. You will need to map out where the shoes are. We did not stumble upon them like we had thought in our 2 days of walking around the city and along the Danube. We came from the Parliament side and had to traverse along a small sidewalk and cross a few lanes of cross traffic. Luckily in Budapest, drivers are friendly and stop for pedestrians (for the most part). Once you arrive at the shoes, remember that they represent a melancholy event in which Jews were shot and pushed into the Danube...sometimes a few people tied together to save on bullets. It is such a sad history. We saw a couple goofs taking silly pictures smiling and laughing standing in the shoes. It's not necessarily a happy uplifting experience visiting the shoes but maybe these people didn't know the history behind the memorial.

Tribute to the Jewish people murdered. This tribute to the Jewish people murdered on the Danube is powerful. It's a row of shoes glued to the edge of the banks. This 'monument' to a very sad/tragic time in Budapest history is one of the best and most moving tributes to the history of the Jewish citizens of Budapest. The Arrow Cross party were basically Hungary's Nazi party, and sent thousands of people to their deaths or Auschwitz. This memorial remembers those who were ordered to take off their shoes on the river bank before being shot, men women and children. The shoes are so detailed and skillfully made, they look so real. From Parliament, go to the river and work your way South. Be careful crossing the road.

Well worth a look!. A very thought provoking art installation on the banks of the Danube not far from Parliament. A few hundred 1940s shoes cast in metal placed on the edge of the promenade to act as a reminder to the people shot by the Nazis on the banks of the Danube. Took a little while to find but was more than worth the walk!

A time to reflect!. This very simple but unique monument sit just along from parliament right on the edge of the Danube Promenade. My advise is to stroll along and take time to sit on the little wall and think about the horrific events that happened here. The realisation of the terror those men women and children must have gone through as they removed there shoes so they could be shot can be overwhelming, but I think it is important that we take the time to remember these events as it is a vital part of history.Truly a good way to spend a little time reflecting!

Heart grabbing. Sixty pair of iron shoes - here a woman's heels, there a man's work boots and a child's school shoes - line a short, curving walk along the banks of the Danube, resting in quiet reminder. Shoes on the Danube - created in 2005 - is a monument to victims of the Holocaust and of a time when the world should have shouted.

Interesting. I wish there was more information around the feature. I heard about it from TripAdvisor and took a photo but didn't fully understand what I was looking at until I came back and read a little more about it. At that point it becomes much more moving. It is a nice memorial.

A place to give some reflection. I am glad I walked along the riverbank to find this (between the Marriott hotel and the Parliament buildings right at the riverbank). It was a moving experience to see the shoes and I had read on TA what it was about. As some say, not much is there but that is not the point. It is a memorial so to speak, not a tourist attraction. I felt there should have been a bit more information at the site for those passing by and a few benches.

Sobering reminder. Seeing these shoes and hearing the history of cities like Prague and Budapest you appreciate what the Jews went through under the Nazis and then later to have tragedy repeated with the Soviets.
Very moving... Very sad to see these shoes, some tiny little ones as well. Glad we went to see this memorial..bring some tissues:(

a moving tribute that stays with you. a beautiful and touching memorial that makes an impact, even if you don't know the story behind it (you can find a summary if you look for it on the pavement, in english, hungerian and hebrew). so simple, yet powerful.
Very poignant. Brings a tear to your eye - especially when you see the childs boots there too! They look so real when you first see them!

Shoes on the Danube Promenade. Cast iron shoes cemented on the river side as a memorial to the Jews who were shot and their bodies pushed into the Danube. Make sure you cross at a safe point - saw a guy knocked down as there is a very busy junction right by this memorial and it is easy to be lazy and try and cross right there - but don't!!!

A low key heartrending must see.. This 'monument' to a very sad/tragic time in Budapest history is one of the best and most moving tribute to the history of the Jewish citizens of Budapest. A real look at what people can do at their worst while looking at a cityscape that shows what people can do at their best.
Touching. This tribute to the Jewish people murdered on the Danube is so powerful. I was truly touched and overcome by the power of such a horrible act.
Much needed memorial. My grandmother was killed by Arrow Cross on the Danube and I found the memorial to be very emotional and an important way to say goodbye to so many.

what? shoes? why?. We literally bumped into this touching memorial on an evening stroll by the Danube. We were looking up at the enchanted parliament with the seagulls like little fireflies and we almost didn't see the shoes. All pointing towards the river, we didn't understood at first but it became clear quite quick. It's one of those memorials that are so simple it leaves you speechless, thinking for a while. We couldn't help looking over the edge into the dark water. Shivery.
Really nothing to see, but still important to know. It's a row of shoes glued to the edge of the banks. From Parliament, go to the river and work your way South. Be careful crossing the road.

A very moving tribute to those who were killed here. This is a very sad and moving tribute to those who were shot murdered here in 1945 and there bodies fell into the danube, men women and children. by the sadistic and merciless Arrow Squadron. bought me close to tears

Take a moment.... Checked out the "shoes" after reading about it in a travel guide. The display of metal shoes is so simple yet packs a powerful message. It makes one feel humble and very grateful to never have experienced such sadness as the holocust. Very moving and worthwhile to visit.

Very moving, worth a few moments of your time. Simple, moving tribute to the Hungarian Jews killed during WWII in Budapest. The Arrow Cross party were basically Hungary's Nazi party, and sent thousands of people to their deaths or Auschwitz . This memorial remembers those who were ordered to take off their shoes on the river bank before being shot. The shoes are so detailed and skilfully made, they look so real. It was very poignant and personal, I felt moved to tears. We have all seen memorials and statues relating to this terrible period in history, but this makes it very 'real' and human. I would urge people to see this and take a few moments to reflect. There were, of course, tourists there from all over the world taking countless pictures (why?) and even some who took off their own shoes and were jokingly pointing at them for photos... i found this a bit distasteful and hope that perhaps they didn't realise what the memorial was.

A most moving experience. Unlike other tourist sites, this one required, (and rightfully so), a little logistics to get to. Although close to the Parliament building, there is no well defined path to get to the shore of the Danube where, during the last months of WWII, the Arrow Cross, (the Hungarian Nazi party), lined up Jewish Citizens on the bank of the Danube, made them remove their shoes and shot them; letting their bodies fall into the Danube. I expected to spend just a little time there, but found myself in tears as I imagined the utter terror of this event. I visited other memorials to the Holocost, but nothing moved me like this. So simple in expression but so profound. If you are in Budapest, do not miss this.
empty shoes of the dead. interesting and different melancholy reminder of the Nazi days here. artistic memorial of metal shoes recalling death by pushing into the river roped together.

Touching. We were walking down the riverside when we saw these enchanting metal shoes. After a slight confusion we realised what they represented and found this a very touching way to remember the holocaust victims,
Profound sight. The sight of hte shoes was profoundly sad but it is something I needed to see fo myself. What I learnt is the unbelievable extent of human cruelty.

must do&see. This is one of the best and most moving monuments I've ever seen!Although difficult to get to still worth it. The way to get to it is NOT to cross the road as you finish the Parliament sightseeing but to start at the Lunchid (chain) Bridge and walk along the river towards the Parliament. Unfortunately you have to then walk back to the bridge to get safely to whenever you want to go after.

very important. Very important to learn about the Antisemitism that made too many jews to die during the last year of WWII.That place Symbols what the fasciest movmebnt of Hungary made to the Jews that were thrown to the danube to die.It is very sorry to see there some people that were trying to measure those shoes....

Very moving. By far one of the most touching Jewish Memorials I have seen during my time in Europe. Physically it is very simple and modest compared to other memorials but by no means is it less meaningful. I highly recommend this attraction, it is an incredibly emotional and moving tribute.
Amazing. I went to go and see the shoes and it just reminds you of things that happened and what people went through. A remakable thing to see. you will learn so much just from visiting Budapest
Very moving tribute. This is an extremely moving tribute to a truly horrible event. The juxtaposition of the beautiful sites along the river on the Buda and this memorial makes it even more moving.
A very moving experience. This is terrific memorial, but it is very sad. What happened to the Jewish people here is a human tragedy that should never be repeated. May God forgive us for our sins!

how weird. When we understood what it was it was really sad. this is such a novel way of acknowledging what happened to the Jews here. The variety of shoes is really sad, it shows how people from all walks of life were affected.
A moving experience. Acknowledges a dark aspect of the past. Just walk along the banks of the Danube away from the Chain Bridge and you will find it past the anchored river boats

simple powerful memorial. very simple and very powerful memorial to the many that lost their lives in a very along the banks of the Danube. The longer I sat there and contemplated what the memorial represented, the more I appreciated it.There are crosswalks and stairs down to the proper level at the bridges so there is no need to cross the dangerous street behind the memorial.

A Very Moving Site. I finally managed to get there on my last visit to Budapest. I took a tram from the Parliament and got down after one stop. I walked back to the direction of the Parliament along the Danube promenade until I saw the Shoes.When I got there I felt sad.I thought about the victims and felt guilty for enjoying a vacation there.
Important to see. Even and because it isn't mentioned in Google maps. it is minutes from the parlament house. on the Danube river.
Powerful. This is very close to Parliament, right on the river. A powerful memorial to the Budapest Jews murdered during WWII.

Sad and very true monument. It is unfortunately true that perhaps tens of thousands of Hungarian Jews were shot and shoved into the Danube towards the end of the war by the Nazis. This is a fitting artistic monument to ensure that such barbaric events do not take place again.
Interesting. Very interesting. Would be nice to have some sort of explanation nearby though. Great for photo, but that takes 5 minutes max.

A must see, if only for the sake of history. This small monument on the east bank of the Danube (near the Budapest Parliament) is a small memorial for the Hungarian Jewish Holocaust, presenting the horrible story of Jews that were thrown into the river in masses.It's a pity the only way to see it, one must cross the main road very carefully where it's not exactly safe.
Very moving. It's important to stop by to see the shoes lined up facing the Danube in tribute to those who lost their lives here.
Nice story about the shoes. You need to know the story about the shoes for it to make an impact, without the story it doesn't make much sense.

Came across it by accident.. We didn't know it was there. We just went for a walk down the Danube to get in front of the Parliament building. Now I understand its significance I wished I had spent a little more time there. Note that if you walk down to it there is no way across the road in front of the Parliament building.
moving. Everyone stops and reflects we came across the shoes unexpectedly after taking in the parliament and you just stop and its so moving.
very moving. It was sad and very moving to see this memorial to the thousands of Hungarian jews that were killed and thrown into the Danube
Too much fuss about nothing. Honestly, once i reached there, I really did not know what to do. The place is quiet missbale if you dont know about it and a little disappointing.
Bountiful site. Nice walk along the river, great view of the river banks. A nice alternative to go from here to there, instead of walking again in the crowded vaci ucha

Lovely but Disappointing because of access. I particularly wanted to see this, and once I found it, it was lovely, but we had trouble finding it, we got a taxi and even the taxi driver had never heard of it, he had to ask another taxi driver, we got there and had to try to get across a main road, which was very busy, then had to climb over the barrier, there were no signs for this, and it is a great shame that this memorial is not recognised more, then it would be excellent

Thought provoking.. This memorial is a poignant reminder of the cruelty that many endured in WW2. The shoes made of Iron to represent those shot on the Danube, sit almost unnoticed on the riverside. Worth a visit but not sign posted. Head towards the parliament building on the promenade.

Moving memorial. We came across these by accident as we were walking along the bank from Chain bridge to Parliament on the Pest side. I had heard about these shoes before my trip but completely forgot about them, until we practically stumbled over them (literally!).
very touching. a very touching memory to a very sad passed ,things like the shoes on the danube are there to remind of are history
A reminder of what the war did to so many jews. It was touching listening to the story behind the shoes... you can feel the goose bumps risin in your arms thinking and what was mede to so many people

Amazing!!. 100 meters southern of the Parlament there is a small and amazing memorial just in one of the most amazing views of the city. It is for the memory of the jews that were killed (It is not truth and the Nazis did not shoot them all, they tied the jewish to each other and shoor only the ones ones on the sides so all of them fell into the river. DO NOT MISS!!!!

This memorial moved me to tears. Sometimes an artist or an architect manages to so completely connect you with their concept and with the subject and this, to me, was such a case. This goes far beyond being a sculpture or an installation art work. It is a poignant and incredibly touching memorial to people who were senselessly murdered in a most brutal manner. To me it is not a question of whether or not the victims were Jewish - its is that they were innocent people who were the victims of blind intolerance. Their shoes stand today on the edge of the Danube waiting for them to return....If you do go, and I believe it is something for all to experience, please, please, please show respect because this is a memorial for those who were murdered.

SAD MEMORIAL TO DREADFUL TIMES. To see this was a moving experience. Having read of the atrocities it was easy to imagine the terror of the events that took place here. If only we could learn from our past!
Shoes. I missed these last time and wanted to see them, they are just opposite the Parliament buildings. Glad we went

poignant & simple. find the memorial at the side of the Danube, a few metres south of the Parliament building. We used the metro to reach the site, which was only a few minutes walk away. Very touching, there is a plaque in English, commemorating the memorial, laid into the paving near to the shoes.

Never Forget!. A heart wrenching site. Never forget the thousands that were thrown into the river. So Very sad. Look into the river, feel where you are standing, and think about the thousands that lost their lives here not many years ago. I will always remember the visit.
Empty shoes. Heart wrenching. The fact that the deportation to death camps began with this incident, and that Hungarian Jews made up so many of the Auchwitz totals was an eye-opener.

Hard to reach, hard to forget. As as resident of Israel, I'm used to seeing Holocaust mentions, memorials, and descriptions. Despite that, the simplicity and silence of the shoes was heart-breaking, and raised many questions -- particularly given the popularity of an anti-Semitic political party in modern Hungary. The memorial's placement so close to the parliament building is impressive, but getting there is quite difficult, and required that we cross a major street dangerously. This was after a long period of searching for an easy, safe way to get there -- so perhaps we're missing something, but it wasn't easy.There are memorial plaquest in the concrete next to the shoes. I don't know what the Hungarian says, but the Hebrew mentioned the fact that it was Jews who were killed on this spot, and the English just mentioned the people who were killed. It was hard not to get a bad feeling from that.We were surprised that there isn't any railing to stop people from falling into the Danube from the walkway alongside it, including where the shoes are. We went with young children, and made sure that they didn't go near the edge, so that they wouldn't get hurt.
Very touching. Some of the shoes are disintegrating but the impact of the memorial remains. It is a touching visual and I would suggest to come at sunset.
Heart stoppingly touching. This is a fantastic sculpture like no other I've seen before. A beautiful memorial to the fragile lives lost.
heartbreaking. Shoes of Jews (even small children) who were forced into the river and shot. A sad memorial to man's inhumanity to man and the horrors of the Nazi regime.

Why does the Hungarian govt make it so hard to find. My trip to Budapest was very important to me since my family had lived there. Growing up, my parents told me about the horrors of the Holocaust. They described to me how many of the Jews were murdered at the end of the war. Apparently, they were running out of bullets, so the Nazi's would tie people together, shoot one in the head; then throw them into the water.What upset me was how hard this memorial was to find. My husband and I walked for over and hour until we came upon the shoes. It's a very touching sight. But, it hurts me to see that one has to go out of their way to find this important memorial.

A very touching memorial. After you figure out how to get to this memorial the bronze shoes (men, women, children) is a dramatic and touching memorial for Jewish people who were lined up on this bank of the Danube by Nazi soldiers, shot and killed so their bodies would fall into the river.
Important to see,. There are brass/bronze shoes and they are another poingant remembrance of the horrors of Nazis. NOt as memorable as other memorials
Moving Site. A moving WWII memorial to a deplorable act at the end of the war in which Jews were rounded up and shot, with their bodies left to fall in to the Danube leaving only their shoes behind.

Stunning. Just when you're walking down the Danube, taking in the beautiful sites of the Parliament building and the Castle across the river, you happen upon this remarkably touching memorial. It brings tears to my eyes even now.

A chilling reminder.. Iron shoes in the style of the 40's, as if taken off and left on the banks after the wears were tied together and only one of them shot into the Danube, dragging the other with them to drown (the murderers were running out of ammunition). Chilling, heartbreaking, silent.

Jewish memorial site. This was so moving and sad. I could imagine those poor people having to take off their shoes and coats before being killed. The shoes and coats then went to German civilians. This is directly behind parliament and well worth a visit.

Hard to get to but worth the stop. Hard to believe people were murdered in front of the Parliament and the memorial is a constant reminder of that event. It's a tough site to get to as you have to go around the Parliament building and across a busy road to get there. We literally "stumbled" upon them walking back from dinner. It definitely called for a moment of silence. If you have the time and can get there, go see it. Most impactful was seeing the shoes of children.
Very sad. Really brought it home to you about the brutality that people suffered. It was very moving. Plaque nearby to mark the attraction. Worth a visit.
Walk in their shoes. This is a constant reminder of our history. The shoe are made of copper and are located on the Danube River walk-way. Stop and take the time to reflect.
If you like History very interesting. This is not something for everyone but if you like history, it is a place not to be missed. it is very well done, but I felt sad when we passed beside kid shoe.

Very Moving. This is a memorial to people shot into the Danube in 1944-45, is thought provoking and a memorial to those who died in such a terrible way. Certainly worth a visit just to remember how lucky we are, and so that we don't forget atrocities of the past.
Beautiful views but a sad history. a reminder of how the hungarian jews were treated during the 2nd world war. the little shoes amongest the adults made me have goose bumps.

So moving. This was so moving, it left me in tears. It's such a simple memorial of a truly horrific event. If you are visiting Budapest, do make time to visit it (it's not far from the Parliament building).
Thought provoking. This memorial is so simple it is amazing. A real reminder that we should work to never let this happen again!
Impressive. This is really a must when visiting Budapest. The story behind the sculpture is terrible - the monument strikes you in your heart: it concerned people.

Arrow Cross Militia. I have been to Budapest before, but this is the first time I had walked the riverside far enough to take in this distressing site. However, we should remember that there was a War at the time and distressing things happen in war time. After seeing this exhibit, I Googled and read the full history

Shoes. Located on the water edge between the Chain Bridge and Parliament. This status of shoes takes your breath away. It represents the thousands of Jews who were shot and pushed into the Danube ( date of visit was Sept 2011)
Must see. It was so very sad. I was choked up knowing what had happened there especially the little baby shoes.. Must be seen and not forgotten !!!!
Memorial on the water. Would have been nice to have more information on the memorial but it was a nice memorial with a wonderful view.

How lucky are we?. Very poignant reminder of a world gone by. Alas no so long ago. Very touching and thought-provoking. Would have liked some explanation of what it was all about. Other than leaving to the imagination that is.
Great Memorial. A great memorial located "off the beaten path" on the Danube. Very poignant and a reminder of the atrocities committed during WWII.

Nice memorial, but needs better explanations.. This was a very simple, nice memorial to the executed Jews on the Danube. It was a little difficult to locate and there was very little explanation about the memorial, but it is definitely worth a visit if in Budapest. It really makes you think, imagining yourself in someone's shoes waiting to be executed, for no reason.
an eery sight. moving -reflects people who drowned in river -did they fall or were they pushed- told indirectly about it by fellow cruise passengers who went on a guided tour- find it near parliament
Lest we forget. This memorial to those who died in the Holocaust is a lovely tribute. Soul destroying to see the mixture of shoes, ladies, men's and babies.
Very moving.. Moving memorial to those shot and pushed into the Danube during WWII. Local guides provide excellent commentary.

A must when visiting Budapest !. Heard about this monument during a city bus tour in Budapest. Because it is small you could easily miss it unless told about it. The monument consists of several pairs of shoes of the 1940's cast in bronze on the banks of the Danube. It is located just behind the main Parliament building which is a beautiful building adjacent to the Danube. The shoes represent the many Jewish families who were shot into the Danube during the Nazi regime. There is a little plaque on the ground nearby outlining this. The sight of the shoes is so powerful -- more powerful than any holocaust museum . The shoes are in all shapes and sizes, for males and females.The ones that affected me most were those of the little children. I could not leave for quite some time and it was nice to see visitors of all ages coming along, looking, obviously thinking, taking photos and staying awhile. A reminder to us all of man's inhumanity to man.

Poignant reminder of persecution and sacrifice. This holocaust memorial is tricky to get to (you have to cross an extremely busy boulevard) but it is worth the effort. This moving tribute will stay in your mind forever.
Daunting. This is a very sad place to visit when you think of why these shoes are there but a poignant reminder of the past for the people of Budapest.

History on the River. Seeing the shoes on the Danube Promenade is better than reading something in a history book. The shoes and the view of the Duna, the view of the Parliament is something you will not forget. Don't leave Budapest without seeing it.

Another heart breaking reminder of the Nazi time. This monument in honour od the Jews who were shot by the nazy on the Danube. History tells us they were told to take their shoes off before being cold blood shot.
My heart sunk looking at the shoes by the river, specially the lil boy's shoes.

Best Memorial I've Seen. This really was the best holocaust memorial I've been to. Not like a holocaust museum is really supposed to be good or anything, but I thought this one was really poignant. Def worth a visit, especially since it's in front of the Parlaiment building which is also one of the main sites in Budapest.

Very touching and sobering. This exhibit, which is a few hundred yards upstream from the Chain Bridge, features a display of bronzed shoes on the edge of the Danube. It represents a location where the Arrow Cross, a fascist Nazi sympathizer organization in Hungary shot many Jews and pushed them into the river. It only takes a few minutes, but is worth the experience.
Nice monument. Very impressive to see, but I wish there were a sign discussing the shoes. I had to look it up online after the fact.
Poignant.. Would have liked more information about this tribute. We heard from the bus driver what they represented.
Impressive monument. Impressive but very sad once you understand why these bronze shoes are placed on the stone wall above the Danube. See it.
Very touching. A beautiful, simple, touching memorial to the Jews who were killed in Budapest. A very moving sight which could easily be missed.

Heartbreaking. There are big shoes and little, fancy and plain, worker's shoes and dress shoes. Some have candles in them, others flowers. Some are on their side, others standing up. They are a memorial to the Jews who were shot by the Nazis and fell into the river. There is a plaque and a white marble bench. One can just imagine all the stories of the people who would have worn these shoes.
moving. hard to access and not mentioned on any of the tours we took but I found it very emotional located across busy roads in front of the parliament building.
Very poignant memorial.. A very sad reminder and you sit on the Danube and wonder who wore the shoes.......who did they leave behind. A rotten time in the World's history

Shoes on the Danube - very powerful. A very powerful reminder of the atrocities of the Holocaust. It represents the shoes of the Jews that were shot and dumped into the Danube river during the 2nd World War.

Simple but touching monument. The monument is located on the Pest side of the Danube bank just in the front of the Parliament building.
Very simple, but toughing monument resembling 60 pairs of empty shoes of those killed by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1945. Make me looking in a different way at the problems we witness today.

Worth the effort to find them. Required some effort to find this monument but worth it for the historical importance and meaning in what you actually see in the shoes, you will understand when you see them, the are on the pest side of the Danube, about 600 meters south of parliament house, however access is difficult, you need to walk along the river from about either bridge as the access is limited due to the road ways. Would def reccomend this to everybody

Simple Memorial. A very simple but extremely thought provoking memorial. On the Pest side of the Danube promenade. between Parliament and the Museum of Science. Worth a visit to sit, look and think how lucky we are for the life we have.
symbolic. very nice place to take pictures.right at the danube. if you have a tour bus, they must let you walk at this place

Made me cry!. A very simple but extremely touching memorial. Seeing the tiny shoes amongst those of men and women made me cry. Worth a visit to show your respect and think about how lucky some of us are.

Solumn Moment. This was a reminder of what was a very devasting part of history. We had a little trouble getting to the site because of the traffic and evidently we didn't enter at the proper spot. Try to follow a suggested route to get to the site.

It is worth to see. The location may be hard to find and after you arrive there is not much information about it, so you should read before you go.The place should be more conserved since it is part of Budapest history. When you pass it, many people stay for some minutes to think and reflect. It is also a calm place by the river.
unexpected surprise. i was just walking when i bumped into it. very nice, i wouldn't go there only for it, but walking by the danube was very nice.

so sad. The shoes are a great memorial to the so many Jewish lives so sadly lost here, but I feel the true extent shouldve been represented and the mere 40 shoes do not do justice to the 200,000 lives so sadly lost. To have replicated the whole 200,000 shoes that wouldve been left here on the banks of the Danube would be a much more powerful and poignant memorial tribute.

Nice memorial but tricky to access.. Shoes on the Danube is quite out of the way and with the roadworks at the moment it was difficult to access and then get back from. The memorial is interesting but unless you know where it is and why it's there you aren't going to think much of it if you just happen across it.

Most powerful picture on my mind.. I knew I had to see it. The monument is a result of a unique conceipt. Extremely touching. Sadly,only few people strolling by the Danube realize what they represent. No wonder. There is no single mark showing the way to the monument, and the plaques telling the story are not visible from a distance at all. You have to get there on your own risk, crossing a very busy road. Why did they make getting closer to the monument so difficult? To avoid questions why sevaral thousands of Jews were thrown into cold waters of Danube by Hungarians during World War II?

A little thought. I would say it is a must because it is sort of a memorial for the Jews who died during the IIWW. It's original, it's part of history and regardless of your origins, it's a little thought you give for those who passed away before their time.

Where human beings has been killed by "animals".... Remember! Uneducated idiots are sometimes get the power and kill those with knowledge, will and success. Here Jews were shot by Hungarian nacis during WW II. and dropped to the river.

Very touching..... A very touching and moving monument to hunderds of people. Sadly it seems some people have no idea what it represents, trying to fit their feet into the shoes. I talked to one young girl doing this, when I explained the memorial to her, she was mortified at what she had done. I pointed her in the direction of the plaque, which sadly is so well hidden and level with the ground, most have no idea it is there. My 10yo was so saddened that they killed little children, she asked if it was ok for her to pull up a flower growing along the banks and place it as a memorial into the baby shoe.

You have to visit this place. There are no signs going to this simple memorial, but simply walk along the river bank on your way to the Parliament and you'll stumble in this place. Seeing the cast iron shoes will move you as you remember the Jews shot and drowned in the Danube river during WWII.
Not sure why these are here. A monument along the bank of the Danube. A load of metal shoes make art of a kind. It needs an explanation as to why they are there.
Moving.. This monument was a sobering moment for our family, and we highly recommend you stop by for a few moments.
Touching. This was very touching. I was not aware of what happened on that spot until my tour guide informed me.
impressive. very impressive - don't forget to visit at least this monument ( near the House of Parliament - on the riverbank)
