Almost Missed Seeing Them. I was following my Rick Steves guidebook and could not see the shoes, so I eventually went closer to the river...and you know...I was just surprised how the bronzed shoes made me feel as I had just previously learned of their history.

Simple but poignant. The Nazis took the jewish children to the river, forced them to take off their shoes, and then shot them and the river wasked their bodies away. This memorial is elegant in its simplicity. Only takes minutes to view, but the sight will remain with you forever. Easy to get to--just minutes walk south of Parliament on the riverfront,

Profound statement. I had read about this memorial while investigating Budapest and felt I just needed to see it. We happened upon the shoes during dusk when we took a stroll off our river cruise boat. It was quite startling to see how realistic these shoes are. More over it was unsettling to think such a terrible time that these people must have endured. Such a simple item that has made a profound statement.

Wonderful, subtle, sobering. We had heard about the Shoes, Budapest's Holocaust Memorial, but seeing them was stunning. Bronze shoes that look so old and worn, men's, women's, and kids shoes, laying as if just taken off. Plaques in three languages tell the brief story of Jews who were told to remove their shoes, then shot, with their bodies falling in the Danube. We went back along the river at night, and it was just as impactful in the dim light from the Chain Bridge and Parliament. Not to be missed.

Sobering Reflections Along the Danube. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade is a sobering reminder of a very sad part of Hungary's history. During WWII, the infamous Arrow Cross Party, an anti-semitic organization operating in Budapest, executed thousands of Jews in Budapest, many of whom were shot along the river, after being ordered to remove their shoes which were left behind as the bodies fell into the water.When trying to understand a country and its history, sometimes it's necessary to learn about the sad and difficult chapters and not only the glorious ones. This memorial is not for the faint-hearted. It will bring tears to your eyes, and many visitors will reflect on this sad and terrible era in the history of the world. The memorial itself is very simple, and a very fitting tribute to the innocent people who lost their lives for doing nothing more than being who they were. I would recommend this for people interested in history, and not afraid to confront one of the more sobering and horrifying chapters of European history.

Very good reminder of violance in history. I was touched to tears by this monument. The shoes are so real, you almost feel the grief and horror of these Jews who were shot to death there just about 70 years ago. 600 000 hungarian Jews were killed- men, women, children. I think this work of art is very powerful and a good reminder for us!

Haunting and well done. This is a very powerful memorial. Seeing the long line of shoes, representing the Jews who were lined up and shot in the backs into the cold Danube over a period of two years was emotional and sobering. There were mens' womens' and childrens' shoes as a reminder of what happened in this spot.

A Walk in Their Shoes. This simple memorial is not easy to find. I am so thankful that our guide included it in our tour. Crossing a very busy street, we found ourselves walking in the shoes of those who came before us but whose journey ended at the banks of the Danube. The iron shoes symbolize, and pay tribute to, the Jews who were systematically shot and thrown into the river. The plaque, which seeks to explain what happened on this spot, is very vague and does not address what really took place. Without a tour guide, or some background reading, a visitor would have little idea of what occured here.This memorial was definitely worth seeing and provided a very moving experience!
A chilling scene!. Had never heard of this history; the shoes made a strong statement of how terrible the times were for the Jewish people and what they had to endure.
Must see if you're interested in WWII. Very moving memorial. It is pretty easy to find if you just walk along Danube on Pest's side, it's quite near to the parliament.

Moving, but an artistic and effective way to remember the past!. An interesting way to illustrate the plight of the Jews during WWII. The simple act of shoes absent of their owners graphically illustrates the loss of people. A larger number of Jews were made to remove their shoes, shot and then dumped in the Danube. Combined with a visit to 'The House of Terror' you get to see an aspect of Budapest history that is symbolically expressed.
Must See Memorial. This is a must see memorial of WWII. It is peaceful and respectful. I recommend that you read about what occurred before you visit it. This is a quick visit

Little known memorial worth a visit. On our first evening in Budapest, we walked along the Danube promenade on the Pest side from the Marriott hotel toward the Chain bridge to the shoe memorial where many died in the river near the end of WWII. It is a moving memorial. Some visitors to the memorial have left stones or candles in the iron shoes. The iron shoes symbolize the shoes left on the bank of the river by those who were drowned when one was shot while the others were tied to the one shot and all were pulled into the river.

Disturbing, artistic, effective. These iron shoes were made to commemorate Jews who were made to take off their shoes and then shot by Hungarian pro-Nazi Arrow Cross members and dumped into the Danube toward the end of WWII. Very effective art.
Sad, but good idea. I new stories about Holocaust in Budapest. It's even hard to think about that. Nice, the citizens of Budapest found the way to express this story correctly and symbolically.

Incredibly moving memorial. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade honors the Jews who were killed by Arrow Cross who marched them to the Danube, ordered them to take off their shoes, and shot them so that their bodies fell into the river. There are 3 signs on the ground, with text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005." The empty shoes are an eloquent memorial.

A memorial worth seeing.. Located on the banks of the Danube is a row of shoes in memory of those who were cruelly shot into the Danube during the second world war. They were asked to remove their shoes, stand on the edge and were shot into the river. All that remained were their shoes and this memorial is to honour those people.

Powerful and strak monument. I came across the shoes while walking along the Danube at dusk and didn't know what they represented until I did some research on the web. The ordinariness of the shoes and the lack of bright lights drawing your attention to the memorial create a powerful metaphor. The people who were shot by the facists were required to remove their shoes before they were executed by a firing squad.

Remember. This is quite a memorial as it fails to identify the fact that the shoes belong to Jewish victims. No one should forget the horror of terrorizing a people for their religious beliefs. Very poignant but sad that the Hungarian government cannot take responsibility for their actions.

Underwhelmed.. This memorial could be and should be so much better. There is nothing wrong with the actual shoes/layout etc. In fact they are if you know the history behind them quite a moving sight. However, there should have been more information rather than just a simple plaque. We came away saying 'is that it' and felt the walk and search to find the memorial (we didn't see any signposts etc) a waste of time and energy. We were totally underwhelmed by it as a memorial.

Very nice memorial, would be nice if there was more information. As others have said, this memorial is largely symbolic. I thought overall it was a very touching memorial. Luckily I was with a guide so I didn't have any trouble finding the memorial--but it does seem that the location would be rather difficult to find if you are in Budapest on your own and are unfamiliar with the city. I thought overall it was a nice memorial--and very different than any other memorials I had seen from the same era.
Very touching. To see all the shoes and never forget that people can do such things.
Poignant. This is a very poignant memorial on the banks of the Danube( on the Pest side). Well worth a visit.

Can be avoided if not Emotional person. he idea to place a monument on the river embankment to the victims of the Arrow Cross terror belongs to Gyula Pauer, Hungarian sculptor awarded the Kossuth-prize, and to his friend Can Togay. The monument contains of 60 pairs of iron shoes, forming a row of about 40 metres. It is a commemoration dedicated to the victims of the fascist Arrow Cross party who shot the people right into the river, sparing themselves the hard work of burials. The victims had to take their shoes off, since shoes were valuable belongings at the time.The site is symbolic, this part of the embankment was not the only one used for this purpose.The iron shoes were placed on the embankment in 2005, on 16th April. The name of the composition is Shoes on the Danube Promenade, each pair being modelled after a contemporary shoe from the 1940's.It has only Emotional Value but nothing otherwise

Holocaust Memorial. The shoes on the Danube is basically 50 pairs of bronze shoes that commemorate the Jews who were killed by the Arrow Cross in 1944. It is very humbling to stand here and think about how these people were killed and their bodies dropped into the Danube. It is a stark reminder of the tragedy of war. It is definitely worth going to the riverbank and catching at lest a glimpse. When we were there the construction makes it difficult to get to and the traffic is heavy. Be very, very careful if you decide to cross the road to get over them embankment to see them. It is very close to Parliament in the Leopold Town center area. It is good to go to Parliament and buy your tickets early morning and then in between the time you buy tickets and waiting for your tour time walk down behind (left side facing) Parliament to see the shoes.
interesting. i have traveled all over the Europe but have not seen anything similar. It is done really interesting and it makes impression. Worth a visit.

Sobering and memorable. Difficult to get to, but a very poignant reminder of a terrible piece of holocause history. If you're not looking for it, you could miss this important, tasteful, touching and memorable memorial.
nice promenade!. wonderful to walk in the evening with all the lights from the beautiful buildings. Nice terraces to sit on to enjoy the view
Impressive. A very fitting memoriam to those that lost their lives
Really moving experience. A real touching monument. Simple but moving... A must see
Very sad but you must visit. The very sad sight of the shoes of people who were shot during the war on the river edge, a must see

Moving. Standing on the banks of the Danube among the shoes and thinking of the lives lost was incredibly moving. I was also saddened by people taking 'funny face photos' and trying on the shoes. Perhaps they were ignorant of the significance. I will not forget this monument.
Very moving!. Knowing the story behind the shoes on the Danube Promenade made it one of the unforgetable places to see. Very simple - yet very moving!
Holocaust Memorial. Ok.. you take your life in your hands crossing the dual carriageway to get there, but it's a simple yet thought provoking piece of work...
Very moving. Definitely a must see. This a very moving tribute to victims of the Holocaust.

Heart wrenching!!. Not easy to find as it's not marked on any maps but well with the search! Between the House of Parliament and the Chain Bridge, this must be one of the most impressive monuments I've seen that actually make you stop and think about what actually happened!

Heartbreaking. We were not aware of this sculpture until we came across it on the last morning of our visit. It was an incredibly moving site and a powerful reminder of the evil that man can do when encouraged by those with darkness in their heart. It is worrying that the far right seem to be gaining popularity in Hungary - their views must be resisted by all means possible and this sculpture should be seen by as many people as possible

Memorial shoes. Memorial shoes on the shore of the Danube are sculptures to remember the Jews who were murdered by the Nazis on this place during World War II. Everybody should say: do not forget and do not forgive!!! never again!!!

Don't miss this incredible monument. Holocaust Monument is not easy to find or reach. We crossed several lanes of traffic to reach it but traffic was very kind and stopped to let us pass as they knew where we wanted to go.The monument consists of 50 pairs of bronze shoes commemorating the Jews who were killed when the Arrow Cross militia massacred them and let their bodies fall into the Danube river.
Very Moving. The city abounds with memorials to the victims of the various extreme regimes, this is one of the simplest and most moving.

Nice area so sit down for 10 minutes taking in the surroundings.. Across from the majestic parliament building lies these random shoes on the banks of the Danube. Sit down and take the surroundings in and take some arty pictures. Very nice and strange at the same time.

Meaningless Shoes. With no background info and no sign on the site, I could only imagine and try to come up with my own interpretation as what those shoes meant. I looked at them with an artist's eye, then with a historical perspective, alas, neither one did anything much for me. Call me dense! I tried to pick up one of them thinking they might have been left there accidentally or might have been a collection of river trash. When I found out they were glued, then I knew, they were there for something!
Expressive!. One of the most expressive and touching monunents I've seen. Don't miss it. And still - a fascist party is growing again in Hungary...

Sad excuse for a memorial. This is site difficult to access. Worse there is no signage whatsoever explaining what you are looking at. Not worth taking your life in hand to cross the busy street and hiking the half mile to the site.
Impressionable. Much like other memorials paying tribute to the tragedies of WWII, this memorial was very impressionable. The shoes are beautifully and hauntingly artistic.
Touching. Small and touching monument with big story behind.
Loved it. I stumbled upon this memorial, it was quite moving and sad. I would recommend having a look.
Evocative. This simple memorial of bronze cast shoes makes you stop and think.
A most touching memorial. There's something so personal about the shoes and their placement. They're unforgettable.

Beautiful. Memorials of this kind are always fraught, but I thought this one achieved a beautiful balance. It is quietly evocative, especially the children's shoes, or the shoes that sit alone, and one happens upon it as one strolls the river bank. In this sense, it is when one isn't look for it, and is disrupted and then disturbed by it, that it works best. I didn't see garbage in the shoes, just flowers and tea lights.

a bit understated. Ok this memorial should cause one to shiver but the problem is it is so understated that you almost miss it unless you actually look for it. Also people throw garbage inside the shoes and that's not very nice. But it is a very important memorial and should not be missed.
This place make me cry. You can miss this place is amazing and to much to think about life.

Off the beaten path.. We visited this memorial our last morning in Budapest. You have to walk along the promenade, north of the Chain Bridge toward the Parliament. It is a very small memorial with little explanation, but as others have said it is moving. It is hard to cross the road after the memorial, so it is best to turn around and go back to the Chain Bridge.

Moving reminder of mans inhumanity to man. First off the shoes are hard to get to a nd dangerous to access unless you are already on the bank of the river.They could be adding more shoes for people run over trying to get there which is pretty sad reallyBad bits over we were touched by theMemorial. My nine year old daughter noticed 1 Shoe on its own and asked why? I explained that the militia probably opened fire before that person removed the other shoeTo me this taught her more about nazism than every book in her schoolA very touching memorial
Very moving. Simple yet effective holocaust memorial. Well worth seeking out.
Very moving!. Although difficult to find, this is a sight no one should miss.

Thought provoking. Not the most famous sight in Budapest but the Shoes memorial was my favourite. I found the memorial, in honor of Jewish people shot by Arrow Cross militiamen during WWII, very moving and it actually brought a tear to my eye. This is a really unique and interesting memorial, definitely a must-see (read up on the history first). Just keep walking along the Pest side of the river and the memorial is about 300 metres south of the Parliament building.

Moving?. How do you rate an attraction that is there for all to see and is free?The sculpture commemorates those Jews of Budapest who were shot and thrown into the Danube, by placing various shoes cast in metal along the embankment near the Parliament building.I appreciate what it is trying to do, but I did not find it poignant, unlike parts of Auschwitz or Terrezin.
Very moving. While we were there a young German woman was watering the flowering plants she placed in some of the shoes the day before. This added to the poignancy of the memorial

Simple, yet moving.. I would recommend doing some research on the Nazi history in Budapest, and reading the stories about the mass executions of Jews into the Danube before heading down to the banks of the river to see this memorial. That said, it was a simple yet extreemely touching monument to an awful time in history. The tiny children's shoes included made me weep at the horrors that humans are capable of. Heartwrenching.
Got teary eyed. I got teary eyed when I saw the 60 pairs of shoes on the Danube promenade. It was a historical reminder of the Holocaust.
Poignant. Seeing the adults and children's shoes on the side of the Danube really brings home the horrors suffered by the Jews during WW2.

A moving experience. Finding the Shoes on the Danube Promenade was a little difficult, but once we found it we were in awe of the memorial. It is almost too life like to see the shoes in a very realistic placement, just how anybody might take off their shoes and leave by the door. It is emotional knowing how many were shot and then thrown into the Danube, but it is a cost free must see while in Budapest. And, once you find it, you need maybe 15-20 minutes to take pictures.
heart wrenching. this site is not well known we didn,t find any reference to it but worth a look and has lovely views of Buda
Moving, puts everything into perspective. The sculptures were moving and reminds us that not only the city but the country has had a very tumultuous 60 years.

Holocaust Memorial. This small memorial was so moving. It brought tears to my eyes. I had read about it in the guide books and knew what it was about. I don't think there was any signage at the site, so if you didn't know much, I'm not sure you'd realize the significance.

Get sweathy and wet with the locals!. We loved the whole experience. The locals seem to be at ease with the tourist enjoying what they have for over 100 years. Try out all the different tubs inside the building! Bring your own towel!
Very moving. A very moving site! Head for the houses of Parliament and it is on the river bank.

sad but well worth a visit.. Yes this sculpture is along the banks of the Danube on the Pest side. It depicts the lives lost of young and old men women and children murdered during the Nazi occupation of Budapest. Its really poinient and brings home the full impact of loss that so many people suffered. A must see but as i said sad though if you dont want to get too close to this sculpture then follow tram line 2 for a quick glimpse as you pass by.
Very sad. The traffic in the area is very busy, so be careful. The monument itself is very sad. The danube is lovely.
Moving. Had a job to reach this as had to cross busy roads to get to it,but it was worth it, very moving

Very meaningful and beautiful monument. The monument i very close to the Parliament, on the Pest bank of Danube. It was erected in the memory of the victims who was shot there by the Arrow Cross Militia in 1945. The view from there is magnificent and you can continue your walk on the promenaede to The Chain Bridge or to Margaret Bridge from here.
Heart wrenching. You have to see this, you think it will not affect you, but anyone with a heart it will touch.
Thought provoking...... Worth the walk to, something to make you reflect on the past. As they are on the bank of the Danube you also get great views up and down the river.
Not as beautiful as in my dreams.. Well the Danube is not blue so I was a little disappointed but the areas along the Danube were beautiful and well worth a visit.

Not sure if it is historically acurate but still should be seen. Located just south of the Parliament and north of the Chain Bridge. As we viewed it it made me wonder as to it's historical accuracy but regardless of this it makes a point that should be absorbed by all.Try to fit it in as part of a day of Jewish history in Budapest it will only add to trying to get the whole picture as to what happened during a very dark period in human history.
Heartbreaking. This was an unknown piece of history for me and I was very moved with the displays of shoes, men women and children from the 1940s which make up the monument.

Subtle and Sober. This quiet collection of bronze shows along the river front has a small plaque laid in the pavement to describe the memorial. It requires a bit of historical knowledge on the part of the viewer, but it is a sobering moment of reflection in the heart of a beautiful river walk.
nice idea. very nice idea beside the river of life and smart one
A must see. A solemn and unobtrusive memorial to Holocaust victims

I wish we had known what they were. I humbly confess we didn't know the meaning of this. We wrongly guessed it was a tribute to suicide victims. Now that I know I'll go and light a candle for all those innocent souls.
Poignent. Facinating, just came across them whilst taking a stroll near the Parliamnet building
a reminder of what has passed. We were pointed out these shoes by our coach rep. It was quite touching in its own way, but we did not go and visit them
Very Sobering Remembrance. Metal sculpture mark the position where Jews were executed during WWI in Budapest
very moving testament. Opposite Parliment, moving tribute and worth visiting.
Poignant. Simple memorial to those shot during the war fleeing across the Danube

Touching Memorial. I came upon this memorial unexpectedly and it was a good reminder of what transpired there many years ago. Amidst the beauty of the Danube and the backdrop of the Buda Castle, lays a sad and grim reality of the history of the Jews. The artwork was done tastefully and leaves a lot to the imagination. Withering flowers on the shoes show that people to this day mourn this tragedy. It was very touching.

Moving. This monument is a thought provoking reminder of the short but exceptionally horrific period of the German occupation in Hungary.Would recommend visiting the House of Terror or doing the a Jewish walking tour or reading about Raoul Wallenberg to know more about the historical background.
If the shoe fits. Nice commemorative display of the Holocaust victims.

A Moving Reminder of a Brutal Period. Shoes on the Danube, located between Parliament and the Chain Link Bridge, is a creative way to portrait a brutal period in Hungarian History and serves as a reminder of these events. It's not hard not imagine what was going through the minds of the victims as they stood at the edge high above the water looking down. Taking a walk along the river to see this site should be on anyone's agenda when visiting Budapest.
Nice tribute. Nice tribute to those who were forced to leave Budapest.
A must see!. This is a must see. My husband went to the shoes and just took a min to take it all in. It was very sad to see a image like that.

Sad and shocking, but true. There is not much to see, just a bunch of bronzed shoes along the bank of the Danube. But if you have children it will give them some knowledge of a dark time in the history of mankind. And if you your imagination run wild you can picture the bloody corpses floating in the Danube.

make sure you see this. This is one of the most intense things I have ever seen. It is a memorial to thousands of Jews shot into the Danube at the end of WWII, sometimes tied together in 2's and 3's with just one person being shot, dragging the others in to drown. The history of what happened to Hungary's Jews is really brutal, and the antisemitism in the city is growing once again. Go to Budapest with your eyes wide open. It is very beautiful, but there is a lot of really bad stuff going on politically right now - it is becoming very right wing, and scary
Poignant. Had seen reviews before travelling but still came as surprise how understated.
Interesting but don't go out of your way. Really sad story, but not worth going out of your way to see.

Moving reminder. You certainly have to dodge traffic to get down to this point of the Danube behind the parliament but the bronzed shoes along the river edge are a poignant reminder of the awful times faced by the people of Budapest at the end of WW2
Somber and sobering. A horrible part of our history that should never be forgotten. A must see. Bring tissues and flowers to leave with your prayers.

Worth a look. I'm always amazed at how artists can find innovative ways to subtley communicate moods and feelings. There is a definite feeling of loss when you look at these bronzed shoes, a sense of time stolen. It's not heavy and oppressive so a trip to the shoes is still a good idea if you're looking for a fun vacation. Just set aside 15 minutes to reflect and pay your respects.

very sad memorial. The iron shoes nailed on the promenade along the danube is a very sad memorial of the world war atrocities committed on jews.I am surprised, there was no placard to highlight the sculpture there. It was just by chance that we happened to pass-by on our way to the parliamentSad so very sad...

Shoes on the Danube promenade - a must. Although not well known; and only discovered on our 3rd trip; this is not to be missed. Only 3 min walk from the Parliament building on the promenade; this really brings history into life and whilst sad, has to be experienced.

Very moving memorial. The memorial is on the bank of the Danube River on the Pest side, between Chain Bridge & Parliament Buildings. It honours the Jews who were killed by the fascist Arrow Cross militiamen during WWII. The Jews were ordered to take off their shoes, and were shot at the edge of the water so that their bodies fell into the river and were carried away. The memorial represents their shoes left behind on the bank. It's so sad, especially the children's shoes. People leave little flowers and candles in or next to the shoes.
Easy to find & poignant. poignant & good to see on a walk not far from the Pest side of the chain bridge towards the parliamentOne chance to get a little closer to the Danube too

not to be missed. a very touching memorial, which must be followed by a visit to the grand synagogue which once held up to 3,700 parishioners. One has to think of the misery of the last sabbaths when so many jews left the synagogue not knowing what would be in store during the coming week. So sad.
Chilling site. Unbelievable memory on how cruel and inhumane the SOB's were!

worth a brief stop. It was extremely windy along the banks of the Danube, and it's a bit of a hike to get to, but there is a nice vista of the castle area on the other side, and the shoes are a reminder of an unfortunate time in the city's history.

Incredibly moving. The most moving experience of my trip. All types of shoes and look like that have just been removed form feet! Very lifelike,and vary tearful when you understand the full story.Not difficult at all to find, just by the parliament building on the riverside

sobering. difficult to reach but located just south of the Parliament building along the wall on the Danube. Very touching. Very little written about this and it was dedicated in 2005 which tells you something right there.

Poignant tribute..... While on the Jewish tour, we were given more information about the shoes and how owners were forced into the freezing Danube and perished. It was shocking how the Nazis were able to massacre so many people within a year.The shoes remind us that the owners may be gone but are not forgotten.
Moving!. Well worth the walk along the Duna. Pity that some of the shoes have been taken/stolen.

Simple, extremely moving and a great work of art!. Simple, extremely moving and a great work of art! I heard of it therefore looked for it, the signs though for tourists which are not familiar with the place are not good enough and one can easily miss the meaning of it all.
Moving. A moving memorial over jewish people that were killed during WW2. Very simple but it makes you think.

Okej okej. It was an pleasant walk. Beatiful views. ok, The restaurang around that area were 3-4 times moore expensive on the beer than your local pub in the backalleys. My tip is to take the tram, nr 2. And you´ll see it all. Even the parliment. Get of at the end station, get up on the bridge, go back to the road and find an beer or food at an very reasonable price instead....
Thought-provoking. I have seen a number of Holocaust memorials, and all are moving. The simplicity of the way that this one memorializes the victims is particularly impactful.

Very touching. We visited this memorial today and were all teary eyed while taking pictures. This is a must see on your visit to Budapest. It was my extremely negligible way of showing that I cared...definitely not much, but the least that I could do. There is no entrance from the Kossuth Lajos Utca tram stop and unless you are comfortable crossing a busy road (which we did), would recommend that you get off one stop earlier (from the Chain Bridge) and walk down towards the parliament from there.

Burying the past instead of remembering it.. A friend of mine from Budapest told me that I had to be sure to see the "shoes memorial." I was shocked to find that in a city of huge buildings and statuary, this remembrance is paltry and practically inaccessible. The memorial consists of about 50 bronzed shoes (of the era, not traced to actual victims) which represent the Hungarian Jews lined up at the river, bound, shot, and pushed in to the Danube literally as Allied forces advanced on the city. These atrocities were committed by Hungarian nationals who felt compelled to continue to round up and kill as many Jews as possible even though Nazi defeat was certain. There is no question of "not knowing" and there is eyewitness proof of both complicity and enthusiasm for the task. A sad chapter in Hungarian history, and a sad monument to recount it. As one of the other reviewers said, it's like they don't want to remember the Holocaust.There is NO signage from the road alerting travelers of the existence of the memorial. The monument itself is located on a small stretch along the banks of the Pest side (opposite the Parliament building), and it is literally inaccessible, unless you are already walking along that stretch of riverfront on that side. To access the memorial you have to cross a busy two lane highway with active tram track and then hop over a divider. If you manage to get there in one piece, you will find a memorial that, while moving, completely fails to demonstrate the scope of the atrocities.Better than nothing? Barely. It's a token.
Be ready to shed tears.. An incredibly moving memorial that is a must see for any visiting Budapest. I have never been to a sight that evokes such emotion.

You may almost miss them. We hadn't heard about them , therefore as we walked down the Danube it was by chance that we came upon them . There was no placard/signpost as to what they were about. if you dont know history you will most certainly miss them.

Very sad. Like all the other reviews, this is a very moving place to visit. What I found so strange though is that during all the tours I took (3 in total), this was never mentioned. It seems they do not wish to mention the history of the holocost.
Understated but moving. This tiny exhibit could easily be missed but we found it very moving and glad we walked the Danube to see it.

Simple but very touching.... I think that it is probably one of the most moving holocaust's monuments I have ever seen... Look for the one toddler pair of shoes- this one will surely break your heart... Very sad, very important...

most moving site/sight in Budapest. There are about 50 pairs of Bronze shoes of all sizes--including one toddler pair. This was a spot alogn the river where |Jews were shot and dumped during WW II. So close to Parliament no one can say they did not know. And of course metaphorically you put yourself into their shoes. Wonderful memorial.
Moving display. Approach from Chain Bridge only cannot be accessed from Parliament end.

Powerful in its simplicity. The Monument of the Shoes interested us as part of the Jewish history of Hungary. I did some walking to find them: They are along the Pest side of the Danube between the Chain Bridge and M. Island Bridge, but closer to the M. Island Bridge. Very moving.

Horrifying, but important to see and to Remember.. This is the site of some horrifying massacres of Jews by Hungarian Fascists during WWII. Groups of 20-30 Jews were bound together with barbed wire, and pushed into the Danube to drown together. My hosts were Jews who'd survived the mass murder and expulsion of the majority of Hungarian Jewry (over 700,000 Jews were murdered, out of over 800,000 expelled, 1942-1945; under 190,000 survived in Hungary).

What a pity. A dark episode in the history of Hungary. Such a pity that this pognant memorial to the thousands that were shot by their fellow Hungarians and thrown into the Blue Danube, turning it red, is almost inaccesible. One has to cross a busy main road and tramline to reach it.
Hard to find. Not sign-posted but managed to find it eventually - on Pest side of Danube, near Parliament building

Sad. This spot was an accident find. We decided to walk the shore of the river to the Parliament and we came across the shoes. We had read about them in our tour guide. Lucky find. Nice memorial. Simple but powerful in its statement.

A very moving experience. Quite hard to find, in fact the receptionist at our hotel had never heard of it. You need to walk between Margit bridge and the Chain bridge. Well worth finding but not well marked at all

Moving!. While difficult to get to given the major highway that runs along the Danube on this Pest side of the river, it is a worthy trip to feel the struggles that Jews felt in Budapest in the 20th century.
powerful image. very impacting to take time and try to envision what had happened in this location not that long ago

A simple, sad statement.. We walked along beside the river from the Pest side of the Chain Bridge having spotted the shoes from the top of the tourist bus we used to help get round the city while my injured knee recovered. This is one of the simplest yet most evocative memorials we have seen to the horrors of the Holocaust era. Each pair or single shoe with their different styles and sizes makes you think carefully about the people, the moment they left them there and their fate. Try not to miss.

Poignant. An incredibly moving memorial. Very much worth reading up about and going to see. One of the best monuments I've been to as it's so powerful. Not really signposted, so to get there walk along the river from the Parliament towards Chain Bridge.

Very thought provoking.. We took a walk along the river looking for these sculptures after a guide in the Jewish quarter told us about them.This is a very moving work and a testament to all of the people who lost their lives during the German occupation of Budapest.
Touches your soul. Sometimes it is the simplicity of an idea that creates the most impact. Museums can't always connect with the emotion of situation the way an artist can.

Harrowing, and unexpected. The group of us- four blokes in our forties and fifties- were enjoying our lunchtime stroll along the beautiful Danube in the gorgeous late April sunshine when suddenly we saw a group of strangely arranged shoes and boots by the side of the river. On closer inspection they turned out to be metal representations of shoes of all sizes- childrens, mens, womens. Knowing something of the history of the City in the 1940's we feared the worst, and our worst fears were confirmed by a young woman who had a guidebook. It was a memorial to a number of Jews of all ages who were marched to the river, ordered to remove their footwear, and then shot and pushed into the river. "It must never Happen Again." Shalom.
The national shame!. Beautiful memories for the innocent murdered Jews of Pest.

Very powerful. This monument spoke volumes. I brought my 3 daughters there - aged 5, 7, and 9. 2 of my daughters had just finished some Girl Guide work on Judaism and had visited a synagogue, so they had a bit of history. I gave them an age appropriate description of the memorial. It was the most talked about thing we did in Budapest. Unfortunately, my daughter mentioned it too late, and we couldn't do it, but she said that she would have liked to have gone back to put some flowers in the shoes to remember some of the people.Definitely worth a visit if you are going to be near the Parliament buildings.

The most poignant spot in Budapest. If you go to the Parliament building first it is very difficult to get to the river edge as the tram line and a very busy road are in between. Best way to approach it is by walking along the river footpath from Roosevelt Ter.
Speechless. After reading history of Budapest before visiting, I was on the look out for these shoes. Waste of human life like this just leave me speechless.
Walk along the prom. Worth just taking your time, takes about 1hour with stop off's on the way. The weather was very warm and humid when I was there so the breaze from the river will cool you down.
Reminder of the bad times. The shoes evoke poignant memories of the horrors which took place in the city.
Bronze shoes. When I first saw these I thought it was a flock of pigeons but they are very realistic metal shoes lying along the promenade. Another photo opportunity

Very moving memorial. This memorial is located on the Pest side of the Danube almost adjacent to the Parliament building. Our guide book did not include any information about it but a friend had suggested we visit prior to our trip. There is no explanation alongside the memorial - just a line of shoes - which represent the shoes left by the Jews who were herded to the edge of the river and shot during their persecution in WW2.
Poignant reminder.... This was a touching tribute to those lost. Well worth a visit...

Read up before you go. There isn't any information on the exhibit by the sight, so unless you already know what it is you don't really know what it's for. It is a touching memorial, but it looks like it needs to be restored a bit (there are a couple of missing shoes, etc.).
Sobering. Very touching reminder of one of history's lowest points and the weakness of mankind.

Important memorial. There is much to remind you of the Communist period in Budapest - reminders of the events of 1956 are everywhere, from statues, memorials and even bullet holes. There is actually very little that reminds people of the facist period - the Terror Museum deals with this, but the focus there is still mainly on the Communist period. Shoes on the Danube reminds everyone of the awful events that occurred during 1944-5. Simple and moving.
Shoes make you think. We were moved by the poingnant "shoes on the Danube Promenade". Worth a visit,
Simple but effective. Poignant. Very simple but enough to make you stand and contemplate. Coupled with a visit to the Museum of the Holocaust in Pava Street, it is very powerful.

very emotive. Budapest has some very good examples of street art and sculptures. This is a simple but very emotive subtle remembrance feature which is easily missed, but well worth spending some time at and reflecting about terrible events in our past.
Moving. We found this by accident, a beautifully poignant commemoration. Well worth a detour if it's not already on your route.
Poignant. A small but powerful way of reminding people of the hard times the Hungarian people had to endure
Sad, but a great reminder. Never forget! It wasn't only the Arrow cross that raped Hungary but the Russians too.

Haunting. Bronze shoes at the Danube. So simple and haunting of a dark time.
Kinda difficult to get to. You can walk up from the Chain Bridge along the Pest side of the river or attempt to cross the road near the Parliament (not so safe). Must see.
Poignant memorial. Stumbled across this by accident - brass shoes lined up on the banks of the Danube. It is a tribute to a massacre of Jews that took place during the second world war.
worth a visit. powerful but small. context is very important. I'll have to wait to process the photos to say more.
Waste of time. C'mon a linne of "old" shoes made os metal. Nothing fancy or special about them.
Very sobering.... This was very sobering moment in our visit to Budapest. You must cross to the riverside before you get to the Shoes on the Danube area. This was very sad and sobering.

Simple yet meaningfull. A very simple (maybe too simple considering what it represents), yet very touching.
I'm glad to have seen it.
i loved it!. next to the river, a little but very characteristic monyment

Reflective but minimal. Any memorial to the holocaust will be moving, and this, in itself is. However it is very minimal, has only a small 'plaque' (in Hungarian) and actually offers little or nothing by way of telling you that it is actually a memorial, had you not known before arriving here; I may well have walked straight by had we not planned the visit.Unless you wish to stand and reflect, there is actually nothing to keep you here for more than a few minutes...
Disapointed. Maybe because everyone talks about it, I was expecting something differente than severam shoes at the riverside
A beautiful and touching memorial. This memorial really reaches across time and connects you to the tragedy. Very affecting.

Wouldn't want to walk in those shoes. The exhibit is on the Danube just near Parliament on the Pest side of the river. It is an emotional one and really makes you think about all the suffering that took place in Budapest during and after the war. The exhibit is simple; several pairs of shoes line the river. It's not something you'll spend a lof of time seeing, but rather a place you can go and reflect on the mistreatment of the Jews. Tip: When you walk down the river, try to cross near the Chain Bridge as it's nearly impossible to cross in front of Parliament.

Heartbreaking. Having recently been to Berlin, I felt like I'd seen quite a few moving memorials, but this one literally took my breath away. It was so simple and understated, but so powerful. You just look at the different styles of shoes, whether they be men's, women's or children's, and have a strong sense of all the people who suffered so tragically.
Here but for the grace of God . . .. A reminder of a tragic past. Many died here for no reason at all other than the free expression of inhumanity.

Stuning memorial. Understated, moving testimonial to a horrible chapter for both Jews and Hungarians. Hard to find - we did not see any signs. It is immediately along the Danube just south of Parliament.
When simplicity is the more touching. You go there. See the shoes. Understand what happened. Become sad. Hope won't happen ever again.

Definite Must-See. This small monument dedicated to those who lost their lives is worthwhile. However, there is not a crosswalk near the location. We walked from Parliment and could not find a crosswalk so we had to jaywalk across a 4 lane, high speed street. I agree with another reviewer, I was also surprised that there wasn't more information at the actual site. I researched Budapest before coming and that is the only reason why I knew the story. More info here --> http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shoes_on_the_Danube_Promenade
Haunting. This is a very touching tribute to the lives that were lost here. You will find it on the Pest side of the river between the Chain bridge and the Parliment.
Good memorial. Its good that they remember the jews that were killed here and the use of shoes is a great symbolism of this.
History Reminder. See what unfounded hate does to people. Shoes on the Danube Promenade and the Great Synagogue be reminder how God's Chosen were killed for no reason.

Simple but effective. This is a very simple memorial outside of the parliament building. There is little to see other than the metal shoes on the side of the river, the impact of this place along with other countries who experienced hatred of this nature is how it makes you feel.When you consider what the owners of the original shoes experienced on this bank, the river side location allows time to reflect and in my opinion make this site a must do.
Strong effect. An inspired, if small, memorial for unspeakable evil.
sad history pure. have to see it to feel it, history comes alive. Very sad memories.

Moving simple memorial. Having also visited the Jewish synagogue and museum we had some awareness of the history behind this memorial.It is a simple thought provoking way of remembering the suffering of the Jews.Is just along the Danube at the chain bridge , so can be part of a pleasant walk .

Poignant. Only realised what they represented because of previous comments, and only found them by chance. There is a plaque in the ground in Hungarian. An unusual memorial to the Jews taken in the 2nd World war. To be found on the enbankment on Pest side opposite the castle.
Beautiful spot. A very touching place. However I found the lack of information at the site a little strange.
significant shoes. So simple yet with so much significanceThis reminds us the worst of mankind yet just opposite the river it also shows the good side of mankind

Poignant reminder. It would be easy to miss this memorial. We stumbled upon it when we walked from the Chain Bridge along the waterfront to the Parliament Building. The shoes are very realistic though and a poignant reminder of the past.

Unforgettable. I have visited numerous other memorial sites, but this is a sight like no other. It is haunting, chilling, and leaves a really deep impression. I saw these shoes years ago on a visit to Budapest, and yet, the image of those tiny children's shoes, or the smart lady's boots just bring home the awful awful realities of the terrible things that happened there. A must see.
Sobering. Yes, if something as sad as this can be called good, this is!

Take a moment to reflect. This is a must visit, but we needed the help of a local guard to help us locate this touching memorial . Located near to the Parliament buildings, finding the shoes caused a number of visitors difficulty In finding.
Thought provoking. A very thought provoking memorial but worth the short walk from the chain bridge.
A Budapest Must-do. A unique and unsual Budapest attraction, slightly tricky to find but well worth the short walk from the Chain Bridge to find them, an important memorial in the city.
Shoes. Very moving, showing the human side. Seeing those shoes in such a beautiful place, contradicted the terrible emotions that the people must have been going through
Reminders of the hard times.. The shoes lined up along the promenade are a reminder to all of the tough times these people have come through.
Moving. A quite moving memorial, and interesting to see, although it would perhaps be better if there was a bigger plaque with more information to give more details
Shoes on Danube Promenade. Very moving memorial to the innocent shot during WW II
Worth a visit, touching memorial. A little difficult to find and not well marked. Almost directly in front of the Parliament building
Must go and see and think!. When I was there, the impression made me wet my eyes. You will think and re-think about the values of life. Go there and feel.

Disturbing and thoughtprovoking. Just before you pass the Parliament on the Donau Promenade towards Margit Island, there are 50+ pairs of shoes on the riverbank. A reminder of what happened right here in the late 1950s...
Holocaust memorial. Few shoes on the bank of the river - very poignant but a tourist attraction?

Beautiful unassuming memorial. We've passed those shoes on a walk and learned their meaning only afterwards, but you can easily guess it is a Jewish memorial. I have to say one of the really beautiful ones with much thought given into it. Have a see and spare a thought for the souls that perished in the World War Second.
Simple and very effective memorial. Definitely worth visiting. We walked down from the Parliament, take care crossing teh road and be patient!
Heartbreaking. I don't think I was ever moved so much as I have been on this trip. I thank God for my freedom, and pray for the souls of the lost.
Very moving. A very simple and moving memorial to what happened here.

Heart wrenching!. We came across the shoes exhibit when strolling alongside the river on new years day. These are shoes belonging to people (including children) who jumped in to the river to try to escape the Nazis in world war two and some were shot. It's heart rending to see the actual shoes and there is a plaque detailing exactly what is there and why. It's a lovely tribute and it made me understand why the market stalls sell little crumpled shoes...but very sad too.

Sad story. Unfortunately I've read about the place and its history on the Internet, but at the place there was no information about it, its story, nothing. From the Parliament building we could only orientate and find the place easy enough, but it could have been much more better marked.

A memorial for those with no graves. I have visited this place several times, and I keep on going back when I visit Budapest.I have had family members shot into the Danube in Budapest during those tragic years, and knowing that they are remembered matters a lot, even after all those years.I definitely recommend a visit this memorial, because there are things that never should be forgotten.

Deeply moved. Couldn't stop tears rolling down on my cheek.. This is the place I determined to visit this time.When I walked down the promenade of Danube towards this sight, I've heard some tinkling noise. I turned around and found a tiny piece of kitchen foil dancing along side. I felt like this little thing guide me to get there. It actually stopped when I reached the sight.The sight itself was not big, but when I got there I was hit almost instantly by huge impact. Seeing these iron cast shes was truely heartbreaking.It was very cold, windy afternoon, I saw big piece of ice floating the danube river. I thought I even wouldn't be able to imagine how scared, how saddend they were.When I saw a pair of little iron shoes, I couldn't hold my tears, it just rolled down on my cheek.I was deeply moved.When I was leaving, a banch of young people arrived. I saw some of girls put their hands on their eyes, or wiped their eyes.This is huge scar of Hungarian history. Should not be forgotten and must visit when you're in Budapest.

Heartbreaking memorial on the banks of the Danube. This is a line of metal shoes, as if they have been kicked off by their wearers. They are a memorial to those who were told to take off their shoes before they were shot and their bodies washed away by the river. A terrible episode in WW2 by the Arrow Militia, Hungarian Fascists.
Poignant. A very sombre, reflective memorial. A beautiful place to reflect on the atrocities of war.

Moving, subtle, remarkable.. This memorial is a sculpture intended as a reminder of the thousands who were shot on the banks of the Danube and shoved into the river, primarily Jews who were systematically rounded up during the rule of the Arrow Cross in late 1944. It's subtle, very sad, and reminds you of the horrors that went on in this beautiful place. Particularly moving are the children's shoes. It's a little hard to get to - be very careful about crossing the road - the legal place to cross is quite a ways back toward the Chain Bridge.
Eeery. There was no sign, but you could tell it was a memorial. We got home and googled it and then realized just how sad a monument it was. Very interesting though.

Visit this place in a cold evening.... Visiting this place in a cold evening takes you back to years ago. You get the feeling of being one of those thrown to the river alive. It is a breathtaking experience. Really horrible ! I took lots of pictures there in a cold evening of late September.... A must see when you are in Budapest.

You must remember. In the winter 1944-45 thousands of people were shot to the Danube, This shoes remembers from them, The idea comes from a famous film Budapesti tavasz (Budapest spring) based on the novel Ferenc Karinthy

Souls of my ancestors. No, it wasn't an easy walk, which we knew beforehand as it was very cold and some fresh snow had just fallen, making it a daring, slippery walk.... a hazy Danube with large pieces of ice ... how cold it must have been for those who ended their life here....However, we were determined to visit this spot, knowing that some far relatives, their close friends and actually so many people who lived in the Budapest Jewish Quarter - not being as lucky as my direct relatives - were brought here, walking their last march ....Yes, it touched us deeply and we were grateful to be alone then and there.What a shame it is that the road upon this memorial place is so difficult and scary (in Winter time). No straight entrance from the busy road, just slippery stairs next to the bridge or one possibility to cross that road ..... near the bridge. But no busstop or taxi stop is created, meaning that elderly and those with physical problems are unable to come here, to sit and commemorate those who left their precious life on this spot .... just because they were Jews.Let this special place become more known and make it easier to reach, for everyone.And please: read about it before coming to Budapest, and realize what the deeper meaning of this simple memorial place is.
Very poignant. Hard to get across very busy road coming from the parliament. Meant to arrive the other way.

Why are these shoes here?. While walking along the promenade one evening this past fall, came upon the shoes and could only imagine why they were there. Time for some research on my part. Just another one of the things that one comes upon when exploring Budapest....

Emotional. This is a emotion provoking monument that you should take a moment to see while walking along the Danube. Putting your feet next to a pair of shoes, imagining the last thoughts these people had...the artist did a great job getting his point across.

Memorial. It's a must-see when you are in Budapest. It's a sober monument. It's located close to the parlement, on the pest side. The monument honors the Jews who were killed during the war. It's a good place to sit and think about the past.

Jewish Memorial on the Danube. I had heard of this memorial, however once I got there the memorial took on a whole new meaning. It had almost a spiritual feeling to it ....almost like when you walk into a church. The memorial is in remembrance of the Jews that were shot before their bodies fell into the Danube but were asked to take their shoes off first since they were considered valuable. A tragic reminder of inhumanity but well worth the visit.
Sobering. To read the story of what happened there and see the shoes forever set, certainly reaches into one's humanity.
Thought provoking. We came across this unexpectedly as we walked along the banks of the Danube. Unfortunately there was nothing to explain what it was nearby, but we read about it in our guidebook.

The sign is almost invisible.. Young people were stepig on the shoes- taking pictures standing on them- there is clearly nO EXPLANATION .I did a explain to two youngsters from Brazil who were totally dumb found! It is so important for tourists to know what has happened there. The horrific event of jewish people shot into the water 15,000 men/women/children by hungarian nazis.

Simple and Touching Holocaust Memorial. The Shoes on the Danube Promenade is a memorial to the Jews who were killed by fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II. They were asked to remove their shoes and were then shot dead at the river's edge and their bodies dropped into the river and were washed away. It is comprised of 60 pairs of cast iron shoes. It is a simple and very piognant holocaust memorial - very haunting and touches the heart.The memorial lies on the riverbank between Roosevelt square and Kossuth square, and one can see it from near the Parliament Building. However, one cannot access it from here. The best way to acces it is to walk near the river to the right of the Chain Bridge when on the Pest side, northwards, for about 10 to 15 minutes.

Very moving experience - go there!!!. Oh my -- during our Jewish Quarter tour, I'm so glad we parked and walked down to the river to see the bronzed shoes. We could imagine what the experience must have been like for Jews to be told to remove their shoes before being shot to fall in the river. Very intense experience. So solemn - so important.

Simple, yet horrifying. This simple monument symbolizes the horrible ordeal for many Hungarian Jews, who were shot on the bank of the Danube and then thrown into the mighty river.This somber monument pays tribute to those poor men, women and children.

A cold walk.. Even though it was colder than our native Florida, we walked the promenade both during the day and at night, to take in the sights. Walking was easier than negotiating the tram system. (Nem beszelek magyarul.)
just freaky. freaky to see the place night time, it makes you believe just happened. A must see in Budapest
A must see. A very moving tribute to those who died in the Danube in WWII
Interesting Memorial. This was a rather interesting memorial. You can find it by walking near the river to the right of the chain bridge when on the Pest side towards Margrat Island.
feel how Hungarians have had to fight. A must ,as part of a visit to the Parliament, to feel how Hungarians have had to fight & suffer for democracy
Why???. No explanation why it happent. A crime against humanity.

So simple and yet so moving. This memorial is so effective. Called a sculpture, the line of 60 iron shoes represent the Jews who were shot and pushed in to the Danube, but made to remove their shoes first, as they were deemed valuable.
Definitely worth a trip to see.
Shoes of the Jews. Very moving unfortunately no information about the meaning.
holocaust memorial - very sad. this is a memorial for the Jewish victims that were killed in 1944-45
very moving.... I had sean photos and read about the shoes, but I always like to see for myself and was glad I did, not many people mention the shoes when you are in Budapest, it is worth a look.
Evocative. I walked up and down the river looking for this and when I finally found it I was very moved by its simplicity of expression.

Moving Memorial. The TA reviews were what prompted me to find this memorial, as it is often just mentioned as a footnote in many Budapest travel guide books. After a bit of an adventure (which involved jaywalking), I found the section of the promenade. It's location, between Széchenyi Lanchid (Chain Bridge) and Orszaghaz (Parliament) on the banks of the Danube, highlights its poignancy. The tragedy suffered by the Hungarian Jews is very much a part of this city's history as its beautiful architecture. I appreciated the simplicity of the memorial: the lack of signage, plaques telling the stories, and even directions to it allows one to experience this memorial. One story I heard before I came to this memorial was that the Arrow Cross didn't have enough bullets, so they tied people together and only shot one, so that the other person ended up drowning in the Danube. I remembered this story as I contemplated the bronzed shoes. I would've stayed there longer if it wasn't such a windy, frigid day. I saw that people had left flowers and tea lights among the shoes. It might be worthwhile to stob by this memorial at twilight. How to find it: Don't do what I did (jaywalk across a busy highway to the embankment from the Attila Jozsef statue). Instead, walk towards the Széchenyi rakpart stop for Tram 2, which is near the Hungarian Academy of Sciences. Cross the tram tracks and you will see a path towards the embankment. Head away from the Chain Bridge towards Parliament. It's about a 10 minute walk. I hope your day is more conducive, weather-wise, for reflections. There are park benches facing Buda nearby.

Chilling. This understated artistry took us by surprise when walking beside the Danube in a howling gale near Parliament buildings-the collection of bronzed very realistic shoe forms look as though some people of all sexes and sizes have only just left them behind and will be back -We had to look twice before we appreciated that these were 'The shoes' we'd read about-the coldness and greyness of the day added to the reality check-Chilling!

So Moving.... Not being familiar with the train/bus process in Budapest, one night after work, I wound my way down the Danube Promenade. As I came to this area with the shoes, there was a group of about 8 older folks (maybe late 60s) taking pictures. I asked one of the ladies about what the shoes meant. She explained that she was Jewish and that this memorial was for the Jews killed by the Arrow Cross Militiamen. They were lined up, shot and allowed to fall into the Danube. The shoes represent them falling into the river. As she is relating this story to me and the impact of the Holocaust on the Hungarian Jews, she starts tearing up as I do. So her and I - two strangers - stood on the banks of the Danube by 60 pairs of cement shoes, crying and mourning the cruelty of humanity to each other. Very moving and powerful. A must-see.

Low profile but very moving. Actually walked past it by accident after walking along the river after visiting the Parliament. It is about 300 metres as you walk south toward the Chain Bridge from the Parliament. I did not know anything about it at the time but still felt very strongly what may have happened here. A very powerful and simple memorial without needing any words.

Put yourself in their shoes..... It is a very sobering moment when you stand next to these shoes and wonder what their final moments were like. It is one of the more moving and effective memorials I have been to. To see empty shoes left on the side of the river makes it all very real as they are shoes your feet would fit into and each one of these victims had a life just like you. It made me grateful to be able to keep my shoes on and able to walk away, but I have not stopped thinking about all that remains from their lives are these shoes.

So Moving. A very poinant reminder of mans inhumanity to man. Very moving especially seeing a small candle lit after dark. Somewhere to go to contemplate and think how we can all improve the world we live in
Poor souls. There is no plaque or way to know what this artisitc memorial could be. A must
very poignant. This doesn't need a review, if you know the history of Europe in the early 20th century then you will understand this art work.
Unexplainable. Excellent tribute/monument to those that lost their lives. Silence all around at this site.
Very Moving. Just that. Very moving experience. Makes you wonder and thank god for the life we have.
Eerie. A very moving sculpture along the Danube very close to the Parliament building

Simple memorial, huge emotional impact. We've seen many holocaust memorials before, including very impressive ones in Berlin. But this one is really the most moving we've seen. These empty shoes along the river bank are so evocative of the people who have been murdered, plus the race of the water below (you're attracted toward the water because the sculptor put one of the shoe off balance at the edge of the bank), everything makes you picture the victims...We walked there on January 1st, a quiet day -we were alone on the Promenade for a moment-. For us it is a don't miss in Budapest.
Very Poignant. Seen on the edge of the Danube outside the Parliament. One of the most poignant Memorials I have seen. Give yourself time for reflection.

A touching memorial to the victims of the Holocaust. Visiting the memorial (brass shoes laid along the edge of the Danube, near Parliament) was probably the most touching moment of our trip. The memorial signifies the jews that were killed by 'Arrow Cross Militiamen' in WWII. Jews were shot into the Danube in WWII, leaving their shoes behind on the shore. The shoes are very realistic, almost transporting you back in time. Very sad!

A very poigniant tribute.. A simple memorial on the banks of the Danube. Easy to find if you simply walk along the river in the right direction, but sadly this is not advertised particularly well so many visitors may miss it.
Memorial. Especially the children shoes were a shock... A really must visit while walking around Danube, just in front of the Parliament.

don't miss this moving memorial. It is hard to find this memorial because i think it is fairly new and not well signed or noted in guidebooks. It is at the base of Zoltan street if it ran to the water. Go to the rivers edge at the Chain bridge and walk about 15 minutes. it is very moving and very well done.
Haunting. Found this by accident having read about it earlier. Very poignant.

A moving tribute to victims of ethnic cleansing. Six hundred thousand Jews were murdered in the Hungarian Holocaust during the Second World War. Some were taken to the banks of the river Danube and told to remove their shoes. Then they were shot so that they fell into the water, leaving only their shoes behind.The shoes on the Danube Promenade are a simple memorial to these victims. They are set in a beautiful spot on the banks of the Danube close to the Parliament building, with magnificent views of the Chain Bridge, the Buda Palace and St Matthias above. Here one can reflect for a moment on these victims and on the intolerant, aggressive tribalism that has motivated fanatics and zealots throughout the ages to murder minorities and steal their belongings in the name of one cause or another.One can reach the shoes by walking down the river bank from the Chain Bridge. It is a pity that access to the Danube Promenade is not easier from the Parliament Building, which is close by but on the other side of a busy road.
not impressive. It was just some regular-sized shoes implanted in the cement in front of Parliament in Pest side of Danube.

Shoes with history.... i did not know what they meant till a fellow tourist explained me and then i knew the facts.... great remembrance of the past but surprised that its still intact....u have to be careful else u can miss this on the walk across danube...
very moving. we visited this site after going round the main Synagogue. The story behind the shoes was brought to life when you saw them and pictured the horrors of what took place
so alone and so sad. a wonderful and very tragic memorial to the budapest jews that were shoved into the river

Very poignant. This is a sinple and very touching reminder of what happened in all European countries during the holocaust and within meters of the Hungarian Parliament Building. It should be promoted more and more accessible.

Hidden, unpublicized memorial. These rows of shoes are on the Danube north of the Chain Bridge. There's not a clear path to get to them, but it's very striking once you get there. Such beautiful scenery, such a sad loss.
Depressing, yet a must. This should be done in daylight, and without small children.
Moving. A moving monument that I came across when walking down the Danu from the parliament building. Very moving way to show and remember the past. Would recommend seeing
Interesting idea. I saw it wen was walking arround in the sunset in the Danube. Cool

Moving. The shoes are very poignant. As a former history student who studied the Holocaust, the shoes were something I was really keen to see. As other reviewers say, the children's shoes are particularly moving, and people place candles in them.
Sombering. Easy to locate along the Banks of the Danube. Evokes sombering thoughts of years past but a site not to be missed. Very easy walking distance from the Chain Bridge.
a neat piece of art. i was not expecting to see rows and rows of iron shoes. liked it very much. but unfortunately they are not maintained in a very good shape.

Little to Talk about. I read about the shoes before the trip and happened to pass them on a morning run. I was glad I happened across them rather than searched for them, just wasn't much to see. Might mean something to people who really know the history well, but...
Emotional moments. Standing beside the shoes, looking into the river, trying to realize that I was viewing the last thing these people saw before their gruesome death was very emotional.

Silent, mournful shoes. There are no words to accurately describe the impact of these empty bronzed shoes of men, women, and children who were murdered ("shot into the Danube") during World War II. Their stillness speaks.

Thought provoking !. Very moving, thought provoking..... effective.
Not sure if I liked all the candles and flowers etc next to them !
A special memorial. I had seen it before a few times and didnt realise what it meant until i got home and told my husband. It is a very sad monument.
A reason to never forget the barbarity of war.. It brings home the realities and barbarism of war.

Great Monument to the Victims. The shoes are a good memorial to the victims that were shot into the Danube River. What a terrible way to die. It is a little walk from the Chain Bridge but I highly recommend.

One of the most poignant Holacaust Memorials I have ever seen. If you do not shed a tear upon viewing this memorial you do not understand the sheer cruelty and disregard for human life being represented. This site, depicting the shooting of innocent people by Hungary's home grown version of the Gestapo, should leave you speechless. Truly a monumental representaion of man's inhumanity to man. Seeing the small shoes of children who were shot and fell into the river evokes indescribable feelings. A must see, but must view it close up, not from above the river. Easy to access from the Chain Bridge.
In their Shoes. Very powerful memorial to those that were murdered. There should be access from the Parliament.

powerfully simple. The shoes stand as a silent and simple reminder of hatred fear and brutality. Encounters are powerful. It is so accessible, so ordinary and so hideously reflective of a terrifying period in Europe, when good broad minded men fell silent to the fears and anger of little men. Cut flowers reach out as if to silence this mark on the world- a testament to loving people's silent shout against hatred. That the flowers seem so small in the face of a powerful and relentless river current, haunts you.
A truly moving monument. Not in the least bit imposing, this truly poignant piece of art speaks to the human tragedy that befell the Jews of Budapest. Simple but powerful.
Spooky. Made me feel un-at-ease but maybe it was because I did not know what it meant and jumped to conclusions

great memorial. I looked for this memorial specifically and found it between the chain bridge and the parliament building. There were no crosswalks right there, so we had to run across traffic, but the memorial is worth seeing and remembering those who lost their lives there.

very intrigatings. Ive seen them twice before, but up until this visit did not know what they where... amaising...good to see them in combination with free tour of jewish district. good to see them at night, be alone and realy take time for every peace of art...
Very touching memorial. I just had to see the "Shoes on the Danube" while in Budapest. It is very touching and so sad that humans can be so cruel to one another.

Dead Mens Shoes. Told about this memorial by another visitor, does not appear to be in any tourist books. From the city centre you need to walk past the Chain Bridge for about 5/10 mins. a selection of male and female shoes and boots have been casted in metal and fixed to the river wall, I was told this is to commemorate the drowning of Jews who had been lined up along the river bank, told to remove their shoes then pushed in to the Danube to drown a very graphic reminder of a tragic time.
Very Moving. Emotional and thought provoking as it makes you realise that these sort of things are still going the world over
Touching. This is a simple and quite lovely memorial to the Jews that were killed by the Arrow Cross

Very Moving and Sobering. This is an attraction you should not miss while in Budapest. It's a bit challenging to get to if you take the Metro 2; you have to cross over a busy street. You can probably get there from farther up or down the Duna, near the bridges. There are 117 shoes, men's women's and children's, all bronzed which tell the story in a very low-key, moving way of what happened during WWII, this time at the hands of the Arrow Cross party.
Very poignant. Pay close attention to the tiny shoes of a child. Your heart will honestly sink for a bit when you see them.

Read about Jewish during second World War before. This is a place ''memorial'' on the bank of Daube river. You can find them very close to Parliament building. It honors the Jews who fell victim to fascist Arrow Cross militiamen in Budapest during World War II, and represents their shoes left behind on the bank when they fell into the river after being shot.This is enough as a comment. Just go there and think...

Shoes Along the Danube Promenade. When we were visiting Budapest, we happened to see a line of bronzed shoes on the promenade. At first we did not know why they were there. We later learned that they are the actual shoes of Budapest Jews massacred by The Arrow Cross, Hungary's local version of the Nazis. The Arrow Cross lined up their victims at that spot and shot them in the back. The bodies fell in the Danube and floated away. It is hard to believe anything that horrible could happen in a city as friendly and beautiful as Budapest. It is a moving and solemn reminder that the horrors of WWII and The Holocaust are not that far off.

Thought provoking. You had to just stand and look for a while to take it in. The childrens'shoes were especially disturbing.A little dificult to get to bu tworth the effort. Directly on the river bank on the Pest side between the Parliament and the Chain Bridge. You must cross busy street and streetcar tracks to get to it.
There is no better way to show the impact of the war. You should see this monument yourself. It is so special, if you know the history and the story...unbelievable.
Very Poignant. I dislike the damage to the memorial by mindless thugs - just the sort of people who committed the murders in the first place - they are still in Budapest.

Shoes with a meaning. Our first time in Budapest we didn't look up what all these shoes stands for, so we never took pictures or anything. We looked it up and found it that the shoes are a tribute to all the Jews who where executed at Donaus shore at the end of World War 2. They all had to take their shoes off. Scary.
Shoes on the Danube. Sobering to see a reminder like this of the many people who were slain during this atrocious period in history

Touching. Get off the 2 Tram just before or at the Parliment building and go down to the promenade. There you will see this sad and emotive sight. People put candles into the shoes and notes. Unfortunately when i was there, there were 2 Chinese tourists trying to fit their feet into the shoes and taking photos holding their noses as if there was a bad smell which I found vile.
Old Memory. You can see few shoes are laying on the river shore.. but it will remind you those days . Not too much tourist are there.But still it will be nice to ahve a walk there
Moving Tribute. Well worth a visit to this symbolic representation of Budapests' difficult history.
Very poignant - worth a visit.. Very thought provoking and worth a visit. Read up a little about it before you go.
Moving. Just a few metres down from the Parliament - simple yet poignant.
Shoes on the banks of The Danube. Needed more information as to why they were there.
Very poignant. Bronze replicas of shoes from the period of 1944-1945 of those shot on the banks of the Danube, they were made to take their shoes off first.

Good memorial. A very moving and emotional memorial. Very unique
Recommended for all who are in the area
Memorial Shoes. Very sobering. Brings the holocaust into focus. Not only men & women's shoes but also little children's shoes.

It makes a nice evening stroll. Not really that striking, especially if you don`t know the history of the arrow-cross. It is a very good area to view the sunset. I took a lot of pictures from there. You have to get down to the promenade from the stair next to the Chain Bridge, then 10 minutes walk towards the Parliament (towards east)

Worth Seeking Out...... From Chain Bridge walk towards Parliament on the Pest Side. You'll be confronted with the Shoes monument by the River. it is sad, painful and terrible. Jewish people were shot and thrown into the Danube. The shoes are dedicated to the victims of those horrible times.

Touching. Watching those shoes was an emotional experience that will remain forever in my mind. I can't describe the thrilling impact that it caused in my heart and how it made me think about the horrors that happened at this very site. The artist found a superb manner to represent the facts without words, without signs, simply placing the shoes as they are. I had read about it before going to Budapest, and was willing to see them but it wasn't easy to find: for some reason, no one talks about it in the city.......It's not mentioned in any of the sightseeing tours......... and when I asked the guides about, we felt as if they didn't want to say much about it. I had the sensation that people in Budapest try to hide this lovely memorial from the tourists. But I could finally find it and it was wonderful. Different from anything else I had ever seen. Don't miss it!
