empty shoes. I had never heard about the shoes on the Danube until we stumbled across them. We were lucky that an English plague was there on the site to explain what the vacant shoes were about. I found it very beautiful yet chilling to see them and realize that these people were all shot and thrown in the river.

An emotional experience. In 1945, the Arrow Cross Militia ruled Hungary. In Budapest, they murdered about 15000 people, mostly Jews, and deported another 80000 to the death camps. Many Jews were taken from the Ghetto to the banks of the Danube, where they were forced to undress. Several were tied together and some were shot, falling into the freezing river and dragging those tied to them into the river to drown. A more horrific sight is hard to imagine. In memory of the victims of this terrible crime, the Shoes on the Danube Promenade memorial was erected. It simply consists of about 50 pairs of shoes embedded in the concrete at the edge of the river. The simplicity of the memorial conveys a powerful emotional message, as this is all that remains of the victims after they were murdered on this site. If anyone needs a reminder of the depths of human cruelty and human suffering, I can't think of a more appropriate memorial.

You must go.. "The composition entitled 'Shoes on the Danube Bank' gives remembrance to the people shot into the Danube during the time of the Arrow Cross terror. The sculptor created sixty pairs of period-appropriate shoes out of iron. The shoes are attached to the stone embankment, and behind them lies a 40 meter long, 70 cm high stone bench. At three points are cast iron signs, with the following text in Hungarian, English, and Hebrew: "To the memory of the victims shot into the Danube by Arrow Cross militiamen in 1944–45. Erected 16 April 2005." Wikipedia

moving. This has to be one of the most poignant memorials ever.Twelve people shot and pushed into the Danube--all that remained were their shoes.The shoes are arranged as if they'd just been kicked off--nothing else is there.It made the hairs on the back of your neck stand up!Even if the story was more complicated it didn't matter.It was a monument to man's inhumanity.

Must see: so simple but incredibly touching. It's just a simple walk along the river, but it is the strongest memory I have of Budapest.You would need few minutes to walk there along the river and you can decide if to continue to go or to stay there, maybe enjoying the sunset, and think.I would say that this place can be exptremely interesting if you are in the right mood, but it could be too "simple" if what you look for is more than an emotional touch. I loved it :)

A sight to move the soul. This is a sculpture well worth visiting in Budapest. We knew of it previously but asking for directions to it was not easy from local people. Even our 5 star hotel would have preferred we not dwell on this sad part of Hungary's past. Do not let them dissuade you from going, however!! We should all take a moment in our busy lives to contemplate, remember and be saddened by what went before. There are a line of beautifully crafted shoes, about fifty pairs, possibly in bronze on the shore. Men's shoes with laces broken, ladies fashionable sandals, kiddies shoes worn and scuffed all seemingly kicked off and left haphazardly on the edge of the Danube just near Parliament House. It commemorates the shooting of Hungarian Jews by the Hungarian Arrow Cross Militia in 1944/45 on this spot before their bodies were thrown into the river. This is an easy walk from the Chain Bridge. I strongly recommend you take it. A wonderful and touching memorial that will move your soul told in the simplest and most moving way possible.

Simple, yet very moving. I challenge anyone to remain unmoved by this simple memorial. A pair of children's shoes amongst the adults' will bring a lump to your throat. Don't miss it. Easy to find by the Danube near the parliament building.

Don't miss this memorial. If you find yourself in Budapest and are walking around near Parliament and the waterfront, don't miss the opportunity to cross the street over to the walk along the river and seek out this memorial. Before making our way to this area, we visited the Terror Museum and learned about several events in Budapest's past, including the events that occurred in the area near this memorial. The memorial is haunting and we enjoyed learning about the history prior to our visit here.

Poignant memorial for Jews murdered by Hungarian Arrow Cross Militia '44-'45. This simple, stark and poignant memorial is for the Hungarian Jews who were rounded up, taken to the bridges crossing the Danube and shot there. Their bodies were then thrown into the river. This little-promoted exhibit sits out of the way on the edge of the Danube a few hundred meters south of the Parliament. Three plaques in different languages, including one in Hebrew are installed into the ground nearby. Walk 10 minutes or so along a sandy path north (in the direction of the Parliament) from the Chain Bridge. Take photos, sit on the low marble wall and contemplate. It's a must see for Jewish and other visitors alike.

Very moving tribute. This is a very simple, yet deep, reminder of the ugliness man can inflict on man. Without words, this display says it all. Each pair of shoes represents a life... an individual human being... a man, woman or child... whose life was taken away by evil... an evil that still robs lives today.
A must see.
A must see..... Very little to add to the other reviews - it is indeed a very moving, thought provoking and emotive memorial, and one visitors should make the effort to visit......
A very poignant and moving memorial. A very poignant and lovely memorial to the attroicites that the jews had to suffer

Definitely worth the walk up. Very moving memorial to the Hungarian Jews shot there. Shoes have a candlelit vigil every night. Just a short walk up on the Pest side from the main bridge, near all the cruise boats. Just a bit furthur is the Parliament.

Simple thing but makes the river bank different from others. While walking from The Parliament, I would suggest to have a look on the Shoes. I didnt know what it is about... there are statues of shoes or just somehow preserved shoes at the bank of the river. It has interesing history

Never a line to wait in. Simply take a tram to Roosevelt square, then (on the north side of the Chain Bridge) walk down the steps to the Danube river walk. At first, we thought we made a mistake since I assumed the shoes were near the bridge, but keep walking north about 10 to 15 minutes and the memorial will finally appear. It was peak tourist season, but few seemed to be aware of this moving tribute.

Sobering reminder of what should never happen again. We accidentally came across the shoes along the bank of Danube and it is a memory seared into our hearts. Very touching memorial and thought provoking. Such monstrous deaths in such a beautiful setting. The candles in the children's shoes are particularly poignant.

My abiding memory of Budapest. I had read about the memorial before my wife and I visited the city but nothing had prepared us for the physical impact of seeing this memorial to those innocents who had been butchered here by members of the notorious Arrow Cross.I urge you to see this for yourselves next time you visit Budapest.Our helpful taxi-driver parked his car by the Chain Bridge and then we walked northwards about half a mile until we found the memorial immediately opposite the CommerzBank building.

Worth the short walk. As beautiful as Budapest is, there is a melancholy side to this City. The understated Holocaust Memorial on the Pest shores of the Danube is a powerful example. It is a series of cast iron shoes along the walkway, which is quite chilling once you realize this was the spot where the Hungarian Arrow Cross (Hungary's indigenous Nazi Party) shot and killed a large number of the City's Jewish residents, and allowed their bodies to drop into the Danube. I'm not big into visiting holocaust memorials, but this one was worth seeking out. To get there, walk along the Pest side of the Danube northward from the Chain Bridge to get there. (Enjoy the excellent views of Buda, of course.) It is difficult to access from the Parliament Building
If you are in Budapest...add this to the top of your must see list!!. It is a very powerful tribute to those who lost their lives. There are some amazing photo opportunities.
